{'uri': '8230384089', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:52:28', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:52:28Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T16:51:31Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.newstalk.com/news/online-abuse-of-athletes-reaches-disturbing-levels-in-ireland-uaoa-1746303', 'title': "Online abuse of athletes reaches 'disturbing levels' in Ireland - UAOA", 'body': 'The online abuse faced by Irish athletes has reached "disturbing levels," according to United Against Online Abuse in Sport (UAOA).\n\nThe coalition convened a forum in Dublin yesterday to address what they describe as a "growing epidemic" of hate speech targeting athletes on the internet.\n\nAmong the attendees were Irish sports stars, including former tennis player Jenny Claffey, Irish rugby player Leah Tarpey and Tom Parsons, chair of the Gaelic Players Association and former Mayo footballer.\n\nOne key proposal discussed was the establishment of an international Trusted Flagger entity for sports organisations under the EU Digital Services Act.\n\nThis entity would expedite the handling of complaints and the removal of abusive comments.\n\nKirby Tarrant, partner in charge of Clarke Hill, legal advisors to UAOA, suggested Ireland as an ideal base for such an entity.\n\n"Ireland already has an experienced and robust regulatory and legal system with the necessary expertise," he said.\n\n"Dublin hosts the EMEA headquarters for social media giants such as Google, Meta/Facebook, Twitter, and LinkedIn. Other major online platforms also have a significant presence here."\n\n"Online abuse in sports is not just a problem for athletes and teams; it impacts sponsors, fans, and the sports community as a whole," Tarrant added.\n\nUAOA coalition founder Mohammed Ben Selayem highlighted the seriousness of the abuse received by athletes.\n\n"Imagine training your entire life for a dream only to be bombarded with threats and hate online. That\'s the reality for 75% of athletes today," he said.\n\n"If we remain idle and athletes are driven from their sports due to online abuse, we will lose the very spirit of competition."\n\nThe UAOA coalition has received endorsements from the governments of Albania, Belgium, France, Greece, Malaysia, Slovenia, Spain, and several international sports federations, including FIFA, the IOC, the ITF, World Athletics, World Netball, and World Squash.', 'source': {'uri': 'newstalk.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Under Construction                 '}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'robert_kindregan@newstalk.com', 'name': 'Robert Kindregan', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://media.radiocms.net/uploads/2024/07/17173925/UAOA-image.jpeg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.08235294117647063, 'wgt': 458931148, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '2024-07-425071619', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:51:25', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:51:25Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T16:50:19Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://bilyonaryo.com/2024/07/18/eu-court-rejects-tiktok-challenge-against-new-eu-digital-rules/technology/', 'title': 'EU court rejects TikTok challenge against new EU digital rules', 'body': 'TikTok lost an appeal Wednesday to escape new digital rules that seek to rein in the power of big tech after an EU court rejected its challenge.\n\nA landmark European Union law known as the Digital Markets Act (DMA) entered into force in March, and regulators believe it will create a fairer market.\n\nThe European Commission designated six "gatekeepers" under the DMA facing the curbs: Google parent Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, Microsoft -- and TikTok owner ByteDance, the only non-US company.\n\nThe EU said in May that Booking would also have to apply the law and gave the online travel agent six months to prepare for compliance.\n\nThe decision by the Luxembourg-based General Court is the first judgement on a DMA challenge by big tech, with cases lodged by Apple and Meta still pending.\n\n"The Court dismisses ByteDance\'s action," it said. TikTok can appeal against the ruling within two months and 10 days of the decision.\n\nTikTok had insisted it was the "most capable challenger" to entrenched players in the digital sphere, but the court dismissed that argument.\n\n"TikTok had succeeded in increasing its number of users very rapidly and exponentially, reaching, in a short time, half the size of Facebook and of Instagram, and a particularly high engagement rate, with young users in particular, who spent more time on TikTok than on other social networks," the court said in a statement.\n\nThe judges acknowledged that in 2018, video sharing app TikTok was indeed a challenger but it had since then "rapidly consolidated its position and even strengthened that position over the following years" despite the launch of similar rival services.\n\n"We are disappointed with this decision. TikTok is a challenger platform that provides important competition to incumbent players," a spokesperson said in a statement.\n\n"While we will now evaluate next steps, we already took measures to comply with the relevant obligations of the DMA ahead of last March\'s deadline."\n\nBut the court determined "ByteDance met the quantitative thresholds laid down in the DMA".\n\nFor Brussels to name a company as a gatekeeper, they must fulfil certain conditions.\n\nThe criteria include having more than 45 million monthly active users in the EU and more than 10,000 yearly active business users established in the bloc.\n\nDigital companies with an annual turnover in the EU of at least 7.5 billion euros ($8.2 billion) or a market value of above 75 billion euros also face the new curbs.\n\nIf a company violates the law, the EU can impose fines of up to 10 percent of a company\'s total global turnover. This can rise to 20 percent for repeat offenders and in the most severe circumstances, the EU can order the break-up of companies.\n\nIt is the second defeat in the courts for TikTok over the DMA. It lost a bid in February to suspend the strict new rules pending the judgement handed down Wednesday.\n\nBig tech is not happy about the new law. Apple, contesting the DMA in the courts, has been vocal in its criticism, saying it puts users\' security at risk. -- Agence France-Presse', 'source': {'uri': 'bilyonaryo.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Bilyonaryo Business News -'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bilyonaryo.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/tiktok-challenge.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.01960784313725483, 'wgt': 458931085, 'relevance': 54}
{'uri': '8230380276', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:49:29', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:49:29Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T16:49:05Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://pantagraph.com/sports/professional/baseball/mlb/chicago_cubs/4-takeaways-from-the-chicago-cubs-draft-including-landing-a-top-defensive-catchers/article_104f459c-d3ab-5958-af46-86c5eebe9d05.html', 'title': "4 takeaways from the Chicago Cubs' draft, including landing a top defensive catchers", 'body': 'In today\'s 10 a.m. "Ten Hochman" sports video -- brought to you by Siteman Cancer Center -- Ben Hochman shares why he\'s fascinated by All-Star starter Paul Skenes. Also, a happy birthday shoutout to Terry Pendleton! And as always, Hochman picks a random St. Louis Cards card!\n\nVice president of scouting Dan Kantrovitz and the Chicago Cubs had a clear-cut plan entering the 2024 MLB draft.\n\nThey expected to be hitter-heavy on Days 1 and 2 for rounds 1-10, and then shift their focus to pitchers on Day 3 during rounds 11-20.\n\n"I think we obtained the right balance based on our assessment of the talent, the draft pool, as well fulfilling whatever needs we might have in the system," Kantrovitz said Tuesday at the conclusion of the three-day draft.\n\nKantrovitz doesn\'t expect any surprises, anticipating all 20 players the Cubs selected will sign. The Cubs ultimately chose nine pitchers (six right-handers and three left-handers), seven infielders, two outfielders and two catchers.\n\nHere are takeaways from the Cubs\' 2024 draft.\n\nPeople are also reading... Felon held by armed resident in Macon County gets 2 years Thousands in Central Illinois without power after second night of summer storms Normal residence heavily damaged, cat perishes in structure fire Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Jury deliberates fate of Bloomington man charged with murder of Decatur teen Normal backs enterprise zone taking in possible $200M Rivian expansion Bloomington man jailed on weapons, drug charges after traffic stop Revolution Dispensary to host grand opening Friday in Normal Dewon Griffin found guilty of murder in 2019 NYE shooting Hundreds evacuate \'imminent\' dam failure in Nashville, Ill. Highways flood and close. Trump picks Sen. JD Vance of Ohio, a once-fierce critic turned loyal ally, as his GOP running mate Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive Bloomington police investigating shots fired Wednesday night Flick Fact: How many State Farm employees are college educated? Flick Fact: Is there really a river under Normal? 1. They went college heavy\n\nBy the time the draft ended, only three of the Cubs\' 20 picks were high school players: shortstops Ronny Cruz (Miami Christian School in Florida) and Ty Southisene (Basic High School in Nevada) in the third and fourth rounds, respectively, and outfielder Eli Lovich (Blue Valley West High School in Kansas) in the 11th round.\n\nIt marked the second straight year the Cubs\' draft skewed toward college players, something Kantrovitz described as not the organization\'s philosophy, but a challenge that comes with taking prep players because of how much they tend to cost to sign.\n\n"In certain rounds, your options are limited," Kantrovitz said. "You try to be in position to draft and sign as many high school players as possible. You just at some point run out of room with the cap."\n\nEven with taking just three prep players, Kantrovitz expects the Cubs\' bonus pool allotment to skew toward them as much as any team. Lovich will require a "pretty substantial investment" to buy out his commitment to Arkansas and with that, like the player a lot. Kantrovitz credited area scout Ty Nichols for "raising the flag early" on Lovich, identifying him as one of the better bats he saw all spring in general, beyond just the high school demographic.\n\nThe 6-foot-4 left-handed hitting Lovich, rated the No. 1 outfielder and No. 3 overall recruit in Kansas by Perfect Game, posted a .402 average, .482 on-base percentage and 1.245 OPS with eight doubles, six triples, five home runs and 15 stolen bases his senior year.\n\nKantrovitz said Lovich put on a show in batting practice during a pre-draft workout at the Cubs complex in Mesa, Ariz., shagging fly balls and participating in high-performance testing.\n\n"We\'re pretty excited to watch his body just transform in the next couple of years and hopefully have that carryover to how hard he\'s hitting the ball and some power numbers too," he said. "But he\'s a pretty exciting one."\n\n2. Valuing performance against the best\n\nOne common theme among many of the Cubs\' selections is their participation and success playing in the Cape Cod League.\n\nIt\'s a group that includes Florida State third baseman Cam Smith (first round), College of Charleston third baseman Cole Mathis (second round), University of California-San Diego third baseman Matt Halbach (10th round), Grand Canyon right-hander Daniel Avitia (12th round), Lipscomb left-hander Hayden Frank (15th round), Georgia Southern right-hander Ben Johnson (17th round) and Indiana right-hander Brayden Risedorph (20th round).\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"The trick is to try to get as much bulk as you can from a performance standpoint, from a sort of a statistical standpoint, and then also be able to have context with that bulk," Kantrovitz said. "I think the way in which we can try to do that the most effectively is if it\'s against the best competition, and that tends to happen in the Cape League and also in the SEC and some of the other major conferences. When we can get players that have bulk in both, it gives us that much more confidence that those numbers are going to translate, and then our equivalencies end up translating to what we might expect them to do.\n\n"When they get into Low A and High A, many of the same players that they\'re competing against were those players that they were competing against in the Cape League or the SEC, so you just kind of have a better idea of where their floor is."\n\n3. Cubs land top defensive catchers\n\nSometimes future major-league caliber catchers can be difficult to find in the draft.\n\nWhen teams do identify some within the draft pool, it can be challenging to predict when they might go off the board, Kantrovitz said.\n\n"And if you\'re a team that takes them, that means you probably draft them a little bit earlier than teams would expect," he added.\n\nIt makes the pick of University of California-San Diego catcher Ariel Armas notable, particularly given his defensive pedigree. Between Armas\' defensive metrics and his accolades, his work behind the plate was considered one of the best in the country.\n\nArmas won the Gold Glove among Division I catchers last month after being named the 2024 West Coast Conference Defensive Player of the Year, and was one of 16 semifinalists for the 2024 Buster Posey National Collegiate Catcher of the Year Award. Armas, 21, owned a .998 fielding percentage while recording 15 caught stealing and led the country with 18.69 Defensive Runs Saved -- 3.58 more runs saved than the next closest player.\n\n"He\'s got a cannon of an arm and just looks really natural back there and he\'s got pretty exceptional framing skills," Kantrovitz said. "And because of this, when he put his framing, his caught stealing, his blocking, his receiving, when you put all those up against the other catchers both analytically and from a scouting standpoint, he stacks up pretty well."\n\n4. Plenty of slug can be found among the college bats\n\nThe Cubs are infusing more slug into their system.\n\nAmong the nine college position players they drafted, a couple certainly aren\'t lacking thump.\n\nSmith and Mathis -- their top two picks -- both feature the type of upside and power potential that\'s ideal in the first two rounds. Smith, 21, had a .654 slugging percentage and 39 extra-base hits as a draft-eligible sophomore at FSU, while Mathis, who turns 21 on July 25, recorded a .650 slugging percentage 33 XBH in his junior season at Charleston.\n\n"When you dig deeper, his chase rates, his in-zone contact rates, his exit velocities, his ability to really just hit the ball hard and in the air, keep the ball off the ground, which if you\'re looking at that from a performance standpoint that\'s indicated just by some of the ground ball-fly ball rates, and he seems to do it fairly effortlessly too," Kantrovitz said of Mathis.\n\n"He\'s a pretty strong kid and he\'s got a natural swing plane that lends itself to consistently hitting the ball in the air and then with his with his size and strength, he ends up putting pretty good charge into it."\n\nNicholls State first baseman Edgar Alvarez (eighth round) has put up dominant numbers, led by a .405/.514/.678 slash line. He hit 21 doubles and 13 home runs in 58 games, and has cut down his strikeout rate while improving his walk rate from his junior to senior season. Although he is on the older side -- he turns 24 in February -- Alvarez, who also won the D-1 Gold Glove this year at his position, was area scout Will Swoope\'s "gut-feel guy" as a player who has baseball card numbers that jump off the page, Kantrovitz said.\n\n"He has a beautiful, pure swing," Kantrovitz said. "As opposed to, like, just some gargantuan exit velos or gaudy numbers, which actually he has both at times. ... I think he could end up being a sleeper."\n\nUniversity of California-Santa Barbara outfielder Ivan Brethowr and his 6-foot-6, 250-pound frame produce strong exit velocity and power to tap into. Brethowr, 21, connected for 10 doubles and 15 home runs this year, part of a .275 average, .405 OBP and .968 OPS in 50 games.\n\n"When you have that base, it ends up being somebody that is also pretty exciting," Kantrovitz said. "He\'s a pretty well-balanced hitter in addition to having some some juice. It\'s good decision-making, it\'s good contact skills. It\'s generally square contact in the air."\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'pantagraph.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'pantagraph.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'armando_l_sanchez@pantagraph.com', 'name': 'Armando L. {'uri': '8230377141', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:47:45', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:47:45Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T16:47:04Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.686274528503418, 'url': 'https://www.americanpress.com/2024/07/17/scooter-hobbs-column-saban-still-the-center-of-attention/', 'title': 'Scooter Hobbs column: Saban still the center of attention - American Press', 'body': 'You can banish Nick Saban to retirement all you want, perhaps, but you can\'t put the GOAT out to pasture.\n\nWhat? You thought the greatest coach of all time was going to sit on the back porch, watch the Weather Channel and, for excitement, play pinochle for the rest of his life?\n\nFat chance.\n\nHalfway through SEC Media Days, the Southeastern Conference has paraded eight of its coaches and 24 players out for public view.\n\nBut the game is over. They can call off the final two days of blah-blah-blah, spare us more yada-yada-yada.\n\nDing-ding-ding -- we have a winner. Saban, from his perch in the back of the grand ball room of the Dallas Omni, is the unquestioned rock star of this latest preseason media days.\n\nAnd he\'s been a breath of fresh air for a week desperately seeking entertainment.\n\nSaban is part of -- if Saban can be just part of anything -- the SEC Network\'s coverage. It\'s a tune-up for his gig this fall on ESPN\'s popular Game Day show before each week\'s college games.\n\n"I\'m still a coach at heart," he kept saying. "I\'ve enjoyed it so far."\n\nYes, he\'s a bona fide, credentialed media member, joining that dispenser of "rat poison" that he so often railed against as Alabama\'s head coach.\n\nHe needs a little work on the "credentialed" angle.\n\nSEC commissioner Greg Sankey related that Saban was at first denied entry into the festivities.\n\nHe had to return to his hotel room to fetch the credential tag he\'d left behind.\n\n"I\'ve never worn a credential in my life and was always for 17 years able to get into SEC media day without a credential," Saban later explained on air. "I had to go back to the room today and get my credential to get in."\n\nIt was the only rookie mistake he made. Us commoners in the media can relate. Those security guards at big events take their jobs seriously, wait all year for a moment like that.\n\nOtherwise, on the first day of his full-time media gig, Saban was already the best thing to happen to sports television since Charles Barkley.\n\nHe already had the best line of the week, unsolicited, about the dominant story line of the week.\n\n"What tickles me," Saban said, "is all these questions about how Texas always ran the (Big 12) conference they were in. They\'re not going to run the SEC. There\'s a whole lot of arrogant people all over the SEC.\n\n"You can forget about that. They will be a good team and are a great program and (Texas head coach and former Saban assistant Steve Sarkisian) will do a great job, but it isn\'t going to be a problem."\n\nIt was good to get that cleared up. Pay attention. The man knows what he\'s talking about.\n\nHe pronounced his previous school, LSU, as one of his "sleeper" teams to win the SEC, in part because he\'s high on quarterback Garrett Nussmeier\'s talent (and patience) in replacing Heisman winner Jayden Daniels.\n\nHe\'s on board with Brian Kelly\'s process-oriented style, a philosophy he seemingly invented.\n\nYou thought maybe Saban was looking for a cushy job to tide him over and keep him out of Miss Terry\'s hair during "retirement?"\n\nRoss Dellenger of Google Sports shadowed Saban around the joint Monday and related that the ex-coach spent the last month talking to all 16 current SEC coaches. Also -- and this qualifies as self-imposed cruel and unusual punishment -- he watched tape of all 16 spring games.\n\nIt shouldn\'t be a surprise that he\'s good -- seemingly a natural -- at his new job. As a head coach, Saban could coach-speak with the best of them if the subject was Bama\'s upcoming game that week.\n\nBut get him on a topic of importance to the overall scheme of college football and you got an E.F. Hutton moment with all heads turned and all ears open.\n\nIf he\'s not the smartest guy in the room, he plays the part well.\n\nThe perfect job -- to match the genius with the pressing need -- would be as the commissioner-czar-whatever of college football.\n\nUntil then, you can look forward to College Game Day this fall.\n\nScooter Hobbs covers LSU athletics. {'uri': '2024-07-425063438', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:44:01', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:44:01Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T14:16:19Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.5058823823928833, 'url': 'https://www.autonews.com/mobility-report/yandex-autonomous-driving-technology-company-reboots-avride', 'title': 'Former Russian self-driving car company Yandex reboots as Avride', 'body': 'Avride Inc. will utilize self-driving technology in both delivery sidewalk robots and passenger-carrying vehicles. The company is based in Austin, Texas.\n\nA core group of executives and engineers once behind the Russian self-driving car company Yandex have regrouped and formed a new autonomous-driving technology effort called Avride Inc.\n\nMuch like its initial efforts, Avride is developing self-driving tech for both sidewalk delivery robots and robotaxis.\n\nThe company is headquartered in Austin, Texas, where it intends to test and deploy its technology. It joins a growing list of competitors, including Waymo, Cruise, Zoox and Volkswagen, testing and commercially deploying self-driving vehicles in Austin.\n\nThe company already has 50 employees working in Austin, company spokesperson Yulia Shveyko said. Operations are ramping up there and in offices in Tel Aviv, Seoul, Dubai and Ann Arbor, Mich.\n\n"Our vehicles are undergoing rigorous testing in a wide variety of environments across different countries," Avride said in a written statement. Avride is utilizing the Hyundai Ioniq 5 electric crossover in testing.\n\nYandex tested autonomous vehicles both in Russia and across the world between 2017 and 2022. The company suspended its efforts weeks after Russia invaded Ukraine when governments and global businesses sought to cut ties with Russia and its leading companies.\n\nAvride\'s emergence has been years in the making. The fledgling brand unveiled its efforts July 16 after its parent company completed a corporate restructuring.\n\nBased in Amsterdam, Nebius Group, formerly Yandex NV, sold its businesses inside Russia to a group of investors for $5.4 billion. Its remaining businesses, all outside of Russia, have been folded into Nebius Group.\n\nNebius Group will build artificial-intelligence infrastructure, cloud platforms and graphics processing unit clusters. Beyond those core capabilities, Nebius has three individual brands, including Avride.\n\nAs it enters this new chapter, Nebius said it has $2.5 billion in cash on hand and no debt. Nebius said it intends to retain its listing on the Nasdaq market and that it expects shares will resume trading in "due course."\n\nIn its previous iteration, Yandex operated a variety of businesses across the world, including many in Russia that spanned a human-driven taxi service to a search engine akin to Google. It began its self-driving vehicle efforts in 2017.\n\nIn its former U.S. efforts, Yandex debuted by showcasing driverless rides with no human safety drivers aboard at CES in January 2019. It later tested robotaxis in Ann Arbor, , where sidewalk robots were also operating, and Detroit.', 'source': {'uri': 'autonews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Automotive News'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'pete_bigelow@autonews.com', 'name': 'Pete Bigelow', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://s3-prod.autonews.com/s3fs-public/styles/1024x512/public/Avride-MAIN_i.png', 'eventUri': 'eng-9733565', 'sentiment': 0.03529411764705892, 'wgt': 458930641, 'relevance': 7}
{'uri': '8230364407', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:38:52', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:38:52Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T16:36:58Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://exbulletin.com/tech/2791995/', 'title': "Google warns that Putin's spies pose a threat to Paris Olympics - ExBulletin", 'body': 'Cybersecurity experts say Russian hackers are preparing to disrupt the Paris Olympics, with targets ranging from spectators to government officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity company and subsidiary of Google, argues that event organizers and attendees need to be on high alert, given the significant risks posed by financially and geopolitically motivated cybercriminals.\n\nIn a report titled "Phishing for Money," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics are "at heightened risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nAuthors Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier assessed with "high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored hackers pose the greatest risk to the Olympics, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also posing a medium threat.\n\nA visitor takes a photo next to the Olympic rings near Place de la Bastilla ahead of the Paris 2024 Olympic Games in Paris, France, July 15, 2024. A new report from Mandiant argued that the Olympics will be particularly vulnerable to cyber attacks given the ban on Russian athletes and France\'s strong support for Ukraine. Read MoreMaya Hitigi/Getty Images\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s chief threat intelligence adviser for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the Olympics\' unique vulnerabilities.\n\n"The Olympics are a high-profile sporting event with a global audience, making them an ideal platform for cyberattacks aimed at psychological and reputational damage," Collier said, "as the impact of any disruption would be significantly amplified."\n\nThe paper outlines a range of cyber risks facing the Olympics, including cyber espionage, "destructive and disruptive" attacks and financially motivated hacking.\n\nBecause it\'s an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes Russian hackers will try to use the event to "gather intelligence" on senior foreign decision makers.\n\nBut attendees should also be vigilant: such a large-scale event presents a perfect opportunity for cybercriminals of all kinds to target tourists with ticket fraud and try to steal their personal information.\n\nFor Collier, the worst-case scenario would be a massive, "destructive" attack, including the deployment of "wiper malware" to wipe data on targeted networks, that would disrupt the Paris Olympics.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin speaks at the IOC Gala Dinner on the eve of the opening ceremony of the 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, Thursday, Feb. 6, 2014. The Mandiant report names Russia as the highest-risk actor in these Olympics because of Russia\'s clear geopolitical motivations and history of disrupting past Olympic Games. More by Andrei Isakovych/Associated Press\n\nCollier argued that a number of factors conspire to make this year\'s Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee deemed Russia\'s invasion of Ukraine a "flagrant violation" of the Olympic Charter and immediately responded by banning Russia from competition in February 2022. Russian and Belarusian athletes will be able to continue competing under neutral flags.\n\nCollier said this gives Putin a "clear incentive" to target the Olympics, and combined with his sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting the Olympics in the past, makes him the greatest risk to the Olympic Games.\n\nMandiant said Russian state-sponsored hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies and conducted reconnaissance on Olympic officials during the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Olympics.\n\nCollier said France\'s fervent support for Ukraine in the wake of Russian aggression also makes the games an attractive target for geopolitically motivated attacks, making France the most likely target for a cyberattack.\n\nBut Collier said the response to the report since it was first released in June has been positive.\n\n"We\'re really encouraged that so many organizations with a stake in the Olympics are reading our report and taking action to address the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever before understand that identifying relevant threats can help them build a more proactive security posture."\n\nHave a story we should feature? Post also expects higher other income to help drive EPS upside (NASDAQ up 8% in the second quarter).\n\nAccording to Post, second-quarter positives include Search upside, positive commentary on AI overviews driving higher usage & CTRs, Shorts driving higher traffic & revenue upside, and Cloud strength as IT dollars shift toward AI.\n\nPost remains optimistic about growing AI integrations across Google's ecosystem and noted that a broader rollout of AI overviews will help drive higher activity in the core Search business.\n\nAI use poses a long-term competitive risk, but in the near term, he noted revenue upside from AI-driven monetization improvements will be a critical second-quarter takeaway.\n\nMoreover, focusing on expense management, Post noted that Y/Y margin growth in 2024 will be a bright spot and potential EPS upside driver.\n\nGiven the market multiple expansion (lower rates), the analyst raised his price target.\n\nPrice Action: GOOGL shares are trading lower by 2.02% at $180.25 at last check Wednesday.\n\nNow Read:", 'source': {'uri': 'markets.businessinsider.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Markets Insider'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'anusuya_lahiri@markets.businessinsider.com', 'name': 'Anusuya Lahiri', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://cdn.benzinga.com/files/imagecache/1024x768xUP/images/story/2024/07/17/Missing-Out-on-Google.jpeg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.3647058823529412, 'wgt': 458930043, 'relevance': 103}
{'uri': '8230331515', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '16:14:36', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T16:14:36Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T16:14:05Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://richmond.com/sports/college/old-dominion-athletic-conference-gallaudet-university/article_01456eec-444c-11ef-9dbf-eb3d93ba2f56.html', 'title': 'By adding Gallaudet, ODAC football incorporates deaf, hard of hearing players', 'body': 'Ferrum is shifting from the Division III Old Dominion Athletic Conference to Division II. Emory & Henry made that move in recent years. Roanoke, restarting a football program, comes aboard in 2025. The ODAC football wing was in a transition phase.\n\nThe league addressed that this month by adding Gallaudet, forming an intriguing football-only affiliation. The university in Washington is dedicated to the advancement of deaf and hard of hearing individuals. The Bison will begin playing ODAC games in 2025.\n\n"About the time (Ferrum) made the decision to move to Division II and announce that, Gallaudet had reached out to ask about associate membership," said Brad Bankston, the ODAC commissioner since 1997. "It really was a convergence of multiple things happening all at once."\n\nPeople are also reading... New Virginia state law changes the way reading is taught Teel: New Richmond ballpark, Henrico arenas would defy odds Preservation leaders question planned demolition of 101-year-old Richmond building L.C. Bird football alumnus, program leader Xavier Carpenter dies in Missouri car crash Opinion: In Richmond, reality seeps in - City Hall dysfunction is systemic Meet the 2024 All-Metro boys lacrosse team, led by St. Christopher\'s Liam Wright Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Midlothian man stopped woman from opening plane\'s emergency door Best in Richmond: The winner of the ice cream tournament is ... Wine Spectator ranks these as best 8 Richmond-area restaurants for wine Youngkin uses convention speech to shine spotlight on Virginia UPDATE: Charges pending in Cumberland buggy crash that killed 1, injured 6 Richmond best ice cream results, vote for the winner!🍧🍨 🍦 Powhatan authorities continue search for \'armed and dangerous\' suspect Trump co-manager takes online shot at Virginia House speaker\n\nThe ODAC was in the expansion market to reduce the number of nonconference games that needed to be scheduled. That had become increasingly challenging for the league whose membership includes Randolph-Macon, Hampden-Sydney, Washington and Lee, and other Virginia schools.\n\n"After a good bit of discussion, all of it positive, we determined (Gallaudet) was a good fit for us, for multiple reasons," Bankston said.\n\nGallaudet won the Eastern Collegiate Football Conference, which also includes Alfred State, Anna Maria, Dean and Vermont State, in 2013 and 2022. The Bison over the last five seasons went 4-5 (3-1 in the ECFC), 7-3 (5-1), 5-3 (3-3), 2-6 (2-3), and 3-5 (3-3).\n\nTheir roster has players from all over the country. Depth is commonly an issue because of the relatively small pool of prospects, and there are other challenges at a school for deaf and hard of hearing student-athletes.\n\nBenefits for Bison\n\nChuck Goldstein, who became Gallaudet\'s coach before the 2010 season, said, "I\'m not going to know what to do with myself when I get back home from an away game at like 8 p.m. That will be the first big difference because we\'ve been road dogs and we go up to (the Northeast frequently). To be able to go down the road a couple of hours and come back, I think that\'s going to be great for everybody involved.\n\n"Competitively, it\'s going to be a challenge, but it\'s a challenge we\'re looking forward to ... Obviously, the strength of schedule is going to increase. We\'re going to keep doing what we do. We\'ve been playing football for over 140 years. We\'re going to recruit. We\'re going to do the best we can. We\'re going to show up.\n\n"It\'s new and exciting."\n\nInventors of the huddle\n\nSpeaking of that Bison football tradition, Gallaudet is credited with creation of the huddle, in 1894. According to the school, Gallaudet quarterback Paul Hubbard was concerned that opposing teams were stealing Gallaudet\'s plays because his signing was in the open. He began circling up his teammates. The huddle was born.\n\nInnovation help\n\nGallaudet last season in one game used the AT&T 5G helmet, which allows a coach through a tablet to send a play to a quarterback helmet that includes a small screen mounted on the facemask.\n\nThe QB then relays the play to his teammates via signing in the huddle. This represented a significant improvement in the offense\'s communication system, according to Goldstein. The Bison could also change a play at the line, with the coach hitting an "alert" that flashed on the QB\'s screen, telling him to look to the sideline.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nQuarterbacks on the team will use that helmet throughout the 2024 season, thanks to an NCAA waiver.\n\n"It would be awesome to have all our players in (the AT&T 5G helmet)," said Goldstein.\n\nThat\'s not possible yet due to cost and current NCAA rules, according to the coach.\n\nStopping on the whistle\n\nAbout half of Gallaudet\'s players are completely deaf and communicate through American Sign Language, and the other half are hard of hearing, said Goldstein.\n\n"Some of those guys have hearing aids, medical implants. Some guys maybe have 30% hearing loss in one ear," he said. "It kind of varies. Some of our guys can hear whistles. Most can\'t."\n\nDefensively, there have been occasional issues with Gallaudet players failing to stop on the officials\' play-ending whistles, which cannot be heard by some of them. Penalties have resulted.\n\n"It does start with the officials. We have a pre-game meeting with officials," Goldstein said. "It\'s making sure they understand that it\'s not just standing there blowing the whistle and moving your hands to signal a play dead. They\'ve got to be active. They\'ve got to run in while they\'re blowing their whistles, so hopefully our players can get them in their peripheral.\n\n"It\'s also on our opponent to stop when the whistle blows."\n\n\'The standard\' applies at Randolph-Macon, splashing again in Division III postseason\n\nDrum vibrations\n\nOn the Gallaudet sideline, a large bass drum is part of the team\'s gear. In years past, vibrations from the drumbeat acted as the snap count, and started Bison plays. The team now uses hand signals for that purpose, but the drum still helps organize pregame drills, during games informs special-teamers when they should be preparing to go on the field, and serves other purposes.\n\nHow will ODAC teams change?\n\n"We have not delved into changes we may make on our campuses yet (for Gallaudet football visits). But I am aware of several things," said Bankston. "One, signing the National Anthem and providing that opportunity for their student-athletes to be able to experience that prior to the start of the game.\n\n"Operationally, from an officiating perspective, it\'s a little different as well. We haven\'t had a lot of conversations about that with our supervisor yet, but I have had conversations with Gallaudet\'s coach. Chuck\'s been very up front about explaining to me as we were having discussions about membership kind of what those perspectives need to be from the officiating side.\n\n"We\'ll have some conversations with our supervisor and our officials as a result of that after they\'ve had a chance to communicate prior to (the Bison) starting play in 2025.\n\n"I think there\'s a lot of this that we\'ll have an opportunity to kind of dissect a little bit with Gallaudet through the (upcoming) season. I plan to attend one of their games this year to get a little more of a hands-on experience from my perspective, an understanding of how they play, and to see their facility in action so I can prepare and communicate that information to our coaches."\n\nClose\n\nEmory & Henry wide receiver Elijah Rice (4) fails to secure a catch as he is defended Randolph-Macon cornerback Stephen Richardson (14) during the first ODAC football championship game on Saturday, April 3, 2021 at Frank Day Field at Randolph Macon in Ashland, Virginia.\n\nSHABAN ATHUMAN/TIMES-DISPATCH\n\nRandolph-Macon quarterback Presley Egbers (15) fumbles the ball during the first ODAC football championship game on Saturday, April 3, 2021 at Frank Day Field at Randolph Macon in Ashland, Virginia.\n\nSHABAN ATHUMAN/TIMES-DISPATCH\n\nEmory & Henry running back Grayson Overstreet (24) blocks for Emory & Henry quarterback Hunter Taylor (1) as he carries the ball during the first ODAC football championship game on Saturday, April 3, 2021 at Frank Day Field at Randolph Macon in Ashland, Virginia.\n\nSHABAN ATHUMAN/TIMES-DISPATCH\n\nEmory & Henry running back Grayson Overstreet (24) stiff arms Randolph-Macon defensive end Matt Vergara (33) during the first ODAC football championship game on Saturday, April 3, 2021 at Frank Day Field at Randolph Macon in Ashland, Virginia.\n\nSHABAN ATHUMAN/TIMES-DISPATCH\n\nRandolph-Macon running back Grayson Overstreet (24) fall after being tripped by Randolph-Macon linebacker Erik Harris (22) and Randolph-Macon defensive end Matt Vergara (33) during the first ODAC football championship game on Saturday, April 3, 2021 at Frank Day Field at Randolph Macon in Ashland, Virginia.\n\nSHABAN ATHUMAN/TIMES-DISPATCH\n\nEmory & Henry quarterback Hunter Taylor (1) makes a pass during the first ODAC football championship game on Saturday, April 3, 2021 at Frank Day Field at Randolph Macon in Ashland, Virginia.\n\nSHABAN ATHUMAN/TIMES-DISPATCH\n\nEmory & Henry running back T.J. A $50 tablet sounds great, but not if your apps take forever to launch on a lackluster display. Lucky for you, PCMag\'s experts test and rate thousands of products each year and can easily spot the best deals. All the products below have earned our Editors\' Choice award, so you can be confident that deal is actually worth it.\n\nFor more editor-vetted deals, check out our Prime Day megapost 220+ of the Best Prime Day Tech Deals to Save You Tons of Money.\n\nSony WF-1000XM5\n\nIn our review, PCMag found that Sony\'s WF-1000XM5 earphones feature some of the best audio quality of the noise-cancelling pairs we\'ve tested, outshining the Bose QuietComfort Earbuds II and the Apple AirPods Pro in the ANC department. Our main concern about these earbuds was their price, but that\'s not a problem on Prime Day; get them now for 24% off.\n\nEcovacs Deebot X2 Omni\n\nThe Ecovacs Deebot X2 Omni is a "supremely self-sufficient robot floor cleaner," we found in our review, thanks to a unique D shape for improved corner and edge cleaning and a more hygienic mop-washing system that flushes the pads with hot water. Pair that with stronger suction power over its predecessor and you get the best two-in-one robot vacuum and mop we\'ve tested. Better yet, it\'s 40% off for Prime Day.\n\nFitbit Charge 6\n\nThe Charge 6 is Fitbit\'s most advanced tracker, with a focus on fitness and health. It features 40 exercise profiles for workout tracking and an option to send your heart rate via Bluetooth to gym equipment (though note that some data requires a Fitbit Premium subscription). But there are also several Google lifestyle apps, including Google Maps, Google Wallet, and YouTube Music. It\'s an excellent investment in your wellness and our Editors\' Choice winner for fitness trackers.\n\nHisense 65U8N\n\nThe Hisense U8N series builds on last year\'s U8K with an even brighter panel and a sleeker remote. This premium TV rivals much more expensive competitors and is a fantastic value, even without the 37% discount for Prime Day.\n\nArlo Pro 3 Floodlight Camera\n\nThe Arlo Pro 3 Floodlight Camera is a battery-powered security cam that offers sharp 2K video, color night vision with a bright floodlight, and plenty of third-party compatibility. Some premium features require an Arlo Smart Plan, but its "superb video quality and ease of use" earn it our Editors\' Choice for smart floodlight cameras. On Prime Day, it\'s 32% off.\n\nMore Can\'t-Miss Prime Day Deals on Editors\' Choice-Winning Products', 'source': {'uri': 'pcmag.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'PC Magazine'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'chloe_albanesius@pcmag.com', 'name': 'Chloe Albanesius', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://i.pcmag.com/imagery/articles/01BNzWJpSBsQBduxcXdcmM7-20.fit_lim.size_1200x630.v1721212557.png', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.4745098039215687, 'wgt': 458927450, 'relevance': 5}
{'uri': '8230288846', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '15:44:51', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T15:44:51Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:44:28Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.hindustantimes.com/sports/olympics/at-paris-2024-india-to-prioritise-mental-health-101721230086510.html', 'title': 'At Paris 2024, India to prioritise mental health', 'body': 'Bengaluru: Divya Jain spent a good part of the pandemic staring into tiny panels of anxious athletes on her Zoom screen. The Tokyo Olympics had been postponed, training centres were shut, Covid-19 protocols were in place and the Olympic athletes she chatted with were having trouble sleeping and staying motivated. Their structured training routines were gone in a poof and the uncertainty was debilitating for many.\n\nAnother Olympics is upon us and this time, Divya, a sports psychologist, along with her senior colleague and psychiatrist, Dr Samir Parikh, are headed to Paris as part of the Indian Olympic Association\'s medical team. This sort of focus on mental health is not something Parikh, who has decades in the profession, would\'ve anticipated even five years ago.\n\n"The conventional idea of athletes needing mental support was largely to do with getting into a zone and reaching an optimal performance state," said Parikh, Chairperson, Fortis National Mental Health Program. "But now, we seem to understand that the mental wellness of an athlete is extremely important too. I wouldn\'t have imagined that there would come a day when two mental health professionals would be included in India\'s Olympic medical team. It\'s a huge step."\n\nIf the pandemic got the conversation started, the Tokyo Olympics intensified the global discourse on the importance of mental health. Simone Biles and the \'twisties\' were at the heart of it. The preternaturally talented Olympic champion gymnast pulled out of multiple events in Tokyo, citing that she had the \'twisties\' - a temporary loss of spatial awareness. According to data analytics company NewsWhip, Biles\' shocking withdrawal generated two million social media interactions and sparked a conversation on mental health, much higher than either Naomi Osaka\'s French Open withdrawal or Prince Harry and Meghan Markle\'s interview with Oprah. Google searches about mental health reportedly spiked on the day of Biles\' withdrawal, touching its highest in two months.\n\nAside from the stigma of seeking help with mental health issues, athletes face an additional hurdle. "There is a public perception of athletes being strong, unbreakable characters. Athletes can worry about being perceived as weak if they express emotions or mental struggle," says Divya, Head, Psychological Services for the Fortis National Mental Health Program. Virat Kohli once spoke of going through a phase in his career where he felt like "it was the end of the world". "In England 2014, I just didn\'t know what to do, what to say to anyone, how to speak, how to communicate. To be honest, I couldn\'t have said I am not feeling great mentally and I want to get away from the game, because you never know how that\'s taken."\n\nFor India\'s Paris-bound athletes, the mental health support by both experts won\'t just be limited to the duration of the Games. "We will be available to assist athletes both before as well as after the Games too," said Parikh. "The impact of the competition does, after all, tend to go on for longer. We\'ll of course be looking at both the performance enhancement aspect - how players are dealing with the pressures and expectations that come with the occasion - while also ensuring mental well-being and managing stress from extraneous factors."\n\nParikh and Divya, along with the rest of the IOA medical team, have been introduced to the Paris-bound athletes. "I travelled to SAI centers and NIS Patiala since it\'s important that athletes know us by name and face so they aren\'t sitting down with someone they\'ve never met before, in Paris. There\'s going to be a medical room where we\'ll be available and if the need arises we\'ll travel to the venues," said Divya.\n\n"At a stage like the Olympics, it\'s likely that many of the concerns could be performance or anxiety related. Whether it\'s a first-timer or someone returning from injury. We use visualisation both for mental rehearsal of technique and for athletes to plan for contingencies. Mindfulness-based training is helpful for regulating our emotions so that they don\'t derail us in high pressure moments. Also, bringing your focus back to the present, rather than fixating on the previous point, ensures you maintain an external locus when necessary and remain flexible. In high-pressure environments, athletes can have a tendency to try too hard, which is when things start to go wrong."\n\nUnlike their regular consultations, the window between an athlete seeking help and a workable solution is rather short in a live sporting event. Parikh sees it as an opportunity. "Rather than thinking we don\'t have time to fix this, we look at it as something where instead of days, the solution just needs to be applied for minutes or over a few games."\n\nThe International Olympic Committee (IOC) first came up with a mental health toolkit ahead of the Tokyo Games. This time, the body has provisioned for athletes to have access to a mindfulness app and a dedicated mental health helpline - operating 24/7 and covering 70 languages.\n\nFor perhaps the first time, mental health is getting the spotlight and preparedness it demands.', 'source': {'uri': 'hindustantimes.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Hindustan Times'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://images.hindustantimes.com/img/2024/07/17/1600x900/The-athletics-contingent--one-of-the-biggest-India_1721230038222.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1764705882352942, 'wgt': 458927091, 'relevance': 51}

Where will the money go?', 'body': 'Julia Poe, Chicago Tribune\n\nThe price of being a Chicago Sky fan just went up.\n\nIt was inevitable. Even a casual viewer this season could see it coming: the sold-out crowds, the back-ordered jerseys, the record-breaking viewership. The popularity of Angel Reese and Kamilla Cardoso -- and the 2024 draft class at large -- has been undeniable, commanding a wave of demand for tickets and merchandise that was certain to be balanced out by a surge in pricing.\n\nBut for many longtime season ticket holders, the change came as a shock this week when the Sky sent out emails detailing next year\'s invoices would be doubled -- or more -- from their original prices. Courtside seats for the 2025 season skyrocketed from $4,500 to $11,000. More affordable 18-game packages for 200-level seats jumped from $270 to $985.\n\nPeople are also reading... Felon held by armed resident in Macon County gets 2 years Thousands in Central Illinois without power after second night of summer storms Normal residence heavily damaged, cat perishes in structure fire Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Jury deliberates fate of Bloomington man charged with murder of Decatur teen Normal backs enterprise zone taking in possible $200M Rivian expansion Bloomington man jailed on weapons, drug charges after traffic stop Revolution Dispensary to host grand opening Friday in Normal Dewon Griffin found guilty of murder in 2019 NYE shooting Hundreds evacuate \'imminent\' dam failure in Nashville, Ill. Highways flood and close. Trump picks Sen. JD Vance of Ohio, a once-fierce critic turned loyal ally, as his GOP running mate Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive Bloomington police investigating shots fired Wednesday night Flick Fact: How many State Farm employees are college educated? Flick Fact: Is there really a river under Normal?\n\nThis sticker shock reflects the intricacies of the transitional period the Sky are currently wading through as they attempt to retain their long-time fanbase while expanding to establish a larger footprint in Chicago. As the front office declines requests to speak about a months-old promise to announce plans for a new training facility, a natural question follows: where exactly will all that money go?\n\nIn the early years of the WNBA, affordability was a driving force in attracting and maintaining fans. In 2021, the average Sky ticket price was $43. Even after the championship win at the end of that season, ticket prices remained relatively stable in ensuing seasons, jumping to an average price of $88 this year. This made the team uniquely accessible to fans in an otherwise expensive sports market.\n\nBut this week\'s jump in pricing seems to reflect that the Sky are adjusting to market norms in Chicago. For instance, it cost an average of $276 to attend a Bulls game last season as the team led the league in attendance despite relatively apathetic results on the court.\n\nIt feels superfluous to pose the question of what exactly changed to garner this sudden spike. What changed? Everything. The WNBA is riding an unprecedented surge of attention and popularity. As a result, teams and the league are attempting to recalibrate their worth - in ticket prices, media rights deals and even in the valuation of the franchises - almost overnight.\n\nAt its core, this is a reflection of success. Women\'s basketball has never been a hotter ticket. And players are already seeing the pay-off as they earn major wins like charter flights that the players union had been fighting to achieve for years.\n\nFor the Sky, the real issue is what comes next. Fans are clamoring for standard improvements to match those beefed-up ticket prices -- including better food and drink options at Wintrust Arena, better perks for season ticket holders and improved in-game entertainment. But for the Sky, investment and revenue is an issue that runs much deeper.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe Sky are still struggling to shake a long-held reputation of being a "cheap" franchise, which is centered around the team training in a public recreation center in Deerfield.\n\nIn an interview with the Chicago Sun-Times earlier this year, Lincolnwood native Jewell Loyd said she passed over the Sky in free agency due to a lack of investment, adding that players across the WNBA are "waiting for Chicago to step up" before the franchise can become a legitimate contender for free agents.\n\nWith the promise created by Cardoso and Reese - along with additions like coach Teresa Weatherspoon and crafty guard Chennedy Carter - the Sky have never been better positioned to redefine themselves. But they can\'t take that step until they move their players into a more professional training facility -- a process that increased revenue could certainly assist.\n\nSky operating chairman Nadia Rawlinson has declined to speak with the Tribune about these efforts and refused questions until the front office is prepared to make a public announcement about the facility. But that announcement should have already been made in May, when Rawlinson promised the Sky would have a significant update on the training facility before the start of the season.\n\nRelated ArticlesChicago Sky | Chennedy Carter scores 34 and Angel Reese records another double-double as Chicago Sky beat Las Vegas AcesChicago Sky | Angel Reese\'s double-double streak comes to an end as the Chicago Sky fall to the New York Liberty 81-67Chicago Sky | Chicago Sky are the worst 3-point shooting team in the WNBA. Is that a problem?Chicago Sky | Angel Reese runs double-double streak to 15 games, but the Chicago Sky fade late in a 91-76 loss to the New York LibertyChicago Sky | Sue Bird predicted Chennedy Carter would outplay her draft class. The Chicago Sky guard believes it: \'Just keep watching.\'\n\nTwo months and 24 games later, the Sky have not provided a timeline or any further updates, other than the fact that their current lease at Sachs Recreation Center runs out at the end of the year. This might seem like a worn out issue, but only because the franchise has been stuck in the same public position for more than a year, continuously stalling with cheery promises that have not been fulfilled.\n\nInertness is a status quo the Sky can no longer afford. Sure, ticket sales are up this year, but this is an inherited value. The Sky did not make Cardoso or Reese a star. And while drafting one of the most popular women\'s athletes in the country - maybe the world - has brought a boom of success for the team this season, that\'s not a sustainable business model to replicate in the future.\n\nRookie contracts are short. Whether they realize it or not, the Sky are already making their free-agency pitches -- both to their rookies and to the potential free agents who could join them to chase down another title. And despite an understanding throughout the franchise of their image around the league, the Sky have yet to "step up" to the challenge set by players like Loyd.\n\nRising ticket prices might be the cost of doing business as the WNBA continues to rise in popularity. But the increase of investment from Sky ownership will have to match it -- or the team risks being left behind once again.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'pantagraph.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'pantagraph.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'julia_poe@pantagraph.com', 'name': 'Julia Poe', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/pantagraph.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/d/92/d92bde03-5f1f-5304-a3e4-453aed8880f4/6697e20074a23.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.003921568627450966, 'wgt': 458926445, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8230256674', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '15:22:34', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T15:22:34Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:22:05Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://pantagraph.com/sports/professional/baseball/mlb/chicago_cubs/4-takeaways-from-the-chicago-cubs-2024-mlb-draft-including-landing-one-of-the-best/article_104f459c-d3ab-5958-af46-86c5eebe9d05.html', 'title': "4 takeaways from the Chicago Cubs' 2024 MLB draft, including landing one of the best defensive catchers", 'body': 'Vice president of scouting Dan Kantrovitz and the Chicago Cubs had a clear-cut plan entering the 2024 MLB draft.\n\nThey expected to be hitter-heavy on Days 1 and 2 for rounds 1-10, and then shift their focus to pitchers on Day 3 during rounds 11-20.\n\n"I think we obtained the right balance based on our assessment of the talent, the draft pool, as well fulfilling whatever needs we might have in the system," Kantrovitz said Tuesday at the conclusion of the three-day draft.\n\nKantrovitz doesn\'t expect any surprises, anticipating all 20 players the Cubs selected will sign. The Cubs ultimately chose nine pitchers (six right-handers and three left-handers), seven infielders, two outfielders and two catchers.\n\nHere are four takeaways from the Cubs\' 2024 draft.\n\nPeople are also reading... Felon held by armed resident in Macon County gets 2 years Thousands in Central Illinois without power after second night of summer storms Normal residence heavily damaged, cat perishes in structure fire Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Jury deliberates fate of Bloomington man charged with murder of Decatur teen Normal backs enterprise zone taking in possible $200M Rivian expansion Bloomington man jailed on weapons, drug charges after traffic stop Revolution Dispensary to host grand opening Friday in Normal Dewon Griffin found guilty of murder in 2019 NYE shooting Hundreds evacuate \'imminent\' dam failure in Nashville, Ill. Highways flood and close. Trump picks Sen. JD Vance of Ohio, a once-fierce critic turned loyal ally, as his GOP running mate Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive Bloomington police investigating shots fired Wednesday night Flick Fact: How many State Farm employees are college educated? Flick Fact: Is there really a river under Normal? 1. They went college heavy with their picks.\n\nBy the time the draft ended, only three of the Cubs\' 20 picks were high school players: shortstops Ronny Cruz (Miami Christian School in Florida) and Ty Southisene (Basic High School in Nevada) in the third and fourth rounds, respectively, and outfielder Eli Lovich (Blue Valley West High School in Kansas) in the 11th round.\n\nIt marked the second straight year the Cubs\' draft skewed toward college players, something Kantrovitz described as not the organization\'s philosophy, but a challenge that comes with taking prep players because of how much they tend to cost to sign.\n\n"In certain rounds, your options are limited," Kantrovitz said. "You try to be in position to draft and sign as many high school players as possible. You just at some point run out of room with the cap."\n\nEven with taking just three prep players, Kantrovitz expects the Cubs\' bonus pool allotment to skew toward them as much as any team. Lovich will require a "pretty substantial investment" to buy out his commitment to Arkansas and with that, like the player a lot. Kantrovitz credited area scout Ty Nichols for "raising the flag early" on Lovich, identifying him as one of the better bats he saw all spring in general, beyond just the high school demographic.\n\nThe 6-foot-4 left-handed hitting Lovich, rated the No. 1 outfielder and No. 3 overall recruit in Kansas by Perfect Game, posted a .402 average, .482 on-base percentage and 1.245 OPS with eight doubles, six triples, five home runs and 15 stolen bases his senior year.\n\nKantrovitz said Lovich put on a show in batting practice during a pre-draft workout at the Cubs complex in Mesa, Ariz., shagging fly balls and participating in high-performance testing.\n\n"We\'re pretty excited to watch his body just transform in the next couple of years and hopefully have that carryover to how hard he\'s hitting the ball and some power numbers too," he said. "But he\'s a pretty exciting one."\n\n2. Valuing performance against the best competition.\n\nOne common theme among many of the Cubs\' selections is their participation and success playing in the Cape Cod League.\n\nIt\'s a group that includes Florida State third baseman Cam Smith (first round), College of Charleston third baseman Cole Mathis (second round), University of California-San Diego third baseman Matt Halbach (10th round), Grand Canyon right-hander Daniel Avitia (12th round), Lipscomb left-hander Hayden Frank (15th round), Georgia Southern right-hander Ben Johnson (17th round) and Indiana right-hander Brayden Risedorph (20th round).\n\n"The trick is to try to get as much bulk as you can from a performance standpoint, from a sort of a statistical standpoint, and then also be able to have context with that bulk," Kantrovitz said. "I think the way in which we can try to do that the most effectively is if it\'s against the best competition, and that tends to happen in the Cape League and also in the SEC and some of the other major conferences. When we can get players that have bulk in both, it gives us that much more confidence that those numbers are going to translate, and then our equivalencies end up translating to what we might expect them to do.\n\n"When they get into Low A and High A, many of the same players that they\'re competing against were those players that they were competing against in the Cape League or the SEC, so you just kind of have a better idea of where their floor is."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n3. Cubs land one of the best defensive catchers in the country.\n\nSometimes future major-league caliber catchers can be difficult to find in the draft.\n\nWhen teams do identify some within the draft pool, it can be challenging to predict when they might go off the board, Kantrovitz said.\n\n"And if you\'re a team that takes them, that means you probably draft them a little bit earlier than teams would expect," he added.\n\n2024 MLB draft: A look at players with Illinois connections who were selected -- and by which teams\n\nIt makes the pick of University of California-San Diego catcher Ariel Armas notable, particularly given his defensive pedigree. Between Armas\' defensive metrics and his accolades, his work behind the plate was considered one of the best in the country.\n\nArmas won the Gold Glove among Division I catchers last month after being named the 2024 West Coast Conference Defensive Player of the Year, and was one of 16 semifinalists for the 2024 Buster Posey National Collegiate Catcher of the Year Award. Armas, 21, owned a .998 fielding percentage while recording 15 caught stealing and led the country with 18.69 Defensive Runs Saved -- 3.58 more runs saved than the next closest player.\n\n"He\'s got a cannon of an arm and just looks really natural back there and he\'s got pretty exceptional framing skills," Kantrovitz said. "And because of this, when he put his framing, his caught stealing, his blocking, his receiving, when you put all those up against the other catchers both analytically and from a scouting standpoint, he stacks up pretty well."\n\n4. Plenty of slug can be found among the college bats.\n\nThe Cubs are infusing more slug into their system.\n\nAmong the nine college position players they drafted, a couple certainly aren\'t lacking thump.\n\nSmith and Mathis -- their top two picks -- both feature the type of upside and power potential that\'s ideal in the first two rounds. Smith, 21, had a .654 slugging percentage and 39 extra-base hits as a draft-eligible sophomore at FSU, while Mathis, who turns 21 on July 25, recorded a .650 slugging percentage 33 XBH in his junior season at Charleston.\n\nRelated ArticlesChicago Cubs | Red Sox\'s Jarren Duran\'s 2-run HR gives the American League a 5-3 win over the National League in the MLB All-Star GameChicago Cubs | Cubs\' Shota Imanaga picks a perfect jingle for All-Star Game, while White Sox\'s Garrett Crochet \'absorbs\' his big momentChicago Cubs | Column: Velocity is the name in the MLB All-Star Game -- and perhaps every game in the futureChicago Cubs | 2024 MLB draft: A look at players with Illinois connections who were selected -- and by which teamsChicago Cubs | MLB players in 2028 Olympics? Robot umpires by 2026? Commissioner Rob Manfred says both are possible.\n\n"When you dig deeper, his chase rates, his in-zone contact rates, his exit velocities, his ability to really just hit the ball hard and in the air, keep the ball off the ground, which if you\'re looking at that from a performance standpoint that\'s indicated just by some of the ground ball-fly ball rates, and he seems to do it fairly effortlessly too," Kantrovitz said of Mathis.\n\n"He\'s a pretty strong kid and he\'s got a natural swing plane that lends itself to consistently hitting the ball in the air and then with his with his size and strength, he ends up putting pretty good charge into it."\n\nNicholls State first baseman Edgar Alvarez (eighth round) has put up dominant numbers, led by a .405/.514/.678 slash line. He hit 21 doubles and 13 home runs in 58 games, and has cut down his strikeout rate while improving his walk rate from his junior to senior season. Although he is on the older side -- he turns 24 in February -- Alvarez, who also won the D-1 Gold Glove this year at his position, was area scout Will Swoope\'s "gut-feel guy" as a player who has baseball card numbers that jump off the page, Kantrovitz said.\n\n"He has a beautiful, pure swing," Kantrovitz said. "As opposed to, like, just some gargantuan exit velos or gaudy numbers, which actually he has both at times. ... I think he could end up being a sleeper."\n\nUniversity of California-Santa Barbara outfielder Ivan Brethowr and his 6-foot-6, 250-pound frame produce strong exit velocity and power to tap into. Brethowr, 21, connected for 10 doubles and 15 home runs this year, part of a .275 average, .405 OBP and .968 OPS in 50 games.\n\n"When you have that base, it ends up being somebody that is also pretty exciting," Kantrovitz said. "He\'s a pretty well-balanced hitter in addition to having some some juice. It\'s good decision-making, it\'s good contact skills. It\'s generally square contact in the air."\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'pantagraph.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'pantagraph.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'meghan_montemurro@pantagraph.com', 'name': 'Meghan Montemurro', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/pantagraph.com/content/tncms/custom/image/b32c1a3a-f6a7-11e5-b75e-6b57a5d92d3d.png?resize=600%2C315', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.06666666666666665, 'wgt': 458925754, 'relevance': 51}

{'uri': '2024-07-424958490', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '15:00:30', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T15:00:30Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T15:00:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://searchengineland.com/search-marketing-gender-pay-gap-2024-444119', 'title': 'Survey: Search marketing gender pay gap is widening', 'body': 'SearchBot: I am trained with Search Engine Land content. Ask me anything!\n\nMen earn an average of 36% more than women in search marketing in 2024, according to a new Search Engine Land survey.\n\nWhile there is less of a gender pay gap disparity in senior positions, there is still a disparity.\n\nAdditionally, women were more likely to have changed jobs or received promotions more recently than men. And men and women are similarly satisfied with their current role, the survey revealed.\n\nWhy we care. People should receive equal compensation for equal work, regardless of gender. However, Search Engine Land\'s 2024 Salary and Career Survey indicates that isn\'t happening. The gap between salaries for men and women in search marketing hasn\'t closed. Rather, pay inequality has widened.\n\nMen earn 36% more than women. Men earned an average of $130,000 in 2024 (vs. $105,250 in 2023) while women earned an average of $95,000 in 2024 (vs. $83,265 in 2023).\n\nThat means men earn $34,500 (or 36%) more, on average, than women in search marketing, according to our survey. Men earned 26% more than women in 2023.\n\nFor context, in the U.S., full-time working women are paid roughly 82% to 84% of what men earn. That means the disparity we see here is more than double the U.S. average.\n\nMen in senior positions earn 8% more than women. The search marketing pay gap is less pronounced in senior positions.\n\nFor director-level and higher positions (i.e., director, senior director, VP, SVP, C-suite), there is an 8% pay difference - $175,479 for men compared to $161,943 for women in 2024. For manager and staff positions, there is a 26% pay difference ($107,026 for men, $85,114 for women).\n\nJob changes and promotions. 38% of women were promoted or changed jobs in the past 12 months, compared to 25% of men.\n\n15% of women and men reported changing jobs or getting a promotion in the past six months. Another 23% of women changed jobs or were promoted within the past year, compared to 10% of men.\n\nJob satisfaction. Women are slightly more satisfied with their current roles. A majority of men and women reported being either extremely or somewhat satisfied with their roles:\n\nExtremely satisfied: 20% of men; 18% of women. Somewhat satisfied: 45% of men; 50% of women.\n\nHowever, compared to last year, both men and women are less satisfied with their roles. In 2023, 24% of men and 27% of women said they were extremely satisfied, while 56% of men and 45% of women were somewhat satisfied.\n\nMen and women were equally neutral about their roles - 14% - while 22% of men said they were somewhat or not satisfied with their roles, compared to 18% of women:\n\nMen: 10% not satisfied; 12% somewhat unsatisfied. Women: 5% not satisfied; 13% somewhat unsatisfied.\n\nMethodology. Our survey results are based on responses from 291 individuals in North America (79%) and Western Europe (21%). Due to the limited number of respondents, other regions were excluded. We used the "median" results for salaries to filter out values that might skew the results.\n\nThe 2024 Search Engine Land Salary and Career Survey was conducted between December and February. Invitations to take the survey were amplified on and by Search Engine Land. The survey included more than 20 questions related to career roles, salary, technology, job satisfaction and challenges/frustrations. Respondents were also asked to reveal their age and gender.\n\nAdd Search Engine Land to your Google News feed.\n\nRelated stories\n\nNew on Search Engine Land\n\nGoogle tightens AdMob policies, reshaping ad placement rules\n\n5 ways to incorporate trends into your SEO content strategy\n\nThe Kanban approach to efficient PPC campaign management\n\nHow to address the top reputation issues impacting brands today\n\nThe Rise of Personalization in E-commerce: 2024 Consumer Insights\n\nAbout the author\n\nStaff\n\nDanny Goodwin\n\nDanny Goodwin has been Managing Editor of Search Engine Land &\n\nSearch Marketing Expo - SMX since 2022.
