{'uri': '2024-07-424946491', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '14:48:25', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T14:48:25Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T14:11:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.ibtimes.com.au/eu-court-rejects-tiktok-challenge-against-new-eu-digital-rules-1849649', 'title': 'EU Court Rejects TikTok Challenge Against New EU Digital Rules', 'body': 'TikTok lost an appeal Wednesday to escape new digital rules that seek to rein in the power of big tech after an EU court rejected its challenge.\n\nA landmark European Union law known as the Digital Markets Act (DMA) entered into force in March, and regulators believe it will create a fairer market.\n\nThe European Commission designated six "gatekeepers" under the DMA facing the curbs: Google parent Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, Microsoft -- and TikTok owner ByteDance, the only non-US company.\n\nThe EU said in May that Booking would also have to apply the law and gave the online travel agent six months to prepare for compliance.\n\nThe decision by the Luxembourg-based General Court is the first judgement on a DMA challenge by big tech, with cases lodged by Apple and Meta still pending.\n\n"The Court dismisses ByteDance\'s action," it said. TikTok can appeal against the ruling within two months and 10 days of the decision.\n\nTikTok had insisted it was the "most capable challenger" to entrenched players in the digital sphere, but the court dismissed that argument.\n\n"TikTok had succeeded in increasing its number of users very rapidly and exponentially, reaching, in a short time, half the size of Facebook and of Instagram, and a particularly high engagement rate, with young users in particular, who spent more time on TikTok than on other social networks," the court said in a statement.\n\nThe judges acknowledged that in 2018, video sharing app TikTok was indeed a challenger but it had since then "rapidly consolidated its position and even strengthened that position over the following years" despite the launch of similar rival services.\n\n"We are disappointed with this decision. TikTok is a challenger platform that provides important competition to incumbent players," a spokesperson said in a statement.\n\n"While we will now evaluate next steps, we already took measures to comply with the relevant obligations of the DMA ahead of last March\'s deadline."\n\nBut the court determined "ByteDance met the quantitative thresholds laid down in the DMA".\n\nFor Brussels to name a company as a gatekeeper, they must fulfil certain conditions.\n\nThe criteria include having more than 45 million monthly active users in the EU and more than 10,000 yearly active business users established in the bloc.\n\nDigital companies with an annual turnover in the EU of at least 7.5 billion euros ($8.2 billion) or a market value of above 75 billion euros also face the new curbs.\n\nIf a company violates the law, the EU can impose fines of up to 10 percent of a company\'s total global turnover. This can rise to 20 percent for repeat offenders and in the most severe circumstances, the EU can order the break-up of companies.\n\nIt is the second defeat in the courts for TikTok over the DMA. It lost a bid in February to suspend the strict new rules pending the judgement handed down Wednesday.\n\nBig tech is not happy about the new law. Apple, contesting the DMA in the courts, has been vocal in its criticism, saying it puts users\' security at risk.', 'source': {'uri': 'ibtimes.com.au', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'International Business Times AU'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://d.ibtimes.com.au/en/full/1854044/digital-markets-act-forces-platforms-like-tiktok-change-their-ways.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.01960784313725483, 'wgt': 458923705, 'relevance': 54}
{'uri': '2024-07-424944944', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '14:46:56', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T14:46:56Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T14:16:50Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://arab.news/csd73', 'title': 'EU court rejects TikTok challenge against new EU digital rules', 'body': 'TikTok claimed to be acting as the "most capable challenger" to digital monopolies\n\nLUXEMBOURG: TikTok lost an appeal Wednesday to escape new digital rules that seek to rein in the power of big tech after an EU court rejected its challenge.\n\nA landmark European Union law known as the Digital Markets Act (DMA) entered into force in March, and regulators believe it will create a fairer market.\n\nThe European Commission designated six "gatekeepers" under the DMA facing the curbs: Google parent Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, Microsoft -- and TikTok owner ByteDance, the only non-US company.\n\nThe EU said in May that Booking would also have to apply the law and gave the online travel agent six months to prepare for compliance.\n\nThe decision by the Luxembourg-based General Court is the first judgment on a DMA challenge by big tech, with cases lodged by Apple and Meta still pending.\n\n"The Court dismisses ByteDance\'s action," it said. TikTok can appeal against the ruling within two months and 10 days of the decision.\n\nTikTok had insisted it was the "most capable challenger" to entrenched players in the digital sphere, but the court dismissed that argument.\n\n"TikTok had succeeded in increasing its number of users very rapidly and exponentially, reaching, in a short time, half the size of Facebook and of Instagram, and a particularly high engagement rate, with young users in particular, who spent more time on TikTok than on other social networks," the court said in a statement.\n\nThe judges acknowledged that in 2018, video sharing app TikTok was indeed a challenger but it had since then "rapidly consolidated its position and even strengthened that position over the following years" despite the launch of similar rival services.\n\n"We are disappointed with this decision. TikTok is a challenger platform that provides important competition to incumbent players," a spokesperson said in a statement.\n\n"While we will now evaluate next steps, we already took measures to comply with the relevant obligations of the DMA ahead of last March\'s deadline."\n\nBut the court determined "ByteDance met the quantitative thresholds laid down in the DMA."\n\nFor Brussels to name a company as a gatekeeper, they must fulfil certain conditions.\n\nThe criteria include having more than 45 million monthly active users in the EU and more than 10,000 yearly active business users established in the bloc.\n\nDigital companies with an annual turnover in the EU of at least 7.5 billion euros ($8.2 billion) or a market value of above 75 billion euros also face the new curbs.\n\nIf a company violates the law, the EU can impose fines of up to 10 percent of a company\'s total global turnover. This can rise to 20 percent for repeat offenders and in the most severe circumstances, the EU can order the break-up of companies.\n\nIt is the second defeat in the courts for TikTok over the DMA. It lost a bid in February to suspend the strict new rules pending the judgment handed down Wednesday.\n\nBig tech is not happy about the new law. Apple, contesting the DMA in the courts, has been vocal in its criticism, saying it puts users\' security at risk.', 'source': {'uri': 'arab.news', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Arab News'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'agence_france_presse@arab.news', 'name': 'Agence France-Presse', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.arabnews.com/sites/default/files/styles/660x371_watermarksaudi/public/main-image/2024/07/17/4470901-1841859747.jpg?itok=-dkHW1F7', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.01960784313725483, 'wgt': 458923616, 'relevance': 54}

He has sustained that momentum at the international level with game-defining moments that helped England reach the final at UEFA EURO 2024 this summer, truly confirming his star status and earning his place on the cover of EA SPORTS FC 25.\n\nI played this game with my brother all the time growing up, and I\'ve always thought about how incredible it would be to one day be featured on the cover, said Jude Bellingham. There have been so many iconic players on the cover over the years, and I am delighted to be the most recent English player to be bestowed with this honour since 2011. I\'m also truly honoured to be featured on the cover of Ultimate Edition with true legends of the game both past and present in Beckham, BonmatÃ\xad, Buffon and Zidane.\n\nDownload EA SPORTS FC Mobile on the App Store and Google (NASDAQ:GOOGL) Play Store to play Anywhere For the Club. {'uri': '8230137054', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '14:03:59', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T14:03:59Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T14:03:30Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://napavalleyregister.com/news/local/napa-flood-control-eminent-domain-environment-weather/article_5e14c91a-42d5-11ef-b499-2f766a6b2670.html', 'title': 'Napa County acquiring land for flood wall project', 'body': 'A new Napa River flood control project segment to be built between Lincoln Avenue and the Oxbow is to include a river trail.\n\nHere\'s a sign the latest Napa River flood control project phase is moving forward -- the Napa County Flood Control and Water Conservation District is acquiring land.\n\nAbout 45 properties in the city of Napa are needed for the next big push. So far, the district has three agreements and has made 40 offers based on appraisals, with the coming months promising a flurry of activity.\n\n"It\'s quite a process," said Richard Thomasser, the district manager.\n\nThe flood control district is poised to use eminent domain powers to acquire land when negotiations with owners fail, allowing the Napa County Superior Court to settle the price.\n\nThis next phase of the flood control project involves building a flood wall on the west side of the Napa River for about a mile, from near the Elks Lodge south of Trancas Street past Lincoln Avenue to the Oxbow area. The goal is to protect hundreds of properties from the peak flood level expected every 100 years.\n\nPeople are also reading... $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Ryan Seacrest\'s Napa County home up for sale at $22 million Customers are raving about Moulin -- downtown Napa\'s new café and bakery Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 Letter: Concerns about St. Helena Agritourism Initiative Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Napa City Council to weigh selling land for downtown development Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life Why is that? Here\'s the lowdown on some Napa head-scratchers Napa County, Hoopes winery file closing arguments in legal clash St. Helena Cyclery to reopen in wake of Trek\'s closure Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Fight between Le Petit Elephant and Alta Heights neighbors gets personal Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive Defendants in Napa double murder delay pleas to Sept. 17\n\nConstruction of the project, which is to include a public trail, is scheduled to begin in late 2025.\n\nOn Tuesday, the flood control district\'s board of directors met and acquisitions were on the agenda. The board approved buying 1.42 acres of vacant industrial land along the Napa River at 501 North Bay Drive near Lincoln Avenue for $675,000.\n\nThe board was also scheduled to initiate eminent domain for vacant property at 1114 Jordan Lane south of Lincoln Avenue. The district and owners have been unable to agree on a price for a 15-foot-wide strip of land along the river and temporary construction easements.\n\nBut the board needs a two-thirds vote to initiate eminent domain. Not enough members attended the meeting to meet that threshold.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"To be continued," said board chair and Napa Mayor Scott Sedgley.\n\nDistrict engineer Andrew Butler told the board that 95% of the design for the project should be completed in the fall. Sedgley called this "really good news."\n\nThis latest phase of the flood control project is to protect an area near Lincoln Avenue and along Soscol Avenue that last flooded during the 2005-06 New Year\'s Eve storms. Muddy Napa River water spilled onto streets and into homes and businesses.\n\nFlood control has long been a concern locally, with the Napa Valley experiencing about two dozen major floods since pioneer days. But the community balked when the federal government in the 1960s proposed lining a section of the Napa River with concrete as a solution.\n\nBig storms in February 1986 once again put flood control in the spotlight. Flooding caused an estimated $140 million in damage, destroyed 250 homes and prompted 7,000 evacuations in Napa Valley.\n\nNapa County communities and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers launched the Napa River flood control project in 1998. Voters passed a now-expired half-cent sales tax to help fund the undertaking, with the federal and state governments also providing money.\n\nFlood control Napa-style would not involve a concrete-lined river. Instead, the emphasis would be on a "living river" concept depending largely on floodplains and flood walls.\n\nSince then, the city of Napa has seen such work down as major bridges replaced and floodplains created. The last major project was the $18.5 million flood control bypass between the Oxbow area and downtown, completed in 2015 and named the Oxbow Commons.\n\nBut work remained. In 2021, Rep. Mike Thompson, D-St. Helena, announced the Army Corps of Engineers would provide $48.3 million for remaining portions of the flood control project. Local funds, grants and developer contributions were to boost the total to about $94 million.\n\nThe Lincoln Avenue-area project is coming first. Next, the flood control district plans to construct a flood wall and trail along the western river from Imola Avenue to near the Napa County Library, much of it along Riverside Drive. Work is also to be done in the Oxbow area.\n\nThrowback Thursday: A look at the Napa River St. Helena on the Napa River Schooner on the Napa River Napa River Scene Napa River 1920 Flood of 1940 at Pearl Street Napa River Sailboats on the Napa River Service boat in Napa River Uncle Sam Wine Cellars from the Napa River Zinfandel Steamer in the Napa River Gondola on the Napa River\n\nYou can reach Barry Eberling at 707-256-2253 or beberling@napanews.com\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '8230136532', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '14:03:44', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T14:03:44Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T14:03:15Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://richmond.com/sports/professional/richard-petty-named-grand-marshal-for-nascar-truck-series-race-at-richmond-raceway/article_92110470-443f-11ef-93bb-079899de25cd.html', 'title': 'Richard Petty named Grand Marshal for NASCAR Truck Series race at Richmond Raceway', 'body': 'Ruby Scoops wins best ice cream in city; Richmonder turns 100; VCU baseball loses coach\n\nRichmond Raceway announced in a Wednesday morning news release that NASCAR Hall of Famer, seven-time Cup Series Champion and the winningest driver in NASCAR history Richard Petty will serve as the Grand Marshal for the Clean Harbors 250 on Aug. 10. Amid the Petty Family\'s 75th year in NASCAR, Petty will say the most famous words in motorsports prior to the NASCAR CRAFTSMAN Truck Series regular season finale, "Drivers, start your engines!"\n\n"An event as significant as this deserves to have one of the most prominent figures in sports history give the command to start engines," said Richmond Raceway President Lori Collier Waran in the news release. "We\'re thrilled and honored to have \'The King\' Richard Petty serve as the Grand Marshal for the Clean Harbors 250 in what should be an electrifying race under the lights."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nDuring his 35-year career, the Level Cross, North Carolina, native has the most NASCAR Cup Series wins (200), most poles (123), most wins in a season (27), most Daytona 500 wins (seven), most consecutive wins (10), most starts (1,185), and is tied for the most championships with Dale Earnhardt and Jimmie Johnson (seven).\n\nPeople are also reading... New Virginia state law changes the way reading is taught Teel: New Richmond ballpark, Henrico arenas would defy odds Preservation leaders question planned demolition of 101-year-old Richmond building L.C. Bird football alumnus, program leader Xavier Carpenter dies in Missouri car crash Opinion: In Richmond, reality seeps in - City Hall dysfunction is systemic Meet the 2024 All-Metro boys lacrosse team, led by St. Christopher\'s Liam Wright Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Midlothian man stopped woman from opening plane\'s emergency door Best in Richmond: The winner of the ice cream tournament is ... Wine Spectator ranks these as best 8 Richmond-area restaurants for wine Youngkin uses convention speech to shine spotlight on Virginia UPDATE: Charges pending in Cumberland buggy crash that killed 1, injured 6 Richmond best ice cream results, vote for the winner!🍧🍨 🍦 Powhatan authorities continue search for \'armed and dangerous\' suspect Trump co-manager takes online shot at Virginia House speaker \'The King\' of NASCAR, says camp for seriously ill children is family\'s true legacy\n\nPetty\'s accomplishments earned him an induction into the inaugural class of the NASCAR Hall of Fame in 2010. He was also named as one of NASCAR\'s 75 Greatest Drivers. Additionally, he has been elected to the National Motorsports Press Association Hall of Fame, International Motorsports Hall of Fame, North Carolina Auto Racing Hall of Fame, the North Carolina Athletic Hall of Fame and serves as Chairman of the North Carolina Motorsports Association.\n\nThe Petty legacy will be well-represented on-track in the Clean Harbors 250, with Richard Petty\'s grandson Thad Moffitt driving the No. 46 Young\'s Motorsports Chevrolet Silverado RST.', 'source': {'uri': 'richmond.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Richmond Times-Dispatch'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@richmond.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/richmond.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/21/92110470-443f-11ef-93bb-079899de25cd/6697c9b9b11c8.preview.jpg?crop=727%2C382%2C4%2C53&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.4823529411764707, 'wgt': 458921024, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '2024-07-424888383', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '13:55:56', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T13:55:56Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T12:11:08Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.thenationalherald.com/they-fled-from-their-home-countries-now-theyll-compete-in-paris-for-the-refugee-olympic-team/', 'title': "They Fled from Their Home Countries. Now, They'll Compete in Paris for the Refugee Olympic Team", 'body': 'They compete under the same flag but speak different languages and come from different parts of the world. After fleeing war and persecution at home, 37 athletes from 11 countries will compete in the Paris Games as part of the Refugee Olympic Team.\n\nThe team was created for the Rio Olympics in 2016 as a symbol of hope and to call attention to the plight of refugees worldwide.\n\nIn Paris, the refugee athletes will take the stage at a time of record global migration, with hundreds of millions of people -- many of them displaced from their homes -- working to reinvent themselves just as these athletes have.\n\nThe record migration comes alongside a rise in far-right populism across much of the world, with officials and parties in many countries promising to clamp down on immigration and asylum.\n\nAt the Games, athletes will compete in a host country where the anti-immigration far-right party saw a surge of voter support in parliamentary elections, but was beaten back by a coalition of the French left and failed to win a majority.\n\nThe refugee athletes will compete in 12 sports, but for many, their journey to Paris is already a victory in itself.\n\nFernando Dayán Jorge, Cuban, canoeing\n\nFernando Dayán Jorge spent his childhood flying past rickety fishing boats and colonial houses in the bay next to his home in Cienfuegos, Cuba.\n\nSince he began practicing there with his father when he was 11, he said it feels as if he\'s lived a thousand lifetimes.\n\nThe 25-year-old canoeist was a two-time Olympian for Cuba\'s national team in Rio de Janeiro and Tokyo. Then, a gold medalist. A deserter of the Cuban team. A migrant. A maintenance worker. And a refugee.\n\nNow, he continues to rocket along on his narrow red-and-white canoe, this time flying past suburban homes in the canals winding through Cape Coral, Florida.\n\nKneeling on his boat, his oar slices through the air as his coach chants "very good work, very good work" from a boat next to him.\n\nJorge\'s eyes are fixed ahead, throwing all his force into his third Olympics.\n\n"After having written off the 2024 Paris Olympics, it\'s a massive opportunity," he said. "There are so many Cubans that come to this country and lose this dream of competing once again, simply because they don\'t know how to get back to this place."\n\nJorge was at the top of his career, having won gold in Tokyo for the 1,000-meter canoe sprint, when he took a daunting step in March 2021. While training in Mexico, Jorge defected, joining a growing number of Cuban athletes in deserting their country amid an ongoing migratory flight.\n\nSome hope to make more money than they can in the communist-run island. Others, like Jorge, say they left because of political differences over how the government treats citizens and athletes.\n\nHe left behind his home and crossed into the United States via the Rio Grande, in hopes of a better -- if uncertain -- life.\n\nArriving to Florida was, in some ways, like starting from scratch. Granted refugee status in the U.S., Jorge said he would wake up hours before sunrise to train, then work eight hours in a maintenance gig to pay his bills.\n\nHe said he watched friends forced to give up everything after migrating, but he fought to continue as a professional athlete.\n\n"I had a hard time getting out of bed every day and keeping my head on straight," he said. "I had no support whatsoever."\n\nBecoming one of the first Cubans to compete on the Refugee Olympic Team changed everything for him, he said. Still, he is among those who\'ve struggled to cover the costs of competing internationally. He opened a GoFundMe page in June to help pay his way to the Games.\n\nCuba has protested the inclusion of Jorge and Cuban weightlifter Ramiro Mora on the team, saying they should not be considered refugees.\n\nToday, Jorge\'s life in Cuba and his future in Florida seem to blend together in his home. His red, blue and white Cuba jersey sits framed over his doorway, while medals from competitions in the U.S. hang over a statue of the Olympic emblem.\n\n"To the refugees and athletes who\'ve been through the same thing, I want to tell them to not give up," he said. "No matter how dark the days become, the sun is always going to rise."\n\nManizha Talash, Afghan, breaking\n\nManizha Talash does not fear the Taliban.\n\n"I\'m here because I want to reach my dream. Not because I\'m scared," she declared from Spain, where she was granted asylum.\n\nOn the outskirts of Madrid, the 21-year-old is training hard for the Games, which for the first time will include breaking, or, as it\'s popularly known, breakdancing. Talash prances and swivels on her hands and feet to the beat of hip-hop, swooshing her black and red hair around before striking a pose signaling the end of her performance.\n\nJust months ago, she was working in a hair salon in the town of Huesca. Talash was among hundreds of Afghans brought to Spain aboard military planes following the return of the Taliban to power in August 2021.\n\nTalash first came across breaking at age 17. She saw a social media video of a man spinning on his head and was skeptical -- it must have been fake, generated by AI, she thought. But the images were real, and she said she soon became obsessed with the sport, scrolling through video after video on her phone.\n\n"I wanted to do it, I wanted to learn it," she said.\n\nShe found a club in Kabul where a dancer from the videos trained and knocked at the door. "There were 55 boys, and I was the only girl," she said. "I told myself, why can\'t a girl do this?"\n\nBreaking in some ways freed her from the problems facing young women in Afghanistan. But it wasn\'t long before Talash was noticed -- international news outlets published stories about the young Afghan woman defying cultural and religious norms. That was enough to become a target.\n\n"The Taliban don\'t like it when a girl dances," she said, even though breaking is more than that -- it\'s a sport.\n\nHer club began receiving threats, Talash said, and one day, when a bomb hit very close, local police asked them to shut down over the dangers.\n\nShe trained behind closed doors in her home until the Taliban\'s return to power. Despite initial promises that women\'s rights wouldn\'t be curtailed, women have since been barred from studying and face several restrictions on employment, travel and health.\n\n"Now, girls can\'t do anything," Talash said.\n\nShe\'s had little time to train while adapting to a foreign country, and at some points, competing in the Games seemed unfathomable.\n\n"But when my friend told me I could join the refugee team, I was so happy," Talash said. "I can now fly."\n\nMohammad Amin Alsalami, Syrian, athletics\n\nWhen Mohammad Amin Alsalami arrived in Berlin in October 2015, he was cold, lonely and homesick.\n\nThe Syrian refugee had left behind his war-torn hometown of Aleppo, fled to Turkey, crossed the Mediterranean on a rubber boat to Greece, and trekked by foot to Germany. Like millions of other migrants, he was in search of a place where he could build a future without bombs and violence.\n\nAlmost a decade later, Alsalami, 29, has been granted asylum, learned German and made new friends. And he\'s living his dream of becoming a world-class athlete.\n\nHe learned just months ago that he got the green light to participate in the Paris Games.\n\n"That moment was so wow," he said. "I get to go to the Olympics. I cried so much. It was really cool."\n\nAlsalami discovered his passion for athletics during physical education in school at age 15. A teacher noticed his talent for long jump and pushed him to participate in local and national competitions in Syria. But when civil war erupted, he could no longer practice. His family -- he\'s the youngest of nine siblings and comes from a family of tailors -- was displaced several times within Syria, then fled to Turkey. Alsalami decided to continue on to Europe on his own.\n\nHe credits his passion for athletics with getting him through the initial hardships in his new country.\n\nDuring the first weeks in Berlin, he looked up different stadiums and gyms on Google maps so he could start practicing long jump again. He remembers walking through the first snow to finally discover one of the city\'s big indoor gymnasiums.\n\n"All the other Berlin track and field athletes were training in this hall," he said. "When I came in and saw how full and how warm it was inside ... it was almost like paradise for me."\n\nOn that first day, a man watched him jump, approached him and asked something in German.\n\n"I didn\'t understand anything, not in English either," Alsalami said. "And then I said \'Hey, I\'m Syrian\' on my cellphone, and he said \'I\'m your trainer from now on.\'"\n\nHe stayed with that first coach for five years, then moved on to a different one -- and said he\'s eternally grateful to both for their support.\n\nDespite his excitement for the Games, Alsalami admits he\'s a bit sad that he can\'t represent his home country.\n\n"Syria is home, I miss it every day," he said. "In the end, that\'s my country, that\'s where I come from."\n\nIman Mahdavi, Iranian, wrestling\n\nIman Mahdavi smiles and dishes up Iranian food that he\'s cooked himself at his Milan home.\n\n"If my mum could see me now," he said with a laugh. "She wouldn\'t believe it."\n\nMahdavi hasn\'t seen his mother since October 2020, when the Iranian wrestler fled his home country over fears for his life.\n\nWith only the clothes he was wearing, Mahdavi made a harrowing journey by foot from Iran to Turkey, then flew to Italy and applied for asylum.\n\n"I didn\'t even really know where I was flying to," said Mahdavi, 29. "Luckily for me, it was Italy."\n\nOnce he was granted asylum, one of Mahdavi\'s first aims was to continue wrestling. His father, once a wrestler himself, had instilled in his son a passion. Mahdavi became a seven-time national junior champion and won more than 50 medals.\n\nThrough a friend he connected with on Instagram, Mahdavi was introduced to a gym on the outskirts of Milan.\n\n"As soon as we had him in the gym, in his first training sessions, we immediately saw that he was an extraordinary athlete, that he was a very, very high-level wrestler," said Giuseppe Gammarota, president of Lotta Club Seggiano. "We immediately started preparing him for competitions."\n\nThe gym has become like family to him -- so much so that he calls his coach, Marco Moroni, "Papi."\n\nMahdavi said his real father died of a heart attack several years ago after being mistakenly told his son died in a car crash.\n\nIt was Moroni who helped Mahdavi find a job, as a nightclub bouncer.\n\nMahdavi admits the schedule can be tough: He works from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m., goes home to sleep, then trains every day. But he has a focus that drives him.\n\n"The Olympics is a dream for any athlete who does any sport," he said. "I hope to come back from the Olympics with the best colored medal I can get. And I will also be thinking about the next Olympics, hoping I\'m still in form."\n\n___\n\nBy MEGAN JANETSKY, RENATA BRITO, KIRSTEN GRIESHABER and DANIELLA MATAR Associated Press\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists Rebecca Blackwell and Daniel Kozin in Cape Coral, Florida, and Iain Sullivan in Madrid contributed to this report.', 'source': {'uri': 'thenationalherald.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The National Herald'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'achilleas_kouremenos@thenationalherald.com', 'name': 'Achilleas Kouremenos', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.thenationalherald.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/AP24191829657160-scaled.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.05098039215686279, 'wgt': 458920556, 'relevance': 7}
{'uri': '2024-07-424877248', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '13:46:16', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T13:46:16Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T13:00:12Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://gamerant.com/once-human-what-are-seasons-explained/', 'title': 'Once Human: Seasons Explained', 'body': 'Once Human: Explore East Blackfell Junction Guide (Elite Enemy, Mystical, Weapon, and Armor Crate Locations)\n\nIn a Post-Apocalyptic World, players assume the role of a meta-human and search for resources necessary for their survival in Once Human. One unique aspect of this game is its seasonal changes, which add a challenging twist.\n\nAs you near the end of the game on one server, you\'ll find yourself battling against a fixed time limit. This is due to the game\'s seasonal changes that occur after a set period, which may be confusing for beginners. Luckily, this guide explains everything you\'ll need to know.\n\nRelated\n\nOnce Human: How To Get The Chefosaurus Deviant\n\nYou can get your very own dino chef in Once Human by catching a Chefosaurus, one of the many friendly deviants you can capture in the game.\n\nSeasons Explained\n\nThe servers for Once Human operate on a seasonal basis, with a new season called a Scenario arriving every six weeks. These Scenarios introduce new missions, game modes, and events, keeping the gameplay fresh and engaging.\n\nWith the change of every season, your character carries over most of their resources from the preceding season into the Eternal Land. This place acts as a storage unit for your currencies and account progression. However, a few things such as the gear, and unlocked memetics won\'t carry over to the next season.\n\nYou can unlock these by completing quests again.\n\nDuring your stay in Eternal Land, you can build structures to showcase your achievements. These structures can be saved as blueprints and carried over to the next season. You can copy and transfer them to the next season instead of building them from scratch.\n\nItems That Will Carry Forward\n\nHere is a list of items that will carry to the next season:\n\nCurrency\n\nAll the important currencies such as Stellar Planula, Crystgins, and Sproulets will transfer to the next season.\n\nFurniture Formulas\n\nThe furniture unlocks from the storage crates and the rest of the item pick-ups will be carried to the next season.\n\nBlueprints\n\nGear blueprints in your inventory will carry forward in the next season.\n\nCosmetics\n\nItems such as Expressions, Namecards, and Poses.\n\nFriends List\n\nAll the friends you\'ve made during your stay on one server will carry forward to the next. You can view the players that have joined your Warband in the preceding seasons.\n\nProgress\n\nThe Task Progress from the main story and a few side quests are carried over to the next season.\n\nEvery season the Map Progress resets too, meaning you\'ll need to hustle again for the Rift Points.\n\nThere is a small chance your guns and ammo will be transferred to the next season.\n\nLongevity Of Seasons\n\nEach season has an average lifespan of six weeks. Every new Scenario will be readily available once the timer for the previous season expires. You can view the "Season Scenario" to understand the amount of time you have left in the Battle Pass.\n\nOnce Human\n\nSystem PC , Mobile , Google , Apple\n\nPlatform(s) PC , Android , iOS\n\nReleased July 9, 2024\n\nDeveloper(s) Starry Studio\n\nPublisher(s) Starry Studio , NetEase, Inc.', 'source': {'uri': 'gamerant.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Game Rant'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'usama_ali@gamerant.com', 'name': 'Usama Ali', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static0.gamerantimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/once-human-seasons-explained.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.003921568627450966, 'wgt': 458919976, 'relevance': 4}

{'uri': '8230043983', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '13:04:32', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T13:04:32Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T13:04:12Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://napavalleyregister.com/sports/napa-american-little-league-mill-valley-section-1-tournament/article_d4561ed2-4427-11ef-8d52-d36a3a1c08fc.html', 'title': 'Section 1 Little League 10-12 All-Star Baseball: Napa American tops Mill Valley to win title', 'body': 'The Napa American 10-12 All-Stars, right, and Mill Valley tell each other "good game" after playing one for the Section 1 title Tuesday night in Dixon.\n\nAndy Wilcox\n\nDIXON -- Trailing by a run after being held to four hits in the first four innings, the Napa American Little League 10-12 All-Stars got its bats going and rallied past Mill Valley, 6-3, to win the Section 1 Tournament on Tuesday night at Hall Memorial Park.\n\nNapa American (7-0) moves on to the Northern California Tournament in Madera, where it will take on Section 7 champion Madera in the first round at 1:30 p.m. Saturday. Madera is on Highway 99 just northeast of Fresno.\n\n"It\'s about three hours away," Napa American manager Tanner Bushby said. "But this hasn\'t happened in a while for Napa, so we\'re super happy to do this for Napa."\n\nDistrict 3 champion Mill Valley had to play all five days of the tournament after losing to District 4\'s Alameda in Friday\'s first round. After beating Vacaville National on Saturday, Mill Valley avenged the loss to Alameda on Sunday and knocked off Petaluma American on Monday to complete its climb to the championship game.\n\nPeople are also reading... $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Ryan Seacrest\'s Napa County home up for sale at $22 million Customers are raving about Moulin -- downtown Napa\'s new café and bakery Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 Letter: Concerns about St. Helena Agritourism Initiative Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Napa City Council to weigh selling land for downtown development Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life Why is that? Here\'s the lowdown on some Napa head-scratchers Napa County, Hoopes winery file closing arguments in legal clash St. Helena Cyclery to reopen in wake of Trek\'s closure Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Fight between Le Petit Elephant and Alta Heights neighbors gets personal Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive Defendants in Napa double murder delay pleas to Sept. 17\n\nRiding a head of steam, Mill Valley sat Napa American down 1-2-3 in the top of the first inning and took a 2-0 lead in the bottom half. Usually dominant Napa American pitcher Landon Houle gave up singles to the first two batters, who both scored, and hit the third batter before retiring the next three. He had another shaky start in the second, allowing a walk and base hit to the first two batters before stranding both.\n\nNapa American got on the board in the second when Jake Tarap (2 for 2) walked and scored on a double by Will Wittmann (1 for 1, two walks, run scored). It tied the score at 2-2 in the fourth, when with two out Cordero Ochoa doubled and scored on a Tarap single.\n\nAfter Mill Valley went down 1-2-3 in the third.\n\nMill Valley went back ahead in the fourth, 3-2, by getting a run with three straight two-out hits. But Napa American knotted things up once again in the fifth, 3-3, when Lucas Wedding, Easton Hardy, Houle, Andrew Keller (2 for 2) and Jam Jam Duhig strung together five consecutive hits. Their team got only one run out of the barrage, however, because Mill Valley threw out two runners trying to score.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nBut Napa American took the lead for good with a three-spot in the top of the sixth. Brayden Bushby walked and was nabbed trying to advance to third base. But Ochoa singled and scored on a single by Tarap, who was thrown out at the plate for the second out. Wittmann walked and Jamie McWilliams singled, both scoring. Brix Leach singled and made his way around the bases before getting thrown out at the plate.\n\nMill Valley didn\'t make Bushby\'s save easy. Relieving Houle to start the sixth, he gave up a leadoff double. The next two batters were retired, including one by left fielder Talon Harley\'s long throw to first in time. A single put runners at the corners with the batter representing the tying run. But Bushby got the next batter to pop up to shortstop Leach to end the game.\n\n"I could feel a little pressure, the boys could feel a little pressure, but the end result was they pushed through. It\'s one of those things where they\'ve been behind before, and they kept their heads, they were level-headed, and they pushed through. We got to the sixth inning and back to the top of the order. We got a walk from Brayden and then we just kept hammering, base hit after base hit. They just got after it."\n\nHoule gave up five earned runs on seven hits, four strikeouts, one walk and one hit batter.\n\nWittman led the way in Sunday\'s 7-2 win over Petaluma National in the winners-bracket final. He pitched the first 5 1/3 innings and allowed three hits and two runs while striking out eight, before Leach came in to get the last two outs. Wittmann also went 2 for 2 at the plate with a solo homer, five total bases, an RBI, a walk and two runs scored.\n\n"Will really carried the team on the mound and got us on the board in the second inning with a monstrous home run to left field," Coach Bushby said. "Our defense had zero errors, which helped us keep Will in the game. It\'s such a huge thing to keep your pitch count down in tournament play and have your defense behind you. Will\'s velo was up and he kept pounding the zone. We are playing with a lot of confidence right now defensively and at the plate."\n\nOchoa was 2 for 2 with a walk, three stolen bases and two runs scored, Harley 2 for 3 with two runs scored, and Brayden Bushby 1 for 3 with a run scored. McWilliams walked and had two RBI.\n\n"Their pitcher had some good off-speed, but we were still able to make some good contact and put the ball in play. They just seemed to always find a defender," Coach Bushby said. "We had to manufacture a few runs with some small ball and being aggressive on the basepaths."\n\nDave Mosher contributed to this report.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. A total of 11 applied for the scholarships, which are either $600 or $500. The $600 scholarships are for the children or grandchildren of club members, while the $500 scholarships are for students outside of the club.\n\nThree of the nine recipients are children or grandchildren of Cool Spring Ruritan Club members and received the $600 award. Jana Whicker, daughter of member Jeff Whicker, and a student at Appalachian State University; Dakota York, grandson of Andy Tomlin; and Timber Hobbs, daughter of Billy Hobbs, received the $600 checks. Timber Hobbs attends Western Carolina University and York will be attending Mitchell Community College.\n\nPeople are also reading... Hobbs, Ferrum College of Virginia; Mallory Kiser, Ferrum College of Virginia; Logan B. Lambert, MCC; Jacob Lister, Western Carolina; and Addison Reavis, Forsyth Tech Community College.\n\nBilly Hobbs, past president of the club, said the money for scholarships is the result of fundraisers the club holds throughout the year, including a chicken barbecue dinner. He said members get to the club building on Old Mocksville Road around 4 a.m. to cook the chicken and get things ready for the fundraiser, and then stay throughout the day selling the dinners and taking in the money.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nHe told the students and their families at the club\'s meeting Monday that scholarship money is thanks to the men and women who give of their time and talents to raise the funds. Hobbs said that while the club was not able to fund all of the applications they hope to be able to do so in the future.\n\nDebbie Davis, past director of National Ruritan, encouraged the students to make the most of this opportunity. "Be the best you are capable of being," she said. The awarding of the scholarships, she said, shows the club believes in the students and in their potential.\n\nThree of the students were not able to attend the meeting but the mother of one, Timber Hobbs, said the money is appreciated. "We are grateful for the money and I know she is too," Kelly Hobbs said.\n\nLong-time member Roy Lazenby said giving out the scholarships is what Ruritan is all about. "It\'s all about giving," he said.\n\nWith this year\'s scholarships handed out, the Ruritan Club isn\'t taking time to rest before starting the fundraising efforts for next year\'s batch.\n\nThe first fundraiser planned is on Aug. 3 when the club will host a yard sale beginning at 7 a.m. Twenty spots are available for anyone wishing to sell items. To reserve a spot, call 704-437-1062. Anyone wishing to donate items for the yard sale can call 704-437-1062. Breakfast and lunch will be sold by the Ruritan Club.\n\nThe club\'s annual Community Day at Cool Spring Elementary School will be Sept. 14 from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. The guest speaker will be Robin Davenport, Ruritan National 2024 president.\n\nAnd they will be cooking and serving chicken again on Oct. 12. All proceeds will benefit the scholarship fund. Now, I truly hate him -- but I don\'t show it," O\'Reilly joked.\n\n"But you hold it very well," Stewart said.\n\nThere was only one topic to talk about Tuesday: the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, the motive of which is still unknown.\n\nO\'Reilly called for calm, criticizing some, including a TV talk show, for what he said was emphasizing the fact that the alleged shooter was a registered Republican, to which Stewart pushed back.\n\n"You and I are both somewhat fossilized practitioners of the rhetorical arts that are confrontational at times, provocative at times," Stewart said. "And we made a really spectacular living pushing those envelopes."\n\nStewart and O\'Reilly have a history of on-air conflict, mirroring two opposite viewpoints, with O\'Reilly the conservative foil to Stewart, and vice versa.\n\nO\'Reilly last appeared on "The Daily Show" in 2014, when the two got into an animated discussion about race and white privilege. The pair previously had a 2012 charity debate dubbed "The Rumble in the Air-Conditioned Auditorium."\n\nStewart left "The Daily Show" in 2015. O\'Reilly was dismissed by Fox in 2017 amid claims of sexual harassment. He denied the claims.\n\nStewart returned to "The Daily Show" this year to host Mondays only, with plans to host that night through the 2024 election.\n\n"The Daily Show" had been planned to be live from Milwaukee, where the Republican National Convention is being held, but stepped-up security following the attempted assassination of the former president meant there was no possibility of a live audience, Stewart said. Instead, it was moved to New York and there was no show Monday.\n\nStewart and O\'Reilly showed much of the same somewhat friendly back-and-forth Tuesday as they did in 2014.\n\nAfter O\'Reilly, who has written books about the assassinations of presidents, said that all of the assassins or would-be assassins in American history have been mentally ill, Stewart brought up President Abraham Lincoln\'s killer John Wilkes Booth.\n\n"Well, John Wilkes Booth was a fanatical conservative and racist who hated Lincoln," O\'Reilly began.\n\n"Good thing that\'s gone out of the country," Stewart joked, in one of the bigger laughs from the crowd in the interview.\n\nStewart opened Tuesday\'s show by mocking conspiratorial takes on X in the wake of the shooting. But in a serious moment, he admitted to searching social media after shocking acts of public violence, in part for personal and political reasons.\n\n"It\'s this pattern I feel like we now have in the country when we hear about a horrific event. You\'re on pins and needles in this sort of reverse demographic lottery to make sure that the psychopathic shooter doesn\'t belong to one of your teams," Stewart said.\n\n"And we\'re all doing it. We\'re all doing it," he said. "Because we have to know what our posture will be on the tragedy: Will it be a haughty \'I told you,\' or perhaps a circumspect, \'Oh, let\'s not rush to judgment. We shouldn\'t generalize.\'"\n\n"And then it ends up being someone we can\'t even f------ figure out in the first place," he said.', 'source': {'uri': 'aol.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Aol'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'phil_helsel@aol.com', 'name': 'Phil Helsel', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/.pxiZP4As35Kg00Sf.qOsQ--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTEyMDA7aD04MDE-/https://media.zenfs.com/en/aol_nbc_universal_184/1ff4a8c5c2bcbb9ca2a1b79e86cbe200', 'eventUri': 'eng-9738195', 'sentiment': -0.01960784313725494, 'wgt': 458915755, 'relevance': 55}

{'uri': '8229927243', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '11:55:05', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T11:55:05Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T11:54:14Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://qctimes.com/news/local/weather/moline-quad-cities-rock-river-flooding-mississippi-davenport/article_87b4cb80-437f-11ef-87cf-fb3ada0cf28d.html', 'title': 'Rock River to flood as Mississippi continues to fall in the Quad-Cities', 'body': 'A timelapse showing the detours to get to downtown Davenport. Flooding on River Drive has closed portions along the East Village and near the YMCA/Quad-City Times Building to Centennial Bridge.\n\nHeavy rain from recent storms is expected to cause major flooding on the Rock River later this week.\n\nThe storm that passed through the area Sunday evening dropped rain all throughout the Rock River Basin, up to the headwaters in Wisconsin, said Matt Wilson, a Senior Service Hydrologist with the Quad-Cities forecast office for the National Weather Service.\n\nThe water-saturated ground was hit by a second storm Monday evening, draining more water into the river.\n\nThe river is expected to reach major flood stage by Friday at the Joslin and Moline gauges and begin to fall Saturday morning.\n\nAs of 12:45 p.m. Tuesday, the Joslin National Weather Service gauge measured the Rock River at 13.95 feet, just .05 feet below "moderate" flood stage. That gauge is expected to reach 16.7 feet by Friday morning, which would upgrade the flood stage from "moderate" to "major."\n\nPeople are also reading... El Compita in Davenport ordered to pay nearly $50,000 in back wages, damages to workers John Deere will lay off an undetermined number of salaried workers beginning next week Quad-Cities weather updates: National Weather Service confirms EF-1 tornado from Monday Iowa restaurant inspection update: Grimy blenders, mouse droppings and bad sushi NEW DETAILS: John Deere announces another 345 layoffs at Waterloo facilities Davenport interim city administrator to leave job in August for private sector 7 Quad Cities restaurants that opened in June An early look at Davenport\'s plans for Main Street Landing One dead in shooting in Hudson Beat the Elite runners to start at 2 mile mark in Quad-City Times Bix 7 WATCH LIVE TONIGHT: Republican National Convention continues in Milwaukee Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Quad-Cities business openings, closings: Scooter\'s Coffee, Hungry Haven food truck \'The best ones that are made\' Standard Byke Company leads the BMX industry for 33 years Woman charged with abandoning infant on Davenport street\n\nAt the Moline gauge, the Rock River is expected to reach major flood stage Friday and crest at river level 14.1 feet and begin to fall Saturday morning.\n\nThe National Weather Service is still collecting information and those numbers are subject to change.\n\nRepresentatives from the city of Moline, the city of Rock Island and the village of Milan said that there isn\'t much needed from the cities to handle the projected level of flooding, beyond potentially manning pumps and closing flood gates. Ben Williamson Park off of 44th Street in Rock Island will be closed due to the level of the river, and the Harold\'s Landing boat dock in Moline is closed until further notice.\n\nAt 14 feet, water affects South Shore Drive and North Shore Drive east of the 27th Street bridge, according to the NWS. Some other roads and residences in the area along the Rock are impacted even earlier, including around Greenvalley Park.\n\nIn addition, the village of Carbon Cliff warned residents that parts of the town could start flooding at around stage 16 feet at the Joslin gauge. Residents along North First Avenue and at the entrance to East Lawn may want to consider sandbagging and other precautions, the village said in an emailed alert.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe flooding has forced the Backwater Gamblers, a water ski show team that performs on the Rock River, to cancel the past three weeks of shows.\n\n"The river is still too high to hold a safe show for you, our fans," the Backwater Gamblers posted on its Facebook page announcing the cancellation of its July 10 show.\n\nMississippi River continues to fall\n\nThe Mississippi River at Rock Island stood at about 18.7 feet Tuesday morning, down from a crest of about 20.1 feet. Forecasts from the National Water Prediction Service predict river levels to fall below 17 feet on Sunday.\n\nDavenport on Monday reopened River Drive at Mound Street near the Village of East Davenport, alleviating detour pressures on motorists, and disassembled some of its sand-filled HESCO barriers downtown.\n\nRiver\'s Edge, 700 W River Dr., a city-owned ice skating rink and recreation center, reopened to the public on Tuesday.\n\nThe Freight House Farmers Market will be held one more weekend at the Scott County Administrative building July 20-21 as floodwaters recede and the Freight House parking lot can be cleaned. The market will be back to its usual spot on July 27.\n\nThe Davenport Compost Facility has reopened. Residents can access the facility by traveling Rockingham/Hwy 22 to Wapello Avenue to Railroad Street.\n\nPhotos: See images of the rising Mississippi River and flood preparations 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nLocal Weather\n\nGet the daily forecast and severe weather alerts in your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. The network plans to broadcast the event across 17 channels, offering more live Olympic coverage than any other television network worldwide.\n\nThe Olympic Games, featuring around 10,500 athletes from 206 countries, will be extensively covered by BeIN Sports, providing nearly 100% live coverage of the events. Special attention will be given to Arab athletes participating in the Games, reflecting the numerous qualifiers from the MENA region.\n\nBeIN\'s pre-event coverage begins on July 19 with a nightly preview show, Welcome to Paris, airing at 22:30 MECCA on BeIN Sports 1. Live coverage of preliminary football matches, including teams from Morocco, Egypt and Iraq, as well as rugby sevens events, will start on July 24. The Opening Ceremony on July 26 will be broadcast live at 20:30 MECCA.\n\nFrom July 27, all Olympic events will be broadcast live across 17 dedicated BeIN Sports channels, with commentary available in both Arabic and English. The main Arabic studio coverage will run for 14 hours daily from 10:00 to 00:00 MECCA, followed by a Daily Highlights programme in both languages. Premium events will be available on BeIN\'s 4K Olympic channel, the only 4K sports channel in the region.\n\nBeIN\'s coverage will feature more than 65 regional and international pundits, including 10 on-the-ground reporters in Paris and 42 expert Arabic commentators. The team will provide real-time updates and in-depth analysis in both Arabic and English.\n\nThe coverage will also include expert studio analysis from a distinguished panel of over 10 world-class analysts, including Oussama Mellouli, a three-time Olympic medalist, Inès Boubakri, a Rio 2016 bronze medalist, and Ahmad Abughaush, Jordan\'s first Olympic medalist. The Arabic coverage will be anchored by presenters such as Asya Abdullah, Jamal Alhasni, Areej Sleem, Mohammad Kidan, Jehad Yousef, Hala Mashharawi and Shaima Alhammadi.\n\nSpeaking about the Olympic coverage, Mohammed Al-Bader, Managing Director of beIN Channels - MENA, said: "We are thrilled to provide extensive coverage of the Olympic Games Paris 2024 to the MENA region. BeIN Sports continues to be the premier platform for showcasing the world\'s biggest sporting events to our audience. With state-of-the-art world-class studios complete with Virtual and Augmented Reality technologies, and a talented team of analysts, presenters, reporters and commentators, we are fully prepared to deliver an exceptional viewing experience for this landmark event in the international sporting landscape and ensuring viewers across the region don\'t miss a moment of the action."\n\nTo complement the live broadcasts, BeIN Sports has produced several original docuseries. These include Do You Know "Olympics", premiering on July 21, which explores various Olympic topics. Other beIN originals include Qatari Athletes, Road to Paris 2024, highlighting the inspiring stories of Qatari Athletes, Olympic History and Records, featuring exclusive interviews with Arab athletes, and Iraq U23 Road to Paris 2024, Egypt U23 Road to Paris 2024 highlighting each country\'s national football team\'s Olympic path. Post-games, a special documentary, Best of Paris 2024, will air on 18 August.\n\nBeIN Sports\' digital coverage will feature a 10-day countdown on social media, highlighting Arab countries and athletes, a Google One-box with medal counts, dedicated playlists on YouTube and Facebook, daily interactive polls, and a dedicated page on the BeIN Sports website in both Arabic and English.\n\nTo ensure accessibility, BeIN Sports will offer 400 hours of free-to-air coverage across its platforms, including live Olympic events. BeIN Sports XTRA 1 and XTRA 2 will provide complimentary access to Olympic content, and a daily Olympics studio show will be available on the free-to-air BeIN Sports channel. {'uri': '8229900837', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '11:37:17', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T11:37:17Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T11:36:19Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.6941176652908325, 'url': 'https://www.wired.com/story/paris-olympics-broadcast-tech-ai/', 'title': 'The Paris Olympics Will Show Us the Future of Sports on TV', 'body': 'This summer\'s Games are going to look bigger and better and louder than ever, thanks to key innovations in the broadcast booth and in the cloud.\n\nThe 2024 Paris Summer Olympics kick off on July 26 and go until August 11. Hundreds of events will take place over the course of a few weeks, many of them occurring simultaneously. It\'s a lot for any sports fan to keep up with. And this year, there are more places than ever to watch.\n\nIn the past, Olympics broadcasts have floundered when trying to satisfy audiences. NBC, the main broadcaster of the Olympics in the US, has gotten flak for its programming strategy during Games past by spreading the events out over too many TV channels and delaying some coverage until prime time instead of presenting the Games the way most people prefer to watch their sports: live. But this time, NBC and other broadcasters seem eager to make it much easier to find what you want to see, when you want to see it.\n\nOnline platforms are going for the gold this year as well. TikTok has an Olympics hub. In the weeks leading up tot the Games, the Instagram account @olympics has been posting training videos and action stills to its 8.2 million followers. NBC is partnering with creators across social media to cover events and to spin up content from Paris. Google will showcase live scores, medal ceremonies, and highlights within search results and inside the answers to queries handled by its Assistant. It\'s a full buffet.\n\n"We are going through a period where one of the most interesting, but to some extent also problematic, elements is the extreme segmentation of the audience," says Yiannis Exarchos, the CEO of the Olympic Broadcasting Service, the organization that produces and manages media output for the Olympics. "You have audiences all over the place, consuming content in different ways, and there are very few opportunities where you can really bring together large audiences."\n\nThe Olympics, he says, is one of those opportunities. The biggest change to Olympics coverage is that there is simply going to be much more of it. The total run time of the various competitions in the Olympic games will clock in at around 3,800 hours. The OBS plans to turn that into more than 11,000 hours of content -- a mixture of live coverage, behind-the-scenes features, narrated analysis, and highlights.\n\nAnyone tuning in will need a way to sift through it all. NBC wants to make that easier on its Peacock streaming platform and has debuted a bunch of new viewing options that will let users curate their own Olympics coverage, in addition streaming nearly every event live from the Olympics and the Paralympics. (The Paralympics, also taking place in Paris, start on August 28.)\n\nIn the Peacock Olympics hub, viewers can sort listings by sport, athlete, or country to find the events they want to watch and then add them to a watch list. This lets viewers create their own schedule to watch events live, as well as a place where they can come back to watch their chosen events later. Viewers can also watch up to four live events on the same screen using a new Multiview tool that makes it easy to flip between concurrent events.', 'source': {'uri': 'wired.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Wired'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'conde_nast@wired.com', 'name': 'Condé Nast', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': "https://media.wired.com/photos/6696dc2b6a7bb10e67ef7e43/191:100/w_1280,c_limit/This-Year's-Olympics-Broadcast-Will-Have-Crazy-Tech,-More-Drones,-and-Gobs-of-AI-GettyImages-2160036174.jpg?mbid=social_retweet", 'eventUri': 'eng-9739975', 'sentiment': 0.2470588235294118, 'wgt': 458912237, 'relevance': 51}

The Guerrilla 450 is the company's new street naked motorcycle and this is the first time that they've forayed in the sub-500cc segment with this bike.\n\nThe design of the Royal Enfield Guerrilla 450, to begin with, is like the quintessential modern-retro motorcycle. You've got a round LED headlight, a 11-litre, teardrop shaped fuel tank and relatively slim tail section. There's a single-piece seat and a tubular grab handle for the pillion that's neatly integrated. On the whole the bike looks good and it comes in a variety of colours, some of which are quite bold.\n\nThe colours are segregated as per the variants- Flash, Dash and Analogue. The Flash variant gets the Brava Blue and Yellow Ribbon colours. The Dash variant comprises the Gold Dip and Playa Black while under Analogue you've got Smoke and Playa Black.\n\nPowering the bike is a 452cc, single-cylinder engine that makes 39.50bhp at 8,000rpm and 40Nm at 5,500rpm. It is paired with a six-speed gearbox.\n\nMoving on to the hardware, the Guerrilla 450 has a steel tubular frame that uses the engine as a stressed member. The frame is suspended by a 43mm telescopic fork with 140m travel and a preload adjustable monoshock with 150mm wheel travel. The bike rides on 17-inch wheels with a 120-section tyre at the front and a fat, 160-section tyre at the rear. These are Ceat Gripp XL tyres.\n\nBraking duties are taken care of by a 310mm disc at the front with a dual piston caliper while at the rear, there is a 270mm disc with a single-piston caliper. Dual-channel ABS is standard.\n\nThe Guerrilla 450 has a long wheelbase, at 1440mm while the ground clearance stands at 169mm. Its kerb weight is 185kg which is heavier than the competition like the Triumph Speed 400.\n\nAs for the features, the bike has all LED lights. The top variant gets the Himalayan's colour, TFT display with Bluetooth connectivity and Google based navigation. It gets the same ride modes as well. The base variant, on the other hand, has a analouge-digital instrument cluster with an optional Tripper navigation pod.\n\nWhile the Analogue variant, as we've mentioned, is priced at Rs 2.39 lakh, the mid-spec, Dash variant costs Rs 2.49 lakh, ex-showroom. The Flash variant, meanwhile, will set you back by Rs 2.54 lakh, ex-showroom.\n\nThe bike goes up against the the Triumph Speed 400 and Hero Mavrick 440.", 'source': {'uri': 'bikewale.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'bikewale.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'rishabh_bhaskar@bikewale.com', 'name': 'Rishabh Bhaskar', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://imgd.aeplcdn.com/642x336/n/cw/ec/182233/royalenfield-guerrilla-450-right-side-view6.jpeg?isig=0&q=80', 'eventUri': 'eng-9739554', 'sentiment': 0.1686274509803922, 'wgt': 458911607, 'relevance': 5}

It just will take place a few miles east of the original site, along the Bettendorf bike path.\n\n"We came up with the idea of this Senior Bix so we can include a lot of people that are getting older and can\'t run the whole race,\'\' said former Bix 7 race director Ed Froehlich, who is helping to plan the 50th anniversary festivities. Speaking, with Joe La Puma, Ronaldinho talked about his first time meeting Michael Jordan for the first time. Ronaldinho shared that he met MJ in Barcelona, and Jordan gave him a special one-of-one version of Jordan PE. Ronaldinho called Jordan one of the greatest people he ever met and noted he still has the shoes.\n\nJoe La Puma: "Another meeting, 2006. Very jealous. Barcelona, you meet Michael Jordan. He laces you with these Jordan 21 PEs with the R10 on them. What was that meeting like and where are those shoes now?"\n\nRonaldinho: "That was special. Being with Jordan is always a special time. They\'re safely kept in my house."\n\n2:28 onwards\n\nBoth Ronaldinho and Michael Jordan are two massive icons, not just in their respective sports, but in global pop culture. Ronaldinho is considered one of the greatest soccer players of all time and has won all the major tournaments possible in his career, including the World Cup, the Copa America, and the UEFA Champions League.\n\nAs for Michael Jordan, many in the world consider him the greatest basketball player of all time. Jordan dominated during his time in the NBA, winning 6 NBA championships and Finals MVP, 5 regular season MVPs, 1 Defensive Player of the Year award, along with 14 All-Star selections, 11 All-NBA selections, and 9 All-Defensive selections.\n\nMichael Jordan Is An Enigma To The Public\n\nAnother soccer icon, Lionel Messi, called Michael Jordan the greatest athlete in history. Messi is perhaps one of the few other figures in the sports world that can claim that title for himself, but he showed the incredible amount of reverence and respect he has for Jordan by giving him that title.\n\nSo many stories fans get to hear about Michael Jordan only add to the myth and the legend surrounding His Airness. Jordan leads an incredibly private lifestyle and doesn\'t do many public appearances or interviews, so these stories are a good glimpse into the kind of person MJ is, and the kind of lifestyle he leads.\n\nRecently, an influencer shed some light on what it is like to attend a Michael Jordan party. She noted that he spares no expense, but is also incredibly selective and secretive about who gets invited and what people are able to attend.\n\nFormer Hornets star Kemba Walker told a story of why he would never gamble with Michael Jordan. Jordan is known to enjoy games of chance regularly, and Walker noted that he couldn\'t keep up with the amount of money Jordan was gambling, and didn\'t want to risk his finances just to match Jordan.\n\nMichael Jordan is unlikely to ever change his lifestyle to accommodate the media or the public. And considering the scrutiny he dealt with during his playing days, it makes sense why he shies away from the media. Till the day comes when MJ decides to address it all publically, we have to rely on these stories to know more about Michael Jordan.\n\nRelated: Ex-Player Slams LeBron For Abusing Power To Force Bronny In The NBA: "MJ Stands On Earned, Not Given"\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. We really appreciate your support.', 'source': {'uri': 'postandcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Post and Courier'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'aaditya_krishnamurthy@postandcourier.com', 'name': 'Aaditya Krishnamurthy', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/postandcourier.com/content/tncms/custom/image/6903687a-a7dc-11e9-896c-0bef6d6c9301.jpg?resize=600%2C314', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.2, 'wgt': 458911248, 'relevance': 26}
{'uri': '2024-07-424700816', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '11:13:59', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T11:13:59Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T10:07:32Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.9725490212440491, 'url': 'https://www.reuters.com/sports/olympics/paris-olympics-marketing-blitz-powered-by-female-athletes-2024-07-17/', 'title': 'Paris Olympics marketing blitz powered by female athletes', 'body': 'July 17 (Reuters) - Global advertisers are hiring more female athletes to launch marketing campaigns ahead of the Paris Summer Olympics, a move aimed at capitalizing on recent record ratings for women\'s sports in the U.S. and Europe to reach new audiences.\n\nWhile the Olympics has long been considered the pinnacle of women\'s sports, increased attention leading up to the Games has prompted more brands to feature female athletes in commercials, shape messaging toward women and increase ad spending on women\'s sports, ad experts said.\n\n"What we\'re seeing of late is an incredible aggregate of women showcasing skills and breaking records in ways that are generating so much attention," said Jenny Storms, chief marketing officer for entertainment and sports at NBCUniversal, which broadcasts the Olympics in the U.S.\n\nAdam Schwartz, director of sports media at ad-buying firm Horizon Media, said he estimates there are now double the number of brand campaigns featuring female athletes compared to previous years. "Advertisers are actively asking \'what can we do to include ourselves with women\'s events,\'" he said.\n\nAdvertiser demand for women\'s sports has grown to a point where GroupM, one of the world\'s largest ad-buying agencies, is now working with NBCUniversal to create new advertising packages that will allow some of GroupM\'s brand clients to specifically appear during women\'s Paris Olympic events, the agency told Reuters exclusively.\n\nThe fan frenzy for U.S. basketball player Caitlin Clark, whose success was credited with driving higher ratings for the women\'s college basketball championship than the men\'s for the first time, is one reason for the increased attention on women\'s sports, the ad experts said.\n\nWhile Clark was not selected for the Olympic basketball team, she and other female athletes are dominating sports-related ads ahead of the Paris Games.\n\nSimone Biles, the most decorated gymnast of all time, is currently starring in several brand campaigns including for diabetes drug Mounjaro and athletic clothing brand Athleta, according to data from TV ad measurement firm iSpot.\n\nIn the Athleta commercial with the tagline "The Power of She," Biles trains alone in a gym, sticking a perfect landing after a flip as her voiceover says "we are here ... for hearing yourself over the crowd and landing in your power."\n\nOlympic swimmer Katie Ledecky, who has seven gold medals, also features in Athleta\'s campaign on social media, as well as TV commercials for protein drink Core Power and sportswear brand TYR.\n\nThe Paris Olympics begin on July 26.\n\nDOUBLE SPENDING\n\nIn March, GroupM said it pledged to double its annual ad spending on women\'s sports, backed by some of its clients including Google, Mars and Unilever.\n\n"I\'ve had many conversations with clients who haven\'t been involved with women\'s sports in the past, who are now thinking and acting on it," said Matt Sweeney, chief investment officer at GroupM U.S.\n\nBeyond categories such as personal care items, advertisers in the travel, pharmaceutical and insurance industries are increasingly interested in women\'s sports, said Mark Marshall, NBCUniversal\'s head of global advertising and partnerships.\n\nDespite the growth in attention for women\'s sports, the size of sponsorship deals for female athletes are still far off from their male counterparts, said Robert Müller von Vultejus, chief growth officer at sports marketing agency Sportfive.\n\n"The individual reach of an athlete like LeBron James is so outstanding, it\'s not yet comparable on the women\'s side," he said. "But in a couple years time, it will get there."\n\n\'PERFECT STORM\'\n\nContinued viewership and support of women\'s sports beyond the Olympics will be key to maintaining the momentum, said Kerri Walsh Jennings, a three-time Olympic gold medalist in beach volleyball.\n\n"If brands say they support female athletes, but don\'t put action behind it, it falls flat," she said. "I hope brands continue showing up and giving us this platform."\n\nJennings appears in a social media campaign beginning this week for Bingo Blitz, an online game from developer Playtika, alongside two-time Olympic gymnast Aly Raisman and American soccer player Alex Morgan. The three athletes each describe a consequential time in their career as their "bingo" moment.\n\n"Years ago, people would say no one really watches women\'s sports. That\'s not the case now," said Nancy Atufunwa, senior vice president at sports marketing agency Octagon, citing the popularity of college level sports and the WNBA. "It\'s the perfect storm at this moment."\n\nReporting by Sheila Dang in Austin; editing by Kenneth Li and Anna Driver\n\nOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles., opens new tab', 'source': {'uri': 'reuters.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Reuters'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'sheila_dang@reuters.com', 'name': 'Sheila Dang', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.reuters.com/resizer/v2/2MRGYCW6DBP7VOOGSWLBHFVPN4.jpg?auth=16c00092a5c8627e1a96eca4a53de37ecaaab45c86774fcc4f8112bafea85e7e&height=1005&width=1920&quality=80&smart=true', 'eventUri': 'eng-9740329', 'sentiment': 0.2549019607843137, 'wgt': 458910839, 'relevance': 12}
