{'uri': '2024-07-424532324', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:51:05', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:51:05Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.fresnobee.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'fresnobee.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Fresno Bee'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@fresnobee.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458902265, 'relevance': 106}
{'uri': '2024-07-424530383', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:48:13', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:48:13Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:47:13Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.9333333373069763, 'url': 'https://www.france24.com/en/live-news/20240717-eu-court-rejects-tiktok-challenge-against-new-eu-digital-rules', 'title': 'EU court rejects TikTok challenge against new EU digital rules', 'body': 'Luxembourg (AFP) - TikTok lost an appeal Wednesday to escape new digital rules that seek to rein in the power of big tech after an EU court rejected its challenge.\n\nA landmark European Union law known as the Digital Markets Act (DMA) entered into force in March, and regulators believe it will create a fairer market.\n\nThe European Commission designated six "gatekeepers" under the DMA facing the curbs: Google parent Alphabet, Amazon, Apple, Meta, Microsoft -- and TikTok owner ByteDance, the only non-US company.\n\nThe EU said in May that Booking would also have to apply the law and gave the online travel agent six months to prepare for compliance.\n\nThe decision by the Luxembourg-based General Court is the first judgement on a DMA challenge by big tech, with cases lodged by Apple and Meta still pending.\n\n"The Court dismisses ByteDance\'s action," it said. TikTok can appeal against the ruling within two months and 10 days of the decision.\n\nTikTok had insisted it was the "most capable challenger" to entrenched players in the digital sphere, but the court dismissed that argument.\n\n"TikTok had succeeded in increasing its number of users very rapidly and exponentially, reaching, in a short time, half the size of Facebook and of Instagram, and a particularly high engagement rate, with young users in particular, who spent more time on TikTok than on other social networks," the court said in a statement.\n\nThe judges acknowledged that in 2018, video sharing app TikTok was indeed a challenger but it had since then "rapidly consolidated its position and even strengthened that position over the following years" despite the launch of similar rival services.\n\nUnhappy big tech\n\n"We are disappointed with this decision. TikTok is a challenger platform that provides important competition to incumbent players," a spokesperson said in a statement.\n\n"While we will now evaluate next steps, we already took measures to comply with the relevant obligations of the DMA ahead of last March\'s deadline."\n\nBut the court determined "ByteDance met the quantitative thresholds laid down in the DMA".\n\nFor Brussels to name a company as a gatekeeper, they must fulfil certain conditions.\n\nThe criteria include having more than 45 million monthly active users in the EU and more than 10,000 yearly active business users established in the bloc.\n\nDigital companies with an annual turnover in the EU of at least 7.5 billion euros ($8.2 billion) or a market value of above 75 billion euros also face the new curbs.\n\nIf a company violates the law, the EU can impose fines of up to 10 percent of a company\'s total global turnover. This can rise to 20 percent for repeat offenders and in the most severe circumstances, the EU can order the break-up of companies.\n\nIt is the second defeat in the courts for TikTok over the DMA. It lost a bid in February to suspend the strict new rules pending the judgement handed down Wednesday.\n\nBig tech is not happy about the new law. Apple, contesting the DMA in the courts, has been vocal in its criticism, saying it puts users\' security at risk.', 'source': {'uri': 'france24.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'France 24'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://s.france24.com/media/display/291a87b4-4419-11ef-9459-005056a90284/2fb561219e08f730ce446d451f00ba366d690532.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.01960784313725483, 'wgt': 458902093, 'relevance': 54}

But any PS player signed by another team to its active roster is guaranteed three weeks of active roster pay first.\n\nChuck from Menomonie, WI\n\nDo you have any insights on the communication process between GM and head coach during preseason? What is he talking about? Is he interfering with the QB\'s cadence or audibles?\n\nNo, he\'s usually declaring to his teammates who the "mike," or middle linebacker, is based on the defensive alignment, because the offense\'s protection call is based on identifying the "mike" and counting out each way from the middle.\n\nWesley from Woodbury, MN\n\nGood morning II, when the offense makes a substitution, the refs will hold up the snap until the defense has time to make a substitution. Is there a time limit the defense has to make this substitution or can they "drag their feet" to run down the play clock? Thanks for all of your insights!\n\nThe substitution has to be immediate, with the player(s) running on/off the field right away. If there\'s any delay, the official can simply step back and let the offense run the play.\n\nRobert from Corpus Christi, TX\n\nWhy don\'t NFL teams have summer practices at Wisconsin universities anymore?\n\nIt was quite the run, wasn\'t it? Bears in my hometown of Platteville from 1984-2000, Saints in La Crosse from 1988-99, Chiefs in River Falls from 1991-2009, and the Jaguars had their inaugural camp in Stevens Point in 1995. They all left for various reasons - staying closer to home, less overall expense, easier for their own fans to attend, local economic impact, etc. - and as teams improved their own facilities over the years, they became better equipped to deal with the heat (the main reason the Saints and Chiefs wanted to train further north all those years, though the Jaguars escaped nothing with that scorching \'95 Midwest heat wave and never came back), plus the amenities of their home facilities became more difficult to replicate elsewhere. But the Cheese League will always have a special place in my heart.\n\nDave from Gwinn, MI\n\nI tried googling this but Google is dumber than a box of wet sweat socks. The next five on my list would be (in chronological order) Adam Timmerman in \'95, Mark Tauscher in 2000, Scott Wells in \'04, Matt Flynn in \'08, and Rasheed Walker in \'22.\n\nKyle from St. Charles, MO\n\nIt\'s hard to believe by this time next week they\'ll have their first practice of 2024 behind them. I remember Aaron Kampman struggling with the change to OLB. Do you think it is easier to change from OLB to DE or DE to OLB?\n\nI would guess the former. Outside \'backers in a 3-4 have pass coverage responsibilities that D-ends in a 4-3 generally don\'t. So while one transition adds to a player\'s plate, the other subtracts from it.\n\nBob from Covington, KY\n\nRewatched last year\'s 49ers game on the NFL Network yesterday. Investigating the area kicks off Lost In Madness, a low-level quest that sends players on a cross-island scavenger hunt using a Cultist's Treasure Map.\n\nLost In Madness is pretty confusing compared to other quests or exploration tasks in Once Human. The lack of quest markers is an issue, and while there's a map provided for players as part of the quest, it's not very helpful either. Here's a complete guide on everything you need to do for the Lost In Madness quest.\n\nHow To Start The Lost In Madness Quest In Once Human\n\nClose\n\nTo begin this side quest, the first thing you have to do is visit a small grocery store called BNMart in the Coastside Plaza area in the eastern end of the Dayton Wetlands region. Interact with the red candle in the corner of the store, and your vision will warp for a moment. Then, a chest will appear in front of you. Loot it, and you'll find the Cultist's Treasure map, which is needed for the rest of the side quest.\n\nCultist's Treasure Map Location\n\nClose\n\nIf you view the Cultist's Treasure Map in your inventory, you'll find that the drawing there isn't very helpful. However, the quest will point you to Chalk Peak, a level 32 region west of the Dayton Wetlands. It's going to be a long trip going to Chalk Peak, so you may want to consider building a car in Once Human so you can have a smoother time driving.\n\nThe location you're looking for is the Believer Colony, which is directly west of Tall Grass Inn. It's a small Vulture camp along the road with three buildings in it. Once you get here, clear the camp and look for the aptly-named Cultist's Treasure Chest. The location of this chest may change from one player to another, but for us, we found it on the second floor west-most one.\n\nThe contents of this chest may also differ from player to player. Opening it yields some account and battle pass EXP, 100 Energy Links, Stellar Planula, and a level 1 Eclipse Cortex. The latter is particularly interesting -- it's one of the main ways of getting Starchrom in Once Human. Starchrom is the main currency used for making wishes and buying blueprints in Wish Machines.\n\nOnce Human\n\nSystem PC , Mobile , Google , Apple\n\nPlatform(s) PC , Android , iOS\n\nReleased July 9, 2024\n\nPublisher(s) Starry Studio , NetEase, Inc.\n\nGenre(s) Survival , Shooter , Open-World", 'source': {'uri': 'gamerant.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Game Rant'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'marc_santos@gamerant.com', 'name': 'Marc Santos', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static0.gamerantimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/20240717135445_1.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.3490196078431372, 'wgt': 458901946, 'relevance': 6}
{'uri': '2024-07-424525985', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:45:36', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:45:36Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.islandpacket.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'islandpacket.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Island Packet'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@islandpacket.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458901936, 'relevance': 106}
{'uri': '2024-07-424520374', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:41:33', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:41:33Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.sanluisobispo.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'sanluisobispo.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Tribune'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@sanluisobispo.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458901693, 'relevance': 106}

{'uri': '2024-07-424515426', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:36:11', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:36:11Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'myrtlebeachonline.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'MyrtleBeachOnline'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@myrtlebeachonline.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458901371, 'relevance': 106}
{'uri': '2024-07-424515939', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:36:06', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:36:06Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.kansas.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'kansas.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Wichita Eagle'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@kansas.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458901366, 'relevance': 106}
{'uri': '2024-07-424514123', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:34:16', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:34:16Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.sacbee.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'sacbee.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Sacramento Bee'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@sacbee.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458901256, 'relevance': 106}
{'uri': '2024-07-424508571', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:32:08', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:32:08Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'charlotteobserver.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Charlotte Observer'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@charlotteobserver.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458901128, 'relevance': 106}
{'uri': '2024-07-424509867', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:31:18', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:31:18Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.bradenton.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'bradenton.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Bradenton Herald'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@bradenton.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458901078, 'relevance': 106}
{'uri': '2024-07-424507526', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:28:30', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:28:30Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.miamiherald.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'miamiherald.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Miami Herald'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@miamiherald.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458900910, 'relevance': 106}
{'uri': '2024-07-424500592', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:23:35', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:23:35Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.kansascity.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'kansascity.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Kansas City Star'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@kansascity.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458900615, 'relevance': 106}

"This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. {'uri': '2024-07-424496059', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:18:26', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:18:26Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.heraldonline.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'heraldonline.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Herald'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@heraldonline.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458900306, 'relevance': 106}
{'uri': '2024-07-424495250', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:17:49', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:17:49Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.bnd.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'bnd.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Belleville News-Democrat'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@bnd.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458900269, 'relevance': 106}
{'uri': '2024-07-424494040', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '08:17:17', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T08:17:17Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T08:13:02Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.idahostatesman.com/news/nation-world/world/article290147239.html', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."', 'source': {'uri': 'idahostatesman.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Idaho Statesman'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'hugh_cameron@idahostatesman.com', 'name': 'Hugh Cameron', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.mcclatchy-wires.com/incoming/xrx4y9/picture290147204/alternates/LANDSCAPE_1140/1663f96e-5e39-4772-94aa-1c659430ab3a', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458900237, 'relevance': 106}
{'uri': '8229538949', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '07:50:43', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T07:50:43Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T07:49:37Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/17/putins-spies-are-a-threat-to-paris-olympics-google-warns/', 'title': "Putin's Spies Are a Threat to Paris Olympics, Google Warns", 'body': 'Russian hackers are gearing up to derail the Paris Olympics, according to cybersecurity experts, with prospective targets ranging from those in the stands to state officials.\n\nNew research from Mandiant, a cybersecurity firm and subsidiary of Google, argued that the events\' organizers and attendees will need to remain on high-alert, given the significant risk posed by cyber-criminals with motivations both financial and geopolitical.\n\nIn a report entitled "Phishing for Gold," Mandiant determined that the Paris Olympics face "an elevated risk of cyber threat activity."\n\nThe authors, Michelle Cantos and Jamie Collier, assessed "with high confidence" that Russian state-sponsored actors posed the greatest risk to the Games, with hackers from China, Iran and North Korea also presenting a moderate threat.\n\nCollier, Mandiant\'s lead threat intelligence advisor for Europe, spoke to Newsweek about the unique vulnerabilities of the Olympic Games.\n\n"As a high profile sporting event with a global audience, the Olympics represents an ideal stage for disruptive cyber operations intended to cause negative psychological effects and reputational damage," Collier said. "This is because the impact of any disruption would be significantly magnified."\n\nThe paper outlines the varied cyber risk that face the Games, including cyber espionage, "Disruptive and destructive" attacks, and financially motivated hacks.\n\nAs an international event attended by government officials and heads of state, Collier believes that Russian hackers will attempt to use the event for "information gathering" on foreign, senior decision makers.\n\nHowever, attendees should also be wary, and such large events present ripe opportunities for cybercriminals of all stripes to target tourists with ticket scams and attempt to steal personal data.\n\nFor Collier, the worst case scenario would be a widescale "destructive" attack, such as the deployment of "wiper malware" which erases data on target networks, and which would throw the Paris Games into disarray.\n\nCollier argued that a coincidence of factors make these Olympics particularly vulnerable.\n\nThe International Olympic Committee banned Russia from competition in February 2022, as an immediate response to the country\'s invasion of Ukraine which the organization deemed a "blatant violation" of the Olympic Charter. Russian and Belarusian athletes still may compete under a neutral flag.\n\nAccording to Collier, this provides Putin with a "clear motivation" to target the Games and, alongside its sophisticated cyber espionage capabilities and track record of targeting previous Olympics, make it the greatest risk to the competition.\n\nDuring the 2016, 2018 and 2020 Games, state-sponsored Russian hackers leaked athlete data, disrupted networks during the opening ceremonies, and conducted reconnaissance of Olympic officials, according to Mandiant.\n\nFrance\'s ardent support for Ukraine following the Russian invasion also makes these games the perfect target for geopolitically motivated attacks, according to Collier, and France the most likely target for cyberattacks.\n\nHowever, Collier said that the reaction to the report has been encouraging since it was first published in June.\n\n"We have been really encouraged by the number of organizations involved in the Olympics that have read our report and are looking to respond to the threats that matter most to them," Collier said. "More organizations than ever now understand that identifying relevant threats helps them build a more proactive security posture."\n\nDo you have a story we should be covering? Do you have any questions about this article? Contact[email protected].\n\nNewsweek is committed to challenging conventional wisdom and finding connections in the search for common ground.\n\nNewsweek is committed to challenging conventional wisdom and finding connections in the search for common ground.', 'source': {'uri': 'dnyuz.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'DNyuz'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://dnyuz.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Putins-Spies-Are-a-Threat-to-Paris-Olympics-Google-Warns.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.2549019607843137, 'wgt': 458898643, 'relevance': 76}

{'uri': '8229445353', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '06:43:57', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T06:43:57Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T06:43:26Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.indiatvnews.com/fact-check/fact-check-did-pm-modi-congratulate-inida-bloc-after-assembly-by-poll-results-know-truth-behind-viral-video-2024-07-17-942234', 'title': 'Fact Check: Did PM Modi congratulate INDIA bloc after assembly by-poll results? Know truth behind viral video', 'body': 'India TV Fact Check: A video is circulating that claims Prime Minister Narendra Modi is overjoyed at the victory of the I.N.D.I.A bloc in the by-elections and has congratulated them. However, a fact-check by India TV has revealed that this claim is completely false.\n\nIn the recently concluded by-polls, the INDIA bloc triumphed by winning 10 out of 13 assembly constituencies across seven states, significantly outperforming the BJP, which secured only two seats.\n\nA video is circulating on social media in which PM Modi is heard congratulating Team India. This video is being shared with the claim that PM Modi is overjoyed after the impressive performance of the INDIA alliance in the recent by-elections held for 13 assembly seats in seven states. The caption of the viral video states, "In the by-elections of 7 states, the INDIA alliance has got a big victory; Narendra Modi ji is overjoyed with this victory."\n\nAs this video was rapidly going viral on social media, with claims it was related to the Indi alliance\'s victory in the assembly by-elections, we decided to investigate. First, we used Google Open Search with relevant keywords to check the video\'s context. During our search, we found the same video on PM Modi\'s \'X\' handle. The video was uploaded on the night of June 29 with the caption, "Champions! Our team brings the T20 World Cup home in style! We are proud of the Indian cricket team. This match was historic." The video actually showed PM Modi celebrating the Indian cricket team\'s victory in the T20 World Cup final.\n\nThe fact check by India TV has revealed that the viral video on social media is neither related to the assembly by-election nor connected to the victory of the Indi alliance. A segment of the video celebrating Team India\'s victory in the T20 World Cup was edited and shared with a false claim. India TV\'s fact check confirmed that the viral video\'s claim of PM Modi congratulating the Indi alliance after the assembly by-elections is false.\n\nAlso Read: Fact Check: Was Trump shot in chest and did bulletproof jacket save his life? (AP-Yonhap)\n\nUS tech giant Google has recently discontinued offering real-time popular searches in Korea, a feature long banned by its Korean rivals such as Naver and Daum due to the possibility of manipulating public opinion.\n\n"We have decided to remove the feature from Google Search in Korea. The feature is no longer available here," Google Korea said in a statement Wednesday. No further elaboration on the reason and timing of the suspension was given.\n\nNaver and Daum suspended their popular search term features in 2020 and 2021, respectively, amid mounting pressures that they could be abused to manipulate public opinion during politically sensitive periods such as elections.\n\nGoogle started providing daily trending searches via its Google Trends feature globally, and the real-time service only became available in Korea late last month. Daily trending searches remain available.\n\n"Despite Korea making up a tiny 1 percent of Google\'s traffic flow, they may be well aware of the negative sentiment toward real-time search terms," an industry source said. "With the latest decision, concerns about the possible reverse discrimination against Naver and Daum have also been relieved."\n\nThe source, however, said the feature could have boosted Google\'s traffic in Korea which is dominated by the two Korean portals.', 'source': {'uri': 'koreaherald.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Korea Herald'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'jie_ye_eun@koreaherald.com', 'name': 'Jie Ye-eun', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://res.heraldm.com/content/image/2024/07/17/20240717050680_0.jpg?1', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458894244, 'relevance': 125}
