{'uri': '2024-07-424373358', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '06:13:50', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T06:13:50Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T23:45:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://lufkindailynews.com/news/local/mirz-brining-magic-show-to-pines-theater/article_454abe8f-fd29-5e4a-a16f-b814d7df1d13.html', 'title': 'Mirz brining magic show to Pines Theater', 'body': 'Zak Mirz will be at The Pines Theater to present a show Friday night.\n\nFor Zak Mirz, his shows are about much more than just magic. They\'re a combination of family, life and fun.\n\nSo if you\'re looking for a fun night out with the family, his show "Flashes of Magic" is just the right fit.\n\nThe entertainer who has worked with David Blaine and appeared on "Fool Us" with Penn & Teller will be in town at The Pines Theater Friday night.\n\n"It\'s a brand new show that\'s been out since June," Mirz said during a phone interview while he was on his way to Alabama Tuesday afternoon. "It\'s a family-friendly show. If anyone has seen anything on me or my previous work, this is a completely new show."\n\nLast year\'s show was titled "Ticket for One." The show coming to Lufkin, "Flashes of Magic," has a different story behind it.\n\n"My first special was a magic show, but it was also a love letter to my father," Mirz said. "Now my daughter just turned 2 last week. This is going to be a magic show and it\'s going to be interactive. It\'s a reminder to everyone that the greatest magic trick you can give yourself is showing the world through the lens of a child."\n\nMirz said his ties to magic go back several years. He is a first-generation American with his parents immigrating from Iran and Afghanistan.\n\nHe tragically lost his father, who was killed when Mirz was just a year old.\n\nOnce he was told of how his father died -- Mirz was approximately 8 at the time -- magic became an outlet for Mirz.\n\n"A lot of my magic is through stories," Mirz said. "I talk about the seasons of losing my father. He\'s my hero. He was a hero that night. He got killed saving so many lives.\n\n"I got into magic shortly after my mom told me what had happened to my dad. I was 8 or 9, and at the time I was embarrassed and sad. I wanted to keep it a secret so I ran to magic. There was the time when I saw the David Blaine special. I thought that\'s what I want to do for the rest of my life. David Blaine really had a big influence on me."\n\nHe said his official introduction to magic wasn\'t any kind of glamorous tale.\n\n"We couldn\'t Google back then," Mirz said. "It was my uncle looking through the yellow pages. They took me to a magic shop, which I think was in Dallas. It just said \'magic shop\' on the front. He took me there, I got a few things and it just went on and on. It\'s been a fun journey."\n\nHe admits the journey of being a magician isn\'t for everyone. He described that path along with the advice he would give to one of the ones he loves most.\n\n"I\'ve done it pretty much my whole life," Mirz said. "I graduated, packed my bags and hit the road. My life has been a little bit of a carnival. I wanted to start at a young age. I knew the more times I failed, the better I\'d be, so I started touring right out of high school. I certainly wouldn\'t wish this on my daughter. Hopefully I can encourage her to take another path."\n\nThat journey has taken him to different parts of the world.\n\nHe estimates he does approximately 120 shows a year. He has been on two tours to Europe and guesses he has performed in each state with the exception of possibly Maine and Alaska.\n\nIn the process, he has met up with some of the country\'s most recognizable names.\n\nHe was on the show "Fool Us," with Penn & Teller, two world-famous musicians.\n\n"I was on their TV show a couple of years ago," Mirz said. "The idea is a magician goes on the stage, and Penn & Teller, who are two of the greatest minds in magic, try to deconstruct the trick and tell you what you\'ve done. Very few magicians succeed. I was lucky enough to fool Penn & Teller. About a month ago, I flew back to Vegas and closed their show with that trick."\n\nIn addition, he was able to work for David Blaine on his show "The Magic Way."\n\n"It\'s amazing," Mirz said. "Magic is one of the few places you get to work with your heroes. He had a TV special \'The Magic Way\' back in 2020 on ABC. Everything was shut down during COVID and they asked if he could make a special. I got to work with him on one of the effects on the show."\n\nNow that journey is taking him to Lufkin Friday night. Despite living in Dallas, he said he doesn\'t remember staying in Lufkin but is excited to perform in town.\n\nHe gave the local audience a preview of what they can expect.\n\n"It\'s a family friendly show," Mirz said. "We\'re going to have a lot of people come on stage. That\'s part of almost every routine, bringing a mom or a dad, a brother or a sister, onto the stage and watching the rest of the family recording it. It\'s highly interactive.\n\n"It\'s amazing. You see standups all the time and they have their routine where it\'s just them. I always say their job is harder than mine. What I think makes my show so entertaining is who we bring on the stage. We try to bring big personalities up there."\n\nFans can learn more about Mirz\'s show at mirztour.com.\n\nTickets for the event can be purchased online at angelinaarts.org or at the box office the night of the event if still available.\n\nThe show starts at 7 p.m.', 'source': {'uri': 'lufkindailynews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Lufkin Daily News'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'josh_havard@lufkindailynews.com', 'name': 'Josh Havard', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/lufkindailynews.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/22/122d7c6b-1cf5-53eb-a7ad-da73ad059c7a/669712ad31a56.image.jpg?crop=1762%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=1200%2C631&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1137254901960785, 'wgt': 458892830, 'relevance': 33}
{'uri': '2024-07-424332290', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '05:19:10', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T05:19:10Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T05:00:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.4666666686534882, 'url': 'https://www.couriermail.com.au/entertainment/celebrity-life/royals/pictures-resurface-of-harry-kate-and-william-as-painful-reminder-of-what-was/news-story/3bdbce028a14334991539df34b303102', 'title': 'Poignant Harry, Kate pics resurface', 'body': 'The UK was awash in patriotic fervour, nylon Union Jacks and five per cent ale as London got set to host the Olympic Games.\n\nThat night, as 900 million people watched on, the late Queen pulled off one of the greatest \'ta-da\' moments of all time when her skit with Daniel Craig\'s James Bond debuted, before \'the Queen\' parachuted into the stadium.\n\nIf we can all agree that Her late Majesty won the Games, then hot on her heels and coming a very close second were the seemingly inseparable triumvirate that was Prince William and Kate, the Prince and Princess of Wales and Prince Harry the Duke of Sussex who flew the flag for Britain with astounding glee.\n\nThis week photos from that moment in time have burbled up through the usual muck and dreck of X, formerly Twitter, and my, they make for some haunting viewing.\n\nOn the surface, look at those three: how jolly, how happy, and how comfortable in each other\'s company.\n\nChatting, laughing, giggling, whispering. Except we now know that that Enid Blyton chumminess hid a far-from-storybook reality. The Famous Three, it turns out, was an optical illusion.\n\nWith the Olympics set to roll around again next week -- bonjour Paree and the first games powered on the back of the baguette -- those old Kate and Harry photos make for a melancholy jaunt down memory lane.\n\nThey perfectly capture how much has been lost and how much the reality differed from superficial appearances. They\'re a reminder of how in-the-dark the world was about what was really going on with Harry.\n\nBut back then in 2012, when blissful ignorance reigned, the royal stocks looked like a buy, buy, buy! The future seemed blindingly bright with the younger generation of Crown Inc coming across as a very clean-behind-the-ears, united, one-for-all pep squad.\n\nWhen, five years later, Harry added fiancé Meghan Markle (now, of course, the Duchess of Sussex) to their pally group, we were officially in a Buckingham Palace bull market. The better quarters of Fleet Street and the public positively mooned over the new couple and the prevailing consensus was simple- these glam, cool kids full of verve and belief in the monarchical mission might save the dog and pony show yet.\n\nTogether, William, Kate, Harry and Meghan, were a dynamite proposition.\n\nNo one knew it then but that was to be the high water mark.\n\nWithin two years, that \'dynamite\' would go kaboom and the royal family would never quite be the same again.\n\nHowever, in 2012, to all appearances Harry and Kate seemed to have a delightfully matey thing going on. It used to be that a reliable cheerer upper was Googling photos of the duo having a giggle together -- at the Olympics, on the Buckingham Palace balcony, at a palace tea party, at a lunch to celebrate the late Queen\'s 90th birthday, at a BAFTA event, church services, a wedding, at Trooping the Colour, at Trooping the Colour again, another Trooping, during a trip to Belgium, at the 2014 Commonwealth Games.\n\nHarry and Kate\'s lives were intertwined professionally too. They shared an office at Kensington Palace and theirs was the unwieldily named Royal Foundation of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Harry. With a certain clockwork predictability the three would be posted off to engagements like a bargain pack of HRHs, a sort of \'buy two, get one free\' arrangement.\n\nAppearances though are shifty, truck things.\n\nHarry\'s time as a "third wheel", as he put it to ITV\'s Tom Bradby last year, "was fun at times but also, I guess slightly awkward at times as well."\n\nAs another Londoner, Oscar Wilde, put it, "the truth is rarely pure and never simple."\n\nIn Spare, Harry does not just offer up something of a biting portrayal of his father and brother but an unfavourable one of Kate too, detailing the distance that existed in their private lives.\n\nHe writes that after his brother and sister-in-law had wed in 2011, "they became a Household, and as such were entitled to more staff, more cars, bigger home, grander office, extra resources, engraved letterheads. I didn\'t care about such perks, but I did care about respect. As a confirmed bachelor I was an outsider, a nonperson within my own family."\n\nWhen in 2013, the year after these Olympics shots were taken, William and Kate were undertaking extensive renovations of their Kensington Palace apartment, and with Harry living "just across the way", he writes that he had imagined popping around "holding a bottle of wine and an armful of kiddie presents."\n\nInstead, "it didn\'t work out that way...I assumed they\'d have me over any minute now. Any day. But day after day it didn\'t happen."\n\nFor all those public giggles between Harry and Kate, those imagined cosy suppers, all Shepherds\' pies and easy, warm family life, they never materialised. It was a magic faraway tree of a domestic idyll.\n\nAdded to which, all the while, Harry was suffering deeply. We now know that his cheeky persona hid incredibly deep psychic pain and trauma from his mother\'s death.\n\nSo, I can\'t be the only one who, looking at those 2012 shots, keeps hearing the words \'if only\' rattling through my head on a loop. If only William and Kate had somehow realised what Harry was going through; if only he had made it plain; if only feelings and resentments hadn\'t been left to ferment and to churn.\n\nWhen the late Queen entered the Olympic arena on that July 27 to awestruck applause and a UK enjoying a giddy high and a prolonged beer buzz, the future of the monarchy looked safe as (palatial) houses.\n\nInstead, those Harry and Kate 2012 photos are portentous - of how soon things would fracture and fall apart and how falteringly and shaky, a decade on in 2022, Crown Inc would be looking.\n\nWhat these resurfaced photos of Harry and Kate represent are not just the ghosts of royal history past but the ghosts of what might have been too.\n\nDaniela Elser is a writer, editor and a royal commentator with more than 15 years\' experience working with a number of Australia\'s leading media titles.\n\nOriginally published as Pictures resurface of Harry, Kate and William as painful reminder of what was', 'source': {'uri': 'couriermail.com.au', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Courier Mail'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'daniela_elser@couriermail.com.au', 'name': 'Daniela Elser', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://content.api.news/v3/images/bin/81e4fd1c6b0ccd352960a55f1b809889', 'eventUri': 'eng-9733305', 'sentiment': 0.3568627450980393, 'wgt': 458889550, 'relevance': 29}
{'uri': '8229301277', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '04:46:18', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T04:46:18Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T04:45:12Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://pressofatlanticcity.com/sports/avalon-wins-ocean-city-beach-patrol-womens-invitational/article_0b880aa0-43d8-11ef-bb57-cba21e7ece58.html', 'title': "Avalon wins Ocean City Beach Patrol Women's Invitational", 'body': 'Guy Gargan\n\nOCEAN CITY -- The women of the Avalon Beach Patrol won three of the first four races and the team title at the Ocean City Beach Patrol Women\'s Invitational on Tuesday.\n\nThe lifeguards endured a rough ocean in five relays in front of a good crowd at the 12th Street beach.\n\nSisters Molly and Regan McDonnell started the evening on a good note for Avalon with a win in the row-swim. Avalon\'s Katie Scanlon and Becca Cubbler followed with a victory in the swim relay. Ocean City\'s Lexi Santer and Brynn Gallagher were first in the paddle relay, but Avalon clinched first place early when Maggie Murphy and Cubbler won the run-swim relay. Ocean City\'s Claudia Booth, Chloe Care, Morgan Decosta and Santer made it a closer final score by winning the surf dash.\n\nAvalon scored 15 points with three wins. Ocean City finished second with 13 points. Longport placed second in two races and totaled eight points for third. Cape May was fourth with seven points, and Margate was fifth with six. Sea Girt (the defending team champion) and Sea Isle City also scored six points, but Margate finished higher in the surf dash, the event\'s tiebreaker.\n\nPeople are also reading... Atlantic City Airshow canceled for 2024 Ocean City\'s Seaspray condo for sale at $7M Cape May County Zoo receives $1.4 million donation Longport resident says rats are coming from borough property 5 hurt, 76 displaced in 5-alarm Atlantic City apartment fire Egg Harbor Township board expected Monday to discuss possible inclusion of Atlantic Shores site in Cardiff plan Wildwood police identify shooting suspect Buddy Tarbotton, a Cape May County high school sports fixture, dies at 63 Atlantic City High School principal accused of failing to report child abuse due back in court Aug. 29 After dream debut, South Jersey native Tyler Phillips will start Saturday for the Phillies: Must Win Route 30 drawbridge stuck open in Atlantic City South Jersey native Tyler Phillips to start Saturday for the Phillies Atlantic City fire union head calls for restoring of Ducktown engine in wake of Georgia Avenue blaze Egg Harbor City rescue in need of fosters, donors to help animals rescued from Galloway home Atlantic County League of Women Voters chair resigns after regretting Trump \'only grazed\'\n\n"Anybody just to be out there tonight, you had to be a pretty competent lifeguard," Avalon Beach Patrol Chief Matt Wolf said. "The ocean was wild. You saw that right from the warmups, and credit our girls, they\'ve been working really hard, and they got out there and competed well tonight. They won three events, last night the Countys (a men\'s and women\'s event won by Avalon) and hopefully the Kerrs (Avalon\'s home event) on Friday, they really highlight the depth of our beach patrol. We\'ve got a lot of really talented lifeguards on every single lifeguard stand."\n\nThe McDonnell sisters rowed to the flag a quarter-mile out, and Molly jumped out and swam to the finish line on the beach.\n\n"It was quite rough. For most of the row we weren\'t first," said Molly McDonnell, 19, a Haddonfield resident and rising sophomore rower at Georgetown University. "But my sister (a former Stanford University rower) and I are like second-half of the race-type people. So we knew at the flag we would probably get them. The water was really, really rough, but it feels good to come out on top."\n\nScanlon got the lead and Cubbler kept it in the swim relay, which had a 300-meter course. Scanlon, 17, is a rising senior at Mount St. Joseph Academy in Pennsylvania. Cubbler, 26, is a former Bloomsburg University swimmer.\n\n"When I went around the second buoy (the turn for home), I just sprinted as hard as I could and tried to catch some waves," Scanlon said. "I was leading. I had a lot of confidence in Becca. I was excited to see her (leading) at the last flag."\n\nCubbler said her only thought was to hold onto the lead.\n\nSanter went first and Gallagher anchored for the O.C. win in the box paddle relay. Gallagher, 16, is a rising senior swimmer and surfer at Ocean City High School. She caught a good wave near the beach.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"The waves were pretty crazy with the wind right now," Gallagher said. "So I knew that if I just stay calm and got a wave in and really pushed on that last run to that finish line, that everything would work out, and it did.\n\n"Lexi\'s awesome. She really pushes all of us girls on the beach patrol. She\'s a really great role model for us younger girls."\n\nMurphy ran a half-mile on the beach and Cubbler swam in Avalon\'s run-swim win. It was Cubbler\'s second victory of the evening.\n\nThe winner of the run leg was Margate\'s Sofia Day, a 17-year-old rising senior at Mainland Regional.\n\nSanter anchored the surf dash win, her third event of the day and second victory.\n\n"I love the surf dash," Santer said. "The Ocean City race is pretty cool in that you get to do a lot of the team relays. The surf dash is always four persons, and we have a really strong group, and I kind of know the three girls before me are always going to put me in a good place."\n\nResults\n\nRow-swim relay: 1. Avalon; 2. Ventnor; 3. Cape May; 4. Brigantine; 5. Atlantic City\n\nBox swim relay: 1. Avalon; 2 Longport; 3. Ocean City; 4. Sea Isle City; 5. Cape May\n\nBox paddle relay: 1. Ocean City; 2. {'uri': '2024-07-424304959', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '04:38:36', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T04:38:36Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T23:45:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://lufkindailynews.com/news/local/mirz-bringing-magic-show-to-pines-theater/article_d4e8615f-e7ad-526c-ac48-354faaa57f6f.html', 'title': 'Mirz bringing magic show to Pines Theater', 'body': 'Zak Mirz will be at The Pines Theater to present a show Friday night.\n\nFor Zak Mirz, his shows are about much more than just magic. They\'re a combination of family, life and fun.\n\nSo if you\'re looking for a fun night out with the family, his show "Flashes of Magic" is just the right fit.\n\nThe entertainer who has worked with David Blaine and appeared on "Fool Us" with Penn & Teller will be in town at The Pines Theater Friday night.\n\n"It\'s a brand new show that\'s been out since June," Mirz said during a phone interview while he was on his way to Alabama Tuesday afternoon. "It\'s a family-friendly show. If anyone has seen anything on me or my previous work, this is a completely new show."\n\nLast year\'s show was titled "Ticket for One." The show coming to Lufkin, "Flashes of Magic," has a different story behind it.\n\n"My first special was a magic show, but it was also a love letter to my father," Mirz said. "Now my daughter just turned 2 last week. This is going to be a magic show and it\'s going to be interactive. It\'s a reminder to everyone that the greatest magic trick you can give yourself is showing the world through the lens of a child."\n\nMirz said his ties to magic go back several years. He is a first-generation American with his parents immigrating from Iran and Afghanistan.\n\nHe tragically lost his father, who was killed when Mirz was just a year old.\n\nOnce he was told of how his father died -- Mirz was approximately 8 at the time -- magic became an outlet for Mirz.\n\n"A lot of my magic is through stories," Mirz said. "I talk about the seasons of losing my father. He\'s my hero. He was a hero that night. He got killed saving so many lives.\n\n"I got into magic shortly after my mom told me what had happened to my dad. I was 8 or 9, and at the time I was embarrassed and sad. I wanted to keep it a secret so I ran to magic. There was the time when I saw the David Blaine special. I thought that\'s what I want to do for the rest of my life. David Blaine really had a big influence on me."\n\nHe said his official introduction to magic wasn\'t any kind of glamorous tale.\n\n"We couldn\'t Google back then," Mirz said. "It was my uncle looking through the yellow pages. They took me to a magic shop, which I think was in Dallas. It just said \'magic shop\' on the front. He took me there, I got a few things and it just went on and on. It\'s been a fun journey."\n\nHe admits the journey of being a magician isn\'t for everyone. He described that path along with the advice he would give to one of the ones he loves most.\n\n"I\'ve done it pretty much my whole life," Mirz said. "I graduated, packed my bags and hit the road. My life has been a little bit of a carnival. I wanted to start at a young age. I knew the more times I failed, the better I\'d be, so I started touring right out of high school. I certainly wouldn\'t wish this on my daughter. Hopefully I can encourage her to take another path."\n\nThat journey has taken him to different parts of the world.\n\nHe estimates he does approximately 120 shows a year. He has been on two tours to Europe and guesses he has performed in each state with the exception of possibly Maine and Alaska.\n\nIn the process, he has met up with some of the country\'s most recognizable names.\n\nHe was on the show "Fool Us," with Penn & Teller, two world-famous musicians.\n\n"I was on their TV show a couple of years ago," Mirz said. "The idea is a magician goes on the stage, and Penn & Teller, who are two of the greatest minds in magic, try to deconstruct the trick and tell you what you\'ve done. Very few magicians succeed. I was lucky enough to fool Penn & Teller. About a month ago, I flew back to Vegas and closed their show with that trick."\n\nIn addition, he was able to work for David Blaine on his show "The Magic Way."\n\n"It\'s amazing," Mirz said. "Magic is one of the few places you get to work with your heroes. He had a TV special \'The Magic Way\' back in 2020 on ABC. Everything was shut down during COVID and they asked if he could make a special. I got to work with him on one of the effects on the show."\n\nNow that journey is taking him to Lufkin Friday night. Despite living in Dallas, he said he doesn\'t remember staying in Lufkin but is excited to perform in town.\n\nHe gave the local audience a preview of what they can expect.\n\n"It\'s a family friendly show," Mirz said. "We\'re going to have a lot of people come on stage. That\'s part of almost every routine, bringing a mom or a dad, a brother or a sister, onto the stage and watching the rest of the family recording it. It\'s highly interactive.\n\n"It\'s amazing. You see standups all the time and they have their routine where it\'s just them. I always say their job is harder than mine. What I think makes my show so entertaining is who we bring on the stage. We try to bring big personalities up there."\n\nFans can learn more about Mirz\'s show at mirztour.com.\n\nTickets for the event can be purchased online at angelinaarts.org or at the box office the night of the event if still available.\n\nThe show starts at 7 p.m.', 'source': {'uri': 'lufkindailynews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Lufkin Daily News'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'josh_havard@lufkindailynews.com', 'name': 'Josh Havard', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/lufkindailynews.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/22/122d7c6b-1cf5-53eb-a7ad-da73ad059c7a/669712ad31a56.image.jpg?crop=1762%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=1200%2C631&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1137254901960785, 'wgt': 458887116, 'relevance': 33}

"I tried it once and I sucked at it and I just quit, but now it\'s getting fun," said Bilombele.She was one of 25 refugee children who visited the Des Moines Driving Range on Tuesday. These children, hailing from various parts of the world, were introduced to the universal game of golf."Golf is universal," stated Mark Egly, golf pro and owner of the driving range.The day was part of a collaboration between Egly and Polk County Sheriff Kevin Schneider. The aim was to introduce these children to local law enforcement through the game of golf. "What we\'re trying to do is increase the communications and relationships with inner city immigrant children who are not familiar with law enforcement," explained Schneider.For many of these children, it was their first time handling a golf club. However, the hope is that it won\'t be their last. "You can tell that this is their first time doing it but they are quick learners today," Egly noted.Bilombele expressed her appreciation for the supportive environment. "The people here are really nice and they can help you how to golf and stuff," she said.This small but impactful gesture is helping these children learn about their new home and a new game. "We have Iowa Nice everywhere. We\'re doing it through the game of golf," Egly said." These children, hailing from various parts of the world, were introduced to the universal game of golf.\n\n"Golf is universal," stated Mark Egly, golf pro and owner of the driving range.\n\nThe day was part of a collaboration between Egly and Polk County Sheriff Kevin Schneider. The aim was to introduce these children to local law enforcement through the game of golf.\n\n"What we\'re trying to do is increase the communications and relationships with inner city immigrant children who are not familiar with law enforcement," explained Schneider.\n\nFor many of these children, it was their first time handling a golf club. {'uri': '8229196262', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '02:59:58', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T02:59:58Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T02:59:18Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://pantagraph.com/sports/mounce-brothers-win-bloomington-normal-two-man-three-peat-playoff/article_29de5b3c-43db-11ef-817e-3b618ee5ec8a.html', 'title': 'El Paso takeover: Mounce brothers capture Two-Man three-peat in playoff victory (copy)', 'body': 'BLOOMINGTON -- Jordan and Pippen, Shaq and Kobe, Michael and Branden Mounce.\n\nThe Mounce brothers conquered Steve and TJ Barger by one hole in a playoff to win the Bloomington-Normal Two-Man Best Position Championship for the third consecutive year, marking an impressive three-peat. The tournament\'s top three flights -- the championship flight, first flight and senior championship -- were all won by El Paso residents, and all three were repeat winners.\n\n"There are a lot of good golfers in El Paso," Branden said. "It goes underrated in the area."\n\nThe championship matchup lived up to the billing. Neither side led by more than one hole, and the match was tied for most of its duration.\n\nThe Bargers took advantage first with a birdie on hole 3, but soon after the Mounces responded. The Bargers bogeyed hole 6 then the Mounces birdied the seventh to take the lead. An immediate Barger response with a birdie on hole 8 soon led to a tie with nine holes to play, both teams out at 31, 5-under.\n\nPeople are also reading... Their selected drive went in the right rough, and neither could find the green on approach out of there. Poor chip shots led to a 25-foot par putt to save the hole, but Steve converted it from long range.\n\nMore concern emerged on the par-3 17th after TJ missed a heavy-breaking 5-footer for par, but, again, Steve came through once again to save the hole, keeping things tied heading into hole 18.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"Steve made a lot of putts," Michael said. "It felt like he wasn\'t missing."\n\nBoth teams had mid-range birdie looks for the win on 18, but the Mounces came up just short. After watching his dad come through to create an opportunity, TJ saw a moment. He fired the putt from just on the front of the green, and it tracked toward the hole with plenty of pace. Right as it approached, it lipped around the hole\'s rim and out -- no good.\n\n"It caught a lot of the hole, it was a really good putt," Branden said. "It looked right down the middle."\n\nIn the playoff, starting back at hole 1, both teams found the fairway, but the Mounces had the early advantage with Branden\'s drive being a 340-yard missile. Their wedge approach stuck to about seven feet while the Bargers were in 20-foot range.\n\nNeither Barger could convert, but the outcome wasn\'t set when Branden missed the birdie putt. However, Michael rolled it in on a perfect line, securing the title. The Mounces finished with a 62, 10-under par.\n\n"Most teams don\'t have two guys who can hit it out there quite a ways like us," Michael said.\n\n"We have a lot of shorter birdie putts because we\'re hitting wedges into the greens," Branden added.\n\nIn the senior championship, Todd Manning and Jim Mounce -- Michael and Branden\'s father -- cruised by going 5-up through nine holes and maintaining it, losing just one hole all match for a 5&4 win. In the first flight, Jason Unzicker and Kyle Tague took the lead on hole 3 and never relinquished it, securing a 2-up victory with a 67, 5-under par. Both teams won their respective divisions last year.\n\nBoth Michael and Branden plan on playing in the Bloomington-Normal Medal Play Tournament in early August. Michael is looking for a summer trifecta after winning the Bloomington-Normal Match Play Championship on June 17.\n\nFollow Will Foley on Twitter: @thewillfoley\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '8229182126', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '02:41:03', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T02:41:03Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T02:40:32Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8666666746139526, 'url': 'https://newsadvance.com/sports/college/will-oklahoma-s-big-12-success-translate-to-sec-new-gauntlet-is-sooners-best-litmus/article_3318938f-5245-5033-80ef-eb907aaadaf6.html', 'title': "Will Oklahoma's Big 12 success translate to SEC? New gauntlet is Sooners' best litmus test.", 'body': 'Brad Townsend, The Dallas Morning News\n\nWith all due respect to its oldest and most cutthroat rival, Oklahoma, not Texas, brings the more sterling football credentials to the Southeastern Conference.\n\nThe Sooners have won seven national titles; the Longhorns four. Oklahoma has 50 conference championships to UT\'s 33, including 14 compared to the Longhorns\' four during the schools\' 29 seasons together in the Big 12.\n\nIt\'s little wonder, then, that when asked Tuesday about his team\'s degree of readiness for its first season in the SEC, Sooners coach Brent Venables all but bowed up and clenched his jaw.\n\n"We\'re excited for the challenge," he said. "Oklahoma isn\'t intimidated as a football program. We\'re running towards the SEC."\n\nFearlessness aside, though, third-year coach Venables admittedly could not project how the Sooners\' relative Big 12 dominance would translate in the almighty SEC.\n\nWith a 10-3 record and No. 15 Associated Press finish last season, Oklahoma among Big 12 brethren was only outranked by No. 3 Texas, which by the way lost to the Sooners 34-30 in October.\n\nConversely, five SEC teams ranked higher than OU: No. 4 Georgia, No. 5 Alabama, No. 8 Missouri, No. 9 Ole Miss and No. 12 LSU. With the exception of Georgia, four of those teams are on OU\'s 2024 schedule, three of them on the road, along with the annual clash against Texas in the Cotton Bowl.\n\n"I think going through it gives you the best litmus test. There\'s nothing that you can read about or even watch on tape, to be honest with you."\n\nBy most metrics, the Oklahoma program is much better positioned to contend in the SEC than this time a year ago, when it was coming off a 6-7 season and Venables appeared to be on tenuous ground in Norman.\n\nThen came a 6-0 start, including the upset of Texas, and a climb to as No. 6 in the country before stumbles at Kansas (38-33) and Oklahoma State (27-24).\n\nOn June 21 Venables received a six-year, $51.6 million contract - a reward not only for last season\'s bounce-back but his third straight top-ten-ranked recruiting class as OU strived to build an SEC-worthy roster after announcing in July of 2021 that it intended to bolt with Texas from the Big 12.\n\n"The trenches is where this conference is decided usually year-in and year-out; incredibly challenging from that standpoint," Venables said, adding these SEC traits. "The length; the speed; the play at quarterback; the coaching acumen from top to bottom."\n\nFor quarterback play, the Sooners are turning to their latest heralded prospect at that position, sophomore Jackson Arnold, the 2022 Gatorade National Player of the Year out of Denton Guyer.\n\nWith SEC Media Days taking place in Texas for the first time, Venables noted that nearly 20 Sooners are from Dallas-Fort Worth area high schools.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nCounting returning players and portal transfers, Venables estimated that 24 Sooners are entering their third year or more as starters.\n\nSenior linebacker Danny Stutsman, out of Windermere, Fla., initially decided to enter the 2024 NFL draft after earning second-team Walter Camp All-America honors last season. His OU locker was even cleared out, but he had a change of heart after meeting with Venables.\n\n"He told me, \'Look, Oklahoma is going to win with or without you.\' " Stutsman recalled Tuesday. "I fully believe that. The program has been amazing before I got here; it\'ll be amazing when I leave here."\n\nHave Venables and his staff built enough depth in the offensive and defensive lines to compete with the SEC\'s elite teams?\n\nVenables says he believes the program has 9-to-11 offensive linemen and 10-to-12 defensive linemen who are capable of playing "winning football."\n\n"There are several guys that maybe don\'t have the depth of experience, but I trust my eyes," he said, adding, "This is a game of development."\n\nThis inaugural season, Venables said, not only will reveal how SEC-ready the Sooners are as currently constructed, but player prototypes and positional needs going forward.\n\nOklahoma of course will be learning the ways of the SEC at the same time as its fellow Big 12 co-alpha dog, Texas, except now the schools will be part of a pack of Rottweilers.\n\nA reporter on Tuesday half-jokingly started to ask Venables whether he and Texas coach Steve Sarkisian would be sharing notes.\n\n"Probably not," Venables interjected before the reporter could finish the question.\n\nWill moving to the SEC in any way affect that rivalry, which dates to 1900?\n\n"It\'s as deep-seated and hate-filled and emotional of a rivalry as there is in all of college football," Venables said. "So I don\'t see how the conference affiliation will make a big difference."\n\nTexas won the first Big 12 title, in 1996, and last season\'s, though the Sooners dominated much of what occurred between.\n\nNow both schools will face multiple near-Texas-OU-caliber conference games every season.\n\n"If you think that one is emotionally taxing, you\'re going to go into a lot of venues that the pageantry is going to be real, the stadiums are going to be completely full," Venables said. "And a lot of people are going to hate your guts for three hours or so."\n\n____\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'newsadvance.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'NewsAdvance.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/newsadvance.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/d/b4/db4bb5ff-0825-56ff-8518-6d72e0138791/66972cc7110de.image.jpg?crop=1764%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9738272', 'sentiment': 0.223529411764706, 'wgt': 458880063, 'relevance': 51}

"Oklahoma isn\'t intimidated as a football program. We\'re running towards the SEC."\n\nFearlessness aside, though, third-year coach Venables admittedly could not project how the Sooners\' relative Big 12 dominance would translate in the almighty SEC.\n\nPeople are also reading... Despite fame and fortune, Loggins was "still from Bristol" HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Coaching innovator Mumme to serve on Sullivan East coaching staff FOOTBALL CAMP: Former Tennessee QBs Hooker, Milton hosts football camp at Sullivan East Kings Dominion gets approval to build new roller coaster LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon falls in Virginia state title game AUTO RACING: Rural Retreat native Will Hostetler\'s a hometown hero at Wythe Raceway BHC GIRLS BASKETBALL COACH OF YEAR: Funk found redemption at Eastside Casino donations near $900,000 with Tuesday presentation LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon advances to title game Simmons to expand manufacturing into Russell County PREP BASEBALL: Porter Gobble (John Battle), Landon Turman (Abingdon), Hayden Reed (Abingdon) to play in Commonwealth Games McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic BHC BOYS BASKETBALL COACH OF YEAR: Bearcats reload, reach first state finals in 64 years HIGH SCHOOL ATHLETICS: Southern Gap Eagles coming soon when Buchanan schools consolidate LITTLE LEAGUE: Monday\'s State Tournament Results\n\nWith a 10-3 record and No. 15 Associated Press finish last season, Oklahoma among Big 12 brethren was only outranked by No. 3 Texas, which by the way lost to the Sooners 34-30 in October.\n\nConversely, five SEC teams ranked higher than OU: No. 4 Georgia, No. 5 Alabama, No. 8 Missouri, No. 9 Ole Miss and No. 12 LSU. With the exception of Georgia, four of those teams are on OU\'s 2024 schedule, three of them on the road, along with the annual clash against Texas in the Cotton Bowl.\n\n"I think going through it gives you the best litmus test. There\'s nothing that you can read about or even watch on tape, to be honest with you."\n\nBy most metrics, the Oklahoma program is much better positioned to contend in the SEC than this time a year ago, when it was coming off a 6-7 season and Venables appeared to be on tenuous ground in Norman.\n\nThen came a 6-0 start, including the upset of Texas, and a climb to as No. 6 in the country before stumbles at Kansas (38-33) and Oklahoma State (27-24).\n\nOn June 21 Venables received a six-year, $51.6 million contract - a reward not only for last season\'s bounce-back but his third straight top-ten-ranked recruiting class as OU strived to build an SEC-worthy roster after announcing in July of 2021 that it intended to bolt with Texas from the Big 12.\n\n"The trenches is where this conference is decided usually year-in and year-out; incredibly challenging from that standpoint," Venables said, adding these SEC traits. "The length; the speed; the play at quarterback; the coaching acumen from top to bottom."\n\nFor quarterback play, the Sooners are turning to their latest heralded prospect at that position, sophomore Jackson Arnold, the 2022 Gatorade National Player of the Year out of Denton Guyer.\n\nWith SEC Media Days taking place in Texas for the first time, Venables noted that nearly 20 Sooners are from Dallas-Fort Worth area high schools.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nCounting returning players and portal transfers, Venables estimated that 24 Sooners are entering their third year or more as starters.\n\nSenior linebacker Danny Stutsman, out of Windermere, Fla., initially decided to enter the 2024 NFL draft after earning second-team Walter Camp All-America honors last season. His OU locker was even cleared out, but he had a change of heart after meeting with Venables.\n\n"He told me, \'Look, Oklahoma is going to win with or without you.\' " Stutsman recalled Tuesday. "I fully believe that. The program has been amazing before I got here; it\'ll be amazing when I leave here."\n\nHave Venables and his staff built enough depth in the offensive and defensive lines to compete with the SEC\'s elite teams?\n\nVenables says he believes the program has 9-to-11 offensive linemen and 10-to-12 defensive linemen who are capable of playing "winning football."\n\n"There are several guys that maybe don\'t have the depth of experience, but I trust my eyes," he said, adding, "This is a game of development."\n\nThis inaugural season, Venables said, not only will reveal how SEC-ready the Sooners are as currently constructed, but player prototypes and positional needs going forward.\n\nOklahoma of course will be learning the ways of the SEC at the same time as its fellow Big 12 co-alpha dog, Texas, except now the schools will be part of a pack of Rottweilers.\n\nA reporter on Tuesday half-jokingly started to ask Venables whether he and Texas coach Steve Sarkisian would be sharing notes.\n\n"Probably not," Venables interjected before the reporter could finish the question.\n\nWill moving to the SEC in any way affect that rivalry, which dates to 1900?\n\n"It\'s as deep-seated and hate-filled and emotional of a rivalry as there is in all of college football," Venables said. "So I don\'t see how the conference affiliation will make a big difference."\n\nTexas won the first Big 12 title, in 1996, and last season\'s, though the Sooners dominated much of what occurred between.\n\nNow both schools will face multiple near-Texas-OU-caliber conference games every season.\n\n"If you think that one is emotionally taxing, you\'re going to go into a lot of venues that the pageantry is going to be real, the stadiums are going to be completely full," Venables said. "And a lot of people are going to hate your guts for three hours or so."\n\n____\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'heraldcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'HeraldCourier.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/ff/fffaa8f9-c7b6-5177-8ff2-891732098267/66972a5643dbd.image.jpg?crop=1764%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9738272', 'sentiment': 0.3647058823529412, 'wgt': 458879914, 'relevance': 26}

She claims the investigation did not violate the athletes\' civil rights.\n\nThe investigation began in September when more than two dozen people, including current and former athletes at Iowa and Iowa State, were charged with illegally placing bets by using other people\'s online gambling accounts.\n\nIn March, the Story County Attorney\'s Office dropped the charges against four of the athletes. {'uri': '8229121882', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '01:28:07', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T01:28:07Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T01:27:37Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8156862854957581, 'url': 'https://heraldcourier.com/sports/college/missouri-s-eliah-drinkwitz-calls-on-nff-to-allow-late-mike-leach-on-hall-of/article_9d1e636e-143d-5020-b312-bb873a0df01e.html', 'title': "Missouri's Eliah Drinkwitz calls on NFF to allow late Mike Leach on Hall of Fame ballot", 'body': 'Sasha Richie, The Dallas Morning News\n\nDALLAS -- Like most around the football world, Missouri head coach Eliah Drinkwitz would like to see the late Mike Leach inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame.\n\nDrinkwitz used his opening statement at SEC Media Days Tuesday to call on the National Football Foundation to allow Leach, the longtime coach of Texas Tech, on the Hall of Fame ballot, despite not meeting one of the criteria.\n\n"Yesterday in Commissioner [Greg] Sankey\'s remarks, he mentioned the new individuals that were going to be inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame ... and it reminded me to call on CEO Steve Hatchell to do the right thing and to nominate Mike Leach for the College Football Hall of Fame," he said at the podium.\n\n"We need to put his name on the ballot."\n\nLeach died unexpectedly of heart complications in 2022 while he was the head coach of Mississippi State. He finished his head coaching career with a .596 winning percentage, just shy of the Hall of Fame\'s .600 standard. If you changed one of his 107 career losses to a win, he would clear the bar and likely be a shoe-in.\n\nPeople are also reading... Despite fame and fortune, Loggins was "still from Bristol" HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Coaching innovator Mumme to serve on Sullivan East coaching staff FOOTBALL CAMP: Former Tennessee QBs Hooker, Milton hosts football camp at Sullivan East LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon falls in Virginia state title game Kings Dominion gets approval to build new roller coaster AUTO RACING: Rural Retreat native Will Hostetler\'s a hometown hero at Wythe Raceway BHC GIRLS BASKETBALL COACH OF YEAR: Funk found redemption at Eastside Casino donations near $900,000 with Tuesday presentation LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon advances to title game Simmons to expand manufacturing into Russell County PREP BASEBALL: Porter Gobble (John Battle), Landon Turman (Abingdon), Hayden Reed (Abingdon) to play in Commonwealth Games McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic BHC BOYS BASKETBALL COACH OF YEAR: Bearcats reload, reach first state finals in 64 years HIGH SCHOOL ATHLETICS: Southern Gap Eagles coming soon when Buchanan schools consolidate LITTLE LEAGUE: Monday\'s State Tournament Results\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\n"I understand that his career winning percentage is .596, one win short of the 60% threshold, and I understand that standards are there for people to make decisions," Drinkwitz said. "But I also understand that Coach Leach would be a great value to the Hall of Fame because of the legacy that he has, because of the impact that he made, because of the innovator that he was, because of the legacy of coaches that he left. In my opinion, not only a winner but a Hall of Famer."\n\nLeach coached college football for 35 years, spending the 21st century as head coach of Texas Tech, Washington State and Mississippi State. He pioneered the Air Raid offense and is credited with popularizing the scheme, now widely used at every level of the sport. His coaching tree is extensive, including big names like Baylor\'s Dave Aranda, TCU\'s Sonny Dykes, USC\'s Lincoln Riley, the Arizona Cardinals\' Kliff Kingsbury and Tennessee\'s Josh Heupel.\n\n"Coach Leach, in my mind, and I believe in most of the people in this room\'s mind, is a no-doubt Hall of Famer. He impacted our game more in the last 50 years than a lot of other people, not only with his legacy, but also with his football acumen," Drinkwitz said. "His Air Raid offense is the dominant offense when you look at high school football, its elements in college football, and all the way translating into the NFL. We all know Y-cross, we all know that six is four verticals. We all understand that rocket laser where tailback screens rocket to the right, laser to the left."\n\nFor coaches under 70 years old -- Leach was 61 when he passed -- three years must have passed since the end of their career before they can be nominated for the Hall of Fame by their schools. Texas Tech and Washington State have already said they will try to nominate Leach, according to The Athletic, meaning the ball is in the NFF\'s court as to whether they allow him on the ballot.\n\nWhile the organization hasn\'t made any definitive statements on Leach\'s eligibility, representatives from the NFF have defended their standards. Still, Drinkwitz called the decision "obvious."\n\n"I hope that Mr. Hatchell will recognize this. As the CEO, he has the ability to utilize his discretion to make the obvious into reality," Drinkwitz said. "That obvious is that the Hall of Fame is incomplete without Coach Mike Leach in it."\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'heraldcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'HeraldCourier.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/7/eb/7ebe5839-6a97-5635-aa4b-1d17a6d3f92a/66971c5b85433.image.jpg?crop=1528%2C802%2C0%2C277&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9738670', 'sentiment': 0.3176470588235294, 'wgt': 458875687, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '2024-07-424197779', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '01:24:43', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T01:24:43Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T23:45:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://lufkindailynews.com/news/local/mirz-brining-magic-show-to-pines-theater/article_d4e8615f-e7ad-526c-ac48-354faaa57f6f.html', 'title': 'Mirz brining magic show to Pines Theater', 'body': 'Zak Mirz will be at The Pines Theater to present a show Friday night.\n\nFor Zak Mirz, his shows are about much more than just magic. They\'re a combination of family, life and fun.\n\nSo if you\'re looking for a fun night out with the family, his show "Flashes of Magic" is just the right fit.\n\nThe entertainer who has worked with David Blaine and appeared on "Fool Us" with Penn & Teller will be in town at The Pines Theater Friday night.\n\n"It\'s a brand new show that\'s been out since June," Mirz said during a phone interview while he was on his way to Alabama Tuesday afternoon. "It\'s a family-friendly show. If anyone has seen anything on me or my previous work, this is a completely new show."\n\nLast year\'s show was titled "Ticket for One." The show coming to Lufkin, "Flashes of Magic," has a different story behind it.\n\n"My first special was a magic show, but it was also a love letter to my father," Mirz said. "Now my daughter just turned 2 last week. This is going to be a magic show and it\'s going to be interactive. It\'s a reminder to everyone that the greatest magic trick you can give yourself is showing the world through the lens of a child."\n\nMirz said his ties to magic go back several years. He is a first-generation American with his parents immigrating from Iran and Afghanistan.\n\nHe tragically lost his father, who was killed when Mirz was just a year old.\n\nOnce he was told of how his father died -- Mirz was approximately 8 at the time -- magic became an outlet for Mirz.\n\n"A lot of my magic is through stories," Mirz said. "I talk about the seasons of losing my father. He\'s my hero. He was a hero that night. He got killed saving so many lives.\n\n"I got into magic shortly after my mom told me what had happened to my dad. I was 8 or 9, and at the time I was embarrassed and sad. I wanted to keep it a secret so I ran to magic. There was the time when I saw the David Blaine special. I thought that\'s what I want to do for the rest of my life. David Blaine really had a big influence on me."\n\nHe said his official introduction to magic wasn\'t any kind of glamorous tale.\n\n"We couldn\'t Google back then," Mirz said. "It was my uncle looking through the yellow pages. They took me to a magic shop, which I think was in Dallas. It just said \'magic shop\' on the front. He took me there, I got a few things and it just went on and on. It\'s been a fun journey."\n\nHe admits the journey of being a magician isn\'t for everyone. He described that path along with the advice he would give to one of the ones he loves most.\n\n"I\'ve done it pretty much my whole life," Mirz said. "I graduated, packed my bags and hit the road. My life has been a little bit of a carnival. I wanted to start at a young age. I knew the more times I failed, the better I\'d be, so I started touring right out of high school. I certainly wouldn\'t wish this on my daughter. Hopefully I can encourage her to take another path."\n\nThat journey has taken him to different parts of the world.\n\nHe estimates he does approximately 120 shows a year. He has been on two tours to Europe and guesses he has performed in each state with the exception of possibly Maine and Alaska.\n\nIn the process, he has met up with some of the country\'s most recognizable names.\n\nHe was on the show "Fool Us," with Penn & Teller, two world-famous musicians.\n\n"I was on their TV show a couple of years ago," Mirz said. "The idea is a magician goes on the stage, and Penn & Teller, who are two of the greatest minds in magic, try to deconstruct the trick and tell you what you\'ve done. Very few magicians succeed. I was lucky enough to fool Penn & Teller. About a month ago, I flew back to Vegas and closed their show with that trick."\n\nIn addition, he was able to work for David Blaine on his show "The Magic Way."\n\n"It\'s amazing," Mirz said. "Magic is one of the few places you get to work with your heroes. He had a TV special \'The Magic Way\' back in 2020 on ABC. Everything was shut down during COVID and they asked if he could make a special. I got to work with him on one of the effects on the show."\n\nNow that journey is taking him to Lufkin Friday night. Despite living in Dallas, he said he doesn\'t remember staying in Lufkin but is excited to perform in town.\n\nHe gave the local audience a preview of what they can expect.\n\n"It\'s a family friendly show," Mirz said. "We\'re going to have a lot of people come on stage. That\'s part of almost every routine, bringing a mom or a dad, a brother or a sister, onto the stage and watching the rest of the family recording it. It\'s highly interactive.\n\n"It\'s amazing. You see standups all the time and they have their routine where it\'s just them. I always say their job is harder than mine. What I think makes my show so entertaining is who we bring on the stage. We try to bring big personalities up there."\n\nFans can learn more about Mirz\'s show at mirztour.com.\n\nTickets for the event can be purchased online at angelinaarts.org or at the box office the night of the event if still available.\n\nThe show starts at 7 p.m.', 'source': {'uri': 'lufkindailynews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Lufkin Daily News'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'josh_havard@lufkindailynews.com', 'name': 'Josh Havard', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/lufkindailynews.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/22/122d7c6b-1cf5-53eb-a7ad-da73ad059c7a/669712ad31a56.image.jpg?crop=1762%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=1200%2C631&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1137254901960785, 'wgt': 458875483, 'relevance': 33}

{'uri': '8229093176', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-17', 'time': '00:53:15', 'dateTime': '2024-07-17T00:53:15Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-17T00:50:12Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.benzinga.com/pressreleases/24/07/n39806009/miami-beach-visitor-and-convention-authority-takes-travelers-beyond-the-beach-this-season-with-exp', 'title': 'Miami Beach Visitor and Convention Authority Takes Travelers Beyond the Beach This Season with Experiential App Featuring Locally-Curated Itineraries', 'body': 'MIAMI BEACH, Fla. , July 16, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- The Miami Beach Visitor and Convention Authority (MBVCA) is giving travelers and beach-goers the tools they need to effortlessly go beyond the beach and make future plans through immersive technology. The new EXP Miami Beach Tours App, now available on Apple and Google, EXP Miami Beach Tours (EXPMiamiBeach.Tours), serves as an extension of the Experience Miami Beach App, a guide for sunseekers that delivers insider takes on the best ways to experience Miami Beach. EXP Miami Beach Tours App users can choose from a selection of curated itineraries including video and visual highlights and pins that allow travelers to self-guide their own day, weekend or week on Miami Beach.\n\n"While our shoreline is world-famous, Miami Beach is home to a variety of experiences, landmarks and installations that represent the history of our city and its global influence. The EXP Miami Beach Tours App takes our visitors on a journey beyond the beach to discover the diversity of our destination," says Peggy Benua, Chairwoman, Miami Beach Visitor and Convention Authority. "Our team has worked with local experts to craft itineraries that cater to varying travel styles and interests. This offering allows visitors to start planning their future visits with ease."\n\nThe EXP Miami Beach Tours App collectively showcases city expert picks and walks users through Miami Beach\'s iconic landmarks and activities including the Art Deco District, a public art collection, Michelin- recognized and awarded restaurants, LGBTQ+ landmarks, historic architecture and design and more. As an entity dedicated to equipping visitors with new resources and tools to make summer travel plans, the EXP Miami Beach Tours App is a strategic enhancement to the Miami Beach Visitor and Convention Authority\'s collection of offerings leveraging user-friendly technology to make planning even easier for future visitors. Travelers can identify the sites and experiences they prefer before they even arrive, leaving more time for them to enjoy the many offerings of Miami Beach. In addition to the EXP Miami Beach Tours App, a new video series highlighting a variety of ways to go beyond the beach will be released weekly on the Experience Miami Beach Instagram handle, featuring the city\'s rooftops, restaurants, pools, art installations and hidden gems.\n\n"We continue to see an increase in EXP Miami Beach Tours App downloads as we head into the back half of the summer season and travelers make future plans, validating the demand from visitors to source recommendations from local experts and resources" add Grisette Marcos, Executive Director, Miami Beach Visitor and Convention Authority. "In addition the EXP Miami Beach Tours App, local and national travel influencers and advisors have personally utilized the fingertip technology to discover new and unique experiences, installation and destinations that can only be found on Miami Beach."\n\nThose ready to become a Miami Beach insider this summer can download the EXP Miami Beach Tours App and now, sign up for a dedicated newsletter featuring events and special offers at destination hotels and restaurants at https://www.miamibeachvca.com/ and follow the @experiencemiamibeach handles on Instagram and Facebook.\n\nCONTACT: mbvca@privatelabel-marketing.com\n\nSOURCE Miami Beach Visitor and Convention Authority\n\nMarket News and Data brought to you by Benzinga APIs', 'source': {'uri': 'benzinga.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Benzinga'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://www.benzinga.com/next-assets/images/schema-image-default.png', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.2, 'wgt': 458873595, 'relevance': 76}
{'uri': '2024-07-424158382', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '23:55:04', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T23:55:04Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T22:41:53Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.9725490212440491, 'url': 'https://omaha.com/life-entertainment/nation-world/wellness/running-gave-him-purpose-after-learning-of-inherited-heart-condition/article_70155408-c71d-57c6-8bb2-a71bba713e26.html', 'title': 'Running gave him purpose after learning of inherited heart condition', 'body': 'At 11, Tom Sutch was playing street hockey when he saw his dad heading out for a work trip.\n\nTom waved goodbye as Kevin Sutch - an EMT in New York City and commissioner of their local volunteer fire department on Long Island - drove off to a fire safety conference a few hours away.\n\nTwo days later, Tom and his sister, Karen, came home from school to find the driveway filled with cars.\n\nTheir mother pulled them aside to tell them the news. Kevin had died in his sleep while out of town. He was 39.\n\nIt didn\'t make sense, Tom thought. His father saved people\'s lives. How could he lose his own while he was sleeping?\n\nA few weeks later, an autopsy report said the cause of death was sudden cardiac arrest possibly related to a calcified aortic valve.\n\nWere Kevin\'s heart problems genetic? Might he have passed something on to Tom and his siblings - Karen and brother, Brian? They went to a cardiologist to find out.\n\nNo problems were detected.\n\nNearly a decade later, one of Kevin\'s brothers began having fainting spells. He went to see a doctor about it. He mentioned that his (and Kevin\'s) mother had a history of seizures.\n\nThis led to genetic testing, something fairly new at the time and far more advanced than the screening Tom and his siblings had gone through.\n\nKevin\'s brother - thus, Tom\'s uncle - was found to have a marker for long QT syndrome, a condition that affects the heart\'s electrical system.\n\nEach heartbeat is mapped as five separate electrical waves. The electrical activity that occurs between the Q and T waves is called the QT interval. It shows electrical activity in the heart\'s lower chambers. A long QT interval can cause sudden, uncontrollable fast heart rhythms. The condition is rare, and not everyone who has it has dangerous heart rhythms. But when they do occur, they can be fatal.\n\nLooking back, the Sutch family could connect other episodes where the condition had likely gone undiagnosed - from seizures experienced by several family members to the sudden death of one of Kevin\'s sisters at age 13. And, of course, perhaps Kevin, too.\n\nSome 60 family members went for genetic testing. More than half tested positive, including Tom, Karen and Brian.\n\nThe doctor told the siblings that they would need to take beta blockers and have an implantable cardioverter defibrillator placed in the chest. If the device detects an abnormal heart rhythm, it delivers an electric shock to restore a normal heartbeat.\n\nTom got the defibrillator implanted just before returning to college for his senior year.\n\nAs difficult as that was, even worse was the litany of doctor\'s orders attached to the diagnosis: No strenuous activity, no heavy lifting and absolutely no contact sports. For a kid who grew up playing street hockey, then moved onto the ice, it was the end of his life as he knew it.\n\n"I was young and energetic with nowhere to put my energy," Tom said. "I just wanted to move my body."\n\nNeeding some outlet, he went jogging for the first time in his life. It soon became a positive among all the negatives.\n\nA couple years later, the family found a new electrophysiologist. This doctor was a runner, too, and he reassured Tom that his body wasn\'t as fragile as the previous specialist suggested.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"He made me feel like we could have normal lives if we do things with caution, instead of living our lives in fear of what could happen," Tom said.\n\nIn 2009, when he was 25, Tom ran his first half-marathon, training every week with childhood friends. Three years later, he ran a full marathon.\n\n"Running made me healthier, gave me discipline and resilience and, above all, it brought me a lot of joy," he said.\n\nOn Christmas Eve 2013, Tom\'s defibrillator started beeping. That meant the battery was low and he\'d need a new device.\n\nTom\'s recovery from the replacement surgery took longer than the original implant. His doctor advised him to not run for several months.\n\nTom gained weight, lost muscle mass and sunk into a depression. But he vowed to turn himself around by the following spring. To do that, he set his sights on a bigger goal: the New York City Marathon.\n\nTom finished the 2015 race, calling it "one of the most demanding and rewarding experiences of my life."\n\nThree years later, he did it again.\n\nSince then, Tom, who lives in Brooklyn and works for a television network in creative marketing, keeps upping the ante.\n\nA few years ago, he joined a hockey league. He wears extra padding to protect his defibrillator and keeps an eye on his heart rate.\n\n"It feels especially good because hockey was taken away from me," Tom said.\n\nBrian, now 42, also recently started playing hockey. Both he and Karen, who is 38, are each married with three children.\n\nTom\'s mother, Kim Halpin, has since remarried. She said that although the initial news about long QT was devastating, she didn\'t want it to define her children.\n\n"They could be afraid of everything, but they\'ve been trying to go on with their lives and not be in hiding," she said. "I\'m sure their father would want to see them happy."\n\nShe and Tom pointed to continued research and science, especially gene therapy, as good signs.\n\n"There\'s hope that future generations won\'t face the same uncertainties and challenges my family faced," Tom said. "We know more about long QT and are getting better at managing it. Medication is preferred over invasive surgery."\n\nThis year, Tom turned 40.\n\n"Even with all these personal accomplishments and proud moments, I can\'t help but feel the void of not having my dad there to see them," he said. "While I may never fully know the man he was, I try to live my life in a way that honors him."\n\nStories From the Heart chronicles the inspiring journeys of heart disease and stroke survivors, caregivers and advocates.\n\nAmerican Heart Association News\n\ncovers heart and brain health. Not all views expressed in this story reflect the official position of the American Heart Association. Copyright is owned or held by the American Heart Association, Inc., and all rights are reserved.', 'source': {'uri': 'omaha.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Omaha.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'diane_daniel@omaha.com', 'name': 'Diane Daniel', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/omaha.com/content/tncms/custom/image/9595a7a2-2379-11e7-b3c5-13eacc36a918.jpg?resize=600%2C315', 'eventUri': 'eng-9738847', 'sentiment': -0.05882352941176472, 'wgt': 458870104, 'relevance': 30}

Manila Standard', 'body': 'Russia on Tuesday demanded Google reinstate more than 200 Russian YouTube channels that the US company blocked due to spreading pro-Kremlin content, including over the conflict in Ukraine.\n\nRussian officials and politicians have repeatedly threatened to block the video-hosting platform, but have so far not moved to cut off access.\n\nRoskomnadzor, the country\'s communications regulator, wrote to Google CEO Sundar Pichai demanding that he "unblock more than 200 channels of media outlets, government bodies, sports clubs and political and artistic personalities that have supported the policies of Russia," the state-run TASS news agency reported.\n\nGoogle-owned YouTube has blocked access to dozens of channels linked to Russian state-funded media and figures that aggressively support Moscow\'s military offensive on Ukraine.\n\nMoscow has also blocked dozens of Western media outlets and deepened its control over the online space amid its military campaign.\n\nSpeculation over whether Russian authorities will outright block YouTube, one of the most popular media platforms in the country, has swirled amid the heightened pressure on US technology companies and media outlets.\n\nRussia outlawed Facebook and Instagram-owner Meta as an extremist organisation in 2022.\n\nLast week a Russian mobile operator, Rostelecom, said that speeds on YouTube had slowed down.\n\nIt blamed it on old equipment, but the announcement triggered a flurry of rumours and public concern that the authorities were behind the move -- something denied by the Kremlin, which also pointed to "problems with Google\'s technical equipment."', 'source': {'uri': 'manilastandard.net', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Manila Standard'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://cdn.manilastandard.net/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/nik-pYoj2nyokOg-unsplash-scaled.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.2313725490196078, 'wgt': 458868618, 'relevance': 100}

But the photos predate the July 13 shooting.', 'body': 'Did former President Donald Trump hit the golf course shortly after a gunman attempted to assassinate him at a July 13 campaign rally?\n\nWe were not able to get an answer to that question, but we do know some photos circulating that show him on a golf course are not proof that he did.\n\n"Imagine getting shot at 7pm and still making your 9am tee time," read text on a July 14 Instagram post that showed a photo of Trump driving a golf cart.\n\nThis post was flagged as part of Meta\'s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed. (Read more about our partnership with Meta, which owns Facebook and Instagram.) We also saw this photo being shared on X.\n\n(Screengrab from Instagram)\n\nThis photo of Trump playing golf is two years old. A reverse-image search using Google Images found that an Associated Press photographer took the photo in 2022 at Trump National Golf Course in Sterling, Virginia.\n\nA July 16 Threads post shared another photo that claimed to show Trump golfing after the shooting. But this photo appeared to originate from a YouTube video posted 10 days before the shooting.\n\nA shooter opened fire on Trump\'s July 13 campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, in what the FBI is investigating as an assassination attempt. Trump said a bullet hit the upper part of his right ear before he was escorted offstage and taken to a local hospital for treatment. One person in the audience was killed and two others were injured. The Secret Service said its snipers killed the gunman.\n\nThat night, Trump traveled to his home at Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, New Jersey.\n\nOn July 14, Trump posted on Truth Social that he would leave at 3:30 p.m. for the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee.\n\nClaims about Trump golfing following the shooting surfaced after Sen. Mike Lee, R-Utah, in a July 14 X post shared -- and later retracted -- a video that he said showed Trump went golfing "the next day" after the shooting. It was tagged with a community note that said the video was not filmed that day, July 14. In an update an hour after his X post, Lee said, "I\'m now told this video was uploaded today but *not* taken today. My bad!"\n\nThe TikTok account that posted the video is now private, so the video cannot be publicly viewed. An archived version of TikTok video showed it was published July 14.\n\nPolitiFact contacted Trump\'s campaign to ask whether Trump played golf during his short stay at the Bedminster golf club, but we did not receive a response by publication.\n\nTrump National Golf Club Bedminster was closed July 14, Politico reported.\n\nWe rate the claim that these photos show Trump golfing after being shot False.', 'source': {'uri': 'politifact.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Politi Fact'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'sara_swann@politifact.com', 'name': 'Sara Swann', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static.politifact.com/CACHE/images/tom_ruling_false_1/ea34b49abd5e30a026cfcbfff93f2bb3.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9740492', 'sentiment': 0.02745098039215677, 'wgt': 458867683, 'relevance': 51}

{'uri': '2024-07-424128451', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '22:46:37', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T22:46:37Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T22:00:13Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.6039215922355652, 'url': 'https://www.topspeed.com/every-toyota-hybrid/', 'title': 'Every Toyota Hybrid In 2024 Ranked By Horsepower', 'body': "Toyota's reputation as a pioneer in hybrid technology is well-deserved. Beginning with the launch of the Prius, which set a new standard for automotive innovation, Over the years, Toyota has continued to refine and expand its hybrid lineup, blending efficiency with performance to meet the diverse needs of modern drivers. At the heart of Toyota's hybrid cars lies a commitment to environmental sustainability without compromising on driving pleasure.\n\nThanks to the brand's innovative hybrid technology, these vehicles offer an impressive balance of horsepower and fuel efficiency, making them a compelling choice for those who seek both power and eco-friendliness. Whether navigating city streets or cruising on the highway, Toyota hybrids deliver a smooth and responsive driving experience. The synergy between the gasoline engine and electric motor not only enhances acceleration but also ensures a quieter ride and reduced emissions.\n\nToyota's hybrid technology seamlessly integrates with various models, from compact cars to SUVs, proving that efficiency can come in many shapes and sizes. As the automotive landscape continues to evolve, Toyota remains at the forefront, demonstrating that it's possible to enjoy a dynamic and engaging driving experience while contributing to a greener future.\n\nThe data used to compile this article was sourced from Toyota and other authoritative sources like the EPA and Car and Driver, ensuring the most up-to-date and accurate information possible.\n\nRelated\n\nEvery Toyota Hybrid SUV Ranked By Fuel Efficiency\n\nToyota has released a number of hybrid SUVs over the years, Here's how all of them stack up against each other in terms of fuel efficiency.\n\n15 2024 Toyota Corolla Hybrid\n\nPower Output: 138 Horses\n\nThe 2024 Corolla Hybrid strikes a perfect chord between efficiency and practicality. Under the hood lies a 1.8-liter four-cylinder engine paired with an electric motor, generating a combined output of 138 horsepower and 105 pound-feet of torque. This translates to smooth acceleration and a surprisingly sprightly response for a compact car.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nPowertrain\n\n1.8-liter four-cylinder hybrid\n\nHorsepower\n\n138 hp\n\nTorque\n\n105 lb-ft\n\nTransmission\n\nECVT\n\nDriveline\n\nFWD or AWD\n\nFuel Economy\n\n50 MPG combined\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n9 seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n114 mph\n\nBut, where the Corolla Hybrid truly shines is in its fuel economy. Thanks to Toyota's proven Hybrid Synergy Drive system, you can expect an impressive 53 miles per gallon (MPG) in city driving and 46 MPG on the highway, reaching a combined EPA-estimated rating of 50 MPG. The electronically controlled continuously variable transmission (ECVT) ensures a seamless transition between electric and gasoline power, making your ride quiet and refined. The Hybrid variant of the Corolla starts at $23,500.\n\n14 2024 Toyota Prius\n\nPower Output: 196 horses\n\nThe 2024 Toyota Prius offers a compelling blend of eco-friendly performance and practicality, earning TopSpeed's Best Small-Sized Sedan of 2024 award. The heart of the Prius lies in its hybrid powertrain, which combines a 2.0-liter four-cylinder Atkinson-cycle engine with two electric motors. This innovative setup generates a combined 194 horsepower and 139 pound-feet of torque for surprisingly brisk acceleration, especially when compared to previous generations of the Prius.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nPowertrain\n\n2.0-liter four-cylinder hybrid\n\nHorsepower\n\n194 hp\n\nTorque\n\n139 lb-ft\n\nTransmission\n\nCVT\n\nDriveline\n\nFWD or AWD\n\nFuel Economy\n\n52 MPG combined\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n7.0-7.2 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n112 mph\n\nThe 2024 Prius remains a champion in efficiency, with an astounding 52 MPG estimated by the EPA in city and highway combined driving. It also offers available all-wheel drive (AWD) for those who need extra traction in various weather conditions. This AWD system utilizes a separate rear-mounted electric motor, adding a slight bump in total horsepower to 196. The MSRP on the 2024 Prius is $45,020.\n\n13 2024 Toyota Corolla Cross Hybrid\n\nPower Output: 196 Horses\n\nThe 2024 Toyota Corolla Cross Hybrid combines practicality with impressive fuel efficiency. Under the hood, a 2.0-liter four-cylinder engine works with three electric motors for a combined output of 196 horsepower and 151 pound-feet of torque. This provides a more spirited driving experience compared to the standard Corolla Cross, achieving 0-60 mph in just 7.3 seconds. All-wheel drive comes standard, ensuring better traction in various conditions. The Corolla Cross Hybrid starts at $28,220.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nPowertrain\n\n2.0-liter four-cylinder hybrid\n\nHorsepower\n\n196 hp\n\nTorque\n\n151 lb-ft\n\nTransmission\n\nCVT\n\nDriveline\n\nAWD\n\nFuel Economy\n\n42 MPG combined\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n7.3 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n113 mph\n\nThe Corolla Cross Hybrid truly shines in fuel economy.
