Power is delivered through a continuously variable automatic transmission (CVT), known for its smooth and efficient operation.\n\nRelated\n\n2024 Toyota RAV4 Hybrid Pricing And Features By Trim Level\n\nAvailable in seven trims to pick from, the 2024 Toyota RAV4 Hybrid offers impressive fuel efficiency and a plethora of features.\n\n12 2024 Toyota RAV4 Hybrid\n\nPower Output: 219 Horses\n\nThe 2024 RAV4 Hybrid seamlessly blends adventure-ready capability with impressive fuel efficiency. Its hybrid powertrain comprises a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine that works in harmony with three electric motors to deliver a combined output of 219 horsepower and 163 pound-feet of torque. This punchy powertrain translates to confident acceleration on highways and a surprising amount of muscle for tackling off-road trails, all while standard all-wheel drive provides added traction in any condition.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nPowertrain\n\n2.5-liter four-cylinder hybrid\n\nHorsepower\n\n219 hp\n\nTorque\n\n163 lb-ft\n\nTransmission\n\nECVT\n\nDriveline\n\nAWD\n\nFuel Economy\n\n39 MPG combined\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n7.8 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n112 mph\n\nToyota's intelligent hybrid system delivers an impressive combined EPA estimated rating of 39 MPG. The RAV4 Hybrid also promises a comfortable and engaging driving experience thanks to its electronically controlled continuously variable transmission (ECVT), which ensures a smooth and quiet ride and seamlessly transitions between electric and gasoline power for optimal performance and efficiency. The Toyota RAV4 Hybrid starts at $31,725.\n\n11 2024 Toyota Venza\n\nPower Output: 219 Horses\n\nThe 2024 Toyota Venza redefines the hybrid experience for the modern driver. At its heart lies a sophisticated hybrid powertrain that seamlessly blends a 2.5-liter four-cylinder engine with an electric motor. This intelligent combination produces a robust 219 horsepower and 163 pound-feet of torque, ensuring confident acceleration and a pleasurable driving experience without sacrificing fuel efficiency.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nPowertrain\n\n2.5-liter four-cylinder hybrid\n\nHorsepower\n\n219 hp\n\nTorque\n\n163 lb-ft\n\nTransmission\n\nECVT\n\nDriveline\n\nAWD\n\nFuel Economy\n\n39 MPG combined\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n7.6 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n118 mph\n\nToyota's meticulous engineering truly pays off when it comes to the Venza's fuel economy. The car boasts an impressive 39 miles per gallon (MPG) combined, thanks in part to its self-charging hybrid system that eliminates the need for external plug-in charging. This translates to exceptional range and fewer trips to the gas station, making the Venza a perfect choice for eco-conscious drivers who don't want to compromise on performance. The Toyota Venza has an MSRP of $35,070.\n\n10 2025 Toyota Camry Hybrid\n\nPower Output: 225-232 Horses\n\nThe 2025 Toyota Camry Hybrid isn't your average eco-conscious car. It boasts a sophisticated powertrain that combines a 2.5-liter Dynamic Force four-cylinder engine with an electric motor for a net system output of 225 horsepower (232 with AWD) and 163 pound-feet of torque. This marriage of electric and gasoline power delivers a surprising punch, making highway merging and passing maneuvers a breeze.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nPowertrain\n\n2.0-liter four-cylinder hybrid\n\nHorsepower\n\n225-232 hp\n\nTorque\n\n163 lb-ft\n\nTransmission\n\nECVT\n\nDriveline\n\nFWD or AWD\n\nFuel Economy\n\n46 MPG combined\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n7.6 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n135 mph\n\nToyota's engineers haven't sacrificed performance for efficiency. The 2025 Camry Hybrid starts at $28,855.\n\n9 2024 Toyota Crown\n\nPower Output: 236-340 Horses\n\nBreaking tradition, the 2024 Toyota Crown boasts a bold design for a midsize car. The video of Gass was widely circulated on social media.\n\n"I was blindsided by what was said at the show on Sunday. I would never condone hate speech or encourage political violence in any form," Black said in a Tuesday statement on Instagram. {'uri': '2024-07-424098879', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '21:53:41', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T21:53:41Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T16:04:12Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://carbuzz.com/mini-may-revive-manual-transmission/', 'title': 'Mini Keeps Our Manual Hopes And Dreams Alive', 'body': 'Key Takeaways\n\nMini lineup for 2025 lacks manual transmissions due to low demand and emission regulations. Mini is open to reintroducing manual transmissions, possibly in an electric vehicle. Potential return of manual transmissions could be seen in upcoming JCW Cooper model, where take rates have historically been high.\n\nMuch to the chagrin of car enthusiasts, the 2025 Mini lineup no longer includes any manual transmissions; both the 2025 Mini Cooper and 2025 Mini Countryman send power through a seven-speed dual-clutch transmission. Speaking with Vice President of Mini of the Americas Michael Peyton, this may not be the case forever. Although manual transmissions are less popular than their two-pedal alternatives, their gradual extinction has been noticed by keen driving enthusiasts, and many automakers are reevaluating whether to introduce the stick shift.\n\n"I wouldn\'t say never on the manual transmission," Peyton told CarBuzz on Mini Takes the States, an event where owners drive across multiple US states. "It\'s not a never again."\n\n2025 Mini John Cooper Works Countryman ALL4\n\n7.6/10\n\nWhat is Buzzscore?\n\nWhy The Manual Died\n\nMini used to offer a manual transmission on every single model but has since moved away from it due to several factors, including low take rate and global emissions regulations. "The manual take rate was only around 6% for the whole brand, though the Cooper three-door was much higher," Peyton explained. In the final year it was offered, the John Cooper Works Cooper three-door saw a 51% take rate. The Cooper S was much lower at around 22%.\n\nAdd CarBuzz to your Google News feed.\n\nFollow On\n\nGoogle News\n\nPeyton explained that keeping the manual transmission became a scale issue, even if the take rate was higher. As a reminder, Mini sold 33,497 units in the US last year (2023), which was a 13.5% increase from 2022. Even counting global sales, Mini sold 295,358 units worldwide. To put that into perspective, Mini\'s parent company BMW sold 362,244 units in the US alone. To continue offering a second transmission for such a low-volume product would be a tough business case.\n\nClose\n\nWhen Could The Manual Return?\n\nIt\'s unclear what form the manual transmission could take in the future, but Peyton said Mini was "looking into" ways to offer some form of shifting in an electric vehicle. We presume it could be similar to what Hyundai offers in the Ioniq 5 N, which has received rave reviews. This is only speculation on our part, but Mini could also tap into its heritage by giving EV owners the ability to choose from iconic sounds, such as the original Cooper or the supercharged (later turbocharged) GP model.\n\nIf Mini wants to bring back the manual in a traditional sense, CarBuzz suggests Mini satisfies the demand by offering the transmission as an option on the upcoming JCW Cooper, which has yet to be announced, since that model had the highest take rate in previous years. If you were holding out on buying a new Mini with a third pedal, there may be a small glimmer of hope. Our prediction: you may not have to wait much longer.\n\nRelated\n\n10 Manual Performance Alternatives For Half The Price Of The 2025 BMW M2\n\nYou\'ve got plenty of manual sports coupes to pick from for half the price of a 2025 BMW M2.', 'source': {'uri': 'carbuzz.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'CarBuzz'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'jared_rosenholtz@carbuzz.com', 'name': 'Jared Rosenholtz', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static0.carbuzzimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/cobb-testfest-021122-19532v2-1.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.0980392156862746, 'wgt': 458862821, 'relevance': 56}
{'uri': '2024-07-424098882', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '21:53:37', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T21:53:37Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T18:29:13Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7254902124404907, 'url': 'https://carbuzz.com/hyundai-three-row-electric-suv-launch-confirmed-2024/', 'title': "This Is When Hyundai's Rivian R1S Rival Will Arrive", 'body': 'Key Takeaways\n\nHyundai teases new electric SUV with 3 rows of seating, likely based on the Hyundai Seven Concept. Production version will have traditional seating, underpinned by the E-GMP platform and offer two powertrain options. Potentially named Ioniq 9, this SUV aims to rival the Kia EV9 with a more conservative design and tech-laden cabin.\n\nHyundai has announced that it will introduce an all-new electric SUV this year. Almost no information was provided, with the automaker only confirming that the new arrival will have three rows of seating and that the world premiere will take place "later in 2024." Despite the vagueness of the announcement, it\'s all but assured that the Korean automaker is referring to the production version of the Hyundai Seven Concept, revealed near the end of 2021. Much like the Kia Concept EV9, this futuristic electric SUV envisioned a cabin where occupants are perched on a curved bench or swiveling lounge chairs, but the production version of the Kia SUV suggests a much more toned-down approach. Remember, Hyundai\'s new SUV must effectively replace the gas-powered Palisade.\n\n2024 Hyundai Palisade\n\n8.4/10\n\nWhat is Buzzscore?\n\nBase MSRP $36,650\n\nEngine 3.8L V6 Gas\n\nHorsepower 291 hp\n\nTorque 262 lb-ft\n\nTransmission 8-speed Automatic\n\nTowing Capacity 5,000 lbs\n\nFuel Economy 19/26/22 mpg (FWD) | 29/24/21 mpg (AWD)\n\nExpand\n\nWhat Can We Expect?\n\nInstead of an open-plan cabin with unusual seating, the three-row SUV will seat seven or eight in the traditional fashion. They will be packaged in a car that is underpinned by Hyundai\'s modular E-GMP platform, which also forms the basis of the Ioniq 5 hatchback and its Kia EV6 sibling, as well as the Kia EV9 SUV (and the smaller Kia EV3). In the EV9, two powertrain options are on offer, with the standard one comprising a 76.1 kWh battery and a 215-horsepower rear motor.\n\nAdd CarBuzz to your Google News feed.\n\nFollow On\n\nGoogle News\n\nAlternatively, a 99.8 kWh battery can be had for up to 300 miles of range, or you can step up to a dual-motor variant with 379 hp and AWD. There\'s also a high-performance EV9 GT coming next year, so we wouldn\'t be surprised if Hyundai\'s seven-seater is later offered in Ioniq 7 N form. Or would that be Ioniq 9 N form?\n\nClose\n\nHyundai Doesn\'t Know What To Call Its EV9 Alternative\n\nAs we touched on earlier, the concept of Korea\'s new electric SUV was called the Seven, so it makes sense for the production version to get similar nomenclature so that buyers make the association, especially since when the Ioniq sub-brand was launched, a three-row SUV called the 7 was said to be in the works. However, with the Kia EV9 using a higher number, Hyundai may be worried that consumers may think the Ioniq SUV is a lesser vehicle than its nearly identical Kia cousin.\n\nAccording to insider sources, the Ioniq 7 may be renamed Ioniq 9, and if true, this would open up more opportunities for niche-filling in the future. With little to go on for now, we can only wait for more information from Hyundai, but spy shots suggest a more conservative design than the EV9 on the outside and a tech-laden experience in the cabin. Keep your fingers crossed for a debut at the LA Auto Show (November 22-December 1).\n\nRelated\n\nHyundai Invents The Ultimate Party Tailgate\n\nThis looks perfect for a beach day or a pre-game tailgate party!', 'source': {'uri': 'carbuzz.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'CarBuzz'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'sebastian_cenizo@carbuzz.com', 'name': 'Sebastian Cenizo', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static0.carbuzzimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/hyundai-seven_concept-2021-1600-09.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9734146', 'sentiment': -0.1843137254901961, 'wgt': 458862817, 'relevance': 29}
{'uri': '8228950237', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '21:53:16', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T21:53:16Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T21:52:43Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7098039388656616, 'url': 'https://napavalleyregister.com/news/state-regional/athletics-temporary-sacramento-ballpark-will-have-hydration-element-because-of-summer-heat/article_a34e9510-e4c2-54ca-a106-70f4b9baa8f9.html', 'title': "Athletics' temporary Sacramento ballpark will have hydration element because of summer heat", 'body': 'By RONALD BLUM - AP Baseball Writer\n\nARLINGTON, Texas (AP) -- A new artificial turf surface at the Oakland Athletics\' temporary home in Sacramento, California, will have a hydration element because of summer heat at the open-air ballpark.\n\n"We think that\'s the best that we can do in terms of playing surface in the heat," baseball Commissioner Rob Manfred said Tuesday.\n\nSutter Health Park\'s field will be changed from grass to synthetic before the A\'s move there for the 2025-27 seasons ahead of an intended relocation to a new fixed-roof ballpark planned to open in Las Vegas for 2028.\n\nDaily highs in Sacramento from July 1-9 averaged 106 (41 Celsius) and similar temperatures are forecast from Sunday through July 25. Temperatures in the past have reached 115 degrees (46 Celsius), according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.\n\nOakland will share the ballpark with the San Francisco Giants\' Triple-A River Cats, necessitating up to 153 regular-season games over 186 days. Murray Cook, MLB\'s field and stadium consultant, has worked on the surface selection process with the Major League Baseball Players Association.\n\nPeople are also reading... $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Ryan Seacrest\'s Napa County home up for sale at $22 million Customers are raving about Moulin -- downtown Napa\'s new café and bakery Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 St. Helena Cyclery to reopen in wake of Trek\'s closure Letter: Concerns about St. Helena Agritourism Initiative Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Napa City Council to weigh selling land for downtown development Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life Napa judge declines to remove temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos Defendants in Napa double murder delay pleas to Sept. 17 Why is that? Here\'s the lowdown on some Napa head-scratchers Napa County, Hoopes winery file closing arguments in legal clash Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive\n\n"The vast, vast majority of the games can be played at night when it\'s cooler," Manfred told the Baseball Writers\' Association of America. "We picked the playing surface in consultation with the MLBPA and Murray Cook, and it has a specific hydration component to it in terms of water being added to it to cool the surface."\n\nMLB said choosing the underlying infrastructure beneath the turf was still in the process of being finalized.\n\nFive of MLB\'s 30 ballparks currently have artificial turf, four with retractable roofs and the Tampa Bay Rays\' Tropicana Field with a fixed dome. Outdoor stadiums with artificial turf led to extremely high field temperatures from the early 1970s to the mid-1990s. Former Cardinals third baseman Keith Hernandez in 2010 recalled the surface temperature in St. Louis reaching 148 (64 Celsius), causing the cleats of outfielder Reggie Smith to melt.\n\nA new home clubhouse is being planned for behind home plate but the visiting clubhouse will remain beyond the outfield. An outfield clubhouse was famously at the Polo Grounds, home of the New York Giants and Mets.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"Obviously, we have no control over where the league decides to to play games or put teams," players\' association head Tony Clark told the BBWAA, speaking before Manfred. "At the point in time they make that determination is when we lean in to ensure the health and safety and well-being of the players that are going to play there. Obviously, there\'s been a lot of dialogue of late about the warmth and the time of day and the scheduling."\n\nOakland\'s lease at the Coliseum expires after this season, and the A\'s announced in the spring of 2023 their intent to move to Las Vegas. Nevada\'s government last year granted $380 million in public financing and MLB owners approved the move in November.\n\nLed by managing partner John Fisher, the A\'s will have to arrange additional financing for the ballpark.\n\nA meeting of the Las Vegas Stadium Authority Board is scheduled for Thursday and supplemental financing could be discussed. The A\'s asked that a non-relocation agreement include a provision for up to eight home games a year to be played elsewhere -- MLB picks teams for international events at special U.S. sites such as the Field of Dreams location in Iowa.\n\n"I talk to John regularly. I am comfortable with the progress they\'ve made with respect to the construction of the stadium in Las Vegas and his ability to put together the financing necessary to get that stadium constructed," Manfred said.\n\nOakland Mayor Sheng Thao faces a possible recall election in November. Manfred said her status would not impact a move.\n\n"Our Oakland decisions have been made and what happens politically in Oakland is between the citizens of Oakland and their elected officials," he said.\n\nAP Sports Writer Mark Anderson in Las Vegas contributed to this report.\n\nAP MLB: https://apnews.com/MLB\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. I would never condone hate speech or encourage political violence in any form," Black said in a Tuesday statement on Instagram. "After much reflection, I no longer feel it is appropriate to continue the Tenacious D tour, and all future creative plans are on hold. I am grateful to the fans for their support and understanding."\n\nFollowing Black\'s statement, Gass apologized on Instagram.\n\n"The line I improvised Sunday night in Sydney was highly inappropriate, dangerous and a terrible mistake," he wrote Tuesday. "I don\'t condone violence in any kind, in any form, against anyone. What happened was a tragedy, and I\'m incredibly sorry for my severe lack of judgement."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nThe band recently completed dates in the U.S. and Europe. Their "Spicy Meatball Tour" was slated to continue Tuesday night in Newcastle, hitting most major cities in Australia and New Zealand this month before returning to the U.S. for a select few dates in October.\n\nMusic\n\nSinger Ingrid Andress says she was drunk during panned MLB anthem performance, will get treatment\n\nBy MARIA SHERMAN AP Music Writer\n\n"Frontier Touring regret to advise that Tenacious D\'s concert tonight at Newcastle Entertainment Centre has been postponed," their touring company announced in a statement on Instagram Tuesday. "Ticket holders are asked to hold onto their tickets until further information is available."\n\nWhen asked for further comment, a represented for the band directed the Associated Press back to Black\'s statement. It's the EV benchmark, the speed demon that everyone wants to outpace, or at least match. But, guess what? There are some fierce contenders out there giving the Plaid a serious run for its money. We're talking about electric marvels like the Rimac Nevera, which has smashed records and left jaws dropping with its blistering performance. This beast of a machine doesn't just keep up with the Plaid -- it's rewriting the rules of what electric cars can do.\n\nThen there's the Nio EP9, a sleek and stylish speedster that's almost in Tesla's rearview mirror. It might not have the Plaid's exact numbers, but it comes dangerously close, making it a thrilling alternative for those who crave excitement and innovation. And, these aren't the only ones; there are other electrifying contenders that are challenging the Plaid's dominance, each with its unique flair and impressive stats. Here are six electric cars that can keep up with the Tesla Model S Plaid, and four that almost make the cut.\n\nRelated\n\n10 Electric Supercars That Aren't As Fast As The Tesla Model S Plaid\n\nTesla's premier performance model outperforms these 10 substantially more expensive supercar rivals.\n\nIn order to give you the most up-to-date and accurate information possible, the data used to compile this article was sourced from various manufacturer websites and other authoritative sources. The first six models listed here are faster than the Model S Plaid, and the last four are ones that are close.\n\n1 Rimac Nevera\n\nTop Speed: 258 MPH\n\nIf there's one electric car that's grabbed headlines and turned heads, it's the Rimac Nevera. This Croatian marvel isn't just about looks; it's an engineering masterpiece that broke records and redefined what's possible in the EV world. {'uri': '8228777055', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '19:04:54', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T19:04:54Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T19:04:13Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://buffalonews.com/news/local/hamburg-nike-base-ice-rink-delays-hockey/article_2207bb3c-4387-11ef-8fa9-f7f384705360.html', 'title': "Mid-November 'best case' scenario for renovated Hamburg rink opening", 'body': 'Hamburg town officials still don\'t know how long the Nike base ice arena will remain closed for renovations, but said this week it could be until mid- to late November.\n\nHamburg ice arena\'s September opening in doubt. Finger-pointing has started\n\nHamburg Town Board members learned at this week\'s regular meeting there are some issues with renovations at the ice arena that could delay the winter hockey and skating season.\n\n"Pushing us back to Nov. 15 is really going to hurt Hamburg hockey," Dave McDermott, president of Hamburg Hawks Hockey, told Town Board members during a special meeting Monday night.\n\nHe said the club, which has about 600 children skating in house and travel teams, is scrambling to find ice time at other rinks. The travel teams are in good shape, and the club plans to go ahead with its house season, which usually starts in October, he said.\n\nPublic Works Superintendent Kenneth Kostowniak said opening the rink Nov. 15 would be the "best case" scenario.\n\nTown Board members approved $63,000 in change orders to cover repairs that were discovered when the renovations started in mid-April, after the last season ended and the ice melted two days later, officials said.\n\nPeople are also reading... He said Tuesday he still believes that.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe board voted in May to borrow $3 million for a $4.5 million project that includes improvements to the refrigeration and dehumidification systems, the demolition and replacement of the ice rink flooring and related cooling pipes, and improvements to the locker room and restroom facilities.\n\nBoard members said they were unaware of the possible lengthy delay until last week\'s meeting, when a member of the public said he\'d heard the ice arena would not be available until December or January.\n\nKostowniak said Monday he did not have all the information on the repairs needed, and cost estimates, until the day after that meeting.\n\n"It put a lot of fear in the hockey community," Council Member Daniel Kozub said.\n\nIn addition to hockey, the arena also is home to the adaptive skating program Gliding Stars, learn to skate and figure skating, skate and shoot and open skate programs.\n\nOne of the change orders involves shortening the rink from 207 feet long to the NHL length of 200 feet. Kostowniak said that helps the project, giving more room between new locker rooms and the ice.\n\nThe most expensive change order is $32,000 to fix the uneven subfloor. Kostowniak said the biggest delay now will be waiting for the concrete pad to cure, which will take 28 days.\n\n"I want to make sure this is built right," the public works superintendent said. "I\'m not going to get hung up on a deadline."\n\nThe board directed Kostowniak to send a status report every Friday afternoon to board members and is requiring the contractor to update the board at the start of every work session.\n\nBoard members also scheduled an informational meeting for the public to receive updates at 4 p.m. Aug. 19.\n\n0 Comments Get local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. He has an associate of science degree from Butte College.\n\nRyan has served in Cal Fire\'s Sonoma-Lake-Napa Unit since joining the state agency as a firefighter in 2001. Among other stations, he worked in Gordon Valley and at Spanish Flat near Lake Berryessa. Both are in Napa County.\n\nPeople are also reading... $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Ryan Seacrest\'s Napa County home up for sale at $22 million Customers are raving about Moulin -- downtown Napa\'s new café and bakery Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 St. Helena Cyclery to reopen in wake of Trek\'s closure Letter: Concerns about St. Helena Agritourism Initiative Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Napa City Council to weigh selling land for downtown development Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life Napa judge declines to remove temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos Defendants in Napa double murder delay pleas to Sept. 17 Why is that? Here\'s the lowdown on some Napa head-scratchers Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Napa County, Hoopes winery file closing arguments in legal clash Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nHe worked as a fire apparatus engineer, spending four years at the station in Yountville. He most recently served as the unit\'s deputy chief of state operations, overseeing unit operations in six North Bay counties, the emergency command center in St. Helena, and the aviation and camp programs, the news release said.\n\nMike Marcucci previously served as unit chief and Napa County fire chief. Marcucci retired from Cal Fire on June 28 to become a Marin County Fire division chief, as well as director of the Marin Emergency Command Center.\n\nNapa County has contracted with Cal Fire to run its fire department since the 1930s. The department has 20 stations in the rural county that use both volunteer and career firefighters.\n\nThe Sonoma-Lake-Napa Unit is responsible for protecting 2.3 million acres in Napa, Sonoma, Lake, Colusa, Solano and Yolo counties.\n\nPHOTOS: Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Baseball Tournament U17 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 2 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 1 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 3 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 4 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 5 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 6 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 7 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 8 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 9 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 10 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 11 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 12 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 13 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 14 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 15 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 16 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 17 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 18 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 19 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 20 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 21 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 22 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 23\n\nYou can reach Barry Eberling at 707-256-2253 or beberling@napanews.com\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. Sign Up Today', 'source': {'uri': 'napavalleyregister.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Napa Valley Register'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'barry_eberling@napavalleyregister.com', 'name': 'Barry Eberling', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/napavalleyregister.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/4/dd/4dddfff0-4382-11ef-b183-0f5293044d72/6696a3ec6bff0.preview.png?crop=417%2C219%2C0%2C8&resize=417%2C219&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.2470588235294118, 'wgt': 458845217, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '2024-07-423863758', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '16:36:17', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T16:36:17Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T16:35:28Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.tntmagazine.com/leisure-entertainment/technology/finding-a-needle-in-a-digital-haystack-the-art-and-science-of-skip-tracing/', 'title': 'Finding A Needle In A Digital Haystack: The Art And Science Of Skip Tracing - TNT Magazine', 'body': 'When you think about the sheer volume of information that you can find about the average person online, you might assume that it\'s difficult to truly "disappear." However, you should never underestimate the perseverance of those who do not wish to be found. Regardless of the reason, many people are actively trying to disappear online - and they\'ll go to enormous lengths to successfully do it.\n\nMaking sense of that particular puzzle represents the daily grind of a skip tracing professional. These are hardworking men and women who locate those who do not wish to be found, often reuniting creditors with the debtors who seem to have vanished overnight. If skip tracing sounds a bit like finding a needle in a (digital) haystack, that\'s because it often feels that way. But it\'s every bit as much an art as it is a science for several reasons, all of which are worth a closer look.\n\nSkip Tracing: The Tools of the Trade\n\nFor many years, public record databases have been a big part of the toolbox of any skip tracing professional. Certain types of documents -- like those about past or active court cases -- are very difficult to truly "hide" from. Skip tracers look over court documents, car registrations, and even voter registrations -- all in the name of trying to figure out where someone is based on where they likely were.\n\nBut thanks to the rate at which technology continues to advance, the types of "databases" that skip tracers can draw information from are constantly changing. Social media platforms can tell you who someone is friends with and who they\'ve recently interacted with. If you know how to use more advanced search techniques on a site like Google, you may uncover someone\'s personal website or an online profile you didn\'t know existed. Even reverse phone lookup services have changed the game in terms of what is possible and how quickly you can accomplish it.\n\nAs the volume of information that skip tracers work with has changed, many find success in combining cutting-edge technologies with old-school detective work. This has proven to be a great match in terms of finding hidden clues to navigate the murky online world someone might be attempting to hide in.\n\nFor the sake of example, say you were looking for a person, and you happened to find their personal Facebook profile. It is short on actionable information, but it does lead you to the profile of someone they know who is much more open. If you do enough digging, you may even find their phone number.\n\nA skip tracer would either call them directly to see if they can help get into contact with the target or use a reverse phone lookup service to find out more information about their address and other contact details. This would then help the skip tracer determine a more precise geographic area that they should be focusing their efforts on.\n\nThe Intrigue of Skip Tracing\n\nAgain, even in the digital realm, there\'s no hiding from a skilled investigator. Think about the fact that most people take photos these days with a smartphone. That smartphone contains a GPS chip -- that\'s how you\'re able to use apps like Waze to get turn-by-turn directions to a destination.\n\nAs a byproduct of that, the GPS chip adds precise location metadata to any photo you take unless you expressly turn it off - which most people don\'t do. If the target takes a photo and uploads it to Facebook, a skilled investigator might be able to download it, read that location metadata, and see exactly where it was taken.\n\nOf course, these have been mostly straightforward examples of what it is possible to do with the power of modern technology by your side. There\'s nothing stopping anyone from scouring over someone\'s Facebook profile to get a sense of their whereabouts - it doesn\'t take a seasoned skip tracer to do that.\n\nData mining and analysis tools, on the other hand, are a bit more sophisticated. Based on the sheer volume of data you collect, these tools can help you identify trends and patterns that you may otherwise have missed. They can even use past location data to predict where someone might be headed with an accuracy far greater than a human might be able to on their own.\n\nThere is also a wide range of digital forensics tools that professional skip tracers often employ. Data can be recovered and analyzed from virtually any source, such as smartphones or other types of electronic devices.\n\nThis is all that is meant by saying that skip tracing is a bit like finding a needle in a digital haystack. Not only could the person you\'re trying to find be virtually anywhere but there are also so many techniques you can use to begin your search. But soon enough, little by little, you do begin to chip away at the facade they\'ve constructed for themselves. At that point, you begin to realize that finding them is truly only a matter of "when," not "if." From that point of view, the digital skip tracer and the old-school detective do have a lot in common.\n\nIn the end, skip tracing is about a lot more than using modern technology to locate those who have "skipped town" (no pun intended). It\'s primarily following a trail of clutches that will help people solve a mystery -- one that just happens to be taking place primarily in the digital world.\n\nYes, sometimes that involves a debt collector trying to find someone who is going to great lengths to avoid paying that which they rightfully owe. But it\'s also about shining a light into the digital shadows. It\'s used in real estate, in the legal profession, and more - and it\'s a technique that is only going to get more powerful as technology continues to advance over the next decade and beyond.', 'source': {'uri': 'tntmagazine.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'TNT Magazine'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://www.tntmagazine.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Shutterstock_1695248794-jpg.webp', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.09019607843137245, 'wgt': 458843777, 'relevance': 32}

Andress is a four-time Grammy-nominated country artist best known for her song titled, "More Hearts Than Mine."\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHere\'s video of Andress\' performance:\n\nAdvertisement\n\nRangers\n\nBe the smartest Rangers fan. Get the latest news.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogle\n\nFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\nCritics wasted no time comparing Andress\' performance to Fergie\'s, which notably gained widespread attention as some of the NBA\'s best struggled to hold back their laughter. {'uri': '8228540488', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '15:58:48', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T15:58:48Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T15:58:18Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8509804010391235, 'url': 'https://www.nwitimes.com/news/state-and-regional/indiana/chinese-swimmers-will-be-under-scrutiny-at-the-paris-olympics-after-positive-doping-tests-revealed/article_e6365253-b2bb-5a0e-a11e-2142d9a2707d.html', 'title': 'Chinese swimmers will be under scrutiny at the Paris Olympics after positive doping tests revealed', 'body': 'By PAUL NEWBERRY - AP National Writer\n\nFew athletes will be under as much scrutiny at the Paris Olympics as the swimmers from China.\n\nRevelations that nearly two dozen elite Chinese swimmers tested positive for a banned substance ahead of the Tokyo Games -- and were allowed to compete with no ramifications -- have raised major concerns from the rest of the world about the seriousness of anti-doping efforts in a sport that has endured its share of scandals over the decades.\n\nFrom the East German\'s systematic, state-sponsored program of the 1970s and \'80s to a previous Chinese doping ring in the 1990s to questions over one-and-done Irish star Michelle Smith at the Atlanta Olympics to positive tests among Russian swimmers, this all feels familiar to those who\'ve been paying attention to the pool for a while.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\n"There are cheaters all around the world. There\'s no doubt in my mind," said 1984 Olympic gold medalist Rowdy Gaines, now a commentator for NBC Sports. "When it becomes systemic, that\'s a whole different issue."\n\nProminent figures such as Katie Ledecky, winner of more individual swimming medals than any other female, and Michael Phelps, the most decorated Olympian ever with a staggering 23 gold medals, have both gone public with their complaints about a system that seems to have dropped the ball on a very clear-cut case.\n\n"I have moved on to the next chapter in my life," said Phelps, who retired after the 2016 Rio de Janeiro Olympics. "But it is imperative that we keep the book open for those who wish to be next."\n\nThe World Anti-Doping Agency kept the book closed on 23 elite Chinese swimmers who tested positive for a banned heart medication ahead of the Tokyo Olympics in 2021. Five of those swimmers went on to win medals, including three golds.\n\nThe positive tests had been kept under wraps until they were reported in April by The New York Times and German broadcaster ARD. The Times further revealed that three of those swimmers had previously tested positive for another banned substance -- again, with no ramifications.\n\nWADA accepted the explanation of Chinese anti-doping officials that its athletes had ingested the banned substance through contaminated food at a hotel. World Aquatics, the governing body of swimming, went along with that decision.\n\n"It should have been handled differently -- for a matter of respect. Respect for the entire swimming and sports world," Italian swimmer Nicolò Martinenghi said. "The situation needs to be fixed."\n\nWith 11 swimmers who tested positive ahead of Tokyo set to compete again in Paris, criticism of the world\'s anti-doping regulator only increased.\n\n"If the international sports world continues to have its integrity impacted by the failures at WADA, the next generation isn\'t going to be able to have the same belief that I once had in the system," Phelps said during recent testimony before the U.S. Congress. "So with this I urge you, the members of Congress, to engage in the fight against doping. We can uphold the values and fairness and integrity that are the cornerstone of Olympic and Paralympic sport."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nTo that end, the U.S. has launched a criminal investigation into how the Chinese doping cases were handled. Brent Nowicki, the executive director of World Aquatics, has been subpoenaed to testify before Congress. World Aquatics said Monday that the Chinese swimmers going to Paris were undergoing increased drug testing of at least eight times this year before the Games.\n\nBut all of this comes too late to make it up to those who may have been cheated out of medals in Tokyo.\n\nTake Ledecky, who swam a stellar anchor leg on the 4x200-meter freestyle relay to finish off a time that would\'ve broken the previous world record, only to have a Chinese squad that included Zhang Yufei go even faster by four-tenths of a second to take both the gold and the world record. Zhang was among those who failed the pre-Olympic doping test.\n\nLedecky now knows what a swimmer like Shirley Babashoff, who was dubbed "Surly Shirley" for griping about the sudden rise of the East Germans at the 1976 Montreal Olympics, must\'ve felt like -- especially when her suspicions were proven to be correct.\n\n"It\'s tough to accept as an athlete, and now also to feel what it\'s like to be an athlete who won a (silver) medal behind some athletes who tested positive," Ledecky told CBS. "I\'ve seen it before with other athletes and always felt for those athletes."\n\nThe doping revelations are sure to cast a pall over the swimming competition in Paris -- especially if the Chinese have a strong performance.\n\nThey were fourth in the medal table at the Tokyo Games with three golds and six medals overall, and they are coming off a stellar showing at the 2024 world championships in Doha, Qatar, with seven golds and a total of 11 medals. China trailed only the United States at that meet, though it must be noted that many top swimmers skipped the most recent worlds because of its unusual timing in an Olympic year.\n\n"It\'s disappointing to have this kind of distraction again around the Olympics," said Tim Hinchey, the executive director of USA Swimming.\n\nThen again, it\'s nothing new for the sport.\n\n"It\'s happened time and time again," Hinchey said. "So that\'s disappointing."\n\nAP Sports Writer Andrew Dampf in Rome contributed to this report.\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. "We are proud that he will be forever memorialized inside Ford Field and as a Detroit Lion."\n\nDetroit drafted Johnson out of Georgia Tech with the No. 2 pick in 2007 and the spectacular player retired after the 2015 season at the age of 30.\n\nIn 2021, he joined Jim Brown and Gale Sayers as Pro Football Hall of Famers inducted at 35 years old or younger.\n\nThe 6-foot-5, 237-pound receiver could run the 40-yard dash in 4.4 seconds, and clear 45 inches with his vertical jump, leading to his "Megatron" nickname.\n\nJohnson broke one of Hall of Famer Jerry Rice\'s records in 2012 with 1,964 yards receiving, a mark that still stands. However, Fleming\'s name was bypassed in the blind draw and he was placed in the back of the field. The earlier Fans Challenge were not claimed so the purse grew each time.\n\nThe normal protocol for the next Fans Challenge would be $3,000 but Pinilis said the next Fans Challenge on Aug. 3 will be $9,000.\n\n"The Fans\' Challenge bonus will be $9,000 for the next 100-lapper on August 3," Pinilis said.\n\nFleming comes into this week\'s racing third in the points behind Burt Myers and Ward. His second-place finish allowed him to pick up some points on Myers. Ward also closed the gap on Myers, who finished sixth after an early-race wreck that nearly ended Myers\' night.\n\nWith six weeks left in the season Myers has a 20-point lead on Ward, the defending champion, and 22-point lead on Fleming, who has never won a points\' title in his outstanding career at the Stadium.\n\nFleming, who has nine top five finishes in 15 starts this season, has 17 career wins which ties him for 33rd all time.\n\nPHOTOS: Bowman Gray racing, June 29, 2024\n\njdell@wsjournal.com\n\n336-727-4081\n\n@johndellWSJ\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'mcdowellnews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'McDowellNews.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'walt_unks@mcdowellnews.com', 'name': 'Walt Unks', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/mcdowellnews.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/b/be/bbed4c46-5c75-52e8-ae8c-4a1285f87bdc/6696805a8a4c7.preview.jpg?crop=1272%2C668%2C96%2C230&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.003921568627450966, 'wgt': 458836599, 'relevance': 26}

If you\'re not a member, you can always sign up for a 30-day free trial. (If you\'re a student, you may be eligible for a discounted Prime Student membership, which includes a 6-month free trial.)\n\nTechnically, yes. Prime Day is an exclusive Prime members-only event. Prime Day began in July 2015, on the company\'s 20th birthday. However, the retail giant has recently expanded its sale periods to become more frequent. For the past two years, Amazon added a sale called Prime Big Deal Days in October, colloquially dubbed "October Prime Day." We expect the same for this year.\n\nFrom March 20-25, 2024, Amazon launched its first-ever Big Spring Sale, a sale event expected to appear again next year.\n\nIn 2020, Amazon ran its Prime Day sale event in October due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Then, in October 2022, the retail giant offered a "Prime Day Early Access" sale event, and most recently, in October 2022, Amazon ran an "October Prime Day" for the first time. {'uri': '8228328395', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '13:38:58', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T13:38:58Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T13:38:32Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.5764706134796143, 'url': 'https://www.dailystar.co.uk/sport/football/harry-kane-dubbed-unluckiest-player-33256976', 'title': "Harry Kane 'curse' means he'll never win a trophy as supercomputer explains why", 'body': 'England captain Harry Kane will never win a trophy, artificial intelligence has claimed.\n\nDespite scoring bucket-loads of goals and winning many individual honours, it appears as if the 30-year-old is destined to have a very empty trophy cabinet whenever he does retire.\n\nFrom a laughable time at Tottenham to a very "Spursy" time at Bayern Munich in his first season, Harry Edward Kane has yet to get his hands on any form of silverware for a team.\n\nREAD MORE: Southgate quits as England manager after second heartbreaking Euros final loss as he shares emotional statement\n\nClick here for the latest news from the Daily Star\n\nAnd with it now being dubbed the "Kane Curse" after England\'s failure to win Euro 2024 - we turned to artificial intelligence to see if it thinks Kane will ever win anything . . . apart from the Audi Cup.\n\nAccording to Google\'s large language model chatbot Gemini, the short answer is no. But the long answer is...well, also no but far better explained.\n\nIt told us, while breaking Kane down into three parts - team dependence, club choice and mentality and leadership: "It\'s definitely true that Kane seems to have come close to trophies a few times but missed out. Euro 2024 is a good example, and depending on how you view Tottenham\'s recent performance, you could argue they haven\'t capitalized on his talent in terms of silverware either.\n\nHere\'s the thing though, "unluckiest ever" is a tough label to place. There are many great players who never lifted a major trophy. Football is a team sport, and sometimes even the best individual talents can\'t carry a team all the way.\n\n"Football is a team sport, and winning trophies relies heavily on the collective strength and performance of the entire squad. Even a world-class striker like Kane can\'t single-handedly win a trophy if the rest of the team isn\'t on the same page or lacks the necessary depth and skill.\n\n"While a move to Bayern Munich aimed to address this, it didn\'t quite work out this past season. His future club choice will be crucial. If he joins a team that\'s consistently challenging for trophies but doesn\'t quite get there, the wait could extend.\n\n"Some players thrive under pressure and can inspire their teammates in big games. If Kane struggles in high-pressure situations or doesn\'t naturally take on a leadership role, it could hinder the team\'s overall performance."\n\nGemini did come up with some positives, and claimed that England could have a chance of winning the 2026 World Cup, with Kane\'s "individual brilliance" leading the way.\n\nAnd with Gareth Southgate resigning today, a new manager could lead the charge...we hope.\n\nFor the latest breaking news and stories from across the globe from the Daily Star, sign up for our newsletters.', 'source': {'uri': 'dailystar.co.uk', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Daily Star'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'adam_cailler@dailystar.co.uk', 'name': 'Adam Cailler', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://i2-prod.dailystar.co.uk/incoming/article33257030.ece/ALTERNATES/s1200/1_Spain-v-England-Final-UEFA-EURO-2024.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9730753', 'sentiment': 0.1294117647058823, 'wgt': 458833138, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '2024-07-423650678', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '13:19:12', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T13:19:12Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T10:30:28Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://eu.fdlreporter.com/story/sports/mlb/brewers/2024/07/16/from-war-to-whip-baseballs-new-stats-and-acronyms-are-bewildering-lori-nickel-column/74381927007/', 'title': 'Lori Nickel: A new (again) baseball fan struggles with modern metrics and their acronyms', 'body': 'Confession: I haven\'t been following baseball. Not the Brewers, not the league, not the World Series.\n\nThere are a lot of reasons why: the disillusioning strike of 1994, the stodgy ultramarathon games and the fact Robin \'The Kid\' Yount couldn\'t play into his pensioner years. I used to celebrate my birthday at County Stadium with my softball glove, and Cecil Cooper and Ben Oglivie buttons. Then I grew up and left the Mark McGwire game entirely to cover football and basketball and everything else.\n\nDecades passed. And the game advanced so much in that time, and the statistics, the specialties, the hyper-specific scenarios that yielded analytics and metrics followed. There\'s stuff called WAR and WHIP and OBP+. There\'s a "hard hit rate" that kind of makes sense, but what the hell is rOBA?\n\nThere\'s Pull%, Cent% and Oppo% - something about batters and their tendencies - and Standard Fielding Pos and lgRFGs. Yuck.\n\nI look at baseball now the way a baby boomer looks at an Uber. You tell me I\'m supposed to trust it, but I don\'t ... and I can\'t remember my app password anyway.\n\nStill, there\'s something about this year, 2024. Major League Baseball finally made pitchers and batters pick up the pace in 2023, and this season these National League Central-leading Brewers became ... intriguing. Everyone in the clubhouse talks about the super-low expectations, and we all know underdog journeys really are the best stories. It was time to face my anxiety - I don\'t know this game, I don\'t understand these intricacies - and see if I could return to baseball. And learn its peculiar language.\n\nMedia. Watch games, listen to broadcasts and podcasts, and read the coverage.\n\nAnd stats - because no other sport marries itself to data more than this one.\n\nA natural place to start was Gold Glove-winner, MVP and all-around good-attitude dude Christian Yelich.\n\nOK, one of the stat websites - baseball-reference.com - features 12 pages. Batting average, plate appearances, home runs, stolen bases, RBIs. It starts with the usual stuff, all makes sense.\n\nAnd then ... OBP, OPS and OPS plus. And ... player value batting.\n\nMy anxiety levels rise. This is clearly a foreign language. I reach out to Jeff Levering, the very kind, very knowledgeable Brewers radio broadcaster. He will help translate.\n\n"I\'ll have to study up, some of these stats are like programming a VCR," he responded via text, and that is funny in more ways than one.\n\nOK, in the meantime, we can always count on broadcasters Brian Anderson and Bill Schroeder. They were calling a Brewers-Boston Red Sox game on June 2 and discussing the batting percentage leaders in the National League when they posited the question: does Yelich have a chance at the NL batting title?\n\nAnderson: A player needs 3.2 at-bat plate appearances per team games to qualify for the batting title. Yelich missed some time mid-April ...\n\nAs I\'m doing a Google search - who is Dom, Brewers? - Anderson and Schroeder jump back to the topic. Their man Dom reports the number is actually 3.1, not 3.2 and ... what were we talking about anyway?\n\nHe rolls his gaze - just a little. It\'s four hours before another game in a summer of endless games and the 32-year-old veteran has likely heard every question that ever existed. God, it must get old. But these stats! They make for endless talking points and debates and Yelich is a newly inducted member of some elite 200 club - career home runs and steals. So Yelich must have a great take on all this; what stats are good, and what are a joke; and which ones are really telling, and which are helpful, and ...\n\n"I don\'t even look at my stats; I couldn\'t tell you a single one of my stats right now. I have zero idea. Like no clue," he said. "They don\'t matter to me until the end of the season because they change so much. So I don\'t look at them."\n\nOh. But ... in general, there must be some stat that\'s valuable?\n\n"Not really. People talk about them - the media and the fans. I don\'t know. Players, like - we don\'t really care."\n\nAwkward silence. It\'s not a slammed door on this story idea but wow, if he doesn\'t care, should we? My anxiety alarms are blaring. This is the MVP who has come to Bucks games to watch the other MVP in town. This is a respected guy in Milwaukee. And he\'s killing this stat story project before its even started. Is he serious? One last weak attempt: BABIP? Does he care about that? Does he care about anything?\n\nBut it makes sense. When someone like Yelich works and trains and plays like he does, what purpose would it serve to look at numbers and trends?\n\n"I don\'t know why you\'d want to put yourself through looking at your stuff like every day," Yelich said. "I care about winning and trying to help the team win."\n\nIt means there\'s room for the rest of us to try to decode the numerical quirks and statistical quarks of the game without the pressure of trying to fake like we know it.\n\nLet\'s head out to the yard. Hey, at least baseball is an inviting sport to the spectator, unlike the dizzying flurry of football and frenetic pace of basketball. Baseball is polite, letting you gather your flock, find your spot and settle in to take in the weather, the people around you and the smell of the roasting hot dogs before you have to be alert. Because nothing ever happens in the first inning.', 'source': {'uri': 'fdlreporter.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Reporter'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://www.gannett-cdn.com/presto/2022/04/06/PMJS/2c9f6134-7a4d-48db-8157-a2e8f7b41d44-BREWERS_1427.JPG?auto=webp&crop=3899,2194,x0,y198&format=pjpg&width=1200', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1294117647058823, 'wgt': 458831952, 'relevance': 9}
{'uri': '8228266846', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '13:01:52', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T13:01:52Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T13:01:15Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://buffalonews.com/sports/professional/nfl/bills/buffalo-bills-radio-chris-brown/article_486bbfe6-4371-11ef-9f32-17c1e8817cbb.html', 'title': 'Bills name Chris Brown full-time play-by-play radio announcer', 'body': 'Mark Gaughan and Katherine Fitzgerald have a playful discussion as they run through a series of hot topics surrounding the Bills before training camp in Rochester at the end of July. Mark and Katherine discuss position battles, players to watch and share their thoughts on some players they h...\n\nThe Buffalo Bills named Chris Brown as their new radio play-by-play announcer Tuesday morning after he served as the interim voice of the team in 2023.\n\nBrown subbed for John Murphy beginning in January 2023 after Murphy sustained a stroke. Brown has called the last 18 regular season games and four playoff games.\n\nIn a statement released by the team, Bills COO Pete Guelli said: "(Brown) has strong institutional knowledge of our team while also understanding the pulse of our fans. We look forward to Chris carrying the torch of the legends this job has produced in Van Miller and John Murphy."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nBrown is the third full-time play-by-play radio announcer in team history, joining Miller (1960-71 and 1978-2003) and Murphy (2004-22). The duo of Al Meltzer/Rick Azar handled the duty from 1972-77.\n\nAccording to Jeff Matthews, vice president of media and content for the Bills, more than 150 people applied for the role and several had auditions alongside radio analyst Eric Wood before the team and the rightsholder, Audacy, decided on Brown.\n\nPeople are also reading... He noted that while he and the rest of Team USA\'s selection committee have respect for Brown as a player, they had to make a decision that would best serve the team and that he can\'t just pick all the superstars in the NBA for the team.\n\n"Guys who\'ve been Finals MVPs, guys who\'ve been a part of the program, guys who\'ve won gold medals, guys who I respect, admire, and enjoy watching. But the responsibility that I have is to put together a team and a team that complements each other, a team that fits a team that will give us the best opportunity for success.\n\nBrown, on his end, has experienced some real positive things in the last few days. He was a big presence at the ESPYs, showing up with former WNBA star Kysre Gondrezick and winning the ESPY for best championship performance at the event.\n\nBrown will probably enter the next season with an even bigger chip on his shoulder. The fact that he was left off Team USA despite being the reigning Finals MVP has really irked him, and he will want to prove to the decision-makers at Team USA why that was a mistake, and that he should have been the first name on the sheet.\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {'uri': '8228184511', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '12:11:24', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T12:11:24Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T12:10:44Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://lacrossetribune.com/sports/professional/lacrosse-speedway-tom-reffner-88-preview/article_240f100a-42d9-11ef-bcf0-0f31efac425c.html', 'title': "La Crosse Fairgrounds Speedway: Reffner 88 honors one of Wisconsin's best drivers", 'body': 'Ty Majeski walks onto track during driver introductions on July 9 at Slinger Speedway. Majeski has five top-five finishes this season in the NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series and three wins in the ASA Midwest Tour.\n\nJames Krause\n\nWEST SALEM -- When it comes to portraying the legacy of Tom Reffner and his impact on Wisconsin stock car racing, there\'s a few ways to go about it.\n\nThere\'s his 391 wins and 13 track championships. There\'s his association with Dick Trickle and John Boegeman as the Blue Knight of the SuperAmerica stable. There\'s his win in the inaugural Oktoberfest feature at La Crosse Fairgrounds Speedway in 1970 and his championship win in the inaugural ARTGO Racing season during his dominant 1975 campaign.\n\nThen, there\'s how Colin Reffner, Tom\'s grandson who races super late models today, puts it.\n\n"His biggest impact on the racing world I think was that he, as well as many others, had a hand in what racing has become today," Colin Reffner said. "He was there when this technology changed and progressed with new cars being built. That was really the beginning stages of that."\n\nPeople are also reading... La Crosse woman arrested after Onalaska traffic stop on drug trafficking charges Steve Cahalan: New South Side Aldi store to open July 25 in La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Melrose gets an event center; La Crosse Aldi store opening date set UW-La Crosse faculty committee recommends Joe Gow to be fired from tenured position on campus Human trafficking in La Crosse: Police department raises awareness after recent arrests Police standoff with 33-year-old man wanted for child sexual assault ends peacefully with arrest Elderly man killed in UTV accident on Ettrick farm Farm ordered to pay $210K for wastewater permit violations; owner disputes Monroe County court ruling Criminal complaint implicates two La Crosse residents for human trafficking 21-year-old man drowns in private pond in Grant County, authorities say Steve Cahalan: Onalaska\'s BHHS North Properties to merge with Minnesota-based Edina Realty Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead $2M project to extend life of Cass Street bridge starts Monday with lane closures expected Massive expansion of MSP airport will bring with it years of demolitions and disruptions Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive\n\nThe inaugural Tom Reffner 88 takes place Wednesday at the La Crosse Fairgrounds Speedway to honor of one of the state\'s most accomplished drivers after his passing last October at 82 years old.\n\nThe event will see twin 44-lap super late model features. Sleepy Hollows Auto Group is offering $8,888 to win in each race and a best average finish bonus means one driver can win $20,000 by sweeping both races.\n\nThe Central Wisconsin Racing Association -- a state-wide touring series that Tom Reffner claimed three championships in -- will run two 30-lap features on the quarter-mile track for the first time ever.\n\nThe event is being promoted by Gregg McKarns, the owner of Madison International Speedway. Colin said his grandfather goes way back with Gregg\'s father John and the entire McKarns family. The event also serves as the opening of the 133rd LaCrosse Interstate Fair.\n\n"It\'s fitting for him to do it and for it to be at La Crosse," Colin Reffner said. "I really think that Gregg, along with La Crosse and Sleepy Hollow Auto Group, have put together an amazing event."\n\nColin, with more than a decade of experience running Super Late Model races during La Crosse\'s Oktoberfest, will be among the 21 drivers entering the event as of Monday.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nTy Majeski, a three-time winner of the Dick Trickle 99 and three-time Oktoberfest champion, returns to La Crosse in the midst of a busy slate for his full-time ride in the NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series.\n\n"We\'ve always kind of seen the Truck Series, at least as long as I\'ve been in it, kind of structured this way," Majeski said. "Just business as usual. Two of the last three weeks I was in Sandusky and wasn\'t racing the late model too much."\n\nMajeski started the late model season with three dominant wins in the ASA Midwest Tour and another in the ASA Stars National Tour event at Madison. He\'s the points leader in both divisions.\n\nThe Reffner 88 will be the fourth of Majeski\'s five races in 10 days with a Truck Series race on Friday at Lucas Oil Indianapolis Raceway Park. His recent results have been mixed, failing to finish at Slinger Nationals or his Truck Series start at Pocono before a runner-up finish at Grundy County Speedway on Saturday.\n\nMajeski fell out of last season\'s Oktoberfest main event after an accident that involved 2018 ASA Midwest Tour champion Dalton Zehr. The Verona-based driver seeks redemption in the Reffner 88.\n\nJohnny Sauter, another former Oktoberfest winner and champion in both NASCAR Trucks and ASA, is also back looking for a bounce-back performance at La Crosse. Sauter was leading last year\'s Oktoberfest 200 late when a mechanical issue denied him a chance to race for the win.\n\nGabe Sommers won the chaotic Oktoberfest 200 and claimed the ASA Midwest Tour championship in his last visit to La Crosse. Sommers returns with momentum, securing a top-10 in his first Slinger Nationals feature and a fifth-place run at Grundy County last week.\n\nSommers is third in ASA Midwest Tour standings this season, sitting behind 19-year old Levon Van Der Geest. Van Der Geest, an engineering student at UW-Milwaukee who won last year\'s Rookie of the Year award, will make his return to La Crosse.\n\nTy Fredrickson, the 15-year old son of multi-time Oktoberfest champion Dan, has proven he\'s already capable of landing in victory lane. Fredrickson won the Icebreaker 100 at Dells Raceway Park on April 13 and leads the track\'s Alive for 5 Series through three events.\n\nOn the other end of the spectrum, veteran drivers Jeremy Lepak and Jeff Storm are among those competing Wednesday.\n\nSeveral NASCAR Kwik Trip Late Model regulars are scattered throughout the lineup including Jacob Goede, Nick Clements and Billy Mohn. Local drivers like Matthew Henderson, Carter Christienson and Joe Scholz all make their return to the Fairgrounds.\n\nJames Krause can be reached by email at James.KrauseJr@lee.net or on Twitter @jkrausepro.\n\nREFFNER 88 ENTRY LIST NO. {'uri': '8228181960', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '12:09:50', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T12:09:50Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T12:09:14Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://journalnow.com/sports/atkins-garrison-dibble-commits-to-navy/article_3bd99d70-415a-11ef-8a32-db89f0184e26.html', 'title': "Atkins' Garrison Dibble commits to Navy", 'body': 'Atkins defensive end Garrison Dibble lines up for a drill during a combined football practice on Thursday, July 11, 2024, at Carver High School in Winston-Salem, N.C. Dibble has committed to play football at Navy.\n\nMARC PRUITT Staff Reporter\n\nGarrison Dibble knew a great opportunity when it presented itself.\n\nDibble, a 6-foot-4, 235-pound rising senior and defensive end for the Atkins football team, has committed to Navy to continue his playing career.\n\nNavy was the first school that made him an official offer during the spring, and Dibble said that the draw of not only playing college football but having a future after football was important.\n\n"Not only are you getting a great education, but you can set yourself up with a life after football as well," Dibble said. "Navy was the first offer that I picked up. I was actually thinking about enlisting in the military after high school anyway if I didn\'t play college football. This way, I can do both."\n\nDibble said that his father, Ryan, was in the Marines and that both of his grandfathers served in the Army, which was also a factor in his decision.\n\nDibble, who also received offers from Elon and Wofford, said he fell in love with Navy\'s campus in Annapolis, Maryland, and got to know defensive lineman Justin Reed during his official visit.\n\n"I met with seven of the players when I was up there and (Reed) talked to me for a few hours himself," Dibble said. "He told me that you make the experience whatever you want it be and to take advantage of the great coaching and the great training program for life after football."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nDibble\'s recruiting stock began to rise after a stellar junior season when he recorded 132 tackles, including 28 for loss, and 11 sacks.\n\nHe said he grew about four inches between his sophomore and junior year and added about 15 pounds.\n\n"My brother, Joseph, who also played (at Atkins), is a personal trainer and I was lifting weights and working out with him a lot between my sophomore and junior year," Dibble said. "I went from about 5-11 and 215 pounds as a sophomore to 6-3 and 230 pounds as a junior. That made a big difference."\n\nDibble also credited former teammate Kadynce Watson, who also played defensive end for the Camels last season and is now playing at Fayetteville State, for helping his development.\n\nWatson finished the 2023 season with 145 tackles and 14 sacks.\n\n"The whole concept of \'Iron sharpens iron\'\', Dibble said. "We pushed each other in practice every day."\n\nDibble has played football for 11 years, starting with the Union Cross Bobcats program in Kernersville.\n\nThis season will mark his third straight as a team captain at Atkins, where he also plays lacrosse and is in the Chess Club and the Environmental Club. He will also see some playing time as a tight end.\n\n"You can expect even more leadership out of me this season," Dibble said. "I love playing football because I love to hit people. That\'s why I love playing defense. But I\'ll do anything I can to help us win."\n\nmpruitt@wsjournal.com\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'journalnow.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Winston-Salem Journal'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/journalnow.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/bd/3bd99d70-415a-11ef-8a32-db89f0184e26/6692f5b3e0bc7.social.jpg?resize=438%2C320', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.2784313725490195, 'wgt': 458827790, 'relevance': 51}

Russia\'s telecom watchdog (Roskomnadzor) has demanded that Google unblock more than 200 YouTube accounts belonging to Russian media outlets, government bodies and politicians.\n\n"Roskomnadzor issued a message to Google LLC CEO Sundar Pichai demanding that more than 200 YouTube accounts of Russian media outlets, federal government bodies, companies and sports clubs, as well as various public and political activists and musicians who support Russia and its authorities be unblocked," it told TASS.\n\nThe watchdog recalled that since 2020, YouTube has imposed restrictions on 207 Russian entities, including 83 in 2024 alone. The sanctions were applied to the RT and RBC television channels, musicians Shaman, Oleg Gazmanov, Yulia Chicherina, author Zakhar Prilepin, designer and blogger Artemy Lebedev and many others.\n\nThe regulator stressed that these sanctions violate the basic principles of the free distribution of information and unimpeded access to it. "Such actions are inadmissible and constitute an act of censorship. YouTube is pursuing an uncompromisingly Russophobic policy, giving preference to those who support pro-Western ideals and blocking accounts of Russian bloggers and journalists without any explanations. Not only those who openly express their position on various political matters but also anyone who speaks about Russia positively falls victim to such a policy," Roskomnadzor said.\n\nHowever, YouTube has not yet removed more than 61,300 materials that were prohibited for containing false information about the special military operation, extremist information, propaganda of nontraditional sexual relations, and content involving children and teenagers committing criminal acts.', 'source': {'uri': 'tass.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'TASS'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://tass.com/img/blocks/common/tass_logo_share_ru.png', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.01960784313725494, 'wgt': 458827642, 'relevance': 100}
{'uri': '8228173394', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '12:04:27', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T12:04:27Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T12:03:59Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7803921699523926, 'url': 'https://www.firstpost.com/tech/hong-kong-testing-its-own-chatgpt-like-genai-tool-as-openai-works-on-blocking-services-in-several-regions-13793689.html', 'title': 'Hong Kong testing its own ChatGPT-like GenAI tool, as OpenAI works on blocking services in several regions', 'body': 'The development of Hong Kong\'s AI tool is part of a broader context of technological competition between China and the United States, with both nations striving for AI supremacy. Image Credit\n\nHong Kong\'s government is developing its own AI tool similar to ChatGPT, aimed initially at government employees but with plans for public availability. This initiative comes in response to OpenAI\'s recent decision to block access from Hong Kong and other unsupported regions.\n\nSun Dong, Hong Kong\'s Secretary for Innovation, Technology, and Industry, announced the development on a Saturday radio show. The AI tool, known in Chinese as "document assistance application for civil servants," is being tested and is expected to be rolled out to the entire government by the end of the year.\n\nThe project is spearheaded by a generative AI research and development centre at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, in collaboration with other universities. Future enhancements are expected to include functions for graphics and video design, though how these capabilities will compare to ChatGPT remains uncertain. Sun emphasized the need for local development due to the unavailability of support from global tech giants like Microsoft and Google.\n\nThe development of Hong Kong\'s AI tool is part of a broader context of technological competition between China and the United States, with both nations striving for AI supremacy. China aims to become the global leader in AI by 2030. However, OpenAI has excluded China, Hong Kong, and Macao from its list of supported regions, leading to the need for local solutions.\n\nOpenAI\'s recent measures to block connections from unsupported regions have been part of ongoing restrictions, though the company has not provided detailed reasons for these actions. Local IT expert Francis Fong expressed cautious optimism about Hong Kong\'s AI capabilities, suggesting that while it may not match ChatGPT, it could still achieve high standards with local input and tailored functionalities.\n\nOne advantage of a locally developed AI system is its ability to address regional languages and issues more accurately. However, given the political climate, there is an expectation that AI might conform to certain ideological constraints. This is particularly relevant in China, where internet content is heavily censored, and AI models must operate within these parameters.\n\nChinese tech companies like Alibaba and Baidu have already introduced AI models similar to ChatGPT, primarily for Chinese-language users, adhering to censorship rules. In May, China\'s cyberspace academy announced the training of an AI chatbot on President Xi Jinping\'s doctrine, underscoring the ideological boundaries within which Chinese AI operates.\n\nIn Hong Kong, SenseTime, a significant player in Chinese AI, launched SenseChat, which serves the Cantonese-speaking population. However, it avoids politically sensitive topics, such as the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown and the 2019 Hong Kong protests, reflecting the constraints imposed on AI systems operating in China.\n\nHong Kong\'s move to develop its own AI tool highlights the region\'s drive to foster technological innovation while navigating the complex landscape of international politics and local regulations. The success of this initiative will depend on its ability to meet high technological standards and address local needs without running afoul of political sensitivities.', 'source': {'uri': 'firstpost.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Firstpost'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://images.firstpost.com/uploads/2024/07/Hong-Kong-testing-its-own-ChatGPT-like-GenAI-tool-as-OpenAI-works-on-blocking-services-in-several-regions-2024-07-0daad0ef439dc87058f2346ba94d1018-1200x675.jpg?im=FitAndFill=(1200,675)', 'eventUri': 'eng-9736000', 'sentiment': 0.1137254901960785, 'wgt': 458827467, 'relevance': 51}
