{'uri': '8228156028', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '11:54:03', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T11:54:03Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T11:53:34Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://greensboro.com/sports/christian-joyces-consistency-has-been-his-trademark-this-season-in-the-street-stock-division/article_8dd1fa3f-bc7f-519b-a54d-7c3fa6d44f40.html', 'title': "Christian Joyce's consistency has been his trademark this season in the Street Stock Division", 'body': 'Christian Joyce doesn\'t talk fast or even walk that fast. As he headed to the driver\'s meeting at Bowman Gray Stadium on Saturday night he wasn\'t rushed and measured each step.\n\nJoyce, however, sure does drive fast.\n\nHe\'s heading toward his second straight Street Stock Division title thanks to a lot of factors. But the one factor that has kept him above his fellow drivers in the division is his ability to get his car around the quarter mile historic track faster than most.\n\n"It\'s about having fun, and if you aren\'t having fun, don\'t do it," said Joyce, who is from Trinity and lives there with his wife, Kaylan.\n\nJoyce, 29, has found the right formula for his Street Stock car with help from Dylan Ward, who sets up the car. Joyce said he isn\'t about to look ahead to what it would mean to repeat as champion.\n\n"I just come out here on a weekly basis and try to do my best," he said. "We only get one shot a week in our division with one race, so you want to make the best of it."\n\nA good example of his experience came on Saturday when he started 11th in the 15-lap race, but worked his way into a second-place finish behind winner Jacob Creed.\n\nWhile there were seven caution flags that slowed the race to a halt, Joyce showed patience, avoided the carnage and had his ninth straight top 10 finish. He has three wins on the season, and after a 13th place showing on opening night in April, he\'s never been out of the top 10.\n\nJoyce\'s father, Steven Outlaw, is also his crew chief and the family keeps the car in Outlaw\'s make-shift garage in his backyard in Archdale.\n\n"We don\'t look at the points and just stay focused each week," Outlaw said.\n\nWhile Joyce says he tries to not look at the points, where he has a big lead on Brad Lewis, he does like to know where he stands.\n\n"If you said you aren\'t looking at the points, you\'d be lying," Joyce said. "I will say that I\'m a whole lot less worried about the points this season than I was last season."\n\nJoyce, who has 11 career wins, won four times last season on the way to his first points\' title.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nJoyce, a graduate of Wheatmore High School, got his start in drag racing because that\'s what his father did. Joyce eventually talked his father in letting him race at Caraway Speedway near Asheboro.\n\nIt didn\'t take long for Joyce to excel at Caraway and then six years ago made a decision to run fulltime in the Street Stock at Bowman Gray Stadium.\n\n"There\'s nothing else like it," Joyce said about racing at Bowman Gray Stadium. "You can\'t go anywhere else with these crowds, the car count, and there\'s nothing like winning here. You can\'t describe it."\n\nOne of Joyce\'s superstitions is he brings his wife, Kalan, to the driver\'s meeting each Saturday night to draw his spot in the field. Some nights she does OK, and other nights it doesn\'t work out so well.\n\nBut the good news is no matter where Joyce starts in the race he usually gets to the top five.\n\nKaylan, who is an x-ray technician, said she loves the way her husband makes sure to focus each week on the one race and not look too far ahead.\n\n"He just takes it week by week and he didn\'t come here this season just thinking it was going to happen again," Kaylan said.\n\nWhile there are a lot of rivalries in all of the divisions at the Stadium fans won\'t find one with Joyce and Lewis. The two are very close and cheer for each other even though they are oftentimes chasing the same checkered flag each Saturday night.\n\n"He\'s just as excited about Brad being in second as he is about being in first place in the points," Kaylan said. "They root for each other and that\'s really cool to see."\n\nLewis says it\'s easy to root for Joyce because he does things the right way and he\'s a good driver.\n\n"He\'s by far the smoothest driver in this division," Lewis said. "He hits his mark every lap and if you pick one off pure talent, he\'s the guy."\n\nThe two have such a healthy respect for each other last year at Caraway Speedway they helped each other out. Joyce\'s engine blew in practice but Lewis offered Joyce his car.\n\n"We were at Caraway and my engine blew up and Brad had just had back surgery so he said go get my car and with his car we started in the rear and we won the race," Joyce said.\n\nLewis, who works at High Point Body and Paint, says having most of his family at the Stadium each week means a lot to him. He doesn\'t take it for granted that he\'s just going to show up and win races.\n\n"We work hard at it," he said. "And the results have been there, but we don\'t want to start looking ahead. One race at a time is the best plan."\n\njdell@wsjournal.com\n\n336-727-4081\n\n@johndellWSJ\n\nUpdated Points Standings\n\nBrad\'s Golf Cars Modified Series\n\nRANK CAR DRIVER POINTS\n\n1 1 Burt Myers 532\n\n2 04 Brandon Ward 512\n\n3 16 Chris Fleming 510\n\n4 83 Tim Brown 486\n\n5 10 Mike Speeney 416\n\n6 4 Jason Myers 410\n\n7 5 Randy Butner 406\n\n8 75 Lee Jeffreys 397\n\n9 07 Riley Neal 378\n\n10 9 Kyle Southern 361\n\n11 00 Danny Propst 329\n\n12 6 Slate Myers 308\n\n13 57 Danny Bohn 270\n\n14 13 Jordan Fleming 248\n\n15 69 John Holleman IV 223\n\n16 77 Susan Harwell 175\n\n17 7 Junior Snow 174\n\n18 99 William Smith 173\n\n19 35 Brandon Butner 168\n\n20 23 Brian Loftin 145\n\n21 72 Bryant Robertson 140\n\n22 79 Ryan Flores 124\n\n23 41 Cory Lovette 106\n\n24 8 Andrew Harrah 102\n\n25 14 Trey Hutchens 98\n\n26 51 Drew Moffitt 76\n\n27 50 Michael Clifton 66\n\n28 39 Gerald Robinson Jr. 46\n\n29 19 Andy Noto 44\n\n44 Daniel Beeson 44\n\n31 8 Kevin Hughes 33\n\n32 48 Robbie Brewer 24\n\n8 Luke Smith 24\n\n34 53 John Smith 22\n\n45 Lee Stimpson 22\n\n36 88 Johnny Mordock 16\n\n37 88 Mason Lawson 10\n\n81 Zack Clifton 10\n\nThe Law Offices of John Barrow Sportsman Series\n\nRANK CAR DRIVER POINTS\n\n1 55 Zack Ore 523\n\n2 31 Chase Robertson 519\n\n3 03 Sterling Plemmons 484\n\n4 19 Michael Adams 460\n\n5 7 Connor Branch 459\n\n6 54 Braden Mills 441\n\n7 12 Justin Taylor 419\n\n8 22 Wesley Thompson 357\n\n9 21 Tommy Neal 356\n\n10 0 Kirk Sheets 339\n\n11 38 Mitch Gales 318\n\n12 15 T. {'uri': '8228150454', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '11:51:29', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T11:51:29Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T11:50:44Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://journalnow.com/sports/christian-joyces-consistency-has-been-his-trademark-this-season-in-the-street-stock-division/article_2bc468fe-42c0-11ef-94ea-5bbef4b5fe8c.html', 'title': "Christian Joyce's consistency has been his trademark this season in the Street Stock Division", 'body': 'Christian Joyce doesn\'t talk fast or even walk that fast. As he headed to the driver\'s meeting at Bowman Gray Stadium on Saturday night he wasn\'t rushed and measured each step.\n\nJoyce, however, sure does drive fast.\n\nHe\'s heading toward his second straight Street Stock Division title thanks to a lot of factors. But the one factor that has kept him above his fellow drivers in the division is his ability to get his car around the quarter mile historic track faster than most.\n\n"It\'s about having fun, and if you aren\'t having fun, don\'t do it," said Joyce, who is from Trinity and lives there with his wife, Kaylan.\n\nJoyce, 29, has found the right formula for his Street Stock car with help from Dylan Ward, who sets up the car. Joyce said he isn\'t about to look ahead to what it would mean to repeat as champion.\n\n"I just come out here on a weekly basis and try to do my best," he said. "We only get one shot a week in our division with one race, so you want to make the best of it."\n\nA good example of his experience came on Saturday when he started 11th in the 15-lap race, but worked his way into a second-place finish behind winner Jacob Creed.\n\nWhile there were seven caution flags that slowed the race to a halt, Joyce showed patience, avoided the carnage and had his ninth straight top 10 finish. He has three wins on the season, and after a 13th place showing on opening night in April, he\'s never been out of the top 10.\n\nJoyce\'s father, Steven Outlaw, is also his crew chief and the family keeps the car in Outlaw\'s make-shift garage in his backyard in Archdale.\n\n"We don\'t look at the points and just stay focused each week," Outlaw said.\n\nWhile Joyce says he tries to not look at the points, where he has a big lead on Brad Lewis, he does like to know where he stands.\n\n"If you said you aren\'t looking at the points, you\'d be lying," Joyce said. "I will say that I\'m a whole lot less worried about the points this season than I was last season."\n\nJoyce, who has 11 career wins, won four times last season on the way to his first points\' title.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nJoyce, a graduate of Wheatmore High School, got his start in drag racing because that\'s what his father did. Joyce eventually talked his father in letting him race at Caraway Speedway near Asheboro.\n\nIt didn\'t take long for Joyce to excel at Caraway and then six years ago made a decision to run fulltime in the Street Stock at Bowman Gray Stadium.\n\n"There\'s nothing else like it," Joyce said about racing at Bowman Gray Stadium. "You can\'t go anywhere else with these crowds, the car count, and there\'s nothing like winning here. You can\'t describe it."\n\nOne of Joyce\'s superstitions is he brings his wife, Kalan, to the driver\'s meeting each Saturday night to draw his spot in the field. Some nights she does OK, and other nights it doesn\'t work out so well.\n\nBut the good news is no matter where Joyce starts in the race he usually gets to the top five.\n\nKaylan, who is an x-ray technician, said she loves the way her husband makes sure to focus each week on the one race and not look too far ahead.\n\n"He just takes it week by week and he didn\'t come here this season just thinking it was going to happen again," Kaylan said.\n\nWhile there are a lot of rivalries in all of the divisions at the Stadium fans won\'t find one with Joyce and Lewis. The two are very close and cheer for each other even though they are oftentimes chasing the same checkered flag each Saturday night.\n\n"He\'s just as excited about Brad being in second as he is about being in first place in the points," Kaylan said. "They root for each other and that\'s really cool to see."\n\nLewis says it\'s easy to root for Joyce because he does things the right way and he\'s a good driver.\n\n"He\'s by far the smoothest driver in this division," Lewis said. "He hits his mark every lap and if you pick one off pure talent, he\'s the guy."\n\nThe two have such a healthy respect for each other last year at Caraway Speedway they helped each other out. Joyce\'s engine blew in practice but Lewis offered Joyce his car.\n\n"We were at Caraway and my engine blew up and Brad had just had back surgery so he said go get my car and with his car we started in the rear and we won the race," Joyce said.\n\nLewis, who works at High Point Body and Paint, says having most of his family at the Stadium each week means a lot to him. He doesn\'t take it for granted that he\'s just going to show up and win races.\n\n"We work hard at it," he said. "And the results have been there, but we don\'t want to start looking ahead. One race at a time is the best plan."\n\njdell@wsjournal.com\n\n336-727-4081\n\n@johndellWSJ\n\nUpdated Points Standings\n\nBrad\'s Golf Cars Modified Series\n\nRANK CAR DRIVER POINTS\n\n1 1 Burt Myers 532\n\n2 04 Brandon Ward 512\n\n3 16 Chris Fleming 510\n\n4 83 Tim Brown 486\n\n5 10 Mike Speeney 416\n\n6 4 Jason Myers 410\n\n7 5 Randy Butner 406\n\n8 75 Lee Jeffreys 397\n\n9 07 Riley Neal 378\n\n10 9 Kyle Southern 361\n\n11 00 Danny Propst 329\n\n12 6 Slate Myers 308\n\n13 57 Danny Bohn 270\n\n14 13 Jordan Fleming 248\n\n15 69 John Holleman IV 223\n\n16 77 Susan Harwell 175\n\n17 7 Junior Snow 174\n\n18 99 William Smith 173\n\n19 35 Brandon Butner 168\n\n20 23 Brian Loftin 145\n\n21 72 Bryant Robertson 140\n\n22 79 Ryan Flores 124\n\n23 41 Cory Lovette 106\n\n24 8 Andrew Harrah 102\n\n25 14 Trey Hutchens 98\n\n26 51 Drew Moffitt 76\n\n27 50 Michael Clifton 66\n\n28 39 Gerald Robinson Jr. 46\n\n29 19 Andy Noto 44\n\n44 Daniel Beeson 44\n\n31 8 Kevin Hughes 33\n\n32 48 Robbie Brewer 24\n\n8 Luke Smith 24\n\n34 53 John Smith 22\n\n45 Lee Stimpson 22\n\n36 88 Johnny Mordock 16\n\n37 88 Mason Lawson 10\n\n81 Zack Clifton 10\n\nThe Law Offices of John Barrow Sportsman Series\n\nRANK CAR DRIVER POINTS\n\n1 55 Zack Ore 523\n\n2 31 Chase Robertson 519\n\n3 03 Sterling Plemmons 484\n\n4 19 Michael Adams 460\n\n5 7 Connor Branch 459\n\n6 54 Braden Mills 441\n\n7 12 Justin Taylor 419\n\n8 22 Wesley Thompson 357\n\n9 21 Tommy Neal 356\n\n10 0 Kirk Sheets 339\n\n11 38 Mitch Gales 318\n\n12 15 T. {'uri': '2024-07-423547500', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '11:49:42', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T11:49:42Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T11:45:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.6941176652908325, 'url': 'https://mooresvilletribune.com/news/local/iredellnc-walk-alzheimers/article_af8669d0-4298-11ef-b653-87252b7bf766.html', 'title': "Iredell residents set to raise awareness, funds for Alzheimer's care, support and research", 'body': "Donna Swicegood\n\nOn Sept. 21, Iredell County and Lake Norman residents will join the fight against Alzheimer's disease at the Alzheimer's Association Walk to End Alzheimer's® -- the world's largest event to raise awareness and funds for Alzheimer's care, support and research.\n\nThe Alzheimer's Association - Western Carolina Chapter will be hosting Walk to End Alzheimer's - Iredell County and Lake Norman at Liberty Park located at 225 E. Iredell Ave. in Mooresville. Check-in opens at 9 a.m. with an opening ceremony at 10 a.m. and a walk start at 10:30 a.m.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nOn walk day, participants honor those affected by Alzheimer's with the poignant Promise Garden ceremony -- a mission-focused experience that signifies our solidarity in the fight against the disease. During the ceremony, walkers will carry flowers of various colors, each color representing their personal connection to the disease.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nCaribou Coffee to open new location in Mooresville Monday Letter: Too much development is destroying Mooresville Silver Alert canceled on woman, 87, from Mooresville North Carolina Public health restaurant and food-stand inspections in Iredell County, June 28-July 11 Perfect timing: Residents elect Town of Mooresville's fourth dog mayor Trump injured but 'fine' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead NC high school student on robotics trip drowns at Ocean Isle Beach Trump picks Sen. JD Vance of Ohio, a once-fierce critic turned loyal ally, as his GOP running mate Erickson's journey comes full circle -- from junior volunteer to Lake Norman Regional Medical Center nurse Tribune print copies move to Tuesday, Weekend editions Hickory Aviation Museum to receive Harrier jump jet on Monday Iredell EMS deputy director talks about his termination. Appeal set for July 10 3 from South Carolina die in Nebo NC plane crash; national safety board investigating Trump heads to convention as authorities investigate motive, security in assassination attempt Summit Place Mooresville celebrates Health Care Appreciation Week\n\nNearly 7 million Americans are living with Alzheimer's disease - a leading cause of death in the United States. Additionally, more than 11 million family members and friends provide care to people living with Alzheimer's and other dementias. In North Carolina alone, there are more than 210,000 people living with the disease and 373,000 caregivers. Iredell County has an Alzheimer's prevalence rate of 10.5% in its age 65 and older population.\n\nTo register as a participant or team captain or to learn more about becoming a sponsor or volunteer of Walk to End Alzheimer's - Iredell Co. & Lake Norman, visit act.alz.org/IredellCoLKN or call 800-272-3900.\n\nThe Alzheimer's Association hosts 17 walks across North Carolina including: Alamance County, Asheville, Charlotte, Gaston/Cleveland/Lincoln Counties, Fayetteville, Guilford County, Henderson County, Unifour (Hickory), Iredell Co. & Lake Norman, Jacksonville, Moore County, Mount Airy, New Bern, Rowan-Cabarrus Counties, Triangle (Raleigh and Durham), Wilmington and Winston-Salem. To register and receive the latest updates on any of this year's Walk to End Alzheimer's, visit: alz.org/walk\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.\n\nDonna Swicegood\n\nLocal Editor\n\nFollow Donna Swicegood\n\nClose Get email notifications on {{subject}} daily!\n\nYour notification has been saved.\n\nThere was a problem saving your notification.\n\n{{description}}\n\nEmail notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items.\n\nSave\n\nManage followed notifications\n\nClose Followed notifications\n\nPlease log in to use this feature Log In\n\nDon't have an account? {'uri': '8228118842', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '11:29:49', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T11:29:49Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T11:29:27Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://richmond.com/sports/college/football/preseason-all-acc-football-ballot-2024/article_5dc46acc-4214-11ef-afc3-f71ac29fc8c3.html', 'title': 'Teel: Transfers, realignment make preseason All-ACC football team a puzzle', 'body': "Distilling the transfer and realignment turbulence that defines college sports in 2024, the Pac-12's top two rushers last season will play this year in the ACC.\n\nCrazy, right? And once, not long ago, when NCAA rules mandated redshirt seasons for transfers, and conferences didn't mock geography, this was impossible.\n\nYet here we are.\n\nCal's Jaydn Ott led the Pac-12 with 109.6 rushing yards per game last year, followed by Oregon State's Damien Martinez at 98.8. Ott and the Golden Bears now compete in the ACC, while Martinez has transferred to Miami.\n\nPeople are also reading... New Virginia state law changes the way reading is taught Teel: New Richmond ballpark, Henrico arenas would defy odds Kings Dominion gets approval to build new roller coaster Trump co-manager takes online shot at Virginia House speaker Trump injured but 'fine' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Midlothian man stopped woman from opening plane's emergency door Opinion: In Richmond, reality seeps in - City Hall dysfunction is systemic Meet the 2024 All-Metro boys lacrosse team, led by St. Christopher's Liam Wright New Richmond ballpark now has general contractors on the team Stray voltage likely cause of death for Colorado teen visiting Smith Mountain Lake L.C. Bird football alumnus, program leader Xavier Carpenter dies in Missouri car crash Pedestrian struck in Henrico County hit-and-run dies; baby in critical condition Youngkin uses convention speech to shine spotlight on Virginia Wine Spectator ranks these as best 8 Richmond-area restaurants for wine UPDATE: Charges pending in Cumberland buggy crash that killed 1, injured 6 Teel: Most important football season in ACC history on horizon\n\nMartinez and Ott also embody the challenge of voting for the preseason All-ACC team. How best to evaluate not only scores of transfers but also three incoming programs in Cal, Stanford and SMU?\n\nConsider, also, the conference's star power at quarterback. Three projected starters averaged at least 250 passing yards per game last year. Another averaged 261.2 while setting a Bowl Subdivision record for efficiency in 2021.\n\nNone played in the ACC last season.\n\nCam Ward, the nation's most prolific returning passer at 311.3 yards per game, transferred from Washington State to Miami. SMU's Preston Stone competed in the American Athletic Conference, while Syracuse's Kyle McCord helped Ohio State to an 11-1 regular season.\n\nGrayson McCall, he of the then-record 207.65 passer rating in 2021 at Coastal Carolina, could lead NC State to ACC contention this season.\n\nSo here's the ballot, due next week when the conference stages its annual media days in Charlotte, North Carolina.\n\nOFFENSE\n\nQuarterback: NC State's McCall. There are myriad quality choices, but Group of Five competition at Coastal notwithstanding, McCall's 88-14 career ratio of touchdown passes to interceptions is remarkable.\n\nRunning back: North Carolina's Omarion Hampton and Miami's Martinez. Hampton (115.7 yards per game) is the FBS' No. 2 returning rusher behind Oklahoma State's Ollie Gordon.\n\nReceiver: NC State's KC Concepcion, Louisville's Caullin Lacy and Miami's Xavier Restrepo. A transfer from South Alabama, Lacy is the nation's top returning pass-catcher (109.7 yards per game).\n\nTight end: North Carolina's Bryson Nesbit. A first-team selection last season, he'll have to adjust to life without quarterback Drake Maye.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nTackle: Florida State's Darius Washington and Miami's Jalen Rivers. Washington is the only offensive lineman returning from the 2023 All-ACC first team.\n\nGuard: SMU's Logan Parr and Louisville's Michael Gonzalez. Parr and teammate Justin Osborne were the first-team All-American Athletic Conference guards last season, and Osborne has moved inside to center.\n\nCenter: Virginia's Brian Stevens. Pro Football Focus graded him the league's best run-blocker at the position in 2023.\n\nAll-purpose: Virginia Tech's Bhayshul Tuten. He was the lone ACC player last year with multiple touchdowns rushing (10), receiving (two) and returning (two kickoffs).\n\nDEFENSE\n\nEnd: Louisville's Ashton Gillotte and Miami's Reuben Bain. This is the ACC's deepest position as eight of the 10 players who made all-league last season return, including Virginia Tech's Antwaun Powell-Ryland. Moreover, there are quality transfers such as Marvin Jones Jr. (Georgia to Florida State) and Fadil Diggs (Texas A&M to Syracuse).\n\nTackle: Florida State's Joshua Farmer and Virginia Tech's Aeneas Peebles. Pro Football Focus graded Peebles, then playing at Duke, second among all defensive tackles in pass rush last season.\n\nLinebacker: Miami's Francisco Mauigoa, Syracuse's Marlowe Wax and Clemson's Barrett Carter. Mauigoa recorded a league-best 15 solo tackles for loss last year.\n\nCornerback: NC State's Aydan White and Virginia Tech's Dorian Strong. From all accounts, Florida State's Azareye'h Thomas dominated spring practices, but 2023 third-team selections Strong and White are more established.\n\nSafety: Virginia's Jonas Sanker and Florida State's Shyheim Brown. Sanker (league-best 73 solo tackles) and Gillotte are the only All-ACC first-team defenders returning from last season.\n\nSPECIAL TEAMS\n\nSpecialist: SMU's Brashard Smith. Playing at Miami last season, Smith led the ACC with 579 yards in kickoff returns and earned second-team all-conference.\n\nKicker: North Carolina's Noah Burnette made 19 for 20 field goals and all 43 PATs last year. Virginia Tech's John Love and FSU's Ryan Fitzgerald also converted all of their PATs and more than 90% of their field goal attempts.\n\nPunter: Florida State's Alex Mastromanno. Flip a coin between Mastromanno and Duke's Porter Wilson. You can't go wrong.\n\nWhat's certain to go wrong is a subsequent column projecting the ACC's order of finish 1-17.\n\nSports Week in Pictures: Wimbledon, Tour de France gain momentum\n\nDavid Teel (804) 649-6546\n\ndteel@timesdispatch.com\n\nDavid Teel\n\nSports Reporter\n\nAuthor twitter Author email Follow David Teel Close Get email notifications on {{subject}} daily! Sign Up Today", 'source': {'uri': 'richmond.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Richmond Times-Dispatch'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'david_teel@richmond.com', 'name': 'David Teel', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/richmond.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/5/dc/5dc46acc-4214-11ef-afc3-f71ac29fc8c3/6694285935a33.preview.jpg?crop=1100%2C578%2C0%2C77&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1137254901960785, 'wgt': 458825389, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8228061925', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '10:56:39', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T10:56:39Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T10:55:29Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://buffalonews.com/sports/professional/nfl/bills/buffalo-bills-position-preview-linebackers-matt-milano-training-camp-nfl/article_d8e55188-42d4-11ef-80f9-5fabf387861e.html', 'title': 'Bills position preview: Return of Matt Milano strengthens linebacking corps', 'body': 'This is the eighth in a series looking at the status of each position before the Buffalo Bills report to training camp on July 23. This installment: Linebackers.\n\nThe biggest addition to the Buffalo Bills\' 2024 defense won\'t come from outside the organization.\n\nThe return of All-Pro linebacker Matt Milano, who suffered a season-ending leg injury last year in Week 5 against the Jaguars, easily is the most important development at a position of strength for the Bills. Milano will join Terrel Bernard, last year\'s breakout star, in forming an imposing duo in the team\'s base defense.\n\nAnalytics website Pro Football Focus placed Milano at No. 4 on its list of top linebackers in the NFL entering the 2024 season despite his extended absence last year - a good indication of the respect that exists for his game.\n\nPeople are also reading... Watch: Video shows Buffalo man killed by police sped off with officer clinging to car Man shot dead by Buffalo police is brother of slain 12-year-old At least four tornadoes, two packing 110 mph winds, hit Western New York, weather service reports After two years of interest, Bills and DeShawn Williams strike a deal Alan Pergament: \'Beatles\' host JP leaves WECK after disagreement with station owner Buddy Shula \'Quite an undertaking\': Cleanup starts after Beryl blows through Western New York Pit bull attack severs woman\'s arm the day before dog was to be put down Tops worker in Cheektowaga helps save customer who had medical emergency in parking lot Pregnant in her sophomore year, Bennett High School graduate finds self-worth - with plenty of help Ryan McLeod\'s \'whirlwind\' trade has new Sabres center \'excited\' to get to Buffalo First of $23.5 million worth of affordable homes will be built in Cheektowaga \'The numbers are just astronomical:\' Why developers are putting more projects on hold State agency, waterside attraction leaders losing patience with stalled project at Canalside Family recipes are the heart of new Marta\'s Market in East Aurora Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead\n\n"Credit to Matt and what he\'s been able to do with our training staff and the work he\'s put in," Bills head coach Sean McDermott said during mandatory minicamp last month. "He\'s so focused. He was focused before this. I feel like he\'s even more focused, if that\'s even possible now, in wanting to get back out there for himself, but also for his teammates."\n\nBills linebacker Baylon Spector knows he must shake off \'injury prone\' label\n\nBaylon Spector knows all too well why the old saying "the best ability is availability" exists in the NFL. The Buffalo Bills\' linebacker endured a frustrating 2023 season, dealing with multiple injuries that resulted in him appearing in just nine regular-season games.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nThe Bills\' base defense is nickel, which means five defensive backs and two linebackers are on the field for most plays. Entering 2023, who would line up next to Milano was an open question. Bernard provided a resounding answer, putting together a fantastic season. Because of that, he enters 2024 with the expectation that he\'ll take a big step forward as both a player and leader.\n\n"Whether it\'s the player-to-coach relationship or the coach-to-player relationship, there\'s a sense of trust that has to be earned, right? The coach has to show a player that you can help them grow and help them succeed," Bills defensive coordinator Bobby Babich said. "And in turn, the player has to show that they can be trustworthy. We can give him the keys to the car and he\'s going to drive it, and it\'s going to be a smooth, smooth ride. And it grew."\n\nReturnees: Matt Milano, Terrell Bernard, Dorian Williams, Baylon Spector.\n\nNewcomers: Joe Andreessen, Nicholas Morrow, Deion Jones, Edefuan Ulofoshio.\n\nDepartures: A.J. Klein, Tyler Matakevich, Tyrel Dodson.\n\nTop battle: Jones vs. Morrow vs. Spector vs. Ulofoshio.\n\nBills position preview: Defensive tackle depth chart undergoes a makeover\n\nThe Buffalo Bills\' front office significantly rebuilt the interior of the team\'s defensive line this offseason.\n\nLet\'s go with a WWE-style, fatal-fourway matchup here. For this purpose, we\'re excluding Andreessen, who is considered a roster long shot. The Bills carried six linebackers on the 53-man roster. Working off that number, it\'s safe to assume Bernard, Milano and Williams, as a 2023 third-round pick, are safe. That leaves three spots for four players. A strong case can be made for each of them. Morrow made 12 starts and 95 tackles for Philadelphia last year. He\'s probably the first choice as Bernard\'s backup at middle linebacker. Spector is entering his third season in Buffalo, so he knows the defensive scheme well and is in line for a key job on special teams, perhaps as Matakevich\'s replacement. The Bills used a fifth-round pick on Ulofoshio and likely don\'t want to expose him to waivers. Jones, meanwhile, is another veteran option, with 91 career starts in eight NFL seasons. Barring an injury, there doesn\'t figure to be room for all of them.\n\nWhat to expect: If Milano and Bernard stay healthy, the Bills should have one of the best duos in the NFL at the position. It would be nice to see Williams take a big step in his second season. That way, the Bills can feel comfortable putting him on the field when they go to three-linebacker sets, or he can be the first backup to come into the game if Bernard and/or Milano miss time. It was clear last year that Williams has the athleticism to make an impact in the NFL, but the coaching staff was hesitant to play him, ultimately deciding on Dodson as Milano\'s long-term replacement. The additions of Morrow and Jones give the team two reliable veteran options. Spector needs to stay healthy. It\'s not a huge deal in the grand scheme of things, but missing mandatory minicamp with an undisclosed injury won\'t do anything to shake the idea that he\'s injury prone. Ulofoshio was a leader at Washington, which made it to the national championship game. He worked his way up from walk-on to team captain with the Huskies. Here\'s some good bar trivia for you: He\'s looking to become just the 16th player ever born in Alaska to appear in an NFL game.\n\n0 Comments Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '2024-07-423473190', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '10:46:35', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T10:46:35Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T10:30:28Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://eu.greenbaypressgazette.com/story/sports/mlb/brewers/2024/07/16/from-war-to-whip-baseballs-new-stats-and-acronyms-are-bewildering-lori-nickel-column/74381927007/', 'title': 'Lori Nickel: A new (again) baseball fan struggles with modern metrics and their acronyms', 'body': 'Confession: I haven\'t been following baseball. Not the Brewers, not the league, not the World Series.\n\nThere are a lot of reasons why: the disillusioning strike of 1994, the stodgy ultramarathon games and the fact Robin \'The Kid\' Yount couldn\'t play into his pensioner years. I used to celebrate my birthday at County Stadium with my softball glove, and Cecil Cooper and Ben Oglivie buttons. Then I grew up and left the Mark McGwire game entirely to cover football and basketball and everything else.\n\nDecades passed. And the game advanced so much in that time, and the statistics, the specialties, the hyper-specific scenarios that yielded analytics and metrics followed. There\'s stuff called WAR and WHIP and OBP+. There\'s a "hard hit rate" that kind of makes sense, but what the hell is rOBA?\n\nThere\'s Pull%, Cent% and Oppo% - something about batters and their tendencies - and Standard Fielding Pos and lgRFGs. Yuck.\n\nI look at baseball now the way a baby boomer looks at an Uber. You tell me I\'m supposed to trust it, but I don\'t ... and I can\'t remember my app password anyway.\n\nStill, there\'s something about this year, 2024. Major League Baseball finally made pitchers and batters pick up the pace in 2023, and this season these National League Central-leading Brewers became ... intriguing. Everyone in the clubhouse talks about the super-low expectations, and we all know underdog journeys really are the best stories. It was time to face my anxiety - I don\'t know this game, I don\'t understand these intricacies - and see if I could return to baseball. And learn its peculiar language.\n\nMedia. Watch games, listen to broadcasts and podcasts, and read the coverage.\n\nAnd stats - because no other sport marries itself to data more than this one.\n\nA natural place to start was Gold Glove-winner, MVP and all-around good-attitude dude Christian Yelich.\n\nOK, one of the stat websites - baseball-reference.com - features 12 pages. Batting average, plate appearances, home runs, stolen bases, RBIs. It starts with the usual stuff, all makes sense.\n\nAnd then ... OBP, OPS and OPS plus. And ... player value batting.\n\nMy anxiety levels rise. This is clearly a foreign language. I reach out to Jeff Levering, the very kind, very knowledgeable Brewers radio broadcaster. He will help translate.\n\n"I\'ll have to study up, some of these stats are like programming a VCR," he responded via text, and that is funny in more ways than one.\n\nOK, in the meantime, we can always count on broadcasters Brian Anderson and Bill Schroeder. They were calling a Brewers-Boston Red Sox game on June 2 and discussing the batting percentage leaders in the National League when they posited the question: does Yelich have a chance at the NL batting title?\n\nAnderson: A player needs 3.2 at-bat plate appearances per team games to qualify for the batting title. Yelich missed some time mid-April ...\n\nAs I\'m doing a Google search - who is Dom, Brewers? - Anderson and Schroeder jump back to the topic. Their man Dom reports the number is actually 3.1, not 3.2 and ... what were we talking about anyway?\n\nHe rolls his gaze - just a little. It\'s four hours before another game in a summer of endless games and the 32-year-old veteran has likely heard every question that ever existed. God, it must get old. But these stats! They make for endless talking points and debates and Yelich is a newly inducted member of some elite 200 club - career home runs and steals. So Yelich must have a great take on all this; what stats are good, and what are a joke; and which ones are really telling, and which are helpful, and ...\n\n"I don\'t even look at my stats; I couldn\'t tell you a single one of my stats right now. I have zero idea. Like no clue," he said. "They don\'t matter to me until the end of the season because they change so much. So I don\'t look at them."\n\nOh. But ... in general, there must be some stat that\'s valuable?\n\n"Not really. People talk about them - the media and the fans. I don\'t know. Players, like - we don\'t really care."\n\nAwkward silence. It\'s not a slammed door on this story idea but wow, if he doesn\'t care, should we? My anxiety alarms are blaring. This is the MVP who has come to Bucks games to watch the other MVP in town. This is a respected guy in Milwaukee. And he\'s killing this stat story project before its even started. Is he serious? One last weak attempt: BABIP? Does he care about that? Does he care about anything?\n\nBut it makes sense. When someone like Yelich works and trains and plays like he does, what purpose would it serve to look at numbers and trends?\n\n"I don\'t know why you\'d want to put yourself through looking at your stuff like every day," Yelich said. "I care about winning and trying to help the team win."\n\nIt means there\'s room for the rest of us to try to decode the numerical quirks and statistical quarks of the game without the pressure of trying to fake like we know it.\n\nLet\'s head out to the yard. Hey, at least baseball is an inviting sport to the spectator, unlike the dizzying flurry of football and frenetic pace of basketball. Baseball is polite, letting you gather your flock, find your spot and settle in to take in the weather, the people around you and the smell of the roasting hot dogs before you have to be alert. Because nothing ever happens in the first inning.', 'source': {'uri': 'greenbaypressgazette.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Green Bay Press-Gazette'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'green_bay_press_gazette@greenbaypressgazette.com', 'name': 'Green Bay Press-Gazette', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.gannett-cdn.com/presto/2022/04/06/PMJS/2c9f6134-7a4d-48db-8157-a2e8f7b41d44-BREWERS_1427.JPG?auto=webp&crop=3899,2194,x0,y198&format=pjpg&width=1200', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1294117647058823, 'wgt': 458822795, 'relevance': 9}

Players, like - we don\'t really care."\n\nAwkward silence. It\'s not a slammed door on this story idea but wow, if he doesn\'t care, should we? My anxiety alarms are blaring. This is the MVP who has come to Bucks games to watch the other MVP in town. This is a respected guy in Milwaukee. And he\'s killing this stat story project before its even started. Is he serious? This is the MVP who has come to Bucks games to watch the other MVP in town. This is a respected guy in Milwaukee. And he\'s killing this stat story project before its even started. Is he serious? One last weak attempt: BABIP? Does he care about that? Does he care about anything?\n\nBut it makes sense. When someone like Yelich works and trains and plays like he does, what purpose would it serve to look at numbers and trends?\n\n"I don\'t know why you\'d want to put yourself through looking at your stuff like every day," Yelich said. "I care about winning and trying to help the team win."\n\nIt means there\'s room for the rest of us to try to decode the numerical quirks and statistical quarks of the game without the pressure of trying to fake like we know it.\n\nLet\'s head out to the yard. Hey, at least baseball is an inviting sport to the spectator, unlike the dizzying flurry of football and frenetic pace of basketball. Baseball is polite, letting you gather your flock, find your spot and settle in to take in the weather, the people around you and the smell of the roasting hot dogs before you have to be alert. Because nothing ever happens in the first inning.', 'source': {'uri': 'wausaudailyherald.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Wausau Daily Herald'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://www.gannett-cdn.com/presto/2022/04/06/PMJS/2c9f6134-7a4d-48db-8157-a2e8f7b41d44-BREWERS_1427.JPG?auto=webp&crop=3899,2194,x0,y198&format=pjpg&width=1200', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1294117647058823, 'wgt': 458822435, 'relevance': 9}
{'uri': '2024-07-423467122', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '10:40:15', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T10:40:15Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T10:30:28Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://eu.postcrescent.com/story/sports/mlb/brewers/2024/07/16/from-war-to-whip-baseballs-new-stats-and-acronyms-are-bewildering-lori-nickel-column/74381927007/', 'title': 'Lori Nickel: A new (again) baseball fan struggles with modern metrics and their acronyms', 'body': 'Confession: I haven\'t been following baseball. Not the Brewers, not the league, not the World Series.\n\nThere are a lot of reasons why: the disillusioning strike of 1994, the stodgy ultramarathon games and the fact Robin \'The Kid\' Yount couldn\'t play into his pensioner years. I used to celebrate my birthday at County Stadium with my softball glove, and Cecil Cooper and Ben Oglivie buttons. Then I grew up and left the Mark McGwire game entirely to cover football and basketball and everything else.\n\nDecades passed. And the game advanced so much in that time, and the statistics, the specialties, the hyper-specific scenarios that yielded analytics and metrics followed. There\'s stuff called WAR and WHIP and OBP+. There\'s a "hard hit rate" that kind of makes sense, but what the hell is rOBA?\n\nThere\'s Pull%, Cent% and Oppo% - something about batters and their tendencies - and Standard Fielding Pos and lgRFGs. Yuck.\n\nI look at baseball now the way a baby boomer looks at an Uber. You tell me I\'m supposed to trust it, but I don\'t ... and I can\'t remember my app password anyway.\n\nStill, there\'s something about this year, 2024. Major League Baseball finally made pitchers and batters pick up the pace in 2023, and this season these National League Central-leading Brewers became ... intriguing. Everyone in the clubhouse talks about the super-low expectations, and we all know underdog journeys really are the best stories. It was time to face my anxiety - I don\'t know this game, I don\'t understand these intricacies - and see if I could return to baseball. And learn its peculiar language.\n\nMedia. Watch games, listen to broadcasts and podcasts, and read the coverage.\n\nAnd stats - because no other sport marries itself to data more than this one.\n\nA natural place to start was Gold Glove-winner, MVP and all-around good-attitude dude Christian Yelich.\n\nOK, one of the stat websites - baseball-reference.com - features 12 pages. Batting average, plate appearances, home runs, stolen bases, RBIs. It starts with the usual stuff, all makes sense.\n\nAnd then ... OBP, OPS and OPS plus. And ... player value batting.\n\nMy anxiety levels rise. This is clearly a foreign language. I reach out to Jeff Levering, the very kind, very knowledgeable Brewers radio broadcaster. He will help translate.\n\n"I\'ll have to study up, some of these stats are like programming a VCR," he responded via text, and that is funny in more ways than one.\n\nOK, in the meantime, we can always count on broadcasters Brian Anderson and Bill Schroeder. They were calling a Brewers-Boston Red Sox game on June 2 and discussing the batting percentage leaders in the National League when they posited the question: does Yelich have a chance at the NL batting title?\n\nAnderson: A player needs 3.2 at-bat plate appearances per team games to qualify for the batting title. Yelich missed some time mid-April ...\n\nAs I\'m doing a Google search - who is Dom, Brewers? - Anderson and Schroeder jump back to the topic. Their man Dom reports the number is actually 3.1, not 3.2 and ... what were we talking about anyway?\n\nHe rolls his gaze - just a little. It\'s four hours before another game in a summer of endless games and the 32-year-old veteran has likely heard every question that ever existed. God, it must get old. But these stats! They make for endless talking points and debates and Yelich is a newly inducted member of some elite 200 club - career home runs and steals. So Yelich must have a great take on all this; what stats are good, and what are a joke; and which ones are really telling, and which are helpful, and ...\n\n"I don\'t even look at my stats; I couldn\'t tell you a single one of my stats right now. I have zero idea. Like no clue," he said. "They don\'t matter to me until the end of the season because they change so much. So I don\'t look at them."\n\nOh. But ... in general, there must be some stat that\'s valuable?\n\n"Not really. People talk about them - the media and the fans. I don\'t know. Players, like - we don\'t really care."\n\nAwkward silence. It\'s not a slammed door on this story idea but wow, if he doesn\'t care, should we? My anxiety alarms are blaring. This is the MVP who has come to Bucks games to watch the other MVP in town. This is a respected guy in Milwaukee. And he\'s killing this stat story project before its even started. Is he serious? One last weak attempt: BABIP? Does he care about that? Does he care about anything?\n\nBut it makes sense. When someone like Yelich works and trains and plays like he does, what purpose would it serve to look at numbers and trends?\n\n"I don\'t know why you\'d want to put yourself through looking at your stuff like every day," Yelich said. "I care about winning and trying to help the team win."\n\nIt means there\'s room for the rest of us to try to decode the numerical quirks and statistical quarks of the game without the pressure of trying to fake like we know it.\n\nLet\'s head out to the yard. Hey, at least baseball is an inviting sport to the spectator, unlike the dizzying flurry of football and frenetic pace of basketball. Baseball is polite, letting you gather your flock, find your spot and settle in to take in the weather, the people around you and the smell of the roasting hot dogs before you have to be alert. Because nothing ever happens in the first inning.', 'source': {'uri': 'postcrescent.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Post-Crescent'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://www.gannett-cdn.com/presto/2022/04/06/PMJS/2c9f6134-7a4d-48db-8157-a2e8f7b41d44-BREWERS_1427.JPG?auto=webp&crop=3899,2194,x0,y198&format=pjpg&width=1200', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.1294117647058823, 'wgt': 458822415, 'relevance': 9}

So we got to be creative with it," Nelson said.\n\nFor anyone looking to venture into a side-hustle, Nelson recommended a "good ol\' brain dump."\n\n"Get all of your ideas into a list. Any ideas you\'ve ever had," she said. "What are you really good at? What do you enjoy doing? (Travis Fortnum/CTV News Windsor)\n\nFrom there, Nelson suggested hitting the net.\n\nGoogle some ideas. A 31-22 road loss to Georgia Tech dropped the Orange to 5-6 and ultimately led to Babers' dismissal after eight seasons.\n\nNunzio Campanile, in an interim role, led Syracuse to a four-point win over Wake Forest in the regular-season finale to secure the Orange's second consecutive bowl berth and an opportunity to play for a winning record in back-to-back seasons for the first time since 2012-13.\n\nThe Boca Raton Bowl didn't fare well for a Syracuse team that was without starting quarterback Garrett Shrader. South Florida held the Orange to 159 yards of total offense in a 45-0 win that spoiled Campanile's two games as interim coach.\n\nSyracuse, which will host Virginia Tech on Nov. 2, hired Fran Brown as head coach to turn around the program. Brown, who spent two seasons as defensive backs coach at Georgia and was known for his recruiting prowess, helped bring in plenty of transfers to fill voids in the Orange roster and currently has one of the nation's top recruiting classes in the 2025 cycle.\n\nPeople are also reading... New Virginia state law changes the way reading is taught Teel: New Richmond ballpark, Henrico arenas would defy odds Kings Dominion gets approval to build new roller coaster Trump co-manager takes online shot at Virginia House speaker Trump injured but 'fine' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Midlothian man stopped woman from opening plane's emergency door Opinion: In Richmond, reality seeps in - City Hall dysfunction is systemic Meet the 2024 All-Metro boys lacrosse team, led by St. Christopher's Liam Wright New Richmond ballpark now has general contractors on the team Stray voltage likely cause of death for Colorado teen visiting Smith Mountain Lake L.C. Bird football alumnus, program leader Xavier Carpenter dies in Missouri car crash Pedestrian struck in Henrico County hit-and-run dies; baby in critical condition Youngkin uses convention speech to shine spotlight on Virginia Wine Spectator ranks these as best 8 Richmond-area restaurants for wine First section of Fall Line Trail opens in Henrico\n\nBrown's tenure opens with four consecutive home games against Ohio, Georgia Tech, Stanford and Holy Cross. The nonconference slate also features a road game against UNLV and a home game against UConn.\n\nThe Orange will play two of the ACC's three new members. They will travel to play at California on Nov. 16.\n\nLast time vs. Virginia Tech: Virginia Tech won 38-10 on Oct. 26, 2023\n\nWhat happened? Malachi Thomas' touchdown pass to Da'Quan Felton was one of the trick plays Tyler Bowen called in the Hokies' blowout win over the Orange on that Thursday night.\n\nTech racked up 528 yards of total offense. Most of that yardage came on the ground as the Hokies rushed for 318 yards, led by 118 from Bhayshul Tuten and 87 from Thomas. Kyron Drones threw for 194 yards and a touchdown as the Hokies moved the ball at will against the beleaguered visitors.\n\nPosition(s) of strength: Syracuse landed one of the top quarterbacks in the transfer portal when Ohio State's Kyle McCord elected to join the ACC program. McCord was coming off his first season as a starter with the Buckeyes and led them to an 11-1 record when he entered the portal.\n\nMcCord instantly upgraded Syracuse's quarterback room. He threw for 3,170 yards, 24 touchdowns and six interceptions last season, and he had more than 200 yards passing in 11 of the 12 games.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nMcCord joined an offense that returns six of the seven offensive linemen who started multiple games last season. (Left guard Chris Bleich, an All-ACC honorable mention selection, is the only one who isn't back.) Leading rusher LeQuint Allen (1,064 yards and nine touchdowns) is returning, along with the Nos. 2 and 3 receivers (Umari Hatcher and Donovan Brown) and top tight end Dan Villari.\n\nThe Orange lost top receiver Damien Alford (33 catches for 610 yards and three touchdowns) to Utah, but replaced him with Colorado State's Justus Ross-Simmons (45 catches for 724 yards and three scores).\n\nWhat's new in Syracuse: Brown's arrival meant a shake-up in the coaching staff. The first-time head coach elected to fill his staff with experience across the board.\n\nTwo coaches who were in the NFL in 2023 (Jeff Nixon with the New York Giants and Ross Douglas with the New England Patriots) are overseeing the running backs and wide receivers, respectively. Elijah Robinson (assistant head coach and defensive coordinator) and Joe Schaefer (defensive backs) were at Texas A&M last season. Robert Wright, the co-defensive coordinator and linebackers coach, was most recently the defensive coordinator at Mid-American Conference program Buffalo.\n\nDale and Nick Williams (not related) both had previous coaching experience at the Power Four level. Dale Williams previously worked at Louisville and Purdue, while Nick Williams had stops at Colorado, Texas A&M and Georgia.\n\nBrown retained only two members from the 2023 staff. Campanile is the offensive associate head coach and quarterbacks coach, and Michael Johnson remained on staff as the co-offensive coordinator and tight ends coach.\n\nThe Orange did have roster turnover with the coaching change. Twenty-eight players elected to enter the transfer portal, while Brown was able to bring in 19 players through the portal.\n\nLingering questions: The Orange actually finished with decent numbers on defense despite some lopsided outcomes. (Four of their seven losses were by at least 28 points.) They ranked midpack in the ACC in rushing and total defense and were decent at getting to the quarterback.\n\nLinebacker Marlowe Wax was instrumental in making sure his teammates were in the right spot, and he is back for another season guiding the unit. However, there aren't as many familiar faces surrounding him.\n\nSyracuse returns four players who started every game last season (Wax, linebacker Derek McDonald, boundary safety Alijah Clark and rover Justin Barron). Defensive tackle Denis Jaquez Jr. started the first three games at defensive tackle before suffering a season-ending injury in the sixth week.\n\nHow will the defense shape up with a new scheme and different faces?\n\nThe Orange's additions through the transfer portal focused on the defensive line and secondary. Four players from each position group were brought in to add depth and battle for starting roles. Wright, the former defensive coordinator at Buffalo, brough safety Devin Grant to Syracuse. Grant led the MAC with five interceptions, which was highlighted by returning two of his three interceptions for touchdowns against Central Michigan.\n\nCornerback Clarence Lewis made 23 starts over four seasons at Notre Dame. Defensive lineman Dion Wilson Jr. recorded 30 tackles last season for New Mexico State.\n\nDamien Sordelett (540) 981-3124\n\ndamien.sordelett@roanoke.com\n\nVTFB gamebug\n\nVIRGINIA TECH AT VANDERBILT\n\nSeason opener\n\nAug. 31: Noon TV: ESPN", 'source': {'uri': 'richmond.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Richmond Times-Dispatch'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@richmond.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/richmond.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/b/94/b945f512-400f-562e-862e-57a282361d22/6687499787908.preview.jpg?crop=1755%2C921%2C4%2C54&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.0117647058823529, 'wgt': 458817436, 'relevance': 51}

Scoring is 5-4-3-2-1 for the first five places.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"The races will be fast, they\'re all sprints," said Ocean City Beach Patrol Deputy Chief Holly Lesser. "The races are near the shore."\n\nLast year was the first time the Invitational was held at 12th Street rather than farther south on the island where there\'s no Boardwalk.\n\nPeople are also reading... Atlantic City Airshow canceled for 2024 Ocean City\'s Seaspray condo for sale at $7M Cape May County Zoo receives $1.4 million donation Longport resident says rats are coming from borough property 5 hurt, 76 displaced in 5-alarm Atlantic City apartment fire Wildwood police identify shooting suspect Atlantic City High School principal accused of failing to report child abuse due back in court Aug. 29 After dream debut, South Jersey native Tyler Phillips will start Saturday for the Phillies: Must Win Buddy Tarbotton, a Cape May County high school sports fixture, dies at 63 Route 30 drawbridge stuck open in Atlantic City South Jersey native Tyler Phillips to start Saturday for the Phillies Atlantic City fire union head calls for restoring of Ducktown engine in wake of Georgia Avenue blaze Egg Harbor City rescue in need of fosters, donors to help animals rescued from Galloway home Atlantic County League of Women Voters chair resigns after regretting Trump \'only grazed\' Kathy Le opened the Sunday Teahouse in Brigantine after two decades in her family\'s nail salon\n\n"It\'s a great event, and it makes it even better to be downtown," Lesser said. "We\'ve shortened up all the events to make them spectator friendly. We\'ll get a bigger crowd. We\'ve already been announcing it on the Boardwalk speakers all week just to get people excited about it and pumped up ready to come watch. The crowd downtown will definitely be more inclusive, and it\'s a fun event."\n\nThe first race, the row-swim, starts out like a doubles row. But at the halfway flag, one guard from each crew jumps out and swims back to the finish line on the beach. In the swim relay, one guard swims out and back, and her teammate will then do the same.\n\nThe third race, the paddle relay, also has two lifeguards teaming up. The run-swim relay starts with one guard doing a half-mile beach run. She tags a teammate who swims out to a flag and back.\n\nSea Girt was first in the run-swim in 2023 and scored 14 points to win the overall team title. Longport was second with 12 points, and Ocean City placed third with 11.\n\nContact Guy Gargan:\n\n609-272-7210\n\nGGargan@pressofac.com\n\nCan\'t get enough High School sports? {'uri': '2024-07-423351512', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '09:03:37', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T09:03:37Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T09:03:26Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.asahi.com/ajw/articles/15348351', 'title': 'Hong Kong is testing out its own ChatGPT-style tool as OpenAI planned extra steps to block access | The Asahi Shimbun Asia & Japan Watch', 'body': 'HONG KONG--Hong Kong\'s government is testing the city\'s own ChatGPT -style tool for its employees, with plans to eventually make it available to the public, its innovation minister said after OpenAI took extra steps to block access from the city and other unsupported regions.\n\nSecretary for Innovation, Technology and Industry Sun Dong said on a Saturday radio show that his bureau was trying out the artificial intelligence program, whose Chinese name translates to "document assistance application for civil servants," to further improve its capabilities. He plans to have it available for the rest of the government this year.\n\nThe program was developed by a generative AI research and development center led by the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology in collaboration with several other universities.\n\nSun said the model would provide functions like graphics and video design in the future. To what degree it would compare to the capabilities of ChatGPT was unclear.\n\nSun\'s bureau did not respond to The Associated Press\' questions about the model\'s functions.\n\nSun said on the radio show that industry players and the government would play a role in the model\'s future development.\n\n"Given Hong Kong\'s current situation, it\'s difficult for Hong Kong to get giant companies like Microsoft and Google to subsidize such projects, so the government had to start doing it," he said.\n\nBeijing and Washington are locked in a race for AI supremacy, with China having ambitions to become the global leader in AI by 2030.\n\nChina, including Hong Kong and neighboring Macao, is not on the list of "supported countries and territories" of OpenAI, one of the best-known artificial intelligence companies.\n\nThe ChatGPT maker has not explained why certain territories were excluded but said accounts in those places attempting to access its services may become blocked.\n\nAccording to a post on OpenAI\'s online forum and local media reports, the company announced in an email to some users that it would be taking additional measures to block connections from regions not on the approved list starting July 9. It did not explain the reasons behind the latest move.\n\nFrancis Fong, the honorary president of the Hong Kong Information Technology Federation, said it was hard to say whether the capabilities of the program in Hong Kong could match those of ChatGPT. With the input of AI companies in the city, Fong said he believed it could technologically catch up with the standards.\n\n"Will it become the top? Maybe may not necessarily be as close as that. But I believe it won\'t be too far behind," he said.\n\nHe also said a locally developed AI program might more accurately address local language and localized issues but adding it would "make sense" if the final product appears to be "politically correct."\n\nLike most foreign websites and applications, ChatGPT is technically unavailable in China because of the country\'s firewall, which censors the internet for residents. Determined individuals can still gain access via commonly available "virtual private networks" that bypass restrictions.\n\nChinese tech giants such as Alibaba and Baidu have already rolled out primarily Chinese-language AI models similar to ChatGPT for public and commercial use. However, these AI models must abide by China\'s censorship rules.\n\nIn May, China\'s cyberspace academy said an AI chatbot was being trained on President Xi Jinping\'s doctrine, a stark reminder of the ideological parameters within which Chinese AI models will operate.\n\nAlso in May, SenseTime, a major Chinese artificial intelligence company, launched SenseChat for users in Hong Kong, where most of the population speaks Cantonese as their mother tongue rather than Mandarin. But a check on Tuesday found the application could not provide answers to politically sensitive questions, such as what the Tiananmen crackdown in 1989 and Hong Kong\'s protests in 2019 were about.\n\nDuring the 1989 crackdown, Chinese troops opened fire on student-led pro-democracy protesters, resulting in hundreds, if not thousands, dead, and that remains a taboo subject in mainland China.\n\nIn 2019, protests that started over unpopular Hong Kong legislation morphed into an anti-government movement and the greatest political challenge to Beijing\'s rule since the former British colony returned to China in 1997.', 'source': {'uri': 'asahi.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': '朝日新聞デジタル'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'asahi_shimbun@asahi.com', 'name': 'Asahi Shimbun', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'japan@asahi.com', 'name': 'Japan', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'china@asahi.com', 'name': 'China', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://p.potaufeu.asahi.com/70df-p/picture/28655118/c775271f17e2e9b9708e0a6024ea6f95.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.003921568627450966, 'wgt': 458816617, 'relevance': 31}

{'uri': '2024-07-423347435', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '08:57:54', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T08:57:54Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T08:40:11Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://gamerant.com/once-human-how-logging-beaver-deviant/', 'title': 'Once Human: How To Get The Logging Beaver Deviant', 'body': "Quick Links\n\nHow To Get Logging Beavers In Once Human\n\nHow To Use Logging Beavers\n\nThe Logging Beaver is a deviant that every player in Once Human should have at their base. These little guys will chew on wood all day, providing players with a constant supply of useful Logs for no effort at all. With a couple of beavers at your base, you'll never have to chop another tree down again.\n\nIf you're planning on stocking up on tons of charcoal in Once Human, then a Logging Beaver is going to be a great help. Getting one of these is going to involve more luck than skill, however. Thankfully, there's a very useful trick that will let you refresh your game in hopes of finding a beaver before anyone else does.\n\n3:04\n\nRelated\n\nOnce Human: Gaia Cliff Monolith Exploration Guide (Elite Enemy, Mystical, Weapon, and Armor Crate Locations)\n\nThis guide will help player complete Settlement Exploration - Gaia Cliff Monolith Danger Zone, an optional quest in Once Human.\n\nHow To Get Logging Beavers In Once Human\n\nThe best way to get a Logging Beaver is to go to Meyer's Market in the Broken Delta. The main quest will tell you to go here as soon as you wrap things up around Deadsville. Once you arrive in the town, activate the nearby teleporter tower, then head south to the pier. If you're lucky, you should be able to see a Logging Beaver bubble floating around. Approach it, then press F to start the capturing process.\n\nIf there is no Logging Beaver at the pier, you can force your way into a different instance by changing worlds in Once Human. Head back to the teleporter tower, then press G. A menu listing all the worlds in your server will appear. Go through each of them while checking the pier if there's a Logging Beaver available, and keep repeating the process until you manage to catch one. If none of the worlds have a Logging Beaver, come back some other time.\n\nHow To Use Logging Beavers\n\nBefore your beavers can begin providing logs, you'll need to make an Isolated Securement Unit for them first. You can find it under the Facility tab of the Build menu, provided you've unlocked its associated node in the Memetics screen. Place the Isolated Securement Unit anywhere on your base, then deposit your Logging Beaver inside it. The beaver will automatically start logging whenever it has enough energy to do so, and you can claim all the Logs it got by interacting with its Securement Unit again.\n\nWith the Beaver inside its own securement unit, you can now modify its behavior to an extent. By default, the Logging Beaver will set out for wood every time its Deviant Power reaches or surpasses 30. If you interact with the Isolated Securement Unit and click on the small gear icon on the right side of the screen, you can change the Deviant Power Threshold, affecting the time your beaver spends working and resting.\n\nSetting the Deviant Power threshold to a higher number means your base deviants will work longer shifts, but they'll also rest for longer too. This shouldn't affect your overall gains too much, but you may want to switch this up depending if you're playing on the Manibus or Evolution's Call servers. If you need to squeeze out as many resources as you can, then keep the threshold as-is.\n\nOnce Human\n\nSystem PC , Mobile , Google , Apple\n\nPlatform(s) PC , Android , iOS\n\nReleased July 9, 2024\n\nPublisher(s) Starry Studio , NetEase, Inc.\n\nGenre(s) Survival , Shooter , Open-World\n\nOnce Human\n\nSystem PC , Mobile , Google , Apple\n\nPlatform(s) PC , Android , iOS\n\nReleased July 9, 2024\n\nPublisher(s) Starry Studio , NetEase, Inc.\n\nGenre(s) Survival , Shooter , Open-World", 'source': {'uri': 'gamerant.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Game Rant'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'marc_santos@gamerant.com', 'name': 'Marc Santos', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static0.gamerantimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/20240716141706_1.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458816274, 'relevance': 5}

{'uri': '2024-07-423257138', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '07:32:39', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T07:32:39Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T03:21:59Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.inc.com/jessica-stillman/3-most-important-words-great-leaders-say-richard-branson.html', 'title': 'The 3 Most Important Words All Great Leaders Say, According to Richard Branson', 'body': 'Why "I don\'t know" are the three most important words for leaders.\n\nLeaders are often celebrated for having all the answers and being ready to set the direction when others feel lost. There is a lot of scientific evidence that we tend to select the most confident among us as leaders, not the most competent. Claiming to know everything can get you pretty far.\n\nBut according to both Branson and Sinek, it won\'t get you as far as admitting when you don\'t know something and asking for help without shame or apology. Just being willing to say "I don\'t know" can be a leadership superpower.\n\nBranson gives two reasons for this in his LinkedIn post: "It encourages others to do the same, and it\'s the fastest way to learn!" Both are backed up by iconic leaders and considerable science.\n\nA decade or so ago, Google devoted years to trying to figure out what made certain teams wildly successful and others mediocre. You may have read about their startlingly simple conclusion, which has received a huge amount of media attention in the years since. Great teams, Google discovered, didn\'t have the smartest individual members or a particular mix of skills or backgrounds. They had "psychological safety."\n\nAs Harvard Business School professor Amy Edmondson explained in a classic 1999 study, psychological safety means a "shared belief held by members of a team that the team is safe for interpersonal risk-taking" and "a sense of confidence that the team will not embarrass, reject, or punish someone for speaking up."\n\nIn short, psychological safety means feeling safe to admit your ignorance, try things, mess up, and learn from mistakes. All without punishment or ridicule. How is it established? In lots of small ways, but one of the most important is by having leaders who model psychological safety by being willing to admit "I don\'t know."\n\nSo when Branson says that asking for help "encourages others to do the same," he\'s drawing on some of the most respected research on how truly great teams function.\n\nAnd how about Branson\'s other claim, that admitting your ignorance and asking for help is one of the fastest ways to learn? Turns out that too is backed by a mountain of research, as well as some of Branson\'s fellow moguls.\n\nIntellectual humility is the ability to admit you might be wrong and look for new information or other possibilities. Studies show it helps people understand other viewpoints, be more curious, and evaluate evidence. Admitting your shortcomings and asking for help and advice even makes you appear more intelligent, science shows. In short, confidently saying, "I don\'t know," as Branson observes, helps you learn faster and be smarter.\n\nWhich might be why intellectual luminaries from Wharton\'s Adam Grant to Harvard\'s Steven Pinker have all suggested that if you want to be more successful, a good place to start is greater intellectual humility. Jeff Bezos says it\'s one of the top qualities he looks for when hiring.\n\nAll of which is a long-winded way to say that, yes, confidence will get you pretty far as a leader. But for true greatness, you need to combine conviction with a keen understanding of your limitations and a willingness to freely admit what you don\'t know. Good leaders have vision. Great leaders have vision plus humility.', 'source': {'uri': 'inc.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Inc.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'jessica_stillman@inc.com', 'name': 'Jessica Stillman', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://img-cdn.inc.com/image/upload/w_1024,h_576,c_fill/images/panoramic/richard-branson_542593_fd0pxj.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.4431372549019608, 'wgt': 458811159, 'relevance': 78}

Apart from Bengaluru, Namma Yatri also offers cab aggregator services in Kochi, Kolkata and Chennai.\n\nThis funding comes close on the heels of the platform marking an expansion to its offerings off its auto and cab rentals to take on counterparts like Ola and Uber.\n\nThe app competes against the likes of Jugnoo, Oye Rickshaw among others.\n\nIt is pertinent to note that with this development Namma Yatri will probably become the first ride-hailing service to pilot auto rentals in the country.\n\nThe Namma Yatri\'s expansion spree is accompanied by the launch of several other similar ride-hailing apps across the nation.\n\nFor instance, a transport union in Bengaluru was reported to roll out an auto rickshaw ride booking app, \'Nagara Metered Auto\', in partnership with Agnibhu Technologies.\n\nWhile it remains to be seen how well the expansion spree bodes for Juspay and Namma Yatri, there is no denying that the competition in the Indian ride-hailing space has picked up.
