{'uri': '2024-07-423212240', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '06:45:14', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T06:45:14Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T06:11:51Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.starobserver.com.au/news/jacques-nieuwoudt-gay-male-beauty-gym-standards/232058', 'title': 'Jacques Nieuwoudt: Gay Male Beauty Standards & Trying to Attain the Unattainable', 'body': 'In this powerful essay, Jacques Nieuwoudt speaks about the unhealthy relationship gay male culture can have with the gym, toxic internalised male beauty standards, and muscle dysmorphia.\n\nNieuwoudt asks if there is a way to find balance with male beauty standards - particularly when surrounded by the yacht parties, circuit parties, and insatiable thirst for gay male beauty in the Sydney scene.\n\nHe asks if there is truly a point of contentment in the middle, somewhere between being proud of a healthy body and constantly trying to attain the unattainable: perfection.\n\n(Why) do you even lift?\n\nI am thirteen when I first step inside a gym. Overweight, inverted nipples, and wearing a T-shirt two sizes too big. My soon-to-be personal trainer enters the consultation room.\n\nWe hit the weights hard. We sort my nutrition, though all I\'m really hungry for are the veins pouring down his forearms. We never discuss how "massive" and "healthy" are not the same thing. Nor that gay men and bodybuilders are two of the highest risk groups for developing Muscle Dysmorphia.\n\nMy training continues more or less into uni, by which time my eyes have absorbed a lethal dose of "inspiration" (#bearmode #yoked #fitnessmodel). The resulting tumour is malignant, shaped like Mr Olympia, and metastasising in my optic nerve. I can no longer see the sex appeal of normal bodies.\n\nThe homogenous hotties of the Sydney gay scene don\'t help. It seems to me the ticket to any one of their yacht parties is a six-pack. I\'m sure what\'s left of my belly is inadmissible. The Daily Jocks speedo I try on agrees.\n\nI Google \'Trenbolone\' for the second time. I am scared. Scared because this time, the long list of side-effects, "neurotoxicity" and "advanced brain ageing" among them, doesn\'t scare me.\n\nBut this pull. This gravity I\'m feeling. It isn\'t just the product of toxic beauty standards or wanting to fit in; it\'s limbic. A lust I feel in my own body.\n\nUnlike the cis straight man, I experience homoeroticism. I don\'t just want my dream body. I\'m attracted to it. While the cis straight man sexualises women, an ontological other, I sexualise men, the grouping I belong to. So when platforms like Grindr, Instagram, and Twitter routinely reduce men into sexual objects, I learn to reduce myself.\n\n"I wish my pecs bulged out like his", "I wish I had his v-line", "Why can\'t my calves look like that?". I learn another man\'s sex appeal is just a deficit in myself. And it only takes a sideward glance by the dumbbells to see I\'m not alone.\n\nBut it isn\'t all bad. Sometimes I enjoy being a sexual object. Especially when I get to appreciate a fat pump in the mirror - or better yet - when it scores me a lingering glance in the changerooms. So I keep lifting.\n\nBy 24, I am 100 kilos and only 11 per cent body fat. Straight girls at the club start calling me superman. Circuit parties are a sea of men staring at the veins pouring down my forearms.\n\nBut still I\'m not muscular enough. Still, my reflection in the heat-smogged bathroom mirror is a checklist of "to-dos".\n\nBut resistance training is much easier than training to resist.\n\nSo I tell myself it\'s okay to want to look "fit". I constantly reiterate the enormous health benefits of weightlifting. Endorphins this and discipline that. I insist bodybuilding isn\'t just about aesthetics; it\'s a sport.\n\nI spin eloquent meta-narratives about the beauty of the process, about pushing oneself, about progress, endurance, and hitting new performance limits. I am persuasive.\n\nBut then I ask myself what came first: the lifting, or this legitimation? Are these neatly woven reasons really why I train? Or are they true because I need them to be? Because if I can\'t convince myself I gym for healthy, normative reasons, I\'ll be forced to stop altogether?\n\nRight now, I\'m dating a boy who, like me, wants to get massive. And, like me, he already is. The hairs below his jawline grow in in a little spiral pattern, and yet he squirms when I stare at him like a Van Gogh. He is articulate and contrarian, but regularly returns the day after a debate with a changed mind.\n\nThe two pillars of muscle running down his lower back seem shaped for my hands to hold (not to mention where they lead).\n\nWhen this boy glances past the cables at some grunting mass and tells me he wishes he were bigger, I am stupefied. I want to shake him.\n\n"You are overwhelming," I want to say. Just looking at him floods me with so much awe that it tickles my sinuses. And yet, even this boy can look at himself and see inadequacy.\n\nBut what makes me the most angry is I\'m in no position to correct him. My biceps, swollen as he says these things, are themselves an endorsement of the mindset we share. Bigger, bigger, but never big enough.\n\nI wish he had never stepped foot in the gym.\n\nIt is at this moment I realise I am no longer comfortable being an apologist for resistance training. It\'s time to answer the question I\'ve lobbed excuse after excuse at, but that, really, I\'m afraid to approach with a ten-foot pole.\n\nI go to the gym because I want a fuckable reflection. Because I enjoy the countless benefits of \'pretty privilege\'. Because I\'ve spent a decade internalising warped standards of male beauty. Because I want muscular men I don\'t know or care for to look me up and down like a piece of meat. Because, due to the wonders of homoeroticism, I can\'t decide if these are men I want to befriend, bed, or be.\n\nA confession from inside the cult of dysmorphia. Wouldn\'t that be an easy place to finish this article.\n\nUnfortunately, resistance training has done me immense good too.\n\nFor one, the food-loving kid inside me can finally eat seven meals a day and not hate himself for it. The meniscus tear in my knee is no longer a source of instability or pain, and I have an understanding of physical health and nutrition that I never would\'ve sought out otherwise.\n\nAnd, as much as I hate to say it, I do enjoy the process (\'endorphins\' this, and \'discipline\' that). I\'m even finally proud of my body (at least, most of the time).\n\nBut does that make it right to parade my musculature around as a monument to resistance training? All while knowing the dissatisfaction, obsession, and superficiality that went into building it? All while knowing some kid might find himself looking at the veins pouring down my forearms, and decide he wants to be a monument too?\n\nGym and I haven\'t broken up. As with any tumultuous long-term relationship, I\'m hoping there\'s a balance to be found. Though I wish the boy I\'m dating had never met gym, the two are well-acquainted now, and I imagine our little dysmorphic throuple will go on for the foreseeable future.\n\nBut it isn\'t all doom and dysmorphia.\n\nI do know one thing: taking a step back and examining my drives has allowed me to reclaim some autonomy. It has allowed me to invest a bit more into the parts of me that will actually outlive my remaining ten years of beauty.', 'source': {'uri': 'starobserver.com.au', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Star Observer'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://www.starobserver.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/JacquesImageJakeWeiszV2.png', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.2470588235294118, 'wgt': 458808314, 'relevance': 56}

Developed with local universities, this AI aims to enhance capabilities like graphics design. The initiative arises from restricted access to popular AI tools like OpenAI\'s ChatGPT in Hong Kong and China.\n\nHong Kong\'s government is pioneering its own ChatGPT-style AI tool for civil servants, aiming for public availability later, revealed Sun Dong, Secretary for Innovation, Technology and Industry, in a radio interview. Currently, the AI, termed as "document assistance application for civil servants," is under internal testing to enhance its diverse capabilities.\n\nThis sophisticated AI program is a collaborative effort spearheaded by the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, alongside other local universities. Planned functionalities include advanced graphics and video design capabilities, though Sun did not provide comparative details with ChatGPT.\n\nSun emphasized the role of both industry and government in the AI\'s future, noting that Hong Kong\'s reliance on government-led initiatives arises from limited support by tech giants like Microsoft and Google. The Himalayan-based roadster is scheduled to break covers on July 17 in Barcelona, Spain. Ahead of its debut tomorrow, the Chennai-based bikemaker is actively promoting the upcoming 450cc roadster on its social media handles.\n\nIn one of the recent teasers, the Guerilla 450 can be seen burning its tyres which in a way highlights the bike's sporty and street nature. The rear wheel gets shod with dual-purpose rubbers with thick sidewalls. In another teaser, the video shows glimpses of the city Barcelona where the Guerilla 450 is going to be unveiled.\n\nRoyal Enfield Guerilla 450: Styling\n\nRecently, the 450cc roadster was spotted in a dealership service station most likely for a quick service training for technicians or a pre-delivery inspection. We already know that Royal Enfield will offer the Guerilla 450 in single-tone as well dual-tone colour options including matte grey, red and black, and yellow and black.\n\nVisual highlights on Guerilla 450 include a chiselled yet muscular fuel tank, a floating tail section, a single-piece seat, split grab rails, an underbelly bash plate, and a stubby exhaust muffler, just like the one seen in Himalayan 450. Signature Royal Enfield elements like a round headlamp, an off-set circular instrument console, and round rear view mirrors have been carried over to the Guerilla.\n\nRoyal Enfield Guerilla 450: Features\n\nThe top-of-the-line Guerilla 450 will boast a feature-packed instrument cluster. This fully-digital display integrates Google Maps navigation, Bluetooth connectivity for calls, texts, music, and even lets you switch between ride modes. Lower trims get a simpler semi-digital setup similar to the Meteor 350 and Super Meteor 650. These might offer Tripper Navigation as an optional add-on.\n\nExpect all variants to come with LED headlights and turn signals, multiple ride mode options, and a USB charging port for your convenience.\n\nRoyal Enfield Guerilla 450: Mechanical specs\n\nTaking a closer look at leaked images, the Guerilla 450 sports a compact profile thanks to its 17-inch alloy wheels front and back. These wheels are wrapped in block-pattern tires, hinting at some off-road capability. The suspension setup appears to be telescopic forks upfront and a preload-adjustable monoshock at the rear, providing a balance of comfort and handling. Disc brakes on both wheels will ensure confident stopping power.\n\nUnder the frame, the Guerilla 450 borrows the same 450cc, single-cylinder, liquid-cooled engine from its sibling, the Himalayan 450. While the Himalayan produces 39 bhp and 40 Nm of torque, the Guerilla's engine tuning might be tweaked for a more road-focused character. Both bikes likely share a 6-speed gearbox with a slipper clutch for smoother gear changes.", 'source': {'uri': 'financialexpress.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Financial Express'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'express_drives_desk@financialexpress.com', 'name': 'Express Drives Desk', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.financialexpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/Royal-Enfield-Guerilla-450.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.0117647058823529, 'wgt': 458805686, 'relevance': 3}

There is also a main story that helps players progress through the world and activate the various Rift Anchors to open the pathway to bosses.\n\nAs players get further into the game and want to join up with allies and partake in PVP, they can join a Warband. Warbands are like clans in Once Human and also offer players unique things to do as various Warbands fight for resources.\n\nRelated\n\nOnce Human: How To Upgrade Weapons\n\nUpgrading weapons in Once Human is simple, but if you don\'t quite have the resources for a big upgrade, there are other ways to get stronger.\n\nHow To Create Or Join A Warband\n\nClose\n\nPlayers can create a Warband by going to the main menu, selecting the, "Get United" option, then selecting, "Warband". A list of existing Warbands in your current world will be displayed along the left side of the screen, with players also able to change worlds in order to get access to different Warbands if they would prefer different options.\n\nSome Warbands require applications, and sending them is as easy as selecting the Warband you want to join and press the, "Join Warband" button in the bottom right of the screen. Next to this button is the option to create a Warband, with players able to customize the name, logo, slogan, and restrictions to join. Creating a Warband makes you the leader, but it also costs 800 Energy Links. Joining a Warband, on the other hand, is free, with players able to join and leave as many Warbands as they want.\n\nRelated\n\nOnce Human: Beginner Mistakes To Avoid\n\nOnce Human is a complex game with a steep learning curve, so make sure you don\'t make these simple mistakes.\n\nBasics Of A Warband\n\nClose\n\nWarbands are the Once Human version of clans. Joining a Warband gives you allies that you can play together with while doing the basic activities in the game. As Warbands get stronger, they are able to take and hold territory to gather resources for all players in the Warband, while also declaring war with other Warbands to take territory.\n\nUpon first joining a Warband, players will get access to the Warband menu, found in the same place players went when trying to join a Warband. In this menu, basic members will be given a few things they can do:\n\nName\n\nExplanation\n\nDonate\n\nIn the Overview menu will be the "Donate Warband Fund" option in the bottom left. Players can donate ten items weekly to earn Warband Credits.\n\nCheck Members\n\nThe members menu lets players see the profiles of all members in the Warband, their ranking in the Warband, and whether they are online or not. This menu also gives players the ability to leave the Warband by holding, "Z".\n\nShop\n\nPlayers can trade their Warband Credits and Stardust Source for various items, with many refreshing weekly.\n\nThere are a few other things that can be done in a Warband, such as taking territory or declaring war, but this is only done by the leader.\n\nOnce Human\n\nSystem PC , Mobile , Google , Apple\n\nPlatform(s) PC , Android , iOS\n\nReleased July 9, 2024\n\nDeveloper(s) Starry Studio\n\nPublisher(s) Starry Studio , NetEase, Inc.', 'source': {'uri': 'gamerant.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Game Rant'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'joshua_leeds@gamerant.com', 'name': 'Joshua Leeds', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static0.gamerantimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/fes-30.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.3960784313725489, 'wgt': 458804699, 'relevance': 7}
{'uri': '8227576603', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '05:37:17', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T05:37:17Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T05:36:55Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.6431372761726379, 'url': 'https://www.theregister.com/2024/07/16/yandex_divests_russian_assets/', 'title': 'Yandex sells its Russian ops, emerges as Nebius Group', 'body': 'Two-year legal saga ends with Netherlands-based entity ready to bring Google clone to the world\n\nYandex has untangled its Dutch entity from its Russian operations in a $5.4 billion deal, the internet search provider announced on Monday - meaning it should be free to pursue customers outside of Vladimir Putin\'s domain.\n\nThe Born-in-Russia Google analog emerged in 1997 amid the dotcom boom, and by 2023 racked up [PDF] $9 billion in annual earnings. By then, the business encompassed not only its core search engine, but maps, navigation, e-commerce, cloud computing, autonomous vehicles and AI services.\n\nThe biz moved its IP out of Russia in 2022 - a strategic gambit "in light of the current geopolitical environment."\n\nThat\'s a polite way of saying "Russia is under heavy sanctions and that spells trouble for us."\n\nIn August of 2023, about a year after stepping down as CEO, Yandex cofounder Arkady Volozh publicly denounced Russia\'s invasion of Ukraine.\n\nVolozh will reportedly now become the CEO of the remaining Dutch-based business, which has chosen the name Nebius Group. The Yandex brand will no longer be used by the parent company after July 30.\n\nThe agreement for the sale of Yandex\'s Russian business to a Russian consortium was inked on February 4, 2024. Monday\'s announcement [PDF] celebrated the final closing of the transaction, at which Yandex offloaded its remaining minority stake of approximately 28 percent for $2.8 billion in cash and 162.5 million parent company class A shares.\n\nAccording to John Boynton, chairman of parent entity Yandex NV, the two-year endeavor to complete the cross-border divestment included the complete redesign of the group\'s operations.\n\nHe declared, "Today\'s announcement marks the end of a long and complicated chapter in the life of our company. All connections with Russia have now been severed." ®', 'source': {'uri': 'theregister.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'theregister.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://regmedia.co.uk/2022/05/05/shutterstock_yandex.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9733565', 'sentiment': 0.1215686274509804, 'wgt': 458804237, 'relevance': 125}
{'uri': '2024-07-423155821', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '05:35:45', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T05:35:45Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T03:58:12Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.6235294342041016, 'url': 'https://fadeawayworld.net/devin-booker-reflects-team-usas-win-australia-we-have-to-stay-on-the-gas', 'title': 'Devin Booker Reflects On Team USA\'s Narrow Win Over Australia: "We Have To Stay On The Gas"', 'body': 'Devin Booker spoke to Fadeaway World about what Team USA has to clean up after their close win over Australia.\n\nDevin Booker came off the bench for Team USA in their second pre-Olympic exhibition and the first one in Abu Dhabi against Australia. While the USA walked out as winners with a 98-92 score, the result was too close to comfort for everyone involved, with Booker stressing the need for the USA to stay engaged and aggressive while speaking to Fadeaway World after the game.\n\n"I think we have to stay on the gas, take care of the silly mistakes, the turnovers, and be the more physical team. We have to rebound and keep teams off the offensive glass."\n\nBooker put up 14 points on 4-7 shooting, going 3-3 on two-point opportunities and 7-7 from the free throw line. He and Anthony Edwards are scrapping to see which one of them will be the starter for Team USA when the Olympics start. Edwards put up a team-high 13 points against Canada and 14 points against Australia in Abu Dhabi.\n\nAlong with his 16 points against Australia, Booker put up 16 points in their win over Canada in Las Vegas. Booker is proven, but Edwards is quickly establishing himself as the new face of the NBA.\n\nWith Booker\'s long-running experience from his college days and the 2020 Olympics as a sixth man, it seems like he might be a better fit for that role. Kerr remarked on how Edwards\' added physicality is a huge tool in USA\'s favor with FIBA rules, something Booker can\'t replicate.\n\n"That\'s just who he is. He\'s a big-time scorer. He gets downhill, gets to the rim, and plays through contact. FIBA is very physical and he\'s a very physical player. I think for sure he will be one of our leading scorers during this tournament."\n\nEdwards has also made it clear that he will do whatever the team needs him to do, whether it\'s the No. 1 option or a lockdown defender. He showed the ability to do both in this game, starting the game without missing a shot in the first quarter while setting the tone for the Wolves\' sensational defense.\n\nBooker as an offensive player is far more refined and consistent, but if Edwards is hot, there\'s almost no stopping him. This is especially true of Edwards\' charging at the rim with a head of steam, as he can easily posterize any opponent.\n\nWhether either of them starts after Kevin Durant returns to the lineup remains to be seen, but both players could have a profound impact on Team USA at this point.\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. This is especially true of Edwards\' charging at the rim with a head of steam, as he can easily posterize any opponent.\n\nWhether either of them starts after Kevin Durant returns to the lineup remains to be seen, but both players could have a profound impact on Team USA at this point.\n\nRelated: Steve Kerr On Potentially Benching Joel Embiid: "Going To Continue Experimenting With The Lineup"\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {'uri': '8227534792', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '05:01:11', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T05:01:11Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T05:00:23Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://pressofatlanticcity.com/sports/avalon-defends-title-at-delayed-cape-may-county-championships/article_94778810-4313-11ef-99e8-d341f12c0cae.html', 'title': 'Avalon defends title at delayed Cape May County Championships', 'body': 'Guy Gargan\n\nWILDWOOD CREST -- The Avalon Beach Patrol dominated the "second half" of the Cape May County Lifeguard Championships on Monday.\n\nAvalon, led by its rowers, won three of the remaining five races to win its second straight team title. Three races were held a week earlier, on July 8, but the rest of the races were postponed. After another postponement, the event was finally completed, this time in perfect weather.\n\nAvalon\'s Gary Nagle and Dave Giulian started off the show by winning the doubles row for the third year in a row. Becca Cubbler won the women\'s swim for the patrol, and Avalon\'s Ryan Finnegan won the singles row for the second straight year.\n\nAfter winning no races last Monday, Avalon came on to win with 29 points. Ocean City placed second with 24, thanks in part to Lexi Santer\'s victory in the women\'s swim. Sea Isle City\'s Andrew Taylor won the open box swim to help his team finish third with 23.\n\nPeople are also reading... Atlantic City Airshow canceled for 2024 Ocean City\'s Seaspray condo for sale at $7M Cape May County Zoo receives $1.4 million donation Longport resident says rats are coming from borough property 5 hurt, 76 displaced in 5-alarm Atlantic City apartment fire Wildwood police identify shooting suspect Atlantic City High School principal accused of failing to report child abuse due back in court Aug. 29 After dream debut, South Jersey native Tyler Phillips will start Saturday for the Phillies: Must Win Buddy Tarbotton, a Cape May County high school sports fixture, dies at 63 Route 30 drawbridge stuck open in Atlantic City South Jersey native Tyler Phillips to start Saturday for the Phillies Atlantic City fire union head calls for restoring of Ducktown engine in wake of Georgia Avenue blaze Egg Harbor City rescue in need of fosters, donors to help animals rescued from Galloway home Atlantic County League of Women Voters chair resigns after regretting Trump \'only grazed\' Cape May fishing case has national impact\n\nScoring was 6-4-3-2-1 for the first five places. No times were kept.\n\n"Honestly, it feels like we\'ve been racing every night," Avalon Beach Patrol Chief Matt Wolf said. "Even on the nights we didn\'t race, they were scheduled and then postponed. We\'ve been competing every day. I told these guys to be ready to go every night, anyone, anywhere, any time, any place, we\'re going to be ready to go, just like a lifeguard on the stand has to be.\n\n"We\'re going to race again (Tuesday) with the women in Ocean City, we host our race Friday night (the David J. Kerr Jr. Memorials), we had our own city race (Avalon\'s patrol championships) last night, so we\'re going every day. These guys are working during the day, so and they\'re putting in a lot of time on their own, and it shows."\n\nFinnegan had a slight lead coming to the shore at the end. Close behind was Sea Isle\'s Danny Rogers, who started riding a wave but was turned sideways. Rogers recovered to get second, and Cape May Point\'s Ben Swan was third.\n\n"It was a little more challenging (being the defending champion), just because I knew people would be looking out for me this year," said Finnegan, a 24-year-old Rowan University graduate. "I wanted to come out here and defend it and keep it going for another year.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"When Gary and Dave came down here and won, that set the momentum for the rest of the night. It helps to have us build on each other when everyone\'s doing well."\n\nThe current pulled the doubles rowers to the northern end of the beach. Nagle and Giulian won by three boat-lengths, and Sea Isle\'s Rogers and Pat Scannapieco were second. Third was Upper Township\'s Jimmy Nilson and James Garoh.\n\n"It (the ocean) was very smooth. We had a long, smooth stroke," said Nagle, the bow and a 24-year-old former Ursinus College wrestler and track and field athlete. "We had no problems tonight; it was a beautiful night."\n\nGiulian said he didn\'t know who was leading at the halfway flags in the ocean.\n\n"But once we turn that flag, we got to turn it up," said Giulian, a 20-year-old rising junior wrestler and footbball player at The College of New Jersey. "We\'re feeling good in the second half of the race always, so that\'s where we know we turn it up and finish strong."\n\nSanter sprinted at the end of the women\'s box paddleboard race to win by about 20 yards. The race had a box course, with a beach run at the beginning and end.\n\n"I think the run worked well for me, but I don\'t like it," said Santer, a 27-year-old former Duquesne University swimmer. "It definitely adds another challenge to the race. By the time you get to the board, you\'re out of breath, so it\'s not just paddling. It adds a whole another thing. And once you get out of the water, you still got to run.\n\nCubbler won the women\'s box swim, with O.C.\'s Summer DeWitt second and Sea Isle\'s Mary Kate Leonard third.\n\n"The swim (part of the race) was about a half(-mile), maybe a little longer," said Cubbler, a 26-year-old former Bloomsburg University swimmer. "It was good. The water\'s a little chilly, but I actually like it a little bit colder to race in."\n\nTaylor won the open box swim and then sat on the ground exhausted.\n\n"Both (the run and the swim) are tiresome," said Taylor, a 22-year-old recent graduate of the University of Delaware. "You run to the first buoy, it\'s basically a sprint, and you got to switch back into distance (swimming) mode till you finish the whole thing. Getting out and finishing with the longest leg of the run is kind of a killer, especially for us swimmers. We\'re not used to running so much."\n\nContact Guy Gargan: 609-272-7210\n\nGGargan@pressofac.com\n\nCan\'t get enough High School sports? {'uri': '8227530418', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '04:57:36', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T04:57:36Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T04:55:41Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8235294222831726, 'url': 'https://japan.cnet.com/release/30999330/', 'title': 'お店のIT&インバウンド対応を一気通貫でサポートする「ヘイメン」、東京初のヴィーガン寿司専門店「Vegan Sushi Tokyo」に導入。', 'body': 'ヴィーガン生活を支える株式会社ブイクックが、2024年6月12日にヴィーガン寿司専門店「Vegan Sushi Tokyo」をオープン。「ヘイメン」でインバウンド顧客の集客から注文対応を完結。\n\n[画像1: リンク ]\n\n株式会社Daft（本社：兵庫県神戸市、代表取締役：的場慎一、以下当社）が開発・提供する「ヘイメン」が東京都初のヴィーガン寿司専門店「Vegan Sushi Tokyo」に導入されたことをお知らせいたします。\n\n導入背景\n\n日本国内では継続的な訪日外客の増加が見込まれています。2024年5月の訪日外国人数は3,040,100人となりました。\n\n- 前年同月比で60.1%増。\n\n- 2019年同月比で9.6%増\n\n過去最高であった2019年5月の2,773,091人を20万人以上上回り、3か月連続で300万人を突破しております(引用: 日本政府観光局(JNTO) リンク )。\n\n[画像2: リンク ]\n\n[画像3: リンク ]\n\nVegan Sushi Tokyoでは、ヴィーガンやベジタリアンである訪日外国人観光客をメインターゲットとしています。そのような方々へ日本人スタッフでも言語や文化の壁を超えた、一貫した快適なサービスを提供できるようにするための標準化が求められていました。\n\n[画像4: リンク ]\n\n予約から注文・会計までを全てAIで多言語化し、トラブルの防止と満足度向上に貢献。\n\n先述のような課題を解決するため、ヘイメンの導入が決定されました。「ヘイメン」は、ネット予約、POSレジアプリ、テーブルオーダー、お店アプリ、AI多言語化対応など、店舗運営に必要な機能をオールインワンで提供するツールです。訪日外国人客でも集客からお会計までスムーズな対応を実現し、顧客満足度の向上に貢献しています。\n\nお会計機能の一般公開は近日予定。\n\nヘイメンとは\n\nHeyman(ヘイメン)は、お店のデジタル化をまるっとこれひとつで実現することが可能になるオールインワンツールです。お店の皆様は、業務に必要なiPad POSレジアプリ、テーブルオーダー、ネット予約、顧客管理、お店アプリ、販促自動化機能など全てをHeymanひとつで活用可能です。\n\nヘイメンが選ばれる理由\n\n１、お店のITとインバウンド対応がこれひとつで完結\n\n複数のツール併用が一般的となり、業務目的に応じてツールを使い分ける必要がありました。これまで個別に管理されていたネット予約、テーブルオーダー、会計管理などが1つのツールで操作できるようになるため、スタッフはより少ない時間と労力でより多くの作業を完結することが可能になります。\n\n２、オールインワンならではのデータ連携による自動化\n\nネット予約を行ったお客様の情報をCRM(顧客管理)へ格納し、注文情報を蓄積。退店後、指定した時期にクーポン・お知らせ配信を自動で行うなどの自動化が可能です。\n\nネット予約、テーブルオーダー、POSレジ、お店アプリでの販促などお客様の来店前から退店後までのプロセス全てのデータを一元管理することで、2度打ちや手入力などを行わずに全ての機能とデータが連動・自動化を実現しています。\n\n３、月額コストの削減\n\nHeymanではネット予約やテーブルオーダー、インバウンド対応、POSレジアプリ等のメイン機能を月額11,700円と手頃な価格でご利用可能です。複数ツールを併用する代わりにHeymanを導入することで、それぞれのツールにかかる導入費用や維持費、さらには操作や管理に関わる時間と労力のコストが削減が見込めます。\n\nVegan Sushi Tokyoとは\n\nVegan Sushi Tokyo は、ヴィーガン生活を支えるスタートアップ株式会社ブイクックが、2024年6月12日にオープンした東京都初(*1)のヴィーガン寿司専門店です。\n\n茗荷やキノコなどの伝統的な『野菜寿司』に加え、植物性の肉、エビフライ、いくら、卵などの新たなジャンルである『ヴィーガン寿司』を提供しています。\n\n開店からわずか1ヶ月で400名以上の来店があり、その大半は訪日外国人です。Google Mapsでのレビューも100件以上を超え、星5.0の評価を得ており、ヴィーガン観光客の人気スポットとなっています。\n\n*1 株式会社ブイクック調べ\n\nホームページ： リンク\n\n住所：東京都渋谷区道玄坂1-17-12 野々ビル 2F\n\nヘイメンご利用方法\n\nサービスの利用をご希望のお店の方は下記のサービスサイトより、資料請求またはお問い合わせをお願いいたします。\n\n▶︎サービスサイト： リンク\n\nプレスリリース提供：PR TIMES リンク', 'source': {'uri': 'cnet.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'CNET'}, 'authors': {'uri': '8227458435', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '03:44:23', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T03:44:23Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T03:43:42Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://factcheck.afp.com/doc.afp.com.363J78B', 'title': "Japanese broadcaster rubbishes claim journalist was 'fired' for World War II commentary", 'body': 'Journalist Hajime Yamamoto was not "fired" for expressing remorse about Japan\'s actions in World War II during a documentary aired in 1993, contrary to a false claim shared by social media users in South Korea. The documentary series was acclaimed at the time and Yamamoto was honoured at one of Japan\'s most prestigious television awards. Japanese public broadcaster NHK, which produced the series, also told AFP there was no record of Yamamoto being dismissed.\n\n"The reason why this Japanese reporter was fired from NHK," read a Korean-language post shared on South Korean forum DC Inside on July 3, 2024.\n\nThe post included a series of screenshots that appear to show a reporter speaking on an old television programme.\n\nKorean-language subtitles on the screenshots suggest the reporter was expressing a critical view of Japan\'s actions in World War II.\n\n"Underlying a distrust in Japanese society is the belief that Japan failed to properly reflect on the crimes it committed in that war and became rich without overcoming its past," he says.\n\n"There is no guarantee that Japan will go on to gain the trust of other Asians if it does not take the stance of actively compensating Asia for the Pacific War."\n\nHe goes on to say a similar "egotism and hubris" from the past seemed to be rearing its head in modern-day Japan.\n\nTies between Japan and South Korea have long been strained over Tokyo\'s brutal decades-long occupation of the Korean peninsula before and during World War II.\n\nAround 780,000 Koreans were conscripted into forced wartime labour by Japan, according to data from Seoul, not including women forced into sexual slavery by Japanese troops.\n\nThe claim and screenshots circulating online were also shared in other South Korean forums, including here and here.\n\nBut the journalist pictured in the screenshots was not fired for his remarks.\n\nA keyword search on Google found the screenshots were taken from a six-part documentary series titled "The Pacific War", which was presented by commentator Hajime Yamamoto (archived link).\n\nThe series was made by Japanese public broadcaster NHK and aired between December 6, 1992 and August 15, 1993.\n\nAFP was able to find the documentary on NHK\'s "On Demand" website, with the scenes used in the false posts appearing in the sixth and last episode of the series broadcast on August 15, 1993 (archived link).\n\nThe full segment of Yamamoto\'s final remarks show he was in fact summarising a series of interviews with people across Asia who felt Japan had not changed following World War II.\n\n"During the course of this series of interviews, I have heard many times from people in Asia that the Japanese have not changed, neither in the past nor in the present.\n\n"How can Japan and we Japanese respond to these voices nearly 50 years after the end of the war, and how can we coexist with the rest of the world? I think the time has come for us to respond to this serious question," he says.\n\nA biography of Yamamoto -- who died in 2006, aged 66 -- on the broadcaster\'s website makes no mention of him being fired (archived link). In fact, it says he was honoured for his work on the series at the prestigious Galaxy Awards (archived link).\n\nBroadcasting records in NHK\'s archives also show Yamamoto contributed to numerous programmes after the final episode was broadcast in 1993 up until 2003 (archived link).\n\nResponding to an AFP enquiry, NHK said there is "no such record" of Yamamoto being fired.', 'source': {'uri': 'factcheck.afp.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Fact Check'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://factcheck.afp.com/sites/default/files/medias/factchecking/g2/2024-07/91df3b922ede631be10b75e6bc5c31af98e9a35f.jpeg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.2156862745098039, 'wgt': 458797463, 'relevance': 51}

The documentary series was acclaimed at the time and Yamamoto was honoured at one of Japan\'s most prestigious television awards. Japanese public broadcaster NHK, which produced the series, also told AFP there was no record of Yamamoto being dismissed.\n\n"The reason why this Japanese reporter was fired from NHK," read a Korean-language post shared on South Korean forum DC Inside on July 3, 2024.\n\nThe post included a series of screenshots that appear to show a reporter speaking on an old television programme.\n\nKorean-language subtitles on the screenshots suggest the reporter was expressing a critical view of Japan\'s actions in World War II.\n\n"Underlying a distrust in Japanese society is the belief that Japan failed to properly reflect on the crimes it committed in that war and became rich without overcoming its past," he says.\n\n"There is no guarantee that Japan will go on to gain the trust of other Asians if it does not take the stance of actively compensating Asia for the Pacific War."\n\nHe goes on to say a similar "egotism and hubris" from the past seemed to be rearing its head in modern-day Japan.\n\nTies between Japan and South Korea have long been strained over Tokyo\'s brutal decades-long occupation of the Korean peninsula before and during World War II.\n\nAround 780,000 Koreans were conscripted into forced wartime labour by Japan, according to data from Seoul, not including women forced into sexual slavery by Japanese troops.\n\nThe claim and screenshots circulating online were also shared in other South Korean forums, including here and here.\n\nBut the journalist pictured in the screenshots was not fired for his remarks.\n\nA keyword search on Google found the screenshots were taken from a six-part documentary series titled "The Pacific War", which was presented by commentator Hajime Yamamoto (archived link).\n\nThe series was made by Japanese public broadcaster NHK and aired between December 6, 1992 and August 15, 1993.\n\nAFP was able to find the documentary on NHK\'s "On Demand" website, with the scenes used in the false posts appearing in the sixth and last episode of the series broadcast on August 15, 1993 (archived link).\n\nThe full segment of Yamamoto\'s final remarks show he was in fact summarising a series of interviews with people across Asia who felt Japan had not changed following World War II.\n\n"During the course of this series of interviews, I have heard many times from people in Asia that the Japanese have not changed, neither in the past nor in the present.\n\n"How can Japan and we Japanese respond to these voices nearly 50 years after the end of the war, and how can we coexist with the rest of the world? I think the time has come for us to respond to this serious question," he says.\n\nA biography of Yamamoto -- who died in 2006, aged 66 -- on the broadcaster\'s website makes no mention of him being fired (archived link). In fact, it says he was honoured for his work on the series at the prestigious Galaxy Awards (archived link).\n\nBroadcasting records in NHK\'s archives also show Yamamoto contributed to numerous programmes after the final episode was broadcast in 1993 up until 2003 (archived link).\n\nResponding to an AFP enquiry, NHK said there is "no such record" of Yamamoto being fired.', 'source': {'uri': 'yahoo.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Yahoo'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/m.Ajljfc7Lk8R2D3nX2nVg--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTEyMDA7aD02NDU7Y2Y9d2VicA--/https://media.zenfs.com/en/afp_factcheck_us_713/cc301a22e5d562678ecbbd801f6b5e81', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.2156862745098039, 'wgt': 458797090, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '2024-07-423064976', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '03:10:11', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T03:10:11Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T02:59:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.5647059082984924, 'url': 'https://www.kcci.com/article/hyvee-ntt-indycar-weekend-a-success-at-iowa-speedway-organizers-say/61601105', 'title': 'IndyCar Weekend a success at Iowa Speedway, organizers say', 'body': 'Monday was a load-out day at the Iowa Speedway in Newton, but it was not too early for some to firmly put the weekend in the win column. "We had another very successful weekend," said Bud Denker, president of Penske Corporation.Denker says success is a recipe that involves the track, the fans, the drivers, the performers and their partner Hy-Vee.It\'s a recipe that he says cooked up about 80,000 fans. This is a 15% increase over last year and an economic booster shot for the community."Forty-four percent of the ticket sales were to people outside the state of Iowa. So we are bringing a lot of people here," Denker said.A Newton official says it is not only huge for the economy but it is also a chance to shine on the global stage."This kind of exposure to what we have here is a unique opportunity not every community in Iowa or anywhere for that matter can boast," said Craig Armstrong, a Newton development specialist.Armstrong is overjoyed with what he believes the Hy-Vee IndyCar Race Weekend can become."This is going to become over and over every single year another one of those legacy events people plan and circle on their calendar," Armstrong said.Race officials said parking issues that may have been a problem in the past were non-existent this year. They said the only other drawback was the heat. This morning, Hy-Vee and its suppliers donated more than 10,000 pounds of food from the weekend event to food pantries and meal sites across central Iowa." Download the free KCCI app to get updates on the go: Apple | Google PlayGet the latest headlines from KCCI\n\nMonday was a load-out day at the Iowa Speedway in Newton, but it was not too early for some to firmly put the weekend in the win column.\n\n"We had another very successful weekend," said Bud Denker, president of Penske Corporation.\n\nDenker says success is a recipe that involves the track, the fans, the drivers, the performers and their partner Hy-Vee.\n\nIt\'s a recipe that he says cooked up about 80,000 fans. {'uri': '8227375364', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-16', 'time': '02:06:27', 'dateTime': '2024-07-16T02:06:27Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-16T02:05:50Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://heraldcourier.com/sports/auto-racing-rob-austin-is-a-winner-and-thats-the-bottom-line-as-his-seven/article_5b272894-42c4-11ef-bf5a-5b67b33addf9.html', 'title': "AUTO RACING: Rob Austin is a winner and that's the bottom line as his seven track championships say so", 'body': 'Rob Austin is a frequent visitor to Victory Lane at Kingsport Speedway.\n\nAllen Gregory\n\nKINGSPORT, Tenn. - Rob Austin is one of the most familiar faces on the short track scene in Northeast Tennessee and far Southwest Virginia.\n\nHe\'s also one of the most successful.\n\nOver the past 30 years, the 60-year-old Castlewood resident estimates that he has won around 200 races with seven track championships in the Street Stock class.\n\n"It\'s been a fun run," Austin said. "I\'ve met and raced with a lot of people and made lasting friendships."\n\nThe fun run began in 1993.\n\n"I never got in karting or Late Models," Austin said. "I enjoyed running go karts in places like Pigeon Forge, and things kind of went from there."\n\nThe NASCAR touring scene was not on Austin\'s radar.\n\nPeople are also reading... HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Coaching innovator Mumme to serve on Sullivan East coaching staff Despite fame and fortune, Loggins was "still from Bristol" Simmons to expand manufacturing into Russell County AUTO RACING: Rural Retreat native Will Hostetler\'s a hometown hero at Wythe Raceway McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic FOOTBALL CAMP: Former Tennessee QBs Hooker, Milton hosts football camp at Sullivan East LITTLE LEAGUE: Monday\'s State Tournament Results LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon falls in Virginia state title game COLLEGE BASEBALL: Chase Hungate (Abingdon) headed to Mississippi State, relishes chance to compete in SEC BHC GIRLS BASKETBALL COACH OF YEAR: Funk found redemption at Eastside COLLEGE FOOTBALL: You can find Brad Robbins (Powell Valley) coaching at UConn now Casino donations near $900,000 with Tuesday presentation LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon advances to title game Marketplace dining opening at Hard Rock Bristol PREP BASEBALL: Porter Gobble (John Battle), Landon Turman (Abingdon), Hayden Reed (Abingdon) to play in Commonwealth Games\n\n"I just stuck with low-budget racing that I had parts for," Austin said. "Years ago, I did think about getting in a Late Model but that takes money."\n\nThe racing connection goes deep in the Austin family. Brother Doug Austin has competed many times against Rob in the Street Stock class at Kingsport and Coeburn.\n\nDoug has raced for nearly 20 years.\n\nIs it hard to compete against your brother?\n\n"No, it\'s fun," Rob said. "I just treat Doug like anybody else and we talk about racing together all the time in the garage.\n\n"I run Doug hard and he races me the same way. We\'ve never had an incident where we lost our tempers at each other."\n\nRob and Doug also discuss racing during breaks from their maintenance jobs at Oldcastle rock quarry in Castlewood.\n\n"Doug and I actually work together," Ron said. "We usually take care of our own cars unless something big comes up. I do the motor work, but we all jump in if we tear a car up."\n\nThe most impressive part of Austin\'s racecraft is his uncanny ability to control his car while battling side-by-side with a competitor for multiple laps.\n\nIt takes guts for a driver to simply make a car stick on the outside lane of a track. A master of car control, Rob often executes passes on the outside.\n\n"I can remember running side-by-side with Roger Neece (Trammel, Va.) for an entire race," Austin said. "As long as I don\'t mess up and the driver next to me doesn\'t mess up, that makes for good racing for the fans. I go to put on a show every week."\n\nRob, who finished third in last Friday\'s event at Kingsport, embraces the challenge of competing at any track.\n\n"I still have the car control, but I don\'t take the chances that I did when I started racing," Austin said. "The racing at Kingsport is a lot closer. If you get together with another car, you are likely to tear something up.\n\n"At Coeburn, you have room to catch your car or at least slow down before you hit something."\n\nAustin said he\'s also competed at Orange Couty Speedway in Durham, North Carolina, Franklin Count Speedway in Callaway, Virginia, and Newport Speedway in Newport, Tennessee.\n\n"We\'ve even ran two Street Stock races at Bristol Motor Speedway with Doug, Duke Bare, Jeff Counts (Castlewood) and several other local racers in 2011," Austin said. "Duke and Jeff both won at Bristol. That whole deal was different and lots of fun."\n\nEvery serious racer dreams of running at least one race, or even one lap, at Bristol.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\n"The Bristol track kind of sucks you down in the seat, and it\'s actually not as hard as some of these short tracks where you feel like you\'re getting thrown out of the car," Austin said.\n\nAustin has a total of eight wins between Kingsport and Coeburn this season.\n\nHow much longer will Rob continue adding to his trophy collection?\n\n"I don\'t really know. I still enjoy racing and still run full-time at Kingsport and Coeburn," Austin said. "I stay in shape by working and staying active. My mom (Bertha) comes to every race at age 81, and we all have a good time together as a family.\n\n"I never thought I would win 200 races when I started and I never worried about making it to NASCAR. I just did it for the fun, and we\'re still having fun."\n\nBRISTOL DRAGWAY: NHRA officials announced last week that the Super Grip NHRA Thunder Valley Nationals will return to its traditional weekend of June 6-8 on the 2025 Mission Foods Drag Racing Series schedule.\n\nThe event will continue to offer two rounds of pro qualifying on Friday, including a night session with fireworks, two final pro qualifying sessions on Saturday, and final eliminations on Sunday afternoon.\n\nWYTHE RACEWAY: Five-time series champion Chris Madden (Gray Court, S.C.) won Saturday\'s Schaeffer\'s Southern Nationals Super Late Model event.\n\nIt was the 29th career Southern Nationals victory for Madden, but first since 2020.\n\nDonald McIntosh (Dawsonville, Ga.) took second, with Benji Hicks (Mount Airy, N.C.), Dale McDowell (Chickamauga, Ga.) and Mike Benedum (Salem, W.Va.) rounding out the top five. Kaede Loudy (Rogersville) finished tenth among the 16-car field.\n\nIn the weekly classes, defending track champion Derek Farris (Chilhowie) passed Kevin Atwell (Rural Retreat) with less than two laps remaining en route to another victory in Pro Mini.\n\nThe other winners included Michael Deskins (Tazewell) in Super Street and Morgan Widener (Chilhowie) in Modifieds.\n\nMcIntosh won the first leg of the 12-race Southern Nationals tour on Friday at Beckley Motor Speedway in West Virginia.\n\nDaniel Lowe (North Tazewell, Va.) took the win in Friday\'s Outlaw Street feature at Beckley. J.R. Davis (Rural Retreat) was third in Sports Mods, with Austin Blevins (Rural Retreat) in sixth.\n\nMcDowell, 58, led all 40 laps of Sunday\'s Southern Nationals event at Volunteer Speedway.\n\nMadden, Ricky Weiss (Manitoba, Canada), Cory Hedgecock (Loudon, Tenn.) and Brandon Overton (Evans, Ga.) rounded out the top five in the 22-car field. Crowd favorite Scott Bloomquist (Mooresburg, Tenn.) took the No. 20 spot.\n\nKINGSPORT SPEEDWAY: The Keith Helton show continues, as the Kingsport driver earned another sweep in Friday\'s Late Model features.\n\nHelton, who entered the night ranked sixth in the NASCAR Weekly Series national standings, has nine wins on the season.\n\nDerek Lane (Kingsport) and Alex Miller (Erwin) both earned finishes of second and third, while defending track champion Jacob York (Asheville) failed to finish inside the top five in either event.\n\nJoey Owens (Clintwood) won for the first time in Street Stock, while Dennis Holdren (Roanoke) was first in Mod 4 and Greg Bohanon (Asheville) recorded his seventh triumph in Super Street.\n\nThe list of drivers visiting Victory Lane also included four-time winner Keith McMurray (Limestone) in Beginner Front Wheel Drive, Tyler Conway (Kingsport) in Crown Vic, and Brandon Sutherland (Johnson City) in Mod 4. Sutherland earned his eighth victory after apparent winner Kirby Gobble (Abingdon) declined to undergo a post-race teardown.\n\nLONESOME PINE MOTORSPORTS PARK: Keith Helton (Kingsport) and Kyle Barnes (Draper) earned sweeps Saturday night.\n\nJamie Whitt (Wise) won in Super Street and Eastside High School student Shelby Stanley captured her first career pole in the Limited class.\n\nMUDDY CREEK RACEWAY: Kyle Bitterman (Belton, S.C.) took the 250 Pro race and Matthew Burkeen (Cary, N.C.) was the 450 Pro winner in Sunday\'s Tennessee State Motocross championships.\n\nCarson Eads (Kingsport) finished fourth overall in 450. Eddie Branch (Bristol) swept both 60-plus motos, while Kevin Walker (Kingsport) earned a sweep in 50-plus.\n\nCHASE DIXON MOTORSPORTS: The team owner and driver from Abingdon was approved last week to compete in the NASCAR Truck Series. {'uri': '2024-07-422974352', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '23:53:26', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T23:53:26Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T23:30:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://newsadvance.com/news/local/liberty-hires-vcus-lecroy-for-open-head-coaching-position/article_9c43c914-42d2-11ef-9994-af897af97544.html', 'title': "Liberty hires VCU's LeCroy for open head coaching position", 'body': 'The search for Liberty baseball\'s next head man came to an end in the Commonwealth. The Flames are hiring VCU\'s head coach Bradley LeCroy for the same position in Lynchburg, the university announced Monday night.\n\nLeCroy, a native of South Carolina and a four-year letterwinner at Clemson University from 1997 to 2000, comes to Liberty after a pair of seasons in Richmond that were capped off with a 2024 Atlantic 10 baseball tournament championship.\n\nIn a statement Monday night, Flames Director of Athletics Ian McCaw commented on LeCroy\'s "remarkable" turnaround at VCU and his two-decades worth of assistant coaching experience that made him worthy of the job.\n\n"Bradley is an outstanding baseball coach who thoroughly impressed us during the search process," McCaw said. "He is very relational, positive and embraces Liberty\'s Christian mission."\n\nLeCroy replaces outgoing head coach Scott Jackson, who resigned last week to accept a position on the coaching staff at North Carolina, where he previously served as an assistant from 2009 to 2016.\n\nIn those eight seasons, Jackson posted a 246-181 career record and became the first coach in program history to take the Flames to three regional appearances. But in the past two seasons, the Flames fell to sub-.500 records. They went 27-31 in 2023 and finished 24-34 in their debut season in Conference USA in 2024.\n\nLeCroy\'s rapid improvement at VCU, taking the team from 25-30 and a ninth-place finish in the Atlantic 10 in 2023 to a 38-23 record and NCAA Regional appearance in 2024, validated his reputation as a rising star in the college baseball community.\n\nHe was ranked as the No. 9 assistant coach in the nation by Baseball America prior to the 2013 season, and D1Baseball named him the No. 10 recruiter in the country before the 2017 campaign.\n\n"I want to thank Ian McCaw and [Senior Associate AD] Mickey Guridy for making this such a seamless process," Bradley said in the school\'s release. "While we will forever cherish our time at VCU, my family and I are looking forward to becoming a part of the Liberty family, and I am incredibly excited to be the next leader of the Liberty baseball program."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nPrior to taking the VCU job in August 2022, the Clemson baseball alumnus (1997-2000) was an assistant coach at several programs, including Tennessee, Western Carolina and, most recently, Clemson.\n\nLeCroy has assistant coaching stints at his alma mater from 2003 to 2005 and 2011 to 2022.\n\nHe will now be tasked with keeping several Liberty baseball players who have entered the transfer portal this offseason -- including its offensive leader in 2024, Kane Kepley -- in the program.\n\nLeCroy\'s move will open up an immediate 30-day transfer portal window for any player with remaining eligibility from VCU. Jackson\'s move last week opened up a similar window for Liberty players.\n\nTwo Flames selected on Day Two of MLB Draft\n\nLiberty starter Cole Hertzler was the squad\'s No. 1 starter in 2024, and pitched to that title in his final start of the season against Sam Houston. The Pennsylvania native threw 120 pitches over 7 ⅔ innings of work, striking out five while allowing one run on four hits to put the Flames in the CUSA baseball tournament winners\' bracket on May 23.\n\nOn Monday, he was the first Liberty player off the board in the 2024 MLB Draft when the Houston Astros selected him with the No. 163 pick in the fifth round. One round later, the Texas Rangers selected Liberty pitcher Garrett Horn with the No. 195 overall pick.\n\nHertzler, a CUSA All-Conference second team selection this season, tossed 84 ⅓ innings for Liberty in 2024, striking out a team-high 94 batters while pitching to a 4.16 ERA. He went 6-6 and was also voted to the CUSA All-Tournament team after his stellar outing in the Flames\' opening game.\n\nHorn, a native of Kernersville, North Carolina, pitched just 20 innings for Liberty in 2024 before an arm injury. But in two seasons prior, he was one of the best arms in the Atlantic Sun.\n\nOver 137 ⅓ career innings, Horn posted a 3.28 ERA, going 13-7 in 36 appearances (26 starts). He fanned 196 batters to just 81 walks, and held opponents to a .203 batting average.\n\nDay Three of the 2024 MLB Draft begins at 2 p.m. on Tuesday.\n\nThe Richmond Times-Dispatch\'s Zach Joachim contributed to this report.\n\nBryson Gordon, (434) 385-5529\n\nbgordon@newsadvance.com\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.\n\nBryson Gordon\n\nSports\n\nFollow Bryson Gordon\n\nClose Get email notifications on {{subject}} daily!\n\nYour notification has been saved.\n\nThere was a problem saving your notification.\n\n{{description}}\n\nEmail notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items.\n\nSave\n\nManage followed notifications\n\nClose Followed notifications\n\nPlease log in to use this feature Log In\n\nDon\'t have an account? Pertumbuhan ekonomi: Angka 7 yang menyerupai panah ke kanan atas merupakan simbol harapan Indonesia untuk meningkatkan investasi dan ekspor untuk memenuhi misi indonesia dalam menggerakkan ekonomi. Keberlanjutan: Arah lengkungan dari segala arah yang saling terhubung satu sama lain, menyimbolkan prinsip pembangunan negara yang berkelanjutan. Ekonomi hijau: Bentuk dahan dan daun dari angka 9 merupakan prinsip pembangunan negara yang berlandaskan ekonomi hijau, bersinergi dengan alam, dan selalu memperhatikan akar budaya dan identitas. Persatuan dan harapan: Kaki angka 7 dan 9 terbuat dari bentuk yang sama, membentuk 2 tangan yang menyatu sebagai simbol persatuan masyarakat Indonesia walaupun memiliki pendapat yang berbeda-beda. Kesetaraan: Dua gelombang dengan arah yang sama di atas dan di bawah merepresentasikan tujuan Indonesia untuk desentralisasi dan memeratakan pembangunan demi mencapai kesetaraan.\n\nDesain terinsipirasi dari aliran sungai\n\nKepala Sekretariat Presiden (Kasetpres) selaku Ketua Pelaksana Peringatan HUT ke-79 Kemerdekaan RI, Heru Budi Hartono mengatakan bahwa desain grafis logonya terinspirasi dari aliran sungai yang menjadi sumber kehidupan. After trying out and testing all of them, here\'s what we think about these features.\n\nCompetitive Research\n\nCompetitive Research is the first one you\'ll see. It\'s great for analyzing your competitors and seeing how they perform to improve your SEO accordingly. You can discover things like domain trust, page trust, organic traffic, the number of keywords, and so on.\n\nAnalyze your competitors with SE Ranking\n\nSE Ranking divulges even paid traffic and keywords along with total traffic cost. We like that it displays traffic distribution by country, which signals where the competitor you\'re analyzing is popular. Scrolling down a bit will show you graphs of the said parameters.\n\nYou\'ll see how the competitor\'s traffic, keywords, and other factors changed over the year or more. SE Ranking displays organic keywords and those that have improved, decreased, or are new or lost. Another feature we like is Intent - also found in Semrush.\n\nIt displays the intent behind the search for keywords. It can be informational, navigational, commercial, local, and transactional. SERP features can also be discovered, such as reviews, featured snippets, videos, site links, and many others.\n\nSE Ranking\'s paid traffic research is basic compared to Semrush. However, there\'s a Competitor Comparison where you can compare up to 2 websites to the analyzed domain. This is your Keyword Gap tool where you\'ll find out more about competitors\' keywords.\n\nCommon, missing, and unique keywords can be found promptly. From here, you can implement some of them and see if you can rank higher than your rivals.\n\nKeyword Research\n\nWhat about keyword research? Is SE Ranking efficient enough? The answer is a resounding YES.\n\nAfter providing the tool with the search term, you\'ll be greeted by an in-depth analysis of its difficulty, search volume, CPC, global volume, keyword ideas, intent, and so forth.\n\nSearch for new keywords with SE Ranking\n\nIts difficulty score is accurate enough and reflects the real-world situation. In some scenarios, it\'s too mild, so obviously "hard" keywords become a tad "easier" in SE Ranking\'s eyes. The tool will inform you if the keyword is "doable" and if not, you\'ll basic advice on how to rank for it.\n\nKeyword suggestions are handy as well. During our test of SE Ranking, we discovered a heap of them by visiting detailed keyword idea reports. You\'ll find similar and related phrases, as well as keyword-related questions. Each detailed report contains more information.\n\nThese include search volumes, trends, difficulty, and intent. Trends are especially valuable because they show you how popular the keyword was in the previous months. Organic results can also be found for the given keyword as they appear in Google SERPs.\n\nFinally, we\'ll briefly mention its Ads History. For every keyword you analyze, you\'ll find Ads History that displays popular ads for it. However, this feature isn\'t available in every plan, so if you\'re into PPC Advertising, you\'ll have to invest a bit more in SE Ranking.\n\nKeyword Manager\n\nAfter trying out the Keyword Manager, we found it\'s decent but not overly useful. It allows you to create bespoke keyword lists and manage them in multiple ways. Those lists can be exported to XLS or updated with new keywords.\n\nYou can add a list, name it, and then enter your keywords into them. Now, you can track each keyword and keep it under your watchful eye. Nothing too exciting, really.\n\nKeyword Grouper\n\nThe Keyword Grouper is slightly more interesting. It allows you to craft keyword clusters and group keywords based on their SERP similarity. Grouping accuracy is determined by you, from 1 to 9, and after entering the keywords, SE Ranking will promptly do the job.\n\nNow, the downside is that you\'ll pay $0.004 per query and if you\'re checking search volumes for each, that\'s an additional $0.005.\n\nIndex Status Checker\n\nThere\'s a nifty little feature called Index Status Checker that we tested in our SE Ranking analysis. It tells you if the page has been indexed by Google, Yahoo, or Bing. Again, it\'s paid additionally for some reason, so each check-up will cost $0.005.\n\nYou can do the same for free in Google Search Console, so what\'s the point? If you\'re looking to rank higher on Yahoo and Bing, however, this tool will be more valid.\n\nWebsite Audits\n\nSo let\'s discuss website audits in our in-depth review of SE Ranking. After trying out this function multiple times, we can only praise it.\n\nThe amount of data you get is unreal - from the health score to core web vitals, domain metrics, page indexation, page depth, and many others.\n\nWe appreciate that SE Ranking highlights the most pressing issues first. Clicking on them displays the problems in-depth and the tool offers solutions to fix them. Moreover, you\'ll get more information about your links - external and internal.\n\nYou\'ll see how many dofollow and nofollow links you have. Core web vitals can also be analyzed per device, so you can select from mobile or desktop options.\n\nAnother handy feature is the On-Page SEO Checker, which analyzes individual pages. We\'ve used this feature a lot in our SE Ranking test. It does a great job in this regard, pointing out the obvious qualities and flaws of each page. There\'s the Page Quality Score.\n\nYou\'ll see things like indexing, internal links, page experience, external links, SERP features, and others. On the right, SE Ranking displays SEO tasks to improve the page. This can be used to increase your Google ranking or drive more traffic.\n\nFor instance, we found that a few of our pages should be more unique. Some pages required minor fixes, such as adding the pages to the sitemap file or including keywords in the URL of the page. This stuff is easy to handle once you detect it.\n\nWe found Semrush\'s On-Page SEO Checker slightly better, however. It displays things like semantic ideas, content ideas, and top-10 benchmarking.\n\nStill, our experience with SE Ranking was positive and its On-Page SEO Checker was useful in many situations.\n\nSE Ranking Link Building (Backlink) Features\n\nRight off the bat, you\'ll notice SE Ranking\'s backlink analysis. Frankly, this isn\'t the best tool for link building compared to Semrush. For one, it doesn\'t have a link-building tool that lets you directly contact websites and request a backlink. Second, it\'s great only for analysis.\n\nAt least in this regard, the tool shines with a huge backlink database and plentiful information. Once you provide the link to the page, the interface will greet you with data like referring domains, backlinks, and anchor texts.\n\nWe love the toxic backlink analysis, which tells you more about your backlink profile. Toxic backlinks decrease your SEO and make ranking higher slower. SE Ranking also displays your non-toxic backlinks, highlighting what you did well.\n\nLike Semrush or Mangools LinkMiner, this tool displays new and lost backlinks. We like the top backlink anchors menu, highlighting the most prominent backlinks on your site. SE Ranking lets you analyze pages individually and examine their backlink profile.\n\nIn addition, we appreciate the ability to see the referring IP addresses of the backlinks. Finally, SE Ranking detects broken backlinks efficiently. This is another crucial factor that must be eliminated if you want to maximize your SEO scores.\n\nBacklink Gap Analyzer\n\nOur experience with SE Ranking led us to its Backlink Gap Analyzer which worked well for the most part. You can add up to 5 competitors and run the analysis to see which domains link to your competitors but not to your website.\n\nThis function is overly simple and doesn\'t contain much information. Yes, you\'ll find all the referring domains and backlinks, which is handy. But Semrush is much better, offering the option to see weak, strong, shared, and unique backlinks.\n\nIt also lets you access its link-building tool directly from here, as you can send the displayed prospects to it. As said, SE Ranking will "inadvertently" improve your backlink profile but not directly like Semrush, which is the #1 SEO tool in this case.\n\nSE Ranking has two excellent content management tools we tested. These tools are paramount for improving your content, ensuring better keyword optimization, and providing better readability to increase dwell time.\n\nContent Editor\n\nSE Ranking\'s Content Editor is the tool we liked a lot in our review. It lets you write articles directly or copy them to the empty page and let the tool analyze them. We love the fact that it\'s a full-fledged writing tool where you can format the article the way you want.\n\nMoreover, the right-hand side is handy for getting more info about the text. Under "Improvements", you\'ll see the content score based on factors like text length, headings, and used terms (keywords). SE Ranking will list the keywords you need to use too.\n\nThe main keyword is displayed first and the software advises using it in the first 100 words, for example. In the Quality tab, you\'ll find metrics like your grammar, stop words, and punctuation. The readability score is also here, indicating how accessible your article is.\n\nOf course, SE Ranking lets you check for plagiarism, alas, only in more expensive plans. We\'ll address that later in our SE Ranking test. The Outline tab is also handy. It analyzes content structure, competitors, links, and keywords for a better overview of the article.\n\nPerhaps the most useful tool is the AI Writer, similar to the one found in Semrush. It lets you generate content based on your needs. For instance, we like its FAQ Section option. We used it to fill our guides with answers to frequently asked questions.\n\nIn addition, AI Writer supports a few tones of voice, such as conversational, authoritative, informational, and a few others. Its AI Writer goes a long way in creating bespoke content without hassle, which can be helpful for faster, yet more efficient content creation.\n\nContent Idea Finder\n\nThis feature is exactly what it sounds like. We discovered its usefulness when brainstorming content ideas for our few websites. To use it, you need to enter the seed keyword and select the country you\'re aiming for. SE Ranking will then create so-called clusters.\n\nThese clusters contain keywords based on the seed keyword you provided. For the "SEO Software" seed keyword, there\'s an "SEO Engine Optimization" cluster. When we click on it, we get numerous cluster ideas with their CPC, difficulty, volume, and competition.\n\nClicking on Titles gives you ideas you can use to title your article - as you can see below, they\'re pretty sensical and good-looking. For a more graphical explanation, SE Ranking includes the Mind Map of clusters you generate.\n\nIn the middle is your seed keyword, while the lines originating from the center are clusters. Clicking on one displays cluster keywords on the right and lets you explore the possible titles. In terms of content management, SE Ranking did a splendid job in our analysis.\n\nHowever, it\'s still a tad underwhelming compared to Semrush. Semrush includes the SEO Content Template, which comes with data like semantically related words, advised backlinks, the readability score you should aim for, and the needed word count for the given term.\n\nLocal Marketing\n\nSE Ranking offers excellent Local Marketing that aids the improvement of local SEO. It\'s a great Ahrefs alternative in this regard, based on our experience with both. We found it pretty simple to use. You can target multiple locations, again, depending on your subscription.\n\nYou can choose from 1 to 50 locations from $7 to $181 a month respectively. Local Marketing is an optional add-on, so if you don\'t need it, you don\'t have to pay for it. If you do, you can add a location and track your ranking in it.\n\nFurthermore, we like the Local Marketing Audit tool. It gives you a score and displays possible issues that harm your local SEO. SE Ranking can also track your Google Business Profile and display views, searches by keywords, and total searches.\n\nWe love that you can see Search and Google Maps views from desktop and mobile platforms separately. If you have a phone line, you can even examine the number of phone calls and messages over a specific period. Reviews can also be tracked.\n\nYou\'ll see the reviews from Google, Facebook, and other websites. SE Ranking shows all of them, with the rating date, and the review content. It\'ll display if you\'ve answered the review as well, ensuring you\'re always in touch with your customers, which adds to your local SEO.\n\nSE Ranking Pricing: How Much Does It Cost?\n\nUnlike Semrush and Mangools, SE Ranking doesn\'t have a free plan - quite a shame. Perhaps, you could read our free SEO tools guide if you have no money to pay.\n\nDiscover SE Ranking\'s offers\n\nHowever, SE Ranking is very affordable, and in this review, we\'ll see it costs way less than its many rivals.\n\nThe Essential plan starts at $44/mo for the annual plan, so it\'s super affordable. To remind you - Semrush starts at over $100/mo! The Essential plan buys you 1 user seat and up to 5 projects. It includes almost all tools from this review of SE Ranking.\n\nHowever, it lacks API access and historical data on domains and keywords. Its Agency Pack, which includes white label reporting and lead generator, can\'t be purchased. The best-value plan is in the middle. It\'s a Pro plan at $87.2/mo for the annual deal.\n\nIt excludes API access but includes everything else. Local Marketing can be bought and so can the Agency Pack, which can only be paid manually a whopping $600! The Pro plan analyzes 2,000 to 3,500 keywords daily compared to the Essential plan with 750 keywords.\n\nFinally, there\'s the Business plan at $191.2/mo. Instead of 3 user seats in the Pro plan, it allows for 5 seats and unlimited projects. It can also track from 5,000 to 15,000 keywords daily, in which case, the price increases to $456/mo.\n\nPrice Review of Other Features\n\nSE Ranking\'s monthly plans are there if you don\'t want to commit for a year. However, they\'re 20% more expensive per month, so they\'re likely not an option. As said in this SE Ranking review, the service includes a few optional extras.\n\nFor instance, its Content Editor is always paid extra and costs from $29/mo to $99/mo, while the Content Idea Finder is a standard feature. The price of the Content Editor depends on several factors displayed below.\n\nThe Agency Pack, as said, costs $600 annually and it\'s the only way of paying for it. An upfront payment of $600 is significant and we dislike the lack of monthly payments for it. If you need to work on your local SEO, here are the packages:\n\nWe also mentioned in this in-depth review that the service charges you extra for some features. These include Keyword Grouper, Parameter Checker, Index Status Checker, Search Engine Autocomplete, and Search Volume Checker.\n\nThese features cost from $0.001 to $0.005 per query/request/keyword/URL. SE Ranking has a 14-day free trial without a credit card. However, the service is non-refundable, which isn\'t a deal breaker considering a generous free trial for testing purposes.\n\nSE Ranking Pros\n\nSE Ranking Cons\n\nVerdict\n\nAfter testing SE Ranking extensively for years, we can conclude it\'s one of the best SEO tools to try out. It has plenty of things going for it and is more adorable than many of its rivals. SE Ranking is cheaper than Semrush but not better. It is, however, a close second, which is great.\n\nThis tool works well for many purposes. Competitive research, keyword analysis, content marketing, and local SEO - all of these will be covered by this tool. With an easy-to-use interface and flexible pricing, we think you\'ll end up more satisfied than you expect.\n\nIts downsides are minor, especially at this price point. If you want more advanced features and SEO-related data, consider using our Semrush coupon. If you\'re an average or even slightly above average user, we\'re confident that SE Ranking will be sufficient.', 'source': {'uri': 'gizmodo.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Gizmodo'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://gizmodo.com/app/uploads/2024/06/SE-Ranking-review.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.2470588235294118, 'wgt': 458782142, 'relevance': 105}
