{'uri': '2024-07-422949187', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '22:57:45', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T22:57:45Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T22:30:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8941176533699036, 'url': 'https://wcfcourier.com/sports/other/olympics/olympics-paris-usa-united-states-us-gymnastics/article_22ef8a2d-4ce3-5ef0-bf34-765ec8c1bf04.html', 'title': "Biles has moved past Tokyo; doesn't care if critics can't", 'body': 'The worlds of music and sport collided Monday morning as NBC shared a video featuring legendary gymnast Simone Biles and singer SZA showcasing their skills. Simone Biles, renowned for her extraordinary gymnastics achievements, including numerous Olympic and World Championship titles, joined ...\n\nSimone Biles has spent the last three years moving past the Tokyo Olympics.\n\nThe gymnastics superstar understands not everyone has.\n\nNo matter how many national titles she wins or how times she stands atop the podium at the world championships, Biles knows she remains frozen in time to critics unwilling or unable to forgive her for pulling out of multiple finals at the 2020 Games to protect herself.\n\nThe proof is in her mentions, the ones she says she tries to ignore but still stumbles across anyway.\n\nThe 27-year-old wants to make something clear as she prepares for a third trip to the Olympics: the redemption she is seeking later this month has nothing to do with silencing those who will tune in just to see if "the twisties" resurface. Mostly because she knows there\'s no use.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nNEW DETAILS: John Deere announces another 345 layoffs at Waterloo facilities Colleagues remember Waverly-Shell Rock principal Suz SmolikHagen One dead in early morning shooting in Hudson UPDATE WITH NAME: One dead in tanker crash south of Hudson Four injured in wrong-way crash Student sentenced to probation in University of Northern Iowa Dance Marathon theft Walnut Ridge Church to move to Tower Park Drive, future uncertain for private school space Waterloo man arrested after alleged assault at Sunnyside County Club Iowa restaurant inspection update: Grimy blenders, mouse droppings and bad sushi Pet friendly restaurants, bars, coffee shops with patio guidelines Waterloo day care operator charged with three counts of child endangerment Former Juvenile Court Services employee indicted for fraud in cedit card case John Eveland: Waterloo businessman makes lasting impact in Cedar Valley community Man arrested in 2017 up-skirt photo investigation Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead\n\n"They\'ll still say like, \'Oh my gosh, you\'re going to quit again? Or are you going to quit again?\' And like, and \'If I did, what are you going to do about it? Tweet me some more?\'" Biles said after winning the Olympic trials last month. "Like I\'ve already dealt with it for three years. But yeah, they want to see us fail."\n\nLife happens\n\nThe woman who will step onto the floor with the rest of the U.S. team during qualifying on July 28 is not the one who left Japan at the center of the sometimes uncomfortable conversation about mental health.\n\nShe has evolved, both personally and professionally, committing herself to therapy -- even during meets -- and making sure her sport no longer defines her, all the while looking perhaps as good as ever more than a decade removed from the first of her record six world all-around titles.\n\nBiles married current Chicago Bears safety Jonathan Owens in the spring of 2023 and her busy personal calendar is dotted with the mileposts of a normal 20-something: from baby showers to weddings to overseeing the details of the house she and her husband are building in the Houston suburbs.\n\nWhen one of her former Olympic teammates welcomed her first child late last year, Biles admitted she felt a pang of "that\'s what I should be doing."\n\nOnly she\'s not. Not yet anyway. Two decades after she took up the sport, Biles still finds herself inside World Champions Centre -- the gym the Biles family owns in Spring, Texas -- countless hours a week. Still flipping. Still twisting. Still "testing my life every day" while dispelling the myth that elite gymnasts peak in their late teens.\n\nWhy?\n\n"I think with everything I\'ve been through, I want to push the limits, I want to see how far I can go," she said. "I want to see what I\'m still capable of so once I step away from this sport, I can truly be happy with my career and say I gave it my all."\n\nMentor and friend\n\nEven as her definition of "all" is changing. The teenage prodigy has become an elder stateswoman who has grown comfortable leading from the front.\n\nWhen good friend and 2020 Olympic champion Sunisa Lee tripped and fell on vault at the U.S. Championships in June -- a scene eerily similar to the sequence that led Biles to remove herself from the team final in Tokyo -- Biles ran over to offer support.\n\nAt the 2023 world championships, Joscelyn Roberson suffered an ankle injury that forced her to miss the vault finals. Biles did her best to lighten the mood by cracking jokes. And when Roberson found herself struggling during a sometimes grueling rehab, Biles left a note of encouragement in Roberson\'s locker that urged her to keep trying.\n\nWhen Jade Carey had problems with her Amanar vault at the Olympic trials, Biles reminded the reigning floor exercise gold medalist to take a step forward on her dismount, something Carey laughingly noted she didn\'t actually do.\n\n"It\'s just really great to have someone like her supporting all of us and helping us get through it," Carey said.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nA singular talent\n\nIt wasn\'t always that way. There has always been an unspoken otherness around Biles. Part of the team -- the center of it most times -- to be sure, but also a one-of-one.\n\n"I\'m like, \'Can you stop being so good and fall every now and then?\'" said Alicia Sacramone Quinn, the co-lead of the U.S. senior women\'s program. "Her talent and her just level of difficulty and her general ability as an athlete, it is mindblowing."\n\nWhen people in Quinn\'s personal life ask her about Biles, Quinn -- whose resume includes 11 medals between the world championships and Olympics -- just shakes her head.\n\n"What you see on TV doesn\'t even do it justice," Quinn said. "Her gymnastics has brought such a larger pool of an audience because people want to see what she can do."\n\nOr, in the case of some, what she can\'t.\n\nCall it the byproduct of making things impossibly hard look impossibly easy so often it sets a standard that no one else -- Biles herself sometimes included -- can match.\n\nDouble-edged sword\n\nThat is the beauty and also the weight of the Olympics, a lesson Biles learned after Tokyo, when all of the glory and gold she brought to the U.S. program through the years suddenly didn\'t matter to a group bent for some reason on taking her down.\n\n"I do think there\'s an unfairness to it because you only watched it once and then if they fall it\'s, \'Oh she sucks\' and it\'s like, \'No, you\'re still sitting on the couch and they\'re still at the Olympics what are you talking about they sucked? They\'re the best in their country,\'" Biles said. "So it\'s hard."\n\nBiles is willingly putting herself under the white-hot microscope the Games provide for a third time, obligated not by ego or fame or money but respect for her own talent.\n\n"Knowing Simone and just the fighter that she is, she will definitely want to leave on what she considers on top," her mother Nellie said. "That I think is what Simone wants for Simone."\n\nAnd what Biles wants more than anything else at this point in her life, is peace. There\'s a very real chance this could be it for an athlete who jokes "I\'m ancient now. Forget grandma, I\'m past that."\n\nShe\'s past a lot of things. Maybe Tokyo most of all.\n\nA final bow?\n\nShe has taken very methodical steps to protect herself in the run-up to Paris. Her therapist remains on call. Her family -- Jonathan included -- will be in the stands. She will be surrounded by friends on the competition floor who know perhaps better than anyone the pressure Biles faces.\n\nAnd then Biles will salute the judges -- the ones who do the scoring and in some ways, the ones sitting at home too -- and throw herself into the breach once more, perhaps for the last time.\n\nMaybe Paris ends with her hand over her heart as "The Star-Bangled Banner" plays as it has so many times before. Maybe it ends like Tokyo. While she\'s taken steps to make sure that doesn\'t happen, she won\'t really know until she does it.\n\nEither way it goes, Biles plans on walking away on her terms. The woman who has redefined gymnastics is no longer letting her gymnastics or the once-every-four-year experts define her.\n\nShe has been quiet about what comes next. She will headline a post-Olympic tour, just as she did three years ago. After that, who knows?\n\nThe greatest gymnast of all time may have offered a hint at the end of Olympic trials. Biles was talking about the nature of being a high-profile athlete and the inevitable pushback that comes with it. She was speaking in generalities while leaving plenty of space to read between the lines.\n\n"They want to see the downfall, which is really unfortunate because sports hasn\'t seen athletes like we\'ve seen before," she said. "So you really have to give them their flowers in the sport because once they\'re gone, you\'re going to miss them."\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'wcfcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Waterloo Cedar Falls Courier'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'charlie_riedel@wcfcourier.com', 'name': 'Charlie Riedel', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'rebecca_blackwell@wcfcourier.com', 'name': 'Rebecca Blackwell', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/wcfcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/2/2e/22ef8a2d-4ce3-5ef0-bf34-765ec8c1bf04/66958d07be546.preview.jpg?crop=1747%2C917%2C5%2C103&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9734092', 'sentiment': 0.1372549019607843, 'wgt': 458780265, 'relevance': 6}

Sound edited in some places to avoid FCC sanctions.\n\nWhen Gracie Flores was getting ready for work Monday morning, she was surprised to see something moving out her front window.\n\nOut of the corner of her eye, she saw "something with long blond hair running" on her sidewalk. She thought, "No way that\'s a dog."\n\nShe whipped her head around "and I saw this frickin\' horse dashing by my window," Flores said.\n\nFlores, who lives on the 400 block of Second Street, spotted the miniature horse at 7:03 a.m.\n\nTwo Grand Island patrol units were slowly following behind the horse.\n\nThe animal nibbled on grass on her lawn. But other than that, the horse stayed on the sidewalk, Flores said. It never used its horsepower to venture into the street.\n\nThe last she saw, the horse took a right on Oak Street.\n\nPeople are also reading... However, Fleming\'s name was bypassed in the blind draw and he was placed in the back of the field. Because of that mix up Fleming was told by race officials he was going for the challenge along with Mike Sweeney and Lee Jeffreys.\n\n"I did get the money and I\'m happy it\'s all worked out," Fleming said on Monday afternoon. "I just want to say that my team and my crew have worked hard all season and I couldn\'t be prouder of what they\'ve done."\n\nLoren Pinilis, who handles media relations for the NASCAR-sanctioned series, said on Monday that Fleming will get his money for finishing second behind Brandon Ward. The Fans Challenge is for the top four qualifiers who can choose to start in the rear of the field with the chance to win the money.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nFleming said no to the challenge in pre-race activities but that did not get conveyed back to the driver\'s meeting where NASCAR officials determine the official starting order for the race. Sweeney and Jeffreys took the challenge but did not finish in the top four.\n\n"There was some miscommunication which led to a little bit of confusion around the Fans\' Challenge," Pinilis said in an e-mail to the Journal. "To resolve it, Chris Fleming is being awarded the $9,000 Fans\' Challenge bonus from Saturday."\n\nThe $9,000 was accumulated from two other Fans Challenges of $3,000 each along with Saturday night\'s challenge. The earlier Fans Challenge were not claimed so the purse grew each time.\n\nThe normal protocol for the next Fans Challenge would be $3,000 but Pinilis said the next Fans Challenge on Aug. 3 will be $9,000.\n\n"The Fans\' Challenge bonus will be $9,000 for the next 100-lapper on August 3," Pinilis said.\n\nFleming comes into this week\'s racing third in the points behind Burt Myers and Ward. His second-place finish allowed him to pick up some points on Myers. Ward also closed the gap on Myers, who finished sixth after an early-race wreck that nearly ended Myers\' night.\n\nWith six weeks left in the season Myers has a 20-point lead on Ward, the defending champion, and 22-point lead on Fleming, who has never won a points\' title in his outstanding career at the Stadium.\n\nFleming, who has nine top five finishes in 15 starts this season, has 17 career wins which ties him for 33rd all time.\n\njdell@wsjournal.com\n\n336-727-4081\n\n@johndellWSJ\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. Sign Up Today', 'source': {'uri': 'greensboro.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Greensboro News and Record'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'john_dell@greensboro.com', 'name': 'John Dell', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/greensboro.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/b/53/b5376aea-4ef9-5c04-94ae-382a7de01a64/669588ee75e5f.preview.jpg?crop=1272%2C668%2C96%2C230&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1607843137254903, 'wgt': 458776326, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '2024-07-422914169', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '21:50:17', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T21:50:17Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T21:32:48Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.nysun.com/article/artificial-intelligences-toll-on-the-environment-is-way-worse-than-you-think-study-finds', 'title': "Artificial Intelligence's Toll on the Environment Is Way Worse Than You Think, Study Finds", 'body': 'Cooling data centers that support AI models requires millions of gallons of water annually.\n\nAs the world becomes more familiar with generative artificial intelligence, the environmental impact of the technology is coming under scrutiny.\n\nOne of the largest expenses is cooling the data centers that support AI models. These facilities require millions of gallons of water annually. For instance, Microsoft estimates that its Goodyear, Arizona, data center will consume around 56 million gallons of drinking water each year, a notable figure for an area already facing water scarcity, Wired reports.\n\nThe website highlights the inefficiency of data centers compared to household water use. "The water that is available for people to use is very limited," an AI researcher at UC Riverside, Shaolei Ren, told the magazine. "It\'s just the fresh surface water and groundwater. Those data centers, they\'re just evaporating water into the air."\n\n"When we get the water from the utility, and then we discharge the water back to the sewage immediately, we are just withdrawing water -- we\'re not consuming water. A data center takes the water from this utility, and they evaporate the water into the sky, into the atmosphere."\n\nDespite these considerable resources, the everyday benefits of AI, such as chatbots and image generators, are often debated. Google\'s AI search summaries, for example, have been criticized for lacking accuracy while using significantly more energy than traditional search methods.\n\n"In the back end, these algorithms that need to be running for any generative AI model are fundamentally very, very different from the traditional kind of Google Search or email," said an AI researcher at the University of Washington, Sajjad Moazeni.\n\n"For basic services, those were very light in terms of the amount of data that needed to go back and forth between the processors," he said.', 'source': {'uri': 'nysun.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The New York Sun'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'joseph_curl@nysun.com', 'name': 'Joseph Curl', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://wp.nysun.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/openAI.jpg?w=1200&h=630&fit=fill&fm=jpg&fl=progressive', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1137254901960785, 'wgt': 458776217, 'relevance': 8}

{'uri': '2024-07-422909119', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '21:39:37', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T21:39:37Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T18:18:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://omaha.com/ap/sports/brian-harman-starts-his-british-open-title-defense-by-returning-the-claret-jug/article_70255da3-acc6-51ae-a90f-975b3bd1e9aa.html', 'title': 'Brian Harman starts his British Open title defense by returning the claret jug', 'body': 'By DOUG FERGUSON - AP Golf Writer\n\nTROON, Scotland (AP) -- Of all the recent traditions in the Royal & Ancient game, what Brian Harman took part in on Monday afternoon might be the least enjoyable.\n\nReturning the claret jug.\n\nThe formal handover of the British Open trophy required a little pomp. Harman was in the back seat of an SUV. The destination was not much longer than the 40-foot birdie putt he made last year on the 14th hole on his way to winning the Open. But he had to wait for the film crew to be set, for the traffic on the road to clear.\n\n"It\'s all yours," Harman told Martin Slumbers, the R&A CEO who took back golf\'s oldest trophy that apparently has seen its share of the finest wine and bourbon in the year since Harman won at Royal Liverpool.\n\nHarman is a straight shooter -- with a rifle, with his mouth and last year with his putter -- but a staged moment as this didn\'t bother him.\n\n"In my opinion, it\'s the coolest trophy in all of sports," Harman said. "So I think it\'s deserving of all of the pageantry that\'s involved with it."\n\nGetting it back by the end of the week is the real challenge.\n\nThe homecoming of the claret jug was an unofficial way to launch the start of the final men\'s major of the year. The 152nd Open Championship begins Thursday on the Scottish links along the Firth of Clyde on the Irish Sea.\n\nRoyal Troon is renowned for its pot bunkers that are so deep they effectively serve as a one-shot penalty when tee shots find them on the longer holes. The outward holes are shorter with the prevailing wind, the inward holes are longer and into the wind.\n\n"You have to take them on," Scottie Scheffler said.\n\nHarman had gone six years without a win until putting together a masterpiece last year to lead over the final 51 holes and win by six. He hasn\'t won since then, a matter of getting his putter to cooperate. He hopes that\'s the case this week.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"You can work and work and work. You just never know when that work is going to pay off," Harman said. "You never know when the peak is coming. You never know when you\'re going to catch a little bit of momentum. So you just have to hope it\'s a big week."\n\nNo one has won back to back in the British Open since Padraig Harrington in 2007 (Carnoustie) and 2008 (Royal Birkdale). Go back to 1960 and the list of repeat winners includes only Tiger Woods, Tom Watson, Lee Trevino and Arnold Palmer.\n\n"A little sad to give it back, but I\'ll remember everywhere it\'s been forever," Harman said. "I\'m happy to give it back, happy to be here. Ready to get going."\n\nRoyal Troon is green and lush, and the rough is particularly thick at the base of turf. This isn\'t likely to be a bright and sunny week along the Ayrshire coast, and the links have been busy.\n\nWoods arrived Sunday and went 18 holes, spending much of his time chipping and putting. His son Charlie is not with him, instead at home preparing for the U.S. Junior Amateur next week outside Detroit.\n\nScheffler got into the competitive spirit, playing alongside Sam Burns as they took some cash from PGA champion Xander Schauffele and Patrick Cantlay.\n\nAfter handing off the jug, Harman headed out to see Royal Troon for the first time. Monday was largely a day of reflection and he was eager to move forward.\n\nBut it was a good year, even without another win. He took the jug to Georgia Bulldogs football and Atlanta Braves baseball games. He took it everywhere he could, a reminder of reaching the pinnacle of his sport.\n\n"You never know how it\'s going to go, but just the reception from everyone back home was overwhelming, just how excited everyone was," he said. "I was obviously very excited, but to be able to share that excitement with people that I care about was probably the best."\n\nHarman was among several players who came across the coast from the Scottish Open last week, a list that included Robert MacIntyre, though his immediately whereabouts could not be confirmed. MacIntyre won the Scottish with an eagle-par-birdie finish and promised he would "celebrate hard" as the first Scot to win his national open in 25 years.\n\nHe was scheduled for a press conference Monday afternoon. It was rescheduled for Wednesday afternoon. That was a big win for him. Next up is one even bigger.\n\nAP golf: https://apnews.com/hub/golf', 'source': {'uri': 'omaha.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Omaha.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'doug_ferguson@omaha.com', 'name': 'Doug Ferguson', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/omaha.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/b/d5/bd5621d6-cc3e-5f59-ab58-a486844b83bd/669593be3c877.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1843137254901961, 'wgt': 458775577, 'relevance': 30}

{'uri': '8227130333', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '21:04:04', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T21:04:04Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T21:03:29Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://newsadvance.com/news/local/vcu-baseball-coach-bradley-lecroy-liberty-rams-flames/article_181f6fd7-41a1-5018-ae74-6ee30e6a237d.html', 'title': 'Report: VCU baseball coach LeCroy leaving for Liberty after two seasons leading Rams', 'body': 'VCU baseball coach Bradley LeCroy, who directed the Rams on an upward trajectory over the past two seasons after taking the helm in August of 2022, is leaving to take the same position at Liberty University, according to a Monday report from Kendall Rogers of D1Baseball.\n\nThe news comes as a relative shock for the VCU community. VCU Athletics declined to comment as of Monday afternoon.\n\nBeset by injuries, transfers and inconsistency on the mound, LeCroy\'s first Rams team in 2023 finished 25-30 and missed out on the Atlantic 10 tournament it hosted at The Diamond.\n\nBut the former Clemson assistant turned things around in his second year.\n\nLed by conference player of the year Brandon Eike (Powhatan High), VCU went 38-23, won an A-10 tournament title and earned a marquee, 1-0 win over No. 22 Wake Forest in the opening round of the Greenville Regional.\n\nLeCroy, a Clemson baseball alumnus (1997-2000) and former assistant at Tennessee, Western Carolina and Division II Anderson University (S.C.), was hired as the seventh coach in VCU baseball history on Aug. 2, 2022, replacing Shawn Stiffler (Notre Dame).\n\nLeCroy is viewed as somewhat of a rising star in the college baseball coaching community.\n\nHe was ranked as the No. 9 assistant coach in the nation by Baseball America prior to the 2013 season, and D1Baseball named him the No. 10 recruiter in the country before the 2017 campaign.\n\nLeCroy will replace former Flames coach Scott Jackson, who resigned last week "to pursue other opportunities in college baseball," according to a July 11 release from the school.\n\nOver eight seasons, Jackson posted a career record of 246-181. His 246 career wins and .576 winning percentage rank third in program history among Liberty\'s seven head coaches.\n\n"I deeply appreciate Coach Jackson\'s many contributions to Liberty baseball over the past eight seasons," said Flames vice president and director of athletics Ian McCaw in the school\'s release.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"His efforts led the program to great success on the field while providing an exceptional, Christ-centered experience for our student-athletes.\n\n"We are excited to build on the strong foundation in place including outstanding facilities, resources and support."\n\nIt could be debated what sort of move the shift from VCU to Liberty symbolizes for LeCroy. The Rams finished last season No. 73 nationally in RPI. Liberty went 24-34 overall, 11-13 in Conference USA.\n\nThe Flames, in a down year by their standards, finished 122nd nationally in RPI. It was the program\'s second consecutive losing season.\n\nBut as recently as 2022, Liberty went 37-23 and earned a spot in the Gainesville Regional, where it fell to Oklahoma and Central Michigan.\n\nIn 2021, Liberty posted a 41-16 mark and made it to the final of the Knoxville Regional, its second regional final in program history.\n\nSo it appears that Flames athletics administration tabbed LeCroy as the man to turn fortunes around for a program that has experienced success in recent years, but floundered in the last couple seasons under Jackson.\n\nThe path forward for VCU baseball is unclear. Faced with their second coaching change in quick succession, the Rams are likely to encounter ample roster turnover this offseason.\n\nAny VCU player with remaining undergraduate eligibility that is not already in the transfer portal has until August 14 to enter their name.\n\nAfter VCU\'s season ended in the Greenville Regional, LeCroy was bullish on the future of his program.\n\n"I told the guys who are returning, \'This isn\'t the end,\'" LeCroy said in early June.\n\n"Our goal is to get into a regional, win it, get into a super regional, win it, and knock the door down to get to Omaha. If you don\'t talk about, if you don\'t believe it, you can\'t achieve it."\n\nIt will be of particular interest to see how LeCroy\'s departure affects VCU\'s incoming recruiting class, a group that includes local standouts such as Mills Godwin P/OF Hank Piersol, Douglas Freeman P Cayman Goode, Matoaca C Jacob Lee, and Benedictine P/OF Elijah Coston and P Riley Roarty.\n\n"It\'s huge to keep those guys in the city," LeCroy said of that group.\n\n"VCU\'s got a really strong brand, especially in baseball. Those guys that have the ties to the community and ties to VCU, there\'s no doubt in my mind that they take more pride in what they\'re doing and want to do great things for their own school in their own city."\n\nZach Joachim (804) 649-6555\n\nzjoachim@timesdispatch.com\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'newsadvance.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'NewsAdvance.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/newsadvance.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/81/181f6fd7-41a1-5018-ae74-6ee30e6a237d/66958c28a9d0f.preview.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.06666666666666665, 'wgt': 458773444, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8227119336', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '20:52:21', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T20:52:21Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T20:51:12Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://omaha.com/ap/sports/from-biles-to-shacarri-team-usa-packed-with-star-power-heading-into-olympic-games/article_16009709-70b8-5506-942f-231ac1da8f62.html', 'title': "From Biles to Sha'Carri, Team USA packed with star power heading into Olympic Games", 'body': 'By PAT GRAHAM - AP Sports Writer\n\nFrom Simone Biles to Sha\'Carri Richardson and Diana Taurasi to Katie Ledecky, Team USA will provide some of the biggest star power at the 2024 Olympic Games.\n\nAnd it will be the women leading the way as the U.S. looks to top the overall medal table for the eighth consecutive Summer Games.\n\nThe nearly 600 athletes going to the Paris Games include more than 250 returning Olympians and 122 Olympic medalists. Golfers Xander Schauffele and Nelly Korda, along with surfer Carissa Moore, are among the numerous Olympians set to defend their titles in France.\n\nIt\'s a loaded U.S. roster where the women outnumber the men 314 to 278, and ages range from 16 to 59. The most decorated member of Team USA in Paris will be Ledecky, who\'s trying to add to her collection of 10 medals (seven golds).\n\nComebacks and redemption\n\nBiles is back in action after pulling out of multiple gymnastics finals in Tokyo to protect her mental health and safety. There\'s Richardson making her Olympic debut after a much-debated absence three years ago because of a positive marijuana test.\n\nBiles leads a U.S. women\'s gymnastics team filled with familiar faces and looking for redemption in Paris. The team settled for silver three years ago behind the Russian athletes competing as the Russian Olympic Committee.\n\nRichardson has become a media sensation for her speed, charisma and perseverance. The 100-meter world champion earned a spot for Tokyo in 2021 but was banned following her positive test for marijuana. It sparked an intense debate about whether she was being unfairly singled out for taking a substance that doesn\'t improve performance.\n\nThe 24-year-old Richardson, who graces the cover of Vogue magazine, said she was "overwhelmed with the emotions of just joy" after making the team.\n\nStar power on the court\n\nOn the court, hoops royalty LeBron James and Diana Taurasi lead their teams. And it\'s no surprise that the men\'s and women\'s basketball squads brimming with talent are heavy favorites to bring home the gold.\n\nJames, Joel Embiid, Kevin Durant and Steph Curry join forces to lead a U.S. contingent going for a fifth straight Olympic title. A\'ja Wilson, Brittney Griner and Taurasi headline a women\'s squad that has won seven consecutive Olympic gold medals. Taurasi has been apart of five of them.\n\nWho else is on the Team USA roster?\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nDecorated swimmers Ledecky and Caeleb Dressel are on deck to shine again in the pool, and majors winners and world No. 1 golfers Scottie Scheffler and Korda take to the links.\n\n"We\'re telling these stories -- we\'re laughing, we\'re crying, we\'re cheering them on," said Lyndsay Signor, senior vice president of consumer engagement at NBC Sports. "So that really warrants both the combination of the athletes themselves and the celebrities we\'ve partnered with."\n\nNBC has been airing promotional Olympic material around the clock. There\'s Biles being interviewed by singer SZA. Other athletes featured in spots include Richardson, sprinter Noah Lyles, 400-meter hurdles world-record holder Sydney McLaughlin-Levrone, Ledecky and reigning Olympic all-around gymnastics winner Suni Lee.\n\nThe U.S. women\'s soccer team, led by new coach Emma Hayes, chases after its first Olympic gold since 2012 and Victor Montalvo -- "B-Boy Victor" -- will be a contender when breaking makes its Olympic debut in Paris. Coco Gauff is among the favorites to bring home a medal on the clay courts at Roland Garros, the site of the French Open.\n\nMedal forecast\n\nThat abundance of star power is why Nielsen\'s Gracenote forecasts the U.S. hauling in 123 medals. That\'s ahead of China (87), Britain (62) and France (56). This could be the eighth straight Summer Games where the Americans have topped the medal table.\n\n"If American athletes win, that drives ratings and endorsements, and makes it attractive for American corporations to invest in the Olympic movement," said Dr. Yoav Dubinsky, an instructor of sports business from the Lundquist College of Business at the University of Oregon. "All part of the story of American lifestyle. Their successes, and at times failures or adversities, contribute to Brand America."\n\nOlympic entertainers\n\nNBC brought in Academy Award-winning director Steven Spielberg to narrate a short film titled, "Land of Stories," where the Olympics set a scene to tell tales.\n\nEven more stars will participate in the network\'s coverage as celebrities Snoop Dogg, Kelly Clarkson, Peyton Manning, Colin Jost, Leslie Jones and Jimmy Fallon make appearances.\n\nSnoop already is trotting out his tracksuits to get in some work. The 52-year-old hip-hop star ran a 200-meter race against Ato Boldon and Wallace Spearmon at the Olympic track trials in Eugene, Oregon, last month.\n\nHis time was 34.44 seconds. Usain Bolt\'s world record of 19.19 remains safe.\n\n"(Snoop) has really brought a perspective that\'s not only fun and interesting," Signor said, "it\'s lovable as well."\n\nAP Summer Olympics: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games', 'source': {'uri': 'omaha.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Omaha.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/omaha.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/07/907537bf-f790-5414-ac87-e34375cf48bd/669585626659f.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1843137254901961, 'wgt': 458772741, 'relevance': 51}

The event, held at Encore Las Vegas, brought together NBA players and gaming enthusiasts in a unique fusion of sports and esports.\n\nBronny James clinched the title by triumphing over Williams in a special Modern Warfare III map, showcasing his gaming prowess. This win marks a significant achievement for James, as he joins the ranks of competitive gaming champions. Last year\'s tournament saw Jaylin Williams of the Oklahoma City Thunder take home the prize, but this year belonged to Bronny.\n\nIn the final moments of the tournament, Bronny showcased his skills in a two-minute drill contest, where he outscored Williams and Detroit Pistons\' Bobi Klintman. With an impressive 84 points, James obliterated the 59 points that secured last year\'s title for Jaylin Williams.\n\nThis performance earned him a custom-made Call of Duty championship belt and a $10,000 prize, solidifying his status as a formidable gamer, one of the best in the league.\n\nThe players also got an exclusive preview of the recently announced Call of Duty: Black Ops 6, adding to the excitement of the event. Bronny James\' victory in the tournament highlights his versatility and competitive spirit, extending beyond the basketball court.\n\nDespite facing challenges in the NBA Summer League, where he has struggled with shooting, Bronny\'s success in the Call of Duty tournament is a testament to his determination and skill. His performance in the tournament has earned him respect and recognition, proving that he is capable of excelling in multiple arenas.\n\nBronny\'s victory also holds symbolic significance as he continues to carve his own path, independent of his father\'s legendary career. While LeBron James prepares for the upcoming Olympics with Team USA, Bronny is making headlines with his accomplishments in esports.\n\nThe Call of Duty tournament win is a highlight of Bronny\'s summer, demonstrating his ability to compete at a high level both on and off the court. As he continues to develop his skills in the NBA, fans can look forward to seeing more from this talented young athlete, whether in basketball or gaming.\n\nBronny James Doesn\'t Have Michael Jordan In 5 Most Favorite Players Of All-Time\n\nBronny James, the son of NBA superstar LeBron James, recently made headlines with his surprising list of top five favorite NBA players of all time. In a recent interview with ESPN, Bronny revealed his selections, and the list notably excluded Michael Jordan, widely considered one of the greatest basketball players in history.\n\n"LeBron - one, Steph - two, Kyrie - three, KD - four, and Ant and Shai tied for the five."\n\nBronny\'s favorite players are all current stars, with his father, LeBron James, unsurprisingly at the top. Following LeBron, Bronny chose Stephen Curry, Kyrie Irving, Kevin Durant, and a tie between Anthony Edwards and Shai Gilgeous-Alexander. This list reflects Bronny\'s admiration for players he has grown up watching and, in some cases, personally interacting with.\n\nThe omission of Michael Jordan, a six-time NBA champion and five-time MVP, is particularly surprising given Jordan\'s legendary status in the sport. Additionally, the exclusion of Kobe Bryant, another all-time great and a Lakers icon, raised eyebrows among fans.\n\nBronny\'s choices highlight the generational shift in basketball fandom, as younger players like him tend to idolize contemporary stars they can see and interact with.\n\nBronny\'s selections sparked a lively debate on social media, with many fans and analysts weighing in on his unconventional picks. While some understand his preference for current players he grew up watching, others believe that legends like Jordan and Bryant deserve a place on any all-time list.\n\nThe scrutiny on Bronny has been intense, especially as he navigates his rookie year with the Los Angeles Lakers after being selected 55th overall in the 2024 NBA Draft. Despite his challenges in the NBA Summer League, where he has struggled to find his rhythm, Bronny remains a focal point of attention due to his lineage and potential.\n\nAs Bronny continues to develop his game, he will undoubtedly face comparisons to the all-time greats, including those he chose to leave off his list. His journey in the NBA is just beginning, and he will have ample opportunity to carve out his own legacy while paying homage to the players who inspire him.\n\nRelated: Gilbert Arenas On Expectations From Bronny James: Stands Up And Claps - \'Go Daddy Go\'\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. You earn points called SB for online activities and then you can cash them in for gift cards to places like Amazon, Target, Walmart, Lowes, Starbucks, Paypal, Bass Pro Shops, Kohl\'s and so many more! It\'s free to join and I have earned a bunch of gift cards in the many years I have been a member.\n\nNew member bonus Swagbucks sign-up code\n\nAs I posted above, new members get SB bonus points when you sign up at Swagbucks.com HERE and enter the bonus code during sign-up. {'uri': '8226914516', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '17:42:21', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T17:42:21Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T17:41:41Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://omaha.com/news/local/safety-concerns-prompt-officials-to-lower-water-level-for-closing-elkhorn-river-access/article_f15f643a-42c8-11ef-a5ce-735d5bae1752.html', 'title': 'Safety concerns prompt officials to lower water level for closing Elkhorn River access', 'body': 'Concerns for safety prompted the Papio-Missouri Natural Resource District to announce Monday the Elkhorn River access sites will close at lower water levels.\n\nThe NRD board of directors voted Thursday to decrease the water level that determines the temporary closure of the access sites. The sites had closed when the water gage at Waterloo reads at a stage height of 5-feet or greater. The access sites will now close when the water gage reads a stage height of 4-feet or greater.\n\n"The Elkhorn River has degraded at least two feet over the past five years, likely due to the large flood events that have occurred," said John Winkler, the NRD general manager. "This has resulted in higher water levels, increased water flows and no visible sandbars. This makes recreation more dangerous."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nWinkler says recreation is more conducive at the new stage height as sandbars are either visible or just below the surface. As is always the case, Winkler says before sites can reopen, river access ramps may need to be cleaned of silt, debris and safety inspected.\n\nThe Elkhorn River access sites: Elkhorn Crossing at the intersection of 252nd & Bennington Road; West Maple Road at West Maple Road northeast of Waterloo; and Graske Crossing at southeast corner of West Dodge Road and west of 204th Street.\n\nThe access sites are open from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. through Nov. 1. River-goers can find out whether the access sites are open or closed by going to the Papio-Missouri NRD website.\n\nPhotos: The Missouri River floods in Omaha', 'source': {'uri': 'omaha.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Omaha.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'kevin_cole@omaha.com', 'name': 'Kevin Cole', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/omaha.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/15/f15f643a-42c8-11ef-a5ce-735d5bae1752/6695564c21608.preview.jpg?crop=1838%2C965%2C153%2C0&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1137254901960785, 'wgt': 458761341, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8226873493', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '17:08:09', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T17:08:09Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T17:07:41Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8823529481887817, 'url': 'https://mcdowellnews.com/news/state-regional/local-teenage-girl-reported-drowning-victim-at-ocean-isle-beach/article_d890ec13-0a60-5c3b-a47b-885b3d99fa8e.html', 'title': 'NC high school student on robotics trip drowns at Ocean Isle Beach', 'body': 'Important things to know about dangerous ocean rip currents. \'The Independent\' reports that rip currents pose the greatest danger to beachgoers, accounting for the most beach rescues every year.\n\nA girl on the robotics team at Reynolds High School died Sunday when she was caught in a rip current at Ocean Isle Beach, according to Winston-Salem/Forsyth County Schools officials and other sources.\n\nReynolds Principal Calvin Freeman told school staffers Sunday night that the student that died was visiting the coast over the weekend and was among three students who got caught in a rip current.\n\nOne of the three students was unresponsive when rescued and could not be revived, Freeman said.\n\nThe drowning occurred shortly after noon on Sunday, sources said. The other two students were safely rescued. When the students returned to Winston-Salem by bus Sunday night, they were met by schools officials.\n\nFreeman did not provide any information identifying the student, saying that he wanted to make sure all family members had been notified.\n\nPeople are also reading... McDowell County Schools moving principals at West Middle, Eastfield and Foothills school 3 from South Carolina die in Nebo plane crash; national safety board investigating 3 dead in plane crash near McDowell, Rutherford county line Marion man meets McDowell paramedic who saved his life 24 years ago McDowell High athlete appointed to NC Student-Athlete Advisory Council Marion NC man\'s charges upgraded to felony after assault on 79-year-old Picasso Keaton, a former WSSU football player, dies in a car crash Marion NC man charged with breaking into home, assault Hickory pastor has a license to practice law. Plus, she\'s been on \'Jeopardy\' Frisbee\'s Galaxy Supermarket in Old Fort now a Piggly Wiggly; still family owned Plane crashes in McDowell; emergency crews ask people to avoid Brackett Town Road Nebo man charged with meth possession McDowell ministry launches program to improve health of those in need Body found Sunday was Marion man; cause of death pending toxicology report McDowell leaders seek land for new animal shelter\n\nThe local press in Ocean Isle said the drowning victim was a teenage girl and that the drowning occurred near the Ocean Isle Beach Fishing Pier.\n\nFreeman said the victim was on the school robotics team, and that the team had visited the beach as part of a robotics-related trip. Freeman said that during a break, students were swimming in the ocean when three students were caught in the rip current.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"Our hearts are heavy, and our prayers are with her family," Freeman said, adding that the victim\'s family had been notified of the drowning by the Winston-Salem Police Department, which learned of the incident from law enforcement at Ocean Isle Beach.\n\n"This is a tragic situation, and as you can imagine, other members of the team are taking the news hard," Freeman said, adding that the school would have counselors on hand to help any students or faculty members who need help coping.\n\nTricia McManus, superintendent of schools, said she was "heartbroken by this tragic news."\n\n"I want the family, and our Reynolds students and staff to know that our district will provide any support they need at this incredibly difficult time," McManus said. "Our prayers are with all of you, and we mourn this loss with you."\n\nThe Ocean Isle Beach newspaper said chaperones were with the students as they made a day trip to the beach.\n\nSmith said two other people were safely rescued from the rip current.\n\n"It\'s just sad when something like this happens -- a fun day at the beach turns into a tragedy," Smith was quoted as saying. "My heart sure breaks for the family, for all of them."\n\nWhat do you do when you\'re drowning? 4 water safety tips from the experts More common than you think\n\nDave Benjamin, co-founder and executive director of the Great Lakes Surf Rescue Project, usually starts his water safety classes by talking about fire. "What do you do in case of a fire emergency?" He normally asks the crowd of children. "Stop, drop and roll," they say.\n\n"What do you do if you\'re drowning?" More often than not, the kids stay silent.\n\n"Now, how often do you play in fire?" He asks. Heads shake. "And how often do you play in water?" For many children and teens, the answer to this last question is: Every. Single. Summer.\n\nDrowning, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, is responsible for more deaths among children age 1 to 4 than all other causes except birth defects. For children age 1 to 14, drowning remains the second-leading cause of unintentional injury-related deaths, just behind motor vehicle crashes. Water safety, Benjamin (pictured speaking) said, "is not common sense." Even the most advanced swimmers could be at risk.\n\nA precautionary tale\n\nOn July 27, 2013, 15-year-old Matthew Kocher was away from home on a camp trip to New Buffalo City Beach in New Buffalo, Michigan, earning community service hours for school. While standing in the shallow Lake Michigan waters, Kocher got caught in a rip current.\n\n"We were basically pool people, like most people," John Kocher (pictured in orange), Matthew\'s father, said.\n\nMatthew had little experience in open water. Kocher suspects his son and several other people in his camp group, were unaware that the waving red flags on the beach signaled hazardous water condition\n\nThe Matthew Kocher Foundation\n\nAfter Matthew\'s funeral, John and his wife, Kathy, set up a foundation in their son\'s name. They have since partnered with Benjamin and the GLSRP to sponsor more than 300 water safety talks in Illinois.\n\nThe following are the water safety tips they hope will save a life.\n\n"We would have told Matt about this. Matt would have listened," John said. "He was that kind of kid."\n\n1. Know before you go\n\n"Check the weather reports, check the wave reports and check for a rip-current warning. See if any flags are up," Kocher said.\n\nAll of this information can be found on the National Weather Service\'s website weather.gov. It is updated each day with watches, warnings and other advisories.\n\nWhen at a beach, red flags signal hazardous conditions that would make swimming more dangerous. Yellow flags indicate rough but non-life threatening water conditions and green flags signal normal conditions.\n\n2. Keep an eye on your child\n\nWhether at the beach or pool, the National Drowning Prevention Alliance suggests parents designate a water watcher or water guardian.\n\n"Even if you are with a group of people, have one adult whose main responsibility is to keep an eye on the kids in the water," Adam Katchmarchi, the executive director of NDPA said.\n\nLifeguards should be additional, rather than sole supervisors.\n\n3. Flip, float, follow\n\nIn a water emergency, GLSRP recommends swimmers flip, float and follow.\n\nFirst flip over onto your back to float. Keep your head above the water, remain calm and conserve energy.\n\nIf in open water with a current, swim perpendicular to its flow, parallel to the shore, until you reach an area free of the current. If you see someone who appears to be drowning, toss a flotation device into the water then alert lifeguards.\n\nrcraver@wsjournal.com\n\n336-727-7376\n\n@rcraverWSJ\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'mcdowellnews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'McDowellNews.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/mcdowellnews.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/d/89/d890ec13-0a60-5c3b-a47b-885b3d99fa8e/6695536e1cb52.preview.jpg?crop=860%2C452%2C0%2C51&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9735518', 'sentiment': -0.003921568627450966, 'wgt': 458759289, 'relevance': 51}

Summer.\n\nDrowning, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, is responsible for more deaths among children age 1 to 4 than all other causes except birth defects. Matt would have listened," John said. "He was that kind of kid."\n\n1. Know before you go\n\n"Check the weather reports, check the wave reports and check for a rip-current warning. See if any flags are up," Kocher said.\n\nAll of this information can be found on the National Weather Service\'s website weather.gov. It is updated each day with watches, warnings and other advisories.\n\nWhen at a beach, red flags signal hazardous conditions that would make swimming more dangerous. Yellow flags indicate rough but non-life threatening water conditions and green flags signal normal conditions.\n\n2. Keep an eye on your child\n\nWhether at the beach or pool, the National Drowning Prevention Alliance suggests parents designate a water watcher or water guardian.\n\n"Even if you are with a group of people, have one adult whose main responsibility is to keep an eye on the kids in the water," Adam Katchmarchi, the executive director of NDPA said.\n\nLifeguards should be additional, rather than sole supervisors.\n\n3. Flip, float, follow\n\nIn a water emergency, GLSRP recommends swimmers flip, float and follow.\n\nFirst flip over onto your back to float. Keep your head above the water, remain calm and conserve energy.\n\nIf in open water with a current, swim perpendicular to its flow, parallel to the shore, until you reach an area free of the current. If you see someone who appears to be drowning, toss a flotation device into the water then alert lifeguards.\n\n4. Learn to swim\n\nSwimming is an essential skill. However, 64% of African American children, 45% of Hispanic children and 40% of white children cannot swim.\n\nThis statistic becomes even more harrowing when it is revealed that of all nonswimming children, 87% plan to visit a beach or pool at least once during the summer.\n\nrcraver@wsjournal.com\n\n336-727-7376\n\n@rcraverWSJ\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'statesville.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Statesville.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/statesville.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/6/7e/67ea8c31-b3a8-54d0-a180-876d48d315d3/6695536e421a8.preview.jpg?crop=860%2C452%2C0%2C51&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9735518', 'sentiment': -0.003921568627450966, 'wgt': 458759083, 'relevance': 51}

For children age 1 to 14, drowning remains the second-leading cause of unintentional injury-related deaths, just behind motor vehicle crashes. Water safety, Benjamin (pictured speaking) said, "is not common sense." Even the most advanced swimmers could be at risk.\n\nA precautionary tale\n\nOn July 27, 2013, 15-year-old Matthew Kocher was away from home on a camp trip to New Buffalo City Beach in New Buffalo, Michigan, earning community service hours for school. While standing in the shallow Lake Michigan waters, Kocher got caught in a rip current.\n\n"We were basically pool people, like most people," John Kocher (pictured in orange), Matthew\'s father, said.\n\nMatthew had little experience in open water. Kocher suspects his son and several other people in his camp group, were unaware that the waving red flags on the beach signaled hazardous water condition\n\nThe Matthew Kocher Foundation\n\nAfter Matthew\'s funeral, John and his wife, Kathy, set up a foundation in their son\'s name. They have since partnered with Benjamin and the GLSRP to sponsor more than 300 water safety talks in Illinois.\n\nThe following are the water safety tips they hope will save a life.\n\n"We would have told Matt about this. Matt would have listened," John said. "He was that kind of kid."\n\n1. Know before you go\n\n"Check the weather reports, check the wave reports and check for a rip-current warning. See if any flags are up," Kocher said.\n\nAll of this information can be found on the National Weather Service\'s website weather.gov. It is updated each day with watches, warnings and other advisories.\n\nWhen at a beach, red flags signal hazardous conditions that would make swimming more dangerous. Yellow flags indicate rough but non-life threatening water conditions and green flags signal normal conditions.\n\n2. Keep an eye on your child\n\nWhether at the beach or pool, the National Drowning Prevention Alliance suggests parents designate a water watcher or water guardian.\n\n"Even if you are with a group of people, have one adult whose main responsibility is to keep an eye on the kids in the water," Adam Katchmarchi, the executive director of NDPA said.\n\nLifeguards should be additional, rather than sole supervisors.\n\n3. Flip, float, follow\n\nIn a water emergency, GLSRP recommends swimmers flip, float and follow.\n\nFirst flip over onto your back to float. Keep your head above the water, remain calm and conserve energy.\n\nIf in open water with a current, swim perpendicular to its flow, parallel to the shore, until you reach an area free of the current. If you see someone who appears to be drowning, toss a flotation device into the water then alert lifeguards.\n\nrcraver@wsjournal.com\n\n336-727-7376\n\n@rcraverWSJ\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'greensboro.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Greensboro News and Record'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/greensboro.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/5/49/5496ca1f-7659-59b7-aa1b-d8d1e36525b0/6695536e1cd46.preview.jpg?crop=860%2C452%2C0%2C51&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9735518', 'sentiment': 0.05882352941176472, 'wgt': 458758930, 'relevance': 76}

The bank\'s Paris campaign includes three ad spots centered around success stories of athletes who have graduated from the bank\'s Training Ground program to qualify for the Olympics.\n\nThe RBC Training Ground program sees the bank work with the Canadian Olympic Committee, a longtime partner, as well as 11 national sports organizations and regional sports institutes to host free events across the country where athletes aged between 14 and 25 are assessed for high-performance potential in Olympic. It\'s identified more than 1,600 athletes as having Olympic potential, and is sending a record 16 graduates of the program to the Olympics this year.\n\nThe bank\'s Paris campaign this year includes the "Hockey Here" spot which features Krissy Scurfield, a hockey player from Canmore, Alberta who attended Training Ground in 2021, and has since risen through the ranks at Rugby Canada to become an offensive threat for the women\'s 7s team. The campaign also includes "Here Together," which tells the story of Canada\'s women\'s sprint track cycling team who had never tried the sport before participating in Training Ground, including Tokyo Games gold medalist Kelsey Mitchell.\n\nA third spot, "Decathlon Here," features Pierce LePage, one of the first notable athletes to be identified through Training Ground. The spot focuses on the lifestyle of an international athlete and how it is enabled by RBC services like the international money transfer banking function on RBC\'s mobile app.\n\n"The main goal is to just do justice to the RBC Training Ground program itself, and the athletes who have put in such hard work to get to the Olympic Games," RBC senior director of brand marketing Mark Thomas says.\n\nThe campaign is part of RBC\'s partnership with the Canadian Olympic Committee, which dates back to 1947. Thomas says the goal of this year\'s campaign is to take the stories of LePage and the newer athletes featured in the creative, and leverage them to bring to life RBC\'s product offerings.\n\nThomas says that the Training Ground program has been well-aligned to RBC\'s commitment to support Canadian youth by investing in the country\'s young athletes, and reshaping how athletes are recruited and developed. He adds that RBC believes its broader sponsorship strategy and Olympic partnership is aligned with its purpose to help clients thrive and communities prosper\n\n"Sport helps to build character, it teaches valuable life lessons and helps to foster healthy communities," Thomas says.\n\nDentsu and Holiday Films developed the creative for the campaign, which is tied to RBC\'s "Ideas Happen Here" platform. Picture: EVGENIA NOVOZHENINA/REUTERS\n\nA deal to split the assets of Russian technology company Yandex was finalised on Monday, with a Russian consortium of investors buying the bulk of Yandex\'s businesses in a cash and shares deal worth about $5.4bn.\n\nThe split marks the end of foreign ownership in Yandex, often dubbed "Russia\'s Google", potentially tightening the Kremlin\'s control of the internet space in Russia, while also finalising the largest corporate exit from Russia since Moscow invaded Ukraine over two years ago.\n\nYandex\'s Dutch parent company Yandex NV (YNV) said it had sold its remaining minority 28% stake as part of the deal\'s second closing, receiving a total of $2.8bn in cash and 162.5- million YNV class A shares.\n\n"With the second closing, YNV has received the agreed upon purchase price and now fully disposed of its remaining interest in the Russian businesses," YNV said.\n\nYandex blazed a trail for Russian technology after setting up in the late 1990s dot-com boom and listing on Nasdaq, becoming a dominant force in search and advertising, ride-hailing,\n\ne-commerce and other online services.\n\nFour artificial intelligence-focused businesses in cloud, data labelling, self-driving cars and education technology are being retained by YNV and will be developed under the Nebius Group name, YNV said.\n\nYandex in Russia said YNV would stop using Yandex brands by July 31.\n\nVOLOZH RETURNS\n\nThe deal is the result of about two years of negotiations and faced various setbacks and hurdles, from Kremlin demands for a discount of at least 50% on foreign asset sales to nationalisation risk and an anti-war outburst from Yandex co-founder Arkady Volozh.\n\nAfter EU sanctions on Volozh were lifted in March, he is now set to return as CEO of Nebius and lead the renamed group, now free from the shackles of its Russia ties, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters.\n\nYNV chair John Boynton thanked the company\'s 1,300 employees, paying particular tribute to Vadim Marchuk, who led the deal team.\n\n"All connections with Russia have now been severed," he said.\n\nWith the deal done, attention may turn to the future of YNV\'s Nasdaq listing, where many Western shareholders are stuck holding stakes in which trading has long been suspended.\n\n"The class A shares received as consideration will be held in treasury, pending use under our equity incentive plans and for further financing purposes," YNV said.\n\nAfter the deal\'s closing, YNV said the aggregate number of class A and Class B ordinary shares outstanding was 199-million.\n\nTrading in Yandex in Russia under the new YDEX ticker will start on July 24.\n\nThe Russian buyers said on Monday that all settlements for a share exchange, converting Moscow-listed shares in Yandex NV to the new Russian entity, MKPAO Yandex, had been completed.\n\nBut the new owners face the headache of a lawsuit filed by about 100 shareholders, accusing the consortium\'s trustee, Solid Management, of imposing discriminatory terms in the exchange of shares.', 'source': {'uri': 'businesslive.co.za', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'BusinessLIVE'}, 'authors': We found that some brands or sellers on Amazon offer rewards or incentives to buyers in an attempt to manipulate reviews and star ratings. When shopping for products on Amazon, it\'s best to read independent reviews from a variety of sources before you part with your cash".\n\n*Our nationally representative survey of 1,556 people ran in August 2023.\n\nThere are a few things you can do to spot fake reviews:\n\nIf you buy a product on Amazon Prime Day and it arrives on your doorstep damaged, the retailer is fully responsible.\n\nUnder the Consumer Rights Acts, your purchase needs to be of satisfactory quality (not faulty or damaged), fit for purpose and as described. If your Prime Day product doesn\'t meet one of these requirements, the retailer (not the manufacturer) is in breach of the Consumer Rights Act. An additional Amazon guarantee protects your purchase when buying from an Amazon marketplace - called the Amazon A-Z guarantee, it now extends to damage caused by unsafe products, too.\n\nAmazon will refund the cost of sending an item back if it was sold or dispatched by Amazon. By Alexander Marrow\n\nA deal to split the assets of Russian technology company Yandex was finalised on Monday, with a Russian consortium of investors buying the bulk of Yandex\'s businesses in a cash and shares deal worth around $5.4 billion.\n\nThe split marks the end of foreign ownership in Yandex, often dubbed "Russia\'s Google", potentially tightening the Kremlin\'s control of the internet space in Russia, while also finalising the largest corporate exit from Russia since Moscow invaded Ukraine over two years ago.\n\nYandex\'s Dutch parent company Yandex NV (YNV) said it had sold its remaining minority 28% stake as part of the deal\'s second closing, receiving a total of $2.8 billion in cash and 162.5 million YNV class A shares.\n\n"With the second closing, YNV has received the agreed upon purchase price and now fully disposed of its remaining interest in the Russian businesses," YNV said.\n\nYandex blazed a trail for Russian technology after setting up in the late 1990s dotcom boom and listing on Nasdaq, becoming a dominant force in search and advertising, ride-hailing, e-commerce and other online services.\n\nFour AI-focused businesses in cloud, data labelling, self-driving cars and education technology are being retained by YNV and will be developed under the Nebius Group name, YNV said.\n\nYandex in Russia said YNV would stop using Yandex brands by July 31.\n\nVOLOZH RETURNS\n\nThe deal is the result of around two years of negotiations and faced various setbacks and hurdles, from Kremlin demands for a discount of at least 50% on foreign asset sales to nationalisation risk and an anti-war outburst from Yandex co-founder Arkady Volozh.\n\nAfter EU sanctions on Volozh were lifted in March, he is now set to return as CEO of Nebius and lead the renamed group, now free from the shackles of its Russia ties, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters.\n\nYNV Chairman John Boynton thanked the company\'s 1,300 employees, paying particular tribute to Vadim Marchuk, who led the deal team.\n\n"All connections with Russia have now been severed," he said.\n\nWith the deal done, attention may turn to the future of YNV\'s Nasdaq listing, where many Western shareholders are stuck holding stakes in which trading has long been suspended.\n\n"The Class A shares received as consideration will be held in treasury, pending use under our equity incentive plans and for further financing purposes," YNV said.\n\nFollowing the deal\'s closing, YNV said the aggregate number of Class A and Class B ordinary shares outstanding was 199 million.\n\nTrading in Yandex in Russia under the new YDEX ticker will start on July 24.\n\nThe Russian buyers said on Monday that all settlements for a share exchange, converting Moscow-listed shares in Yandex NV to the new Russian entity, MKPAO Yandex, had been completed.\n\nBut the new owners face the headache of a lawsuit filed by around 100 shareholders, accusing the consortium\'s trustee, Solid Management, of imposing discriminatory terms in the exchange of shares.', 'source': {'uri': 'telecom.economictimes.indiatimes.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'ETTelecom.com'}, 'authors': [], And as things stand, there haven\'t been any notable barriers to entry for white American players in the league.\n\nCould we see a re-emergence of white American stars in the NBA? There were plenty of kids playing on the playground, but he was the only one keen on earning the title of Mullet Champ in the USA Mullet Championships.\n\n"There\'s a lot of spikes. Last year and this year I\'ve been doing a lot of spikes," he said of his mullet. "I think I\'ve got about a 50% chance to win the competition."\n\nVerzani isn\'t sporting the haircut some call a Kentucky Waterfall just to turn heads and get compliments. The USA Mullet Championships are part of a fundraiser for Jared Allen\'s Homes for Wounded Warriors. The group\'s mission is to provide veterans who were wounded in combat with an accessible, mortgage-free, injury-specific home, according to its website.\n\nIn a family full of military veterans, that\'s an easy cause to get behind.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nCaribou Coffee to open new location in Mooresville Monday Letter: Too much development is destroying Mooresville Silver Alert canceled on woman, 87, from Mooresville 3 from South Carolina die in Nebo NC plane crash; national safety board investigating North Carolina Public health restaurant and food-stand inspections in Iredell County, June 28-July 11 Perfect timing: Residents elect Town of Mooresville\'s fourth dog mayor Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Iredell EMS deputy director talks about his termination. He later saw a teenager sporting the same look.\n\nLuke asked his mother, Samantha Verzani, about the mullet. But it very much suits his personality."\n\nThe mischievous part was evident as Luke crawled on top of the playground equipment in Troutman, testing his mother\'s patience.\n\nMullet Champ\n\nThe USA Mullet Championships are a national competition where haircuts like Luke\'s are judged by three things: online votes, judges, and money raised for Jared Allen\'s Homes for Wounded Warriors.\n\nThose wanting to vote for Luke and donate to his cause can go to mulletchamp.com/mullets and search for Luke.\n\nContestants are separated into different age groups, with Luke competing against other kids ages 8-12.\n\nThe opening round of qualification voting continues until July 17. If enough fans vote and enough money is raised, Luke will advance to round 2, which is July 24-30. In the final round, the top hairdos are judged by professional motocross athlete Aaron Plessinger and "The Pat McAfee Show" co-host Boston Connor.
