{'uri': '2024-07-422367156', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '11:33:29', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T11:33:29Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T11:26:30Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.5764706134796143, 'url': 'https://uk.style.yahoo.com/menopause-driving-anxiety-women-fear-112630413.html', 'title': 'Menopause anxiety leading to fear of driving for some women', 'body': 'Menopause has many well-known symptoms - night sweats, brain fog and hot flashes to name but a few - but there are also some unexpected side effects of the mid-life period including suddenly developing an anxiety about driving.\n\nGoogle searches for "menopause driving anxiety" have skyrocketed by 200% in the last year alone, as more women are seeking advice on how to deal with this debilitating symptom.\n\nOthers have been heading to social media to share their personal experiences of living with the life-altering impact, commenting under TikTok videos that they too have developed a sudden fear of driving during their menopausal years.\n\nWhen medical journalist Fiona Clark posted on her @harleystreetemprium Instagram account, which focuses on menopause, posted about \'vehophobia\' (fear of driving) and \'amexophobia\' (fear of being a passenger), she was flooded with comments.\n\n"We need to get it out there that this is an actual symptom of perimenopause because I actually thought at one point that I was going crazy," one woman wrote.\n\n"I had no idea there was a connection to this issue and menopause," another wrote. "Thank you for sharing and raising awareness."\n\n"As someone who has experienced anxiety alongside driving for many years this is so important!" yet another user added.\n\nJulie\'s first experience of menopause driving fear began two years ago and has now stopped her from driving in rush hour traffic, forcing her to find alternative transport to get to work.\n\n"They don\'t tell you how most symptoms of menopause can change your life, but I never expected this, to be scared behind the wheel of my own car," the 57-year-old told Nationwide Vehicle Contracts.\n\n"I live in a quiet town, where we don\'t even get much traffic, but I now avoid driving in rush hour and driving any long journeys as it scares the life out of me - even the smallest thing like someone overtaking me can shake me up and I find myself not wanting to drive.\n\n"I\'m now on HRT, but I\'ve been nervous about driving now for two years, so I worry the fear won\'t ever change."\n\nSo what\'s causing this seemingly irrational fear of getting behind the wheel?\n\nIntimate health and hormone expert Dr Shirin Lakhani says many women going through the menopause don\'t just experience physical changes, but mental ones, too.\n\nDue to hormone levels fluctuating during perimenopause and menopause, Dr Lakhani says what were once simple, everyday tasks can turn into something more daunting.\n\n"Driving anxiety can often occur for those with anxious tendencies, which can of course be exaggerated during menopause," she explains. "Many have anxiety surrounding it due to the danger you are putting yourself in when driving. And although for most people they don\'t feel too worried about it, during menopause anxieties can increase about everything, even the things we once thought little of."\n\nBut there are other factors at play, aside from anxiety.\n\n"Menopause affects the nervous system, potentially impacting reaction times, balance, and overall coordination," explains Kate Toby, health and wellness expert at Zego Car Insurance. "These physical changes can make women feel less in control and more vulnerable on the road."\n\nThere\'s also often an increased awareness of ageing and mortality.\n\n"This heightened awareness can contribute to a general sense of vulnerability and fear, including when driving," she continues.\n\nAnd having a sudden loss of confidence behind the wheel can also contribute.\n\n"Menopause can lead to a decline in self-confidence. Everyday activities, including driving, may feel more daunting, and the fear of making mistakes or having an accident can become more pronounced," XX adds.\n\nContinuously driving, even for short distances, helps maintain and build confidence. "Avoiding driving can worsen anxiety, so regular practice is essential," Toby explains.\n\nMindfulness and relaxation techniques\n\nPracticing mindfulness, deep breathing, and other relaxation techniques can help manage anxiety. "These methods can be particularly useful before and during driving," Toby explains.\n\nHealthy lifestyle choices\n\nToby suggests maintaining a balanced diet, exercising regularly, and getting adequate sleep can positively impact overall health and reduce anxiety levels.\n\nShare the journey\n\nHaving a confident driver in the passenger seat while you\'re driving can also help to ease discomfort. "They may help to calmly direct you to your destination, offer encouragement whilst navigating traffic and roundabouts, or even just be a comforting ear to vent to," explains an expert from Nationwide Vehicle Contracts.\n\nProfessional support\n\nSeeking support from a therapist or counsellor can provide strategies to manage anxiety. "Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), in particular, can be effective in addressing specific fears related to driving," Toby adds.\n\nDriving courses\n\nEnrolling in a refresher driving course can help regain confidence and improve driving skills. "These courses offer practical advice and provide a safe environment to practice driving," Toby says.\n\nOpen communication\n\nDiscussing fears and anxieties with family and friends can provide emotional support. "Sometimes, just talking about these concerns can alleviate some of the stress associated with driving," Toby explains.\n\n"By understanding these contributing factors and implementing practical strategies, women can regain their driving confidence and continue to navigate the roads safely and comfortably during menopause," she adds.\n\nMenopause: Read more', 'source': {'uri': 'uk.style.yahoo.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Yahoo!'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'marie_claire_dorking@uk.style.yahoo.com', 'name': 'Marie-Claire Dorking', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://s.yimg.com/ny/api/res/1.2/hn8BfTFM5F0zFL.nHs89Sw--/YXBwaWQ9aGlnaGxhbmRlcjt3PTEyMDA7aD04MDA-/https://s.yimg.com/os/creatr-uploaded-images/2024-07/3f8d7590-3f7a-11ef-bdd5-0300d1285320', 'eventUri': 'eng-9731435', 'sentiment': -0.2549019607843137, 'wgt': 458739209, 'relevance': 60}
{'uri': '8226377606', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '11:33:17', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T11:33:17Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T11:32:48Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.47843137383461, 'url': 'https://ftw.usatoday.com/2024/07/angel-reese-caitlin-clark-wnba-rookie-of-the-year-advanced-stats', 'title': 'Angel Reese or Caitlin Clark for WNBA Rookie of the Year? Here is what the advanced stats teach us.', 'body': 'Led by former collegiate rivals Angel Reese and Caitlin Clark, this is a particularly special group of rookies in the WNBA.\n\nAs we approach the upcoming WNBA All-Star Game, where the two will play alongside one another, we have some time to sit back and reflect on what these two have accomplished at this point in their professional careers.\n\nNot only have the players helped grow the game in incredible ways with countless new fans from around the world, but they have both impressed on the court as well. They are both worth turning on the TV whenever they have games scheduled.\n\nClark (-100) is currently the heavy favorite to win the 2024 WNBA Rookie of the Year, per BetMGM. Her heavy implied probability suggests that it is unlikely anyone else gets the award.\n\nBut is that a disservice to Reese, an underdog (+500) whose implied probability of 20.0 percent suggests she is still a legitimate candidate?\n\nThe Rookie of the Year campaigns for Clark and Reese\n\nWhile there is a lot of intrigue around the WNBA\'s Rookie of the Year this season, many fans and media members may hold some form of biases based on preconceived notions of Reese and Clark.\n\nSo we wanted to bring some numbers into the mix using advanced stats known as catch-all or all-in-one metrics. These are basically a single number that attempts to evaluate, on various scales, the success of a basketball player on a court. It\'s like the film (and book!) Moneyball but for the hardwood.\n\nThe WNBA\'s Rookie of the Year isn\'t just based on stats, of course, or the league would have the decision made by a machine. Evaluators have several factors to consider, but the numbers can and should play a role.\n\nBased on the advanced analytics made evaluable to us, similar to what we have done in the NBA, we created a bit of a rudimentary model that could help make a determination.\n\nI\'ve written about these stats in the NBA and they\'re very useful and worth citing during player evaluations. But they do have shortcomings worth noting. For example, one particularly relevant note is that post players tend to perform better than high-usage guards due to efficiency.\n\nWe can look back at these scores later in the season to track progress.\n\nRELATED: Caitlin Clark and Angel Reese are neck and neck for Rookie of The Year\n\nThe results\n\nUsing the metrics that are publicly available, here is how the top rookies performed across each measurement. It is enjoyable and informative to look at just to compare overall productivity. We included the top performers, but there are other notable rookies who could appear on these leaderboards later.\n\nBold indicates that they lead all first-year players in that stat:\n\nNAME Estimated Contributions Estmated Win Probability Added Player Efficiency Rating Player Impact Estimate RAM RAPTOR Win Shares Angel Reese 0.1 0.5 19.2 13.3 7.7 2.04 2.6 Caitlin Clark -1.2 0.1 17.1 12.4 8.2 -0.28 1.3 Leonie Fiebich 0.9 0.3 10.3 5.9 4.9 -0.41 1.1 Aaliyah Edwards -1.9 0.4 14.1 10.1 6.0 -2.35 1.1 Rickea Jackson -2.1 0.7 11.6 7.2 6.0 -4.65 0.4 Kamilla Cardoso -1.5 -0.1 14.1 8.8 5.8 -3.88 0.9\n\nHowever, because not all statistics are created equally, we included a few more steps.\n\nWe also adjusted for playing time to avoid small size concerns and later standardized each metric using something called a Z-Score. The numbers below suggest how much better than average each player is at each metric relative to the entire WNBA.\n\nFor example, Reese\'s Z-Score for PER (Player Efficiency Rating) is 1.56 right now. That means when adjusted for playing time, her PER is currently more than 1.5 standard deviations above the mode of the average WNBA player for this season.\n\nHer average Z-Score across all these metrics is 1.04, the leader among all rookies. Here is the basic math:\n\nNAME AVERAGE EC eWPA PER PIE RAM RAPTOR WS Angel Reese 1.04 0.02 0.28 1.56 1.60 1.29 0.94 1.58 Caitlin Clark 0.57 -1.04 -0.35 1.52 1.69 1.74 -0.15 0.58 Leonie Fiebich -0.14 0.34 -0.29 -0.24 -0.35 -0.23 -0.13 -0.11 Aaliyah Edwards -0.20 -0.95 -0.18 0.15 0.23 0.06 -0.71 -0.07 Rickea Jackson -0.34 -1.31 0.36 0.21 0.11 0.37 -1.76 -0.40 Kamilla Cardoso -0.37 -0.71 -0.60 0.06 -0.01 -0.06 -1.08 -0.21\n\nAll statistics are accurate as of July 12, 2024.\n\nWhat did we learn?\n\nAs of right now, this study says Reese is clearly the top rookie this season. She was also the only first-year WNBA player who performed better than average across every advanced metric.\n\nIn fact, her overall score would currently make her one of the top-25 most positively impactful players in the WNBA so far season. While our methods were very different than what was recently used by Neil Paine for ESPN, the results were fairly similar.\n\nThis likely suggests that if you look solely at trusted advanced analytics for this decision, Reese is the pick. But as we know, for many, the decision will include more factors than that.\n\nThere is still plenty of time left in the season for players to make their case.\n\nRELATED: Angel Reese has taken over the WNBA Rookie of the Year race\n\nMore about the methodology\n\nThis used a methodology suggested by Owen Phillips, who now works in the front office for the New York Knicks. But the idea was simple: Find all of the advanced metrics you like and put them on a spreadsheet.\n\nThis next part is going to sound like a lot math, but it\'s actually fairly simple if you know how to Microsoft Excel or Google Sheets.\n\nHowever, if all of this begins to sound like a whole lot of numbers, worry not. Instead, just look at the "score" for a clean metric that summarizes the overall productivity of a player.\n\nBased on a tip from another individual who works in a front office for an NBA team, we adjusted for playing time by multiplying their impact contribution on each metric by the percentage of possible minutes they have played for their team so far this season.\n\nWe standardized each score by finding the Z-score for each player in each metric. The Z-score measures how many standard deviations from the mean for each data point. If a Z-score is 0, that means the player is exactly league average.\n\nAs the last step, we took the average Z-score that a player had across each metric.\n\nMore details about the metrics Estimated Contributions | Positive Residual | MORE INFO Expected Wins Probability Added (eWPA) | inpredictable | MORE INFO Player Efficiency Rating (PER) | HerHoopStats | MORE INFO Player Impact Estimate (PIE) | WNBA.com | MORE INFO RAPTOR (Estimated) | Neil\'s Substack | MORE INFO RAM | Cerebro Sports | MORE INFO Win Shares (WS) | HerHoopStats | MORE INFO Cierra Burdick: 5 facts about the veteran for the USA 3x3 women\'s basketball team at the Olympics Caitlin Clark gave a young Fever fan the game shoes off her feet after victory against Lynx Caitlin Clark gave a delightfully droll response to question on getting closer to rookie assists record in Minneapolis Caitlin Clark got the traveling Fever fans to their feet in Minnesota right before massive win Caitlin Clark crossed up Lynx\'s Bridget Carleton on the way to this ankle-breaking layup', 'source': {'uri': 'ftw.usatoday.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'For The Win'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'bryan_kalbrosky@ftw.usatoday.com', 'name': 'Bryan Kalbrosky', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://ftw.usatoday.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/90/2024/07/2157848123-e1720799593978.jpg?w=640', 'eventUri': 'eng-9727976', 'sentiment': 0.4274509803921569, 'wgt': 458739197, 'relevance': 26}

'sim': 0.8901960849761963, 'url': 'https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13635615/Yandex-split-finalized-Russian-assets-sold-5-4-bln-deal.html', 'title': 'Yandex split finalized as Russian assets sold in $5.4 bln deal', 'body': 'Yandex NV completes divestment of Russian assets\n\n*\n\nCash and shares deal valued at around $5.4 bln\n\n*\n\nRetained businesses to come under new Nebius Group\n\n*\n\nYandex co-founder Volozh to become Nebius CEO, says source\n\n(Adds bullets, detail in paragraphs 7-8, 10-13, 16-18)\n\nBy Alexander Marrow\n\nJuly 15 (Reuters) - A deal to split the assets of Russian technology company Yandex was finalized on Monday, with a Russian consortium of investors buying the bulk of Yandex\'s businesses in a cash and shares deal worth around $5.4 billion.\n\nThe split marks the end of foreign ownership in Yandex, often dubbed "Russia\'s Google," potentially tightening the Kremlin\'s control of the internet space in Russia, while also finalizing the largest corporate exit from Russia since Moscow invaded Ukraine over two years ago.\n\nYandex\'s Dutch parent company Yandex NV (YNV) said it had sold its remaining minority 28% stake as part of the deal\'s second closing, receiving a total of $2.8 billion in cash and 162.5 million YNV class A shares.\n\n"With the second closing, YNV has received the agreed upon purchase price and now fully disposed of its remaining interest in the Russian businesses," YNV said.\n\nYandex blazed a trail for Russian technology after setting up in the late 1990s dotcom boom and listing on Nasdaq, becoming a dominant force in search and advertising, ride-hailing, e-commerce and other online services.\n\nFour AI-focused businesses in cloud, data labeling, self-driving cars and education technology are being retained by YNV and will be developed under the Nebius Group name, YNV said.\n\nYandex in Russia said YNV would stop using Yandex brands by July 31.\n\nVOLOZH RETURNS\n\nThe deal is the result of around two years of negotiations and faced various setbacks and hurdles, from Kremlin demands for a discount of at least 50% on foreign asset sales to nationalization risk and an anti-war outburst from Yandex co-founder Arkady Volozh.\n\nAfter EU sanctions on Volozh were lifted in March, he is now set to return as CEO of Nebius and lead the renamed group, now free from the shackles of its Russia ties, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters.\n\nYNV Chairman John Boynton thanked the company\'s 1,300 employees, paying particular tribute to Vadim Marchuk, who led the deal team.\n\n"All connections with Russia have now been severed," he said.\n\nWith the deal done, attention may turn to the future of YNV\'s Nasdaq listing, where many Western shareholders are stuck holding stakes in which trading has long been suspended.\n\n"The Class A shares received as consideration will be held in treasury, pending use under our equity incentive plans and for further financing purposes," YNV said.\n\nFollowing the deal\'s closing, YNV said the aggregate number of Class A and Class B ordinary shares outstanding was 199 million.\n\nTrading in Yandex in Russia under the new YDEX ticker will start on July 24.\n\nThe Russian buyers said on Monday that all settlements for a share exchange, converting Moscow-listed shares in Yandex NV to the new Russian entity, MKPAO Yandex, had been completed.\n\nBut the new owners face the headache of a lawsuit filed by around 100 shareholders, accusing the consortium\'s trustee, Solid Management, of imposing discriminatory terms in the exchange of shares. (Reporting by Alexander Marrow, Editing by Louise Heavens and David Evans)', 'source': {'uri': 'dailymail.co.uk', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Daily Mail Online'}, 'authors': [], 'image': None, 'eventUri': 'eng-9733565', 'sentiment': 0.2941176470588236, 'wgt': 458739169, 'relevance': 76}

{'uri': '2024-07-422362012', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '11:29:49', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T11:29:49Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T09:57:30Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.sussexexpress.co.uk/sport/other-sport/an-extraordinary-weekend-at-2024-festival-of-speed-4702702', 'title': 'An extraordinary weekend at 2024 Festival of Speed', 'body': 'The Festival of Speed presented by Mastercard celebrated another incredible weekend, bringing together legendary drivers, riders and showcasing an outstanding collection of cars and motorcycles, with premieres and debuts around every corner.\n\nFormula 1Renowned as the place to see some of the most legendary drivers and riders in motorsport, the 2024 Festival of Speed served as no exception, welcoming both current and former Formula 1 teams, drivers and cars.\n\nCelebrating its 20th anniversary and marking Goodwood\'s biggest celebration of a Formula 1 team to date, Oracle Red Bull Racing brought together an incredible lineup of drivers from across the team\'s history.\n\nMaking his Festival of Speed debut at the event this year, the Festival of Speed was delighted to welcome current and three-time Formula 1 World Champion Max Verstappen who took to the Hill on Sunday in the RB16B in which he claimed his first world title in 2021.\n\nJoined by teammate Sergio Pérez and Team Principal and CEO Christian Horner, as well as former Red Bull drivers David Coulthard, Christian Klien, Daniel Ricciardo and Mark Webber, the hugely successful Formula 1 team took to the Goodwood balcony on Sunday giving fans the opportunity to salute the seven drivers who between them, hold a phenomenal 97 Formula 1 race wins.\n\nAlongside the celebrations for Oracle Red Bull Racing, the event hosted five additional current Formula 1 teams: BWT Alpine F1 Team, Scuderia Ferrari HP, McLaren Formula 1 Team, Mercedes-AMG PETRONAS Formula One Team and Williams Racing. Fans had the rare opportunity to see legendary cars from across the decades and meet the teams and drivers, with crowds flocking to see Alex Albon, Fernando Alonso, Oliver Bearman, Jack Doohan, Logan Sargeant, Yuki Tsunoda, Frederik Vesti, Sophie Flörsch, Kush Maini and James Vowles across the weekend.\n\nBoth Oracle Red Bull Racing and Williams Racing brought their respective F1 Academy drivers, Hamda Al Qubaisi and Lia Block, with the latter driving a Formula 1 car for the first time in public on the Hill.\n\nMotorsport icons and legends Joining us on two wheels, Michael Dunlop - the most successful rider in the history of the Isle of Man TT with 29 victories - rode his 2024 IOM TT Superstock bike alongside 23-time winner and lap record-holder John McGuinness and 14-time winner and Mountain Course lap record-holder Peter Hickman. Dunlop also celebrated his recent triumph at the Isle of Man TT with a moment on the balcony of Goodwood House on Saturday.\n\nSeven-time NASCAR Cup Series Champion Richard Petty attended across the weekend, as the Petty family celebrated 75 years of their involvement with motorsport. Returning to the Festival of Speed, Petty was joined by his famous 1970 Plymouth Superbird, driven by son Kyle, as Goodwood celebrated "The King" and his extraordinary career.\n\nOther drivers, riders and motorsport legends who joined us over the weekend included, the Iron Dames Julie Amblard, Karen Gaillard, Célia Martin and Sarah Rumeau, Giacomo Agostini, Karun Chandhok, Mick Doohan, Elfyn Evans, Damon Hill, Jacky Ickx, Sebastian Ogier, Emanuele Pirro, the championship-winning father-son duo of Kenny Roberts Senior and Junior, Kalle Rovenperä, Carlos Sainz Senior and and Kevin Schwantz.\n\nCentral FeatureMG celebrated its centenary at the Festival of Speed this year, headlining the event with the monumental Central Feature on the lawn outside Goodwood House and a daily extravaganza. Gerry Judah\'s highly-anticipated sculpture featured the Cyberster EV roadster and MGB. The two cars from MG\'s past and present, perfectly illustrated this year\'s \'Horseless to Hybrid\' theme which recognised the advances in technology and propulsion that have shaped the automotive industry over the last 130 years.\n\nWorld-exclusives, debuts and revealsVisitors were some of the first to witness global marques and manufacturers unveiling their latest projects at the Festival of Speed, including debuts of the new Porsche 911, BMW M5, BMW XM Label Red, BYD SEAL U DM-I, Defender OCTA, All-Electric Ford Capri, Honda Civic Type R, Jaecoo J7, Maserati M20, Pagani Epitome, Pagani Imola Roadster, RB17 and the Yangwang U8, among many others.\n\nA step into the futureLocated at the heart of the event and exhibiting some of the very latest technology, Future Lab presented by Randox showcased \'Technology for a Better World\', with exhibitors grouped into four sub-themes: \'Protecting the Planet\', \'Robots to the Rescue\', \'Future of Flight\' and \'Our World in Pixels\'. The interactive hub welcomed entrepreneurs and innovators, including Dronamics, Drone City, Performit Live, sees.ai, and Shadow Robot who have collaborated with Google DeepMind on their latest robotic hand.\n\nThe Indy Autonomous Challenge (IAC) returned to the Festival of Speed, following their debut in 2023, and took to the Hill across the weekend with the AV-24, the world\'s first fully-autonomous racecar piloted by software from the PoliMOVE-MSU team. On Thursday, Durham University\'s Solar Car set the first time for a solar car on the Goodwood Hill.\n\nOver at Electric Avenue - the home of electric mobility at the Festival of Speed - the exhibition focused on four zones displaying urban cars, SUV and family cars, performance sports cars and future cars, featuring the likes of the BMW i5 Touring, Honda e:Ny1, Hyundai IONIQ 5 N, Maserati GranCabrio Folgore and the Polestar 4.\n\nCartier classicsThe Cartier Style et Luxe concours d\'elegance welcomed some of the most intriguing and beautiful vehicles at the event, celebrating incredible automotive design, exquisite restoration and marked a number of significant anniversaries in the motoring world. Featuring some of the most varied and fascinating classes ever seen at the Festival of Speed, \'Best in Show\' was taken by the 1937 Bugatti Type 57S Corsica, as judged by Thomas Brodie-Sangster, David Gandy, Kenya Hunt, Mai Ikuzawa, Flavio Manzoni, Marek Reichman, Micheal Ward and Adrian van Hooydonk.\n\nBonhams|Cars AuctionA collection of spectacular and unique vehicles went under the hammer at the Bonhams|Cars Auction on Friday afternoon. Highlights included the 1928 Mercedes-Benz 36/220 S-Type Four-Seated Sports Tourer which sold for £2,871,000, the 1955 Mercedes-Benz 300 SL \'Gullwing\' Coupé which sold for £1,135,000 and the 1962 Mercedes-Benz 300 SL Roadster which sold for £1,045,400. The sale achieved a total of £11,035,691 - the highest total for a Bonhams|Cars\' UK sale to date in 2024.\n\nForest Rally StageOver at the top of the event and winding its way through the trees of the Goodwood Estate, the Forest Rally Stage saw current and former rally drivers going head-to-head. Among those competing and highlighting contemporary cars of the past decade, Aoife Raftery - the first female driver in the Motorsport Ireland Rally Academy - took to the course in the 2014 Peugeot 208 T16 R5, whilst the Iron Dames brought their 2024 Ford Fiesta Rally2.\n\nOther cars on the stage included the 2018 Ford Fiesta R5 driven by Steve Chamberlain and the 2021 version of the Proton IRIZ R5, which previously won on the Forest Rally Stage back in 2017. Also on the stage were current WRC drivers Elfyn Evans and Dani Sordo in their Toyota Yaris Rally1 Hybrid and Hyundai i20N WRC respectively.\n\nSurtees Pavilion with Ollie DabbousProviding uninterrupted views of the Goodwood hillclimb, the Festival of Speed\'s new Surtees Pavilion worked with Co-Founder and Executive Chef of Michelin-starred restaurant HIDE, Ollie Dabbous, to provide a modern twist on classic dining. The unique dining experience showcased the very best produce from the Goodwood Estate and local area.\n\nEvent charityThis year\'s Festival of Speed supported Two Wheels for Life, a charity dedicated to transforming healthcare across Africa using the power of motorcycles. Two Wheels for Life were on site across the weekend with volunteers sharing details of the incredible work they do, and some of the vehicles used for the delivery of healthcare on display.\n\nThe 2025 eventThe 2025 Festival of Speed presented by Mastercard will take place Thursday 10 - Sunday 13 July. 2024 ticket buyers, Members and Fellows can purchase tickets for the 2025 event from 10:00hrs on Monday 15 July. Tickets will go on sale to the public later in the year. Sign up for ticket alerts here.\n\nCatch up on the actionFor those who couldn\'t make this year\'s event, catch up on all the action on ITV1 on Monday, July 22 at 22.45 and Tuesday, July 23 at 23.00.\n\nMotorsport returns to Goodwood later in the year with the Goodwood Revival on Friday to Sunday, September 6 to 8.', 'source': {'uri': 'sussexexpress.co.uk', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'SussexWorld'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://www.sussexexpress.co.uk/webimg/b25lY21zOjgwZDI1NDdlLWZkMzgtNDg1OC1hY2E4LWQzZTQ0MzM0MWQxYjo4NmNmYzk1OS03MGNhLTQ2OGYtYTg2OC0xNWM4OWM2OGQzN2I=.jpg?width=640&auto=webp&quality=75&crop=3:2,smart&trim=', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.584313725490196, 'wgt': 458738989, 'relevance': 33}

'sim': 0.843137264251709, 'url': 'https://www.channelnewsasia.com/business/yandex-split-finalised-russian-assets-sold-54-billion-deal-4480791', 'title': 'Yandex split finalised as Russian assets sold in $5.4 billion deal', 'body': ':A deal to split the assets of Russian technology company Yandex was finalised on Monday, with a Russian consortium of investors buying the bulk of Yandex\'s businesses in a cash and shares deal worth around $5.4 billion.\n\nThe split marks the end of foreign ownership in Yandex, often dubbed "Russia\'s Google", potentially tightening the Kremlin\'s control of the internet space in Russia, while also finalising the largest corporate exit from Russia since Moscow invaded Ukraine over two years ago.\n\nYandex\'s Dutch parent company Yandex NV (YNV) said it had sold its remaining minority 28 per cent stake as part of the deal\'s second closing, receiving a total of $2.8 billion in cash and 162.5 million YNV class A shares.\n\n"With the second closing, YNV has received the agreed upon purchase price and now fully disposed of its remaining interest in the Russian businesses," YNV said.\n\nYandex blazed a trail for Russian technology after setting up in the late 1990s dotcom boom and listing on Nasdaq, becoming a dominant force in search and advertising, ride-hailing, e-commerce and other online services.\n\nFour AI-focused businesses in cloud, data labelling, self-driving cars and education technology are being retained by YNV and will be developed under the Nebius Group name, YNV said.\n\nYandex in Russia said YNV would stop using Yandex brands by July 31.\n\nVOLOZH RETURNS\n\nThe deal is the result of around two years of negotiations and faced various setbacks and hurdles, from Kremlin demands for a discount of at least 50 per cent on foreign asset sales to nationalisation risk and an anti-war outburst from Yandex co-founder Arkady Volozh.\n\nAfter EU sanctions on Volozh were lifted in March, he is now set to return as CEO of Nebius and lead the renamed group, now free from the shackles of its Russia ties, a person familiar with the matter told Reuters.\n\nYNV Chairman John Boynton thanked the company\'s 1,300 employees, paying particular tribute to Vadim Marchuk, who led the deal team.\n\n"All connections with Russia have now been severed," he said.\n\nWith the deal done, attention may turn to the future of YNV\'s Nasdaq listing, where many Western shareholders are stuck holding stakes in which trading has long been suspended.\n\n"The Class A shares received as consideration will be held in treasury, pending use under our equity incentive plans and for further financing purposes," YNV said.\n\nFollowing the deal\'s closing, YNV said the aggregate number of Class A and Class B ordinary shares outstanding was 199 million.\n\nTrading in Yandex in Russia under the new YDEX ticker will start on July 24.\n\nThe Russian buyers said on Monday that all settlements for a share exchange, converting Moscow-listed shares in Yandex NV to the new Russian entity, MKPAO Yandex, had been completed.\n\nBut the new owners face the headache of a lawsuit filed by around 100 shareholders, accusing the consortium\'s trustee, Solid Management, of imposing discriminatory terms in the exchange of shares.', 'source': {'uri': 'channelnewsasia.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'CNA'}, 'authors': [], {'uri': '8226279855', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '10:30:25', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T10:30:25Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T10:29:23Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://buffalonews.com/opinion/my-view-the-siren-fanfare-of-the-olympic-games-will-soon-be-calling-us/article_7fd18826-4060-11ef-882e-1f8c0efd3f0a.html', 'title': 'My View:  The siren fanfare of the Olympic Games will soon be calling us', 'body': 'Has it really been four years since the last Olympics? Actually, no: the 2020 Games were held in 2021 due to the pandemic (extra points if you remember where). The 2024 Olympics will be upon us shortly. These events have captivated me since I was young.\n\nI remember Bob Beamon\'s long jump record, which we measured off in my sixth-grade classroom. It was an incredible feat that wasn\'t equaled for another 50-some years. In those same Mexico City Games I also remember the raised fists of Tommie Smith and John Carlos on the medal stand, denoting black power and unity, a controversy representing the intersection of athletics and political protest which I\'m sure will be echoed this year.\n\nI prefer to focus on the athletics, especially since many of the competitors participate in sports that get little, if any, recognition. Trial competitions have been ongoing, with swimming, track and field, and gymnastics being televised. My son was a competitive swimmer and I will testify to long, twice daily practices for years, before and after school and on weekends. It\'s what helped me realize how much time and effort goes into these endeavors.\n\nPeople are also reading... Watch: Video shows Buffalo man killed by police sped off with officer clinging to car Man shot dead by Buffalo police is brother of slain 12-year-old At least four tornadoes, two packing 110 mph winds, hit Western New York, weather service reports Alan Pergament: \'Beatles\' host JP leaves WECK after disagreement with station owner Buddy Shula \'Quite an undertaking\': Cleanup starts after Beryl blows through Western New York Pregnant in her sophomore year, Bennett High School graduate finds self-worth - with plenty of help Pit bull attack severs woman\'s arm the day before dog was to be put down Ryan McLeod\'s \'whirlwind\' trade has new Sabres center \'excited\' to get to Buffalo \'The numbers are just astronomical:\' Why developers are putting more projects on hold State agency, waterside attraction leaders losing patience with stalled project at Canalside Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Family recipes are the heart of new Marta\'s Market in East Aurora Tops worker in Cheektowaga helps save customer who had medical emergency in parking lot Do the Sabres need a goal-scorer after landing Ryan McLeod to center the third line? Authorities hunt for clues, but motive of man who tried to assassinate Donald Trump remains elusive\n\nI look forward to our swim champions facing the Australians, the other traditional powerhouses. The Aussies won\'t have Rowdy Gaines, a former medalist turned broadcaster, who is the Dick Vitale of competitive swimming. He\'ll cover the races and if enthusiasm counted, we would sweep the events.\n\nTrack and field trials feature athletes who will challenge in marquee events such as the 100 and 200 meter "fastest in the world" races, and stand an excellent chance at the gold medal, as do our shot-put competitors.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | Stitcher | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nUnfortunately, even the best athletes can literally fall short, as happened in a distance race where the favorite veered into another runner and fell. Despite being the gold medal favorite, she won\'t be competing in the Paris race.\n\nLastly, I watch the gymnastics. While it features graceful tumbling events, it\'s a brutal sport for injuries. I tried the balance beam in high school and twisted an ankle falling off after a couple steps.\n\nSome of our most well-known athletes, particularly from the women\'s team, compete in solo and team events. This year we\'ll see Simone Biles again, who made the decision to withdraw in 2021 after suffering disorientation in the air during the vault event. I hope she does well this time, and never understood the criticism she endured after placing her mental health first.\n\nThen there are the sports I think of as more professional endeavors- basketball, golf, tennis, etc. At least now our professional athletes can compete, not amateurs facing professionals masquerading as amateurs on the Soviet or East German teams. I\'ll never forget the controversial 1972 basketball final, where questionable refereeing led to decisions that handed the gold medal to the Soviets. The second-place silver medals are still in a vault, as the American team refused them and did not attend the medal ceremony.\n\nAs for so many other sports - rhythm gymnastics, synchronized swim, dressage, archery, shooting, trampoline, sailing, badminton, and others - some heretofore unknowns will have their moment in the sun, as they stand on the medal platform and hear their country\'s national anthem. We\'ll never know their names, but they\'ll always be winners.\n\nI plan to be ensconced on my couch, competing for the gold in prolonged butt-planting, as soon as the booming opening drums of the Olympic theme are heard.\n\n0 Comments Catch the latest in Opinion\n\nGet opinion pieces, letters and editorials sent directly to your inbox weekly!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'buffalonews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Buffalo News'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/buffalonews.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/7/fd/7fd18826-4060-11ef-882e-1f8c0efd3f0a/66914b3ef0f64.preview.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.08235294117647052, 'wgt': 458735425, 'relevance': 26}

But don\'t judge a book by its cover. In the middle is what looks like an "X" made of black pavers. Those who stand in the middle have been known to experience a strange auditory anomaly, like an echo that can only be heard if you\'re standing on the "X."\n\nHere\'s what some Google reviewers have experienced:\n\nSummer fun: From water parks to fun-filled festivals, here are Georgia\'s best summer things-to-do\n\nAccording to a previous Savannah Morning News story, it\'s unclear what is causing this phenomenon. But don\'t judge a book by its cover. In the middle is what looks like an "X" made of black pavers. Those who stand in the middle have been known to experience a strange auditory anomaly, like an echo that can only be heard if you\'re standing on the "X."\n\nHere\'s what some Google reviewers have experienced:\n\nSummer fun:From water parks to fun-filled festivals, here are Georgia\'s best summer things-to-do\n\nNeed a break? {'uri': '8226258605', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '10:16:21', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T10:16:21Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T10:15:16Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7686274647712708, 'url': 'https://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/Articles/2024/07/15/motorsports', 'title': "NASCAR's sponsorship sales team going through big changes", 'body': 'NASCAR is looking to extend the deals of premier partners Geico and Xfinity.getty images\n\nThese are busy times for NASCAR Holdings when it comes to corporate sponsorship -- reshuffling its sales team, bringing in a brand consultant and working to renew or land several important deals.\n\nWhile NASCAR\'s sales team has had success since the pandemic, major sponsorships with blue-chip companies new to the sport have been harder to come by during that time, and competition has increased fiercely. NASCAR is also preparing for a new era next year with the start of a new media rights cycle, all factors that appear to be contributing to NASCAR\'s latest moves.\n\nAfter 30 years of service to NASCAR and International Speedway Corp., NASCAR\'s executive vice president and chief revenue officer, Daryl Wolfe, told colleagues this month he will retire after the 2024 season. NASCAR also recently let go multiple salespeople under Wolfe and, in a move that came several months ago, quietly hired Denver-based brand consultancy Monigle to change how the company goes to the market overall, including in the sponsorship space.\n\nXfinity and Geico, two of NASCAR\'s four premier partners, are said to be in renewal discussions, while a third, Coca-Cola, has been making changes to its deal. NASCAR is looking for a fifth premier partner, soures said, in what would be the first new brand to come in at that level since the system debuted in 2020. Moreover, it\'s looking to fill smaller deals in a host of open categories, including technology.\n\nTaken together, there\'s a lot going on for NASCAR, and top brass appear determined to get more aggressive in driving revenue.\n\n"If, as a league, they don\'t evolve and grow with the way the marketplace is going, then they\'re going to fall behind," said Kami Taylor, executive vice president of experiential at Octagon, which works with several brands in NASCAR. "However, I think the overall health of NASCAR is strong and they still provide robust sponsorship opportunities for brands looking to grow regionally or domestically."\n\nNASCAR officials declined to comment.\n\nSponsorship has been a part of the 76-year-old sport for decades to defray the cost of running a race team and the league. Over time, that formula -- combined with the massive fan base that NASCAR developed -- helped turn NASCAR into a marketing and licensing powerhouse. But following the 2008 financial crisis, sponsorship started to dry up relative to its peak.\n\nJust as NASCAR was switching to its new premier partner system in 2020, Formula 1 grew its popularity immensely through the opportunely timed Netflix series "Drive to Survive," which got many Americans into the sport while they were stuck at home during pandemic lockdowns. Corporate partners quickly followed, and 2021 and 2022 were filled with announcements from brands based in the U.S. getting into F1 for the first time or renewing. In 2024, roughly 75% of all technology-related sponsors in F1 -- including team sponsors -- are American companies, according to Spomotion Analytics, with more than 40 from the U.S. compared to just six from Europe. That includes Amazon, Google, Microsoft, American Express, Oracle, Visa, Dell Technologies, Hewlett Packard, Cash App and Meta\'s WhatsApp messaging platform.\n\nIn 2023, NASCAR said it added seven official sponsors, and it\'s added two more this year. Brands added since 2023 include FanDuel, Powerball, Hard Rock Bet, ABB, Cabo Wabo tequila, RTIC coolers, Leidos, Ally Financial and Liquid Death.\n\nWhen NASCAR moved to the premier partner system for its top Cup Series, it asked around $15 million annually over three- to five-year terms for those positions, sources said at the time, but it was unclear how much incremental revenue NASCAR saw because the four brands that signed on were already official partners. On top of Xfinity, Geico and Coke, the fourth premier partner is Anheuser-Busch\'s Busch Light brand.\n\nNASCAR has looked into landing a fifth premier partner and doing so would ensure that the racing property would still have at least four if one of the original partners left.\n\nXfinity became title sponsor of NASCAR\'s second-level series in 2015 as part of a corporate synergy strategy from Comcast, whose NBC Sports began broadcasting NASCAR races that year. Matt Lederer, Comcast\'s vice president of branded partnerships and activation, has said Xfinity is in renewal talks with NASCAR. But the company wants to shake up the terms of its agreement, be more flexible with its spending and possibly redirect some of its league-level spending to other parts of the NASCAR industry, such as its team relationship with 23XI Racing.\n\nXfinity Mobile is a key product for Comcast and figures to be an important part of the next deal. Xfinity currently spends more than $10 million in the sport annually, all told, according to sources. The major question is whether Comcast will continue being both a premier partner of NASCAR and title sponsor of the Xfinity Series. Sources say it\'s possible Xfinity could do a short-term renewal as title sponsor before shifting its relationship in the coming years to just being a premier partner.\n\nGeico also is said to be in renewal discussions, and industry executives have waffled all year on whether the Berkshire Hathaway-owned insurer will renew. The company has had a multitude of executive and agency changes in recent years, which often equals change in sports marketing deals.\n\nMeanwhile, Coke\'s deal is expected to continue next year, but the company has been making changes to its asset mix, sources say. Some NASCAR-owned tracks have started selling their soda rights to other brands -- such as Kansas Speedway having 7UP sponsorship at its race this year -- which shows how Coca-Cola has changed some of its asset mix.\n\nThe new structure of NASCAR\'s sales team and whether NASCAR will hire a new CRO to directly replace Wolfe was unclear. Taylor, the Octagon executive, recommended that NASCAR continue to partner with teams on sponsorship packages to make deals "one larger package instead of just disparate pieces from an asset perspective." The sport has improved its cool factor since the pandemic, and Taylor noted that should help the company find new sponsors.\n\n"That does help, because now they have got a different product than they had before to go out and sell with," Taylor said.', 'source': {'uri': 'sportsbusinessjournal.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'sportsbusinessjournal.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'adam_stern@sportsbusinessjournal.com', 'name': 'Adam Stern', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://www.sportsbusinessjournal.com/-/media/Images/Journal/2024/07/15/pg-08-NASCAR-Matchbox-20-Rob-Thomas-at-Coca-Cola-600_Getty.ashx', 'eventUri': 'eng-9737592', 'sentiment': 0.1294117647058823, 'wgt': 458734581, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8226246696', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '10:08:29', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T10:08:29Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T10:08:04Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8549019694328308, 'url': 'https://www.profit.ro/insider/companii/exclusiv-ultima-ora-foto-video-romania-semnat-memorandum-gigantul-google-planuri-anterioare-centru-date-gigantul-american-ar-investi-peste-2-miliarde-dolari-vrea-centru-regional-rival-polonia-21668958', 'title': 'EXCLUSIV ULTIMA ORĂ FOTO&VIDEO România a semnat un memorandum cu gigantul Google. Se vrea centru regional, rival cu Polonia', 'body': 'România a semnat un memorandum de colaborare cu gigantul american Google, conform informațiilor Profit.ro.\n\nActul a fost semnat, cu ministerul român de resort, după o discuție între premierul Ciolacu și Thomas Kurian, director executiv al Google Cloud, conform informațiilor Profit.ro.\n\n"Este un memorandum de colaborare pe cloud, securitate cibernetică și alte servicii digitale. Este un document de angajament", au transmis sursele pentru Profit.ro.\n\nUPDATE 12,50 Guvernul României a confirmat informația și a transmis că memorandumul de înțelegere între Guvernul României și Google a fost semnat în contextul proiectelor pe care țara noastră le va dezvolta în infrastructura digitală, inovare și cercetare. Memorandumul de înțelegere a fost semnat, din partea Guvernului, de ministrul Cercetării, Inovării și Digitalizării, Bogdan Ivan.\n\n"A fost o onoare să mă întâlnesc cu Marcel Ciolacu, premierul României, și cu ministrul digitalizării, Bogdan Ivan, pentru a discuta despre accelerarea transformării digitale pentru serviciile publice din România și oportunitățile de implementare a inteligenței artificiale. Google Cloud este dedicat să contribuie la creșterea adoptării tehnologiilor cloud și la facilitarea serviciilor publice digitale inovatoare, în conformitate cu obiectivele României de transformare digitală și cu țintele Deceniului Digital al Europei pentru 2030", a declarat Thomas Kurian, CEO al Google Cloud, potrivit Executivului.\n\nReprezentanții Google și-au reafirmat, de asemenea, sprijinul pentru a contribui la creșterea rezilienței cibernetice a structurilor guvernamentale prin schimbul de bune practici, consolidarea competențelor digitale de bază și avansate și adoptarea tehnologiilor de cloud computing.\n\nAceastă colaborare vizează utilizarea tehnologiilor moderne precum Inteligența Artificială, îmbunătățirea eficienței operaționale, îmbunătățirea experiențelor cetățenilor, sporirea securității digitale a Guvernului și promovarea inovației în sectorul public.\n\n"Avem proiecte ambițioase de reformă a administrației publice, care implică utilizarea tehnologiilor moderne precum Inteligența Artificială, îmbunătățirea eficienței operaționale, creșterea securității digitale, promovarea inovației în sectorul public și adoptarea cloud-ului. Avansăm în ceea ce privește transformarea digitală a serviciilor publice, suntem în linie dreaptă cu modernizarea sistemului fiscal pentru detectarea fraudelor și creșterea colectării, iar fiecare zi ne arată cât este de importantă creșterea rezilienței cibernetice. De asemenea, ne-am asumat operaționalizarea cloud-ului guvernamental. Expertiza și contribuția Google sunt esențiale pentru a pune în practică servicii publice performante și sigure pentru români", a afirmat premierul Marcel Ciolacu.\n\nPrim-ministrul a subliniat că România este o piață atractivă pentru investitorii din domeniul tehnologiei informațiilor, atât prin oportunitatea proiectelor majore în centre de date și servicii de cloud, cât și datorită specialiștilor cu înaltă formare profesională și a legislației avansate.\n\n"Inteligența artificială și celelalte tehnologii emergente se bazează pe infrastructuri digitale de tip cloud pentru a deveni un sprijin esențial pentru utilizatori. România are o șansă fantastică de a se dezvolta prin tehnologiile viitorului. Vom avea rezultate pentru că punem la aceeași masă cei mai buni specialiști români și expertiza giganților globali din IT. Împreună, ducem România la următorul nivel!", a declarat și ministrul Digitalizării, Bgdan Ivan.\n\nGigantul american Google ar putea investi într-un centru de date care să fie deschis în România peste 2 miliarde de dolari, au declarat anterior surse guvernamentale. În cadrul negocierilor, Guvernul insistă ca viitorul centru de date să aibă un rol regional.\n\nDe ce este important: Premierul Ciolacu a discutat anul trecut cu conducerea Google chiar în SUA despre înființarea acestui centru, iar apoi discuțiile au continuat și la București.\n\n"Un data center în România. Cred ca suntem cei mai îndreptățiți să avem acest lucru. Microsoft cred că are aproape 5.000 de angajați în România, Google vreo 500. Cunoaștem cu toții ce înseamnă un data center pe teritoriul României? Extraordinar de mult! Reprezentanții Google mi-au spus că România are o resursă umană uriașă în domeniul IT, specialiștii noștri fiind printre cei mai bine cotați pe plan mondial. Sunt convins că, folosind talentul lor și expertiza de top a Google, vom reuși să demarăm cele mai ambițioase proiecte în zona noilor tehnologii. Mai mult, vom da astfel un semnal clar și altor mari companii din IT care vor să se extindă în Europa de Est că aici, în România, găsesc oportunități excelente de dezvoltare a afacerilor", spunea Ciolacu în SUA.\n\nRecent, surse guvernamentale arătau că negocierile pentru acest centru de date sunt în curs, iar investiția va depăși 2 miliarde de dolari.\n\nAcest lucru însemană că un posibil centru de date local va rivaliza cu cel din Polonia, în care, în urmă cu patru ani, Google a decis că va investi până la 2 miliarde de dolari, pentru a extinde prezența companiei pe segmentul serviciilor de cloud computing.\n\nGoogle a anunțat atunci că vrea să creeze o "regiune Google Cloud", iar directorul general, Sundar Pichai, a dezvăluit și un plan de investiții de 3 miliarde de dolari în extinderea centrelor de date din Europa într-un orizont de doi ani.\n\nSurse guvermentale arată de altfel că România insistă ca noul centru să aibă un astfel de rol regional.\n\nÎn România, Google Bucharest SRL, filiala Google în România, a fost inclusă în 2016 de Fisc pe lista companiilor din industria online investigate deoarece continua să raporteze un profit de sub 2 milioane lei.\n\nVeniturile Google în Romania erau estimate însă în piață la 75-100 milioane de euro anual, în principal din publicitate.', 'source': {'uri': 'profit.ro', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Profit.ro'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://i0.1616.ro/media/2/2621/34129/21668958/2/google.jpg?width=640', 'eventUri': 'eng-9738070', 'sentiment': 0.05098039215686279, 'wgt': 458734109, 'relevance': 125}
{'uri': '8226241481', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '10:05:44', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T10:05:44Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T10:05:18Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7098039388656616, 'url': 'https://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/inside-track/no-copyright-infringement-taylor-swift-ready-stadium-clark/', 'title': "'No copyright infringement intended' for planned 'Taylor Swift-ready' stadium in Clark", 'body': 'The Clark International Airport Corporation used a US firm\'s design while showcasing their own plans for the Clark stadium\n\nDid you hear about the "Taylor Swift-ready" stadium that\'s soon to rise in the sprawling Clark Civil Aviation Complex?\n\nA presentation slide by the Clark International Airport Corporation (CIAC) made the rounds online after it claimed that project development has started for a shiny, new stadium in Clark. "Taylor Swift concert ready by 2028," the now-viral slide boldly claimed.\n\nBut it went viral for another reason too: the stadium shown in the slide looked awfully similar to a new sports arena in San Diego, California.\n\nA photo of the slide was initially reported online in a now-deleted post on X. Since then, it has been shared and reposted thousands of times on Facebook and Twitter. The slide features a dimmed background, seemingly a conceptual rendering of an arena complex. Although the slide discussed the planned stadium in Clark, it did not explicitly state that the image depicted the actual project.\n\nAnd it certainly didn\'t. A quick Google reverse image search showed that it was actually a conceptual rendering of "Midway Rising," a 48-acre development in San Diego that includes a sports arena. The project is designed by Safdie Rabines Architects, and the architectural firm has on their website a conceptual rendering similar to what was used in the CIAC\'s slide.\n\nAfter facing backlash online for using the image without attribution, CIAC quickly released a statement claiming "there was no copyright infringement intended."\n\n"CIAC is proud to conceive of this project with the inspiration of the likes of the rising San Diego Sports Arena in California, as presented at the second Clark Technical Working Group (TWG) on the Enhancement of the Utilization of Clark International Airport (CRK) meeting. There was no copyright infringement intended in the course of presenting the benchmarks of our project development process to like minds and peers among national leaders and private sector stakeholders," the CIAC said in a post on Saturday, July 13.\n\nMeanwhile, the Department of Tourism (DOT) was also quick to clear its name, clarifying that they were not involved in the CIAC\'s presentation or plans.\n\n"The DOT wishes to clarify erroneous information circulating online wrongly attributing to the DOT and Tourism Secretary Christina Frasco the imagery used in the presentation of CIAC President Arrey Perez for the Clark Complex in Pampanga. Neither the DOT nor Secretary Frasco were involved in the creation or delivery of these plans made and presented by Mr. Perez," the DOT said in a statement posted an hour before CIAC\'s.\n\nApparently, the now-viral slide was shown during a TWG meeting, which happened to include other high-level government officials, such as Tourism Secretary Frasco.\n\n"On his own accord, CIAC President Arrey Perez gave a presentation on his future plans for the Clark Complex, including a proposal to construct a facility capable of hosting major events such as concerts," the DOT added. "The DOT has requested the CIAC to confirm that neither the DOT nor the Secretary has any involvement in their plans and presentation."\n\nAnd sure enough, that\'s what CIAC did.\n\n"We are grateful to the Department of Tourism - Philippines for their unequivocal support for Clark and in giving us the creative freedom, as they had no hand in developing the viral deck, to present our vision for the performance arena," the government corporation said.\n\nEven with these early issues aside, the stadium still has a long way to go before being realized. It\'s just one part of a 37-hectare Entertainment and Events Center near the Clark International Airport, which will be developed through a public-private partnership from 2024 to 2027. While CIAC President Perez said that there are already at least three interested private sector partners, nothing is final yet.\n\nLet\'s hope the final stadium comes out better than this shaky start - or as Taylor would say, CIAC needs to shake it off! - Rappler.com', 'source': {'uri': 'rappler.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Rappler'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://www.rappler.com/tachyon/2024/07/taylor-swift-ready-stadium.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9728853', 'sentiment': 0.1372549019607843, 'wgt': 458733944, 'relevance': 51}

The Hokies finally got complementary play in Brent Pry's first season. Keli Lawson's pick-six and Tucker Holloway's 90-yard punt return touchdown allowed the hosts to build an 11-point lead heading into the fourth quarter.\n\nThat's when it went downhill. Quickly. Georgia Tech had scoring drives of 90 and 73 yards in the fourth quarter to take the lead. The first score came after a Virginia Tech fumble, and the second came on a drive in which the Yellow Jackets converted on third-and-19. A second fourth-quarter turnover sealed the Hokies' fate in their sixth consecutive loss.\n\nPosition(s) of strength: Georgia Tech's offense took a massive step forward in 2023 during Key's first full season. The Jackets led the Bowl Subdivision by improving their scoring average by 13.9 points from 2022 (31.1 points per game in 2023 compared to 17.2 in 2022) and averaging 99.4 yards per game more than they did in 2022 (424.6 compared to 325.2).\n\nAlmost every player responsible for the offensive turnaround is back for another season.\n\nThe group is led by quarterback Haynes King. The redshirt junior put up gaudy numbers with 2,842 passing yards, 737 rushing yards, 27 passing touchdowns and 10 rushing touchdowns. He was the fourth ACC quarterback since 2000 to put up those types of numbers, joining Deshaun Watson, Jerod Evans and Lamar Jackson. His 37 touchdowns responsible for set a program record previously held by Joe Hamilton.\n\nKing didn't have to do it all. He will have plenty of weapons at his disposal with leading rusher Jamal Haynes (1,059 yards and seven touchdowns) and No. 4 runner Trey Cooley (274 yards and three scores).\n\nThe Jackets' top three receivers from one year ago are back. Eric Singleton Jr., Malik Rutherford and Christian Leary combined for 1,525 yards and 12 touchdowns on 119 catches.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nKing returns four starters on the offensive line in left tackle Ethan Mackenny, left guard Joe Fusile, center Weston Franklin and right tackle Jordan Williams.\n\nMiddle Tennessee transfer Keylan Rutledge is expected to start at right guard.\n\nMississippi State transfer Ryland Goede is projected to fill in Dylan Leonard's role at tight end.\n\nWhat's new in Atlanta: The inability for Georgia Tech's defense to get off the field in key situations last season led to Key making wholesale changes on that side of the ball.\n\nKey replaced the entire defensive staff. He brought in former Duke and Texas A&M defensive coordinator Tyler Santucci to lead the unit, and Santucci rounded out his staff with Jess Simpson (defensive line), Cory Peoples (defensive backs) and Kyle Pope (outside linebackers).\n\nThe coaching changes trickled down to a mass exodus of players entering the transfer portal. Twenty of the 32 Georgia Tech players who entered the transfer portal were defensive players, and that included two players who arrived through the portal for spring practice and left in the second transfer window (Jack Barton and Ayo Tifase).\n\nWhile Georgia Tech didn't sign that many players out of the transfer portal (12), it did sign 23 high school players to help fill out the roster.\n\nKey made one change on offense with Trent McKnight joining as wide receivers coach.\n\nLingering questions: Santucci turned Duke's defense into one of the ACC's best units in 2023. Now he'll be tasked with duplicating the task at Georgia Tech with a defense that returns five starters and two others who cracked the starting lineup from a year ago.\n\nSantucci isn't simply replacing a starter here and there. He's also needing to establish depth across the board after 11 contributors entered the transfer portal after the season.\n\nThe Yellow Jackets had two starters graduate (linebacker Paul Moala and cornerback Myles Sims) and lost 11 other contributors to the transfer portal. Those who left include starting defensive tackle D'Quan Douse, rush end Kyle Kennard and nickel K.J. Wallace. The other eight appeared on the depth chart throughout the season, including key backups on the defensive line, linebacker and cornerback.\n\nGeorgia Tech brought in 12 players from the transfer portal. Nine of those are defensive players expected to help fill the voids that were created with the departures.\n\nSantucci's defense at Duke led the ACC in scoring (19 points per game allowed) and ranked top 50 in the nation in seven major categories.\n\nHe can rely on linemen Makius Scott and Zeek Biggers, linebacker Trenilyas Tatum and defensive backs LaMiles Brooks and Ahmari Harvey from last season's squad.\n\nThe Jackets brought in six defensive players from Power Four programs. EJ Lightsey (Georgia) and Jackson Hamilton (Tennessee) are expected to solidify the linebacker position. The defensive line gained depth with end Romello Height (Southern Cal) and interior lineman Jordan van den Berg (Penn State). This move ends foreign ownership in Yandex and could further Kremlin control over Russia's internet. Yandex received $2.8 billion in cash and 162.5 million YNV class A shares.\n\nDutch company Yandex NV on Monday announced it has concluded the sale of its Russia-based technology assets to a consortium of Russian investors. The deal, valued at approximately $5.4 billion, includes cash and shares. It also represents the most significant corporate departure from Russia since the country's invasion of Ukraine over two years ago.\n\nIn the second phase of the transaction, Yandex NV sold its remaining 28% minority stake, securing $2.8 billion in cash and 162.5 million YNV class A shares. {'uri': '2024-07-422186133', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '08:49:32', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T08:49:32Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T08:49:27Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8784313797950745, 'url': 'https://www.moneycontrol.com/europe/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.moneycontrol.com%2Findia%2Fstockpricequote%2Ffinance-investments%2Fwoodsvilla%2FCPC01', 'title': 'Ola-Uber challenger Namma Yatri pilots auto, cab rentals', 'body': "Namma Yatri, the zero-commission ride-hailing service, has gone live with rentals across different categories as it looks to expand its offerings and take on rivals Ola and Uber, Moneycontrol has learnt.\n\nThe service is piloting auto and cab rentals with select Android users in Bengaluru, while it is testing cab rentals in Chennai, sources aware of the development told Moneycontrol. Namma Yatri plans to expand the test to Delhi- NCR in about a fortnight, sources said.\n\nWith this move, Namma Yatri will probably become the first ride-hailing service to pilot auto rentals in the country. Ola and Uber have been offering cab rentals in the country for a few years.\n\nThe service, built on the Open Network for Digital Commerce (ONDC) network, offers passengers packages starting at Rs 190 for a 10-kilometer, one-hour auto rental. For the same distance and duration, the rates are Rs 250 for non-AC mini cabs, Rs 285 for AC mini cabs, Rs 320 for sedans, and Rs 390 for XL cabs, Moneycontrol has learnt.\n\nFor distances above 10 kilometers and an hour, Namma Yatri will charge an additional distance fare ranging from Rs 10-21 per kilometer depending on the vehicle type along with a flat usage fare of Rs 3 per minute. The service will also levy pickup charges ranging from Rs 20-30 based on the vehicle type.\n\nFor night rides, Namma Yatri will charge a flat fee of Rs 250 if the ride starts or ends anytime between 10pm and 5am. Toll charges and other surcharges will be separate. Moneycontrol has reached out to Namma Yatri for comments on this pilot and will update once a response is received.\n\nNamma Yatri was launched by SoftBank-backed fintech firm JusPay in collaboration with Nandan Nilekani's BECKN Foundation and with the support of Bengaluru's Auto Rickshaw Driver's Union (ARDU) in November 2022. A key attraction is zero commission levied from drivers as compared to Ola and Uber which take a 30-40 percent commission.\n\nInitially an auto-only service, the company launched cab services in Bengaluru in April this year.\n\nNamma Yatri makes money by collecting a subscription fee from drivers to sustain its no-commission. Drivers have two options under the plan: Rs 25 for unlimited trips per day or Rs 3.50 per ride (no charges after 10 trips).\n\nThe service was spun out of JusPay earlier this year into a separate firm called Moving Tech Innovations Limited. Shan M S and Magizhan Selvan, who were part of JusPay, are currently leading the spun-off mobility business.\n\nMoneycontrol reported in April that the firm is in final talks to raise $10-$15 million in its maiden funding round. The firm is in talks with investors such as Blume Ventures, Singapore-based Antler and Google, sources told Moneycontrol at the time. JusPay continues to be the majority investor in the ride-hailing firm.", 'source': {'uri': 'moneycontrol.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'MoneyControl'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://images.moneycontrol.com/static-mcnews/2024/02/Namma-Yatri-770x433-770x431.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9734024', 'sentiment': 0.0980392156862746, 'wgt': 458729372, 'relevance': 5}

According to the THE website, the ranking is based on the institutions\' teaching, research environment, research quality, industry innovations and international outlook.\n\n"Friday fortune: Chula is on the World Top 20 Universities with the best-looking alumni rankings," read part of the Thai caption in a Facebook post published on March 15, 2024.\n\nThe post shared an image with text that read "World Top 20 Universities with the best-looking alumni" and a distinct THE logo visible in the top left-hand corner.\n\nThailand\'s Chulalongkorn University was ranked tenth in the false post.\n\nComments showed some users believed the ranking was genuinely published by THE, while some users took credit for their contributions to the university\'s purported ranking.\n\n"Oops!! Now I immediately feel I\'m good-looking," read one Thai user\'s comment.\n\n"It\'s a good survey to study. IQ is probably not everything. Appearance is also an important factor," read the Thai caption of a Facebook user\'s post sharing the image.\n\nNot a genuine ranking\n\nClaire Baumforth, director of corporate communications at THE, told AFP by email that the claim was "completely false".\n\n"Times Higher Education would never compile a ranking of this nature," Baumforth wrote.\n\nKeyword searches on Google did not find the purported rankings published on THE\'s website or in reliable reports.\n\nThe magazine\'s university rankings are published annually (archived link).\n\nUniversities are ranked globally based on five key metrics -- teaching, research environment, research quality, industry innovations, and international outlook, as shown below (archived link):\n\nAccording to information on THE\'s website about the 2024 rankings, the magazine\'s methodology has been tweaked several times since 2004. However, alumni appearance has never been part of its ranking metric (archived link).\n\nAccording to THE\'s publication in 2024, Chulalongkorn University received a global ranking of #601-800 and #117 for Asia.', 'source': {'uri': 'uk.news.yahoo.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Yahoo News UK'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'afp_thailand@uk.news.yahoo.com', 'name': 'Afp Thailand', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://media.zenfs.com/en/afp_factcheck_uk_202/9dd1b2571e2f539796899ce98a04e9d6', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.2784313725490195, 'wgt': 458725220, 'relevance': 6}
{'uri': '2024-07-422094343', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-15', 'time': '07:16:55', 'dateTime': '2024-07-15T07:16:55Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-15T07:00:05Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.800000011920929, 'url': 'https://ca.style.yahoo.com/4-ways-daily-walk-more-070005832.html', 'title': '4 Ways To Make Your Daily Walk More Effective', 'body': 'It\'s hard to overstate the benefits of frequent walks. While this form of exercise may not feel as impactful as a high-intensity workout or distance run, walking actually does wonders for the body.\n\n"Physically it will improve cardiovascular health by strengthening the heart, thereby helping circulation, lower blood pressure, helping in the prevention of heart disease and stroke," Matthew Nolan, a chief instructor at Barry\'s in New York City, told HuffPost.\n\n"Mental health is also a great benefit to walking. The release of the endorphins while walking will help boost mood and overall mental state," he added.\n\nWhat\'s more, daily walking can help build bone and muscle strength and improve joint health, said Nolan. In fact, people with chronic lower back pain and knee pain can benefit from a regular walking regimen, said Tyler Moldoff, a physical therapist at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York.\n\n"It\'s really been exciting more recently seeing a lot of new research coming out about how something as simple as walking can really be an exceptional exercise, when done properly," he said.\n\nTo Moldoff, "done properly" means getting 150 to 300 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise each week. This equates to at least 30 minutes of walking, five days a week -- and you should aim for 5,000 to 10,000 steps (or more) daily.\n\nOnce you hit these requirements, there are additional ways to get even more out of your exercise regimen. Below, experts share what you can do to challenge yourself while building up strength and endurance during your walks:\n\n1. Keep up a quick walking speed.\n\nU.S. government guidelines note that adults need at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise each week, which can include brisk walking -- but not walking at a snail\'s pace.\n\nMoldoff said the intensity of aerobic activity is typically measured in relation to your heart rate.\n\nWhile it can be hard to know your exact heart rate during a walk, a good way to ensure you\'re pushing yourself is to listen to a fast-paced song -- starting at, say, 100 beats per minute -- and then move to the music\'s beat, Moldoff added.\n\n"You can simply do a Google search or even on Spotify or Apple Music, look for different genres of songs that may be enjoyable for individuals at 100 beats per minute, and then trying to sync your cadence to the beat of the song," he said.\n\n"And if you\'re following along [to a] song that is ... 100 beats per minute, you can be sure that after a few minutes you\'ll start to work up a little bit of a breath and you\'ll be hitting that moderate intensity."\n\nIf that tempo feels too slow for you, look up songs that are 110 or 120 beats per minute instead.\n\nAnd as a bonus, music makes walking more enjoyable, Moldoff said.\n\n2. Try interval jogging or speed walking.\n\nIf you\'re not quite ready to maintain a fast walking pace for all 30-plus minutes of your walk, consider incorporating a faster pace at select times during your workout.\n\nNolan said that in Barry\'s classes, instructors frequently do interval-based training, which you can try in your walk, too.\n\n"You can do [this] at home by incorporating short bursts of fast walking or even jogging to increase intensity," Nolan stated.\n\nFor example, you might start small with a 30-second jog or minute-long speed walk and increase the duration when your body feels ready.\n\n3. Add strength training to your walk.\n\n"You could also walk with light weights or do some simple body weight exercises like squats, lunges or pushups during points of the walk to work different muscle groups," Nolan said.\n\nTo start, simply plan your walk ahead of time and pick some designated places, such as your driveway or a local park, to do some body weight training. Writing out your workout in advance can also help you hold yourself accountable.\n\nYou might do five pushups, 15 crunches and a one-minute plank repeated three times, or whatever combination makes sense for you. Just be sure to switch up your strength workout to target different muscles in your exercise regimen.\n\nYou could also try walking with a weighted vest or a backpack filled with books for an added challenge, Moldoff said.\n\n"Simply by doing that, you can help increase your metabolic rate, which improves your oxygen consumption, and that relates to a greater calorie burn," he stated, adding that this can "strengthen the muscle groups of the leg."\n\n4. Or walk along a hilly path.\n\nWalking on a path with hills is another way to boost your daily walk, Moldoff said.\n\nWalking downhill has been shown to improve muscle strength in the lower extremities and reduce the stress that\'s put on the cardiovascular system, he stated.\n\n"So, interestingly enough, it will likely be less stressful on our breathing and our heart rate," Moldoff noted. "It will make it more comfortable, but at the same time, you\'re actually improving your muscle strength more effectively relative to simply level walking."\n\nMeanwhile, walking uphill can provide more of a challenge to your cardiovascular system, and some research suggests that it can benefit people with knee joint issues.\n\nNo matter what you do to up your walking regimen, it\'s important to stay consistent, said Nolan.\n\n"The benefits of walking are best realized with regular, consistent practice," he said. "Aim for at least 30 minutes most days of the week."\n\nBut it\'s important to take days off when you need them and listen to your body for any signs of pain or discomfort, Nolan added.\n\nIt may take time to build up enough strength and endurance to incorporate these walking challenges, and that\'s OK. As you commit to a regular walking regimen, the benefits will begin to emerge.\n\n"Walking is a simple, accessible form of exercise that can truly open the door to a healthier lifestyle," Nolan stated. "By incorporating these tips, you can maximize the benefits and enjoy daily walks even more."\n\nWant to get in some more steps? But JB tied it up with a three-spot in the top of the fifth. Conwell went back ahead 6-5 in the bottom half when Bella Shackford led off with a single and scored.\n\nIn the sixth for JB, Melia Shimel led off with a single before getting caught stealing. But Gianna Rowles followed with a walk and stole her way around the bases to tie the score 6-6. Emily Leon also walked, and got to second base before getting stranded by Conwell pitcher Ryann Chaddock.\n\nIn the bottom half, Ella Gomez ripped a two-out triple and stole home for the lead. Shackford followed with a single and Antonia Cuevas a walk, but were both left on base.\n\nPeople are also reading... $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Ryan Seacrest's Napa County home up for sale at $22 million Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 St. Helena Cyclery to reopen in wake of Trek's closure Napa judge declines to remove temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos Napa City Council to weigh selling land for downtown development Letter: Concerns about St. Helena Agritourism Initiative Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Defendants in Napa double murder delay pleas to Sept. 17 Judge considers vacating temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos Trump injured but 'fine' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Napa Farmers Market: There's always a place for you at the market A Napa teen was killed by gun violence. She stole second base, but an infield popup ended the thriller.\n\nGomez and Shackford each went 3 for 4 and scored twice, while Chaddock was 3 for 4 with one run scored. Mackenzie Matoza walked twice and scored once, and Lola Ames walked once.\n\nShimel doubled and scored on a Madison Sampson sacrifice bunt for JB in the bottom of the seventh to nix the shutout bid. JB had only one other baserunner, Karly Botts, who was hit by a pitch before getting caught stealing in the fifth.\n\nMajor Division\n\nSoscol Auto Body 8, K&S Asphalt 3\n\nOn Thursday, Soscol didn't get any hits off K&S pitcher Sophia Tavizon but used 11 walks and aggressive baserunning to score eight runs. After coming up empty with the bases loaded in the first inning, the winner exploded for six runs in the second and added two in the third.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nFor Soscol, pitcher Ari Ruiz and Rylie Olmstead each walked twice and scored once, Hannah Hanes, Jenna Barnes, Marina Holman and Lyla Petithomme each walked once and scored once, K.K. Abby Webster and Ginger Skillings followed with walks and scored.\n\nSoscol Auto Body 14, Sticky Business BBQ 12\n\nOn June 26, Sticky erased a 7-0 deficit with a 13-run outburst in the third inning, capitalizing on six hits and six walks in 17 at-bats. Soscol rallied for three runs in the fourth and two in the fifth to make it respectable.\n\nFor the winners, Olmstead went 3 for 4 with two doubles and two runs scored, Bowers 2 for 3 with a run scored, Clark 2 for 4 with a run scored, Hanes 1 for 3 with a walk and two runs scored, and Rybicki 1 for 4 with a run scored.
