{'uri': '8225492916', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '21:36:50', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T21:36:50Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T21:35:43Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://pressofatlanticcity.com/news/local/800-rowers-compete-in-dragon-boat-festival-to-help-fight-cancer-support-survivors/article_ffab7350-41f4-11ef-ab25-4798c32b70ae.html', 'title': '800 rowers compete in Dragon Boat Festival to help fight cancer, support survivors', 'body': 'The New York Community Bank Dragons, racing under the team name Puff Puff Dragon, were one of the several club teams to row Sunday at the Cancer Support Community NJ Dragon Boat Festival on Lake Lenape in Mays Landing. Clubs like the NYCB Dragons compete all around the world, said member Demar Ayee, 30, of New York City, shown top left.\n\nJohn Russo\n\nMAYS LANDING -- Tema Morelli had never competed in team sports until she found the River Sisters, a dragon boat racing club comprised of women who have survived breast cancer.\n\n"It\'s been very important that I\'ve stayed with the River Sisters," said the 71-year-old Maple Shade, Burlington County, resident who has been cancer-free for 19 years.\n\nThe hardest part, though, isn\'t the paddling.\n\n"It\'s difficult that to be on this team you have to be a member of that experience. That part\'s hard," Morelli said.\n\nWomen and men, from cancer survivors like Morelli to their supporters, hit Lake Lenape on Sunday for the eighth annual Cancer Support Community Dragon Boast Festival. As drums blasted and strokes were called out, rowers in 40-foot boats raced 200 meters to support families impacted by cancer -- and maybe to win a couple of races along the way.\n\nPeople are also reading... Atlantic City Airshow canceled for 2024 Ocean City\'s Seaspray condo for sale at $7M Scientists know rising seas will one day swallow this Jersey Shore climate research center Cape May County Zoo receives $1.4 million donation Longport resident says rats are coming from borough property 5 hurt, 76 displaced in 5-alarm Atlantic City apartment fire Wildwood police identify shooting suspect After dream debut, South Jersey native Tyler Phillips will start Saturday for the Phillies: Must Win Atlantic City High School principal accused of failing to report child abuse due back in court Aug. 29 Route 30 drawbridge stuck open in Atlantic City South Jersey native Tyler Phillips to start Saturday for the Phillies Buddy Tarbotton, a Cape May County high school sports fixture, dies at 63 Greg Goodwin, influential Absegami coach, dies at 63 Atlantic City fire union head calls for restoring of Ducktown engine in wake of Georgia Avenue blaze Egg Harbor City rescue in need of fosters, donors to help animals rescued from Galloway home\n\nJessica Melville, the development director for CSCNJ, said 40 boats signed up this year, the most in the festival\'s eight years. It began in 2016, and no races were held in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.\n\nThe morning was filled with qualifying races in which each boat competed at least twice. There were three main categories of races -- community teams, corporate sponsors and clubs -- with a few subclasses in each. A flower ceremony to honor those who have died from cancer and a lunch session split the morning qualifiers and afternoon finals.\n\nEach boat has 20 paddlers and a drummer, so about 800 people participated on the water.\n\nCSC, which formed in 2002 after a merger of The Wellness Community (founded in 1982) and Gilda\'s Club (1991), is a national organization that provides support groups and other programing to people impacted by cancer, from patients to families and loved ones to caregivers. The New Jersey branch, the only one in the state, is based in Linwood.\n\n"Most of these people, with the exception of a few that are first-timers, a majority have come year after year after year," Melville said. "This is a wonderful event, we look forward to this every year, and we love inviting the public and telling everybody about our mission. It is our goal that nobody faces cancer alone."\n\nThe entry fees, from $1,100 to $2,400, with some groups donating more, go toward the foundation, Melville said. Last year, the event raised $110,000, and she hoped this year exceeds that.\n\nThere were T-shirt, hat sales and games to benefit CSCNJ. Hard Rock Hotel & Casino Atlantic City held raffles, Somers Point Brewery donated a few kegs of beer, and Tito\'s Vodka was a top sponsor providing refreshments, Melville said. Vendors and food trucks were also on hand.\n\n"This is our largest fundraiser every year," Melville said.\n\n\'It\'s living\'\n\nMelville lost her mother to cancer nearly 20 years ago. She said it\'s difficult to find somebody who has not been closely impacted by cancer.\n\n"I was in high school when she was diagnosed and in college when she died," said Melville, 42, of Linwood. "And 20 years ago, people weren\'t talking about it the way they are today (and) finding support groups when they need mental health support. It\'s great that we offer it, and it\'s great that we talk about it."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nMorelli called herself the poster child for getting a mammography and said she was lucky because her cancer was caught early.\n\n"I can\'t say the same for a lot of our teammates. We have some people on the team who have had their third round (fighting cancer)," Morelli said.\n\nTeri Reed, 53, of Pitman, Gloucester County, will have been cancer-free for one year on Sept. 5. She is also a member of the River Sisters, which is based in Pennsauken, Camden County.\n\nShe said the support on a dragon boating team is similar to the support fighters need in their cancer journey.\n\n"You\'re determined, you\'re working together, and the support...," said Reed as she got emotional. "I\'ve only been with them for a couple months, but there\'s so much heart, there\'s so much support with each other and encouragement that I feel very fortunate to be with such a great amazing group of ladies."\n\nMorelli and Reed stressed the importance of programs like the Rivers Sisters. When they\'re together, they don\'t often talk about their struggles or their survival. Instead, the conversations are about rowing techniques and upcoming races.\n\n"It\'s living. We\'re focused on living!" Reed said.\n\n\'A win-win\'\n\nSunday\'s festival was welcome to veterans of dragon boating as well as newcomers.\n\nDana Patson-Denner and her Galloway Township-based company EOS Medical Supply competed for the first time Sunday. Her team, the EOS Medical Warriors, was decked out in pink bandanas. Patson-Denner wore a pirate hat and drummed the boat to a second-place finish in their heat. She was still feeling the nerves when she reached the shore.\n\n"I have a group of survivors, I have a group of doctors, and I have a group of nurses and friends," said Patson-Denner, 56, of Brigantine. "We\'ve all come together for one cause, and that\'s to fight cancer."\n\nPatson-Denner has owned her company for 18 years. She called the experience the perfect opportunity for team bonding at her office.\n\n"This last race was absolutely phenomenal, and we were much better than our first race," she said. "We\'re looking forward to next year and being able to sponsor again."\n\nThe New York Community Bank Dragons, who raced Sunday under the name Puff Puff Dragon, travel around the word to compete in these events, said member Demar Ayee.\n\nAyee, 30, of New York City, joined the team on a whim five years ago because its first race was on his birthday and he felt it was a different way to celebrate.\n\n"It\'s great because this is something we love to do, and also it\'s great that we can be here to support an important cause as well," Ayee said. "It\'s a win-win, if you think about it. A lot of times we will go to these things and there is some kind of support the money is going toward. You\'re racing, but you\'re also supporting something really nice."\n\nGALLERY: 8th annual Cancer Support Community Dragon Boat Festival\n\nContact John Russo: 609-272-7184\n\njrusso@pressofac.com\n\nTwitter: @ACPress_Russo\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '2024-07-421783844', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '21:13:17', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T21:13:17Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T20:31:47Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://gamerant.com/destiny-2-episode-revenant-story-missions-release-act-good-bad-why/', 'title': "Destiny 2's Episodic Narrative Change is a Double-Edged Sword", 'body': "Destiny 2 Player Makes Their Titan Look Like a Giant Banana, Complete With Matching Sparrow and Ship\n\nHighlights\n\nDestiny 2's new episodic model aims to deliver constant content flow after The Final Shape's success. Bungie's decision to release all missions for each act at once may lead to player FOMO in some cases. Releasing all story missions at once in Episode 2 could either work well or backfire for Destiny 2.\n\nDestiny 2's The Final Shape managed to go above and beyond players' expectations in terms of narrative, gameplay, and overall design, and it led the charge to the game's renaissance after a not-so-great year after Lightfall. With all eyes on Echoes Act 2 and beyond, Destiny 2's new episodic model has to succeed in many big ways - namely, it has to live up to the expectations players have after The Final Shape, and this means good content and constant content flow. Both of these feats are not easily accomplished, and with Destiny 2's Echoes sparking multiple controversies already, Revenant and Heresy have a huge weight on their shoulders.\n\nOne of the biggest complaints about Echoes is that Destiny 2 started time-gating content even more than the seasonal model ever did, with each act having three weeks' worth of missions to play, and then weapons and Season Pass levels unlocking with each act. Bungie is seemingly listening to all feedback from players, to the point that Destiny 2 is buffing Titans soon and Prismatic Hunter is being nerfed in terms of PvP efficiency, and now a new change is planned for Episode 2 - Revenant. In fact, Bungie intends to make all missions available on release for each act, giving players freedom in how they choose to tackle content.\n\nRelated\n\nDestiny 2's Echoes Act 2 is Shooting Itself in The Foot by Buffing The Strongest Build in The Game\n\nDestiny 2's upcoming Act 2 for Echoes is making changes that will buff the game's best build even further.\n\nThe Argument For Destiny 2 to Release Story Missions With Each Episode 2 Act\n\nClose\n\nDestiny 2 is Making Big Changes to Its Narrative Episodic Model\n\nThere is no clear right or wrong path with the release of episodic content just yet, as Bungie is experimenting with a few possible solutions to make the game as enjoyable as possible. The same holds true for making all missions available from the get-go as each act is unlocked, rather than having them released on a weekly basis. This was Destiny 2's narrative model when the game first came out, and like back then, there are pros and cons to this.\n\nThe main benefit of having all act-related story missions available immediately is that players have free rein on how they want to tackle them - be it completing them as soon as possible or taking them on slowly in order not to drain the content well too soon. On one hand, this is a good way to address Destiny 2's FOMO problem (the fear of missing out) because it's up to players to decide what they want to do with it and when they want to play each mission, but it can also foster FOMO in another way.\n\nWhy Destiny 2 Might Shoot Itself In The Foot By Releasing All Story Missions At Once\n\nClose\n\nDestiny 2's New Narrative Approach For Episode 2 Revenant Could Backfire\n\nFor example, Destiny 2's Exotic mission for Echoes is set to be one of the biggest Bungie has ever done, but it's rumored to come out in Act 3 - meaning players won't be able to play it until at least August 27, but more likely weeks later. Without the current structure for weekly story missions, such an Exotic quest would drop immediately alongside Act 3, but it may still require players to complete a couple of weeks' worth of missions before it's even available. As such, one can decide to play at their own leisure, but if an Exotic is meta or build-defining, it may be worth it to speed up the process and complete all missions on launch.\n\nThis is still FOMO, but a different kind of it. Furthermore, it has happened in the past that by having all seasonal content available on launch, the game would dry up for weeks or months, with little incentive to keep playing. This could be a problem if Destiny 2's Episodes 2 and 3 want to retain players beyond the story missions and have them return as frequently as possible. As it stands, Bungie's decision could very well do good and make for a great change to the current model - but it has equal chances of backfiring.\n\nDestiny 2\n\nBungie's Destiny 2 is an online FPS that blends single-player and multiplayer content. Constantly evolving, the shooter has established a strong following since its 2017 debut.\n\nSystem Google , PC , PlayStation , Xbox\n\nPlatform(s) PS5 , PS4 , Xbox Series X , Xbox Series S , Xbox One , PC , Stadia\n\nReleased August 28, 2017\n\nDeveloper(s) Bungie\n\nPublisher(s) Bungie\n\nGenre(s) FPS\n\nMultiplayer Online Multiplayer , Online Co-Op\n\nEngine Tiger Engine\n\nESRB T For TEEN for Blood, Language, and Violence\n\nExpansions Destiny 2: Forsaken , Destiny 2: Shadowkeep , Destiny 2: Beyond Light , Destiny 2: The Witch Queen , Destiny 2: Lightfall\n\nHow Long To Beat 100+\n\nMetascore 85\n\nPlatforms That Support Crossplay PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One & Xbox Series X|S\n\nNumber of Players 1-6 (Co-Op)\n\nPS Plus Availability Essential, Extra, & Premium (The Witch Queen)\n\nExpand\n\nSee at Xbox Games StoreSee at Playstation StoreSee at SteamSee at Amazon", 'source': {'uri': 'gamerant.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Game Rant'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'andrea_trama@gamerant.com', 'name': 'Andrea Trama', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static0.gamerantimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/destiny-2-episode-rev-11-1.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1686274509803922, 'wgt': 458687597, 'relevance': 5}

{'uri': '8225382690', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '19:17:29', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T19:17:29Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T19:16:24Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://pantagraph.com/sports/mounce-brothers-win-bloomington-normal-two-man-three-peat-playoff/article_6909452c-420c-11ef-992e-53196a77d49f.html', 'title': 'El Paso takeover: Mounce brothers capture Two-Man three-peat in playoff victory', 'body': 'BLOOMINGTON -- Jordan and Pippen, Shaq and Kobe, Michael and Branden Mounce.\n\nThe Mounce brothers conquered Steve and TJ Barger by one hole in a playoff to win the Bloomington-Normal Two-Man Best Position Championship for the third consecutive year, marking an impressive three-peat. The tournament\'s top three flights -- the championship flight, first flight and senior championship -- were all won by El Paso residents, and all three were repeat winners.\n\n"There are a lot of good golfers in El Paso," Branden said. "It goes underrated in the area."\n\nThe championship matchup lived up to the billing. Neither side led by more than one hole, and the match was tied for most of its duration.\n\nThe Bargers took advantage first with a birdie on hole 3, but soon after the Mounces responded. The Bargers bogeyed hole 6 then the Mounces birdied the seventh to take the lead. An immediate Barger response with a birdie on hole 8 soon led to a tie with nine holes to play, both teams out at 31, 5-under.\n\nPeople are also reading... Bloomington woman faces DUI in crash that killed her 8-year-old son Felon held by armed resident in Macon County gets 2 years Revolution Dispensary to host grand opening Friday in Normal Man found unresponsive in Bloomington had suffered medical event, police said Opening statements begin in trial of man accused of killing teen at NYE party in Normal Trump injured but \'fine\' after attempted assassination at rally; shooter and one attendee are dead Normal residence heavily damaged, cat perishes in structure fire Jury deliberates fate of Bloomington man charged with murder of Decatur teen Bloomington police investigating shots fired Wednesday night Behind the Pritzker administration\'s quest to signal Illinois is \'open for business\' Flick Fact: Is there really a river under Normal?\n\nTaking advantage of their length off the tee, the Mounce group eagled the 522-yard par-5 tenth to regain a 1-up lead but were once again met with a response after a bogey on hole 12 evened things out again.\n\nThe teams went shot-for-shot, neither side budging until the Bargers encountered trouble at the 16th. Their selected drive went in the right rough, and neither could find the green on approach out of there. Poor chip shots led to a 25-foot par putt to save the hole, but Steve converted it from long range.\n\nMore concern emerged on the par-3 17th after TJ missed a heavy-breaking 5-footer for par, but, again, Steve came through once again to save the hole, keeping things tied heading into hole 18.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"Steve made a lot of putts," Michael said. "It felt like he wasn\'t missing."\n\nBoth teams had mid-range birdie looks for the win on 18, but the Mounces came up just short. After watching his dad come through to create an opportunity, TJ saw a moment. He fired the putt from just on the front of the green, and it tracked toward the hole with plenty of pace. Right as it approached, it lipped around the hole\'s rim and out -- no good.\n\n"It caught a lot of the hole, it was a really good putt," Branden said. "It looked right down the middle."\n\nIn the playoff, starting back at hole 1, both teams found the fairway, but the Mounces had the early advantage with Branden\'s drive being a 340-yard missile. Their wedge approach stuck to about seven feet while the Bargers were in 20-foot range.\n\nNeither Barger could convert, but the outcome wasn\'t set when Branden missed the birdie putt. However, Michael rolled it in on a perfect line, securing the title. The Mounces finished with a 62, 10-under par.\n\n"Most teams don\'t have two guys who can hit it out there quite a ways like us," Michael said.\n\n"We have a lot of shorter birdie putts because we\'re hitting wedges into the greens," Branden added.\n\nIn the senior championship, Todd Manning and Jim Mounce -- Michael and Branden\'s father -- cruised by going 5-up through nine holes and maintaining it, losing just one hole all match for a 5&4 win. In the first flight, Jason Unzicker and Kyle Tague took the lead on hole 3 and never relinquished it, securing a 2-up victory with a 67, 5-under par. Both teams won their respective divisions last year.\n\nBoth Michael and Branden plan on playing in the Bloomington-Normal Medal Play Tournament in early August. Michael is looking for a summer trifecta after winning the Bloomington-Normal Match Play Championship on June 17.\n\nFollow Will Foley on Twitter: @thewillfoley\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '8225280925', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '17:21:57', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T17:21:57Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T17:20:51Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://greensboro.com/sports/brandon-ward-withstands-a-lot-to-win-100-lapper-zack-ore-wesley-thompson-win-in/article_484f5ae2-41f8-11ef-b1eb-878523e42bf6.html', 'title': 'Brandon Ward withstands a lot to win 100 lapper; Zack Ore, Wesley Thompson win in Sportsman Division (copy)', 'body': 'Street Stock driver Jacob Creed (05) leads the 20-lap Street Stock race on Saturday, July 13, 2024, at Bowman Gray Stadium in Winston-Salem, N.C.\n\nJohn Dell\n\nBrandon Ward withstood the heat, the humidity and the charges from Chris Fleming on Saturday night in front of around 9,000 fans at Bowman Gray Stadium.\n\nWard, the defending champion in the Modified Division, won the Shooting Targets USA 100-lap race for his fourth win of the season.\n\nBut it wasn\'t easy.\n\nDuring the middle of the race Ward and Danny Bohn went back and forth with the lead, then it was Fleming who was knocking on Ward\'s back bumper.\n\n"We got it better," Ward said about the restarts that came with double file on a double-points night. "We didn\'t get it fired up earlier in the year, but we fired off pretty well tonight and that\'s a testament to this crew."\n\nThere were seven cautions in the race, but during the late cautions Ward stayed on his line and came out firing to stay in the lead.\n\nWith six weeks left in the season Ward doesn\'t feel like he\'s out of it as he chases Burt Myers who has been the leader all season.\n\n"You can\'t count points right now," Ward said. "There are still a handful of cars still in it and we found that out the last two years. All in all, it was a good night and it\'s about winning races."\n\nFor Fleming, it was also a good night because he started in the back of the field and maneuvered his way up to the front. He may or may not have won the Fans Challenge and an extra $9,000 for finishing in the top four.\n\nFleming, along with Lee Jeffreys, Mike Speeney and Tim Brown had the four fastest qualifying times. They then had an option to start in the back of the field for the chance to win the $9,000 by finishing in the top four.\n\nTrack announcer Randy Pulliam asked each one of them in pre-race activities if they wanted to start in the rear of the field. Brown said no and so did Fleming while Jeffreys and Speeney took on the challenge. Jeffreys and Speeney failed to make it back into the top four.\n\nFleming, however, said after the race that he was forced to take the challenge because of a mix up for the blind draw.\n\n"(NASCAR officials) made me take the challenge," Fleming said. "They did it for me. I went in there to draw and they skipped me and we argued trying to get them to redraw and they would not redraw so they made me start in the rear."\n\nBefore Pulliam interviewed Ward in Victory Lane he announced that Fleming had taken the challenge and was $9,000 richer. However, race officials in the press box late Saturday night would not confirm that Fleming did win the fan\'s challenge.\n\n"I\'ve worked on this car all week and other than church on Wednesday night I was in the shop working every night and I didn\'t even go to my wife\'s birthday party but she\'s a part of this team," Fleming said. "That\'s how my wife is and she said get the car ready and don\'t worry about it."\n\nIf he did indeed win the $9,000 maybe Fleming, who turned 61 earlier in the week, can get his wife a late gift with that money.\n\n"Hopefully I\'ll get some of that money," he said with a smile. "I had a good car all night, but (Ward) won the race but I got the $9,000."\n\nOn lap 10 points\' leader Myers and Drew Moffit came together in a wreck and Myers ended up at the back of the field when the caution was over. About 25 laps later, however, Myers had worked his way up to 11th.\n\nMyers did wind up finishing sixth and said it could have been a lot worse.\n\n"We could have lost 80 points or so if I would have had to gone out after that wreck," Myers said. "So we just battled to make it what it was tonight. I know I told you earlier this season when we had three wins and everything was clicking, but Bowman Gray is like that. You just never know from week to week."\n\nAlso having a good night was Modified rookie Riley Neal, who finished just behind Myers for seventh place. Neal, who is in a battle with Slate Myers for rookie of the year in that division, started on the front row and hung around the lead pack the entire way. It was Neal\'s best showing in a 100 lap race this season.\n\nSlate Myers wound up finishing 13th after starting in the second row.\n\nZack Ore helps his points cause\n\nThe mild-mannered Zack Ore is working out just fine this season in the Sportsman Division.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nOre said before the year started, he was going to be less of a hot head and more of a driver. He led from start to finish in the first 20-lap Sportsman race for the 20th time in his career.\n\nOre and Chase Robertson, the defending champion, are in a battle for the title. Robertson wound up 10th in the first race.\n\n"That\'s exactly what we needed to do, and we knew we had to have a good night because Chase and I are in a battle," Ore said referring to double-points night.\n\nZack Clifton was second, Connor Branch was third with Kirk Sheets fourth and Michael Adams was fifth.\n\n"I told myself I needed to be a little more aggressive here in the second half of the season," Ore said. "But this worked out."\n\nIn the second Sportsman race, Wesley Thompson got his first win of the season holding off Zack Clifton with Sterling Plemmons third.\n\n"This was my first win in two years," Thompson said. "(The fans) haven\'t seen me here (in Victory Lane) in a long time. I just have an awesome group behind me who keep working hard."\n\nRobertson did finish in sixth to salvage the night and Ore wound up 14th in the second race.\n\nJacob Creed rolls to win\n\nIn the 15-lap Street Stock race it was Jacob Creed winning for the first time as he raced Hayden Hall\'s car to change things up for Hall\'s team.\n\nCreed, who led from the pole and despite the four cautions, got the victory.\n\n"Hayden had been struggling so we just mixed it up a little bit and decided I\'d drive for him," Creed said. "And it worked out because the car was great. He\'s my best friend so I\'m just happy to get this win."\n\nCreed held off points\' leader Christian Joyce who was second with Kevin Gilbert third and Andy Southern fourth. Brad Lewis, who headed into the night second in the points behind Joyce, was involved in an early wreck but did get back on the track to get a 13th-place finish.\n\nKeaton, Andrews win in Stadium Stock\n\nGrayson Keaton held off A.J. Sanders to win the first 15-lap race in the Stadium Stock. Tyler McDonald was third and Chuck Wall was fourth.\n\nIn the second 15-lapper it was Billy Andrews winning with Pat-rick Mullen second and James Allison third. D.J. Dan was fourth with Billy Cameron Jr. fifth.\n\nTim Brown honored before races\n\nIt was two weeks ago when Tim Brown added to his lead for the most wins in track history with 100 Modified victories.\n\nOfficials honored Brown in pre-race activities, and he appreciated the gesture.\n\n"It\'s funny but since that win there\'s been a lot of people reaching out who aren\'t regular fans over here," said Brown, who lives in Tobaccoville. "I had a kid at McDonald\'s stop me and he congratulated me and I drove through Bojangles and the lady told me she was happy for me."\n\nBrown, 53, laughed when asked if he took his No. 83 through the drive thru.\n\n"No, I\'d get in trouble for that," he said. "Seriously, it\'s been fun now that we reached that 100-victory mark but like I said two weeks ago, I\'m not done."\n\nNext week\'s racing\n\nThere will be two 25-lap Modified Division races this Saturday to go along with two 20-lap Sportsman races. Also on the schedule is a 15-lap Street Stock race and either one or two 15-lap Stadium Stock races.\n\nAlso on Saturday will be the popular Truliant Federal Credit Union Night of Destruction which will include a Monster Truck crushing exhibition along with a demolition derby.\n\nPHOTOS: Bowman Gray Racing, July 13, 2024\n\njdell@wsjournal.com\n\n336-727-4081\n\n@johndellWSJ\n\nSaturday\'s {'uri': '2024-07-421596559', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '15:17:55', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T15:17:55Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T15:00:12Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.topspeed.com/most-powerful-four-cylinder-suv-2024/', 'title': 'The Most Powerful Gas-Powered Four-Cylinder SUV Available In 2024', 'body': "The world is moving towards electrification and a side effect of this is that traditional gas-powered engines are downsizing. More and more four-cylinder engines are popping up, with forced induction making them just as powerful as the V-shaped engines that they're replacing. This has, of course, caused quite a stir.\n\nIf you're looking for an SUV with a powerful four-cylinder, there are plenty of brand-new options hitting the market. Leading the charge, though, is Chevrolet, with an incredible turbocharged four-cylinder that makes 328 horsepower. That puts it in the same realm as some turbocharged V-6s on the market.\n\nWe take a close look at the 2024 Chevrolet Traverse, dissecting its powertrain and the benefits it has over past models. We look at just how capable the four-cylinder SUV is and what kind of performance you can expect. We also uncover some of the closest competitors to the Traverse in the everlasting horsepower wars.\n\nIn order to give you the most up-to-date and accurate information possible, the data used to compile this article was sourced from various manufacturer websites and other authoritative sources, including the EPA and CarBuzz.\n\nReview\n\n2024 Chevrolet Traverse: A Comprehensive Guide On Features, Specs, And Pricing\n\nThe 2024 Chevy Traverse hits the midsize crossover and SUV market with an all-new look, new off-road Z71 trim, and great standard technology.\n\nThe 2024 Traverse Comes Standard With A 328 Horsepower Inline-Four\n\nClose\n\nThe outgoing Traverse had a V-6 powertrain that had a maximum output of 310 horsepower. The 2024 model enters a new generation and brings in a new four-cylinder powertrain capable of even more power while also being more efficient. This new trend of turbocharged four-cylinders is something we expect to see more often moving forward.\n\nPerformance\n\nEngine\n\n2.5-Liter Turbocharged Inline-Four\n\nTransmission\n\n8-Speed Automatic\n\nHorsepower\n\n328 HP\n\nTorque\n\n326 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nFWD or AWD\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n6.7 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n130 MPH\n\nMaximum Towing Capacity\n\n5,000 LBS\n\nEvery 2024 Traverse is powered by the same 2.5-liter inline-four. This turbocharged four-cylinder is paired with an eight-speed automatic transmission and your choice of front-wheel drive or all-wheel drive. While maybe not as quick as some of its rivals, the Traverse still offers plenty of hustle, and you won't find highway overtaking too difficult.\n\nChevrolet offers an optional Trailering Package on the Traverse. This package can be had on every trim except the base model and will set you back an additional $650. It adds a heavy-duty cooling system, a 220-amp alternator, and a hitch view camera. This package is necessary if you want to achieve the Traverse's maximum towing capacity of 5,000 pounds.\n\nFuel Economy\n\nModel\n\nCity\n\nHighway\n\nCombined\n\nFWD\n\n18 MPG\n\n26 MPG\n\n21 MPG\n\nAWD\n\n17 MPG\n\n25 MPG\n\n20 MPG\n\nOne of the biggest claimed benefits of going with a four-cylinder over a V-shaped engine is fuel economy. The Traverse doesn't do too badly in this department, especially for a car of its size. There is only a small difference between the estimated fuel efficiency of the front-wheel drive models compared to the all-wheel drive models, so you're not penalized for going with the latter.\n\nAdd TopSpeed to your Google News feed.\n\nFollow On\n\nGoogle News\n\nDespite four-cylinders being generally more efficient, the four-cylinder in the Traverse doesn't represent that much of a difference. While you get more miles per gallon in the city, highway figures are identical to the outgoing model. However, it should be noted that the four-cylinder engine is way more powerful, so breaking even isn't that bad.\n\nRelated\n\n10 Best Four-Cylinder Vehicles In 2024 Ranked By Horsepower\n\nDiscover the top 10 four-cylinder vehicles of 2024, ranked by horsepower, blending performance and efficiency for an exhilarating driving experience.\n\nTwo High-Performance Trims Make Use Of The Engine In Different Environments\n\nChevrolet's 2024 makes good use of its high-output four-cylinder engine. While there are still everyday trims, there are two standout models that put the Traverse through its paces in different ways. The RS trim offers sporty styling elements as well as some unique tuning to make the Traverse a more exciting SUV. Meanwhile, the new Z71 trim equips the Traverse with all it needs to tackle fearsome off-road obstacles.\n\nTraverse Z71\n\nThe Z71 is a brand-new addition to the Traverse's trim lineup for the 2024 model year. It slots in right above the LS and the LT, which cater more to your average buyers. The Z71 brings some classic Chevy rough-and-tumble energy to the mid-size SUV, allowing it to travel further off the beaten path than most of its rivals.\n\nThe Z71 starts at $47,795 and comes ready to hit the trails. The first change over the rest of the lineup is that the Z71 has a slightly lifted suspension as well as all-terrain tires. More impressively, it features a standard twin-clutch four-wheel drive system, unique suspension dampening, and selectable driving modes that are terrain-specific.\n\nTraverse RS\n\nThe RS model replaces the Premier and High Country trims at the top of the ladder for the 2024 model year. With the brand-new peppy engine, Chevrolet obviously feels that the Traverse has more appeal as a sporty three-row SUV. While it doesn't come with a higher output engine, it features plenty of equipment that makes it more exciting.\n\nLooking at it from the outside, you can tell it apart from the rest of the lineup due to its 22-inch glossy black wheels and the black trim that it sports. Alongside styling elements, the RS also comes with a unique suspension tune that makes it feel a little more agile when taking corners.\n\nRelated\n\nI Took The 2024 Chevrolet Colorado ZR2 In A Muddy Trail And, Unsurprisingly, It Delivered\n\nUnsurprisingly, Chevrolet managed to make the iconic Colorado ZR2 even better with this second-generation model.\n\nThe Traverse Offers Tons Of Value On The Inside As Well\n\nWhile the new four-cylinder engine under the hood of the Traverse is a treat, to be sure, its real value is only realized on the inside. The Traverse has always been one of the most spacious and comfortable mid-size SUVs out there, and the changes to the 2024 model have only helped solidify its status as the perfect family hauler.\n\nInterior Dimensions\n\nFirst Row Headroom\n\n42.6 Inches\n\nFirst Row Legroom\n\n44.29 Inches\n\nSecond Row Headroom\n\n39.96 Inches\n\nSecond Row Legroom\n\n41.46 Inches\n\nThird Row Headroom\n\n38.27 Inches\n\nThird Row Legroom\n\n32.13 Inches\n\nCargo Space Behind Third Row\n\n22.9 Cubic Feet\n\nIf you plan on driving around with a large family, then the Traverse has you covered in terms of interior space. The base trim seats up to eight people in three rows of seating, but every other trim swaps out the second-row bench for captains' chairs, reducing passenger capacity to seven.\n\nThe third row of seating is probably the most realistic third row in the mid-size segment. Where the Traverse's rivals have third rows that are only really suitable for children, even adults will be able to comfortably slide into the rear seats in Chevy's SUV. Cargo space is just as generous as seating space, with a maximum of 97 cubic feet of space with both the third row and the second row folded away.\n\nNotable Features\n\nThe most noticeable piece of tech in the 2024 Traverse is the massive 17.7-inch standard touchscreen which spans across the dashboard. This infotainment system utilizes Google's new software interface and is quick and responsive. Also standard is an 11-inch digital gauge cluster that is customizable.\n\nThere are plenty of comfort and convenience features available in the 2024 Traverse, such as a wrapped, heated steering wheel and heated front-row seats. A Bose premium audio system is also available. There is plenty of driver-assist tech that comes standard, with Super Cruise also being an optional extra.\n\nRelated\n\nThe Most Affordable Mid-Size SUV To Offer Third-Row Seats As Standard\n\nBlending affordability with spaciousness for families on a budget, the mid-size Subaru Ascent comes with standard three-row seats from the factory\n\nThere Is Some Stiff Competition From Other Four-Cylinder SUVs\n\nThe Chevy Traverse isn't the only four-cylinder SUV capable of breaking the 300-horsepower mark. There are some other really impressive options on the market. Some of these options also offer a more refined experience that is more performance-focused than Chevy's family hauler.\n\nBMW X2 M35i\n\nWhile the standard BMW X2 has an output of 241 horsepower, the M-tuned version pushes the four-cylinder engine to its limits. Instead, the M35i is capable of outputting up to 312 horsepower from its two-liter turbocharged inline-four. If you're looking for more of a sports SUV, then this is the way to go. It has upgraded brakes and a uniquely tuned suspension, as well as a punchy engine that helps rocket the X2 from a standstill to 60 miles per hour in 4.7 seconds.\n\nFord Bronco\n\nWhile a couple of horses shy of the Chevrolet's output, the Bronco still packs a punch. The base turbocharged 2.3-liter inline-four in the Bronco pushes out 300 horsepower and an impressive 325 pound-feet of torque. The Bronco is more focused on outdoor adventuring than the Traverse. If you're looking to tackle the outdoors in a mid-size SUV, then the Bronco offers some of the most fun you can have on four wheels.", 'source': {'uri': 'topspeed.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Top Speed'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'tyler_dupont@topspeed.com', 'name': 'Tyler Dupont', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static1.topspeedimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/10.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1058823529411765, 'wgt': 458666275, 'relevance': 56}
{'uri': '8225146467', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '15:05:37', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T15:05:37Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T15:05:12Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://roanoke.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/donald-trump-election-2024-black-latino-voters-support-poll-shows/article_60ffc4bf-4370-526d-b452-7cd119a9eadd.html', 'title': "Trump wants Black and Latino support. But he's not popular with either group, poll analysis shows", 'body': 'WASHINGTON -- As he prepares to accept the Republican nomination for the third time, Donald Trump has promised new efforts to expand his coalition -- and, in particular, to win over more of the nonwhite voters who largely rejected him during the 2020 election.\n\nBut an AP analysis of two consecutive polls conducted in June by the AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research shows that about 7 in 10 Black Americans have a somewhat or very unfavorable view of Trump, as do about half of Hispanic Americans. While both groups do see Trump a little more favorably than when he left office in 2021, their opinion of him is still more negative than positive.\n\nAny gains in support among Black or Hispanic Americans would be helpful for Trump, who won 35% of Hispanic voters and 8% of Black voters in 2020, according to AP VoteCast, and has struggled to grow his appeal beyond his base. He\'s hoping, in part, to capitalize on frustration with his opponent, since President Joe Biden\'s favorability among Black and Hispanic Americans has also fallen since 2021. It\'s not clear, though, that Biden\'s loss of enthusiasm among Black and Hispanic adults is helping Trump\'s own standing among these groups.\n\nMost Americans have a negative view of Trump, according to the AP-NORC analysis, which combined two polls conducted close together to yield a bigger sample size. About 6 in 10 U.S. adults have a very or somewhat unfavorable opinion of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable opinion. Overall views of Trump were similar in January and July 2021, too, in the months after Biden took office.\n\nViews of Trump are generally very stable -- even a felony conviction didn\'t change how Americans see him. After he was convicted in May of 34 felony counts in New York for falsifying business documents, polls from the AP-NORC Center found that overall views of Trump barely budged. During the Trump presidency, Gallup polls found that Trump\'s average job approval rating was 41%, and it never exceeded 50%.\n\nTrump has said on the campaign trail that he has "great support" from Hispanic communities. But the AP analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of Trump. About 4 in 10 Hispanic adults in the recent AP-NORC polls see Trump positively, up from about 3 in 10 in January 2021.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAnd even though Trump\'s campaign advisers have said he has specific appeal among Hispanic men and younger Hispanic adults because of his business focus, that\'s not what the poll analysis shows. Current views of Trump are similar among Hispanic men and women, older and younger Hispanic adults, and those with and without a college degree.\n\nBiden, too, is facing a perception problem among this group. The new analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable view. That\'s a substantial decline from early 2021, when about 6 in 10 Hispanic Americans saw Biden positively.\n\nThe Trump campaign has claimed that he could perform better among Black adults this year than in 2020, speculating that his legal woes could endear him to a community that has faced systematic discrimination by the criminal justice system, and that his immigration policies could also hold appeal.\n\nBlack adults continue to have broadly negatively views of Trump, however: About 7 in 10 Black adults have an unfavorable view of Trump, a decrease of about 20 percentage points since early 2021. And although the Trump campaign has said Black men may be more receptive to his message, Black men and women have similar views of him.\n\nYounger Black Americans might be a little more open to Trump\'s appeals. About one-third of Black younger adults -- those under 45 -- see him positively, compared to around 1 in 10 Black adults who are 45 or older. But most younger Black adults view him unfavorably.\n\nAbout 6 in 10 Black Americans, meanwhile, have a positive view of Biden -- down from 8 in 10 when he took office.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'roanoke.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Roanoke Times'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@roanoke.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'rebecca_blackwell@roanoke.com', 'name': 'Rebecca Blackwell', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/roanoke.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/6/0f/60ffc4bf-4370-526d-b452-7cd119a9eadd/6691427d29ce8.preview.jpg?crop=709%2C372%2C471%2C53&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1764705882352942, 'wgt': 458665537, 'relevance': 51}

{'uri': '8224943045', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '11:53:06', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T11:53:06Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T11:52:19Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://newsadvance.com/news/local/amherst-youth-baseball-headed-to-world-series/article_f3e46718-408f-11ef-a763-9fb7879a4fa8.html', 'title': 'Amherst Youth Baseball headed to World Series', 'body': 'Harper Lawson\n\nAfter dominating Virginia\'s "Ozone" state tournament on July 8, the 11-player Amherst Youth Baseball team will travel to Bossier City, Louisiana for the 2024 Dixie Youth Baseball World Series.\n\nThe team, playing for the Division II Ozone league, is made up of players ages 11 and 12, four from Nelson County and seven from Amherst.\n\nBeginning July 25, they have a shot at the world championship as long as they don\'t lose two games -- the number that results in elimination. Their first game will be against the Texas team, who beat them in the state tournament two years ago. The series concludes on July 31.\n\nAssistant coach Jeff Mayo said that the team also made it to and lost the state tournament last year, but said this season, "We finally got over the hump."\n\n"Every little kid who plays baseball says they want to play in a World Series," said designated "team mom" Mary Kathryn Allen. "It\'s just a great opportunity for them as young men."\n\nAnother assistant coach, Jim Allen, agreed that the tournament\'s personal opportunities were just as important for the boys as the athletic experience.\n\n"They get to meet kids from other areas that they wouldn\'t normally meet or interact with," he said. "It\'s not a video game."\n\nThe boys have generated some impressive statistics throughout their journey toward the World Series, such as scoring a combined 78 runs and allowing a combined nine runs in their last two tournaments.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nEleven-year-old Kendall Nappier particularly wowed his coaches and family with a .777 batting average in the state tournament. He said that one important thing he is working on with the team for the World Series is their "attitudes."\n\nBill Dawson, a pitching coach at Amherst County High School and the Amherst Youth Baseball team\'s head coach, is confident his team has what it takes to prove themselves in the World Series.\n\n"I think the strength of this team...is that they are highly competitive, which means they want to win at any cost," he said. "They lay it on the line. And it\'s not just one of them, it\'s all of them."\n\nHe explained that the boys respond to a loss by using it as motivation in future games and he admires how they always have each other\'s backs when experiencing frustration.\n\nDawson witnesses the dedication and skill of his players through coaching this team as well as the Main Street Mound Hawks, a travel ball team that eight of the Amherst Youth Baseball players are also a part of.\n\n"Our guys are really seasoned," he said.\n\nWhile the boys practice two to four times per week to ready themselves for the World Series, their parents must make certain preparations themselves. Allen shared that raising money to help with the team\'s travel, lodging and food has not been easy.\n\nWhile the Nelson County Board of Supervisors recently granted the team $5,000 after hearing a persuasive presentation from Allen, a Nelson resident who serves on the county\'s planning commission, the trip is still estimated to cost a minimum of $2,500 per player. Allen shared that any and all financial support would greatly benefit the team, and that "no amount is too small."\n\nThe team encourages people to visit their "fish fry" fundraiser on July 19, including food and bake sales, a raffle and an auction. Attendees can use cash or a check to donate toward a fish or chicken dinner with two side options such as mac n\' cheese, corn on the cob, baked beans and coleslaw.\n\nThe event will run from 4 to 8 p.m. at the Massies Mill Ruritan Club in Roseland. All proceeds will help fund the team\'s trip to Louisiana.\n\nThe group also has a GoFundMe that is currently accepting donations.\n\nHarper Lawson\n\nhlawson@newsadvance.com\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '2024-07-421446210', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '11:35:15', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T11:35:15Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T11:22:20Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://exbulletin.com/sports/2787573/', 'title': 'I biked 30 miles to late night hockey game in Everett, then biked another 30 miles home - Seattle Bike Blog', 'body': 'As a kid growing up in the suburbs of St. Louis, I was obsessed with hockey. One of my earliest hockey memories was watching Brett Hull score 50 goals in 50 games when I was five years old. I spent so much time on inline skates in my driveway or in nearby church parking lots that a wheel fell off my Roller Blades and I broke my finger in the fall. I also played ice hockey from kindergarten through high school. And when I was indoors, I played NHL \'95 on my SEGA. But then I went to college in a small town with no ice rink, and then moved around a bit before ending up in Seattle with no car, very little money, and very little storage space. For 13 years, hockey was just something I did when I was younger.\n\nBut then I became a dad and bought an electric cargo bike to haul the kid around. During those long days at home with a baby, I had to find excuses to get out of the house and move my body. I needed something that didn\'t involve work or being a dad or worrying about all those other adult responsibilities. I was watching a Blues game with the kid sleeping on my shoulder when I realized that with the cargo bike I could probably ride my stuff to hockey rinks. My parents shipped my old high school hockey gear to Seattle and I signed up to play in a local beer league (although I don\'t think they want us to call it that). It\'s a no-hitting adult league that is now called the Kraken Hockey League, although I signed up before the city had a team and before the rink at Northgate was built. I went to an evaluation skate, got "drafted" to a team, and have been playing with them ever since. Other than breaking another finger, it\'s been great. It\'s a planned physical activity for after the kids go to bed, where I can fully immerse myself in the fresh air for an hour and a half, followed by a relaxing bike ride home late at night.\n\nMost of our games are at rinks in Mountlake Terrace, Lynnwood, and Northgate, with the occasional game in Kent and Everett. I bike to almost every game at the first three rinks, and I\'ve biked to Kent Valley Ice Center twice. But Everett has always been the rink where I borrow a car or carpool with a teammate. When people see me outside a rink with my gear and poles on my bike, they always ask me, "Do you bike to every game?" And I\'ve always said, "Well, I\'ve biked to every rink except Everett." But not anymore.\n\n- Advertisement -\n\nWednesday night, as my husband and kiddo were beginning their bedtime routine, I packed my gear into the bike, plugged in both batteries, and set out on the 30-mile ride along the Interurban North bike trail from Seattle to Everett. Not only was this the first time I\'d ridden all my hockey gear this far, it was also the first time in years that I\'d ridden the Interurban North past Lynnwood. It\'s a great route, even if it\'s not complete. There are a few significant detours to miss freeway intersections, but the signs are mostly easy to follow. I only turned around a handful of times, but each time it was quickly apparent that I was going the wrong way. Google\'s bike routes, which seem to be getting worse and worse, didn\'t always follow the official route accurately, but the physical signs along the route were reliable. If you do ride this route, trust the signs instead of Google.\n\nThe ride there was thankfully uneventful, although I did expend more power than necessary by keeping the power setting on the bike low, worrying about whether I would have enough battery power to get home later that evening. As it turns out, I didn\'t need to. The Tern GSD had more than enough range to use the higher power settings for the entire 60 mile round trip, especially since I had brought the charger so I could plug in the batteries while I was out on the ice.\n\nI could have really used some extra leg power and energy for the game. There were only three of us on defense, so our shifts were about 50% longer than normal. Hockey is a brutally exhausting sport, and somewhere in the middle of the second period I cracked. I had no more calories to burn and my legs just couldn\'t recover during the short breaks on the bench. By the end of the game I could barely keep going. Two and a half hours of riding (and maybe not enough food) for the extra long shifts was too much. As I slowly stripped off my gear in the locker room afterwards, my legs feeling like jelly, it hit me that I still had 30 miles to ride before I could get home and go to sleep. It was 12:30 am by the time I got back on my bike. I had already eaten all my emergency fruit snacks. Time to get pedaling.\n\nThe good news was that while my legs were tired, none of my joints were sore. I can sometimes get knee pain when riding long distances, but my knees behaved themselves. Even more good news was that my bike\'s computer estimated that I could keep the e-assist motor in "turbo" and make it home with energy to spare. So I did. But even with the assist, it still takes energy and stamina to pedal. On top of that, my back and butt hurt, and my core was exhausted. I wasn\'t sure I was going to make it, but I didn\'t have any other easy choices. I\'m also extremely stubborn and more than a little stupid. So I persevered and put on old Sonic Youth albums on the bluetooth speaker to keep my energy up.\n\nThe Interurban North bike trail largely follows the former route of the Everett-Seattle electric passenger train (1910-1939). Remember that scene in Fremont with the people and the dog with the human face waiting on a platform? That\'s the train they\'re waiting for. And if you\'ve never noticed before that the dog has a human face, I\'m so sorry I ruined your life. Once you see it, it\'s all you can see. I\'m a monster for writing this paragraph. This is the punishment for getting this far in a meandering essay about biking to hockey.\n\nMost of the ride is on sections of trail built on old railroad tracks. It\'s also a somewhat unusual corridor because much of it is owned by the electric companies. Over the years, several sections have been built over by residential or retail development, freeways or freeway ramps. Municipalities, along with King and Snohomish Counties, have been trying to patch it back together for decades, but the long stretches of trail that do exist are truly a delight. Yes, you spend a lot of time with I-5 roaring by, but the trail is mostly tree-lined and feels almost like a secret path. Most of the on-street sections are either on very quiet side streets with little traffic, have bike lanes, or have a widened sidewalk that serves as a trail. There are a few unfriendly sections, such as the section at NE 205th Street near the county line (The North Sound Bicycle Advocates are on it!), but the only truly awful ride on the street was the Maple Road Bridge over I-5 in Lynnwood, which has only narrow shoulders next to sidewalks that are far too narrow to bike on (there\'s even a sign at the beginning of the bridge saying bikes are not allowed on the sidewalks). It\'s the only part of the entire ride where I\'d be afraid to take a child.\n\nThere are a few projects in the works to make the route a little better, but I can\'t find any active projects to improve the Maple Road problem (let me know in the comments if I\'m missing something). Snohomish County currently has a survey going on about a project to improve walking and biking conditions south of Everett that is worth filling in. Snohomish County will also build a path connection from 160th Street SW to 167th Place SW next year a section where there are now only narrow cycle paths.\n\nAbout an hour into my drive home, it was 1:30 a.m. and I had barely seen anyone else. I was starving and felt ridiculous for not bringing more food. I had planned to stop at a fast food restaurant along the way, but I hadn\'t seen one yet. I was starting to worry that everything would be closed this late on a Wednesday night deep in the suburbs. The trail veered away from the woods and led me onto a street, another detour onto the street before I got back to the trail. And then I saw it. It was hard to believe it was real. A 24-hour Subway? I had no idea such a thing existed. But there it was, and it was beautiful.\n\nI ordered an Italian footlong and sat down at a table. I had been riding on adrenaline and Sonic Youth for a while and I finally realized how exhausted I was as I sat down and waited for my sandwich. My legs had barely any strength left. I wolfed it down when it was ready and immediately felt a lot better. The guy working alone that night was impressively patient as drunk people kept stumbling in from the bar a few doors down. He didn\'t get upset or frustrated at all when he had to repeat himself over and over to get people to place their sandwich orders. He just let it take as long as it took and made sure people got fed. He kept the city of Lynnwood together that night.\n\nI can\'t even tell you what was in the sandwich I ate, because I wasn\'t looking at it as I devoured it. However, I could feel the energy coursing through my body and at least some strength returning to my legs. I still had about an hour and a half to go, but now I knew I was going to make it. I queued up Teen Age Riot and pressed play, then continued cycling south.\n\nIt\'s time to go around\n\nA one-man showdown, teach us how to fail\n\nWe are now off the streets\n\nAnd back on the road, on the riot trail\n\nThe rest of the ride was tiring, but went as smoothly as it could. It\'s funny how familiarity with a route makes it seem shorter. For example, I got to Mountlake Terrace and thought, "Oh, good, I\'m almost home," even though I knew I had almost an hour to go. But at least I knew all the hills, turns, and bumps from there on out.\n\nI rolled home at 3am. It felt great to flop down on the couch. I had done something ambitious on impulse, and I had made mistakes and taken unnecessary risks. It was the kind of adventure I haven\'t had since I got older, always planning everything to make sure everyone is taken care of. I did something stupid, and I loved it.', 'source': {'uri': 'exbulletin.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'ExBulletin'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://i.imgur.com/AoyxWyw.png', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.02745098039215688, 'wgt': 458652915, 'relevance': 60}
{'uri': '8224869265', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '10:43:15', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T10:43:15Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T10:42:39Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://buffalonews.com/news/local/buffalo-bills-stadium-oversight-development-by-jem-women-and-minority-owned-businesses/article_621ca2a6-3f9e-11ef-bd51-33732c7e4114.html', 'title': "How the Bills' community benefits deal suddenly got three years longer", 'body': 'Penny Semaia, vice president of stadium relations for the Bills, goes over workforce numbers and goals for the new stadium project.\n\nWhen the community benefits deal tied to the construction of the new Buffalo Bills stadium was first revealed, it was believed to be an agreement that would last for 30 years.\n\nBut as it turns out, it\'s really a 33-year deal.\n\nSo how did the agreement suddenly get longer?\n\nIt all hinged on a closer look at the deal\'s terms by the Bills\' legal team and their determination that the agreement didn\'t kick in when the stadium opened, but rather once the lease was signed. It is a legal twist that Erie County\'s top attorney admits he didn\'t see coming.\n\n"I want to be real public about the team deserving credit for stepping in ... and coming to a conclusion that, quite frankly, I missed," Erie County Attorney Jeremy Toth said.\n\nAnd that means more money - upward of $9 million - will be flowing into the community under the terms of a Community Benefits Agreement that is expected to pump more than $100 million in initiatives backed by the settlement over the next 33 years.\n\nPeople are also reading... Watch: Video shows Buffalo man killed by police sped off with officer clinging to car Man shot dead by Buffalo police is brother of slain 12-year-old At least four tornadoes, two packing 110 mph winds, hit Western New York, weather service reports Alan Pergament: \'Beatles\' host JP leaves WECK after disagreement with station owner Buddy Shula \'Quite an undertaking\': Cleanup starts after Beryl blows through Western New York Pregnant in her sophomore year, Bennett High School graduate finds self-worth - with plenty of help Do the Sabres need a goal-scorer after landing Ryan McLeod to center the third line? Bills quarterback Mitch Trubisky finds his way back home Ryan McLeod\'s \'whirlwind\' trade has new Sabres center \'excited\' to get to Buffalo \'The numbers are just astronomical:\' Why developers are putting more projects on hold State agency, waterside attraction leaders losing patience with stalled project at Canalside Stop and look: How the new Bills stadium is already drawing in spectators Shooting at Trump rally is being investigated as assassination attempt, AP sources say Free concerts fill Buffalo parks with rock, jazz and country Family recipes are the heart of new Marta\'s Market in East Aurora\n\nAs part of the original agreement, the team committed to reinvesting that more than $100 million into the community over what was initially thought to be the life of the stadium lease.\n\nAs it turns out, the term of the CBA started March 29, 2023, and ends at the end of the 30-year stadium lease, and it was the team\'s attorneys who pointed this out to Erie County.\n\nThe initial expectation was that the Bills\' annual investment would be allocated toward community initiatives and run in tandem with the start of the new 30-year stadium lease in 2026.\n\nThat is how it was originally interpreted by the county\'s legal team in the agreement, as originally written.\n\nOversight committee looks for more say in Bills community fund allocations\n\nWhen the New Stadium Community Benefits Oversight Committee first met in February, members thought the Buffalo Bills\' $3 million annual community allocation would start once the team completed the stadium in 2026, but after reviewing the CBA, they found out it is active during the three years of construction. Now the committee is prioritizing coming up with a system to make sure the money is being properly allocated, which will include public participation in the process to better understand the most pressing needs.\n\nBut when the agreement was reviewed by the new legal team of the Bills that includes Terry Gilbride and Toni Cannady, they determined that the language about the community funds was actually tied to the beginning of stadium construction, which started last year.\n\nWhy the fresh look?\n\nJust about every Bills employee who negotiated the original new stadium deal is no longer with the team - that is staff on the business side, including in the legal department.\n\nGilbride came from the Buffalo law firm Hodgson Russ earlier this year to become senior vice president and chief legal officer with the Bills, and Cannady serves as the team\'s assistant general counsel.\n\nToth said it is not unusual that a new set of eyes reviewing a contract would notice something "everyone else had taken for granted, to that point."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nStop and look: How the new Bills stadium is already drawing in spectators\n\nThe Buffalo Bills new stadium project site has been an attraction from the start of construction last June, but this summer may become an even more prime time for fans, sightseers and neighbors to come out as the stadium really begins taking shape, the weather gets even warmer and school is out until the fall.\n\n"I think the Bills\' lawyers just read what we drafted and what we wrote, and what we agreed to had the investment beginning commensurate with the execution of the documents, and so there\'s the construction period ,and then there\'s the 30-year lease period," Toth said.\n\nThat also partly explains why the New Stadium Community Benefits Oversight Committee, which oversees the community investment, wasn\'t able to review the team\'s allocation during the first year of the stadium deal. The group also didn\'t form until too late in the process.\n\n"That\'s why, at the beginning of all this, there was a little bit of a scramble," Toth said.\n\nGoing forward, committee members said at a meeting Monday that they want to make sure area residents have more input into where the Bills allocate those millions of dollars in the years to come.\n\n"We will now help in how those funds are allocated," said the Rev. Mark E. Blue, the committee chair. "We did not have a say in it this time, but we will develop a formula for how things can be done, and funds allocated going forward."\n\nThe cost of the new Bills stadium keeps rising. Will fans have to pick up the tab?\n\nWill all the money really come from the wallet of Bills billionaire owner Terry Pegula or should season ticket holders expect to at least share in those costs?\n\n"Not saying they were done unjustly or unfairly, but we just don\'t know," he added. "Now that we do know, we\'ll be more proactive."\n\nThe team is confident it made at least $3 million in fund allocations for continuing and new initiatives in the community and in workforce development efforts from March 29, 2023, to March 28, 2024.\n\nFor now, though, the committee isn\'t sure what all those investments were. The specifics on where that money went will be documented in an annual report that is to be released July 29.\n\n"It will highlight not only where the community investment went, but also all of the effort as it pertains to making sure that the team is staying active with the community and supporting the various spaces and needs," said Penny Semaia, vice president of stadium relations for the Bills.\n\nOnce the report comes out, Toth said committee members will evaluate and respond to the Bills\' community investments. The committee is slated to meet Aug. 12.\n\nBlue said the committee will come up with a system to make sure the money is being properly allocated, which will include public participation in the process to better understand the most pressing needs for it. But the Bills have the final say in determining where the funds are allocated each year.\n\n"Will they be disappointed? Will they be enthusiastic? I don\'t know," Toth said.\n\n"And how does that play into next year?," he asked. "It\'s important that the public understand that the committee doesn\'t have any direct authority over this money, but the Bills are not going to ignore them. We set this up with the expectation that the Bills wouldn\'t be interested in fighting with a bunch of community members."\n\nToth said that there are no other NFL teams with a setup like this one, and he feels that if both parties work together for a common purpose, the accomplishments could be "extraordinary." But the process will take at least the next few years to evolve, because there is no blueprint for it, he added.\n\n"If it works effectively, it\'s going to be a partnership between this community group and the Buffalo Bills, and as long as there is good will and good faith on both sides, I think it is going to be a real exciting and interesting development for this community," Toth said.\n\n0 Comments Get local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.
