{'uri': '8224845231', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '10:21:26', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T10:21:26Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T10:20:10Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.westernpeople.ie/masal-bugduv-a-prodigy-that-never-was_arid-24320.html', 'title': 'Masal Bugduv: a prodigy that never was - sport - Western People', 'body': 'Towards the end of 2008, as the January transfer window approached, a Moldovan teenager by the name of Masal Bugduv was apparently one of the hottest prospects in the game. The 16-year-old was, according to several reports, attracting the eyes of scouts at many of Europe\'s major clubs.\n\nThe name had been popping up in football discourse for a few months at this stage. He was, by all accounts, a hugely talented prospect. His coaches in his native Moldova couldn\'t speak highly enough of him. Reports of his performances on the field pointed to a generational talent with the potential to dominate European football for years to come. It was only a matter of time before one of Europe\'s giants swooped in to make the youngster an offer he simply couldn\'t turn down.\n\nThere was only one very small issue with the hype surrounding the teenager. The young Moldovan was merely a figment of a Mayo journalist\'s imagination.\n\nDuring the mid-noughties, the football transfer market was developing into the carnival of gossip and general silliness it continues to be known for today. Any given day would provide a new rumour that was in all likelihood built on idle chatter at best and, at worst, subterfuge. Ballinrobe man Declan Varley had become both intrigued and frustrated by the colourful tapestry of rumours that were churned out in a bid to whet the appetite of fans as the club game recessed for the summer months.\n\nIt led Varley, who is currently editor at the Galway Advertiser as well as being a celebrated author, to an idea - he was going to devise a social experiment that would explore just how far a rumour could travel. Though the true power of the internet had not yet been realised, there were already subtle signs to suggest misinformation could be propagated fair and wide. He began by coming up with the name Masal Bugduv. It was based on M\'asal Beag Dubh, which translates as My Little Black Donkey, a short story by renowned Galway author and journalist Pádraic Ó Conaire.\n\nAs an avid Arsenal fan, it was only natural that he would attempt to connect his club with the apocryphal footballer. He began by posting the rumour online on football fan blogs. But the football universe was soon eating the hoax up.\n\nFootball fans were, as is their wont, consumed by the idea of Europe\'s next young talent arriving at their club. More worrying though was the manner in which sports media, too, took the bait hook, line and sinker.\n\nAs always, the devil was in the detail. So, Varley carefully manufactured a fake backstory, including bogus quotes from people supposedly close to the teenager and reports of his exemplary performances on the field. These details were then posted online, drop by drop, allowing the rumour mill to do most of the heavy lifting.\n\nThe prodigy, fans were told, had made his debut for Moldovan side Olimpia Balti as a 15-year-old and had already scored a hat-trick in a cup game. His rise was so rapid that he had already made his senior international debut during his country\'s 2-2 draw with Armenia in May 2008. There were also reports of his participation in his country\'s World Cup qualifier with Luxembourg.\n\nThe fabrication\'s tentacles continued to grow and the Bugduvt\'s name soon began appearing in mainstream media.\n\nReputable outlets such as The Times and The Guardian began reporting about the manner in which clubs were advancing on the teenager in the hope of securing his signature. The Times ranked him as one of the world\'s best 50 young footballers. It didn\'t take long until respected "sources" were endorsing the talent. His fictional agent was also seen leaving Arsenal\'s training ground, telling reporters: "I have no doubt that he has the ability of Fabregas and Nasri, but he needs a stage to perform and prove this."\n\nVarley sat back and watched the drama unfold. He had cast the net, the fish did the rest of the work.\n\nA short while later, with no move for Bugduv coming and no sight of the teenage sensation in London, Munich, Milan or Madrid, some investigative journalists finally began to do some digging of their own and unearthed the hoax.\n\nThough Varley initially kept his silence, he eventually came forward to unveil the reasoning behind such a cunning scheme. In an interview with the New York Times, he explained how he came up with the ruse, drawing a correlation between Ó Conaire\'s donkey and the transfer market. The protagonist in Ó Connaire\'s short story "knows his donkey is useless", he said. "But [he] tries to sell it to the highest bidder."\n\nThe entire affair served as a cautionary tale for both sports journalists and football fans who consumed football content relating to their respective clubs like it was written on tablets at the summit of Mount Sinai. Journalists at reputable outlets had been exposed for failing to maintain acceptable standards of accuracy - Bugduv\'s tale laid bare how speed and the power of an eye-catching headline regularly came at the cost of truth.\n\nBut the affair also reminded readers that they have a duty to approach rumour with a sense of healthy scepticism, just as Varley did when encountering unreliable gossip day after day.\n\n"People will believe what they want to believe," Varley told the New York Times. "And there is a desire to be seen as though you are in the know, not to want to admit you aren\'t on top of the game." Alas, it could be argued that the world of football remains as gullible as ever, despite Bugduv\'s notorious rise to fame. Football has merely become a by-product of the internet, where anyone can choose what they want to believe and point to multiple supposedly reliable sources to back up their beliefs.\n\nAs former Google CEO Eric Schmidt once noted, the internet is "the largest experience in anarchy that we ever had".\n\nVarley merely exposed that fact before the rest of us had caught up with reality.', 'source': {'uri': 'westernpeople.ie', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Western People'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://www.westernpeople.ie/cms_media/module_img/7482/3741411_7_org_Masal_20Bugduv.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1450980392156862, 'wgt': 458648486, 'relevance': 26}
{'uri': '8224827006', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '10:04:21', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T10:04:21Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T10:03:47Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.5529412031173706, 'url': 'https://heraldcourier.com/sports/college/mike-vorel-college-footballs-new-normal-big-12-plants-flag-on-pac-12s-ashes/article_950e7808-ba2f-5fb5-a1ee-4b580287365b.html', 'title': "Mike Vorel: College football's new normal: Big 12 plants flag on Pac-12's ashes", 'body': 'Mike Vorel, The Seattle Times\n\nSEATTLE -- On Dec. 1, delirious Dawgs danced inside Allegiant Stadium. Purple confetti fell from the big barn\'s roof, blanketing the Pac-12 logo at midfield. Conference commissioner George Kliavkoff (remember him?) congratulated Washington athletic director Troy Dannen (remember him?) and coach Kalen DeBoer (remember him?). The field was littered with Husky legends Dante Pettis and Will Dissly and Marcus Peters and more.\n\nThe Pac-12\'s final football game -- a 34-31 University of Washington victory over rival Oregon -- ended at 8:46 p.m. Less than two hours later, the end-zone art had already been ripped out, removed and replaced. The confetti had been cleared. Boise State and UNLV would meet in the Mountain West Championship Game the next night in the same stadium. A dying conference\'s last stand was unceremoniously erased, a masterpiece on an Etch A Sketch.\n\nLas Vegas keeps no allegiances. It\'s a merciless moneymaking machine.\n\nPeople are also reading... McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Coaching innovator Mumme to serve on Sullivan East coaching staff Simmons to expand manufacturing into Russell County LITTLE LEAGUE: Good day for local teams in state softball tournament \'Vampire\' series gives Sam Reid plenty to bite into AUTO RACING: Rural Retreat native Will Hostetler\'s a hometown hero at Wythe Raceway COLLEGE BASEBALL: Chase Hungate (Abingdon) headed to Mississippi State, relishes chance to compete in SEC FOOTBALL CAMP: Former Tennessee QBs Hooker, Milton hosts football camp at Sullivan East TVA announces changes at South Holston, Boone properties COLLEGE FOOTBALL: You can find Brad Robbins (Powell Valley) coaching at UConn now LITTLE LEAGUE: Monday\'s State Tournament Results LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon falls in Virginia state title game Casino donations near $900,000 with Tuesday presentation Marketplace dining opening at Hard Rock Bristol LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon advances to title game\n\nSound familiar?\n\nAs the 2024 season approaches, college football has been unrecognizably reshaped, as conference realignment laid waste to rivalries. A game of media-rights "musical chairs" left two schools standing after the song abruptly stopped.\n\nFor better or worse, this is college football\'s new normal. The past can\'t be reclaimed. Eight months after Allegiant Stadium hosted the Pac-12\'s football finale, its most vocal adversary planted a flag on the ashes.\n\n"Being in Vegas is critically important to us," Big 12 commissioner Brett Yormark said this week while hosting his conference\'s media days at Allegiant Stadium. "Even before last year\'s realignment I said we had to be in Vegas and a little bit more west. This is the entertainment and sports capital of the world right now. So being here is critically important to our brand and our business."\n\nIn college football\'s new normal, business is booming. The Big 12 arrived this week with an air of ostentatiousness -- with showgirls in bedazzled headdresses posing for photos on the field; with the conference\'s new mascots cruising the strip in a Chevelle convertible, driven by an Elvis impersonator; with Yormark declaring: "I will not stop until we are the No. 1 conference in America."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nTo do that, he pillaged the Pac-12 for four programs -- Arizona, Arizona State, Colorado and Utah. And though the SEC and Big Ten remain college football\'s dueling dynamos, Yormark is considering selling the Big 12\'s naming rights (hello, Allstate 12!) and partnering with private equity firms to close the garish gap.\n\nIn college football\'s new normal, success is bought and sold. When asked at Big 12 media days why his program\'s recruiting has recently improved, Baylor coach Dave Aranda had an easy explanation for SicEm365.com writer Craig Smoak.\n\n"We\'re paying players," he said.\n\nThe same day, Montlake Futures -- UW\'s NIL collective -- launched the "WIN BIG" campaign, and coach Jedd Fisch implored Husky fans to help them pay for players.\n\n"As we all know, and we\'ve all read, NIL is an important aspect of retaining players, recruiting players, and most important, winning championships," Fisch said in a video message. "We know that we have one of the greatest settings in all of college football, and we know we have one of the greatest programs in all of college football. What we need to do is we need to continue to bring in the best athletes here to the University of Washington.\n\n"It will take you and your support [of] Montlake Futures. It will take your gifts, it will take your donations, and it will take your membership to allow us to bring in the absolute best players that will help us win on Saturdays and throughout all of December and January, as we enter into this conference that is one of the best, if not the best, in the world."\n\nIn college football\'s new normal, the B1G logo lives between the 20- and 30-yard line inside Husky Stadium. UW will play conference road games at Rutgers, Iowa, Indiana and Penn State this fall. The Apple Cup will be streamed on Peacock on Sept. 14 and played at Lumen Field.\n\nOh, and speaking of: the Cougs are co-captaining a conference\'s ghost ship, orphaned by the bottom line. After the Big 12 stormed Allegiant Stadium on Wednesday, Washington State and Oregon State held a more modest media event -- "After Hours with the Beavs and Cougs" -- at the Bellagio. In place of a preseason all-league list, it featured Butch T. Cougar in a crimson blazer and a bare midriff ... as well as an open bar.\n\n"If anyone has earned the right to drink," Pac-12 commissioner Teresa Gould said, according to a column by John Canzano, "it\'s the Pac-12."\n\nCollege football\'s new normal is not for everyone. It\'s an increasingly unsentimental enterprise, a place where Utah will travel to Central Florida for a Big 12 finale on Nov. 29 that no one ever wanted. Where rivalries and regionalism are exchanged for revenue. Where FOX and ESPN are left to shake the Etch A Sketch, waylaying all we knew.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'heraldcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'HeraldCourier.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/7/ec/7ec82bc0-35df-5b84-a995-675057670852/66939e4acdc5f.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C125&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9724957', 'sentiment': 0.1137254901960785, 'wgt': 458647461, 'relevance': 51}

{'uri': '2024-07-421281983', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '07:32:57', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T07:32:57Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T07:28:35Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.telegraphindia.com/sports/wimbledon-to-copa-america-euro-final-to-cricket-when-and-where-to-catch-the-sports-super-sunday/cid/2033659', 'title': 'Wimbledon to Copa America, Euro final to cricket, when and where to catch the sports Super Sunday', 'body': "July 14: It's not often that so many major events align on a single day, but July 14th, 2024 is one for the books. From Wimbledon to Berlin, Miami to Harare - today's sports action spans the globe. Whether you're a fan of serve-and-volley, the beautiful game, or willow on leather, this is a day not to be missed.\n\nThe footballing spectacle of the summer reaches its climax as England face Spain in the Euro 2024 final at Berlin's Olympiastadion.\n\nEngland, led by Gareth Southgate, will be aiming to end their 58-year trophy drought after narrowly missing out in the Euro 2020 final. For online streaming, you can enjoy the match on the Disney+ Hotstar app and website.\n\nCentre Court at the All England Club will witness a rematch of last year's thrilling final as Novak Djokovic takes on Carlos Alcaraz. The match is scheduled to begin at 14:00 BST.\n\nDjokovic, seeking a record 25th Grand Slam title, has looked imperious en route to the final. The 21-year-old phenom will be keen to prove that last year's triumph was no flash in the pan.\n\nThis generational clash between the old guard and the new promises to be a classic.\n\nWhere to watch: Unfortunately, no TV channel or streaming platform will be showing the match live in India. {'uri': '8224633450', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '07:07:44', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T07:07:44Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T07:00:20Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.886274516582489, 'url': 'https://pantagraph.com/refugees-still-a-symbol-of-hope/article_415f567e-c064-5a06-851f-b4a4c70627ee.html', 'title': "'Refugees' still a symbol of hope", 'body': 'Manizha Talash, originally from Afghanistan, will compete in breaking with the refugee Olympic Team in the Olympic games.\n\nMEGAN JANETSKY, RENATA BRITO, IRSTEN GRIESHABER and DANIELLA MATAR\n\nAssociated Press\n\nThey compete under the same flag but speak different languages and come from different parts of the world. After fleeing war and persecution at home, 36 athletes from 11 countries will compete in the Paris Games as part of the Refugee Olympic Team.\n\nThe team was created for the Rio Olympics in 2016 as a symbol of hope and to call attention to the plight of refugees worldwide.\n\nIn Paris, the refugee athletes will take the stage at a time of record global migration, with hundreds of millions of people -- many of them displaced from their homes -- working to reinvent themselves just as these athletes have.\n\nThe record migration comes alongside a rise in far-right populism across much of the world, with officials and parties in many countries promising to clamp down on immigration and asylum.\n\nAt the Games, athletes will compete in a host country where the anti-immigration far-right party saw a surge of voter support in parliamentary elections, but was beaten back by a coalition of the French left and failed to win a majority.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man found dead behind the wheel of vehicle on Veterans Parkway, police say Body pulled from Illinois River identified as Bloomington teen Bloomington man jailed on weapons, drug charges after traffic stop Flick Fact: How many State Farm employees are college educated? Bloomington woman faces DUI in crash that killed her 8-year-old son Felon held by armed resident in Macon County gets 2 years Revolution Dispensary to host grand opening Friday in Normal Man found unresponsive in Bloomington had suffered medical event, police said Opening statements begin in trial of man accused of killing teen at NYE party in Normal Shooting at Trump rally is being investigated as assassination attempt, AP sources say Normal residence heavily damaged, cat perishes in structure fire Bloomington police investigating shots fired Wednesday night Jury deliberates fate of Bloomington man charged with murder of Decatur teen Behind the Pritzker administration\'s quest to signal Illinois is \'open for business\' Flick Fact: Is there really a river under Normal?\n\nThe refugee athletes will compete in 12 sports, but for many, their journey to Paris is already a victory in itself.\n\nFernando Dayán Jorge, Cuban, canoeing\n\nFernando Dayán Jorge spent his childhood flying past rickety fishing boats and colonial houses in the bay next to his home in Cienfuegos, Cuba.\n\nSince he began practicing there with his father when he was 11, he said it feels as if he\'s lived a thousand lifetimes.\n\nThe 25-year-old canoeist was a two-time Olympian for Cuba\'s national team in Rio de Janeiro and Tokyo. Then, a gold medalist. A deserter of the Cuban team. A migrant. A maintenance worker. And a refugee.\n\nNow, he continues to rocket along on his narrow red-and-white canoe, this time flying past suburban homes in the canals winding through Cape Coral, Florida.\n\nKneeling on his boat, his oar slices through the air as his coach chants "very good work, very good work" from a boat next to him.\n\nJorge\'s eyes are fixed ahead, throwing all his force into his third Olympics.\n\n"After having written off the 2024 Paris Olympics, it\'s a massive opportunity," he said. "There are so many Cubans that come to this country and lose this dream of competing once again, simply because they don\'t know how to get back to this place."\n\nJorge was at the top of his career, having won gold in Tokyo for the 1,000-meter canoe sprint, when he took a daunting step in March 2021. While training in Mexico, Jorge defected, joining a growing number of Cuban athletes in deserting their country amid an ongoing migratory flight.\n\nSome hope to make more money than they can in the communist-run island. Others, like Jorge, say they left because of political differences over how the government treats citizens and athletes.\n\nHe left behind his home and crossed into the United States via the Rio Grande, in hopes of a better -- if uncertain -- life.\n\nArriving to Florida was, in some ways, like starting from scratch. Granted refugee status in the U.S., Jorge said he would wake up hours before sunrise to train, then work eight hours in a maintenance gig to pay his bills.\n\nHe said he watched friends forced to give up everything after migrating, but he fought to continue as a professional athlete.\n\n"I had a hard time getting out of bed every day and keeping my head on straight," he said. "I had no support whatsoever."\n\nBecoming one of the first Cubans to compete on the Refugee Olympic Team changed everything for him, he said. Still, he is among those who\'ve struggled to cover the costs of competing internationally. He opened a GoFundMe page in June to help pay his way to the Games.\n\nCuba has protested the inclusion of Jorge and Cuban weightlifter Ramiro Mora on the team, saying they should not be considered refugees.\n\nToday, Jorge\'s life in Cuba and his future in Florida seem to blend together in his home. His red, blue and white Cuba jersey sits framed over his doorway, while medals from competitions in the U.S. hang over a statue of the Olympic emblem.\n\n"To the refugees and athletes who\'ve been through the same thing, I want to tell them to not give up," he said. "No matter how dark the days become, the sun is always going to rise."\n\nManizha Talash, Afghan, breaking\n\nManizha Talash does not fear the Taliban.\n\n"I\'m here because I want to reach my dream. Not because I\'m scared," she declared from Spain, where she was granted asylum.\n\nOn the outskirts of Madrid, the 21-year-old is training hard for the Games, which for the first time will include breaking, or, as it\'s popularly known, breakdancing. Talash prances and swivels on her hands and feet to the beat of hip-hop, swooshing her black and red hair around before striking a pose signaling the end of her performance.\n\nJust months ago, she was working in a hair salon in the town of Huesca. Talash was among hundreds of Afghans brought to Spain aboard military planes following the return of the Taliban to power in August 2021.\n\nTalash first came across breaking at age 17. She saw a social media video of a man spinning on his head and was skeptical -- it must have been fake, generated by AI, she thought. But the images were real, and she said she soon became obsessed with the sport, scrolling through video after video on her phone.\n\n"I wanted to do it, I wanted to learn it," she said.\n\nShe found a club in Kabul where a dancer from the videos trained and knocked at the door. "There were 55 boys, and I was the only girl," she said. "I told myself, why can\'t a girl do this?"\n\nBreaking in some ways freed her from the problems facing young women in Afghanistan. But it wasn\'t long before Talash was noticed -- international news outlets published stories about the young Afghan woman defying cultural and religious norms. That was enough to become a target.\n\n"The Taliban don\'t like it when a girl dances," she said, even though breaking is more than that -- it\'s a sport.\n\nHer club began receiving threats, Talash said, and one day, when a bomb hit very close, local police asked them to shut down over the dangers.\n\nShe trained behind closed doors in her home until the Taliban\'s return to power. Despite initial promises that women\'s rights wouldn\'t be curtailed, women have since been barred from studying and face several restrictions on employment, travel and health.\n\n"Now, girls can\'t do anything," Talash said.\n\nShe\'s had little time to train while adapting to a foreign country, and at some points, competing in the Games seemed unfathomable.\n\n"But when my friend told me I could join the refugee team, I was so happy," Talash said. "I can now fly."\n\nMohammad Amin Alsalami, Syrian, athletics\n\nWhen Mohammad Amin Alsalami arrived in Berlin in October 2015, he was cold, lonely and homesick.\n\nThe Syrian refugee had left behind his war-torn hometown of Aleppo, fled to Turkey, crossed the Mediterranean on a rubber boat to Greece, and trekked by foot to Germany. Like millions of other migrants, he was in search of a place where he could build a future without bombs and violence.\n\nAlmost a decade later, Alsalami, 29, has been granted asylum, learned German and made new friends. And he\'s living his dream of becoming a world-class athlete.\n\nHe learned just months ago that he got the green light to participate in the Paris Games.\n\n"That moment was so wow," he said. "I get to go to the Olympics. I cried so much. It was really cool."\n\nAlsalami discovered his passion for athletics during physical education in school at age 15. A teacher noticed his talent for long jump and pushed him to participate in local and national competitions in Syria. But when civil war erupted, he could no longer practice. His family -- he\'s the youngest of nine siblings and comes from a family of tailors -- was displaced several times within Syria, then fled to Turkey. Alsalami decided to continue on to Europe on his own.\n\nHe credits his passion for athletics with getting him through the initial hardships in his new country.\n\nDuring the first weeks in Berlin, he looked up different stadiums and gyms on Google maps so he could start practicing long jump again. He remembers walking through the first snow to finally discover one of the city\'s big indoor gymnasiums.\n\n"All the other Berlin track and field athletes were training in this hall," he said. "When I came in and saw how full and how warm it was inside ... it was almost like paradise for me."\n\nOn that first day, a man watched him jump, approached him and asked something in German.\n\n"I didn\'t understand anything, not in English either," Alsalami said. "And then I said \'Hey, I\'m Syrian\' on my cellphone, and he said \'I\'m your trainer from now on.\'"\n\nHe stayed with that first coach for five years, then moved on to a different one -- and said he\'s eternally grateful to both for their support.\n\nDespite his excitement for the Games, Alsalami admits he\'s a bit sad that he can\'t represent his home country.\n\n"Syria is home, I miss it every day," he said. "In the end, that\'s my country, that\'s where I come from."\n\nIman Mahdavi, Iranian, wrestling\n\nIman Mahdavi smiles and dishes up Iranian food that he\'s cooked himself at his Milan home.\n\n"If my mum could see me now," he said with a laugh. "She wouldn\'t believe it."\n\nMahdavi hasn\'t seen his mother since October 2020, when the Iranian wrestler fled his home country over fears for his life.\n\nWith only the clothes he was wearing, Mahdavi made a harrowing journey by foot from Iran to Turkey, then flew to Italy and applied for asylum.\n\n"I didn\'t even really know where I was flying to," said Mahdavi, 29. "Luckily for me, it was Italy."\n\nOnce he was granted asylum, one of Mahdavi\'s first aims was to continue wrestling. His father, once a wrestler himself, had instilled in his son a passion. Mahdavi became a seven-time national junior champion and won more than 50 medals.\n\nThrough a friend he connected with on Instagram, Mahdavi was introduced to a gym on the outskirts of Milan.\n\n"As soon as we had him in the gym, in his first training sessions, we immediately saw that he was an extraordinary athlete, that he was a very, very high-level wrestler," said Giuseppe Gammarota, president of Lotta Club Seggiano. "We immediately started preparing him for competitions."\n\nThe gym has become like family to him -- so much so that he calls his coach, Marco Moroni, "Papi."\n\nMahdavi said his real father died of a heart attack several years ago after being mistakenly told his son died in a car crash.\n\nIt was Moroni who helped Mahdavi find a job, as a nightclub bouncer.\n\nMahdavi admits the schedule can be tough: He works from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m., goes home to sleep, then trains every day. But he has a focus that drives him.\n\n"The Olympics is a dream for any athlete who does any sport," he said. "I hope to come back from the Olympics with the best colored medal I can get. And I will also be thinking about the next Olympics, hoping I\'m still in form."\n\nAssociated Press journalists Rebecca Blackwell and Daniel Kozin in Cape Coral, Florida, and Iain Sullivan in Madrid contributed to this report.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'pantagraph.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'pantagraph.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'megan_janetsky@pantagraph.com', 'name': 'Megan Janetsky', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/pantagraph.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/a/85/a8543f5d-04f0-5bc8-8761-e67b014aa38a/669375a046ae8.image.jpg?crop=600%2C315%2C0%2C62&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9725114', 'sentiment': -0.04313725490196074, 'wgt': 458636864, 'relevance': 26}
{'uri': '8224619281', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '06:46:52', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T06:46:52Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T06:45:15Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.indiatvnews.com/fact-check/fact-check-vande-bharat-train-did-not-meet-with-accident-viral-video-false-latest-updates-2024-07-14-941717', 'title': 'Fact Check: Did Vande Bharat train meet with accident? Know truth behind viral claim', 'body': 'India TV Fact Check: A video claiming an accident involving the Vande Bharat train is being circulated on social media. India TV\'s fact-check team has investigated this viral video.\n\nLast month, the Kanchanjunga train accident occurred in Darjeeling, West Bengal. In this accident, 9 people died, and over 30 were seriously injured. Following this train accident, it is being claimed that the Vande Bharat train has also met with an accident. A video with this claim has been uploaded on the social media platform Facebook. The video was uploaded from an account named "Naresh Bihari Official," which has over 13,000 followers. Along with the video, the caption read, "What happened to the Vande Bharat?" In this video, a white train is seen climbing over a freight train after an accident. People are sharing this video, believing it to be true.\n\nWhat is the truth behind the claim of the Vande Bharat train accident? India TV\'s fact-check team has conducted a thorough investigation. The team searched the screenshots of the video shared on the "Naresh Bihari Official" Facebook account using Google Reverse Image. Several photos and links to news websites related to this train accident emerged. One link led to India TV\'s English website, which had a news article titled "Chile: At least two killed, several injured as Chilean train on test run collides with cargo train | VIDEO." This article contained the same photo as the one in the video uploaded on the Facebook account.\n\nUpon opening the link to the news article on India TV\'s English website, it became clear that the incident was not related to the Vande Bharat train. On June 20, 2024, a train accident occurred in Chile, South America. In this accident, 2 people died, and many were injured. The train involved in the Chilean accident was white, resembling India\'s Vande Bharat train. The video of the Chilean train accident was being shared on the Facebook platform, falsely claiming it to be the Vande Bharat train.\n\nAdditionally, the India TV fact-check team found another video related to this incident from the news agency Associated Press. This video was uploaded on the Associated Press YouTube channel. The Associated Press video, dated June 20, 2024, reported that at least 2 people died and 9 others were injured in a train collision in Chile.\n\nThus, the video of the train accident that occurred in Chile on June 20 is being falsely shared on social media platforms with claims about the Vande Bharat train. India TV\'s fact-check team has found the claim of the Vande Bharat train accident shared by "Naresh Bihari Official" to be completely false. No Vande Bharat train has met with any such accident.', 'source': {'uri': 'indiatvnews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'India TV News'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://resize.indiatvnews.com/en/resize/newbucket/1200_-/2024/07/fact-check-4-1720938222.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.2392156862745098, 'wgt': 458635612, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8224421025', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-14', 'time': '02:40:32', 'dateTime': '2024-07-14T02:40:32Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-14T02:39:52Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://newsadvance.com/sports/professional/hillcats-sweep-doubleheader-against-delmarva-as-chourio-velazquez-compete-in-futures-game/article_3ba0a7d6-4187-11ef-b5ce-232370e39101.html', 'title': 'Hillcats sweep doubleheader against Delmarva as Chourio, Velazquez compete in Futures Game', 'body': "Ralphy Velazquez runs to first after putting a ball in play against Kannapolis at the Bank of the James Stadium in May.\n\nBryson Gordon\n\nAs a pair of their top bats were a time zone away taking center stage with some of Major League Baseball's top prospects, the Hillcats didn't miss a beat back home, toppling Delmarva in both games of a Saturday twin bill at Bank of the James Stadium.\n\nIn the first game of the day, Lynchburg starter Alex Clemmey and reliever Deretd Parra combined to allow just three hits in the seven-inning affair, and the offense tallied seven hits to win 5-1 without first baseman Ralphy Velazquez and outfielder Jaison Chourio.\n\nThe usual two and three hitters in the Hillcats lineup were in Arlington, Texas, Saturday taking the field in the MLB All Star Futures Game, an annual exhibition during the league's All Star festivities pitting the top prospects in the game against each other.\n\nFor Chourio, it was an opportunity to follow in the footsteps of his brother, Jackson, who appeared in the game a year ago as he was rising through the prospect ranks. For Velazquez, it was a weekend that marked a year since he was a first round draft pick in the 2023 MLB Draft.\n\nThey each reached base in the game and Chourio drove in the American League's lone run with an RBI single up the middle in the fourth inning. The National League Futures team won 6-1, getting a home run from Cincinnati Reds prospect Cam Collier, who took home MVP honors.\n\nChourio started in left for the American League, getting two at-bats and driving in Yankees prospect Spencer Jones during the second. Velazquez pinch hit in the plate appearance after Chourio's RBI single and drew a walk. He struck out in his at-bat later in the game.\n\nThe two joined local college standouts Kyle Teel, the former Virginia catcher who was selected in the first round by the Boston Red Sox last season, and Gavin Cross, who played for Virginia Tech from 2020 to 2022 and is in the Kansas City farm currently.\n\nChourio is the 85th ranked prospect in baseball, per MLB Pipeline, while Velazquez is just behind him at No. 87. The two were the first Hillcats to appear in the game since Nolan Jones was selected for the 2019 edition.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nDuring the first game back home in Lynchburg, Wuilfredo Antunez stepped into the No. 2 spot in the lineup and notched two hits, driving in the first of three runs for the Hillcats in the fifth inning that helped open up its 5-1 lead. Antunez scored Tommy Hawke with the ninth triple of his season, and Esteban Gonzalez, who currently leads the Hillcats in OPS, drove in Antunez with a double one batter later\n\nThe start by Clemmey was a continuation of a nice stretch of starts for the 2023 draftee. On Saturday, he tossed 4⅓ innings while allowing three hits and the lone Delmarva run in the top of the fifth. He fanned six batters and walked just one.\n\nParra allowed no hits in his 2⅔ innings of work and picked up his second win of the season.\n\nIn Saturday's nightcap, the Hillcats offense worked nine walks off of Delmarva pitching and needed just five hits to collect eight runs. Two more Lynchburg pitchers combined to hold the Shorebirds to three hits again to pick up the 8-2 win.\n\nThe Hillcats wasted no time scoring in the first, putting three straight runners on after the Shorebirds retired the leadoff batter. Rafael Ramirez Jr. grounded out to plate Christian Knapczyk, who would go on to lead Lynchburg on offense in the game.\n\nKnapczyk tallied just one hit -- a double in the sixth that extended the Lynchburg lead to 6-0 -- but he worked a trio of walks, drove in three runs and scored twice himself.\n\nDelmarva worked a pair of runs off of Josh Harlow in the seventh, both unearned, after a Lynchburg error in the frame. Yorman Gomez got the start and worked five innings while allowing two hits. He fanned five batters and walked three while picking up his sixth win of the season.\n\nHarlow struck out five in two innings and allowed just one hit.\n\nThe Hillcats (48-38, 11-9 second half) will close out their week with Delmarva on Sunday, with first pitch set for 2 p.m., and then enjoy a midseason break as MLB holds its All Star festivities.\n\nAfter Sunday, they will return to action on Friday on the road against the Carolina Mudcats.\n\nBryson Gordon, (434) 385-5529\n\nbgordon@newsadvance.com\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '8224310104', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '23:53:42', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T23:53:42Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T23:53:09Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://pressofatlanticcity.com/news/local/acx1-studios-in-atlantic-city-hosts-90s-wrestling-con/article_0e2d410a-4147-11ef-998e-27e6f69ee638.html', 'title': 'ACX1 Studios in Atlantic City hosts 90s Wrestling Con', 'body': 'Selena Vazquez\n\nATLANTIC CITY -- The city offered a lot of great entertainment options in the 1990s, and pro wrestling was one of them, Brian O\'Connor says.\n\n"I\'m a wrestling fan in general, but watching wrestling in the \'90s was fun," said O\'Connor, 40, of Forked River.\n\nSo when he saw there was a 1990s Wrestling Con Fan Festival being held Saturday in the resort, he knew he had to attend the event with his two boys, Kevin, 14, and Brayden, 5.\n\n"I introduced my kids to the world of wrestling that I grew up watching, so this allows them to form their own opinion of the newer generation," O\'Connor said. "I grew up on wrestling as a kid, so I appreciate the impact it has on the kids. It gives them something to look up to."\n\nThe 90s Wrestling Con was hosted by ACX1 Studios (short for Atlantic City Experiences), located at 1 Atlantic Ocean on the Boardwalk. ACX1 Studios is the organization reimagining the four-story, 550,000 square-foot property formerly known as the Pier Shops into a television and media production site.\n\nPeople are also reading... Atlantic City Airshow canceled for 2024 Scientists know rising seas will one day swallow this Jersey Shore climate research center Cape May County Zoo receives $1.4 million donation Longport resident says rats are coming from borough property 5 hurt, 76 displaced in 5-alarm Atlantic City apartment fire Rents are up, but vacationers are still heading to the Jersey Shore Wildwood police identify shooting suspect Ocean City\'s Seaspray condo for sale at $7M Atlantic City High School principal accused of failing to report child abuse due back in court Aug. 29 Greg Goodwin, influential Absegami coach, dies at 63 After dream debut, South Jersey native Tyler Phillips will start Saturday for the Phillies: Must Win Egg Harbor City rescue in need of fosters, donors to help animals rescued from Galloway home Atlantic City fire union head calls for restoring of Ducktown engine in wake of Georgia Avenue blaze Cape May fishing case has national impact Route 30 reopened in both directions following repairs to Absecon Drawbridge\n\nThe event was, in a way, one of the studio\'s first major events, said Roy Koriakin, one of the co-founders of the studio and its president of film and television.\n\n"If you\'re in your 30s, it\'s like meeting your childhood heroes. It\'s nostalgic," said Koriakin, 47. "It feels good. It\'s like satisfying your inner child."\n\nThe resort has a deep wrestling history that includes having hosted WrestleMania IV in 1988 and WrestleMania V in 1989 at what\'s now known as Jim Whelan Boardwalk Hall.\n\nGame Changer Wrestling holds multiple shows a year at Showboat Resort Atlantic City.\n\nBrian Heffron, who wrestled for Philadelphia-based Extreme Championship Wrestling and then WWE, grew up in Atlantic City and graduated from the city\'s high school in 1993. He said it was also a full-circle moment for him since he worked at the Pier Shops before moving out of the city when he was 21 and making his ECW debut two years later in 1995.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"It\'s cool to come back to A.C., where I have so many memories here, and get to meet new people, or even see old friends that I used to wrestle with. It\'s like a family reunion," Heffron said. "It really is the best of both worlds."\n\nAppearing Saturday were a variety of WWE stars, as well as the former promotions of ECW and World Championship Wrestling, including Eric Bischoff, X-Pac, Scott Steiner, Jonathan Coachman, D-Von Dudley, Sabu, Sandman and more. Stars such as Blue Meanie, Big Vito and ECW referee Jim Molineaux were there.\n\nMike Kobalo, of Perth Amboy, came to see two of the most notable wrestlers from the 1990s -- Matt and Jeff Hardy of the Hardy Boyz.\n\n"Their fearlessness, the fact that they\'re not afraid to be themselves, it makes them unique," said Kobalo, 34, who was dressed in red and black with his face painted as Jeff Hardy paints his. "They were always my favorite wrestlers and still are, so this is something I wasn\'t expecting to happen ever."\n\nBesides meet-and-greets, the event featured vendors selling collectible toys, merchandise and other wrestling goodies.\n\nLike many attending, Joss Hernandez brought championship belts. Other fans wore New World Order shirts, Hulk Hogan bandanas and Hardy Boyz necklaces.\n\nHernandez, 27, of the Bronx, New York, said the event was pretty small and chill, but that allowed him to see all of his favorites, like X-Pac, Sandman and The Coach (Coachman).\n\n"It allows us to be more intimate," said Vito LoGrasso, who wrestled as Big Vito and Vito.\n\nLoGrasso said he enjoyed talking to fans and meeting the newer generation of people that still watch him perform.\n\nThere were also live matches, wrestling "Jeopardy," the Bill Apter Show, extreme Q&A with Tod Gordon, cosplay contests, ISPW Wrestling with former WWE Tag Team Champions the Head Bangers, a Hardy Party and plenty of other activities to keep people entertained throughout the day.\n\n"Usually when we get to interact with fans, it\'s right before we go on stage," Heffron said. "This is a fun way to have a conversation with them without the anxiety of being rushed into a ring."\n\nContact Selena Vazquez:\n\n609-272-7225\n\nsvazquez@pressofac.com\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '8224231001', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '22:01:33', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T22:01:33Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T21:58:55Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.nwitimes.com/news/local/groom-surprised-on-wedding-day-by-white-horse-that-made-a-scene-in-downtown-whiting/article_9e88c18a-415a-11ef-94a4-a70318307b0d.html', 'title': 'Groom surprised on wedding day by white horse that made a scene in downtown Whiting', 'body': 'Video provided in partnership with The Times, JEDtv and WJOB. Sponsored by Strack & Van Til.\n\nA well-groomed white horse with a silky mane named Beauty caused a stir in downtown Whiting Saturday, attracting many onlookers and photographers and causing passing cars to stop to get a better look or snap a quick pic.\n\nAn avid horseman was getting married at St. John the Baptist Church on 119th Street Saturday afternoon.\n\nHe had wanted to involve his horses in the wedding ceremony but couldn\'t so the women in the wedding party brought in a horse and carriage to surprise him, horse trainer Tamara Nevinger said.\n\n"The groom in the wedding is a horseman and was upset he couldn\'t have any of his courses so the gals got together to surprise him with this. He has no idea," she said. "It\'s for a nice little photo shoot so he will have a horse in his wedding photos outside the church. It was important to his family."\n\nAntique Coach and Carriage from Homer Glen supplied the horse and carriage for a photo op outside the church. The firm has brought horse-drawn carriages to weddings, quinceañeras, birthday parties and other special occasions across Northwest Indiana and Chicagoland since 1985.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\n"We\'ve done jobs in Michigan, even Iowa," Nevinger said. "We\'ve been to this same church before. We do a lot of jobs in Chesterton at the Sand Creek Country Club."\n\nThe spectacle of setting the horse up on 119th Street drew a crowd of the curious before it trotted over to the Catholic church. Beauty is a Percheron, an elegant French draft horse breed that\'s often used in harness racing. It\'s one of 10 horses that Antique Coach & Carriage keeps in its stables.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"She does light duty and gets requested for weddings because she\'s white," Nevinger said. "This should be emotional for him because of how much horses mean to him so it\'s going to be fantastic for him to see that horse. All the women in his family are doing this for him to make his day extra special."\n\nPeople often choose to surprise unsuspecting loved ones with horses at weddings, Nevinger said.\n\n"It\'s either for pizzazz or for the horse lover who\'s missing having their horse in whatever celebration they\'re doing. It\'s like having a dog lover or a cat lover. Horse lovers are the same. You just can\'t bring the horse anywhere. Just having a horse here will do a lot with him."\n\nThe horses usually turn heads when out trotting around in public, Nevinger said.\n\n"They always get attention when people see a horse on the street," she said. "Horses are one of those beautiful things that people just admire."\n\nWeddings account for about 35% of Antique Coach & Carriage\'s business, owner Debbie Hay said.\n\nHay said she sometimes gets jokes about how on-the-nose her surname is given her line of business but said it\'s from a Scottish clan she descended from. She said the firm also does cotillions, sweet sixteens and festivals.\n\n"If you wanted to have a carriage for like Pierogi Fest, we\'d come out," she said. "We\'re open year-round."\n\nA look back at Northwest Indiana businesses that closed in 2023\n\nA look back at Region businesses that closed in 2023\n\nLocal News Alert Top Story Urgent Beer Geeks craft beer bar in Highland closes, to reopen as B-Side Bar & Lounge Joseph S. {'uri': '2024-07-421034720', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '21:56:49', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T21:56:49Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T21:30:11Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.686274528503418, 'url': 'https://screenrant.com/cyberpunk-2077-timed-mission-permadeath/', 'title': 'Delaying One Cyberpunk 2077 Mission Could Mean Permadeath For One Character', 'body': 'Elden Ring: All Bell Bearing Locations In Shadow of the Erdtree DLC\n\nSummary\n\nCyberpunk 2077 doesn\'t have many time-limited quests, but the few that are included pose disastrous consequences for taking too long. The rare timed quest "Fortunate Son" can lead to losing a character permanently if it\'s not completed almost immediately, adding urgency players may not expect. Saving Scooter in "Fortunate Son" unlocks a touching scene and exclusive song, making it worth prioritizing for impact.\n\nTaking too long to complete one Cyberpunk 2077 mission could lead to the permanent loss of a recurring character. For all its open-world interactivity, Cyberpunk doesn\'t actually have many timed quests or world events. For the most part, players can complete all its main and side jobs in whatever order they wish. But it is possible to lock oneself out of certain content, either by doing certain quests in the wrong order, or by making the wrong Cyberpunk story choices at important moments.\n\nEven so, there are a few timed quests in Cyberpunk, including one that could ruin the entirety of the Phantom Liberty DLC. Their rarity actually makes them more dangerous: the player is naturally conditioned to expect the plot will wait for them. But that\'s not always the case, especially in the case of one particular side job. Its particulars do suggest the need for urgency, but other than that, the game doesn\'t make its time-limited nature totally clear. And that can lead to disaster.\n\nRelated\n\nPhantom Liberty Fixed Cyberpunk 2077\'s Biggest Open-World Issue\n\nCyberpunk 2077\'s open-world suffered from repetitive side-content; an issue that was redressed by Phantom Liberty multilayered gigs.\n\nThe Cyberpunk Side Job "Fortunate Son" Is Secretly Timed\n\n"Fortunate Son": Time Limit & Consequences\n\nClose\n\nThe "Fortunate Son" side quest in Cyberpunk has a secret timer, and one of the involved NPCs can die if the player isn\'t fast enough. This side job begins immediately after "Queen of the Highway," an important step in Panam\'s Cyberpunk 2077 questline. Talk to Bob at the nomad camp, and he\'ll explain that one of his buddies - Jake Scooter - needs a kidney, and fast. He has a lead on a cybernetic implant that could save Scooter, but it\'s all the way across town in Little China.\n\nSo V has to race across Night City in order to pick up the kidney implant, then bring it back to Bob. There are some additional wrinkles, and if the player sees things through, they\'ll learn that the police installed a virus in the implant in an effort to catch a completely different group of nomads. As long as V figures that out and explains it to Bob, he\'ll be able to uninstall the virus and save Scooter. However, it\'s easy to mess this job up long before then: take more than 24 hours to get back to Bob with the kidney, and Scooter will die.\n\nOf course, it shouldn\'t take anywhere close to 24 hours just to get to Little China and back. Instead, this hidden time limit is meant to punish players who put "Fortunate Son" off. As a result, it\'s important to watch the preceding scene carefully, and take the urgency of Scooter\'s condition into consideration. But as long as V heads out almost immediately, they\'ll get back in plenty of time, and get a nice little reward for it further down the line.\n\n2:01\n\nRelated\n\nCyberpunk 2077 Player Finds A Way To Date Every Romanceable Character At Once\n\nCyberpunk 2077 had restricted its romance options in the past, but one player has found a way to date all of the game\'s love interests simultaneously.\n\nCompleting Cyberpunk\'s "Fortunate Son" Unlocks A Touching Scene Later\n\nPlus, A Hidden Reference To The Star Ending\n\nIf Scooter is saved during "Fortunate Son," he\'ll appear later to serenade the Aldecaldos camp. Scooter has a pretty varied repertoire: he can play "The Beast of Beauclair," a boss theme from The Witcher 3\'s Blood and Wine expansion, and one of many Witcher references littered throughout Cyberpunk. He can also sometimes be heard covering fictional in-universe band Us Cracks, who can be heard on the radio throughout Night City. Their rivalry with Kerry Eurodyne also eventually plays into his personal quest.\n\nBut if V decides to ally with the Aldecaldos during "Nocturne Op55N1," they\'ll unlock an additional quest called "We Gotta Live Together." Check in on Scooter during that job, and he\'ll sing an entirely different kind of song. It\'s a tragic ballad about a rootless boy whose wanderings lead him into a deadly gunfight. There are obvious parallels to many of the game\'s most tragic figures, and the Aldecaldo nomads themselves, but the melody is borrowed from the game\'s score.\n\nThe same tune plays during "Pyramid Song," the final job in Judy Álvarez\'s storyline - the narrative about a person forced to wander after their home is destroyed makes perfect sense in the context of Judy\'s life. It also plays during The Star ending, which V has to unlock in order to hear Scooter\'s cover.\n\nSo, while Scooter isn\'t the most central character in the story, saving him does unlock a sweet scene, and a beautiful song exclusive to The Star ending. Either way, it\'s worth prioritizing "Fortunate Son" in order to save Scooter\'s life in a timely manner. It\'s one of very few time-limited quests in Cyberpunk 2077, but it leaves a lasting impact either way.\n\nCyberpunk 2077\n\nBased on the 1988 tabletop game, Cyberpunk 2077 is a first-person action RPG game set in a dystopian cyber future developed by CD Projekt Red. Players will tackle the streets of Night City as customizable protagonist V, who struggles to keep their memories intact after receiving a strange cybernetic implant that slowly overrides their memories by a deceased celebrity known as Johnny Silverhand, played by Keanu Reeves.\n\nPlatform(s) PC , Xbox One , Stadia , PS4 , PS5 , Xbox Series S , Xbox Series X\n\nReleased December 10, 2020\n\nDeveloper(s) CD Projekt Red\n\nPublisher(s) CD Projekt Red\n\nGenre(s) RPG , Action\n\nEngine REDengine 4\n\nESRB M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Strong Language, Strong Sexual Content, Use of Drugs and Alcohol\n\nHow Long To Beat 25 Hours\n\nMode\n\nMetascore 75\n\nPS Plus Availability N/A\n\nSystem Google , PC , PlayStation , Xbox\n\nExpand', 'source': {'uri': 'screenrant.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'ScreenRant'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'lee_d@screenrant.com', 'name': 'Lee D', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static1.srcdn.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/johnny-silverhand-in-the-foreground-with-judy-panam-from-cyberpunk-2077.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9735152', 'sentiment': -0.02745098039215688, 'wgt': 458603809, 'relevance': 6}
{'uri': '2024-07-421030638', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '21:44:49', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T21:44:49Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T21:44:38Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://newsinfo.inquirer.net/1960863/second-mayor-grilled-over-pogo-has-his-folks-support', 'title': "Second mayor grilled over Pogo has his folks' support", 'body': 'ANGELES CITY, PAMPANGA, Philippines -- The mayor of Porac, Pampanga, where a Philippine offshore gaming operator (Pogo) was raided last month for alleged illegal activities, has received "solid and unwavering support" from all of his village chiefs unlike embattled Mayor Alice Guo of Bamban, Tarlac, where a Pogo company was shut down in March.\n\nMayor Jaime Capil has been under scrutiny by senators investigating alleged criminal activities, including human trafficking and online scams, by Lucky South 99 Pogo company operating in his town.\n\nFollowing the June 4 and June 5 raids on Lucky South led by the Presidential Anti-Organized Crime Commission (PAOCC), Capil\'s critics accused him of being a coddler and close friend of the Pogo company\'s bosses, and published pictures of the mayor dining with them. He was also castigated during a provincial board meeting.\n\nIn last Wednesday\'s Senate hearing, Sen. Sherwin Gatchalian said he personally believed that Capil gave special treatment to the Lucky South Pogo hub.\n\nThe mayor denied being a Pogo supporter and said that he even refused to issue a business permit to Lucky South in January this year. He earlier argued that it was the responsibility of the state gaming regulator, Philippine Amusement and Gaming Corp. (Pagcor), not local governments, to monitor Pogo activities.\n\nIn a "Manifesto of Support for our Porac Chief Executive" posted on the Facebook page of the local newspaper, Punto, on June 28, all the 29 barangay chairs of the town said they believed Capil was not involved in any irregularity in relation to the Pogo company and that he was also responsible for making their town more progressive.\n\nThe manifesto was reposted on the official Facebook page of Porac town and its Public Information Office later on the same day.\n\nA rarity in Porac\n\n"We reject and disprove all baseless attempts against his leadership, to discredit his personality and character that will weaken the confidence and trust of his constituents in this Pogo crisis," said the manifesto signed by the village chiefs.\n\nAn identical statement also was signed and released by all the 29 leaders of Porac\'s Sangguniang Kabataan.\n\n"I am sincerely grateful to you for your support," Capil said during a meeting with the village chiefs on Thursday. "This is rare in the municipality of Porac when all village chiefs support their mayor. This is the first time it has happened."\n\nDuring a hearing called by the Senate committee on women, children and family relations a day earlier, Capil was questioned by Gatchalian about his office\'s supposed inaction on the alleged illegal activities at the Lucky South compound and the nearby Hotel Royal leased by the Pogo company.\n\nSen. Risa Hontiveros, the committee head, said Capil did not respond to a July 19, 2021, letter from Police Maj. Arvin Hosmillo, the Criminal Investigation and Detection Group chief for Pampanga, who reported alleged serious illegal detention, cybercrime, prostitution and illegal drug activities going on at Hotel Royal, formerly known as Hotel Aramis.\n\nThe mayor repeatedly insisted that he did not receive the letter.\n\n\'Convenient excuse\'\n\nWhen Hontiveros pointed out that the letter had a receipt stamp from the municipal government, Capil replied: "I am sorry but, in all honesty, I didn\'t get that letter. If I had only received it, I would have taken action."\n\nHontiveros described Capil\'s answer as "regrettable" and Gatchalian called it a "very convenient excuse."\n\nCapil also said that there was no Hotel Royal in his town.\n\nBut Google Maps and Google Street Views show that the hotel is located beside the 10-hectare Lucky South compound and the Royal golf course, which is on the Porac side of the 106-ha Royal Garden Estate that straddles Angeles City and Porac.\n\nThe Angeles City business permit and licensing division had no Royal or Aramis Hotel registered in its system, indicating that it is outside its jurisdiction, according to a staff who spoke with the Inquirer on condition of anonymity for not being authorized to speak with the media.\n\nNo knowledge\n\nHosmillo\'s letter to Capil, which was coursed through the Porac\'s municipal business permit and licensing office, said that "Royal Hotel (is) located at Pulung Maba, Sta. Cruz, Porac," which is also the location of Lucky South.\n\nCapil also told the senators that he did not know about the alleged crimes at Lucky South.\n\nHe read from a "comprehensive report" by the Porac police that it had received eight separate "intelligence reports" from May 2023 to March 20, 2024 about alleged criminal activities in buildings operated by Lucky South but found no irregularities or crimes committed upon inspection.\n\nFormer Pampanga police director Col. Levi Hope Basilio reported on March 24 that the Porac Pogo hub was being used for human trafficking, kidnapping, cybercrime and prostitution.\n\nBut Porac officials only took action on his report in May. They, however, failed to conduct a proper inspection as the Lucky South authorities refused to allow them to enter the estate.\n\nPink shirts for Alice\n\nIn Bamban, about 22 kilometers from Porac, there was no similar manifesto from local officials for its suspended mayor, but hundreds of residents wearing pink shirts rallied on June 8 to express support for her. Some carried placards saying, "We love you, Mayor Alice."\n\nPosters expressing support for Guo were displayed on electric posts and fences along the town\'s major roads.\n\nElected officials, including Vice Mayor Leonardo Anunciacion, the acting mayor, councilors and village chiefs have chosen to keep a collective silence on the issues facing the mayor, including questions about her true nationality and her alleged involvement in Pogo operation.\n\nThe Court of Appeals ordered the freezing of Guo\'s assets as the Department of Justice investigates a PAOCC complaint of qualified human trafficking against her and 13 other respondents allegedly involved in the Bamban Pogo, Zun Yuan Technology Inc., which was padlocked in March.', 'source': {'uri': 'newsinfo.inquirer.net', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Inquirer.net'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'jun_a_malig@newsinfo.inquirer.net', 'name': 'Jun A. Code Generator.\n\nThe research has revealed the best 10 and worst 10 Wetherspoons pubs and the company studied a list of 869 pubs and hotels to find which had the best ratings by using the average percentage of excellent reviews posted on Google Reviews, reports The Star.\n\nOne Lancashire Wetherspoons made the list of the top 10 best and none of them fell into the list of the 10 worst.\n\nThe newspaper reports that it was The Velvet Coaster in Blackpool which is among the Wetherspoons pubs with the highest percentages of 5-star reviews on Google Reviews.\n\nThe Velvet Coaster came in at ninth place with a percentage of 55.07.\n\nWith a 4-star rating from 3,952 reviews, The Velvet Coaster has been praised on Tripadvisor too.\n\nOne reviewer said: "We stumbled across this on arrival in Blackpool as it was super close to our accommodation. We ended up eating here initially for lunch, but then every morning for breakfast, and one dinner (their Thursday curry night!). This is a really well run place! Ordering is quick and easy, food is delivered quickly, and the staff couldn\'t have been more helpful and friendly.\n\n"The food is also very good! Yes it\'s a Wetherspoon pub, but the food was always freshly prepared, tasted great, and was excellent value. I had a wrap at lunch, a variety of breakfasts (porridge, fresh fruit, cooked), and their curry night is not to be missed - very tasty curries at a great price, served with naan and rice.\n\n"The place is also modern, spacious, and relaxed, with multiple floors, outside seating (for when the sun came out!) and a variety of seating (tables, booths, bar stools, etc). Will definitely be back when we re-visit Blackpool in future."\n\nAnother commented: "Visited on a popular sunny Saturday...plenty room inside..great food and great staff, very impressed, well done to you all."', 'source': {'uri': 'messengernewspapers.co.uk', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Messenger Newspapers'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://www.messengernewspapers.co.uk/resources/images/18282782/', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.3176470588235294, 'wgt': 458600454, 'relevance': 100}

{'uri': '2024-07-420990842', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '20:02:15', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T20:02:15Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T20:00:12Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.topspeed.com/fastest-electric-suvs-ranked-by-top-speed/', 'title': 'Top 10 Fastest Electric SUVs Ranked By Top Speed', 'body': "Now that electromobility has reached the SUV world, we're starting to see some of the craziest claimed acceleration times that the segment has ever offered. Massive family movers weighing well over 4,000 pounds are able to outrun the fastest supercars from just five years ago while maintaining a substantially lower price tag.\n\nThe downside, however, is that they don't really reach that high top speeds because of their high curb weights, transmission, and battery limitations. There are some SUVs that can reach impressive top speeds by electric car standards, while still comfortably seating multiple passengers with a host of comfort and safety features.\n\nIn order to give you the most up-to-date and accurate information possible, the data used to compile this article was sourced from various manufacturer websites and other authoritative sources, including Edmunds, Car and Driver, and MotorTrend. We've ranked the models below based on their top speed figures, from slowest to fastest.\n\nRelated\n\n10 Fastest Mainstream AWD Electric Cars In 2024\n\nThere is no dearth of EVs in the market, be it RWD or AWD, and here are the 10 fastest mass-market AWD EVs that you can buy in 2024.\n\n10 Genesis GV60 Sport Plus\n\nTop Speed: 146 MPH\n\nThe Genesis GV60 Sport Plus trim features a dual permanent-magnet motor configuration, affording it a 146 MPH top speed and 4.0-second 0-60 MPH claimed acceleration time. Independent reviews reveal that you can cover this sprint in around 3.9 seconds.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nMotor Setup\n\nDual permanent-magnet motors\n\nTransmission\n\nSingle-Speed Automatic\n\nHorsepower\n\n483 HP\n\nTorque\n\n516 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nAll-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n4.0 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n146 MPH\n\nTowing Capacity\n\n2,000 Pounds\n\nPayload Capacity\n\n2,039 Pounds\n\nDespite producing 483 horsepower and 516 pound-feet outputs, this smaller EV only tows 2,000 pounds, but it can carry a more generous 2,039-pound payload.\n\n9 Mercedes-AMG EQE 53 SUV\n\nTop Speed: 149 MPH\n\nMercedes-Benz handed its mid-size EQE executive electric SUV to its AMG department, which has yielded some impressive results. With the optional Dynamic Package fitted and in launch control mode, the dual-motor configuration produces 678 horsepower and 738 pound-feet.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nMotor Setup\n\nDual Permanent-Magnet Motors\n\nTransmission\n\nSingle-Speed Automatic\n\nHorsepower\n\n678 HP\n\nTorque\n\n738 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nAll-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n3.2 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n149 MPH\n\nTowing Capacity\n\n3,500 Pounds\n\nPayload Capacity\n\n1,279 Pounds\n\nIn this state, it will sprint from 0-60 MPH in a claimed 3.2 seconds until it hits its 149 MPH top speed. The luxurious SUV can also tow up to 3,500 pounds with a 1,279-pound payload capacity.\n\n8 Tesla Model Y Performance\n\nTop Speed: 155 MPH\n\nThe Model Y Performance honors its title thanks to Tesla front AC induction and rear permanent-magnet motor configuration. This affords it a combined 456 horsepower and 497 pound-feet output, resulting in a claimed 3.5-second 0-60 MPH time and 155 MPH top speed.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nMotor Setup\n\nFront AC Induction and rear permanent-magnet motors\n\nTransmission\n\nSingle-Speed Automatic\n\nHorsepower\n\n456 HP\n\nTorque\n\n497 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nAll-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n3.5 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n155 MPH\n\nDue to the nature of its drivetrain, you can't use the Model Y for towing purposes, so it is a relatively limited crossover option. It does benefit from some of the best interior packaging, so it's not too bad of a mild utility vehicle.\n\nRelated\n\nThe 10 Lightest Electric Cars On The Market In 2024\n\nIf you're looking for an EV with lower curb weight figures, these are the only options you should be looking at.\n\n7 BMW iX M60\n\nTop Speed: 155 MPH\n\nThe BMW iX M60 is the brand's flagship all-electric model, featuring a pair of motors that the Bavarian company's M-division has specially tuned. The performance EV SUV generates a combined 610 horsepower and 811 pound-feet, resulting in a 3.2-second 0-60 MPH time and 155 MPH top speed if you opt for the Driver's Package.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nMotor Setup\n\nDual-Permanent-Magnet Motors\n\nTransmission\n\nSingle-Speed Automatic\n\nHorsepower\n\n610 HP\n\nTorque\n\n811 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nAll-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n3.2 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n155 MPH\n\nTowing Capacity\n\n5,512 Pounds\n\nPayload Capacity\n\n1,003 Pounds\n\nThis is BMW's first step into high-performance electrification in a premium SUV, and while the design may divide a lot of fans, there's no denying its performance is very impressive. It can also haul an impressive 5,512 pounds while towing and carry a 1,003-pound payload.\n\n6 Porsche Taycan Turbo S Cross Turismo\n\nTop Speed: 155 MPH\n\nNow, this might seem controversial since the Cross Turismo is more likely a wagon than an SUV, it cannot be classified in the same category as the standard Taycan, which is why we decided to add it to this list. Porsche transformed its Taycan Turbo S into a crossover by increasing the ride height and adding some plastic cladding. Thankfully, it retains the dual motor configuration, which produces 750 horsepower and 818 pound-feet.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nMotor Setup\n\nDual Permanent-Magnet Motors\n\nTransmission\n\nTwo-Speed Automatic\n\nHorsepower\n\n750 HP\n\nTorque\n\n818 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nAll-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n2.4 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n155 MPH\n\nThis is all it needs to get from 0-60 MPH in 2.7 seconds before it hits its limited 155 MPH top speed. Unfortunately, you can't use the Cross Turismo for towing, but its generous rear section can more than accommodate larger items.\n\nAdd TopSpeed to your Google News feed.\n\nFollow On\n\nGoogle News\n\n5 Kia EV6 GT\n\nTop Speed: 161 MPH\n\nThe Kia EV6 GT is the second-last South Korean EV SUV we feature on this list, which is an impressive feat considering how the Hyundai Group is relatively late to the high-performance game. This E-GMP-based EV features a pair of electric motors that generate 576 horsepower and 545 pound-feet.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nMotor Setup\n\nDual Permanent-Magnet Motors\n\nTransmission\n\nSingle-Speed Automatic\n\nHorsepower\n\n576 HP\n\nTorque\n\n545 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nAll-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n3.5 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n161 MPH\n\nTowing Capacity\n\n2,300 Pounds\n\nPayload Capacity\n\n937 Pounds\n\nKia claims that this sleek EV will cover a 0-60 MPH sprint in 3.5 seconds and reach a limited 161 MPH top speed. Independent reviews prove that it can cut its sprint time down to 3.2 seconds. Its 2,000-pound towing capacity and 93-pound payload capacity add to its versatile appeal.\n\nRelated\n\nThe 10 Most Value For Money Electric SUVs On the Market Today\n\nWith the market continuing to grow, these 10 electric SUVs offer plenty of features and capabilities for their respective price tags.\n\n4 Porsche Macan Turbo EV\n\nTop Speed: 162 MPH\n\nPorsche's all-new fully electric Macan Turbo doesn't waste any time in making a name for itself when pitted against its rivals. The top-of-the-range variant features the brand's dual-motor configuration, affording it a 630-horsepower and 833-pound-feet state-of-tune.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nMotor Setup\n\nDual Permanent-Magnet Motors\n\nTransmission\n\nTwo-Speed Automatic\n\nHorsepower\n\n630 HP\n\nTorque\n\n833 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nAll-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n3.1 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n162 MPH\n\nTowing Capacity\n\n4,400 Pounds\n\nPayload Capacity\n\n1,200 Pounds\n\nThis will get you from 0-60 MPH in just 3.1 seconds and hit a top speed of 162 MPH, making it even faster than its lower-riding Cross Turismo sibling. You can also use this high-performance EV to tow up to 4,000 pounds and carry 1,200 pounds worth of cargo in the trunk.\n\n3 Hyundai Ioniq 5 N\n\nTop Speed: 162 MPH\n\nThe Hyundai Ioniq 5 N is a purpose-built performance electric SUV, which is pretty much the first of its kind. Hyundai has evolved its N division, which is why we now have access to a 641-horsepower and 568 pound-feet electric SUV that can cover 0-60 MPH in just 3.25 seconds.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nMotor Setup\n\nDual Permanent-Magnet Motor\n\nTransmission\n\nSingle-Speed Automatic\n\nHorsepower\n\n641 HP\n\nTorque\n\n568 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nAll-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n3.25 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n162 MPH\n\nHyundai limits the top speed to 162 MPH, which sounds relatively low considering it's a full-on performance model. However, you need to consider that this EV prioritizes lap times and handling characteristics. This is something many reviewers highlight that the Ioniq N achieves with composure.\n\n2 Tesla Model X Plaid\n\nTop Speed: 163 MPH\n\nThe Tesla Model X Plaid features the Model S's triple motor configuration, producing an identical 1,020 horsepower and 752 pound-feet output. Despite this, it can't hit the same numbers as the brand's halo model.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nMotor Setup\n\nTriple AC permanent synchronous motor\n\nTransmission\n\nSingle-Speed Automatic\n\nHorsepower\n\n1,020 HP\n\nTorque\n\n752 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nAll-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n2.5 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n163 MPH\n\nTowing Capacity\n\n5,000 Pounds\n\nPayload Capacity\n\n1,115 Pounds\n\nTesla claims its largest EV will sprint from 0-60 MPH in 2.4 seconds before reaching its 163 MPH limited top speed. While impressive, this is substantially lower than the Model S Plaid's 205 MPH top speed figure. Thankfully, you can use this to tow up to 5,000 pounds and carry a 1,115-pound payload.\n\nRelated\n\nEco-Friendly Family Fun: Best Electric SUVs For Busy Parents\n\nFind out which SUVs are the most practical for families, have plenty of space for passengers and baggage, and are easy on the environment.\n\n1 Lotus Eletre R\n\nTop Speed: 165 MPH\n\nIt's quite fitting that Lotus's first-ever SUV features an electric drivetrain. Geely's substantial investments in the brand means that the British marque was able to craft a high-riding EV that reaches 165 MPH without breaking a sweat, making it one of the fastest EV SUVs currently available on the new car market.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nMotor Setup\n\nDual Permanent-Magnet Motors\n\nTransmission\n\nTwo-Speed Automatic\n\nHorsepower\n\n905 HP\n\nTorque\n\n726 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nAll-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n2.7 Seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n165 MPH\n\nThe Eletre's dual-motor configuration produces 905 horsepower and 726 pound-feet, which gets it from 0-60 MPH in a claimed 2.7 seconds. Considering this, we're sure the newcomer can achieve much higher speeds with the limiter removed.", 'source': {'uri': 'topspeed.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Top Speed'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'nikesh_kooverjee@topspeed.com', 'name': 'Nikesh Kooverjee', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static1.topspeedimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2023/02/collage-maker-19-feb-2023-04-47-pm.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1607843137254903, 'wgt': 458596935, 'relevance': 30}
