{'uri': '2024-07-420913261', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '17:19:17', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T17:19:17Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T16:54:14Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8117647171020508, 'url': 'https://internewscast.com/sport/england-supporters-rush-to-secure-tickets-for-euros-final-priced-at-12500-online-however-fans-are-advised-to-beware-of-facebook-scams-that-could-result-in-paying-a-hefty-sum-without-receiving-any/', 'title': 'England supporters rush to secure tickets for Euros final, priced at £12,500, online. However, fans are advised to beware of Facebook scams that could result in paying a hefty sum without receiving any tickets. - Internewscast Journal', 'body': 'England fans have been warned they risk losing \'a lot of money\' amid the risk of attempting to buy Euro 2024 final tickets from fake accounts and resale websites.\n\nFans have taken to social media to beg for tickets after the Three Lions booked their place in the final by beating the Netherlands on Wednesday night.\n\nSupporters are being asked to pay king\'s ransom online for a seat at Sunday\'s final against Spain.\n\nLucrative seats have been listed on high-profile ticket resale websites and social media pages after England reached the final.\n\nTickets on re-sale sites were being offered from around £2,000.\n\nUEFA have priced category one tickets for the final at €1,000 (£842), but Mail Sport has seen tickets priced as high as £12,643.\n\nA Fans First ticket, UEFA\'s lowest price category at €95 (£80), was also spotted at being on sale for as much as £7,000.\n\nMeanwhile some hospitality tickets for the game are being flogged for as much as £40,000.\n\nThe Free Lions Fan Embassy has warned fans against attempting to purchase tickets via resale websites of individuals online.\n\n\'Our advice is simple. As an England fan, you should only be purchasing tickets either through the FA if you are a member, or through UEFA,\' Free Lions told Mail Sport.\n\n\'Third party websites or random people online are too expensive and too risky.\'\n\nThe Football Supporters Association reiterated advice its Euro 2024 ticketing advice, warning fans were going to risk \'a lot money\' by attempting to secure tickets through touts.\n\n\'We are reminding supporters of the risks when purchasing tickets via unofficial third party websites or social media accounts,\' the FSA said.\n\n\'There is every chance you could lose your money and end up with no ticket - it happens to many fans at every tournament.\n\n\'Don\'t buy tickets from people you don\'t know on social media accounts - and common sense would also tell you that new accounts with low numbers of followers could very well be scammers.\n\n\'Even if they\'re "real" ticket touts you\'re going to risk a lot of money to find out.\'\n\nAdam Webb, from campaign group FanFair Alliance, warned ticket tout websites continue to buy their way to the top of internet search results.\n\nHe added that England\'s progression to the Euro 2024 final was likely to bring out scammers, who are looking to cash in on fans hunt for tickets.\n\n\'Unfortunately, high demand sports and music events also bring out scammers and speculators looking to make a quick buck. Many of whom will be listing tickets on the \'unofficial\' resale websites that pay to top Google search,\' Webb said.\n\n\'None of the tickets on these websites are guaranteed, and some probably won\'t even exist.\n\n\'It\'s hugely frustrating that Google continues to support and amplify this black market. Thankfully, the new Government has committed to protect fans by taking further action against touts - including the capping of resale prices. That action can\'t come soon enough.\'\n\nEuropean football\'s governing body UEFA had also issued warnings to fans over the use of authorised websites and social media sites.\n\nUEFA stressed that fans could be at risk of having tickets cancelled or be refused entry if they have not bought tickets through their official portal.\n\n\'Tickets purchased from unauthorised third parties, websites or agencies, as well as on social media sites, or from touts may be cancelled by UEFA at any time and fans are likely to be refused entry or be ejected from the stadium,\' UEFA stated ahead of Euro 2024.\n\n\'Moreover, under certain laws, unauthorised sale of match tickets may constitute a criminal offence and is a matter that UEFA takes very seriously.\n\n\'UEFA actively enforces its ticketing terms and conditions and, in fact, several hundred tickets have already been cancelled ahead of the UEFA club competition finals and UEFA EURO 2024 as they were offered and/or transferred in breach of the ticketing terms and conditions.\'', 'source': {'uri': 'internewscast.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Internewscast Journal'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://internewscast.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/rewrite-this-title-England-fans-scramble-to-be-a-part.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9727822', 'sentiment': -0.0117647058823529, 'wgt': 458587157, 'relevance': 32}
{'uri': '2024-07-420908841', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '17:10:53', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T17:10:53Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T16:30:10Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.cbr.com/rdr2-all-endings-explained/', 'title': 'Every Red Dead Redemption 2 Ending, Explained', 'body': 'Summary\n\nIn Red Dead Redemption 2 , player choices affect Arthur\'s honor and ultimately determine the game\'s endings. Low honor leads to a bad ending with betrayal and violence, while high honor offers a more peaceful conclusion. The epilogue allows players to continue as John Marston, seeking revenge and closure after Arthur\'s story ends.\n\nIt\'s hard to believe that Red Dead Redemption 2 is almost six years old -- it was released on Oct. 26th, 2018. In the game, players follow Arthur Morgan, a Van der Linde gang member, traveling across the Wild West, robbing people, fighting other outlaws, and hunting animals. RDR2 lets players do so many things, both good and bad.\n\nThroughout the game, players will have a variety of choices to make. Depending on what they do, it will affect their "Honor." If players do good deeds, such as saving people from being attacked or being kind to strangers, their honor will go up. If they do evil things, such as shooting innocent people or just being plain old rude, their honor would go down. It will affect a lot depending on how far their honor will go. How Arthur would talk to people on the streets, some of the latter choices, and even which ending of the game players would achieve.\n\nEnding 1: Getting the Money Back (Low Honor)\n\nIs the Money Really Worth the Backstabbing?\n\nPlayers agree that this is the definitive bad ending. Players must have Low Honor and choose to get the money.\n\nRelated\n\nHow to Unlock Red Dead Redemption 2\'s Bonus Ending (and What It Means)\n\nRed Dead Redemption 2 offers an emotional bonus ending for those players who go the extra mile. Here\'s how to unlock it.\n\nWhile the Honor System does affect how the ending is played out, there is still one choice in the story that lets players decide which direction the ending goes. In the final mission, Arthur and John confront Dutch and Micha, trying to convince the former of the latter\'s betrayal. Dutch hesitates to decide, giving the Pinkertons plenty of time to run up and start shooting. During the escape, players will have one last choice to make. They can leave John and go back to the hideout to grab the money, or they can go with John and make sure he can get home to his wife and kid.\n\nIf the player chooses to go back to the hideout, they are locked into the game\'s "bad" ending. Arthur will tell John that he\'s heading back. While John protests, Arthur gives John his hat and tells him to leave and be with his family. This where the honor system comes into play. Players will return to the hideout and grab the money that was locked in the chest. Once they leave the cave, they will be attacked by Micah and start one last fistfight. Throughout the fight, Arthur will start to get wobbly. His tuberculosis is winning.\n\nIf the player\'s honor level is low, Micah will stab Arthur in the chest. Before it can go any further, Dutch will come to stop the fight. Arthur will try one last time to convince his old friend that Micah is the reason everything went downhill. It seems that Dutch will have some clarity and start walking away from the situation, much to Micah\'s dismay. Arthur starts to crawl away, only for Micah to run up to him and stab him in the back, finishing Arthur off. At the end, players will see a wolf, symbolizing Arthur\'s low honor.\n\nEnding 2: Getting the Money Back (High Honor)\n\nMoney Is Still Not Worth It\n\nWhile the ending is still similar, some things do change throughout it. As in the previous one, players will have to choose to go back to the hideout to grab the money. This time during the fight against Micah, right before Arthur gets stabbed, he bites Micah\'s hand, separating the two before Dutch gets involved.\n\nArthur brings up a better argument to Dutch about how Micah has betrayed them. This time, while Dutch walks away from everything, so does Micah. Arthur then tries to get back to his feet, but it seems like all of his strength is gone. He looks up to a break in the trees, where the sun rests on him. He lies back down on the ground and passes away. The players will see a deer, more specifically a stag, right before the credits start.\n\nWhile this one is better than the worst ending, the way Arthur dies can be seen by fans as a bit anti-climactic. To just pass away with the view of the sun between the trees doesn\'t feel like Arthur\'s grand send-off players would hope for. Luckily for players, there are a couple more endings that they can get.\n\nEnding 3: Helping John (Low Honor)\n\nIt\'s All About Family\n\nRelated\n\nDoes Red Dead Redemption Need a Live-Action Adaptation?\n\nConsidering that it\'s one of the most popular games of all time, it\'s worth considering whether Red Dead Redemption needs a live-action adaptation.\n\nDuring Arthur and John\'s escape from the Pinkertons, the player will have a choice between going back to the hideout to get the money or go help John escape to reach his wife and child. The obvious morally correct choice is to go and help John. Players will find themselves in one last shootout on top of a cliff. After killing a few Pinkertons, Arthur realizes that he can\'t go on anymore. He tells John to leave and that he\'ll hold them back. John protests, but Arthur knows that both of them won\'t make it. He gives John his hat and tells him to run to his family.\n\nAfter John heads out, the player will have to shoot a couple of more Pinkertons, to make sure John makes it. But unknowing to both the player and Arthur, Micah sneaks in from behind and attacks him. Here they get into one last fistfight. By this point, Arthur\'s tuberculosis is hindering him greatly. Near the end of the fight, Arthur crawls towards a gun that is on the ground, but once he reaches it, Dutch steps on Arthur\'s hand.\n\nArthur pleads with Dutch, telling him how Micah betrayed them. Micah tries to refute this, but Dutch doesn\'t know what to do or who to believe. He leaves Micah and Arthur, leaving both of them in a state of confusion. Micah is furious. He walks up to Arthur and shoots him in the face at point-blank range. Arthur dies unceremoniously in the cold, wet rain.\n\nEnding 4: Helping John (High Honor)\n\nArthur Finds Inner Peace\n\nClose\n\nFans agree that this is the true ending of the game. Players must have high honor and help out John.\n\nThis ending is similar to the last one. However, when the player has high honor, it changes a lot. Running through the canyon, shooting Pinkertons, and having a one-on-one fight with Micah is still the same. But when players get to the very end, when Dutch leaves, Micah does so as well, leaving Arthur by himself. He starts to crawl through the canyon. Once he makes it to a certain point, he rests, watching the beautiful sun across the land as he passes away.\n\nFans consider this to be the true ending of the game. How Arthur passes, the location and the sight of where he passes give fans some closure. During the post-game, this is the location of where his grave will be.\n\nThe Epilogue Ending\n\n"It\'s Over, Abigail. It\'s All Over."\n\nRelated\n\n10 Things You Didn\'t Know About John Marston\'s Past in Red Dead Redemption\n\nJohn Marston\'s life is revealed across Red Dead Redemption and Red Dead Redemption 2, but fans may have missed out on aspects of this outlaw\'s past.\n\nWhile Arthur Morgan\'s story has ended, players will get to continue the game as John. They will play through John building his house, finish any unfinished quests, and get revenge on Micah. The final story mission for John finds him, Sadie, and Charles starting to climb up a mountain because they find out that Micah has been hiding up there. During the climb, Charles gets injured and has to be left behind.\n\nThey will fight against plenty of Micah\'s men. Near the top, Sadie gets injured, leaving John by himself to confront Micah. After the two exchange a few words (and Micah threatens John\'s family), the two start shooting it out. During the fight, Sadie will sneak in and try to corner Micah, only to be quickly taken hostage once Dutch enters the fray. John, Micah, and Dutch have a stand-off. Micah pleads with John to join them in starting a new heist, while John is trying to settle the situation.\n\nAfter a bit, Dutch turns on Micah, shooting him, and setting Sadie free. The player will have one more chance to shoot Micah a bunch of times before he finally dies. Dutch will make his exit, leaving the chest full of gold and money for John to have. As the team goes back down the mountain, they cut back to John\'s house, where he tells his wife, Abigail, that it\'s all over.\n\nRed Dead Redemption 2\n\nPlayed from a first- or third-person perspective, the game is set in an open-world environment featuring a fictionalized version of the United States in 1899.\n\nPlatform(s) PS4 , Xbox One , PC , Stadia\n\nReleased October 26, 2018\n\nDeveloper(s) Rockstar Games\n\nPublisher(s) Rockstar Games\n\nGenre(s) Action , Adventure\n\nMultiplayer Online Multiplayer\n\nEngine RAGE\n\nESRB M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Use of Drugs and Alcohol\n\nHow Long To Beat 50 Hours\n\nMetascore 97\n\nPS Plus Availability Extra & Premium\n\nSystem Google , PC , PlayStation , Xbox\n\nExpand', 'source': {'uri': 'cbr.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'CBR'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'jullian_brown@cbr.com', 'name': 'Jullian Brown', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/red-dead-redemption-2-horse-trick.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.2470588235294118, 'wgt': 458586653, 'relevance': 6}

He\'s part of the fraternity, no matter if he\'s here or not. He has to take care of himself and that\'s all that matters."\n\nKawhi was the most accomplished star on Team USA behind the big three of James, Stephen Curry, and Kevin Durant. The two-time Finals MVP did participate in internal scrimmages last weekend before dropping out of the camp and being replaced by Derrick White.\n\nWhite\'s inclusion has been controversial, as he was picked ahead of teammate and reigning Finals MVP Jaylen Brown. LeBron reacted to White\'s inclusion on the team.\n\n"What can Derrick White add? Just poise, his ability to guard, his ability to shoot the ball. Bringing in another championship DNA guy, it\'s great"\n\nJames seems to be on board with White being the replacement, as the low-maintenance and versatile guard would allow Team USA to not upset the team\'s internal chemistry by adding another star player. But given how all NBA stars are buying into specific roles for the Olympics, it\'s unfair to suggest that Brown couldn\'t have provided a spark while fitting into the team\'s overall plans.\n\nAll the options would be worse than a healthy and engaged Leonard, who averaged 23.7 points, 6.1 rebounds, and 3.6 assists last season as he was named to the All-NBA Second Team. It\'s unclear what his health status going into the season will be, as Leonard couldn\'t compete in the 2024 Playoffs due to injury before also dropping out of Team USA.\n\nWithout Paul George by his side next season, Leonard\'s regular season load will be heavier as well. He must take this summer and focus on himself, as Leonard inches closer to most believing he\'ll never rediscover the health he enjoyed earlier in his career.\n\nStephen Curry Was Sad To See Leonard Being Unable To Play For Team USA\n\nThe news of Leonard dropping out of Team USA was upsetting to many veteran stars on the roster. LeBron focused on hoping Leonard would take care of himself before the season started, and Stephen Curry also weighed in on the news.\n\nCurry praised Kawhi for trying his best before understanding why the USAB, Kawhi, and the Clippers took the decision to sit him out for the Olympics.\n\n"Kawhi gave it everything he had when we were preparing the last few days of camp. There were conversations between USAB leadership, Kawhi, and his team to make sure he was set up for success."\n\nThe 33-year-old Leonard might not get another shot at representing Team USA at the Olympics. While Kevin Durant could lift his fourth Gold medal this Olympics, Leonard has never been part of a medal-winning Olympic roster. Kawhi was part of the USA Select Team in 2012 and competed against LeBron and Durant on the main team, but didn\'t play in the 2016 or 2020 Olympics.\n\nWhether Leonard can represent Team USA at the age of 37 in 2028 is unknown, though the chances of the same look slim already with pundits wondering if Leonard is headed towards retirement.\n\nRelated: Grant Hill Explains Why Kawhi Leonard Left Team USA\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {'uri': '2024-07-420887185', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '16:32:58', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T16:32:58Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T16:02:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://qctimes.com/sports/bix-runnerup-achieves-olympic-dream/article_cd78f842-1dd4-11ef-831d-8be671578c7c.html', 'title': 'Bix runnerup achieves Olympic dream', 'body': "Meb Keflezighi takes a victory lap after winning the Bix 7 in 2004. Two years later, he made history by winning a silver medal in the Olympic marathon.\n\nDon Doxsie\n\nClayton Young had the second fastest qualifying time entering the U.S. Olympic marathon trials earlier this year, but he still was considered a bit of a longshot to make the team for the Paris games.\n\nBut the longshot came through.\n\nYoung, who burst on the running scene with a second-place finish in last year's Quad-City Times Bix 7, ran with close friend and training partner Conner Mantz through most of the last part of the marathon trials and the two men crossed the finish line almost side-by-side. Mantz actually was credited with first place and Young second, but both of them will be in Paris for the Olympic finals on August 10.\n\nThree-time Bix 7 champion Leonard Korir was third in the U.S. trials and also will be running in Paris, making his second Olympic appearance.\n\nYoung is the 113th former Bix 7 competitor -- the 50th man -- to make an Olympic team. With a strong effort in Paris, he could become only the sixth Bix 7 male competitor to earn an Olympic medal.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nAn early look at Davenport's plans for Main Street Landing El Compita in Davenport ordered to pay nearly $50,000 in back wages, damages to workers 7 Quad Cities restaurants that opened in June NEW DETAILS: John Deere announces another 345 layoffs at Waterloo facilities Quad-Cities business openings, closings: Shelly's Sweet Sensations, Crawford Brew Works and more Moline woman gave report of missing mail to postal worker accused of stealing mail Chicago company buys apartment buildings in Davenport, Moline Driver of vehicle in LeClaire crash identified Police identify woman killed by crash Monday afternoon northwest of Davenport Review: Lainey Wilson sings in the rain Sunday at the John Deere Classic Iowa restaurant inspection update: Grimy blenders, mouse droppings and bad sushi Hungry? The only other men who have run the Bix 7 and also medaled in the Olympics are Meb Kefelzighi (silver in 2004 marathon), John Treacy (silver in 1984 marathon) and Jim Ryun (silver in 1968 1,500 meters).\n\nA male or female Bix alum has won an Olympic medal in 11 of the last 14 games.\n\nA list of all the Bix 7 men's entries who have been Olympians:\n\nAbdi Abdirahman, U.S.\n\nBix: Second in 2002, sixth in 2011.\n\nOlympics: Five-time Olympian. Fifth in 10,000 in 1972.\n\nGerman Silva, Mexico\n\nBix: Third in 1994.\n\nOlympics: Sixth in 10,000 in 1992 and marathon in 1996.\n\nGeoff Smith, Great Britain\n\nBix: First in 1986, fifth in 1987.\n\nOlympics: Ran 10,000 in 1980 and marathon in 1984.\n\nSteve Spence, U.S.\n\nBix: Ran four times; third in 1989 and 1990.\n\nOlympics: 12th in 1992 marathon.\n\nPatrick Tiernan, Australia\n\nBix: Champion in 2022.\n\nOlympics: Ran 5,000 in 2016 and 10,000 in 2021 (19th).\n\nJohn Treacy, Ireland\n\nBix: 15th in 1993.\n\nOlympics: Silver medal in 1984 marathon, 51st in 1992 and did not finish in 1988. Ran 10,000 in 1980 and 1984 (ninth). Seventh in 5,000 in 1980.\n\nSean Wade, New Zealand\n\nBix: Second in 1995.\n\nOlympics: 83rd in 1996 marathon.\n\nPeter Whitehead, Great Britain\n\nBix: Sixth in 1995.\n\nOlympics: 55th in 1996 marathon.\n\nClayton Young, U.S.\n\nBix: Second in 2023.\n\nOlympics: Will run marathon in 2024.\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", 'source': {'uri': 'qctimes.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Quad-City Times'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'don_doxsie_newsroom@qctimes.com', 'name': 'Don Doxsie Newsroom', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/qctimes.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/7/dc/7dcfa9d8-1dd6-11ef-8e5c-bb5f7ae88347/665754fd07889.image.jpg?crop=1505%2C790%2C0%2C292&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.3098039215686275, 'wgt': 458584378, 'relevance': 7}
{'uri': '8223958328', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '16:23:35', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T16:23:35Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T16:22:19Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://buffalonews.com/sports/professional/nfl/bills/jack-kemp-pro-football-hall-of-fame-buffalo-bills-afl-nfl/article_1d8d0eae-3fa9-11ef-a24c-97b06e477f22.html', 'title': "Bills mailbag: Assessing Jack Kemp's worthiness as a Hall of Fame candidate", 'body': 'It is still the quiet part of the NFL schedule before the start of training camps, but we have plenty of hot topics from fans in this week\'s mailbag.\n\nBill Gordon from North Buffalo asks: How come Jack Kemp isn\'t a Pro Football Hall of Famer, and what\'s your view on his worthiness?\n\nMark: Kemp would have been 89 years old on July 13, and he is worthy of consideration as a senior candidate to the hall.\n\nLet\'s review the case for Kemp. He quarterbacked teams to the AFL championship game five times in the first six years of the league. He won with the Bills in 1964 and 1965. He lost in the title game in \'60 and \'61 with the Chargers and in \'66 with the Bills. He was the title game MVP in \'64 and \'65. He was the AFL MVP for the \'65 season. He was 65-37-3 as a starter, which speaks to his greatness as a field general and leader. He has the most total passing yards in AFL history with 21,218.\n\nPeople are also reading... At least four tornadoes, two packing 110 mph winds, hit Western New York, weather service reports Man shot dead by Buffalo police is brother of slain 12-year-old Watch: Video shows Buffalo man killed by police sped off with officer clinging to car Alan Pergament: \'Beatles\' host JP leaves WECK after disagreement with station owner Buddy Shula Pregnant in her sophomore year, Bennett High School graduate finds self-worth - with plenty of help Stop and look: How the new Bills stadium is already drawing in spectators Bills quarterback Mitch Trubisky finds his way back home Do the Sabres need a goal-scorer after landing Ryan McLeod to center the third line? \'Quite an undertaking\': Cleanup starts after Beryl blows through Western New York Erie County real estate transactions Ryan McLeod\'s \'whirlwind\' trade has new Sabres center \'excited\' to get to Buffalo \'The numbers are just astronomical:\' Why developers are putting more projects on hold State agency, waterside attraction leaders losing patience with stalled project at Canalside Fear of assassinations, witness retaliation sparks dispute over evidence in Gerace, Outlaws Motorcycle Club case Free concerts fill Buffalo parks with rock, jazz and country\n\nKemp had big-time arm talent. He had a cannon and was a superb downfield passer. He led the AFL in yards per attempt in \'60 and \'64, was second in \'61 and third in \'63.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nAnother strength: Kemp was a fine runner. He scored 40 career rushing touchdowns, second in pro football history at the time of his retirement behind Otto Graham\'s 44. Now Kemp is fifth in career QB rushing TDs (Cam Newton is first with 75, Josh Allen second with 53).\n\nMy opinion is Kemp is in the "Hall of Great," but is not a Hall of Famer. My biggest reason is Greater Buffalo Sports Hall of Fame sportswriter Larry Felser never strongly advocated for Kemp to be enshrined. Felser liked and greatly respected Kemp, but didn\'t think he quite made the grade. Felser\'s mission was to get guard Billy Shaw elected, which happened in 1999.\n\nThe No. 1 reason the Bills won back-to-back titles was their great defense, which led the league in fewest points allowed in \'64, \'65 and \'66. The best element of the \'64 offense was the rushing game, which ranked No. 1 thanks to Cookie Gilchrist. Kemp was brilliant amid a slew of offensive injuries in \'65. But again, the defense led the way, and the passing game ranked seventh (out of eight) in the AFL. Kemp was ninth, sixth and seventh in passer rating index in the AFL from \'64 to \'66.\n\nThe Buffalo-area voter on the Hall of Fame selection committee is Greater Buffalo Sports Hall of Famer Vic Carucci. Carucci is a strong supporter of Kemp\'s candidacy, for all the positive reasons outlined above. The Hall of Fame is subjective. The pool of senior candidates is deep, but Kemp still has a shot.\n\nJames Cook hosts three days of kids football camps: \'Giving back is always good\'\n\nCampers ages 6 to 16 spent a few hours on the field running through different drills, and even getting to play some seven-on-seven with Cook, who played quarterback throughout the day.\n\nEd Helinski asks: What\'s your opinion on why Shaq Lawson hasn\'t been signed by the Buffalo Bills or anyone else? Has his ship sailed and his pro football career gone kaput?\n\nMark: Lawson played 30% of the defensive snaps last season and managed just one sack. He is 30. He still can play. NFL teams could do worse than him, but he is a No. 5 defensive end at this point, and hasn\'t been as effective as he was in 2019 in Buffalo when he had a career-best 6.5 sacks.\n\nLawson is a stout edge defender against the run. The Bills essentially replaced him - and they hope upgraded a bit - when they gave a one-year contract to Dawuane Smoot. He is 29 and 6-foot-3, 275 pounds. Big. He had between five and six sacks for four straight years from 2019 to 2022. He had just one sack for Jacksonville last year while playing 30% of the snaps.\n\nBills position preview: Front office runs it back at tight end\n\nThe position is looked at as a strength of the roster heading into the 2024 season, which will be offensive coordinator Joe Brady\'s first full season on the job in Buffalo.\n\nThe Bills face some tough rushing teams this season, starting with the opener against Arizona, which was fourth last year in rushing. Baltimore, Miami, Indianapolis (probably), Detroit and San Francisco are other tough run teams on the schedule. The Bills are going to need the stout Smoot on the edge in those games, especially. Expect Smoot and Casey Toohill to rotate between No. 4 and No. 5 at defensive end, depending on the matchup.\n\nJeffrey Miller asks: A non-Bills question, but certainly in their interest. What is the contract situation with Travis Kelce? How much does he make and for how long? Because the Chiefs have so much vested in Patrick Mahomes, as the Bills have with Josh Allen, will they be able to afford him "perpetually?" And at what sacrifice to the rest of the team? Of course, you know what answer I\'d like to see.\n\nMark: You\'ll be happy to know Kelce turns 35 on Oct. 5. You\'ll be unhappy to know great tight ends Tony Gonzalez and Jason Witten were mostly great through their age-37 season. Antonio Gates started to tail off at age 35. Shannon Sharpe was great through his final season at age 35.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nKelce had 93 catches last season, third-most among tight ends. He\'s making $17 million a year, tops at the position, and his deal runs through 2025.\n\nKelce\'s contract is a bargain, because he is the No. 1 weapon in the offense. So while his contract is big, it is relative peanuts compared with wide receivers who are by far the No. 1 target in their offenses. Minnesota\'s Justin Jefferson averages $35 million a year. Cleveland\'s Amari Cooper, the 20th-highest paid wide receiver according to Spotrac.com, makes $20 million a year. Jacksonville\'s Gabe Davis makes $13 million a year, tied for 28th.\n\nYou could argue that the value they\'re getting from their No. 1 receiving weapon puts them $10 million to the good versus most other teams in the league. (This also is a reason why if Dalton Kincaid can keep ascending, he could be a big, long-term value for the Bills, even on a second contract. But that\'s a story for a year or two from now.) The Chiefs easily could get out of the Kelce deal after this season, but why? It is far more likely he has another good year and they extend him.\n\nThere s a better chance that Kelce has age-related injury issues the next couple years than he becomes cost-prohibitive to the Chiefs. But that is probably wishful thinking for Bills fans. Kelce has missed five games in the last 10 years.\n\nWhy Bills trust Quintin Morris in any role at tight end\n\nAs the No. 3 tight end on the active roster, Morris has to be prepared to step in for either Dawson Knox or Dalton Kincaid, who are used in different ways.\n\nEric Kollig asks: Straight up, do you think Josh Allen will win Buffalo its first Super Bowl? And: Was there one commonality that stopped the 1990s Bills from winning one? Or was it individual differences each year?\n\nMark: I\'d be lying if I told you my crystal ball is any better than yours on the Super Bowl over the next 10 years. As long as Allen is healthy, the Bills should be in the hunt to win the AFC title for the next eight years or so. Let\'s talk short term. If you told me Von Miller or Greg Rousseau were getting 12 sacks this year, I would say the bar for the Bills is making the Super Bowl. The Bills will be in good cap shape in 2025. I\'d say their Super Bowl chances will be even better in 2025 than 2024.\n\nAs for the Super Bowls, how much time do you have? The biggest reason they didn\'t win Super Bowl XXV was their defense played a bad game against a bland offense, which stayed on the field 40 minutes. If the defense gets just one more third-down stop, the Bills probably win. After that, the Bills\' defense was inferior to great opposition defenses. The Bills\' defense ranked 19th, 14th and fifth in points allowed the last three Super Bowl seasons (and were 27th in yards in 1991 and 1993). The opposing teams\' defenses ranked second, fifth and second in points allowed those three years. (The Giants were first in 1990). The Bills couldn\'t stop the Cowboys\' power-run game. In fairness, Dallas had one of the greatest running backs and offensive lines of all time. Give the Bills credit for getting past Dan Marino (twice) and John Elway in the absolute prime of their careers from 1990 to \'92.\n\nBills position preview: Stoutness of middle three looks like asset for offensive line\n\nThe middle three is looking just as stout if not stouter this season. Connor McGovern moves over to center to replace Mitch Morse, and David Edwards takes over at left guard.\n\nEdward Doody asks: Do you know if the new Bills field will be big enough to host major international soccer events? Would they be able to lay sod over the turf? It would be nice to have a USA venue that is not also a home crowd for team Mexico.\n\nMark: It would be big enough. Numerous NFL stadiums also host MLS teams, including Gillette Stadium in Foxborough, Massachusetts, Bank of America Stadium in Charlotte, North Carolina, and Soldier Field in Chicago. The international requirement is 110 to 120 yards long by 70 to 80 yards wide. The NFL field is 120 yards by 53.5 yards. (Actually, the FIFA "recommendation" is 114 by 74 yards, but there\'s wiggle room.) New Highmark Stadium will have natural grass. We\'d be talking a North American (CONCACAF) match or an international friendly. Whether Buffalo would or could lure such an event - given there are 27 MLS markets with a far better track record of supporting soccer - is uncertain.\n\nEric Tichy asks: Is it just me or do Bills receivers with Allen not have a lot of YAC? So often it seems receivers have to make a play for the ball rather than make a catch in stride and rack up yards afterward.\n\nConnor McGovern is \'going back home\' to center on Bills\' offensive line. Here\'s why that matters\n\nThe Bills love what they saw last season from Connor McGovern, who they signed in March 2023 as a prime free-agent acquisition from Dallas. And while McGovern gives Morse proper respect, he has no apprehension about moving from guard to center this season. "I would say center is my natural position," McGovern said. "So it\'s just going back home."\n\nMark: The answer is yes. In 2021, Brain Daboll\'s last year as coordinator, the Bills were 32nd in average YAC yards per catch (4.2), according to Sportradar. In 2022, they were 26th in total yards after catch and 26th in YAC yards per catch (4.37).\n\nIt got better last year. The Bills improved to 15th in total yards after catch with 2,046, according to Pro Football Focus and ranked tied for 20th in YAC yards per catch (5.1).\n\nThe Bills got better receiving production out of running back James Cook, tight end Dalton Kincaid and slot receiver Khalil Shakir. Stefon Diggs led the Bills in YAC, but his total was just about the same as the previous year.\n\nCook had 405 yards after catch, compared with 259 by Devin Singletary in 2022. Cook\'s YAC per reception was 9.2, 12th best among backs with at least 20 catches.\n\nShakir had 286 yards after the catch and an average of 7.3 yards after catch per reception. That ranked third best in the NFL among any wideout with at least 20 catches. Kincaid had 104 more yards of YAC than Dawson Knox did in 2022.\n\nYAC isn\'t the ultimate goal, of course. Cole Beasley in his prime didn\'t get a lot of YAC, but he got such great separation, it far outweighed his modest YAC totals. Still, you\'d like to be at least in the middle of the pack.\n\nThank you for all the questions this week!\n\n0 Comments Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '2024-07-420820220', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '14:43:30', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T14:43:30Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T14:30:10Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.cbr.com/rdr2-rockstar-most-detailed-game/', 'title': "10 Ways Red Dead Redemption 2 is Rockstar's Most Detailed Game", 'body': "Red Dead Redemption 2 has been celebrated for its meticulous historical accuracy since its release in 2018. This vast open-world outlaw adventure has fundamentally altered the way players view realism in games. Players who value exploration and discovery enter the world Rockstar carefully crafted for an immersive and detailed experience where freedom is in the expression of the game's most realistic elements, from touching and horrifying animal behaviors to seemingly lifelike NPCs.\n\nThe majority of player freedom in Red Dead Redemption 2 is crafted not as inherent problems to be solved but as engaging, thoughtful experiences to be observed and reacted to. Whether or not players decide to engage with these details, the gameplay is affected every step of the way.\n\n10 Weapons Are Not as Effective When Not Maintained\n\nChores Connect Players' Actions with the Realistic Evolution of Surroundings\n\nClose\n\nRelated\n\nRed Dead 2 Lets Gamers Live Out Their Wildest Westworld Fantasies\n\nWhile Westworld isn't coming back, fans can still experience a breathing, living Western world in the form of Red Dead Redemption 2.\n\nWeapons in Red Dead Redemption 2 require regular maintenance to function properly. Visually, the guns will build up dirt and rust based on player actions moving through mud and water, which signifies needed player action to remove. If neglected, this will make the game harder, suggesting players must slow down, be observant of their resources, and engage with more of the game's details for the optimal gameplay experience.\n\nThis realistic approach rewards thoughtful gameplay with optimization, and doesn't only apply to weapons but also in doing chores around camp for more positive interactions with NPCs, bonding with the horse to unlock new mechanics, and being mindful of the time and location of player behavior to affect anything from dialogue to honor level, the latter of which has lasting effects throughout the game.\n\n9 NPCs Escape Hogties if Left Unattended for Too Long\n\nDynamic NPC Reactions to Time-Related Player Inaction Create Realism in Gameplay Decisions\n\nPlayers cannot passively take action without considering the consequences in Red Dead Redemption 2. One of the best examples of this is how NPCs will react to player actions such as hog-tying. In many games, combative actions might trigger passive behavior from the NPC, already resulting in a win for the player, but for more realism, the NPCs don't give up so quickly. They fight back in many complex situations, from being hogtied or when bumped into on the street. This necessitates a more strategic approach, making the gameplay more challenging and engaging.\n\nWhile these actions may seem, on the surface, to merely create more work for players and mindless tasks in order to solve ordinarily simple problems (something cheats in RDR2 could help get around), they also add a layer of complexity that can result in new strategic gameplay, such as needing to finish off the rest of a group quickly, or throw the hog-tied enemy on the horse and escape before they can.\n\n8 Precise Shooting Provides Non-Lethal Strategy of Shooting Guns Out of Hands\n\nRealistic NPC Reactions to Player Actions Give Players Strategic Options in Combat\n\nRed Dead Redemption 2 has dynamic results associated with where the player shoots an NPC, which can lead to strategic gameplay decisions, such as non-lethal interactions from shooting the gun out of someone's hand instead of killing them. This offers players more choices in how they use their tools, not for efficiency, but for a more human result since players are able to complete some encounters with less violence, which can affect wanted levels and have repercussions throughout the game.\n\nShooting an enemy's hand is not a mechanic commonly found in other games and requires players to aim carefully and consider the consequences of their actions. This mechanic not only adds a layer of strategy but also emphasizes the game's commitment to realism.\n\n7 Corpses Attract Scavengers if Left Out in the Open\n\nRealistic Wildlife Interactions Create an Ever-Changing Environment\n\nClose\n\nRelated\n\n15 Secrets You Didn't Know Were Hidden In Red Dead Redemption 2's Map\n\nRed Dead Redemption 2's enormous map contains several secrets, hidden locations, and unforgettable encounters that keep players coming back.\n\nEvery game approaches the results of violence differently, but many opt to brush by what happens to all the corpses left in a player's wake. While some may include features for NPCs to find bodies and alert them to the player's presence, Red Dead Redemption 2 takes it a step further with a realistic approach, allowing wildlife to interact with bodies as well.\n\nIf players leave the results of their violence out in the open, animals may come to scavenge the body, so time is of the essence in skinning and taking animal meat, hiding bodies from NPCs who might be alerted from a much further distance when they say animals swarming and even needing to hide bodies in areas they wouldn't normally consider in other games. While this may seem like an unnecessary feature taking realism a step too far, this detail also allows for unique experiences and player creativity in disposing of the results of their actions, which can force players to examine if their violence is worth the consequences.\n\n6 Construction Progresses in Towns Over Time\n\nEvolving Environments Reflect the Passage of Time\n\nIn many games, players are left wondering why NPCs work so hard, to no avail, but in Red Dead Redemption 2, players who keenly observe their surroundings as time passes in the game, are rewarded. In the towns, there are buildings under construction at the beginning of the game that are completed by the end. One such evolving building is a restaurant in Valentine.\n\nBuildings are not the only things that change as time passes in the game; Arthur's hair grows and can be maintained, cut, and styled by the player, and players can watch railroad tracks being hammered down and progressively added. In fact, the Central Union Railroad construction allows players to perform missions for the group, and throughout the chapters, the camp moves further along the tracks until it disappears, entirely, at the railroad's completion.\n\n5 Frogs Croak in Swamplands\n\nAuthentic Sound Design Immerses Players\n\nMuch work was put into the sound design in Red Dead Redemption 2, which is arguably one of the most immersive features of the game. Players can close their eyes and determine what type of ground they're passing over, if weather patterns are shifting, and where they are geographically, simply by the realistic sounds.\n\nThese aren't simply random auditorily pleasing sounds, from leaves rustling in the wind, rain and thunder creating an oppresive sound fitting of the decreased visibility, flies buzzing around decomposing items, gunshot variations indoors and outdoors, and frogs croaking in a swampland, the realistic sounds make players feel immersed in RDR2's world.\n\n4 Eating Results in Weight Gain and Loss\n\nRealistic Character Changes Give Players Motivation to Manage Health\n\nClose\n\nRed Dead Redemption 2 gives players visual cues of realistic progression due to player actions, such as if you feed Arthur too much and aren't keeping him active, he'll gain weight. This mechanic doesn't just affect Arthur visually, gameplay is drastically affected by his food intake.\n\nOpting for this realistic approach to food consumption also influences players to interact more with the environment around them in hunting, fishing, cooking, and donating to the camp's food stores in order to provide an optimal gameplay environment. This feature affects nearly every facet of the game in arguably the most realistic way any video game has ever done.\n\n3 NPCs Feel More Realistic Due to Detailed Routines\n\nNPCs Have Scripted Routines With Just Enough Dynamic Features to Feel Multi-Dimensional\n\nRelated\n\nRed Dead Redemption 2: 5 Side-Quests Every Player Should Complete\n\nRed Dead Redemption II has a big world with many fun distractions, with these being among the most fulfilling and notable among players.\n\nNPCs in Red Dead Redemption 2 have detailed schedules and routines based on loose stories to create what feels like living and breathing characters. These routines provide a foundation for more organic reactions to events in the world, such as weather, along with those caused by the player's decisions.\n\nPlayers can follow NPCs and find them to have specific work schedules as in many other games, but unique to RDR2 is the ability to follow NPCs to lunch and extracurricular activities such as dinner, drinks, and poker at the Saloon. This can result in unique, planned opportunities for the most committed players.\n\n2 NPCs React to Blood and Mud Accumulation on Clothing and Skin\n\nDynamic NPC Reactions to Player Actions Give Seemingly Conversational Experiences With NPCs\n\nArthur's hair isn't the only maintenance players can affect in Red Dead Redemption 2, and one specific feature is much more eventful if players choose to neglect it. If players fall into the mud or get blood on them during a fight, Arthur visually stays dirty, and they'll need to wash him by purchasing a bath at a local hotel or taking a dip in a stream.\n\nIf players choose to ignore this feature, they'll find NPCs won't take kindly to Arthur's health choices and will comment on his disheveled appearance. When pairing these NPC reactions with their routines and memories of players' past actions, the uniquely layered character interactions become multi-dimensional, realistic-seeming conversations.\n\n1 Horses' Muscles Move and Anatomy Changes Realistically in Weather\n\nDetailed Horse Design Creates Bonding Experience for Players\n\nClose\n\nRelated\n\nRed Dead Redemption 2: What Do Arthur's Dreams About the Wolf and Deer Mean?\n\nThe symbolic nature of the animals in Arthur's visions speaks profoundly about the nature of Red Dead Redemption II's central theme.\n\nMany players' favorite details to mention are those associated with their horses. Red Dead Redemption 2 requires significant time spent with horses, no matter how players engage with the game, and no details were spared on this important feature.\n\nFrom weather realistically altering the horses' anatomy, to players bonding with their horse by frequent caretaking, to muscle contractions during movements, to dust kicked up behind their hoves, to being upset if players approach without a calm demeanor, to custom naming for each stabled furry friend, the horse is one of the most memorable and detailed experiences players can have in the world of Red Dead Redemption 2, and for many players, won't soon be forgotten.\n\nRed Dead Redemption 2\n\nPlayed from a first- or third-person perspective, the game is set in an open-world environment featuring a fictionalized version of the United States in 1899.\n\nPlatform(s) PS4 , Xbox One , PC , Stadia\n\nReleased October 26, 2018\n\nDeveloper(s) Rockstar Games\n\nPublisher(s) Rockstar Games\n\nGenre(s) Action , Adventure\n\nMultiplayer Online Multiplayer\n\nEngine RAGE\n\nESRB M for Mature: Blood and Gore, Intense Violence, Nudity, Sexual Content, Strong Language, Use of Drugs and Alcohol\n\nHow Long To Beat 50 Hours\n\nMetascore 97\n\nPS Plus Availability Extra & Premium\n\nSystem Google , PC , PlayStation , Xbox\n\nExpand", 'source': {'uri': 'cbr.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'CBR'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/arthur-morgan-horse-and-poker.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.06666666666666665, 'wgt': 458577810, 'relevance': 7}
{'uri': '8223790838', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '13:34:48', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T13:34:48Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T13:34:26Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.929411768913269, 'url': 'https://siouxcityjournal.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/donald-trump-election-2024-black-latino-voters-support-poll-shows/article_a9296013-29d8-5691-af81-5b420e621bbf.html', 'title': "Trump wants Black and Latino support. But he's not popular with either group, poll analysis shows", 'body': 'WASHINGTON -- As he prepares to accept the Republican nomination for the third time, Donald Trump has promised new efforts to expand his coalition -- and, in particular, to win over more of the nonwhite voters who largely rejected him during the 2020 election.\n\nBut an AP analysis of two consecutive polls conducted in June by the AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research shows that about 7 in 10 Black Americans have a somewhat or very unfavorable view of Trump, as do about half of Hispanic Americans. While both groups do see Trump a little more favorably than when he left office in 2021, their opinion of him is still more negative than positive.\n\nAny gains in support among Black or Hispanic Americans would be helpful for Trump, who won 35% of Hispanic voters and 8% of Black voters in 2020, according to AP VoteCast, and has struggled to grow his appeal beyond his base. He\'s hoping, in part, to capitalize on frustration with his opponent, since President Joe Biden\'s favorability among Black and Hispanic Americans has also fallen since 2021. It\'s not clear, though, that Biden\'s loss of enthusiasm among Black and Hispanic adults is helping Trump\'s own standing among these groups.\n\nPeople are also reading... McCook Lake Association president: \'There\'s really no compensation\' for flood losses Belly up to the bar-cade: Warp Zone brings bar and arcade combo to downtown Sioux City Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for July 8, 2024 Sioux City woman claims $300,000 lottery prize 1 killed, 1 hurt in crash near Lake Park REVIEW: Bleachers teach plenty at Saturday in the Park Panel looks to release more water from Okoboji lakes without hurting flood-stricken Spencer, Cherokee Iowa legislator J.D. Scholten earns win in last-minute start for Sioux City Explorers Woman arrested after chase exceeding 115 mph on I-29 High school softball: Sioux City West snaps 12-year postseason drought with win City of Okoboji urges governor to increase releases from Iowa Great Lakes High school baseball: McCarty leading successful, youthful MOC-FV squad into playoffs 10 taken into custody in Storm Lake standoff Portion of Outer Drive to temporarily close Ex-Ponca city clerk charged with destroying public records\n\nMost Americans have a negative view of Trump, according to the AP-NORC analysis, which combined two polls conducted close together to yield a bigger sample size. About 6 in 10 U.S. adults have a very or somewhat unfavorable opinion of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable opinion. Overall views of Trump were similar in January and July 2021, too, in the months after Biden took office.\n\nViews of Trump are generally very stable -- even a felony conviction didn\'t change how Americans see him. After he was convicted in May of 34 felony counts in New York for falsifying business documents, polls from the AP-NORC Center found that overall views of Trump barely budged. During the Trump presidency, Gallup polls found that Trump\'s average job approval rating was 41%, and it never exceeded 50%.\n\nTrump has said on the campaign trail that he has "great support" from Hispanic communities. But the AP analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of Trump. About 4 in 10 Hispanic adults in the recent AP-NORC polls see Trump positively, up from about 3 in 10 in January 2021.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAnd even though Trump\'s campaign advisers have said he has specific appeal among Hispanic men and younger Hispanic adults because of his business focus, that\'s not what the poll analysis shows. Current views of Trump are similar among Hispanic men and women, older and younger Hispanic adults, and those with and without a college degree.\n\nBiden, too, is facing a perception problem among this group. The new analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable view. That\'s a substantial decline from early 2021, when about 6 in 10 Hispanic Americans saw Biden positively.\n\nBlack voters weigh in on 2024 election\n\nRepublicans are looking to pick up support in the Democratic city, and Black voters will play a crucial role in deciding who wins battleground...\n\nThe Trump campaign has claimed that he could perform better among Black adults this year than in 2020, speculating that his legal woes could endear him to a community that has faced systematic discrimination by the criminal justice system, and that his immigration policies could also hold appeal.\n\nBlack adults continue to have broadly negatively views of Trump, however: About 7 in 10 Black adults have an unfavorable view of Trump, a decrease of about 20 percentage points since early 2021. And although the Trump campaign has said Black men may be more receptive to his message, Black men and women have similar views of him.\n\nYounger Black Americans might be a little more open to Trump\'s appeals. About one-third of Black younger adults -- those under 45 -- see him positively, compared to around 1 in 10 Black adults who are 45 or older. But most younger Black adults view him unfavorably.\n\nAbout 6 in 10 Black Americans, meanwhile, have a positive view of Biden -- down from 8 in 10 when he took office.\n\nThe suburban problem that could cost Trump the election The suburban problem that could cost Trump the election Contributions speak to one part of a complex story Is the drop in Trump\'s fundraising a red herring or a reliable sign of what\'s to come? 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'siouxcityjournal.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Sioux City Journal'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@siouxcityjournal.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': True}, {'uri': 'rebecca_blackwell@siouxcityjournal.com', 'name': 'Rebecca Blackwell', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/siouxcityjournal.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/a/92/a9296013-29d8-5691-af81-5b420e621bbf/6691427d11da3.preview.jpg?crop=709%2C372%2C471%2C53&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9723557', 'sentiment': 0.1372549019607843, 'wgt': 458573688, 'relevance': 26}

But he's not popular with either group, poll analysis shows", 'body': 'WASHINGTON -- As he prepares to accept the Republican nomination for the third time, Donald Trump has promised new efforts to expand his coalition -- and, in particular, to win over more of the nonwhite voters who largely rejected him during the 2020 election.\n\nBut an AP analysis of two consecutive polls conducted in June by the AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research shows that about 7 in 10 Black Americans have a somewhat or very unfavorable view of Trump, as do about half of Hispanic Americans. While both groups do see Trump a little more favorably than when he left office in 2021, their opinion of him is still more negative than positive.\n\nAny gains in support among Black or Hispanic Americans would be helpful for Trump, who won 35% of Hispanic voters and 8% of Black voters in 2020, according to AP VoteCast, and has struggled to grow his appeal beyond his base. He\'s hoping, in part, to capitalize on frustration with his opponent, since President Joe Biden\'s favorability among Black and Hispanic Americans has also fallen since 2021. About 6 in 10 U.S. adults have a very or somewhat unfavorable opinion of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable opinion. Overall views of Trump were similar in January and July 2021, too, in the months after Biden took office.\n\nViews of Trump are generally very stable -- even a felony conviction didn\'t change how Americans see him. After he was convicted in May of 34 felony counts in New York for falsifying business documents, polls from the AP-NORC Center found that overall views of Trump barely budged. During the Trump presidency, Gallup polls found that Trump\'s average job approval rating was 41%, and it never exceeded 50%.\n\nTrump has said on the campaign trail that he has "great support" from Hispanic communities. But the AP analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of Trump. About 4 in 10 Hispanic adults in the recent AP-NORC polls see Trump positively, up from about 3 in 10 in January 2021.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAnd even though Trump\'s campaign advisers have said he has specific appeal among Hispanic men and younger Hispanic adults because of his business focus, that\'s not what the poll analysis shows. Current views of Trump are similar among Hispanic men and women, older and younger Hispanic adults, and those with and without a college degree.\n\nBiden, too, is facing a perception problem among this group. The new analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable view. That\'s a substantial decline from early 2021, when about 6 in 10 Hispanic Americans saw Biden positively.\n\nBlack voters weigh in on 2024 election\n\nRepublicans are looking to pick up support in the Democratic city, and Black voters will play a crucial role in deciding who wins battleground...\n\nThe Trump campaign has claimed that he could perform better among Black adults this year than in 2020, speculating that his legal woes could endear him to a community that has faced systematic discrimination by the criminal justice system, and that his immigration policies could also hold appeal.\n\nBlack adults continue to have broadly negatively views of Trump, however: About 7 in 10 Black adults have an unfavorable view of Trump, a decrease of about 20 percentage points since early 2021. And although the Trump campaign has said Black men may be more receptive to his message, Black men and women have similar views of him.\n\nYounger Black Americans might be a little more open to Trump\'s appeals. About one-third of Black younger adults -- those under 45 -- see him positively, compared to around 1 in 10 Black adults who are 45 or older. But most younger Black adults view him unfavorably.\n\nAbout 6 in 10 Black Americans, meanwhile, have a positive view of Biden -- down from 8 in 10 when he took office.\n\nThe suburban problem that could cost Trump the election The suburban problem that could cost Trump the election 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'wcfcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Waterloo Cedar Falls Courier'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/wcfcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/e/53/e531856b-14e1-53af-a318-2a1ceced4402/6691427d9176a.preview.jpg?crop=709%2C372%2C471%2C53&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9723557', 'sentiment': 0.1137254901960785, 'wgt': 458571468, 'relevance': 26}

But he's not popular with either group, poll analysis shows", 'body': 'WASHINGTON -- As he prepares to accept the Republican nomination for the third time, Donald Trump has promised new efforts to expand his coalition -- and, in particular, to win over more of the nonwhite voters who largely rejected him during the 2020 election.\n\nBut an AP analysis of two consecutive polls conducted in June by the AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research shows that about 7 in 10 Black Americans have a somewhat or very unfavorable view of Trump, as do about half of Hispanic Americans. While both groups do see Trump a little more favorably than when he left office in 2021, their opinion of him is still more negative than positive.\n\nAny gains in support among Black or Hispanic Americans would be helpful for Trump, who won 35% of Hispanic voters and 8% of Black voters in 2020, according to AP VoteCast, and has struggled to grow his appeal beyond his base. He\'s hoping, in part, to capitalize on frustration with his opponent, since President Joe Biden\'s favorability among Black and Hispanic Americans has also fallen since 2021. It\'s not clear, though, that Biden\'s loss of enthusiasm among Black and Hispanic adults is helping Trump\'s own standing among these groups.\n\nPeople are also reading... $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Ryan Seacrest\'s Napa County home up for sale at $22 million A Napa teen was killed by gun violence. About 6 in 10 U.S. adults have a very or somewhat unfavorable opinion of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable opinion. Overall views of Trump were similar in January and July 2021, too, in the months after Biden took office.\n\nViews of Trump are generally very stable -- even a felony conviction didn\'t change how Americans see him. After he was convicted in May of 34 felony counts in New York for falsifying business documents, polls from the AP-NORC Center found that overall views of Trump barely budged. During the Trump presidency, Gallup polls found that Trump\'s average job approval rating was 41%, and it never exceeded 50%.\n\nTrump has said on the campaign trail that he has "great support" from Hispanic communities. But the AP analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of Trump. About 4 in 10 Hispanic adults in the recent AP-NORC polls see Trump positively, up from about 3 in 10 in January 2021.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAnd even though Trump\'s campaign advisers have said he has specific appeal among Hispanic men and younger Hispanic adults because of his business focus, that\'s not what the poll analysis shows. Current views of Trump are similar among Hispanic men and women, older and younger Hispanic adults, and those with and without a college degree.\n\nBiden, too, is facing a perception problem among this group. The new analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable view. That\'s a substantial decline from early 2021, when about 6 in 10 Hispanic Americans saw Biden positively.\n\nBlack voters weigh in on 2024 election\n\nRepublicans are looking to pick up support in the Democratic city, and Black voters will play a crucial role in deciding who wins battleground...\n\nThe Trump campaign has claimed that he could perform better among Black adults this year than in 2020, speculating that his legal woes could endear him to a community that has faced systematic discrimination by the criminal justice system, and that his immigration policies could also hold appeal.\n\nBlack adults continue to have broadly negatively views of Trump, however: About 7 in 10 Black adults have an unfavorable view of Trump, a decrease of about 20 percentage points since early 2021. But he's not popular with either group, poll analysis shows", 'body': 'WASHINGTON -- As he prepares to accept the Republican nomination for the third time, Donald Trump has promised new efforts to expand his coalition -- and, in particular, to win over more of the nonwhite voters who largely rejected him during the 2020 election.\n\nBut an AP analysis of two consecutive polls conducted in June by the AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research shows that about 7 in 10 Black Americans have a somewhat or very unfavorable view of Trump, as do about half of Hispanic Americans. While both groups do see Trump a little more favorably than when he left office in 2021, their opinion of him is still more negative than positive.\n\nAny gains in support among Black or Hispanic Americans would be helpful for Trump, who won 35% of Hispanic voters and 8% of Black voters in 2020, according to AP VoteCast, and has struggled to grow his appeal beyond his base. He\'s hoping, in part, to capitalize on frustration with his opponent, since President Joe Biden\'s favorability among Black and Hispanic Americans has also fallen since 2021. It\'s not clear, though, that Biden\'s loss of enthusiasm among Black and Hispanic adults is helping Trump\'s own standing among these groups.\n\nMost Americans have a negative view of Trump, according to the AP-NORC analysis, which combined two polls conducted close together to yield a bigger sample size. About 6 in 10 U.S. adults have a very or somewhat unfavorable opinion of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable opinion. Overall views of Trump were similar in January and July 2021, too, in the months after Biden took office.\n\nViews of Trump are generally very stable -- even a felony conviction didn\'t change how Americans see him. After he was convicted in May of 34 felony counts in New York for falsifying business documents, polls from the AP-NORC Center found that overall views of Trump barely budged. During the Trump presidency, Gallup polls found that Trump\'s average job approval rating was 41%, and it never exceeded 50%.\n\nTrump has said on the campaign trail that he has "great support" from Hispanic communities. But the AP analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of Trump. About 4 in 10 Hispanic adults in the recent AP-NORC polls see Trump positively, up from about 3 in 10 in January 2021.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAnd even though Trump\'s campaign advisers have said he has specific appeal among Hispanic men and younger Hispanic adults because of his business focus, that\'s not what the poll analysis shows. Current views of Trump are similar among Hispanic men and women, older and younger Hispanic adults, and those with and without a college degree.\n\nBiden, too, is facing a perception problem among this group. The new analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable view. That\'s a substantial decline from early 2021, when about 6 in 10 Hispanic Americans saw Biden positively.\n\nBlack voters weigh in on 2024 election\n\nRepublicans are looking to pick up support in the Democratic city, and Black voters will play a crucial role in deciding who wins battleground...\n\nThe Trump campaign has claimed that he could perform better among Black adults this year than in 2020, speculating that his legal woes could endear him to a community that has faced systematic discrimination by the criminal justice system, and that his immigration policies could also hold appeal.\n\nBlack adults continue to have broadly negatively views of Trump, however: About 7 in 10 Black adults have an unfavorable view of Trump, a decrease of about 20 percentage points since early 2021. And although the Trump campaign has said Black men may be more receptive to his message, Black men and women have similar views of him.\n\nYounger Black Americans might be a little more open to Trump\'s appeals. About one-third of Black younger adults -- those under 45 -- see him positively, compared to around 1 in 10 Black adults who are 45 or older. But most younger Black adults view him unfavorably.\n\nAbout 6 in 10 Black Americans, meanwhile, have a positive view of Biden -- down from 8 in 10 when he took office.\n\nThe suburban problem that could cost Trump the election Contributions speak to one part of a complex story Is the drop in Trump\'s fundraising a red herring or a reliable sign of what\'s to come? {'uri': '8223737109', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '12:44:20', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T12:44:20Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T12:43:18Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.9058823585510254, 'url': 'https://lacrossetribune.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/donald-trump-election-2024-black-latino-voters-support-poll-shows/article_f888f083-d41b-5e3e-b7ff-2829522a0550.html', 'title': "Trump wants Black and Latino support. But he's not popular with either group, poll analysis shows", 'body': 'WASHINGTON -- As he prepares to accept the Republican nomination for the third time, Donald Trump has promised new efforts to expand his coalition -- and, in particular, to win over more of the nonwhite voters who largely rejected him during the 2020 election.\n\nBut an AP analysis of two consecutive polls conducted in June by the AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research shows that about 7 in 10 Black Americans have a somewhat or very unfavorable view of Trump, as do about half of Hispanic Americans. While both groups do see Trump a little more favorably than when he left office in 2021, their opinion of him is still more negative than positive.\n\nAny gains in support among Black or Hispanic Americans would be helpful for Trump, who won 35% of Hispanic voters and 8% of Black voters in 2020, according to AP VoteCast, and has struggled to grow his appeal beyond his base. He\'s hoping, in part, to capitalize on frustration with his opponent, since President Joe Biden\'s favorability among Black and Hispanic Americans has also fallen since 2021. It\'s not clear, though, that Biden\'s loss of enthusiasm among Black and Hispanic adults is helping Trump\'s own standing among these groups.\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Batter and Brew hits the streets in La Crosse Steve Cahalan: New South Side Aldi store to open July 25 in La Crosse Human trafficking in La Crosse: Police department raises awareness after recent arrests Local talent shines in first-ever Riverfest Idol karaoke tournament Galesville man charged with eluding police and stealing vehicle in Onalaska Elderly man killed in UTV accident on Ettrick farm Farm ordered to pay $210K for wastewater permit violations; owner disputes Monroe County court ruling Criminal complaint implicates two La Crosse residents for human trafficking UPDATE: $500K bond set for man charged with assault in Winona that led to shelter-in-place order 21-year-old man drowns in private pond in Grant County, authorities say Steve Cahalan: Downtown Holiday Inn converting to boutique hotel in La Crosse Amtrak reports strong ticket sales for new line running through Wisconsin Steve Cahalan: Onalaska\'s BHHS North Properties to merge with Minnesota-based Edina Realty Tellurian awarded $35,000 from Mayo Health One injured in three vehicle crash near Arcadia\n\nMost Americans have a negative view of Trump, according to the AP-NORC analysis, which combined two polls conducted close together to yield a bigger sample size. About 6 in 10 U.S. adults have a very or somewhat unfavorable opinion of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable opinion. Overall views of Trump were similar in January and July 2021, too, in the months after Biden took office.\n\nViews of Trump are generally very stable -- even a felony conviction didn\'t change how Americans see him. After he was convicted in May of 34 felony counts in New York for falsifying business documents, polls from the AP-NORC Center found that overall views of Trump barely budged. During the Trump presidency, Gallup polls found that Trump\'s average job approval rating was 41%, and it never exceeded 50%.\n\nTrump has said on the campaign trail that he has "great support" from Hispanic communities. But the AP analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of Trump. About 4 in 10 Hispanic adults in the recent AP-NORC polls see Trump positively, up from about 3 in 10 in January 2021.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAnd even though Trump\'s campaign advisers have said he has specific appeal among Hispanic men and younger Hispanic adults because of his business focus, that\'s not what the poll analysis shows. Current views of Trump are similar among Hispanic men and women, older and younger Hispanic adults, and those with and without a college degree.\n\nBiden, too, is facing a perception problem among this group. The new analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable view. That\'s a substantial decline from early 2021, when about 6 in 10 Hispanic Americans saw Biden positively.\n\nBlack voters weigh in on 2024 election\n\nRepublicans are looking to pick up support in the Democratic city, and Black voters will play a crucial role in deciding who wins battleground...\n\nThe Trump campaign has claimed that he could perform better among Black adults this year than in 2020, speculating that his legal woes could endear him to a community that has faced systematic discrimination by the criminal justice system, and that his immigration policies could also hold appeal.\n\nBlack adults continue to have broadly negatively views of Trump, however: About 7 in 10 Black adults have an unfavorable view of Trump, a decrease of about 20 percentage points since early 2021. And although the Trump campaign has said Black men may be more receptive to his message, Black men and women have similar views of him.\n\nYounger Black Americans might be a little more open to Trump\'s appeals. About one-third of Black younger adults -- those under 45 -- see him positively, compared to around 1 in 10 Black adults who are 45 or older. But most younger Black adults view him unfavorably.\n\nAbout 6 in 10 Black Americans, meanwhile, have a positive view of Biden -- down from 8 in 10 when he took office.\n\nThe suburban problem that could cost Trump the election Contributions speak to one part of a complex story Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'lacrossetribune.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'La Crosse Tribune'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@lacrossetribune.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'rebecca_blackwell@lacrossetribune.com', 'name': 'Rebecca Blackwell', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/lacrossetribune.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/88/f888f083-d41b-5e3e-b7ff-2829522a0550/6691427c1d76c.preview.jpg?crop=709%2C372%2C471%2C53&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9723557', 'sentiment': 0.2392156862745098, 'wgt': 458570660, 'relevance': 26}

But he's not popular with either group, poll analysis shows", 'body': 'WASHINGTON -- As he prepares to accept the Republican nomination for the third time, Donald Trump has promised new efforts to expand his coalition -- and, in particular, to win over more of the nonwhite voters who largely rejected him during the 2020 election.\n\nBut an AP analysis of two consecutive polls conducted in June by the AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research shows that about 7 in 10 Black Americans have a somewhat or very unfavorable view of Trump, as do about half of Hispanic Americans. While both groups do see Trump a little more favorably than when he left office in 2021, their opinion of him is still more negative than positive.\n\nAny gains in support among Black or Hispanic Americans would be helpful for Trump, who won 35% of Hispanic voters and 8% of Black voters in 2020, according to AP VoteCast, and has struggled to grow his appeal beyond his base. He\'s hoping, in part, to capitalize on frustration with his opponent, since President Joe Biden\'s favorability among Black and Hispanic Americans has also fallen since 2021. It\'s not clear, though, that Biden\'s loss of enthusiasm among Black and Hispanic adults is helping Trump\'s own standing among these groups.\n\nPeople are also reading... About 6 in 10 U.S. adults have a very or somewhat unfavorable opinion of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable opinion. Overall views of Trump were similar in January and July 2021, too, in the months after Biden took office.\n\nViews of Trump are generally very stable -- even a felony conviction didn\'t change how Americans see him. After he was convicted in May of 34 felony counts in New York for falsifying business documents, polls from the AP-NORC Center found that overall views of Trump barely budged. During the Trump presidency, Gallup polls found that Trump\'s average job approval rating was 41%, and it never exceeded 50%.\n\nTrump has said on the campaign trail that he has "great support" from Hispanic communities. But the AP analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of Trump. About 4 in 10 Hispanic adults in the recent AP-NORC polls see Trump positively, up from about 3 in 10 in January 2021.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAnd even though Trump\'s campaign advisers have said he has specific appeal among Hispanic men and younger Hispanic adults because of his business focus, that\'s not what the poll analysis shows. Current views of Trump are similar among Hispanic men and women, older and younger Hispanic adults, and those with and without a college degree.\n\nBiden, too, is facing a perception problem among this group. The new analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable view. That\'s a substantial decline from early 2021, when about 6 in 10 Hispanic Americans saw Biden positively.\n\nBlack voters weigh in on 2024 election\n\nRepublicans are looking to pick up support in the Democratic city, and Black voters will play a crucial role in deciding who wins battleground...\n\nThe Trump campaign has claimed that he could perform better among Black adults this year than in 2020, speculating that his legal woes could endear him to a community that has faced systematic discrimination by the criminal justice system, and that his immigration policies could also hold appeal.\n\nBlack adults continue to have broadly negatively views of Trump, however: About 7 in 10 Black adults have an unfavorable view of Trump, a decrease of about 20 percentage points since early 2021. And although the Trump campaign has said Black men may be more receptive to his message, Black men and women have similar views of him.\n\nYounger Black Americans might be a little more open to Trump\'s appeals. About one-third of Black younger adults -- those under 45 -- see him positively, compared to around 1 in 10 Black adults who are 45 or older.
