{'uri': '8223730037', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '12:36:26', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T12:36:26Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T12:35:57Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://newsadvance.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/donald-trump-election-2024-black-latino-voters-support-poll-shows/article_e9aa5d46-20d3-5abf-906f-620de003da59.html', 'title': "Trump wants Black and Latino support. But he's not popular with either group, poll analysis shows", 'body': 'WASHINGTON -- As he prepares to accept the Republican nomination for the third time, Donald Trump has promised new efforts to expand his coalition -- and, in particular, to win over more of the nonwhite voters who largely rejected him during the 2020 election.\n\nBut an AP analysis of two consecutive polls conducted in June by the AP-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research shows that about 7 in 10 Black Americans have a somewhat or very unfavorable view of Trump, as do about half of Hispanic Americans. While both groups do see Trump a little more favorably than when he left office in 2021, their opinion of him is still more negative than positive.\n\nAny gains in support among Black or Hispanic Americans would be helpful for Trump, who won 35% of Hispanic voters and 8% of Black voters in 2020, according to AP VoteCast, and has struggled to grow his appeal beyond his base. He\'s hoping, in part, to capitalize on frustration with his opponent, since President Joe Biden\'s favorability among Black and Hispanic Americans has also fallen since 2021. It\'s not clear, though, that Biden\'s loss of enthusiasm among Black and Hispanic adults is helping Trump\'s own standing among these groups.\n\nMost Americans have a negative view of Trump, according to the AP-NORC analysis, which combined two polls conducted close together to yield a bigger sample size. About 6 in 10 U.S. adults have a very or somewhat unfavorable opinion of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable opinion. Overall views of Trump were similar in January and July 2021, too, in the months after Biden took office.\n\nViews of Trump are generally very stable -- even a felony conviction didn\'t change how Americans see him. After he was convicted in May of 34 felony counts in New York for falsifying business documents, polls from the AP-NORC Center found that overall views of Trump barely budged. During the Trump presidency, Gallup polls found that Trump\'s average job approval rating was 41%, and it never exceeded 50%.\n\nTrump has said on the campaign trail that he has "great support" from Hispanic communities. But the AP analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of Trump. About 4 in 10 Hispanic adults in the recent AP-NORC polls see Trump positively, up from about 3 in 10 in January 2021.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAnd even though Trump\'s campaign advisers have said he has specific appeal among Hispanic men and younger Hispanic adults because of his business focus, that\'s not what the poll analysis shows. Current views of Trump are similar among Hispanic men and women, older and younger Hispanic adults, and those with and without a college degree.\n\nBiden, too, is facing a perception problem among this group. The new analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable view. That\'s a substantial decline from early 2021, when about 6 in 10 Hispanic Americans saw Biden positively.\n\nThe Trump campaign has claimed that he could perform better among Black adults this year than in 2020, speculating that his legal woes could endear him to a community that has faced systematic discrimination by the criminal justice system, and that his immigration policies could also hold appeal.\n\nBlack adults continue to have broadly negatively views of Trump, however: About 7 in 10 Black adults have an unfavorable view of Trump, a decrease of about 20 percentage points since early 2021. And although the Trump campaign has said Black men may be more receptive to his message, Black men and women have similar views of him.\n\nYounger Black Americans might be a little more open to Trump\'s appeals. About one-third of Black younger adults -- those under 45 -- see him positively, compared to around 1 in 10 Black adults who are 45 or older. But most younger Black adults view him unfavorably.\n\nAbout 6 in 10 Black Americans, meanwhile, have a positive view of Biden -- down from 8 in 10 when he took office.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'newsadvance.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'NewsAdvance.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@newsadvance.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'rebecca_blackwell@newsadvance.com', 'name': 'Rebecca Blackwell', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/newsadvance.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/e/9a/e9aa5d46-20d3-5abf-906f-620de003da59/6691427cc81dd.preview.jpg?crop=709%2C372%2C471%2C53&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1764705882352942, 'wgt': 458570186, 'relevance': 51}

About 6 in 10 U.S. adults have a very or somewhat unfavorable opinion of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable opinion. Overall views of Trump were similar in January and July 2021, too, in the months after Biden took office.\n\nViews of Trump are generally very stable -- even a felony conviction didn\'t change how Americans see him. After he was convicted in May of 34 felony counts in New York for falsifying business documents, polls from the AP-NORC Center found that overall views of Trump barely budged. During the Trump presidency, Gallup polls found that Trump\'s average job approval rating was 41%, and it never exceeded 50%.\n\nTrump has said on the campaign trail that he has "great support" from Hispanic communities. But the AP analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of Trump. About 4 in 10 Hispanic adults in the recent AP-NORC polls see Trump positively, up from about 3 in 10 in January 2021.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nAnd even though Trump\'s campaign advisers have said he has specific appeal among Hispanic men and younger Hispanic adults because of his business focus, that\'s not what the poll analysis shows. Current views of Trump are similar among Hispanic men and women, older and younger Hispanic adults, and those with and without a college degree.\n\nBiden, too, is facing a perception problem among this group. The new analysis found that about half of Hispanic adults have an unfavorable view of him, while about 4 in 10 have a favorable view. That\'s a substantial decline from early 2021, when about 6 in 10 Hispanic Americans saw Biden positively.\n\nThe Trump campaign has claimed that he could perform better among Black adults this year than in 2020, speculating that his legal woes could endear him to a community that has faced systematic discrimination by the criminal justice system, and that his immigration policies could also hold appeal.\n\nBlack adults continue to have broadly negatively views of Trump, however: About 7 in 10 Black adults have an unfavorable view of Trump, a decrease of about 20 percentage points since early 2021. And although the Trump campaign has said Black men may be more receptive to his message, Black men and women have similar views of him.\n\nYounger Black Americans might be a little more open to Trump\'s appeals. About one-third of Black younger adults -- those under 45 -- see him positively, compared to around 1 in 10 Black adults who are 45 or older. But most younger Black adults view him unfavorably.\n\nAbout 6 in 10 Black Americans, meanwhile, have a positive view of Biden -- down from 8 in 10 when he took office.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'journalnow.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Winston-Salem Journal'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@journalnow.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': True}, {'uri': 'rebecca_blackwell@journalnow.com', 'name': 'Rebecca Blackwell', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/journalnow.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/2d/32dab082-3ebf-5968-8560-07623c743b0a/6691427c3efc1.preview.jpg?crop=709%2C372%2C471%2C53&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9723557', 'sentiment': 0.1764705882352942, 'wgt': 458570111, 'relevance': 51}

So, it was inevitable that after the Quad-City Times Bix 7 began offering prize money to the top 10 male and female finishers in 1989, the Kenyan\'s influence would be felt.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIt was. From 1992 through 2009, the Bix 7 men\'s race was won by a foreign-born runner every year and in 13 of those 18 years, the winner was from Kenya. Through the years, the women\'s champion has been from Kenya 15 times.\n\nKenya\'s John Korir won the Bix 7 five times and has held the course record for 26 years. Three other Kenya-born runners -- Catherine Ndereba, Silas Kipruto and Leonard Korir (now an American citizen) -- have three Bix championships to their credit.\n\n"This is their one big sport,\'\' Bill Rodgers said of the Kenya contingent. {'uri': '8223622227', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '10:57:45', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T10:57:45Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T10:57:04Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.9372549057006836, 'url': 'https://newsadvance.com/sports/college/kevin-sherrington-as-texas-heads-to-the-sec-longhorns-finally-have-a-jury-of-their/article_f93e4cea-7a1a-56fb-a181-561a262636b2.html', 'title': 'Kevin Sherrington: As Texas heads to the SEC, Longhorns finally have a jury of their peers', 'body': 'Kevin Sherrington, The Dallas Morning News\n\nDALLAS -- The spring of 1989 brought the first bloom of rumors that Texas was interested in the SEC and vice versa. An apoplectic Fred Jacoby, the Southwest Conference commissioner, called it "crazy."\n\nWhy, the SEC was already bursting at the seams with 10 teams! Poaching not just Texas but Texas A&M and Arkansas, as reported, would give it enough inventory for two conferences!\n\nTurns out the scoop was 35 years premature, at least in Texas\' case, but, ready or not, here we are at last.\n\nTexas\' first official act as an SEC member -- unless you count pirating the baseball coach in College Station -- will take place when SEC Media Days convene downtown at the Omni with all the humility of Mardi Gras.\n\nSince their transfer was processed three summers ago, Texas and Oklahoma partisans had waited on July 1, the day it became official, like it was the end of Prohibition. They\'ve been fishing kids out of fountains on both campuses ever since.\n\nAnd make no mistake, the buzz is what it\'s all about. Frankly, this is what Jacoby missed back in \'89 and what yours truly failed to see when A&M beat Texas to the punch a dozen years ago. Back then, I figured the Aggies\' prime motivation for going to the SEC was to get out from under the shadow of their biggest rival. That no doubt played a part, but it was superseded by the lure of this:\n\nAn invitation to the biggest show in college football.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nThis is what SEC Media Days -- and their "record" 49 hours of original programming -- are all about. This is what SEC fans are saying when they chant "S-E-C" at the underprivileged. We may only be 7-5, but we were mediocre in the world\'s greatest football conference. We may not have won as much as a division title in the BCS/CFP era, but SEC schools have won 15 national championships since 1998, and that reflects well on all of us. We believe if there\'s such a thing as guilt by association, the opposite must be true, too. That\'s what Sancho Panza tried to tell Don Quixote, anyway.\n\nYou are the company you keep, even if that company beats your brains in every week.\n\nLike A&M did with Johnny Football during its first couple years in the SEC, the Longhorns will do just fine in football, at least initially. Texas doesn\'t need membership in an exclusive club to feel good about itself, either. Once asked about keeping up with the Joneses, Texas\' former athletic director, DeLoss Dodds, famously said, "We are the Joneses." Texas simply got tired of the company it kept. That\'s what killed the SWC. The Big 12 had promise until it first atrophied, then bloated. Even at that, Texas won just four Big 12 football titles, a distant second to Oklahoma\'s 14. Winning only gets harder now, not that it seems to matter.\n\nWill Texas make more money? Sure, but only A&M has rivaled it in football revenue year in and year out. Will the Longhorns recruit better? No doubt, but ultimately NIL and collectives will have more to say about the destination of teenagers than conference affiliations.\n\nMy problem for years was looking at it strictly from a football perspective. If the objective is to make the playoffs, why take the hardest path possible? Didn\'t Texas just go to the semifinals as a Big 12 member? Wouldn\'t it be easier to do it again from the Big 12, especially in an expanded playoff format?\n\nNo one would have called it cheap if Texas had won it all last season, just like no one questions the validity of its national titles from the \'60s while dominating a mostly two-team league.\n\nLike A&M, Arkansas and Missouri before them, Texas will find that football in the SEC is a grind. There will be no more parachuting into Tuscaloosa for a signature win, then stealing out again. Every week is more of the same. That sort of thing wears on you after a while.\n\nOf course, maybe Steve Sarkisian has the Longhorns ready for just such a jump in competition. He knows the SEC as well as anyone and has all the resources necessary to win at a national level. Then again Texas has always had those resources and had its hands full just dealing with Oklahoma. Now the Longhorns will have three or four games a year at least as tough as Texas-OU.\n\nThe crazy thing is, that\'s exactly what they want. The prospects of losing don\'t matter as much to the masses as the entertainment value of worthy opponents who might be proven equals. Selling out all 100,000-plus seats at DKR-Memorial will be a snap. On the road, the locals will have to find space in neighboring airports to accommodate all those private jets from Texas, like they did last year in Tuscaloosa. This is the new norm. The Longhorns finally have a jury of their peers. A verdict awaits on football, but the buzz is back.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'newsadvance.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'NewsAdvance.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/newsadvance.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/6/b1/6b193e1e-d274-5659-9056-92602ecb7d7e/66925747ce699.image.jpg?crop=1773%2C931%2C0%2C119&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9730111', 'sentiment': 0.03529411764705892, 'wgt': 458564265, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8223622228', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '10:57:35', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T10:57:35Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T10:57:04Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://newsadvance.com/sports/professional/john-romano-nothing-at-stake-except-the-rays-city-s-future-and-a-long-ago/article_3c64e1d0-0a70-508a-95ca-65a29739e939.html', 'title': "John Romano: Nothing at stake except the Rays, city's future and a long-ago promise", 'body': 'John Romano, Tampa Bay Times\n\nST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- They are in charge of a city\'s future, a chore as inscrutable as it sounds.\n\nDocuments, lawyers and polls, they have. Absolute certainty, they do not. How do you predict the next week, let alone the next decade? Who do you turn to for help? Where, exactly, does one find answers about the future?\n\nStrangely enough, perhaps in the past.\n\nThe St. Pete City Council is scheduled to decide Thursday on a proposed $6.5 billion redevelopment of the Historic Gas Plant District that includes a new baseball stadium for the Rays. It\'s as monumental a decision as any local council has made since ...\n\nThe last time the St. Pete City Council approved a Rays stadium deal.\n\nThe circumstances were different, but the stakes were just as high. Back in 1986, St. Pete was the civic manifestation of an inferiority complex, except with beaches. Local leaders made a seemingly unhinged decision to build a domed stadium despite having neither a team, a viable ownership group, nor a plausible downtown.\n\n"I look at the council today, and their decision seems so much easier than the decision we had because they\'ve already got a team, they\'ve got an owner that\'s going to pay over 50 percent of the stadium costs, and the city\'s share is down around 25 percent," said Bill Bond, who was one of the council members who approved the construction of Tropicana Field by a 6-3 vote in 1986. "I know the current group is agonizing over this, but this deal is far better than what we had to go through.\n\n"All we had was a great belief in the future of St. Petersburg and our gut instincts."\n\nIt took some time, but that belief in the community has been justified. Five years after the opening of the Trop in 1990 -- then known as the Florida Suncoast Dome -- Major League Baseball awarded an expansion franchise to Tampa Bay.\n\nAs a business model, the team has been forever under siege. As a community asset, it has fared far better, even if the stadium was not the only investment the city made around that time. The Bayfront Center and The Pier both underwent renovations, and a tenant was found to reopen the dilapidated Vinoy hotel.\n\nTo what degree the baseball team played in the growth of the city is impossible to say, but it was clearly part of the critical mass that has led to skyscrapers, museums, a thriving nightlife and a real estate boom across the past 30 years.\n\nAnd now the council is again pondering a baseball stadium, along with an ambitious redevelopment plan that would include hotels, housing, office space, an African American museum, an outdoor theater, bike trails, green space and restaurants/bars.\n\n"This is a different scenario than the one we had to deal with," said Bob Stewart, another former council member who voted for the stadium in 1986. "We didn\'t have any guarantee from baseball, but we were headstrong. This time, there\'s a team, a competitive team, already here.\n\n"But there\'s also a lot more at stake, a lot more riding on this vote, that goes far beyond the building of a stadium. I haven\'t sat at the table, I haven\'t looked at all the information, but the significance of this vote is far more complicated than it was back in the 80s."\n\nComplications? You could say that.\n\nThe Rays have been seeking a new stadium for 15 years, looking in Ybor City, on the Tampa Riverwalk, on the St. Pete waterfront and numerous other locations around the bay area. All of their plans have collapsed, usually due to disagreements over the amount of public funds requested for stadium construction.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe plan to reimagine the Tropicana Field site was borne out of desperation -- and also the lure of 86 prime acres and the team\'s current stadium use agreement that gives the Rays a cut of any redevelopment proceeds. The Rays were willing to pay a greater portion of stadium costs than they were in Hillsborough County, because they stood to make a sizable profit on the redevelopment of the surrounding land.\n\nThat led to additional complications, because critics of the deal -- along with several council members -- insist the city is giving away too much in public subsidies along with relinquishing control of the redevelopment plan to the Rays and their partner, Hines. Between the city\'s share ($287.5 million) and Pinellas County\'s portion ($312.5 million) of construction costs, this would be the largest public contribution ever for an MLB stadium.\n\nBut there\'s a caveat.\n\nIt\'s a record-breaking number only because of inflation. In terms of percentage, the city/county contribution is similar or less than other recent MLB stadium projects. With the Rays picking up $700 million (plus overruns) of the anticipated $1.3 billion ballpark, the public\'s share is roughly 46%.\n\nIn Arlington, Texas, where a stadium for the Rangers opened in 2020, the public share was about 42%. In Atlanta (2017) it was 45%, and in both Miami (2012) and Minnesota (2010) it was 75%. The raw numbers in the city/county share of the Gas Plant deal will also be eclipsed by the $625 million the city of Jacksonville just committed to rebuild a football stadium for the NFL\'s Jaguars.\n\nExpensive, yes. Unprecedented, no.\n\nWhile economists seem almost unanimous in their opinion that sports venues are not great economic drivers and usually end up costing municipalities far more than they bring in, the argument in this case is that the Historic Gas Plant makeover is more than just a stadium construction project.\n\nThere was once a thriving community where Tropicana Field sits. Perhaps it was low-income -- a blighted area is how the city designated it in 1978 -- but it was home to generations of Black families with churches, grocery stores and schools of their own. When the land was razed, years before a baseball stadium was proposed, 27 businesses and more than 280 families had to relocate.\n\nThe original stadium was pitched as a boon for nearby residents, although the most tangible benefits seemed weighted more toward downtown.\n\nThis redevelopment plan replaces acres of parking spaces with more attractive community assets, including affordable housing.\n\n"I think we have learned lessons from the last time," said St. Pete Mayor Ken Welch, whose father, David, was on the council in 1986 and voted in favor of the stadium. "These are not just some vague promises (in the redevelopment deal), these are documented agreements, legal agreements and commitments to make sure this development is equitable and does have those inclusive community benefits that are detailed.\n\n"We documented the promise this time, and we\'ve got a partner going into this that really understands and has embraced our approach."\n\nSo, will this ongoing saga reach a conclusion in the coming days?\n\nNot quite. The council still has a workshop to go over revisions that were made in response to questions. Even if the city approves the project -- and votes on ancillary matters have passed with a 5-3 majority in recent weeks -- the county commission must still give the go-ahead for its share of the bill. In other words, sit tight.\n\nIt\'s been 45 years since the old Gas Plant neighborhood was informed of its impending doom. It\'s been more than 30 years since a bold City Council took a leap of faith on baseball. It\'s been more than 15 years since Stuart Sternberg bought the Rays and began talking of a stadium that could be an asset instead of a mere convenience.\n\nTurns out, baseball has not been the cure-all for every issue that was facing St. Pete in 1986.\n\nBut it helped bring us to a point where multi-billion-dollar development deals are the latest conversation.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'newsadvance.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'NewsAdvance.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/newsadvance.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/d/db/ddb58c09-7e34-566b-8507-f7d4709cd6e0/66925749ba031.image.jpg?crop=1699%2C892%2C0%2C164&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.05098039215686279, 'wgt': 458564255, 'relevance': 51}

I haven\'t sat at the table, I haven\'t looked at all the information, but the significance of this vote is far more complicated than it was back in the 80s."\n\nComplications? You could say that.\n\nThe Rays have been seeking a new stadium for 15 years, looking in Ybor City, on the Tampa Riverwalk, on the St. Pete waterfront and numerous other locations around the bay area. All of their plans have collapsed, usually due to disagreements over the amount of public funds requested for stadium construction.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe plan to reimagine the Tropicana Field site was borne out of desperation -- and also the lure of 86 prime acres and the team\'s current stadium use agreement that gives the Rays a cut of any redevelopment proceeds. The Rays were willing to pay a greater portion of stadium costs than they were in Hillsborough County, because they stood to make a sizable profit on the redevelopment of the surrounding land.\n\nThat led to additional complications, because critics of the deal -- along with several council members -- insist the city is giving away too much in public subsidies along with relinquishing control of the redevelopment plan to the Rays and their partner, Hines. Between the city\'s share ($287.5 million) and Pinellas County\'s portion ($312.5 million) of construction costs, this would be the largest public contribution ever for an MLB stadium.\n\nBut there\'s a caveat.\n\nIt\'s a record-breaking number only because of inflation. In terms of percentage, the city/county contribution is similar or less than other recent MLB stadium projects. With the Rays picking up $700 million (plus overruns) of the anticipated $1.3 billion ballpark, the public\'s share is roughly 46%.\n\nIn Arlington, Texas, where a stadium for the Rangers opened in 2020, the public share was about 42%. In Atlanta (2017) it was 45%, and in both Miami (2012) and Minnesota (2010) it was 75%. The raw numbers in the city/county share of the Gas Plant deal will also be eclipsed by the $625 million the city of Jacksonville just committed to rebuild a football stadium for the NFL\'s Jaguars.\n\nExpensive, yes. Unprecedented, no.\n\nWhile economists seem almost unanimous in their opinion that sports venues are not great economic drivers and usually end up costing municipalities far more than they bring in, the argument in this case is that the Historic Gas Plant makeover is more than just a stadium construction project.\n\nThere was once a thriving community where Tropicana Field sits. Perhaps it was low-income -- a blighted area is how the city designated it in 1978 -- but it was home to generations of Black families with churches, grocery stores and schools of their own. When the land was razed, years before a baseball stadium was proposed, 27 businesses and more than 280 families had to relocate.\n\nThe original stadium was pitched as a boon for nearby residents, although the most tangible benefits seemed weighted more toward downtown.\n\nThis redevelopment plan replaces acres of parking spaces with more attractive community assets, including affordable housing.\n\n"I think we have learned lessons from the last time," said St. Pete Mayor Ken Welch, whose father, David, was on the council in 1986 and voted in favor of the stadium. "These are not just some vague promises (in the redevelopment deal), these are documented agreements, legal agreements and commitments to make sure this development is equitable and does have those inclusive community benefits that are detailed.\n\n"We documented the promise this time, and we\'ve got a partner going into this that really understands and has embraced our approach."\n\nSo, will this ongoing saga reach a conclusion in the coming days?\n\nNot quite. The council still has a workshop to go over revisions that were made in response to questions. Even if the city approves the project -- and votes on ancillary matters have passed with a 5-3 majority in recent weeks -- the county commission must still give the go-ahead for its share of the bill. In other words, sit tight.\n\nIt\'s been 45 years since the old Gas Plant neighborhood was informed of its impending doom. It\'s been more than 30 years since a bold City Council took a leap of faith on baseball. It\'s been more than 15 years since Stuart Sternberg bought the Rays and began talking of a stadium that could be an asset instead of a mere convenience.\n\nTurns out, baseball has not been the cure-all for every issue that was facing St. Pete in 1986.\n\nBut it helped bring us to a point where multi-billion-dollar development deals are the latest conversation.', 'source': {'uri': 'omaha.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Omaha.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/omaha.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/bf/9bf7be10-47e7-5d88-9e01-529189cd19ce/66925757db9ef.image.jpg?crop=1699%2C892%2C0%2C164&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.05098039215686279, 'wgt': 458563844, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8223605463', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '10:42:13', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T10:42:13Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T10:41:43Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8745098114013672, 'url': 'https://mcdowellnews.com/sports/professional/john-romano-nothing-at-stake-except-the-rays-city-s-future-and-a-long-ago/article_c86fc38e-ae7c-5c58-9164-dcf2e1737d98.html', 'title': "John Romano: Nothing at stake except the Rays, city's future and a long-ago promise", 'body': 'John Romano, Tampa Bay Times\n\nST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- They are in charge of a city\'s future, a chore as inscrutable as it sounds.\n\nDocuments, lawyers and polls, they have. Absolute certainty, they do not. How do you predict the next week, let alone the next decade? Who do you turn to for help? Where, exactly, does one find answers about the future?\n\nStrangely enough, perhaps in the past.\n\nThe St. Pete City Council is scheduled to decide Thursday on a proposed $6.5 billion redevelopment of the Historic Gas Plant District that includes a new baseball stadium for the Rays. It\'s as monumental a decision as any local council has made since ...\n\nThe last time the St. Pete City Council approved a Rays stadium deal.\n\nThe circumstances were different, but the stakes were just as high. Back in 1986, St. Pete was the civic manifestation of an inferiority complex, except with beaches. Local leaders made a seemingly unhinged decision to build a domed stadium despite having neither a team, a viable ownership group, nor a plausible downtown.\n\nPeople are also reading... 3 dead in plane crash near McDowell, Rutherford county line McDowell County Schools moving principals at West Middle, Eastfield and Foothills school Plane crashes in McDowell; emergency crews ask people to avoid Brackett Town Road Marion man meets McDowell paramedic who saved his life 24 years ago 3 from South Carolina die in Nebo plane crash; national safety board investigating Marion NC man\'s charges upgraded to felony after assault on 79-year-old McDowell High athlete appointed to NC Student-Athlete Advisory Council Picasso Keaton, a former WSSU football player, dies in a car crash Marion NC man charged with breaking into home, assault Hickory pastor has a license to practice law. Plus, she\'s been on \'Jeopardy\' Body found Sunday was Marion man; cause of death pending toxicology report Frisbee\'s Galaxy Supermarket in Old Fort now a Piggly Wiggly; still family owned Golden Hour Charcuterie opens in Marion\'s Depot District HanesBrands moving headquarters to downtown Winston-Salem. Carolina University to move to Hanesbrands site. Nebo man charged with meth possession\n\n"I look at the council today, and their decision seems so much easier than the decision we had because they\'ve already got a team, they\'ve got an owner that\'s going to pay over 50 percent of the stadium costs, and the city\'s share is down around 25 percent," said Bill Bond, who was one of the council members who approved the construction of Tropicana Field by a 6-3 vote in 1986. "I know the current group is agonizing over this, but this deal is far better than what we had to go through.\n\n"All we had was a great belief in the future of St. Petersburg and our gut instincts."\n\nIt took some time, but that belief in the community has been justified. Five years after the opening of the Trop in 1990 -- then known as the Florida Suncoast Dome -- Major League Baseball awarded an expansion franchise to Tampa Bay.\n\nAs a business model, the team has been forever under siege. As a community asset, it has fared far better, even if the stadium was not the only investment the city made around that time. The Bayfront Center and The Pier both underwent renovations, and a tenant was found to reopen the dilapidated Vinoy hotel.\n\nTo what degree the baseball team played in the growth of the city is impossible to say, but it was clearly part of the critical mass that has led to skyscrapers, museums, a thriving nightlife and a real estate boom across the past 30 years.\n\nAnd now the council is again pondering a baseball stadium, along with an ambitious redevelopment plan that would include hotels, housing, office space, an African American museum, an outdoor theater, bike trails, green space and restaurants/bars.\n\n"This is a different scenario than the one we had to deal with," said Bob Stewart, another former council member who voted for the stadium in 1986. "We didn\'t have any guarantee from baseball, but we were headstrong. This time, there\'s a team, a competitive team, already here.\n\n"But there\'s also a lot more at stake, a lot more riding on this vote, that goes far beyond the building of a stadium. I haven\'t sat at the table, I haven\'t looked at all the information, but the significance of this vote is far more complicated than it was back in the 80s."\n\nComplications? You could say that.\n\nThe Rays have been seeking a new stadium for 15 years, looking in Ybor City, on the Tampa Riverwalk, on the St. Pete waterfront and numerous other locations around the bay area. All of their plans have collapsed, usually due to disagreements over the amount of public funds requested for stadium construction.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe plan to reimagine the Tropicana Field site was borne out of desperation -- and also the lure of 86 prime acres and the team\'s current stadium use agreement that gives the Rays a cut of any redevelopment proceeds. The Rays were willing to pay a greater portion of stadium costs than they were in Hillsborough County, because they stood to make a sizable profit on the redevelopment of the surrounding land.\n\nThat led to additional complications, because critics of the deal -- along with several council members -- insist the city is giving away too much in public subsidies along with relinquishing control of the redevelopment plan to the Rays and their partner, Hines. Between the city\'s share ($287.5 million) and Pinellas County\'s portion ($312.5 million) of construction costs, this would be the largest public contribution ever for an MLB stadium.\n\nBut there\'s a caveat.\n\nIt\'s a record-breaking number only because of inflation. In terms of percentage, the city/county contribution is similar or less than other recent MLB stadium projects. With the Rays picking up $700 million (plus overruns) of the anticipated $1.3 billion ballpark, the public\'s share is roughly 46%.\n\nIn Arlington, Texas, where a stadium for the Rangers opened in 2020, the public share was about 42%. In Atlanta (2017) it was 45%, and in both Miami (2012) and Minnesota (2010) it was 75%. The raw numbers in the city/county share of the Gas Plant deal will also be eclipsed by the $625 million the city of Jacksonville just committed to rebuild a football stadium for the NFL\'s Jaguars.\n\nExpensive, yes. Unprecedented, no.\n\nWhile economists seem almost unanimous in their opinion that sports venues are not great economic drivers and usually end up costing municipalities far more than they bring in, the argument in this case is that the Historic Gas Plant makeover is more than just a stadium construction project.\n\nThere was once a thriving community where Tropicana Field sits. Perhaps it was low-income -- a blighted area is how the city designated it in 1978 -- but it was home to generations of Black families with churches, grocery stores and schools of their own. When the land was razed, years before a baseball stadium was proposed, 27 businesses and more than 280 families had to relocate.\n\nThe original stadium was pitched as a boon for nearby residents, although the most tangible benefits seemed weighted more toward downtown.\n\nThis redevelopment plan replaces acres of parking spaces with more attractive community assets, including affordable housing.\n\n"I think we have learned lessons from the last time," said St. Pete Mayor Ken Welch, whose father, David, was on the council in 1986 and voted in favor of the stadium. "These are not just some vague promises (in the redevelopment deal), these are documented agreements, legal agreements and commitments to make sure this development is equitable and does have those inclusive community benefits that are detailed.\n\n"We documented the promise this time, and we\'ve got a partner going into this that really understands and has embraced our approach."\n\nSo, will this ongoing saga reach a conclusion in the coming days?\n\nNot quite. The council still has a workshop to go over revisions that were made in response to questions. Even if the city approves the project -- and votes on ancillary matters have passed with a 5-3 majority in recent weeks -- the county commission must still give the go-ahead for its share of the bill. In other words, sit tight.\n\nIt\'s been 45 years since the old Gas Plant neighborhood was informed of its impending doom. It\'s been more than 30 years since a bold City Council took a leap of faith on baseball. It\'s been more than 15 years since Stuart Sternberg bought the Rays and began talking of a stadium that could be an asset instead of a mere convenience.\n\nTurns out, baseball has not been the cure-all for every issue that was facing St. Pete in 1986.\n\nBut it helped bring us to a point where multi-billion-dollar development deals are the latest conversation.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'mcdowellnews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'McDowellNews.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/mcdowellnews.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/c3/3c3f639b-7f94-5afa-88a1-3c59c77bd24f/6692574f1def8.image.jpg?crop=1699%2C892%2C0%2C164&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9730158', 'sentiment': 0.05098039215686279, 'wgt': 458563333, 'relevance': 51}

Perhaps it was low-income -- a blighted area is how the city designated it in 1978 -- but it was home to generations of Black families with churches, grocery stores and schools of their own. When the land was razed, years before a baseball stadium was proposed, 27 businesses and more than 280 families had to relocate.\n\nThe original stadium was pitched as a boon for nearby residents, although the most tangible benefits seemed weighted more toward downtown.\n\nThis redevelopment plan replaces acres of parking spaces with more attractive community assets, including affordable housing.\n\n"I think we have learned lessons from the last time," said St. Pete Mayor Ken Welch, whose father, David, was on the council in 1986 and voted in favor of the stadium. "These are not just some vague promises (in the redevelopment deal), these are documented agreements, legal agreements and commitments to make sure this development is equitable and does have those inclusive community benefits that are detailed.\n\n"We documented the promise this time, and we\'ve got a partner going into this that really understands and has embraced our approach."\n\nSo, will this ongoing saga reach a conclusion in the coming days?\n\nNot quite. The council still has a workshop to go over revisions that were made in response to questions. Even if the city approves the project -- and votes on ancillary matters have passed with a 5-3 majority in recent weeks -- the county commission must still give the go-ahead for its share of the bill. In other words, sit tight.\n\nIt\'s been 45 years since the old Gas Plant neighborhood was informed of its impending doom. It\'s been more than 30 years since a bold City Council took a leap of faith on baseball. It\'s been more than 15 years since Stuart Sternberg bought the Rays and began talking of a stadium that could be an asset instead of a mere convenience.\n\nTurns out, baseball has not been the cure-all for every issue that was facing St. Pete in 1986.\n\nBut it helped bring us to a point where multi-billion-dollar development deals are the latest conversation.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'pantagraph.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'pantagraph.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/pantagraph.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/e/17/e17e35fc-0e1f-594e-83bd-a3cf443391b5/66925617e85b8.image.jpg?crop=1699%2C892%2C0%2C164&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9730158', 'sentiment': 0.05098039215686279, 'wgt': 458562867, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8223595941', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '10:33:32', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T10:33:32Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T10:33:07Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8509804010391235, 'url': 'https://heraldcourier.com/sports/college/kevin-sherrington-as-texas-heads-to-the-sec-longhorns-finally-have-a-jury-of-their/article_ca7b034c-93df-5b99-80ad-5452d010c8ae.html', 'title': 'Kevin Sherrington: As Texas heads to the SEC, Longhorns finally have a jury of their peers', 'body': 'Kevin Sherrington, The Dallas Morning News\n\nDALLAS -- The spring of 1989 brought the first bloom of rumors that Texas was interested in the SEC and vice versa. An apoplectic Fred Jacoby, the Southwest Conference commissioner, called it "crazy."\n\nWhy, the SEC was already bursting at the seams with 10 teams! Poaching not just Texas but Texas A&M and Arkansas, as reported, would give it enough inventory for two conferences!\n\nTurns out the scoop was 35 years premature, at least in Texas\' case, but, ready or not, here we are at last.\n\nTexas\' first official act as an SEC member -- unless you count pirating the baseball coach in College Station -- will take place when SEC Media Days convene downtown at the Omni with all the humility of Mardi Gras.\n\nSince their transfer was processed three summers ago, Texas and Oklahoma partisans had waited on July 1, the day it became official, like it was the end of Prohibition. They\'ve been fishing kids out of fountains on both campuses ever since.\n\nPeople are also reading... McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic LITTLE LEAGUE: Good day for local teams in state softball tournament TVA announces changes at South Holston, Boone properties \'Vampire\' series gives Sam Reid plenty to bite into HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Coaching innovator Mumme to serve on Sullivan East coaching staff Simmons to expand manufacturing into Russell County AUTO RACING: Rural Retreat native Will Hostetler\'s a hometown hero at Wythe Raceway COLLEGE BASEBALL: Chase Hungate (Abingdon) headed to Mississippi State, relishes chance to compete in SEC COLLEGE FOOTBALL: You can find Brad Robbins (Powell Valley) coaching at UConn now FOOTBALL CAMP: Former Tennessee QBs Hooker, Milton hosts football camp at Sullivan East LITTLE LEAGUE: Monday\'s State Tournament Results LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon falls in Virginia state title game PREP FOOTBALL: The VHSL master schedule was released on Thursday. Here are some games with intriguing storylines Marketplace dining opening at Hard Rock Bristol Casino donations near $900,000 with Tuesday presentation\n\nAnd make no mistake, the buzz is what it\'s all about. Frankly, this is what Jacoby missed back in \'89 and what yours truly failed to see when A&M beat Texas to the punch a dozen years ago. Back then, I figured the Aggies\' prime motivation for going to the SEC was to get out from under the shadow of their biggest rival. That no doubt played a part, but it was superseded by the lure of this:\n\nAn invitation to the biggest show in college football.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nThis is what SEC Media Days -- and their "record" 49 hours of original programming -- are all about. This is what SEC fans are saying when they chant "S-E-C" at the underprivileged. We may only be 7-5, but we were mediocre in the world\'s greatest football conference. We may not have won as much as a division title in the BCS/CFP era, but SEC schools have won 15 national championships since 1998, and that reflects well on all of us. We believe if there\'s such a thing as guilt by association, the opposite must be true, too. That\'s what Sancho Panza tried to tell Don Quixote, anyway.\n\nYou are the company you keep, even if that company beats your brains in every week.\n\nLike A&M did with Johnny Football during its first couple years in the SEC, the Longhorns will do just fine in football, at least initially. Texas doesn\'t need membership in an exclusive club to feel good about itself, either. Once asked about keeping up with the Joneses, Texas\' former athletic director, DeLoss Dodds, famously said, "We are the Joneses." Texas simply got tired of the company it kept. That\'s what killed the SWC. The Big 12 had promise until it first atrophied, then bloated. Even at that, Texas won just four Big 12 football titles, a distant second to Oklahoma\'s 14. Winning only gets harder now, not that it seems to matter.\n\nWill Texas make more money? Sure, but only A&M has rivaled it in football revenue year in and year out. Will the Longhorns recruit better? No doubt, but ultimately NIL and collectives will have more to say about the destination of teenagers than conference affiliations.\n\nMy problem for years was looking at it strictly from a football perspective. If the objective is to make the playoffs, why take the hardest path possible? Didn\'t Texas just go to the semifinals as a Big 12 member? Wouldn\'t it be easier to do it again from the Big 12, especially in an expanded playoff format?\n\nNo one would have called it cheap if Texas had won it all last season, just like no one questions the validity of its national titles from the \'60s while dominating a mostly two-team league.\n\nLike A&M, Arkansas and Missouri before them, Texas will find that football in the SEC is a grind. There will be no more parachuting into Tuscaloosa for a signature win, then stealing out again. Every week is more of the same. That sort of thing wears on you after a while.\n\nOf course, maybe Steve Sarkisian has the Longhorns ready for just such a jump in competition. He knows the SEC as well as anyone and has all the resources necessary to win at a national level. Then again Texas has always had those resources and had its hands full just dealing with Oklahoma. Now the Longhorns will have three or four games a year at least as tough as Texas-OU.\n\nThe crazy thing is, that\'s exactly what they want. The prospects of losing don\'t matter as much to the masses as the entertainment value of worthy opponents who might be proven equals. Selling out all 100,000-plus seats at DKR-Memorial will be a snap. On the road, the locals will have to find space in neighboring airports to accommodate all those private jets from Texas, like they did last year in Tuscaloosa. This is the new norm. The Longhorns finally have a jury of their peers. A verdict awaits on football, but the buzz is back.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'heraldcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'HeraldCourier.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/f6/ff6b3611-68cc-52ef-b6bd-29ad93da4395/66925619240ce.image.jpg?crop=1773%2C931%2C0%2C119&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9730111', 'sentiment': 0.2470588235294118, 'wgt': 458562812, 'relevance': 51}

{'uri': '8223504521', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '09:12:09', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T09:12:09Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T09:10:50Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.eagletribune.com/news/new_hampshire/citizen-scientists-map-changes-to-granite-state-beaches/article_3ea7b228-3ec9-11ef-b347-7ba7db1bec8e.html', 'title': 'Citizen scientists map changes to Granite State beaches', 'body': 'Jennifer Stetson, Rebecca Beasley and Mark Wiley work at Hampton Beach as part of the University of New Hampshire\'s Volunteer Beach Profile Monitoring Program.\n\nFor six years, citizen scientists have helped track New Hampshire\'s changing coastline through seasons and storms.\n\nThat data has helped scientists better understand the unique response of each beach to weather events: Some bounce back quickly, while others rebound slowly. As coastal risks mount, with climate change raising waters and intensifying storms, the shoreline mapping helps scientists detect the most vulnerable areas.\n\nIn other words: "Where are the beaches that need the most help to prevent the worst impacts of storms?" said Larry Ward, one of the principal investigators of the University of New Hampshire\'s Volunteer Beach Profile Monitoring Program.\n\nThirty-nine regular volunteers and five substitutes, who fill in periodically, help answer that question and others, performing beach profiles at 15 stations on a mostly monthly basis. Those volunteers, ranging from high schoolers to retirees, undergo "a very stringent training program" with UNH scientists, Ward said.\n\nThe scientists - professionals and volunteers - have together mapped stories of recovery with data. and their findings have reinforced the fact that just as each beach is different, so is its comeback from a storm.\n\nAfter three storms in a two-week period in March 2018, New Hampshire\'s coastal beaches were devastated, Ward said. Some beaches have lower elevations than others, "so, when a storm does come, those low-lying beaches get hit harder," he said.\n\nHampton Beach was "heavily eroded," Ward said, "but bounced back relatively fast." Meanwhile, he said, "North Beach and North Hampton Beach still have changed from it." They have low elevations that haven\'t fully rebounded since that series of hits more than six years ago. Wallis Sands Beach in Rye lies somewhere in between in terms of recovery.\n\nDetailed reports\n\nThose findings and others have been detailed in reports emanating from the program. and they come from a citizen approach to science. Alyson Eberhardt, the other principal investigator of the program, focuses on the volunteer aspect of it, her colleague said.\n\n"We couldn\'t possibly do this study without a large set of volunteers helping us," Ward said.\n\nVolunteers aren\'t just collecting data; they\'re also going back home and talking about their work with the people around them. That engagement cultivates "a partnership between the scientists and the managers and the people that live (on) and use the beach," Ward said.\n\nVolunteers typically have "ownership" over a beach, meaning they are returning to collect data at the same station month after month, Ward said, typically working in a group of three.\n\nNew volunteers are trained by UNH scientists, who accompany them on two to three profiling trips to teach them proper field procedures, how to run the profiles, and how to record the information, Ward said.\n\nThen the newcomers pair up with an experienced group. Some volunteers have been part of the program for years and are as adept at the data collection as the scientists who manage the program, Ward said.\n\nNew volunteers\n\nEventually, those new volunteers are woven into the existing group or placed where there is an opening. The UNH scientists visit the stations periodically to work with the volunteers and refresh their skills.\n\nThey extensively prepare the volunteers, but "we give them a lot of independence once they are trained," Ward said. "Ninety-nine percent of the time everything looks great," he said, but if the numbers don\'t look quite right, they\'ll reach out to the volunteers and figure out the issue.\n\nCitizen scientists look a little different than others hitting the beach, armed with clipboards and calibrated rods. and sometimes they have to ask a fellow beachgoer to move for a moment so they can measure the plot of sand they\'re sunbathing on.\n\nThough they time their summer profiling sessions to avoid the crowds, their presence on beaches often elicits curiosity, Ward said, another source of public engagement with the science.\n\nThe volunteers are typically given a three- or four-day window to go out each month, with the process taking about an hour, Ward said. In the cold months, when they time their profiles to midday to avoid the worst temperatures, it can take slightly longer because the volunteers are sometimes taking their gloves on and off.\n\nThe volunteers will brave snow and ice to make measurements, but plovers - an endangered species of bird - have kept the profilers from one or two stations recently, Ward said. Still, monthly changes are mostly documented.\n\nFinding the markers\n\nWhen volunteers get to their beach, they head out to the station marker, designated with a painted spot on the seawall or a stake in the ground.\n\nThen, the groups use what\'s called the Emery method to profile the beach, using the two sticks of identical length to record elevation, starting from the marker and moving down the beach.\n\nThey also snap pictures so the UNH scientists can see the condition of the beach, which helps verify that the measurements make sense with how the beach looks.\n\nFinally, the data and photos are uploaded to a Google Drive, and the scientists look at how sand volume and elevation have changed over time and visualize that data into charts and graphs.\n\nThe program recently had $32,000 in federal grants, routed through the Department of Environmental Services, approved by the Executive Council. UNH will provide $20,000 of matching funds, according to a letter describing the program to the council from DES Commissioner Robert R. Scott.\n\nThe program is looking at additional funding sources to continue the work into the future, Ward said.\n\n"Sometimes, it\'s fun," he said of the program, though joking it was not quite as much on one winter holiday where he was profiling a bitterly cold beach. "Sometimes, it\'s beautiful."\n\nNew Hampshire Bulletin is part of States Newsroom, a nonprofit news network supported by grants and a coalition of donors as a 501c(3) public charity.', 'source': {'uri': 'eagletribune.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Eagle-Tribune'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'new_hampshire_bulletin@eagletribune.com', 'name': 'New Hampshire Bulletin', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'claire_sullivan@eagletribune.com', 'name': 'Claire Sullivan', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/eagletribune.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/36/f36e5eaa-3ec9-11ef-8919-8f5e1f8ad7f4/668e9d99da222.image.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=1200%2C630&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.05098039215686279, 'wgt': 458557929, 'relevance': 26}

Visitors can experience the South-East\'s widest and fastest outdoor go-karting race track, suitable for adults and junior karting enthusiasts of all skill levels.\n\nBrentwood Go Karting opened on May 1st 1994 as an off-road kart circuit and has since undergone two circuit upgrades; the first one to change it to an all-weather tarmac surface to guarantee year-round racing and the latest one, in 2006, boosting the circuit size from 5m wide and 250m long to a massive 8m wide and 825m long.\n\nThe circuit is very quick and smooth to drive, with only one corner requiring firm braking. And while the layout means it is perfectly suited to first-timers, it is certainly a challenge to get a good lap time.\n\nREAD MORE: The new \'stylish\' Essex restaurant with \'lovely food\' that claims to be town\'s new \'top spot\'\n\nREAD MORE: Hidden gem Essex park with riverside views that was once crucial in defending the country\n\nNot only does it offer numerous racing lines, but also plenty of overtaking opportunities. The karts are weight-balanced so all drivers have a fair chance, differentiating Brentwood from many tracks. I feel it\'s one of the best environments to develop race craft."\n\nAnother said: "Our son started Bambino Karts in November 2023. The guys at Brentwood Karting have been absolutely incredible from the start. They are guiding children from (ages) 6 to 8 on how to drive a kart which must be incredibly hard (and frustrating) but do it with care and consideration for their needs."\n\nGet more What\'s On news from EssexLive straight to your inbox for FREE', 'source': {'uri': 'essexlive.news', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Essex Live'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'jodie_bradley@essexlive.news', 'name': 'Jodie Bradley', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://i2-prod.essexlive.news/incoming/article9398395.ece/ALTERNATES/s1200/0_IMG_0941.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.4588235294117646, 'wgt': 458554139, 'relevance': 26}
{'uri': '8223369158', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '07:08:17', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T07:08:17Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T07:07:36Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://amgreatness.com/2024/07/13/when-a-horse-is-more-than-a-horse/', 'title': 'When a Horse is More Than a Horse " American Greatness', 'body': 'A mishap at a Maryland Independence Day Parade illustrates the uselessness of today\'s media in serving as bulwarks against the corruptions and failures of government.\n\nThis Independence Day, I had the privilege of marching with my brethren in the Takoma Park Maryland Fourth of July Parade, helping to carry the banner of our organization. Immediately ahead of us in the procession was a unit of troopers, two riders accompanied by several attendants, all attired in splendid blue cavalry uniforms.\n\nFor as long as we marched, this little band of cavalry maintained perfect order and discipline. But when we reached the end of the route, some accident or error caused one of the horses to bolt and gallop through the parade route for many blocks, slightly injuring a bystander and bringing the march to a halt until order was restored.\n\nLocal media in the D.C. area reported on the runaway horse. No coverage that I have seen, however, not even in the flagship Washington Post, reported on who exactly had brought the horses to the parade or bothered trying to explain what went wrong.\n\nSometimes a horse is more than a horse. Although this episode could have produced serious injury both to the horse and to humans, it may seem rather insignificant in the scheme of things. But it is, in fact, worth thinking about if we want to understand why many of us are deeply concerned for the future of our country and its media.\n\nAccording to the official program, the troopers and their horses came from Troop A of the Maryland Defense Force Cavalry. What I learned about this in the few minutes it took to do a Google search was apparently not of interest to the host of supposed professional journalists who took the time to put out stories on this mishap.\n\nUnderstand that the Maryland state military was not in the parade just for fun. The troopers were there with their war horses to show off their power and discipline. They marched to demonstrate that danger and to show that their force, like the precision and power of more famous ceremonial units like the U.S. Navy\'s Blue Angels, was at the service of our government to be employed for the defense of the country against enemies foreign and domestic.\n\nUnfortunately, due to a few seconds of inattention or some other unspecified accident they failed to control, the Maryland Cavalry displayed the danger more vividly than their discipline. Instead of scaring our enemies, the bolting horse rightly scared us.\n\nWe Marylanders don\'t know what went wrong, and if we rely on our establishment media, we may never find out who or what was responsible for what went wrong.\n\nThe United States rose to paramount power not only because of its continental situation, the attendant population and the resources at its command, but also because our free and uncontrolled press has always been quick to report when something in the raising, training, equipping, or deployment of our military seemed poorly planned or executed, reveling in the opportunity to embarrass the military brass or its civilian overseers. Do they still?\n\nIf our military malfunctions on parade, we should be concerned about what worse, even potentially devastating malfunctions will happen when our enemies get a vote on what happens. It is the job of our media, which nobody else can do with the same potential freedom from the influence of party or personal interests, to voice those fears and concerns and help ensure that those we elect adequately address them.\n\nTo paraphrase former Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, we go to war with the media we have, not the media we want. The media we have defines "professionalism" as sharing and enforcing the opinions prevalent among their colleagues and parroting what progressives in power tell them rather than enforcing the old standards and tools of professional journalism.\n\nToo many in our media choose to help those in power police voters from voting "wrong" instead of being the first to ask "who, what, when, where, and how" when something goes wrong.\n\nThis leaves us blind to the dangers our enemies pose as well as the dangers of the inadequately controlled, trained, and equipped forces we have in place to confront our enemies if that should be required. It is not just the White House press corps that has seemingly forgotten how to afflict the powerful in order to comfort the afflicted; it\'s all of our mainstream press. Whether the disaster is minor or serious, the press should be there to make sure lessons will be learned and the sufferings occasioned by a disaster will not be proved vain.', 'source': {'uri': 'amgreatness.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'American Greatness'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'michael_s_kochin@amgreatness.com', 'name': 'Michael S. Kochin', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://cdn.amgreatness.com/app/uploads/2024/07/GettyImages-1335673491.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.06666666666666665, 'wgt': 458550497, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8223314041', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '06:12:46', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T06:12:46Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T06:11:05Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.9647058844566345, 'url': 'https://www.newstribune.com/news/2024/jul/13/athletes-competing-in-paris-for-refugee-olympic-team/', 'title': 'Athletes competing in Paris for Refugee Olympic Team', 'body': 'They compete under the same flag but speak different languages and come from different parts of the world. After fleeing war and persecution at home, 36 athletes from 11 countries will compete in the Paris Games as part of the Refugee Olympic Team.\n\nThe team was created for the Rio Olympics in 2016 as a symbol of hope and to call attention to the plight of refugees worldwide.\n\nIn Paris, the refugee athletes will take the stage at a time of record global migration, with hundreds of millions of people -- many of them displaced from their homes -- working to reinvent themselves just as these athletes have.\n\nThe record migration comes alongside a rise in far-right populism across much of the world, with officials and parties in many countries promising to clamp down on immigration and asylum.\n\nAt the Games, athletes will compete in a host country where the anti-immigration far-right party saw a surge of voter support in parliamentary elections, but was beaten back by a coalition of the French left and failed to win a majority.\n\nThe refugee athletes will compete in 12 sports, but for many, their journey to Paris is already a victory in itself.\n\nFernando Dayán Jorge, Cuban, canoeing\n\nFernando Dayán Jorge spent his childhood flying past rickety fishing boats and colonial houses in the bay next to his home in Cienfuegos, Cuba.\n\nSince he began practicing there with his father when he was 11, he said it feels as if he has lived a thousand lifetimes.\n\nThe 25-year-old canoeist was a two-time Olympian for Cuba\'s national team in Rio de Janeiro and Tokyo. Then, a gold medalist. A deserter of the Cuban team. A migrant. A maintenance worker. And a refugee.\n\nNow, he continues to rocket along on his narrow red-and-white canoe, this time flying past suburban homes in the canals winding through Cape Coral, Fla.\n\nKneeling on his boat, his oar slices through the air as his coach chants "very good work, very good work" from a boat next to him.\n\nJorge\'s eyes are fixed ahead, throwing all his force into his third Olympics.\n\n"After having written off the 2024 Paris Olympics, it\'s a massive opportunity," he said. "There are so many Cubans that come to this country and lose this dream of competing once again, simply because they don\'t know how to get back to this place."\n\nJorge was at the top of his career, having won gold in Tokyo for the 1,000-meter canoe sprint, when he took a daunting step in March 2021. While training in Mexico, Jorge defected, joining a growing number of Cuban athletes in deserting their country amid an ongoing migratory flight.\n\nSome hope to make more money than they can in the communist-run island. Others, like Jorge, say they left because of political differences about how the government treats citizens and athletes.\n\nHe left behind his home and crossed into the United States via the Rio Grande, in hopes of a better -- if uncertain -- life.\n\nArriving to Florida was, in some ways, like starting from scratch. Granted refugee status in the U.S., Jorge said he would wake up hours before sunrise to train, then work eight hours in a maintenance gig to pay his bills.\n\nHe said he watched friends forced to give up everything after migrating, but he fought to continue as a professional athlete.\n\n"I had a hard time getting out of bed every day and keeping my head on straight," he said. "I had no support whatsoever."\n\nBecoming one of the first Cubans to compete on the Refugee Olympic Team changed everything for him, he said. Still, he is among those who\'ve struggled to cover the costs of competing internationally. He opened a GoFundMe page in June to help pay his way to the Games.\n\nCuba has protested the inclusion of Jorge and Cuban weightlifter Ramiro Mora on the team, saying they should not be considered refugees.\n\nToday, Jorge\'s life in Cuba and his future in Florida seem to blend together in his home. His red, blue and white Cuba jersey sits framed over his doorway, while medals from competitions in the U.S. hang over a statue of the Olympic emblem.\n\n"To the refugees and athletes who\'ve been through the same thing, I want to tell them to not give up," he said. "No matter how dark the days become, the sun is always going to rise."\n\nManizha Talash, Afghan, breaking\n\nManizha Talash does not fear the Taliban.\n\n"I\'m here because I want to reach my dream. Not because I\'m scared," she declared from Spain, where she was granted asylum.\n\nOn the outskirts of Madrid, the 21-year-old is training hard for the Games, which for the first time will include breaking, or, as it\'s popularly known, breakdancing. Talash prances and swivels on her hands and feet to the beat of hip-hop, swooshing her black and red hair around before striking a pose signaling the end of her performance.\n\nJust months ago, she was working in a hair salon in the town of Huesca. Talash was among hundreds of Afghans brought to Spain aboard military planes following the return of the Taliban to power in August 2021.\n\nTalash first came across breaking at age 17. She saw a social media video of a man spinning on his head and was skeptical -- it must have been fake, generated by AI, she thought. But the images were real, and she said she soon became obsessed with the sport, scrolling through video after video on her phone.\n\n"I wanted to do it, I wanted to learn it," she said.\n\nShe found a club in Kabul where a dancer from the videos trained and knocked at the door. "There were 55 boys, and I was the only girl," she said. "I told myself, why can\'t a girl do this?"\n\nBreaking in some ways freed her from the problems facing young women in Afghanistan. But it wasn\'t long before Talash was noticed -- international news outlets published stories about the young Afghan woman defying cultural and religious norms. That was enough to become a target.\n\n"The Taliban don\'t like it when a girl dances," she said, even though breaking is more than that -- it\'s a sport.\n\nHer club began receiving threats, Talash said, and one day, when a bomb hit very close, local police asked them to shut down over the dangers.\n\nShe trained behind closed doors in her home until the Taliban\'s return to power. Despite initial promises women\'s rights wouldn\'t be curtailed, women have since been barred from studying and face several restrictions on employment, travel and health.\n\n"Now, girls can\'t do anything," Talash said.\n\nShe\'s had little time to train while adapting to a foreign country, and at some points, competing in the Games seemed unfathomable.\n\n"But when my friend told me I could join the refugee team, I was so happy," Talash said. "I can now fly."\n\nMohammad Amin Alsalami, Syrian, athletics\n\nWhen Mohammad Amin Alsalami arrived in Berlin in October 2015, he was cold, lonely and homesick.\n\nThe Syrian refugee had left behind his war-torn hometown of Aleppo, fled to Turkey, crossed the Mediterranean on a rubber boat to Greece, and trekked by foot to Germany. Like millions of other migrants, he was in search of a place where he could build a future without bombs and violence.\n\nAlmost a decade later, Alsalami, 29, has been granted asylum, learned German and made new friends. And he\'s living his dream of becoming a world-class athlete.\n\nHe learned just months ago he got the green light to participate in the Paris Games.\n\n"That moment was so wow," he said. "I get to go to the Olympics. I cried so much. It was really cool."\n\nAlsalami discovered his passion for athletics during physical education in school at age 15. A teacher noticed his talent for long jump and pushed him to participate in local and national competitions in Syria. But when civil war erupted, he could no longer practice. His family -- he\'s the youngest of nine siblings and comes from a family of tailors -- was displaced several times within Syria, then fled to Turkey. Alsalami decided to continue on to Europe on his own.\n\nHe credits his passion for athletics with getting him through the initial hardships in his new country.\n\nDuring the first weeks in Berlin, he looked up different stadiums and gyms on Google maps so he could start practicing long jump again. He remembers walking through the first snow to finally discover one of the city\'s big indoor gymnasiums.\n\n"All the other Berlin track and field athletes were training in this hall," he said. "When I came in and saw how full and how warm it was inside ... it was almost like paradise for me."\n\nOn that first day, a man watched him jump, approached him and asked something in German.\n\n"I didn\'t understand anything, not in English either," Alsalami said. "And then I said \'Hey, I\'m Syrian\' on my cellphone, and he said \'I\'m your trainer from now on.\'"\n\nHe stayed with that first coach for five years, then moved on to a different one -- and said he\'s eternally grateful to both for their support.\n\nDespite his excitement for the Games, Alsalami admits he\'s a bit sad that he can\'t represent his home country.\n\n"Syria is home, I miss it every day," he said. "In the end, that\'s my country, that\'s where I come from."\n\nIman Mahdavi, Iranian, wrestling\n\nIman Mahdavi smiles and dishes up Iranian food he has cooked himself at his Milan home.\n\n"If my mum could see me now," he said with a laugh. "She wouldn\'t believe it."\n\nMahdavi hasn\'t seen his mother since October 2020, when the Iranian wrestler fled his home country fearing for his life.\n\nWith only the clothes he was wearing, Mahdavi made a harrowing journey by foot from Iran to Turkey, then flew to Italy and applied for asylum.\n\n"I didn\'t even really know where I was flying to," said Mahdavi, 29. "Luckily for me, it was Italy."\n\nOnce he was granted asylum, one of Mahdavi\'s first aims was to continue wrestling. His father, once a wrestler himself, had instilled in his son a passion. Mahdavi became a seven-time national junior champion and won more than 50 medals.\n\nThrough a friend he connected with on Instagram, Mahdavi was introduced to a gym on the outskirts of Milan.\n\n"As soon as we had him in the gym, in his first training sessions, we immediately saw that he was an extraordinary athlete, that he was a very, very high-level wrestler," said Giuseppe Gammarota, president of Lotta Club Seggiano. "We immediately started preparing him for competitions."\n\nThe gym has become like family to him -- so much so that he calls his coach, Marco Moroni, "Papi."\n\nMahdavi said his real father died of a heart attack several years ago after being mistakenly told his son died in a car crash.\n\nIt was Moroni who helped Mahdavi find a job, as a nightclub bouncer.\n\nMahdavi admits the schedule can be tough: He works from 11 p.m.-5 a.m., goes home to sleep, then trains every day. But he has a focus that drives him.\n\n"The Olympics is a dream for any athlete who does any sport," he said. "I hope to come back from the Olympics with the best colored medal I can get. And I will also be thinking about the next Olympics, hoping I\'m still in form."', 'source': {'uri': 'newstribune.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Jefferson City News Tribune'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://wehco.media.clients.ellingtoncms.com/static-4/sites/newstribune/img/branding/story-placeholder.png', 'eventUri': 'eng-9725114', 'sentiment': 0.05882352941176472, 'wgt': 458547166, 'relevance': 26}
