Cropp led the Vikings to consecutive state championships in 1971 and 1972.\n\nStaff reports\n\nBristol Tennessee City Schools (BTCS) has announced the establishment of the Bristol Tennessee City Schools Athletic Hall of Fame.\n\nAccording to a press release unveiled on Monday, the inaugural class will be inducted on Sunday, September 8 at Tennessee High School, starting with a ceremony at 3 p.m. in the auditorium and continuing in Viking Hall, where the permanent Hall of Fame display will be unveiled.\n\nThe release states that the new initiative will recognize and honor athletes, teams, coaches, administrators and special contributors who have made historically noteworthy contributions to the school district\'s athletic programs, including both Tennessee High School and Slater High School. Tennessee High School, which first opened its doors in 1916, and Slater High School, which served African American students from 1919 until its integration with Tennessee High School in 1965, both have a rich tradition of athletic excellence.\n\nPeople are also reading... McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic LITTLE LEAGUE: Good day for local teams in state softball tournament TVA announces changes at South Holston, Boone properties \'Vampire\' series gives Sam Reid plenty to bite into Simmons to expand manufacturing into Russell County HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Coaching innovator Mumme to serve on Sullivan East coaching staff AUTO RACING: Rural Retreat native Will Hostetler\'s a hometown hero at Wythe Raceway COLLEGE BASEBALL: Chase Hungate (Abingdon) headed to Mississippi State, relishes chance to compete in SEC COLLEGE FOOTBALL: You can find Brad Robbins (Powell Valley) coaching at UConn now FOOTBALL CAMP: Former Tennessee QBs Hooker, Milton hosts football camp at Sullivan East LITTLE LEAGUE: Monday\'s State Tournament Results LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon falls in Virginia state title game PREP FOOTBALL: The VHSL master schedule was released on Thursday. Here are some games with intriguing storylines Marketplace dining opening at Hard Rock Bristol Casino donations near $900,000 with Tuesday presentation\n\n"It is important for us to recognize individuals from both schools, as some truly incredible athletes played sports at THS and Slater," said Lori Worley, who serves on the BTCS Athletic Hall of Fame advisory committee. "The same can be said of the many coaches, administrators and special contributors who supported the schools. With both schools opening more than 100 years ago, the creation of a sports hall of fame has been a long time coming."\n\nThe inaugural class of the BTCS Athletic Hall of Fame includes a diverse group of 26 individuals and teams from various sports and different eras, representing both schools\' exceptional talent and dedication, according to the release.\n\n"Selecting the inaugural class was not an easy task," said Tommy McDaniel, who serves on the advisory committee. "It required a great deal of research and time from a group of committed individuals who are very familiar with the athletic programs at Slater and THS. We feel we\'ve got a solid group in this inaugural class, all very deserving of being part of the BTCS Athletic Hall of Fame."\n\nThe BTCS Athletic Hall of Fame is designed to be an ongoing project, with new elements added over the coming years to celebrate and preserve the rich athletic history of the schools. Moving forward, the community can submit nominations via the BTCS Athletic Hall of Fame website. Nominations can be made by individuals or anyone wishing to recognize a former athlete or special contributor. To be eligible, nominees must have been out of school for at least five years.\n\nFor more information, visit the BTCS Athletic Hall of Fame website at www.btcs.org/hof or contact the Tennessee High {'uri': '2024-07-420445768', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '05:16:50', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T05:16:50Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T05:00:35Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.5882353186607361, 'url': 'https://ca.news.yahoo.com/flights-hotels-berlin-huge-demand-050035996.html', 'title': 'Flights and hotels in Berlin in huge demand as England fans rush to Berlin for Euros final', 'body': 'Going into the Euro 2024 semi-final on Wednesday, some oft-burned England fans were convinced their team wouldn\'t take the win - but they did, beating the Netherlands 2-1.\n\nSince that triumph, Google searches for "Euros final Berlin" have seen a 694 per cent increase, with England fans desperate to get in on the atmosphere in Germany ahead of the final on Sunday.\n\nEngland will take on Spain at the iconic Olympiastadion in Berlin.\n\nDemand is so high that holiday provider Travel Republic has now revealed that England\'s place in the UEFA Euros final has caused a phenomenal increase in demand.\n\nFans keen to head to the German capital have pushed Google searches for "flights to Berlin" up 712 per cent. The search term "hotels in Berlin" has seen an incredible 777 per cent rise since they defeated Netherlands in the semi-final.\n\nHow has the hospitality industry in Berlin reacted to the surge?\n\nWhile some England fans won\'t see money as any object in the way of seeing their team play, many will miss out on the chance.\n\nAirlines and hotels have reacted quickly, seeing prices soaring after England\'s win.\n\n"After the incredible win last night I decided to take a look at hotels in Berlin, with the hypothetical idea that me and my mates might fly to Berlin on Sunday for the match. I found a hotel that was just over £100 when the game had ended, but when I looked again this morning it\'s nearly 10 times more expensive," one fan, Nick, told Travel Republic.\n\nNick\'s experience is not unusual. Many potential customers have seen the immediate impact on supply and demand affecting airline and hotel pricing ahead of the final.\n\nEven if they\'ll have nowhere to stay - at least nowhere cheap - some fans have been able to get tickets to the final.\n\nThey\'re the lucky ones, though, as there\'s also been a 1,262 per cent increase in searches for "Euros final tickets" since Wednesday.\n\nAny remaining tickets for England\'s unprecedented appearance in the final on Sunday cost between €95 and €2,025 - but they\'re likely to be snapped up extremely quickly.\n\nThe final is set to take place at Berlin\'s Olympiastadion - the largest host of any of the Euros matches this time around.\n\nHome to just short of 75,000 seats, those fans who can\'t secure a precious spot will likely stay in Berlin and cheer on players from fan zones as well as the many pubs and bars of the capital.\n\nHas Germany seen an increase in tourism since the beginning of the Euros?\n\nEnglish football fans have already made history with more than 300,000 of them travelling to Germany to watch the tournament unfold over the course of the 2024 Euros.\n\nThat\'s the highest attendance of England fans since the 2016 Euros hosted in France.\n\nTaking part in ten cities across Germany, including Berlin, interest in the nation has been significant.\n\nOnline travel agent Opodo says, since kickoff on 14 June, there\'s been a 39 per cent increase in bookings for travel to Germany between then and 14 July - compared to the same period in 2023.\n\nUK-based football fans have made up 17 per cent of the total bookings among fans travelling to the cities where the matches are taking place.\n\nDuring the first three England matches, which took place from 14 June to 26 June, 38 per cent of all Opodo bookings came from the UK, with most staying between 2 and 4 days to see their team triumph on the pitch.', 'source': {'uri': 'ca.news.yahoo.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Yahoo'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://media.zenfs.com/en/euronews_uk_articles_973/e5e20d60f7927ab817f8c12b2a318daa', 'eventUri': 'eng-9724220', 'sentiment': 0.08235294117647052, 'wgt': 458543810, 'relevance': 78}
{'uri': '2024-07-420438743', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '05:03:00', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T05:03:00Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T04:00:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://magicvalley.com/news/nation-world/crime-courts/tulsa-race-massacres-first-identified-victim-from-unmarked-burials-is-a-wwi-veteran/article_95ff6bfc-f359-5d8e-a86c-f5aab1e5b911.html', 'title': "Tulsa Race Massacre's first identified victim from unmarked burials is a WWI veteran", 'body': 'Randy Krehbiel Tulsa World\n\nA partially disabled World War I veteran trying to get home to his mother has been identified as a 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre victim buried anonymously in the city\'s Oaklawn Cemetery, researchers and Mayor G.T. Bynum said Friday.\n\nC.L. Daniel, a Georgia native whose name had never before come to the attention of race massacre researchers, is the first person identified through a project launched five years ago by Bynum to find unmarked burials from the May 31-June 1 calamity in which more than 35 square blocks of Tulsa\'s Black Greenwood District were destroyed by whites and dozens and perhaps hundreds of people were killed.\n\nDNA comparisons, genealogical research and two letters in the National Archives led Intermountain Forensics, a firm working with the city, to Daniel. The DNA and genealogy narrowed the search to two brothers with that last name.\n\nOne of the letters, a 1936 missive from a Georgia attorney to the U.S. Veterans Administration on behalf of Daniel\'s mother, identified Daniel as almost certainly the occupant of what archeologists denote as Burial #3 in the old Black paupers\' section of Oaklawn.\n\nThe letter, from Stanford Arnold of Newnan, Georgia, on behalf of Amanda Daniel, seeks "any benefits that be due her" because of her son\'s service and honorable discharge because of injury.\n\n"She has no discharge (papers) and is going to have difficulty in establishing his death," Arnold wrote. "C.L. was killed in a race riot in Tulsa Oklahoma in 1921 according to best information she has furnished me."\n\nIt is unclear whether the VA responded or if Amanda Daniel, whom the lawyer described as "in destitute circumstances," received any assistance.\n\nThe National Archives search also produced a letter written by C.L. Daniel, apparently to the Army, in February 1921 from Ogden, Utah. In poignant language, Daniel said his legs pained him, apparently from an injury suffered in the Army, and made finding work difficult. Daniel says he spent 19 days in the Camp Gordon, Georgia, hospital.\n\n"(F)or some time I have traveled this country over and now sufriend (suffering) with complance (complaints) that (I) was in the base hospitle (hospital) with," Daniel wrote, his spelling and grammar a testament to the sort of education many Americans and especially Black Americans received in the early 20th century. "(D)ear sir, please send me a nof (enough) money to git me a job and to eat with till I Get better."\n\nDaniel\'s burial place was among the first uncovered in 2020 by the team headed by state archeologist Kary Stackelbeck and University of Florida forensic anthropologist Phoebe Stubblefield. Its proximity to the headstones of two known massacre victims, Reuben Everett and Eddie Lockard, and to an area in which other remains were similarly buried, make the researchers reasonably certain they have found the "original 18" -- 18 Black massacre victims reported at the time to have been buried in Oaklawn Cemetery but without information about their exact location -- and two sets of remains with signs of gunshot wounds.\n\nStubblefield said a cause of death could not be determined for Daniel, whose remains were exhumed in 2021 and later reinterred in the same grave. She said it appeared that the body had been scrunched into a coffin too small for him.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nBynum indicated that Daniel\'s family, whose members were not identified, have not decided how they want to proceed with final burial.\n\n"We\'re going to work with them every step of the way," Bynum said. "Whatever they decide to do with the remains, the city of Tulsa is fully supportive of that."\n\nDaniel\'s identification accounts for one of several of the Original 18 listed on death certificates as "unknown." It also has reinvigorated the project.\n\nAt Friday\'s press conference, Bynum said the archeological team will return to Oaklawn on July 22. Stackelbeck indicated that this phase will last more than a week and will concentrate on the Original 18 area.\n\n"We now feel doubly confident of the criteria we\'ve been using to know which ones are good candidates for exhumation," she said.\n\nDanny Hellwig, director of Intermountain\'s Laboratory Development, said Daniel\'s identification is really the first of its kind.\n\n"This hasn\'t really been done before," Hellwig said. "We\'ve been learning through the process. As we\'ve learned and adapted, we\'re getting better at it. ... We hope this will provide some confidence and context and maybe a lot more trust so that we can expand on this."\n\nIdentification relies on voluntarily submitted DNA, public databases and families\' willingness to answer questions about relatives or ancestors.\n\nIn Daniel\'s case, researchers said, extended family members were mostly unaware of the circumstances of his death, if they knew of him at all. Intermountain\'s Alison Wilde, who handles the genealogical side, said many living family members did not know each other, much less the story of a great uncle who died without direct descendants more than a century ago.\n\nThe Tulsa World is where your story lives\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nIn 1921, white mobs invaded Greenwood and burned it down\n\nA growing but divided city had tensions rising. How World War I influenced residents.\n\nKey figures in 1921\n\nGreenwood was defined by freedom and opportunity\n\nAn encounter on an elevator and concerns about a lynching\n\nTulsa Tribune article cited for sparking massacre\n\nDick Rowland\'s life threatened while jailed as crowd gathers outside\n\nTulsans take up arms and there are issues with special deputies\n\nFighting begins in Greenwood and the neighborhood is soon overrun\n\nMobs won\'t let firefighters douse the flames\n\nAirplanes flew over Greenwood as it was attacked\n\nNational Guard called in, denies report that machine guns were used to kill dozens\n\nDr. A.C. Jackson was killed as he tried to surrender in his front yard\n\nDeath toll remains unknown; search for graves continues today\n\nBlack Tulsans were marched through the streets and detained at camps throughout city\n\nRed Cross reports the massive devastation in Greenwood\n\nKey locations in Tulsa during the 1921 Race Massacre\n\nMount Zion Baptist Church was burned down but, like Greenwood, persevered and rebuilt\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Quotes from survivors, officials and others\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Recommended reading\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Was 1921 the first aerial assault on U.S. soil?\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\n"The first time Americans were terrorized by an aerial assault was not Pearl Harbor," a CBS News story says leading up to coverage this weekend of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.\n\n"Scott Pelley reports on a race massacre in which an estimated 300 people, mostly African American men, women and children, were killed, and aircraft were used to drop incendiary devices on a black neighborhood in Tulsa, Oklahoma. The Greenwood Massacre of 1921 has been largely ignored by history, but Pelley finds a Tulsa community seeking to shed more light on what\'s been called the worst race massacre in history," a preview reads for a "60 Minutes" story airing 6 p.m. Sunday on CBS.\n\nContext for viewers: Six airplanes circled the Greenwood area during the morning hours of June 1.\n\nWhat they were doing, and why there were so many, has long been a matter of passionate debate. Many people believe they were used to shoot at people on the ground and bomb Greenwood.\n\nOfficials said the small craft, generally thought to be two-seat, single-engine Curtis "Jenny" biplanes, were merely keeping track of activities on the ground and relaying the information through written messages dropped in weighted metal cylinders attached to streamers.\n\nTo what extent this explanation was initially challenged is unclear, but in October 1921 the Chicago Defender published a story in which it said Greenwood had been bombed under orders of "prominent city officials."\n\nThe story cited a Van B. Hurley, who the newspaper said had given a signed statement to Elisha Scott, a Kansas attorney.\n\nScott filed dozens of lawsuits on behalf of victims but doesn\'t seem to have ever entered the Hurley affidavit into the record. There is no record of a Van B. Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance. Many people believed city officials were behind the burning of Greenwood, and the explanation that the squadron of planes was only used for surveillance struck some as suspiciously thin.\n\nCertainly the planes had a great psychological impact on many. For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. It is also highly unstable and dangerous.\n\nThat has caused some to speculate that something like Molotov cocktails might have been used, or "turpentine balls" -- rags soaked in flammable liquid and wrapped around the head of a stick.\n\nThere are several practical reasons why trying to light and throw incendiary devices from an open cockpit airplane of that era would seem a difficult, dangerous and even foolish idea.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean it wasn\'t done.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921', 'source': {'uri': 'magicvalley.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Magic Valley'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/magicvalley.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/5f/95ff6bfc-f359-5d8e-a86c-f5aab1e5b911/66919e3a65bb1.preview.jpg?crop=1764%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.2313725490196078, 'wgt': 458542980, 'relevance': 31}

{'uri': '2024-07-420395466', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '03:26:18', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T03:26:18Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T02:54:09Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8627451062202454, 'url': 'https://internewscast.com/news/us/landscaper-compares-treatment-to-a-murderer-over-hefty-fine-for-filling-unsafe-hole/', 'title': "Landscaper compares treatment to a 'murderer' over hefty fine for filling unsafe hole - Internewscast Journal", 'body': 'The fine was followed by a demand to inspect his property for "unsafe" building work after he took his story to the media.\n\nAdam Marsal, 40, says he was only trying to do the right thing when he filled in a large hole that had been left by a fallen tree in the nature strip near his Cranbourne Road home in Frankston late last year.\n\nThe roughly two-meter hole, just behind a bus stop, had been left for months and Mr. Marsal had "seen people tumble off the side".\n\n"I tried to do the right thing," he said.\n\n"This tree stump was huge. I sort of smoothed it out, used my skills to fix it all up. I put some soil in, put some plants."\n\nThe landscaper, who grew up in nearby Mentone, said he was "passionate about the area" and wanted to help clean it up.\n\n"Driving around you see rubbish everywhere," he said.\n\n"I\'m just sorting out my little patch. It\'s that broken windows philosophy -- cleaning up rubbish and needles, making it look normal, it deters people dumping stuff."\n\nBut to his surprise, Mr. Marsal was contacted by Frankston City Council officers earlier this year requesting he come to discuss the unauthorized works, after a tip-off by another local.\n\nMr. Marsal said he thought he was "just going in to have a conversation", but instead was subjected to an extraordinary police-style interrogation by Bruce Gardiner, the council\'s prosecutions co-ordinator.\n\nFrom the beginning of the 20-minute grilling, described as "disturbing" by a local MP, Mr. Marsal was "already on the defensive" after what he alleges was Mr. Gardiner\'s "rude and arrogant" treatment of him on the phone.\n\nMr. Gardiner -- who made headlines last year after pop star Tones and I and her husband were slapped with $25,000 [$16,915 USD] in fines for illegal renovations to their Frankston investment property -- opens the on-camera interview by telling Mr. Marsal he was going to ask about "some allegations about the illegal deposit of litter on the side of the road".\n\n"I don\'t know that it\'s litter, but OK," Mr. Marsal says.\n\nMr. Gardiner proceeds to read Mr. Marsal his rights and requests he state his full name, sparking a hostile back-and-forth that sets the tone for the remainder of the combative interview.\n\n"There\'s probably a lot of Adam Marsals in the world," Mr. Gardiner says.\n\n"No not really, if you want to do a Google search," Mr. Marsal says.\n\n"Do you want to state your full name or not?" Mr. Gardiner says.\n\n"I\'ll just say Adam Marsal," Mr. Marsal says.\n\n"Do you want to state your full name or not?" Mr. Gardiner says.\n\nMr. Gardiner bristles when Mr. Marsal similarly refuses to give his age and date of birth, or answer questions about his business, saying he doesn\'t "see how that\'s relevant".\n\n"Well answer my questions or don\'t answer my questions, let me work out what\'s relevant and what\'s not, OK?" Mr. Gardiner says.\n\nLater in the interview Mr. Gardiner produces a series of photos of the hole.\n\n"Yeah I\'ve cleaned up the site, it used to be a f**king derelict site, full of s**t," Mr. Marsal says angrily.\n\n"Mind you, there was this big gum tree, it fell over and you left a hole in the ground two metres deep and about four metres wide, right here, for about six months, so I cleaned it up."\n\n"You work for the council -- the council left the hole in the ground," Mr. Marsal says.\n\n"Adam, why did you put those items on the side of the road?" Mr. Gardiner says.\n\n"I\'ve just been telling you," Mr. Marsal says.\n\n"Did you hear what I\'ve been talking about. Does that answer your question?"\n\n"No it doesn\'t," Mr. Gardiner says.\n\n"Your suggestion is that you put those items there to beautify the area."\n\nHe tells Mr. Marsal council has no record of him having reported the hole.\n\nMr. Marsal insists "I called you guys, I called VicRoads, I cleaned it up because no one was coming".\n\n"This is my home, I live across the road from this place," he says.\n\n"I\'ve spent thousands of dollars buying stuff for this."\n\nMr. Gardiner informs him that to do works in a road reserve he needs a permit, which Mr. Marsal concedes he does not have.\n\nLast month, Mr. Marsal received two infringement notices -- one to himself and one to his company -- for "depositing waste of more than 1000 liters" in violation of the Environment Protection Act 2017, totaling $11,500 [$7,781 USD].\n\nAfter his story was featured on Nine\'s A Current Affair earlier this week, Mr. Marsal then received another letter from council requesting access to his property for a building inspection on Monday, July 15.\n\n"Frankston City Council has received information that there is potentially unsafe or non-compliant building work at the abovementioned property that requires inspection," the letter said.\n\nnews.com.au does not suggest that Mr. Gardiner had any involvement in the issuing of the letter.\n\nMr. Marsal said he had owned his two-bedroom freestanding unit for nearly 10 years.\n\n"Years ago I did some renovations inside and landscaped it, put retaining walls up, fixed the veranda that was falling down and put in some stairs," he said.\n\n"That\'s the extent of it. It\'s been like that for years, and coincidentally after the other issue they sent [this letter]. It makes me feel intimidated and harassed. I\'m pretty sure they can go to any house in Australia and pick someone up on anything."\n\nMr. Marsal said he did not intend to give consent to the search, meaning the council "have the option to go to a magistrate and get a search warrant".\n\n"I\'m not a murderer, I\'m not a drug dealer," he said.\n\n"I try to keep my head down in life, I don\'t want these kinds of issues. You just don\'t go and treat people like this."\n\nPaul Edbrooke, the Labor state MP for Frankston, said watching how Mr. Marsal was treated in the video "was actually quite disturbing".\n\n"These kinds of issues can be treated in a much more pragmatic and productive manner," he said.\n\n"In the last few months we\'ve had quite a few complaints in regards to the way ratepayers are being treated by council over issues such as this one. Personally I have no idea why council would be this heavy-handed on someone that basically did their job for them."\n\nMr. Edbrooke said he had "no idea at all why you would treat anyone in your community like that."\n\n"The effect on Adam\'s small business is just amazing and very, very disruptive," he said.\n\nThe MP also said he found the timing of the letter "really suspicious".\n\n"A reasonable person could start thinking that this is targeting, intimidating and bullying someone," he said.\n\n"This council has been pulled up quite a few times for alleged bullying. I think there is some big cultural issue."\n\nMr. Edbrooke said "overall the message I\'ve gotten" from constituents was the council was "out of touch, out of focus and they\'ve got a culture problem".\n\n"People are just wondering, when the rates, roads and rubbish portion of their council rates, they don\'t get those services, why council are focusing on these other pet projects they\'ve got," he said.\n\n"Meanwhile a hole that had been there more than six months, two metres deep, a guy that has to take matters into his own hands is then charged $11,500 [$7,781 USD]."\n\nAdam Glezer from Consumer Champion, who is representing Mr. Marsal, said he had "seen council issues but nothing nearly as disgraceful as this situation".\n\n"It seems like a classic case of bullying," he said.\n\n"The tactics that the council used in this situation were extremely inappropriate."\n\nMr. Glezer said from what he had heard, "this is a systemic problem with Frankston City Council".\n\n"How can you give a good Samaritan a $11,500 fine for making an area safe that the council failed to do themselves?" he said.\n\n"Adam went in for a meeting with his local city council, not the AFP. That\'s exactly how they came across."\n\nHe added that "rather than apologising for their egregious behaviour, the council has doubled down".\n\n"He\'s done nothing different to his house in several years, yet the council thought it was appropriate to send him [an inspection] letter shortly after I got involved in his case," he said.\n\n"Frankston City Council representatives need to have a good, hard look at themselves because they are an absolute embarrassment. It appears they couldn\'t care less about their community."\n\nLate on Friday, after news.com.au sent questions to Frankston City Council, Mr. Marsal said he received an email informing him Monday\'s inspection would not go ahead.', 'source': {'uri': 'internewscast.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Internewscast Journal'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://internewscast.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Landscaper-claims-hes-being-treated-like-a-murderer-after-being.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9729747', 'sentiment': 0.07450980392156858, 'wgt': 458537178, 'relevance': 29}
{'uri': '2024-07-420380927', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '02:50:54', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T02:50:54Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T02:45:55Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://nypost.com/2024/07/12/lifestyle/landscaper-claims-hes-being-treated-like-a-murderer-after-being-fined-thousands-for-filling-in-a-dangerous-hole/', 'title': "Landscaper claims he's being treated like a 'murderer' after being...", 'body': 'A Melbourne landscaper says he is being treated like a "murderer or a drug dealer" by his local council after he was slapped with an $11,500 [$7,781 USD] fine for filling in a dangerous hole.\n\nThe fine was followed by a demand to inspect his property for "unsafe" building work after he took his story to the media.\n\nAdam Marsal, 40, says he was only trying to do the right thing when he filled in a large hole that had been left by a fallen tree in the nature strip near his Cranbourne Road home in Frankston late last year.\n\nThe roughly two-meter hole, just behind a bus stop, had been left for months and Mr. Marsal had "seen people tumble off the side".\n\n"I tried to do the right thing," he said.\n\n"This tree stump was huge. I sort of smoothed it out, used my skills to fix it all up. I put some soil in, put some plants."\n\nThe landscaper, who grew up in nearby Mentone, said he was "passionate about the area" and wanted to help clean it up.\n\n"Driving around you see rubbish everywhere," he said.\n\n"I\'m just sorting out my little patch. It\'s that broken windows philosophy -- cleaning up rubbish and needles, making it look normal, it deters people dumping stuff."\n\nBut to his surprise, Mr. Marsal was contacted by Frankston City Council officers earlier this year requesting he come to discuss the unauthorized works, after a tip-off by another local.\n\nMr. Marsal said he thought he was "just going in to have a conversation", but instead was subjected to an extraordinary police-style interrogation by Bruce Gardiner, the council\'s prosecutions co-ordinator.\n\nFrom the beginning of the 20-minute grilling, described as "disturbing" by a local MP, Mr. Marsal was "already on the defensive" after what he alleges was Mr. Gardiner\'s "rude and arrogant" treatment of him on the phone.\n\nMr. Gardiner -- who made headlines last year after pop star Tones and I and her husband were slapped with $25,000 [$16,915 USD] in fines for illegal renovations to their Frankston investment property -- opens the on-camera interview by telling Mr. Marsal he was going to ask about "some allegations about the illegal deposit of litter on the side of the road".\n\n"I don\'t know that it\'s litter, but OK," Mr. Marsal says.\n\nMr. Gardiner proceeds to read Mr. Marsal his rights and requests he state his full name, sparking a hostile back-and-forth that sets the tone for the remainder of the combative interview.\n\n"There\'s probably a lot of Adam Marsals in the world," Mr. Gardiner says.\n\n"No not really, if you want to do a Google search," Mr. Marsal says.\n\n"Do you want to state your full name or not?" Mr. Gardiner says.\n\n"I\'ll just say Adam Marsal," Mr. Marsal says.\n\n"Do you want to state your full name or not?" Mr. Gardiner says.\n\nMr. Gardiner bristles when Mr. Marsal similarly refuses to give his age and date of birth, or answer questions about his business, saying he doesn\'t "see how that\'s relevant".\n\n"Well answer my questions or don\'t answer my questions, let me work out what\'s relevant and what\'s not, OK?" Mr. Gardiner says.\n\nLater in the interview Mr. Gardiner produces a series of photos of the hole.\n\n"Yeah I\'ve cleaned up the site, it used to be a f**king derelict site, full of s**t," Mr. Marsal says angrily.\n\n"Mind you, there was this big gum tree, it fell over and you left a hole in the ground two metres deep and about four metres wide, right here, for about six months, so I cleaned it up."\n\n"You work for the council -- the council left the hole in the ground," Mr. Marsal says.\n\n"Adam, why did you put those items on the side of the road?" Mr. Gardiner says.\n\n"I\'ve just been telling you," Mr. Marsal says.\n\n"Did you hear what I\'ve been talking about. Does that answer your question?"\n\n"No it doesn\'t," Mr. Gardiner says.\n\n"Your suggestion is that you put those items there to beautify the area."\n\nHe tells Mr. Marsal council has no record of him having reported the hole.\n\nMr. Marsal insists "I called you guys, I called VicRoads, I cleaned it up because no one was coming".\n\n"This is my home, I live across the road from this place," he says.\n\n"I\'ve spent thousands of dollars buying stuff for this."\n\nMr. Gardiner informs him that to do works in a road reserve he needs a permit, which Mr. Marsal concedes he does not have.\n\nLast month, Mr. Marsal received two infringement notices -- one to himself and one to his company -- for "depositing waste of more than 1000 liters" in violation of the Environment Protection Act 2017, totaling $11,500 [$7,781 USD].\n\nAfter his story was featured on Nine\'s A Current Affair earlier this week, Mr. Marsal then received another letter from council requesting access to his property for a building inspection on Monday, July 15.\n\n"Frankston City Council has received information that there is potentially unsafe or non-compliant building work at the abovementioned property that requires inspection," the letter said.\n\nnews.com.au does not suggest that Mr. Gardiner had any involvement in the issuing of the letter.\n\nMr. Marsal said he had owned his two-bedroom freestanding unit for nearly 10 years.\n\n"Years ago I did some renovations inside and landscaped it, put retaining walls up, fixed the veranda that was falling down and put in some stairs," he said.\n\n"That\'s the extent of it. It\'s been like that for years, and coincidentally after the other issue they sent [this letter]. It makes me feel intimidated and harassed. I\'m pretty sure they can go to any house in Australia and pick someone up on anything."\n\nMr. Marsal said he did not intend to give consent to the search, meaning the council "have the option to go to a magistrate and get a search warrant".\n\n"I\'m not a murderer, I\'m not a drug dealer," he said.\n\n"I try to keep my head down in life, I don\'t want these kinds of issues. You just don\'t go and treat people like this."\n\nPaul Edbrooke, the Labor state MP for Frankston, said watching how Mr. Marsal was treated in the video "was actually quite disturbing".\n\n"These kinds of issues can be treated in a much more pragmatic and productive manner," he said.\n\n"In the last few months we\'ve had quite a few complaints in regards to the way ratepayers are being treated by council over issues such as this one. Personally I have no idea why council would be this heavy-handed on someone that basically did their job for them."\n\nMr. Edbrooke said he had "no idea at all why you would treat anyone in your community like that."\n\n"The effect on Adam\'s small business is just amazing and very, very disruptive," he said.\n\nThe MP also said he found the timing of the letter "really suspicious".\n\n"A reasonable person could start thinking that this is targeting, intimidating and bullying someone," he said.\n\n"This council has been pulled up quite a few times for alleged bullying. I think there is some big cultural issue."\n\nMr. Edbrooke said "overall the message I\'ve gotten" from constituents was the council was "out of touch, out of focus and they\'ve got a culture problem".\n\n"People are just wondering, when the rates, roads and rubbish portion of their council rates, they don\'t get those services, why council are focusing on these other pet projects they\'ve got," he said.\n\n"Meanwhile a hole that had been there more than six months, two metres deep, a guy that has to take matters into his own hands is then charged $11,500 [$7,781 USD]."\n\nAdam Glezer from Consumer Champion, who is representing Mr. Marsal, said he had "seen council issues but nothing nearly as disgraceful as this situation".\n\n"It seems like a classic case of bullying," he said.\n\n"The tactics that the council used in this situation were extremely inappropriate."\n\nMr. Glezer said from what he had heard, "this is a systemic problem with Frankston City Council".\n\n"How can you give a good Samaritan a $11,500 fine for making an area safe that the council failed to do themselves?" he said.\n\n"Adam went in for a meeting with his local city council, not the AFP. That\'s exactly how they came across."\n\nHe added that "rather than apologising for their egregious behaviour, the council has doubled down".\n\n"He\'s done nothing different to his house in several years, yet the council thought it was appropriate to send him [an inspection] letter shortly after I got involved in his case," he said.\n\n"Frankston City Council representatives need to have a good, hard look at themselves because they are an absolute embarrassment. It appears they couldn\'t care less about their community."\n\nLate on Friday, after news.com.au sent questions to Frankston City Council, Mr. Marsal said he received an email informing him Monday\'s inspection would not go ahead.', 'source': {'uri': 'nypost.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'New York Post'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://nypost.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2024/07/500-council-filling-hole-now-85372989.jpg?quality=75&strip=all&w=1024', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.02745098039215688, 'wgt': 458535054, 'relevance': 29}
{'uri': '8223141296', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '02:39:54', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T02:39:54Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-13T02:39:20Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8078431487083435, 'url': 'https://newsadvance.com/sports/college/did-kansas-state-really-offer-a-colorado-state-football-player-600-000-to-transfer/article_edabaedd-61f8-5dfc-86a6-d953b34a6dfb.html', 'title': 'Did Kansas State really offer a Colorado State football player $600,000 to transfer?', 'body': 'Kellis Robinett, The Wichita Eagle\n\nColorado State football coach Jay Norvell isn\'t happy that other teams tried to convince some of his best players to enter the transfer portal after the conclusion of the 2023 season.\n\nHe is so angry about it, in fact, that he accused three teams of tampering while he spoke to reporters at Mountain West Media Days earlier this week in Las Vegas. One of them was Kansas State, which he said reached out and offered a very large sum of money to either quarterback Brayden Fowler-Nicolosi or wide receiver Tory Horton (it was unclear to whom he was referring) in exchange for them transferring to the Wildcats.\n\n"If you have enough evidence you can prove it," Norvell said. "But, you know, a smoking gun is a smoking gun. He said a guy from Kansas State called and offered him $600,000 because they lost their quarterback, offered him $600,000 if he entered the portal. I\'m not accusing Kansas State of anything. I\'m just telling you what the kid told me. If they don\'t want their name thrown in it, they should probably get a handle on their people."\n\nK-State made news in Las Vegas even after Chris Klieman and five football players left Big 12 Media Days inside Allegiant Stadium on Monday. Go figure.\n\nNorvell went on to say that Texas A&M and Mississippi also tried entice those players to leave with similar offers.\n\nThis type of thing likely happens all the time, given the current age of college sports. It is technically against NCAA rules for a coaching staff to recruit a football player from another team\'s roster unless his name appears in the transfer portal. But it goes without saying that teams use third parties to reach out to players and express interest.\n\nMost of those conversations are kept private.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nQuestion is: Did the Wildcats really bend the rules to reach out with a lucrative offer for a Colorado State football player?\n\nBased on the context of his statement, it seems like Norvell is most likely referring to Fowler-Nicolosi, who threw for 3,460 yards and 22 touchdowns last season. If that was the case, it wouldn\'t make a ton of sense for the Wildcats to offer him $600,000 because sophomore Avery Johnson is locked in as the team\'s starting quarterback.\n\nWill Howard transferring to Ohio State left a hole on the K-State depth chart at QB, but only at the No. 2 spot. Would the Wildcats really be willing to spend an exorbitant amount on a backup?\n\nK-State ended up landing Connecticut transfer Ta\'Quan Roberson on what is believed to be a much lower NIL deal. He is now expected to serve as QB2 this season.\n\nThe dollar figure that Norvell referred to would make more sense for a star receiver like Horton, who had 1,136 yards and eight touchdowns on 96 catches last season. But a deal of that magnitude would also raise eyebrows because of how confident Klieman seems in the receivers he has returning.\n\nKlieman said earlier this week that he expects big things from Jayce Brown, Keagan Johnson and several others. So much so, that he wants to throw the ball more this season.\n\nThen again, NIL arrangements keep getting higher and higher. It\'s possible that either of these Colorado State players could command $600,000 from Big 12 or SEC teams on the open market.\n\nIt\'s impossible to know what really transpired here. But Norvell wasn\'t afraid to point his finger at a few programs.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'newsadvance.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'NewsAdvance.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/newsadvance.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/75/37598aef-f5b1-5bf8-b56a-da95d1b43bb2/6691dfc42b2e6.image.jpg?crop=1714%2C900%2C0%2C154&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9726297', 'sentiment': -0.1215686274509804, 'wgt': 458534394, 'relevance': 51}

{'uri': '2024-07-420322129', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-13', 'time': '00:03:37', 'dateTime': '2024-07-13T00:03:37Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T23:36:40Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.843137264251709, 'url': 'https://www.businessinsider.in/tech/news/a-string-of-waymo-tire-slashings-is-the-latest-example-of-vandalism-against-self-driving-cars-in-san-francisco/articleshow/111700583.cms', 'title': 'A string of Waymo tire slashings is the latest example of vandalism against self-driving cars in San Francisco | Business Insider India', 'body': 'Over a dozen of Waymo\'s self-driving cars were vandalized in San Francisco.\n\nA string of tire slashings and charges brought against the woman who police believe is responsible highlight that tensions remain within some in the city and the futuristic driving technology.\n\nSan Francisco District Attorney Brooke Jenkins announced Thursday that 36-year-old Ronaile Joshua Burton has been charged with 17 counts of vandalism on Waymo self-driving vehicles. Waymo, which was formerly Google\'s self-driving car project, is now a subsidiary of the tech giant\'s parent company, Alphabet.\n\nThe incidents, which each allotted damages exceeding $400, took place in the city\'s Tenderloin between June 24 and 26, according to the DA\'s office. Each instance was caught on cameras installed in the vehicles, the authorities said.\n\nProsecutors also alleged that Burton slashed the tires of a three-car Waymo caravan. Court records indicate Burton has been assigned a public defender. Burton\'s attorney, Deputy Public Defender Adam Birka-White, said in a statement that she chosen to plead not guilty.\n\n"Ms. Burton is someone in need of help and not jail, which is why our social workers are actively working to identify and secure appropriate services," Birka-White said. "The District Attorney continues to prioritize punishing poor people at the behest of corporations."\n\nWaymo said in a statement that it is "taking steps to recover the damages sustained, and mitigate the potential for future events."\n\n"Waymo exists to make roads safer, and with that in mind we will always prioritize the safety of our riders and community," it added.\n\nThe arrest follows other reported incidents of vandalism against Waymo\'s self-driving cars in the last year. In February, a Waymo robotaxi was set on fire while driving through the city\'s Chinatown during Lunar New Year celebrations.\n\nAlthough Mayor London Breed at the time had described the vandalism as "an isolated incident," Reuters reported that a passenger in a Waymo the day after the incident had fireworks shot at him.\n\nSan Francisco is one of the main test beds for self-driving tech, and incidents involving the vehicles -- as well as traditional human-driven cars -- are bound to come up. In addition to Waymo, Tesla tested its Full Self-Driving feature in the city earlier this year, and Amazon-owned Zoox took to the winding streets for the first time back in 2018.\n\nCruise, which is owned by General Motors, began operating driverless vehicles in the city in 2022 before suspending testing operations the following year following a collision with a pedestrian who was dragged beneath the vehicle. The company has begun operating again with human drivers behind the wheel, though it said its goal is to eventually resume driverless rides.\n\nSome riders have marveled at Waymo\'s robotaxis -- Business Insider\'s Lloyd Lee recently took a ride in one and wrote that the self-driving vehicle felt like a better driver than some human drivers in San Francisco.\n\nHowever, the vandalism incidents and high level of scrutiny around the cars\' safety over the last year demonstrate the challenges the companies behind the futuristic vehicles face -- even in a techie city like San Francisco.', 'source': {'uri': 'businessinsider.in', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Business Insider India'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'jaures_yip@businessinsider.in', 'name': 'Jaures Yip', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://staticbiassets.in/thumb/msid-111698584,width-700,resizemode-4,imgsize-2262478/img661d3bab1caec1275a701438.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9726648', 'sentiment': -0.08235294117647063, 'wgt': 458525017, 'relevance': 57}
{'uri': '8223015371', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '23:37:10', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T23:37:10Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T23:36:28Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.729411780834198, 'url': 'https://heraldcourier.com/sports/bhc-girls-basketball-coach-of-year-funk-found-redemption-at-eastside/article_230f4870-4002-11ef-bd1e-9346d51e0913.html', 'title': 'BHC GIRLS BASKETBALL COACH OF YEAR: Funk found redemption at Eastside', 'body': 'Eastside\'s Lexi Carter hugs head coach Terri Anne Hill Funk after the Spartans defeated Brunswick to win the Class 1 state title in Richmond.\n\nAllen Gregory\n\nCOEBURN, Va. - As the final seconds of the 2024 VHSL Class 1 girls basketball title game clicked off at Virginia Commonwealth University, Eastside Spartans head coach Terri Anne Funk reflected on her long journey to the summit.\n\n"It\'s been quite a story for my players and for myself," Funk said. "It goes from sorrow to success, forgiveness and joy."\n\nFlash back to the 2023 Class 1 finals at VCU where Eastside dropped a 70-65 decision to Rappahannock County.\n\n"We never forgot that loss and we definitely used it for motivation," Eastside post player Lexi Carter said.\n\nConsider the first step as head coach for Funk at the newly consolidated Eastside High School in 2011.\n\n"They fired me after one year," Funk said. "We were district champs despite having seven girls quit at mid-season, we won more games than St. Paul and Coeburn ever won, and we were selected as coaching staff of the year in the district.\n\nPeople are also reading... McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic LITTLE LEAGUE: Good day for local teams in state softball tournament TVA announces changes at South Holston, Boone properties \'Vampire\' series gives Sam Reid plenty to bite into Simmons to expand manufacturing into Russell County AUTO RACING: Rural Retreat native Will Hostetler\'s a hometown hero at Wythe Raceway COLLEGE BASEBALL: Chase Hungate (Abingdon) headed to Mississippi State, relishes chance to compete in SEC COLLEGE FOOTBALL: You can find Brad Robbins (Powell Valley) coaching at UConn now HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Coaching innovator Mumme to serve on Sullivan East coaching staff LITTLE LEAGUE: Monday\'s State Tournament Results FOOTBALL CAMP: Former Tennessee QBs Hooker, Milton hosts football camp at Sullivan East PREP FOOTBALL: The VHSL master schedule was released on Thursday. Here are some games with intriguing storylines LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon falls in Virginia state title game Marketplace dining opening at Hard Rock Bristol Casino donations near $900,000 with Tuesday presentation\n\n"The (administration) wanted to go in a different direction, and I asked them if that direction was losing. But looking back, all that turned out to be a blessing because my husband and had more time together."\n\nThe redemption came in the 2024 title game where the Spartans recorded a 55-50 win over a 25-2 Brunswick squad.\n\n"I\'ve watched that replay at least 15 times, and we played horrible," Funk said. "We turned the ball over on our first six possessions before Shelby Stanley came off the bench to score six straight points."\n\nA 5-foot-6 rising junior, Stanley was nicknamed "The Wolf" because of her aggressive playing style and fearless approach on defense.\n\nStanley credits her head coach for instilling confidence in all the Spartans.\n\n"I really got to know Coach Funk around three years ago," Stanley said. "She has pushed me hard in all aspects of the basketball, especially on defense."\n\nStanley said there are two different sides to Funk.\n\n"And I\'ve seen them both," Stanley said. "When Coach Funk yells at us, there\'s always a positive point to her message and it pays off in the end. Coach Funk is like a life coach off the court, helping us with anything we need. "\n\nAccording to Carter, Funk relies on the basics of competition and compassion instead of gimmicks or formulas.\n\n"It just comes down to hard work and dedication to the program," Carter said. "Coach Funk yelled at me a few times, but she\'s the reason I stuck with basketball."\n\nEntering her junior season, Carter was not even sure she wanted to play.\n\n"I had a lot of doubts and just felt done with the game," Carter said. "I had a few long talks with Coach Funk and she pushed me to do my best. And as a senior, I wanted to see how far I could go with my teammates."\n\nThe sorrowful chapter of Funk\'s story deals with a never-ending struggle rooted in deep faith.\n\nBrock Funk, Terri\'s husband, died suddenly on Jan. 16 of 2015 after contracting bacterial meningitis from a sinus infection. He was 28.\n\nIt was left to Terri Anne Funk to raise the couple\'s young children, Zeke and Zoe, as a single mother.\n\nBrock and Terri Anne met at the University of Virginia\'s College at Wise, where they were both athletes.\n\n"When everything happened with Brock, I completely stepped away from sports because around games kept everything so fresh," Funk said. "I just felt like the Lord wanted to give me a time to heal and to be a mother."\n\nFunk grew up around athletics and starred in five sports at St. Paul High School.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\n"It was not hard being without away from sports at the time," Funk said. "But you don\'t realize how much you miss something until you start getting back into it."\n\nFunk returned to coaching during the 2017-18 season as an assistant under boys basketball head coach Patrick Damron.\n\n"I wouldn\'t have thought about getting back into basketball until Coach Damron called with the job offer," Funk said.\n\nAfter taking another break, Funk was selected to direct the Eastside girls program for the second time last year.\n\n"I had no desire at all to get back into coaching but I just felt like it was the hand of the Lord opening the door," Funk said. "I credit Coach Damron for helping me reach this point."\n\nAfter the Spartans posted a 24-6 record en route to the 2023 Class 1 title game, Funk was selected as the Bristol Herald Courier coach of the year.\n\n"I knew there was some talent when I took over this program, and it\'s my responsibility to get the most out of each player," Funk said. "You can\'t always reach that goal by being nice. Sometimes you have to scream and make corrections."\n\nWhat is Funk\'s bottom-line approach to coaching?\n\n"I believe that if you build trust and have a relationship with your athletes first, they will do anything for you," Funk said. "We have some very strenuous practices at the beginning of the season."\n\nThe extra work is designed to teach the Spartans the importance of defense and team pride.\n\n"I love man-to-man defense," Funk said.\n\nAccording to Carter, the state championship buzz was intense.\n\n"Oh yes, I was on Cloud nine," Carter said. "I will always remember that feeling and this season."\n\nFor Funk, the state championship vibe remains.\n\n"It\'s still sinking in. It was such a blessing to see an amazing group of young ladies come together and make school history," Funk said. "I was in the right place at the right time, and everything just fell into place."\n\nFunk said she doesn\'t look back in bitterness at what happened in her first stint as the Eastside coach.\n\n"There have been times when I maybe want to get back at people. But I believe in the Lord being our avenger, so He took care of all that," Funk said.\n\nThe story of the 2024 Eastside Spartans featured a bonus chapter via an appearance Good Morning America.\n\n"That was completely unexpected and it all started with the girls pranking me on video," Funk said.\n\nSeconds after clinching the state title, the video clip shows the Eastside players sitting in the locker room with dejected expressions.\n\nFunk appeared surprised when she came through the door and started spraying water on her players. But the Eastside players soon surrounded the coach in a celebration dance.\n\n"Lexi made the original post and a couple people shared it. Things went viral from there," Funk said. "It turned into great publicity for our program and school."\n\nFunk was contacted by producers from ESPN before the Good Morning America segment.\n\n"It was an amazing season," Funk said. "I still remember standing at the end of the bench in that state championship game and just absorbing it all, especially the last 30 seconds.\n\n"I\'ve had several people tell me that a movie should be made about all that\'s happened since my first year here in 2011. And I really do think a movie will be made some day."\n\nagregory@bristolnews.com -- Twitter: @Greg_BHCSports <&dateline> (276) 645-2544\n\nagregory@bristolnews.com | Twitter: @Greg_BHCSports | (276) 645-2544\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. It cut a paw after apparently leaning on a window and breaking it, officials said.\n\nThere was "no meaningful effect on the hospital\'s operations," Daniel Gibson, a spokesman for TMC said in an email. No one was injured.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe lion was tranquilized about 12:30 p.m. and loaded it onto a Game and Fish pickup truck. The mountain lion was then taken to the department\'s regional office, said Michael Colaianni, an agency spokesman.\n\nPeople are also reading... {'uri': '8222991286', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '23:05:21', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T23:05:21Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T23:04:43Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://omaha.com/sports/professional/bradley-ryder-cup-captain-surprise/article_e6410791-3bd8-5f80-9b96-96f66f6b8670.html', 'title': 'Bradley as Ryder Cup captain raises questions whether U.S. task force plan is over', 'body': 'NORTH BERWICK, Scotland -- Justin Thomas was just starting his rookie season on the PGA Tour when the Americans formed the infamous "Ryder Cup Task Force" geared toward building continuity with hopes of restoring U.S. dominance in the matches.\n\nTen years later, Thomas was part of the Ryder Cup Committee that selected Keegan Bradley as the next captain.\n\nIt was a surprising choice because Bradley played in only two Ryder Cups and had no experience as an assistant. That was part of the template that came out of the task force. Future captains would first be groomed as assistants. Captains would stay on as an assistant at the following Ryder Cup. Everyone would be on the same page.\n\nIt\'s what led Phil Mickelson to declare in early 2015 after the task force came up with the plan, "I\'m excited about where we are now, and I\'m excited about where we are headed -- not just into 2016, but really for the next 10 or 20 years."\n\nIs that the end of the task force plan?\n\n"Yes and no," Thomas said at the Scottish Open. "My thing is I want us to pick the best captain. I don\'t want it to feel like it needs to fit a certain résumé; it doesn\'t need to fit this right mold. It\'s like, \'Look, who\'s our best captain right now?\'\n\n"It doesn\'t matter what they\'ve done," he said. "Are the guys going to be excited to play for him? Is he going to mesh with everybody? That\'s all that matters. That\'s something that potentially is the hope going forward. Next year is the only one that matters right now."\n\nDavis Love III was the first captain that came out of the task force for the 2016 matches at Hazeltine, a U.S. victory against a European team that had six rookies, five of whom never played in another Ryder Cup.\n\nHis assistants included Jim Furyk, Steve Stricker and Tiger Woods. Furyk was the next captain for 2018 in France. His assistants included Stricker, Woods and Zach Johnson. Then it was Stricker\'s turn in Wisconsin. Furyk was an assistant, along with Love (again) and Johnson. And then Johnson got the job for Marco Simone outside Rome.\n\nAnd on it went, the home side winning each time.\n\nIn some respects, Bradley broke the mold. He hasn\'t been involved in a Ryder Cup or Presidents Cup since 2014, except for being part of the Netflix docuseries that filmed him getting the awkward call from Johnson that he would not be a captain\'s pick.\n\nRory McIlroy is a keen observer of all things Ryder Cup and was surprised by Bradley choice, like so many others.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"I think Keegan was probably in disbelief, at some point, too," McIlroy said with a smile. "But certainly an interesting pick."\n\nWhen asked whether he felt it was it was a departure from what the Ryder Cup task force set out to do in 2014, McIlroy couldn\'t say except to note that players still had a voice. Thomas, Johnson and Jordan Spieth are on the committee.\n\n"It seems quite reactionary in terms of what happened in Rome," McIlroy said, referring to the Americans losing a seventh consecutive road match.\n\nMost surprising about the selection was that Bradley says he was never interviewed. The first phone call was to offer him the job. Thomas said he played a practice round with Bradley before that phone call and found it "difficult to act normal."\n\nOther names kicked around if Woods wasn\'t interested included Stewart Cink and Matt Kuchar. Both had been assistants. That was template.\n\n"I don\'t think anyone is ever an obvious choice, especially going outside the box," Thomas said. "It was very apparent that it wasn\'t an obvious choice in the beginning. I think after everybody got together and talked about it, all of the light bulbs flicked off for all of us at the right time.\n\n"Once that was the thought, there was no other way."\n\nBradley will be 39 next year when the 2025 matches take place at Bethpage Black, making him the youngest captain since Arnold Palmer was 34 and a playing captain in 1963 at East Lake. He was the last playing captain in the Ryder Cup.\n\nBradley also is No. 19 in the world and said flatly he wants to play on the next team if he were to qualify.\n\nThat hasn\'t been a serious consideration for the Ryder Cup since Tom Kite was captain in 1997, the year he was runner-up (by 12 shots) to Woods at the Masters. Kite finished 35th on the PGA Tour money list that year.\n\nWoods was a playing captain at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne in 2019. He went 3-0, though the Presidents Cup is not in the same league as the Ryder Cup in attention, promotion or the level of external pressure.\n\nAny American team in golf is tough to make these days. Bradley still is a long way off regardless of his world ranking. Thomas thinks it could happen because the U.S. hired former caddie John Wood as team manager to help with the details.\n\nMcIlroy said his name was kicked around for the 2027 matches in Adare Manor in Ireland, especially if Woods is the U.S. captain. Imagine how much hype a Woods-McIlroy captaincy would create.\n\nEven as a fantasy idea, however, McIlroy wasn\'t buying.\n\n"It\'s been mentioned and I\'ve said, \'No way.\' There\'s no way," he said. "If you want to be the best captain you can be, you can\'t play. And if you want to be the best player you can be, you can\'t captain. It\'s one or the other, especially with how big the Ryder Cup has become."', 'source': {'uri': 'omaha.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Omaha.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@omaha.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'seth_wenig@omaha.com', 'name': 'Seth Wenig', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/omaha.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/e/64/e6410791-3bd8-5f80-9b96-96f66f6b8670/6691a680c6f4c.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1764705882352942, 'wgt': 458521521, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8222990870', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '23:04:45', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T23:04:45Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T23:04:07Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://heraldcourier.com/sports/bhc-boys-basketball-coach-of-year-bearcats-reload-reach-first-state-finals-in-64-years/article_eb6c9292-3bd3-11ef-b713-27147de93e6a.html', 'title': 'BHC BOYS BASKETBALL COACH OF YEAR: Bearcats reload, reach first state finals in 64 years', 'body': 'Virginia High head coach Julius Gallishaw watches intently during the Bearcats\' 72-42 Southwest District tournament semifinal victory over Marion on Friday night at the Bearcat Den.\n\nBRIAN WOODSON Bristol Herald Courier\n\nEvery team dreams of playing for a state championship.\n\nNo boys basketball team at Virginia High School had done that since 1960 until the Bearcats of 2024. That, despite losing five seniors, including four starters, from the previous season that finished 22-6, losing in the Class 2 state quarterfinals for a second straight year.\n\n"Honestly going into the season I didn\'t have high expectations for this team," said Julius Gallishaw, entering his fifth year as Virginia High head coach. "I just wanted us to do the best we could. I knew I had some talent there and I knew if we played hard we could be in games.\n\n"My kids worked their tails off. I know other teams do that as well, but they were always in the gym, they were lifting weights on their own, they really wanted to be successful. I think that was the biggest thing, them doing that and I had a good staff with me and supporting me. All of it kind of fell into place."\n\nPeople are also reading... McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic LITTLE LEAGUE: Good day for local teams in state softball tournament TVA announces changes at South Holston, Boone properties \'Vampire\' series gives Sam Reid plenty to bite into Simmons to expand manufacturing into Russell County AUTO RACING: Rural Retreat native Will Hostetler\'s a hometown hero at Wythe Raceway COLLEGE BASEBALL: Chase Hungate (Abingdon) headed to Mississippi State, relishes chance to compete in SEC COLLEGE FOOTBALL: You can find Brad Robbins (Powell Valley) coaching at UConn now HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Coaching innovator Mumme to serve on Sullivan East coaching staff LITTLE LEAGUE: Monday\'s State Tournament Results FOOTBALL CAMP: Former Tennessee QBs Hooker, Milton hosts football camp at Sullivan East PREP FOOTBALL: The VHSL master schedule was released on Thursday. Here are some games with intriguing storylines LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon falls in Virginia state title game Marketplace dining opening at Hard Rock Bristol Casino donations near $900,000 with Tuesday presentation\n\nFor sure. All Virginia High did was finish 23-6, win the Southwest District regular season and tournament titles and the Region 2D titles for the second year in a row. They kept going from there, advancing to the Class 2 state semifinals for the first time since 2012 and reaching the Class 2 state championship game for the first time in 64 years.\n\nNo wonder Gallishaw has been selected as the Bristol Herald boys basketball coach of the year, the second time he had earned those honors in the last three seasons.\n\n"I really do thank God, He is the head of my life," said Gallishaw, who won a state championship as a teammate of NBA legend Ray Allen at Hillcrest High School in South Carolina in 1993, and also had a standout career at the now-defunct Virginia Intermont College. "I couldn\'t have this opportunity without Him, without my family. I just appreciate the award."\n\nBeing a coach isn\'t for everybody. Gallishaw is done just fine, leading the Bearcats to an average of 21 wins over the last three seasons. He is ably assisted by former University of Virginia\'s College at Wise standout Parker Gemmell and Derrick Lee, who played point guard at Virginia High and at Bluefield College (now University).\n\n"Certain players just don\'t have the coaching ability. They are good players, but they just don\'t have that coaching ability," Gallishaw said. "Coach Parker and Coach Lee, they have that ability. They help me out tremendously in situations where I am asking questions, what to do here and what to do here. I just thank the Lord for people like that helping me out on my staff."\n\nGallishaw learned well, playing for James Smith, who won five state high school championships in South Carolina, and Phil Worrell at Virginia Intermont. He also worked under Barry Wade at Tennessee High and George Pitts at King University. All that prepared him for his chance that came four years ago.\n\n"I will be honest with you, I knew graduating college that I wanted to be a coach," Gallishaw said. "In that aspect when I was high school I got a little bit from my high school coach who won five state championships in South Carolina. I was blessed to have Coach Worrell and just got a little bit from him.\n\n"Then I was blessed to be under some good coaches as an assistant coach. Coach Wade at Tennessee High School, Coach Pitts at King, I was blessed to be under those guys and I just kind of got things right there, kind of how to deal with players, how to execute on the offensive end and the defensive end, things of that nature from them."\n\nHe learned well. Among the seniors that left after the 2023 season was Dante Worley, the Region 2D player of the year, who is now playing at UVa-Wise. Up stepped Deonte Mozell, a junior last year at Virginia High, who earned Virginia High School League Class 2 second team all-state honors.\n\n"Dante was a big part of our success those previous years because we didn\'t have to worry about things that some coaches have to worry about, like dribbling the ball, getting the ball down in the press and getting us in our offense and things of that nature," Gallishaw said. "Obviously there were some question marks going into the season about losing Dante.\n\n"Our guys started playing in the gym all the time and working out all the time. That was Deonte, he was a gym rat and he still is. He just got in there, worked his butt off to get better each day. We were a little cautious about that going into the season, we didn\'t miss a beat going in there with Deonte."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nThere were plenty of other contributors, from rising senior Te\'ron Woolen, rising sophomores Landon Lee and Ollie Carpenter and departed seniors Jalen Lang and Ethan Carpenter, who was lost for the season in January with a knee injury.\n\n"I am going to keep on bragging my team. Sometimes coaching can be overrated," Gallishaw said. "My guys, instead of them growing apart during that time, losing a big guy like Ethan because he is so good. Losing somebody like him can tear a team apart, they came together more and worked as a team more. Going into there and being a coach of that and seeing those guys instead of getting down on themselves and making excuses, going out there and fighting. You can\'t be nothing but happy for those kids."\n\nVirginia High had just six losses during the season, three to Tennessee schools. Two came against Tennessee High, including a close loss at the Bearcat Den when all-state guard Colin Brown willed the Vikings to victory. That is when Gallishaw realized these Bearcats might be special.\n\n"Tennessee High is really good. I knew that we were going to be pretty good going into that game and giving them everything they wanted during that game," Gallishaw said. "It came down to one shot at the end of the game so I knew at that particular time that we had something special going into the district."\n\nAll Virginia High did after that loss was go 20-2, with the lone losses coming to Wise County Central by two points and Graham, one of five meetings between the schools, with the Bearcats winning four of them. That included a halfcourt buzzer-beater by Woolen to claim the Region 2D crown and the \'Cats earned a two-point win over the G-Men in the state semifinals at Lebanon.\n\nAll that awaited in Richmond was John Marshall, one of the nation\'s top programs, a squad that has drawn the ire of coaches across Virginia due to a roster full of transfers and a head coach who is also involved with the Team Loaded AAU program. The Justices have won four of the last five Class 2 state titles, and the one they didn\'t win was because they didn\'t play due to COVID in 2020.\n\n"To be honest obviously playing in a state championship was a blessing for us and everything, but I couldn\'t help but being disheartened for my guys because they deserved more of a chance to actually win the state championship," Gallishaw said. "I am not here to diminish what John Marshall did during that time because I don\'t think that is my place, but I felt like we were deserving to at least compete in that state championship and we didn\'t get that opportunity like we wanted it.\n\n"Obviously that is a great program and they do a good job over there, but I felt like my guys deserved more of an opportunity. That is all."\n\nVirginia High led 2-0 on a Mozell basket and were within 18-11 after one quarter before the Justices poured it on, earning an 89-32 rout of the Bearcats, who never quit playing hard.\n\n"That is thing with my guys, I have never had to teach effort," Gallishaw said. "I can teach Xs and Os and stuff like that, but my guys always bring the effort and I am just proud of my guys for doing that. Even when that game got away from us in the state championship game my guys kept on playing. I was happy about that."\n\nGallishaw, who credits being able to develop strong relationships with his players through his role as a physical education teacher at Virginia High, won\'t let his Bearcats forget the process it took to get to that point.\n\n"I try to relate to them as much as possible on a one-on-one level and talk to them and see what is going on in their world," he said. "I think the beauty of being a coach is getting to know these kids on their level and knowing that they know that you care and that goes a long way with them playing hard and really running through a wall for you because they know you care. That is my biggest thing...\n\n"I think being in school and being around those kids every day and getting to talk to them on an individual basis is one of the biggest keys."\n\nDon\'t count out another run for the Bearcats, who have been in the weight room this summer, while also attending camps at UVa-Wise and Milligan. Four starters return and they will face a tougher schedule, with Virginia High slated to play in the Arby\'s Classic for the first time since the inaugural event in 1983.\n\n"What I told my kids was, \'Hey, treat every game like it is a championship game, don\'t go into games assuming we are Virginia High and we are pretty good and we are just going to win ball games. That is not how it works\'," said Gallishaw, "The beauty of sports is that you never know. A team could just come in your back door and just beat you. We put our head down and just took it one game at a time and the next thing you know we are in the state championship.\n\n"Hats off to the guys, man, they did an excellent job."\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'heraldcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'HeraldCourier.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/e/b6/eb6c9292-3bd3-11ef-b713-27147de93e6a/66919db17e28b.preview.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.4274509803921569, 'wgt': 458521485, 'relevance': 51}
