The decision comes as a huge surprise to everyone.\n\nNORTH BERWICK, Scotland -- Justin Thomas was just starting his rookie season on the PGA Tour when the Americans formed the infamous "Ryder Cup Task Force" geared toward building continuity with hopes of restoring U.S. dominance in the matches.\n\nTen years later, Thomas was part of the Ryder Cup Committee that selected Keegan Bradley as the next captain.\n\nIt was a surprising choice because Bradley played in only two Ryder Cups and had no experience as an assistant. That was part of the template that came out of the task force. Future captains would first be groomed as assistants. Captains would stay on as an assistant at the following Ryder Cup. Everyone would be on the same page.\n\nIt\'s what led Phil Mickelson to declare in early 2015 after the task force came up with the plan, "I\'m excited about where we are now, and I\'m excited about where we are headed -- not just into 2016, but really for the next 10 or 20 years."\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nGolden Corral in Merrillville reopens after closing in 2020 after then-franchisee\'s cold case arrest for Missouri murder 18-year-old dies in car crash on Fourth of July in Portage, police said Judge rejects plea in domestic shooting; man threatens to throw chair at judge NWI Business Ins and Outs: Taco Pros, Brass Idol, Red Zone Sports Bar, Windy City Pizza Kitchen, Sweet Circle, Starbucks, Alexander McQueen and Caribbean Roots opening; Evvy\'s Coffee and Deep Blue Seafood closing Cedar Lake man found dead while sitting in a pond, police say Dispensaries stacking up on Michigan border despite weed remaining illegal in Indiana New store opens at Southlake Mall Church\'s much-anticipated Harvest Square Strip Mall to have ribbon-cutting, bring \'services of suburbs\' to Gary Mother charged with neglect after 18-month-old overdoses Indiana Toll Road increases tolls 3 injured by runaway draft horse at LaPorte County Fair Twisted Sugar opens in Schererville Friday Inmate death at Porter County Jail ruled a suicide, officials say Hobart roundabout moving to phase two Latest alleged prison smuggling attempt involves cocaine, marijuana and lasagna\n\nIs that the end of the task force plan?\n\n"Yes and no," Thomas said at the Scottish Open. "My thing is I want us to pick the best captain. I don\'t want it to feel like it needs to fit a certain résumé; it doesn\'t need to fit this right mold. It\'s like, \'Look, who\'s our best captain right now?\'\n\n"It doesn\'t matter what they\'ve done," he said. "Are the guys going to be excited to play for him? Is he going to mesh with everybody? That\'s all that matters. That\'s something that potentially is the hope going forward. Next year is the only one that matters right now."\n\nDavis Love III was the first captain that came out of the task force for the 2016 matches at Hazeltine, a U.S. victory against a European team that had six rookies, five of whom never played in another Ryder Cup.\n\nHis assistants included Jim Furyk, Steve Stricker and Tiger Woods. Furyk was the next captain for 2018 in France. His assistants included Stricker, Woods and Zach Johnson. Then it was Stricker\'s turn in Wisconsin. Furyk was an assistant, along with Love (again) and Johnson. And then Johnson got the job for Marco Simone outside Rome.\n\nAnd on it went, the home side winning each time.\n\nIn some respects, Bradley broke the mold. He hasn\'t been involved in a Ryder Cup or Presidents Cup since 2014, except for being part of the Netflix docuseries that filmed him getting the awkward call from Johnson that he would not be a captain\'s pick.\n\nRory McIlroy is a keen observer of all things Ryder Cup and was surprised by Bradley choice, like so many others.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"I think Keegan was probably in disbelief, at some point, too," McIlroy said with a smile. "But certainly an interesting pick."\n\nWhen asked whether he felt it was it was a departure from what the Ryder Cup task force set out to do in 2014, McIlroy couldn\'t say except to note that players still had a voice. Thomas, Johnson and Jordan Spieth are on the committee.\n\n"It seems quite reactionary in terms of what happened in Rome," McIlroy said, referring to the Americans losing a seventh consecutive road match.\n\nMost surprising about the selection was that Bradley says he was never interviewed. The first phone call was to offer him the job. Thomas said he played a practice round with Bradley before that phone call and found it "difficult to act normal."\n\nOther names kicked around if Woods wasn\'t interested included Stewart Cink and Matt Kuchar. Both had been assistants. That was template.\n\n"I don\'t think anyone is ever an obvious choice, especially going outside the box," Thomas said. "It was very apparent that it wasn\'t an obvious choice in the beginning. I think after everybody got together and talked about it, all of the light bulbs flicked off for all of us at the right time.\n\n"Once that was the thought, there was no other way."\n\nBradley will be 39 next year when the 2025 matches take place at Bethpage Black, making him the youngest captain since Arnold Palmer was 34 and a playing captain in 1963 at East Lake. He was the last playing captain in the Ryder Cup.\n\nBradley also is No. 19 in the world and said flatly he wants to play on the next team if he were to qualify.\n\nThat hasn\'t been a serious consideration for the Ryder Cup since Tom Kite was captain in 1997, the year he was runner-up (by 12 shots) to Woods at the Masters. Kite finished 35th on the PGA Tour money list that year.\n\nWoods was a playing captain at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne in 2019. He went 3-0, though the Presidents Cup is not in the same league as the Ryder Cup in attention, promotion or the level of external pressure.\n\nAny American team in golf is tough to make these days. Bradley still is a long way off regardless of his world ranking. Thomas thinks it could happen because the U.S. hired former caddie John Wood as team manager to help with the details.\n\nMcIlroy said his name was kicked around for the 2027 matches in Adare Manor in Ireland, especially if Woods is the U.S. captain. Imagine how much hype a Woods-McIlroy captaincy would create.\n\nEven as a fantasy idea, however, McIlroy wasn\'t buying.\n\n"It\'s been mentioned and I\'ve said, \'No way.\' There\'s no way," he said. "If you want to be the best captain you can be, you can\'t play. And if you want to be the best player you can be, you can\'t captain. It\'s one or the other, especially with how big the Ryder Cup has become."\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'nwitimes.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'nwi.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'assets@nwitimes.com', 'name': 'assets', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'tncms@nwitimes.com', 'name': 'tncms', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/nwitimes.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/7/fb/7fb8d983-7109-5076-9721-f4d9f86e85fa/6691a68090013.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9727963', 'sentiment': 0.1372549019607843, 'wgt': 458521162, 'relevance': 6}
{'uri': '2024-07-420298293', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:59:21', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:59:21Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:15:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8588235378265381, 'url': 'https://www.nwitimes.com/sports/professional/spain-england-euro-2024-soccer-final/article_f9e25042-1f48-5310-85bf-5022b250507d.html', 'title': 'Euro 2024 final features the best team against the most resilient', 'body': 'The Euro 2024 Finals are set! Will Spain win their record-breaking fourth Euro title or will England claim their first? Euro Odds: https://go.neo.bet/4jZxynK\n\nBERLIN -- One is the best team in the tournament, on the brink potentially of a new era of success because of a teenage wonderkid, an outstanding midfield and a tweak in philosophy.\n\nThe other is a survivor, limping to the end with big moments, resilience and an oft-criticized coach who has another chance to end his country\'s long wait for a major men\'s title.\n\nThe European Championship final between Spain and England on Sunday is dripping with narrative -- with one arguably standing out above the rest.\n\nInside Olympiastadion, the historic venue in Berlin built by the Nazis for the 1936 Olympic Games, Lamine Yamal -- a day after his 17th birthday -- will look to crown his breakthrough as soccer\'s newest superstar by leading Spain to a first major men\'s trophy since the 2008-12 era, when it won back-to-back Euros either side of the World Cup in 2010.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nGolden Corral in Merrillville reopens after closing in 2020 after then-franchisee\'s cold case arrest for Missouri murder 18-year-old dies in car crash on Fourth of July in Portage, police said Judge rejects plea in domestic shooting; man threatens to throw chair at judge NWI Business Ins and Outs: Taco Pros, Brass Idol, Red Zone Sports Bar, Windy City Pizza Kitchen, Sweet Circle, Starbucks, Alexander McQueen and Caribbean Roots opening; Evvy\'s Coffee and Deep Blue Seafood closing Cedar Lake man found dead while sitting in a pond, police say Dispensaries stacking up on Michigan border despite weed remaining illegal in Indiana New store opens at Southlake Mall Church\'s much-anticipated Harvest Square Strip Mall to have ribbon-cutting, bring \'services of suburbs\' to Gary Mother charged with neglect after 18-month-old overdoses Indiana Toll Road increases tolls 3 injured by runaway draft horse at LaPorte County Fair Twisted Sugar opens in Schererville Friday Inmate death at Porter County Jail ruled a suicide, officials say Hobart roundabout moving to phase two Latest alleged prison smuggling attempt involves cocaine, marijuana and lasagna\n\nYamal has been the shining light in a tournament where many of the high-profile figures -- Cristiano Ronaldo, Kylian Mbappé, even England\'s Harry Kane -- have underwhelmed. If his three assists before the semifinals hinted at his undoubted promise, Yamal\'s spectacular curling shot that propelled Spain to a 2-1 win over France in the last four signaled a new star had arrived.\n\n"He\'s a generational talent," England striker Ollie Watkins said Friday of Yamal. "He has got the world at his feet."\n\nWhile Yamal and fellow winger Nico Williams now offer their national team a hitherto-lacking directness out wide, it\'s the central midfield that has given Spain the edge over all of its rivals.\n\nRodri, perhaps pound-for-pound the world\'s most effective player, and Fabian Ruiz are the axis from which Spain thrives. Dani Olmo has joined them as the most attacking of pretty much a complete central-midfield three that England will struggle to contain.\n\nSpain topped a group containing defending champion Italy and 2022 World Cup semifinalist Croatia, before eliminating host nation Germany and Mbappé\'s France, for many the pre-tournament favorite.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIt\'s six straight wins for La Roja. No wonder they are being so heavily backed ahead of the final.\n\n"They have been the best team," England coach Gareth Southgate said of Spain. "... but we are there and from what we have shown to this point, we have as good a chance as they do."\n\nIndeed, Spain should not underestimate England, whose tenacity and character have stood out way above its quality of play at Euro 2024. The nation\'s most talented squad for 20 years has underperformed, looking unbalanced, short of ideas and in some cases fatigued, but has somehow scrapped through to a second straight European Championship final.\n\nThree years ago, England lost to Italy in a penalty shootout on home soil at Wembley Stadium, extending the birthplace of soccer\'s painful wait for a major men\'s title since its one and only at the 1966 World Cup.\n\nSouthgate\'s team is back in the title match -- its first ever outside England -- and is an increasingly confident underdog, with potential matchwinners dotted throughout the team in Jude Bellingham, Phil Foden, Bukayo Saka and Kane. Someone has always popped up with a crucial goal -- Bellingham with the stoppage-time equalizer against Slovakia in the last 16, Saka with the 80th-minute equalizer against Switzerland in the quarterfinals, even backup striker Watkins pretty much exactly on 90 minutes against the Netherlands in the semifinals.\n\nWho will come to Southgate\'s rescue on Sunday -- if indeed someone does?\n\n"They are able to inflict a lot of damage, even without playing in a very fluid way," Spain defender Dani Vivian said. "But they have that quality that makes them able to produce those sparks."\n\nThe smart money, though, is on Spain winning a seventh straight game to clinch a record fourth European Championship title.\n\nIt would be a just end to a tournament where few teams really clicked apart from the Spanish, who have dovetailed a more ruthless attacking edge with their longstanding possession game that perhaps peaked in the Euro 2012 final when a team of midfielders -- notably Xavi Hernandez, Andres Iniesta, Sergio Busquets, Xabi Alonso and David Silva -- ran over Italy in Spain\'s 4-0 win.\n\nThe class of 2024 might not have those names, but they\'d be worthy successors.\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'nwitimes.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'nwi.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'assets@nwitimes.com', 'name': 'assets', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'tncms@nwitimes.com', 'name': 'tncms', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/nwitimes.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/9e/f9e25042-1f48-5310-85bf-5022b250507d/6691a4f9e6cfc.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9729240', 'sentiment': 0.4980392156862745, 'wgt': 458521161, 'relevance': 5}
{'uri': '8222981164', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:57:06', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:57:06Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:53:03Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.9176470637321472, 'url': 'https://siouxcityjournal.com/sports/professional/bradley-ryder-cup-captain-surprise/article_1876043b-5d74-502a-bbf9-20290e41bffb.html', 'title': 'Bradley as Ryder Cup captain raises questions whether U.S. task force plan is over', 'body': 'NORTH BERWICK, Scotland -- Justin Thomas was just starting his rookie season on the PGA Tour when the Americans formed the infamous "Ryder Cup Task Force" geared toward building continuity with hopes of restoring U.S. dominance in the matches.\n\nTen years later, Thomas was part of the Ryder Cup Committee that selected Keegan Bradley as the next captain.\n\nIt was a surprising choice because Bradley played in only two Ryder Cups and had no experience as an assistant. That was part of the template that came out of the task force. Future captains would first be groomed as assistants. Captains would stay on as an assistant at the following Ryder Cup. Everyone would be on the same page.\n\nIt\'s what led Phil Mickelson to declare in early 2015 after the task force came up with the plan, "I\'m excited about where we are now, and I\'m excited about where we are headed -- not just into 2016, but really for the next 10 or 20 years."\n\nPeople are also reading... McCook Lake Association president: \'There\'s really no compensation\' for flood losses Belly up to the bar-cade: Warp Zone brings bar and arcade combo to downtown Sioux City Marriage licenses for Woodbury County for July 8, 2024 Panel looks to release more water from Okoboji lakes without hurting flood-stricken Spencer, Cherokee Sioux City woman claims $300,000 lottery prize 1 killed, 1 hurt in crash near Lake Park REVIEW: Bleachers teach plenty at Saturday in the Park Iowa legislator J.D. Scholten earns win in last-minute start for Sioux City Explorers Woman arrested after chase exceeding 115 mph on I-29 City of Okoboji urges governor to increase releases from Iowa Great Lakes Saturday in the Park 2024 kicks-off with high spirits 10 taken into custody in Storm Lake standoff McCook Lake residents seek answers Ex-Ponca city clerk charged with destroying public records Portion of Outer Drive to temporarily close\n\nIs that the end of the task force plan?\n\n"Yes and no," Thomas said at the Scottish Open. "My thing is I want us to pick the best captain. I don\'t want it to feel like it needs to fit a certain résumé; it doesn\'t need to fit this right mold. It\'s like, \'Look, who\'s our best captain right now?\'\n\n"It doesn\'t matter what they\'ve done," he said. "Are the guys going to be excited to play for him? Is he going to mesh with everybody? That\'s all that matters. That\'s something that potentially is the hope going forward. Next year is the only one that matters right now."\n\nDavis Love III was the first captain that came out of the task force for the 2016 matches at Hazeltine, a U.S. victory against a European team that had six rookies, five of whom never played in another Ryder Cup.\n\nHis assistants included Jim Furyk, Steve Stricker and Tiger Woods. Furyk was the next captain for 2018 in France. His assistants included Stricker, Woods and Zach Johnson. Then it was Stricker\'s turn in Wisconsin. Furyk was an assistant, along with Love (again) and Johnson. And then Johnson got the job for Marco Simone outside Rome.\n\nAnd on it went, the home side winning each time.\n\nIn some respects, Bradley broke the mold. He hasn\'t been involved in a Ryder Cup or Presidents Cup since 2014, except for being part of the Netflix docuseries that filmed him getting the awkward call from Johnson that he would not be a captain\'s pick.\n\nRory McIlroy is a keen observer of all things Ryder Cup and was surprised by Bradley choice, like so many others.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"I think Keegan was probably in disbelief, at some point, too," McIlroy said with a smile. "But certainly an interesting pick."\n\nWhen asked whether he felt it was it was a departure from what the Ryder Cup task force set out to do in 2014, McIlroy couldn\'t say except to note that players still had a voice. Thomas, Johnson and Jordan Spieth are on the committee.\n\n"It seems quite reactionary in terms of what happened in Rome," McIlroy said, referring to the Americans losing a seventh consecutive road match.\n\nMost surprising about the selection was that Bradley says he was never interviewed. The first phone call was to offer him the job. Thomas said he played a practice round with Bradley before that phone call and found it "difficult to act normal."\n\nOther names kicked around if Woods wasn\'t interested included Stewart Cink and Matt Kuchar. Both had been assistants. That was template.\n\n"I don\'t think anyone is ever an obvious choice, especially going outside the box," Thomas said. "It was very apparent that it wasn\'t an obvious choice in the beginning. I think after everybody got together and talked about it, all of the light bulbs flicked off for all of us at the right time.\n\n"Once that was the thought, there was no other way."\n\nBradley will be 39 next year when the 2025 matches take place at Bethpage Black, making him the youngest captain since Arnold Palmer was 34 and a playing captain in 1963 at East Lake. He was the last playing captain in the Ryder Cup.\n\nBradley also is No. 19 in the world and said flatly he wants to play on the next team if he were to qualify.\n\nThat hasn\'t been a serious consideration for the Ryder Cup since Tom Kite was captain in 1997, the year he was runner-up (by 12 shots) to Woods at the Masters. Kite finished 35th on the PGA Tour money list that year.\n\nWoods was a playing captain at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne in 2019. He went 3-0, though the Presidents Cup is not in the same league as the Ryder Cup in attention, promotion or the level of external pressure.\n\nAny American team in golf is tough to make these days. Bradley still is a long way off regardless of his world ranking. Thomas thinks it could happen because the U.S. hired former caddie John Wood as team manager to help with the details.\n\nMcIlroy said his name was kicked around for the 2027 matches in Adare Manor in Ireland, especially if Woods is the U.S. captain. Imagine how much hype a Woods-McIlroy captaincy would create.\n\nEven as a fantasy idea, however, McIlroy wasn\'t buying.\n\n"It\'s been mentioned and I\'ve said, \'No way.\' There\'s no way," he said. "If you want to be the best captain you can be, you can\'t play. And if you want to be the best player you can be, you can\'t captain. It\'s one or the other, especially with how big the Ryder Cup has become."\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'siouxcityjournal.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Sioux City Journal'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@siouxcityjournal.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': True}, {'uri': 'seth_wenig@siouxcityjournal.com', 'name': 'Seth Wenig', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/siouxcityjournal.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/87/1876043b-5d74-502a-bbf9-20290e41bffb/6691a68107e6f.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9727963', 'sentiment': 0.1058823529411765, 'wgt': 458521026, 'relevance': 51}

At the heart of the matter is a letter from Solano County Child Welfare Services involving Ramos that Dommen said she obtained from public Napa County Superior Court files.\n\nA judge had previously ordered papers related to the Child Welfare Services investigation sealed. However, the Napa Valley Register found that the letter had indeed been included with the publicly available filings in a court case involving Ramos and her former husband.\n\nOn Friday, the court held a hearing on Ramos\' request to change venues for the case involving the Dommen restraining order. No decision was made. Instead, a scheduled posted by the court on Friday afternoon shows Aug. 8 as a day for possible decisions.\n\nPeople are also reading... "We want a decision-maker to look at it and decide if it should remain in effect."\n\nThe restraining order, among other things, says Dommen cannot be within 100 yards of Ramos or two of her children.\n\nRamos in court papers said Dommen shared the Child Welfare Services letter with others during Ramos\' 2024 reelection campaign. She also accused Dommen of making public remarks that alluded to the investigation within Ramos\' presence and online.\n\nPHOTOS: Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Baseball Tournament U17 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 2 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 1 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 3 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 4 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 5 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 6 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 7 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 8 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 9 Bill Buckner Memorial 4th of July Tournament U17 10 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 11 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 12 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 13 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 14 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 15 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 16 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 17 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 18 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 19 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 20 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 21 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 22 Bill Buckner 4th of July Memorial Tournament U17 23\n\nYou can reach Barry Eberling at 707-256-2253 or beberling@napanews.com\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '8222968969', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:39:05', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:39:05Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:37:22Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.843137264251709, 'url': 'https://mcdowellnews.com/sports/professional/spain-england-euro-2024-soccer-final/article_ccd730d2-cffe-5955-bd4e-829e7d0d2040.html', 'title': 'Euro 2024 final features the best team against the most resilient', 'body': 'BERLIN -- One is the best team in the tournament, on the brink potentially of a new era of success because of a teenage wonderkid, an outstanding midfield and a tweak in philosophy.\n\nThe other is a survivor, limping to the end with big moments, resilience and an oft-criticized coach who has another chance to end his country\'s long wait for a major men\'s title.\n\nThe European Championship final between Spain and England on Sunday is dripping with narrative -- with one arguably standing out above the rest.\n\nInside Olympiastadion, the historic venue in Berlin built by the Nazis for the 1936 Olympic Games, Lamine Yamal -- a day after his 17th birthday -- will look to crown his breakthrough as soccer\'s newest superstar by leading Spain to a first major men\'s trophy since the 2008-12 era, when it won back-to-back Euros either side of the World Cup in 2010.\n\nPeople are also reading... 3 dead in plane crash near McDowell, Rutherford county line Plane crashes in McDowell; emergency crews ask people to avoid Brackett Town Road McDowell County Schools moving principals at West Middle, Eastfield and Foothills school Marion man meets McDowell paramedic who saved his life 24 years ago 3 from South Carolina die in Nebo plane crash; national safety board investigating Marion NC man\'s charges upgraded to felony after assault on 79-year-old Body found Sunday was Marion man; cause of death pending toxicology report Marion NC man charged with breaking into home, assault Hickory pastor has a license to practice law. Plus, she\'s been on \'Jeopardy\' Toddler killed by truck at Steel Creek campground north of Morganton Frisbee\'s Galaxy Supermarket in Old Fort now a Piggly Wiggly; still family owned Picasso Keaton, a former WSSU football player, dies in a car crash Nebo woman charged with break-in Golden Hour Charcuterie opens in Marion\'s Depot District McDowell High athlete appointed to NC Student-Athlete Advisory Council\n\nYamal has been the shining light in a tournament where many of the high-profile figures -- Cristiano Ronaldo, Kylian Mbappé, even England\'s Harry Kane -- have underwhelmed. If his three assists before the semifinals hinted at his undoubted promise, Yamal\'s spectacular curling shot that propelled Spain to a 2-1 win over France in the last four signaled a new star had arrived.\n\n"He\'s a generational talent," England striker Ollie Watkins said Friday of Yamal. "He has got the world at his feet."\n\nWhile Yamal and fellow winger Nico Williams now offer their national team a hitherto-lacking directness out wide, it\'s the central midfield that has given Spain the edge over all of its rivals.\n\nRodri, perhaps pound-for-pound the world\'s most effective player, and Fabian Ruiz are the axis from which Spain thrives. Dani Olmo has joined them as the most attacking of pretty much a complete central-midfield three that England will struggle to contain.\n\nSpain topped a group containing defending champion Italy and 2022 World Cup semifinalist Croatia, before eliminating host nation Germany and Mbappé\'s France, for many the pre-tournament favorite.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIt\'s six straight wins for La Roja. No wonder they are being so heavily backed ahead of the final.\n\n"They have been the best team," England coach Gareth Southgate said of Spain. "... but we are there and from what we have shown to this point, we have as good a chance as they do."\n\nIndeed, Spain should not underestimate England, whose tenacity and character have stood out way above its quality of play at Euro 2024. The nation\'s most talented squad for 20 years has underperformed, looking unbalanced, short of ideas and in some cases fatigued, but has somehow scrapped through to a second straight European Championship final.\n\nThree years ago, England lost to Italy in a penalty shootout on home soil at Wembley Stadium, extending the birthplace of soccer\'s painful wait for a major men\'s title since its one and only at the 1966 World Cup.\n\nSouthgate\'s team is back in the title match -- its first ever outside England -- and is an increasingly confident underdog, with potential matchwinners dotted throughout the team in Jude Bellingham, Phil Foden, Bukayo Saka and Kane. Someone has always popped up with a crucial goal -- Bellingham with the stoppage-time equalizer against Slovakia in the last 16, Saka with the 80th-minute equalizer against Switzerland in the quarterfinals, even backup striker Watkins pretty much exactly on 90 minutes against the Netherlands in the semifinals.\n\nWho will come to Southgate\'s rescue on Sunday -- if indeed someone does?\n\n"They are able to inflict a lot of damage, even without playing in a very fluid way," Spain defender Dani Vivian said. "But they have that quality that makes them able to produce those sparks."\n\nThe smart money, though, is on Spain winning a seventh straight game to clinch a record fourth European Championship title.\n\nIt would be a just end to a tournament where few teams really clicked apart from the Spanish, who have dovetailed a more ruthless attacking edge with their longstanding possession game that perhaps peaked in the Euro 2012 final when a team of midfielders -- notably Xavi Hernandez, Andres Iniesta, Sergio Busquets, Xabi Alonso and David Silva -- ran over Italy in Spain\'s 4-0 win.\n\nThe class of 2024 might not have those names, but they\'d be worthy successors.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'mcdowellnews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'McDowellNews.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@mcdowellnews.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/mcdowellnews.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/c/cd/ccd730d2-cffe-5955-bd4e-829e7d0d2040/6691a4f9b873e.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9729240', 'sentiment': 0.2549019607843137, 'wgt': 458519945, 'relevance': 26}
{'uri': '8222968970', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:38:38', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:38:38Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:37:22Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8980392217636108, 'url': 'https://mcdowellnews.com/sports/professional/bradley-ryder-cup-captain-surprise/article_6bfcbf54-f530-5df1-8173-0017cd73066f.html', 'title': 'Bradley as Ryder Cup captain raises questions whether U.S. task force plan is over', 'body': 'NORTH BERWICK, Scotland -- Justin Thomas was just starting his rookie season on the PGA Tour when the Americans formed the infamous "Ryder Cup Task Force" geared toward building continuity with hopes of restoring U.S. dominance in the matches.\n\nTen years later, Thomas was part of the Ryder Cup Committee that selected Keegan Bradley as the next captain.\n\nIt was a surprising choice because Bradley played in only two Ryder Cups and had no experience as an assistant. That was part of the template that came out of the task force. Future captains would first be groomed as assistants. Captains would stay on as an assistant at the following Ryder Cup. Everyone would be on the same page.\n\nIt\'s what led Phil Mickelson to declare in early 2015 after the task force came up with the plan, "I\'m excited about where we are now, and I\'m excited about where we are headed -- not just into 2016, but really for the next 10 or 20 years."\n\nPeople are also reading... 3 dead in plane crash near McDowell, Rutherford county line Plane crashes in McDowell; emergency crews ask people to avoid Brackett Town Road McDowell County Schools moving principals at West Middle, Eastfield and Foothills school Marion man meets McDowell paramedic who saved his life 24 years ago 3 from South Carolina die in Nebo plane crash; national safety board investigating Marion NC man\'s charges upgraded to felony after assault on 79-year-old Body found Sunday was Marion man; cause of death pending toxicology report Marion NC man charged with breaking into home, assault Hickory pastor has a license to practice law. Plus, she\'s been on \'Jeopardy\' Toddler killed by truck at Steel Creek campground north of Morganton Frisbee\'s Galaxy Supermarket in Old Fort now a Piggly Wiggly; still family owned Picasso Keaton, a former WSSU football player, dies in a car crash Nebo woman charged with break-in Golden Hour Charcuterie opens in Marion\'s Depot District McDowell High athlete appointed to NC Student-Athlete Advisory Council\n\nIs that the end of the task force plan?\n\n"Yes and no," Thomas said at the Scottish Open. "My thing is I want us to pick the best captain. I don\'t want it to feel like it needs to fit a certain résumé; it doesn\'t need to fit this right mold. It\'s like, \'Look, who\'s our best captain right now?\'\n\n"It doesn\'t matter what they\'ve done," he said. "Are the guys going to be excited to play for him? Is he going to mesh with everybody? That\'s all that matters. That\'s something that potentially is the hope going forward. Next year is the only one that matters right now."\n\nDavis Love III was the first captain that came out of the task force for the 2016 matches at Hazeltine, a U.S. victory against a European team that had six rookies, five of whom never played in another Ryder Cup.\n\nHis assistants included Jim Furyk, Steve Stricker and Tiger Woods. Furyk was the next captain for 2018 in France. His assistants included Stricker, Woods and Zach Johnson. Then it was Stricker\'s turn in Wisconsin. Furyk was an assistant, along with Love (again) and Johnson. And then Johnson got the job for Marco Simone outside Rome.\n\nAnd on it went, the home side winning each time.\n\nIn some respects, Bradley broke the mold. He hasn\'t been involved in a Ryder Cup or Presidents Cup since 2014, except for being part of the Netflix docuseries that filmed him getting the awkward call from Johnson that he would not be a captain\'s pick.\n\nRory McIlroy is a keen observer of all things Ryder Cup and was surprised by Bradley choice, like so many others.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"I think Keegan was probably in disbelief, at some point, too," McIlroy said with a smile. "But certainly an interesting pick."\n\nWhen asked whether he felt it was it was a departure from what the Ryder Cup task force set out to do in 2014, McIlroy couldn\'t say except to note that players still had a voice. Thomas, Johnson and Jordan Spieth are on the committee.\n\n"It seems quite reactionary in terms of what happened in Rome," McIlroy said, referring to the Americans losing a seventh consecutive road match.\n\nMost surprising about the selection was that Bradley says he was never interviewed. The first phone call was to offer him the job. Thomas said he played a practice round with Bradley before that phone call and found it "difficult to act normal."\n\nOther names kicked around if Woods wasn\'t interested included Stewart Cink and Matt Kuchar. Both had been assistants. That was template.\n\n"I don\'t think anyone is ever an obvious choice, especially going outside the box," Thomas said. "It was very apparent that it wasn\'t an obvious choice in the beginning. I think after everybody got together and talked about it, all of the light bulbs flicked off for all of us at the right time.\n\n"Once that was the thought, there was no other way."\n\nBradley will be 39 next year when the 2025 matches take place at Bethpage Black, making him the youngest captain since Arnold Palmer was 34 and a playing captain in 1963 at East Lake. He was the last playing captain in the Ryder Cup.\n\nBradley also is No. 19 in the world and said flatly he wants to play on the next team if he were to qualify.\n\nThat hasn\'t been a serious consideration for the Ryder Cup since Tom Kite was captain in 1997, the year he was runner-up (by 12 shots) to Woods at the Masters. Kite finished 35th on the PGA Tour money list that year.\n\nWoods was a playing captain at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne in 2019. He went 3-0, though the Presidents Cup is not in the same league as the Ryder Cup in attention, promotion or the level of external pressure.\n\nAny American team in golf is tough to make these days. Bradley still is a long way off regardless of his world ranking. Thomas thinks it could happen because the U.S. hired former caddie John Wood as team manager to help with the details.\n\nMcIlroy said his name was kicked around for the 2027 matches in Adare Manor in Ireland, especially if Woods is the U.S. captain. Imagine how much hype a Woods-McIlroy captaincy would create.\n\nEven as a fantasy idea, however, McIlroy wasn\'t buying.\n\n"It\'s been mentioned and I\'ve said, \'No way.\' There\'s no way," he said. "If you want to be the best captain you can be, you can\'t play. And if you want to be the best player you can be, you can\'t captain. It\'s one or the other, especially with how big the Ryder Cup has become."\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'mcdowellnews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'McDowellNews.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@mcdowellnews.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'seth_wenig@mcdowellnews.com', 'name': 'Seth Wenig', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/mcdowellnews.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/6/bf/6bfcbf54-f530-5df1-8173-0017cd73066f/6691a68077d8d.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9727963', 'sentiment': 0.04313725490196085, 'wgt': 458519918, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8222965659', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:33:49', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:33:49Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:33:05Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://heraldcourier.com/sports/bhc-girls-basketball-player-of-year-it-was-love-at-first-bounce-for-mcamis/article_37a2ac6c-3fdc-11ef-8112-8b23c83e3d4b.html', 'title': 'BHC GIRLS BASKETBALL PLAYER OF YEAR: It was love at first bounce for McAmis', 'body': 'Central\'s Emmah McAmis dribbles toward the basket Gate City\'s Kendall Glover slides to defend Friday night at UVA-Wise for the Region 2D Semifinals.\n\nALLEN GREGORY Bristol Herald Courier\n\nWISE, Va. - For Wise County Central senior Emmah McAmis, basketball has been a story of love at first bounce.\n\n"I grew up in a gym and was dribbling a ball before I could walk," McAmis said.\n\nThe first mentor and role model for McAmis was her father.\n\nIn a 20-year run, T.J. McAmis won 241 games while serving as the head boys basketball coach of J.J. Kelly, Twin Springs and Wise Central.\n\n"I was able to attend dad\'s basketball camps, practices and games growing up and that really brought out my love for the sport," Emmah said.\n\nOver time, Emmah learned that no prize comes without hours of preparation.\n\n"I took in everything I possibly could at an early age and still remember much of what dad taught his players," McAmis said.\n\nPeople are also reading... McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic LITTLE LEAGUE: Good day for local teams in state softball tournament TVA announces changes at South Holston, Boone properties \'Vampire\' series gives Sam Reid plenty to bite into Simmons to expand manufacturing into Russell County AUTO RACING: Rural Retreat native Will Hostetler\'s a hometown hero at Wythe Raceway COLLEGE BASEBALL: Chase Hungate (Abingdon) headed to Mississippi State, relishes chance to compete in SEC COLLEGE FOOTBALL: You can find Brad Robbins (Powell Valley) coaching at UConn now HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Coaching innovator Mumme to serve on Sullivan East coaching staff LITTLE LEAGUE: Monday\'s State Tournament Results FOOTBALL CAMP: Former Tennessee QBs Hooker, Milton hosts football camp at Sullivan East PREP FOOTBALL: The VHSL master schedule was released on Thursday. Here are some games with intriguing storylines LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon falls in Virginia state title game Marketplace dining opening at Hard Rock Bristol Casino donations near $900,000 with Tuesday presentation\n\nMcAmis received further inspiration and guidance from watching and competing with her older siblings and cousins.\n\nHer brother Isaiah scored 1,693 points at Wise Central before finding a spot with the basketball program at the University of Virginia\'s College at Wise.\n\n"I was always their biggest fan," McAmis said. "My family never took it easy on me, and they taught me many valuable life lessons that shaped who I am today."\n\nIn three seasons at Wise Central, Emmah McAmis scored 2,203 points and generated an assortment of headlines and highlights that have attracted the attention of college recruiters at all levels.\n\nWith McAmis setting a torrid pace on offense, the Wise Central Warriors have advanced to the VHSL Class 2 title game three years with two wins and a runner-up finish.\n\n"My overall goal was to win state all four years, but coming up short in my sophomore motivated me," McAmis said. "We\'re held to a high standard here and I enjoy that."\n\nThe taskmaster for the Wise Central Warriors is veteran coach Robin Dotson.\n\n"Emmah\'s impact on our program has been invaluable," Dotson said. "Her competitiveness and drive are off the charts. And Emmah is just so athletic that she presents matchup nightmares for opposing teams."\n\nDotson pointed to another dimension that elevates McAmis above the crowd.\n\n"The bigger the game, the bigger Emmah plays," Dotson said.\n\nIn the 2024 Class 2 championship, McAmis delivered 27 points, six rebounds, four assists and three steals as the Warriors posted a 58-41 win against John Marshall.\n\nFor the season, she averaged 24.2 points, 6.7 rebounds and 3.4 assists. That was enough to earn Bristol Herald Courier player of the year honors.\n\n"I don\'t think words can explain the feeling of winning a state title," McAmis said. "The accomplishment is just so satisfying. I think about those games daily."\n\nMcAmis embraces challenge. For example, there is the issue of her size at five-foot-seven.\n\n"I hit my last grow spurt after this past basketball season, so I think I am done growing," McAmis said. "There are times that I wish I was taller.\n\n"There are also times that I like my height because I\'ve heard many people say that I\'m too short and I\'ll never make it. That gives me motivation to prove those people wrong and show that height doesn\'t matter."\n\nMcAmis has been silencing critics for years, on the high school, travel ball and camp level.\n\n"Once I reached a certain age, my dad actually started letting me practice with his teams," McAmis said. "I was able to do the drills and scrimmage against the boys. I just loved being the around the game and was super excited when I had the chance to play for Coach Dotson."\n\nThe travel ball grind stated in the eighth grade. After facing regional competition with the Nautilus Express squad, McAmis moved to the Under Armour Circuit and the West Virginia Thunder.\n\n"I\'ve played in a bunch of different states over the past five years, McAmis said. "There is a lot of talent on the Under Armor Circuit, and many of the girls I have played against have signed with NCAA Division 1 college. That experience has definitely helped me to better my skills."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nMcAmis said she has received offers from the likes of Western Carolina, East Tennessee State, Colgate, Appalachian State, Marshall, Purdue, Fort Wayne, Wofford, and Youngstown State.\n\n"I\'ve taken six visits, but all were unofficial," McAmis said. "I plan to take more visits after my travel ball season is over.\n\n"Sometimes the recruiting process can be a little stressful, but at the same time it\'s very fun. Not every player gets this experience, so I\'m so thankful for the opportunities."\n\nAs for her much anticipated decision, McAmis said she\' in the exploratory phase.\n\n"I\'m still not sure where I\'m at with that process, but I hope to make a decision before basketball season starts this winter," McAmis said.\n\nFor now, McAmis is testing her skills against taller and quicker opponents in her version of hoops summer school.\n\n"I want to be a complete player for my senior year," McAmis said. "My ability to get to the rim and either finish under the rim or get my teammates open is something that sets me apart, but I\'m still working on the consistency of my 3-point shot and just gaining more confidence."\n\nThe pace is fast for McAmis, but she manages to keep her eyes on the ultimate prize.\n\n"I actually have my trophies in my room on a shelf and it\'s the first thing I see when I walk in," McAmis said. "Whether I\'m having a bad day or good day, seeing those trophies help me to keep pushing for my goals."\n\nHow does McAmis want to wrap up the high school version of her basketball love story?\n\n"With another state championship," McAmis said. "I\'ve worked hard and been blessed with great coaches and teammates through the years.\n\n"Now, I want to keep building my legacy at Wise Central with one more accomplishment."\n\n*\n\nAll-BHC Girls Basketball Team\n\nPlayer of Year: Emmah McAmis, Wise County Central\n\nCoach of Year: Terri Anne Hill Funk, Eastside\n\nFirst Team\n\nTaylor Clay, Eastside\n\nEmmah McAmis, Wise County Central\n\nAnnsley Trivette, Abingdon\n\nAlayna McNulty, Honaker\n\nAddie Wilhoit, Tennessee High\n\nSecond Team\n\nJaydyn Carrico, Gate City\n\nMadison Looney, Wise County Central\n\nElla Moss, Marion\n\nMakaylan Luttrell, George Wythe\n\nTailor Nolley, Honaker\n\nagregory@bristolnews.com -- Twitter: @Greg_BHCSports <&dateline> (276) 645-2544\n\nagregory@bristolnews.com | Twitter: @Greg_BHCSports | (276) 645-2544\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'heraldcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'HeraldCourier.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/7a/37a2ac6c-3fdc-11ef-8112-8b23c83e3d4b/66919d7b8741d.preview.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.3960784313725489, 'wgt': 458519629, 'relevance': 26}
{'uri': '8222962451', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:30:00', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:30:00Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:28:14Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8352941274642944, 'url': 'https://magicvalley.com/sports/professional/spain-england-euro-2024-soccer-final/article_bf220751-7c86-5f7d-bd3f-647a7f131fd5.html', 'title': 'Euro 2024 final features the best team against the most resilient', 'body': 'BERLIN -- One is the best team in the tournament, on the brink potentially of a new era of success because of a teenage wonderkid, an outstanding midfield and a tweak in philosophy.\n\nThe other is a survivor, limping to the end with big moments, resilience and an oft-criticized coach who has another chance to end his country\'s long wait for a major men\'s title.\n\nThe European Championship final between Spain and England on Sunday is dripping with narrative -- with one arguably standing out above the rest.\n\nInside Olympiastadion, the historic venue in Berlin built by the Nazis for the 1936 Olympic Games, Lamine Yamal -- a day after his 17th birthday -- will look to crown his breakthrough as soccer\'s newest superstar by leading Spain to a first major men\'s trophy since the 2008-12 era, when it won back-to-back Euros either side of the World Cup in 2010.\n\nPeople are also reading... Albertsons says it plans to divest Twin Falls store Twin Falls County Most Wanted Twin Falls man charged with murder Police: Man charged with DUI, eluding and battery after Twin Falls pursuit ISP: Buhl woman charged with DUI, leaving crash that left individual seriously injured Twin Falls infant hospitalized after possible drug exposure Crash critically injures motorcyclist COMMENTARY: Don\'t do it Police release photos of possible suspects after Twin Falls gunshot death Death Notices Death Notices Retail Therapy Boutique wants to be your cheerleader Kathleen (Stocks) Gosnell Death Notices From Oakley to Burley, Kyler Robinson likes to be \'the guy that is in charge\'\n\nYamal has been the shining light in a tournament where many of the high-profile figures -- Cristiano Ronaldo, Kylian Mbappé, even England\'s Harry Kane -- have underwhelmed. If his three assists before the semifinals hinted at his undoubted promise, Yamal\'s spectacular curling shot that propelled Spain to a 2-1 win over France in the last four signaled a new star had arrived.\n\n"He\'s a generational talent," England striker Ollie Watkins said Friday of Yamal. "He has got the world at his feet."\n\nWhile Yamal and fellow winger Nico Williams now offer their national team a hitherto-lacking directness out wide, it\'s the central midfield that has given Spain the edge over all of its rivals.\n\nRodri, perhaps pound-for-pound the world\'s most effective player, and Fabian Ruiz are the axis from which Spain thrives. Dani Olmo has joined them as the most attacking of pretty much a complete central-midfield three that England will struggle to contain.\n\nSpain topped a group containing defending champion Italy and 2022 World Cup semifinalist Croatia, before eliminating host nation Germany and Mbappé\'s France, for many the pre-tournament favorite.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIt\'s six straight wins for La Roja. No wonder they are being so heavily backed ahead of the final.\n\n"They have been the best team," England coach Gareth Southgate said of Spain. "... but we are there and from what we have shown to this point, we have as good a chance as they do."\n\nIndeed, Spain should not underestimate England, whose tenacity and character have stood out way above its quality of play at Euro 2024. The nation\'s most talented squad for 20 years has underperformed, looking unbalanced, short of ideas and in some cases fatigued, but has somehow scrapped through to a second straight European Championship final.\n\nThree years ago, England lost to Italy in a penalty shootout on home soil at Wembley Stadium, extending the birthplace of soccer\'s painful wait for a major men\'s title since its one and only at the 1966 World Cup.\n\nSouthgate\'s team is back in the title match -- its first ever outside England -- and is an increasingly confident underdog, with potential matchwinners dotted throughout the team in Jude Bellingham, Phil Foden, Bukayo Saka and Kane. Someone has always popped up with a crucial goal -- Bellingham with the stoppage-time equalizer against Slovakia in the last 16, Saka with the 80th-minute equalizer against Switzerland in the quarterfinals, even backup striker Watkins pretty much exactly on 90 minutes against the Netherlands in the semifinals.\n\nWho will come to Southgate\'s rescue on Sunday -- if indeed someone does?\n\n"They are able to inflict a lot of damage, even without playing in a very fluid way," Spain defender Dani Vivian said. "But they have that quality that makes them able to produce those sparks."\n\nThe smart money, though, is on Spain winning a seventh straight game to clinch a record fourth European Championship title.\n\nIt would be a just end to a tournament where few teams really clicked apart from the Spanish, who have dovetailed a more ruthless attacking edge with their longstanding possession game that perhaps peaked in the Euro 2012 final when a team of midfielders -- notably Xavi Hernandez, Andres Iniesta, Sergio Busquets, Xabi Alonso and David Silva -- ran over Italy in Spain\'s 4-0 win.\n\nThe class of 2024 might not have those names, but they\'d be worthy successors.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'magicvalley.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Magic Valley'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@magicvalley.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': True}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/magicvalley.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/b/f2/bf220751-7c86-5f7d-bd3f-647a7f131fd5/6691a4f974407.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9729240', 'sentiment': 0.2549019607843137, 'wgt': 458519400, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8222962453', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:29:18', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:29:18Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:28:14Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.886274516582489, 'url': 'https://magicvalley.com/sports/professional/bradley-ryder-cup-captain-surprise/article_90d0f7a8-2822-5448-ac57-129c2223eaae.html', 'title': 'Bradley as Ryder Cup captain raises questions whether U.S. task force plan is over', 'body': 'NORTH BERWICK, Scotland -- Justin Thomas was just starting his rookie season on the PGA Tour when the Americans formed the infamous "Ryder Cup Task Force" geared toward building continuity with hopes of restoring U.S. dominance in the matches.\n\nTen years later, Thomas was part of the Ryder Cup Committee that selected Keegan Bradley as the next captain.\n\nIt was a surprising choice because Bradley played in only two Ryder Cups and had no experience as an assistant. That was part of the template that came out of the task force. Future captains would first be groomed as assistants. Captains would stay on as an assistant at the following Ryder Cup. Everyone would be on the same page.\n\nIt\'s what led Phil Mickelson to declare in early 2015 after the task force came up with the plan, "I\'m excited about where we are now, and I\'m excited about where we are headed -- not just into 2016, but really for the next 10 or 20 years."\n\nPeople are also reading... Albertsons says it plans to divest Twin Falls store Twin Falls County Most Wanted Twin Falls man charged with murder Police: Man charged with DUI, eluding and battery after Twin Falls pursuit ISP: Buhl woman charged with DUI, leaving crash that left individual seriously injured Twin Falls infant hospitalized after possible drug exposure Crash critically injures motorcyclist COMMENTARY: Don\'t do it Police release photos of possible suspects after Twin Falls gunshot death Death Notices Death Notices Retail Therapy Boutique wants to be your cheerleader Kathleen (Stocks) Gosnell Death Notices From Oakley to Burley, Kyler Robinson likes to be \'the guy that is in charge\'\n\nIs that the end of the task force plan?\n\n"Yes and no," Thomas said at the Scottish Open. "My thing is I want us to pick the best captain. I don\'t want it to feel like it needs to fit a certain résumé; it doesn\'t need to fit this right mold. It\'s like, \'Look, who\'s our best captain right now?\'\n\n"It doesn\'t matter what they\'ve done," he said. "Are the guys going to be excited to play for him? Is he going to mesh with everybody? That\'s all that matters. That\'s something that potentially is the hope going forward. Next year is the only one that matters right now."\n\nDavis Love III was the first captain that came out of the task force for the 2016 matches at Hazeltine, a U.S. victory against a European team that had six rookies, five of whom never played in another Ryder Cup.\n\nHis assistants included Jim Furyk, Steve Stricker and Tiger Woods. Furyk was the next captain for 2018 in France. His assistants included Stricker, Woods and Zach Johnson. Then it was Stricker\'s turn in Wisconsin. Furyk was an assistant, along with Love (again) and Johnson. And then Johnson got the job for Marco Simone outside Rome.\n\nAnd on it went, the home side winning each time.\n\nIn some respects, Bradley broke the mold. He hasn\'t been involved in a Ryder Cup or Presidents Cup since 2014, except for being part of the Netflix docuseries that filmed him getting the awkward call from Johnson that he would not be a captain\'s pick.\n\nRory McIlroy is a keen observer of all things Ryder Cup and was surprised by Bradley choice, like so many others.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"I think Keegan was probably in disbelief, at some point, too," McIlroy said with a smile. "But certainly an interesting pick."\n\nWhen asked whether he felt it was it was a departure from what the Ryder Cup task force set out to do in 2014, McIlroy couldn\'t say except to note that players still had a voice. Thomas, Johnson and Jordan Spieth are on the committee.\n\n"It seems quite reactionary in terms of what happened in Rome," McIlroy said, referring to the Americans losing a seventh consecutive road match.\n\nMost surprising about the selection was that Bradley says he was never interviewed. The first phone call was to offer him the job. Thomas said he played a practice round with Bradley before that phone call and found it "difficult to act normal."\n\nOther names kicked around if Woods wasn\'t interested included Stewart Cink and Matt Kuchar. Both had been assistants. That was template.\n\n"I don\'t think anyone is ever an obvious choice, especially going outside the box," Thomas said. "It was very apparent that it wasn\'t an obvious choice in the beginning. I think after everybody got together and talked about it, all of the light bulbs flicked off for all of us at the right time.\n\n"Once that was the thought, there was no other way."\n\nBradley will be 39 next year when the 2025 matches take place at Bethpage Black, making him the youngest captain since Arnold Palmer was 34 and a playing captain in 1963 at East Lake. He was the last playing captain in the Ryder Cup.\n\nBradley also is No. 19 in the world and said flatly he wants to play on the next team if he were to qualify.\n\nThat hasn\'t been a serious consideration for the Ryder Cup since Tom Kite was captain in 1997, the year he was runner-up (by 12 shots) to Woods at the Masters. Kite finished 35th on the PGA Tour money list that year.\n\nWoods was a playing captain at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne in 2019. He went 3-0, though the Presidents Cup is not in the same league as the Ryder Cup in attention, promotion or the level of external pressure.\n\nAny American team in golf is tough to make these days. Bradley still is a long way off regardless of his world ranking. Thomas thinks it could happen because the U.S. hired former caddie John Wood as team manager to help with the details.\n\nMcIlroy said his name was kicked around for the 2027 matches in Adare Manor in Ireland, especially if Woods is the U.S. captain. Imagine how much hype a Woods-McIlroy captaincy would create.\n\nEven as a fantasy idea, however, McIlroy wasn\'t buying.\n\n"It\'s been mentioned and I\'ve said, \'No way.\' There\'s no way," he said. "If you want to be the best captain you can be, you can\'t play. And if you want to be the best player you can be, you can\'t captain. It\'s one or the other, especially with how big the Ryder Cup has become."\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'magicvalley.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Magic Valley'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@magicvalley.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': True}, {'uri': 'seth_wenig@magicvalley.com', 'name': 'Seth Wenig', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/magicvalley.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/0d/90d0f7a8-2822-5448-ac57-129c2223eaae/6691a68018c8b.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9727963', 'sentiment': 0.04313725490196085, 'wgt': 458519358, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '2024-07-420283076', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:25:07', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:25:07Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T18:15:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.wnewsj.com/2024/07/12/they-fled-from-their-home-countries-now-theyll-compete-in-paris-for-refugee-olympic-team/', 'title': "They fled from their home countries, now they'll compete in Paris for Refugee Olympic Team", 'body': 'They compete under the same flag but speak different languages and come from different parts of the world. After fleeing war and persecution at home, 36 athletes from 11 countries will compete in the Paris Games as part of the Refugee Olympic Team.\n\nThe team was created for the Rio Olympics in 2016 as a symbol of hope and to call attention to the plight of refugees worldwide.\n\nIn Paris, the refugee athletes will take the stage at a time of record global migration, with hundreds of millions of people -- many of them displaced from their homes -- working to reinvent themselves just as these athletes have.\n\nThe record migration comes alongside a rise in far-right populism across much of the world, with officials and parties in many countries promising to clamp down on immigration and asylum.\n\nAt the Games, athletes will compete in a host country where the anti-immigration far-right party saw a surge of voter support in parliamentary elections, but was beaten back by a coalition of the French left and failed to win a majority.\n\nThe refugee athletes will compete in 12 sports, but for many, their journey to Paris is already a victory in itself.\n\nFernando Dayán Jorge, Cuban, canoeing\n\nFernando Dayán Jorge spent his childhood flying past rickety fishing boats and colonial houses in the bay next to his home in Cienfuegos, Cuba.\n\nSince he began practicing there with his father when he was 11, he said it feels as if he\'s lived a thousand lifetimes.\n\nThe 25-year-old canoeist was a two-time Olympian for Cuba\'s national team in Rio de Janeiro and Tokyo. Then, a gold medalist. A deserter of the Cuban team. A migrant. A maintenance worker. And a refugee.\n\nNow, he continues to rocket along on his narrow red-and-white canoe, this time flying past suburban homes in the canals winding through Cape Coral, Florida.\n\nKneeling on his boat, his oar slices through the air as his coach chants "very good work, very good work" from a boat next to him.\n\nJorge\'s eyes are fixed ahead, throwing all his force into his third Olympics.\n\n"After having written off the 2024 Paris Olympics, it\'s a massive opportunity," he said. "There are so many Cubans that come to this country and lose this dream of competing once again, simply because they don\'t know how to get back to this place."\n\nJorge was at the top of his career, having won gold in Tokyo for the 1,000-meter canoe sprint, when he took a daunting step in March 2021. While training in Mexico, Jorge defected, joining a growing number of Cuban athletes in deserting their country amid an ongoing migratory flight.\n\nSome hope to make more money than they can in the communist-run island. Others, like Jorge, say they left because of political differences over how the government treats citizens and athletes.\n\nHe left behind his home and crossed into the United States via the Rio Grande, in hopes of a better -- if uncertain -- life.\n\nArriving to Florida was, in some ways, like starting from scratch. Granted refugee status in the U.S., Jorge said he would wake up hours before sunrise to train, then work eight hours in a maintenance gig to pay his bills.\n\nHe said he watched friends forced to give up everything after migrating, but he fought to continue as a professional athlete.\n\n"I had a hard time getting out of bed every day and keeping my head on straight," he said. "I had no support whatsoever."\n\nBecoming one of the first Cubans to compete on the Refugee Olympic Team changed everything for him, he said. Still, he is among those who\'ve struggled to cover the costs of competing internationally. He opened a GoFundMe page in June to help pay his way to the Games.\n\nCuba has protested the inclusion of Jorge and Cuban weightlifter Ramiro Mora on the team, saying they should not be considered refugees.\n\nToday, Jorge\'s life in Cuba and his future in Florida seem to blend together in his home. His red, blue and white Cuba jersey sits framed over his doorway, while medals from competitions in the U.S. hang over a statue of the Olympic emblem.\n\n"To the refugees and athletes who\'ve been through the same thing, I want to tell them to not give up," he said. "No matter how dark the days become, the sun is always going to rise."\n\n"I\'m here because I want to reach my dream. Not because I\'m scared," she declared from Spain, where she was granted asylum.\n\nOn the outskirts of Madrid, the 21-year-old is training hard for the Games, which for the first time will include breaking, or, as it\'s popularly known, breakdancing. Talash prances and swivels on her hands and feet to the beat of hip-hop, swooshing her black and red hair around before striking a pose signaling the end of her performance.\n\nJust months ago, she was working in a hair salon in the town of Huesca. Talash was among hundreds of Afghans brought to Spain aboard military planes following the return of the Taliban to power in August 2021.\n\nTalash first came across breaking at age 17. She saw a social media video of a man spinning on his head and was skeptical -- it must have been fake, generated by AI, she thought. But the images were real, and she said she soon became obsessed with the sport, scrolling through video after video on her phone.\n\n"I wanted to do it, I wanted to learn it," she said.\n\nShe found a club in Kabul where a dancer from the videos trained and knocked at the door. "There were 55 boys, and I was the only girl," she said. "I told myself, why can\'t a girl do this?"\n\nBreaking in some ways freed her from the problems facing young women in Afghanistan. But it wasn\'t long before Talash was noticed -- international news outlets published stories about the young Afghan woman defying cultural and religious norms. That was enough to become a target.\n\n"The Taliban don\'t like it when a girl dances," she said, even though breaking is more than that -- it\'s a sport.\n\nHer club began receiving threats, Talash said, and one day, when a bomb hit very close, local police asked them to shut down over the dangers.\n\nShe trained behind closed doors in her home until the Taliban\'s return to power. Despite initial promises that women\'s rights wouldn\'t be curtailed, women have since been barred from studying and face several restrictions on employment, travel and health.\n\n"Now, girls can\'t do anything," Talash said.\n\nShe\'s had little time to train while adapting to a foreign country, and at some points, competing in the Games seemed unfathomable.\n\n"But when my friend told me I could join the refugee team, I was so happy," Talash said. "I can now fly."\n\nMohammad Amin Alsalami, Syrian, athletics\n\nWhen Mohammad Amin Alsalami arrived in Berlin in October 2015, he was cold, lonely and homesick.\n\nThe Syrian refugee had left behind his war-torn hometown of Aleppo, fled to Turkey, crossed the Mediterranean on a rubber boat to Greece, and trekked by foot to Germany. Like millions of other migrants, he was in search of a place where he could build a future without bombs and violence.\n\nAlmost a decade later, Alsalami, 29, has been granted asylum, learned German and made new friends. And he\'s living his dream of becoming a world-class athlete.\n\nHe learned just months ago that he got the green light to participate in the Paris Games.\n\n"That moment was so wow," he said. "I get to go to the Olympics. I cried so much. It was really cool."\n\nAlsalami discovered his passion for athletics during physical education in school at age 15. A teacher noticed his talent for long jump and pushed him to participate in local and national competitions in Syria. But when civil war erupted, he could no longer practice. His family -- he\'s the youngest of nine siblings and comes from a family of tailors -- was displaced several times within Syria, then fled to Turkey. Alsalami decided to continue on to Europe on his own.\n\nHe credits his passion for athletics with getting him through the initial hardships in his new country.\n\nDuring the first weeks in Berlin, he looked up different stadiums and gyms on Google maps so he could start practicing long jump again. He remembers walking through the first snow to finally discover one of the city\'s big indoor gymnasiums.\n\n"All the other Berlin track and field athletes were training in this hall," he said. "When I came in and saw how full and how warm it was inside ... it was almost like paradise for me."\n\nOn that first day, a man watched him jump, approached him and asked something in German.\n\n"I didn\'t understand anything, not in English either," Alsalami said. "And then I said \'Hey, I\'m Syrian\' on my cellphone, and he said \'I\'m your trainer from now on.\'"\n\nHe stayed with that first coach for five years, then moved on to a different one -- and said he\'s eternally grateful to both for their support.\n\nDespite his excitement for the Games, Alsalami admits he\'s a bit sad that he can\'t represent his home country.\n\n"Syria is home, I miss it every day," he said. "In the end, that\'s my country, that\'s where I come from."\n\nIman Mahdavi, Iranian, wrestling\n\nIman Mahdavi smiles and dishes up Iranian food that he\'s cooked himself at his Milan home.\n\n"If my mum could see me now," he said with a laugh. "She wouldn\'t believe it."\n\nMahdavi hasn\'t seen his mother since October 2020, when the Iranian wrestler fled his home country over fears for his life.\n\nWith only the clothes he was wearing, Mahdavi made a harrowing journey by foot from Iran to Turkey, then flew to Italy and applied for asylum.\n\n"I didn\'t even really know where I was flying to," said Mahdavi, 29. "Luckily for me, it was Italy."\n\nOnce he was granted asylum, one of Mahdavi\'s first aims was to continue wrestling. His father, once a wrestler himself, had instilled in his son a passion. Mahdavi became a seven-time national junior champion and won more than 50 medals.\n\nThrough a friend he connected with on Instagram, Mahdavi was introduced to a gym on the outskirts of Milan.\n\n"As soon as we had him in the gym, in his first training sessions, we immediately saw that he was an extraordinary athlete, that he was a very, very high-level wrestler," said Giuseppe Gammarota, president of Lotta Club Seggiano. "We immediately started preparing him for competitions."\n\nThe gym has become like family to him -- so much so that he calls his coach, Marco Moroni, "Papi."\n\nMahdavi said his real father died of a heart attack several years ago after being mistakenly told his son died in a car crash.\n\nIt was Moroni who helped Mahdavi find a job, as a nightclub bouncer.\n\nMahdavi admits the schedule can be tough: He works from 11 p.m. to 5 a.m., goes home to sleep, then trains every day. But he has a focus that drives him.\n\n"The Olympics is a dream for any athlete who does any sport," he said. "I hope to come back from the Olympics with the best colored medal I can get. And I will also be thinking about the next Olympics, hoping I\'m still in form."\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press journalists Rebecca Blackwell and Daniel Kozin in Cape Coral, Florida, and Iain Sullivan in Madrid contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nMore Paris Olympics news: https://apnews.com/hub/2024-paris-olympic-games', 'source': {'uri': 'wnewsj.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Wilmington News Journal'}, 'authors': [], 'image': None, 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.05882352941176472, 'wgt': 458519107, 'relevance': 7}

Pub II marking 50th anniversary with party in uptown Normal Revolution Dispensary to host grand opening Friday in Normal Man found unresponsive in Bloomington had suffered medical event, police said Behind the Pritzker administration\'s quest to signal Illinois is \'open for business\' Opening statements begin in trial of man accused of killing teen at NYE party in Normal Bloomington police investigating shots fired Wednesday night\n\nYamal has been the shining light in a tournament where many of the high-profile figures -- Cristiano Ronaldo, Kylian Mbappé, even England\'s Harry Kane -- have underwhelmed. If his three assists before the semifinals hinted at his undoubted promise, Yamal\'s spectacular curling shot that propelled Spain to a 2-1 win over France in the last four signaled a new star had arrived.\n\n"He\'s a generational talent," England striker Ollie Watkins said Friday of Yamal. "He has got the world at his feet."\n\nWhile Yamal and fellow winger Nico Williams now offer their national team a hitherto-lacking directness out wide, it\'s the central midfield that has given Spain the edge over all of its rivals.\n\nRodri, perhaps pound-for-pound the world\'s most effective player, and Fabian Ruiz are the axis from which Spain thrives. Dani Olmo has joined them as the most attacking of pretty much a complete central-midfield three that England will struggle to contain.\n\nSpain topped a group containing defending champion Italy and 2022 World Cup semifinalist Croatia, before eliminating host nation Germany and Mbappé\'s France, for many the pre-tournament favorite.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIt\'s six straight wins for La Roja. No wonder they are being so heavily backed ahead of the final.\n\n"They have been the best team," England coach Gareth Southgate said of Spain. "... but we are there and from what we have shown to this point, we have as good a chance as they do."\n\nIndeed, Spain should not underestimate England, whose tenacity and character have stood out way above its quality of play at Euro 2024. The nation\'s most talented squad for 20 years has underperformed, looking unbalanced, short of ideas and in some cases fatigued, but has somehow scrapped through to a second straight European Championship final.\n\nThree years ago, England lost to Italy in a penalty shootout on home soil at Wembley Stadium, extending the birthplace of soccer\'s painful wait for a major men\'s title since its one and only at the 1966 World Cup.\n\nSouthgate\'s team is back in the title match -- its first ever outside England -- and is an increasingly confident underdog, with potential matchwinners dotted throughout the team in Jude Bellingham, Phil Foden, Bukayo Saka and Kane. Someone has always popped up with a crucial goal -- Bellingham with the stoppage-time equalizer against Slovakia in the last 16, Saka with the 80th-minute equalizer against Switzerland in the quarterfinals, even backup striker Watkins pretty much exactly on 90 minutes against the Netherlands in the semifinals.\n\nWho will come to Southgate\'s rescue on Sunday -- if indeed someone does?\n\n"They are able to inflict a lot of damage, even without playing in a very fluid way," Spain defender Dani Vivian said. "But they have that quality that makes them able to produce those sparks."\n\nThe smart money, though, is on Spain winning a seventh straight game to clinch a record fourth European Championship title.\n\nIt would be a just end to a tournament where few teams really clicked apart from the Spanish, who have dovetailed a more ruthless attacking edge with their longstanding possession game that perhaps peaked in the Euro 2012 final when a team of midfielders -- notably Xavi Hernandez, Andres Iniesta, Sergio Busquets, Xabi Alonso and David Silva -- ran over Italy in Spain\'s 4-0 win.\n\nThe class of 2024 might not have those names, but they\'d be worthy successors.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'pantagraph.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'pantagraph.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@pantagraph.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/pantagraph.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/d/2b/d2b6b94c-6ccf-56cd-8767-468f7c332081/6691a4fa29c11.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9729240', 'sentiment': 0.1137254901960785, 'wgt': 458519095, 'relevance': 51}
