If his three assists before the semifinals hinted at his undoubted promise, Yamal\'s spectacular curling shot that propelled Spain to a 2-1 win over France in the last four signaled a new star had arrived.\n\n"He\'s a generational talent," England striker Ollie Watkins said Friday of Yamal. "He has got the world at his feet."\n\nWhile Yamal and fellow winger Nico Williams now offer their national team a hitherto-lacking directness out wide, it\'s the central midfield that has given Spain the edge over all of its rivals.\n\nRodri, perhaps pound-for-pound the world\'s most effective player, and Fabian Ruiz are the axis from which Spain thrives. Dani Olmo has joined them as the most attacking of pretty much a complete central-midfield three that England will struggle to contain.\n\nSpain topped a group containing defending champion Italy and 2022 World Cup semifinalist Croatia, before eliminating host nation Germany and Mbappé\'s France, for many the pre-tournament favorite.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIt\'s six straight wins for La Roja. No wonder they are being so heavily backed ahead of the final.\n\n"They have been the best team," England coach Gareth Southgate said of Spain. "... but we are there and from what we have shown to this point, we have as good a chance as they do."\n\nIndeed, Spain should not underestimate England, whose tenacity and character have stood out way above its quality of play at Euro 2024. The nation\'s most talented squad for 20 years has underperformed, looking unbalanced, short of ideas and in some cases fatigued, but has somehow scrapped through to a second straight European Championship final.\n\nThree years ago, England lost to Italy in a penalty shootout on home soil at Wembley Stadium, extending the birthplace of soccer\'s painful wait for a major men\'s title since its one and only at the 1966 World Cup.\n\nSouthgate\'s team is back in the title match -- its first ever outside England -- and is an increasingly confident underdog, with potential matchwinners dotted throughout the team in Jude Bellingham, Phil Foden, Bukayo Saka and Kane. Someone has always popped up with a crucial goal -- Bellingham with the stoppage-time equalizer against Slovakia in the last 16, Saka with the 80th-minute equalizer against Switzerland in the quarterfinals, even backup striker Watkins pretty much exactly on 90 minutes against the Netherlands in the semifinals.\n\nWho will come to Southgate\'s rescue on Sunday -- if indeed someone does?\n\n"They are able to inflict a lot of damage, even without playing in a very fluid way," Spain defender Dani Vivian said. "But they have that quality that makes them able to produce those sparks."\n\nThe smart money, though, is on Spain winning a seventh straight game to clinch a record fourth European Championship title.\n\nIt would be a just end to a tournament where few teams really clicked apart from the Spanish, who have dovetailed a more ruthless attacking edge with their longstanding possession game that perhaps peaked in the Euro 2012 final when a team of midfielders -- notably Xavi Hernandez, Andres Iniesta, Sergio Busquets, Xabi Alonso and David Silva -- ran over Italy in Spain\'s 4-0 win.\n\nThe class of 2024 might not have those names, but they\'d be worthy successors.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'wcfcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Waterloo Cedar Falls Courier'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@wcfcourier.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': True}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/wcfcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/52/152b8e59-f7d9-552d-835a-e2f70da9808a/6691a4faf21e3.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9729240', 'sentiment': 0.2549019607843137, 'wgt': 458519079, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8222957596', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:23:33', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:23:33Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:21:19Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8941176533699036, 'url': 'https://wcfcourier.com/sports/professional/pga/bradley-ryder-cup-captain-surprise/article_1d7f17d6-943c-53a5-b9ad-ec75ad352987.html', 'title': 'Bradley as Ryder Cup captain raises questions whether U.S. task force plan is over', 'body': 'NORTH BERWICK, Scotland -- Justin Thomas was just starting his rookie season on the PGA Tour when the Americans formed the infamous "Ryder Cup Task Force" geared toward building continuity with hopes of restoring U.S. dominance in the matches.\n\nTen years later, Thomas was part of the Ryder Cup Committee that selected Keegan Bradley as the next captain.\n\nIt was a surprising choice because Bradley played in only two Ryder Cups and had no experience as an assistant. That was part of the template that came out of the task force. Future captains would first be groomed as assistants. Captains would stay on as an assistant at the following Ryder Cup. Everyone would be on the same page.\n\nIt\'s what led Phil Mickelson to declare in early 2015 after the task force came up with the plan, "I\'m excited about where we are now, and I\'m excited about where we are headed -- not just into 2016, but really for the next 10 or 20 years."\n\nPeople are also reading... NEW DETAILS: John Deere announces another 345 layoffs at Waterloo facilities Man shot outside bar in downtown Waterloo Colleagues remember Waverly-Shell Rock principal Suz SmolikHagen Woman identified in fatal crash Ag expert: Deere prepares for future losses due to downturned ag economy Waterloo man arrested after alleged assault at Sunnyside County Club UPDATE WITH NAME: One dead in tanker crash south of Hudson Woman arrested for assaulting multiple people, punching officer, ramming property in Waterloo Iowa restaurant inspection update: Grimy blenders, mouse droppings and bad sushi John Eveland: Waterloo businessman makes lasting impact in Cedar Valley community Student sentenced to probation in University of Northern Iowa Dance Marathon theft Woman dead in single-vehicle accident Walnut Ridge Church to move to Tower Park Drive, future uncertain for private school space Former Juvenile Court Services employee indicted for fraud in cedit card case Pet friendly restaurants, bars, coffee shops with patio guidelines\n\nIs that the end of the task force plan?\n\n"Yes and no," Thomas said at the Scottish Open. "My thing is I want us to pick the best captain. I don\'t want it to feel like it needs to fit a certain résumé; it doesn\'t need to fit this right mold. It\'s like, \'Look, who\'s our best captain right now?\'\n\n"It doesn\'t matter what they\'ve done," he said. "Are the guys going to be excited to play for him? Is he going to mesh with everybody? That\'s all that matters. That\'s something that potentially is the hope going forward. Next year is the only one that matters right now."\n\nDavis Love III was the first captain that came out of the task force for the 2016 matches at Hazeltine, a U.S. victory against a European team that had six rookies, five of whom never played in another Ryder Cup.\n\nHis assistants included Jim Furyk, Steve Stricker and Tiger Woods. Furyk was the next captain for 2018 in France. His assistants included Stricker, Woods and Zach Johnson. Then it was Stricker\'s turn in Wisconsin. Furyk was an assistant, along with Love (again) and Johnson. And then Johnson got the job for Marco Simone outside Rome.\n\nAnd on it went, the home side winning each time.\n\nIn some respects, Bradley broke the mold. He hasn\'t been involved in a Ryder Cup or Presidents Cup since 2014, except for being part of the Netflix docuseries that filmed him getting the awkward call from Johnson that he would not be a captain\'s pick.\n\nRory McIlroy is a keen observer of all things Ryder Cup and was surprised by Bradley choice, like so many others.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"I think Keegan was probably in disbelief, at some point, too," McIlroy said with a smile. "But certainly an interesting pick."\n\nWhen asked whether he felt it was it was a departure from what the Ryder Cup task force set out to do in 2014, McIlroy couldn\'t say except to note that players still had a voice. Thomas, Johnson and Jordan Spieth are on the committee.\n\n"It seems quite reactionary in terms of what happened in Rome," McIlroy said, referring to the Americans losing a seventh consecutive road match.\n\nMost surprising about the selection was that Bradley says he was never interviewed. The first phone call was to offer him the job. Thomas said he played a practice round with Bradley before that phone call and found it "difficult to act normal."\n\nOther names kicked around if Woods wasn\'t interested included Stewart Cink and Matt Kuchar. Both had been assistants. That was template.\n\n"I don\'t think anyone is ever an obvious choice, especially going outside the box," Thomas said. "It was very apparent that it wasn\'t an obvious choice in the beginning. I think after everybody got together and talked about it, all of the light bulbs flicked off for all of us at the right time.\n\n"Once that was the thought, there was no other way."\n\nBradley will be 39 next year when the 2025 matches take place at Bethpage Black, making him the youngest captain since Arnold Palmer was 34 and a playing captain in 1963 at East Lake. He was the last playing captain in the Ryder Cup.\n\nBradley also is No. 19 in the world and said flatly he wants to play on the next team if he were to qualify.\n\nThat hasn\'t been a serious consideration for the Ryder Cup since Tom Kite was captain in 1997, the year he was runner-up (by 12 shots) to Woods at the Masters. Kite finished 35th on the PGA Tour money list that year.\n\nWoods was a playing captain at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne in 2019. He went 3-0, though the Presidents Cup is not in the same league as the Ryder Cup in attention, promotion or the level of external pressure.\n\nAny American team in golf is tough to make these days. Bradley still is a long way off regardless of his world ranking. Thomas thinks it could happen because the U.S. hired former caddie John Wood as team manager to help with the details.\n\nMcIlroy said his name was kicked around for the 2027 matches in Adare Manor in Ireland, especially if Woods is the U.S. captain. Imagine how much hype a Woods-McIlroy captaincy would create.\n\nEven as a fantasy idea, however, McIlroy wasn\'t buying.\n\n"It\'s been mentioned and I\'ve said, \'No way.\' There\'s no way," he said. "If you want to be the best captain you can be, you can\'t play. And if you want to be the best player you can be, you can\'t captain. It\'s one or the other, especially with how big the Ryder Cup has become."\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'wcfcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Waterloo Cedar Falls Courier'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'seth_wenig@wcfcourier.com', 'name': 'Seth Wenig', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/wcfcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/d7/1d7f17d6-943c-53a5-b9ad-ec75ad352987/6691a6817f11c.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9727963', 'sentiment': 0.04313725490196085, 'wgt': 458519013, 'relevance': 51}

"He has got the world at his feet."\n\nWhile Yamal and fellow winger Nico Williams now offer their national team a hitherto-lacking directness out wide, it\'s the central midfield that has given Spain the edge over all of its rivals.\n\nRodri, perhaps pound-for-pound the world\'s most effective player, and Fabian Ruiz are the axis from which Spain thrives. Dani Olmo has joined them as the most attacking of pretty much a complete central-midfield three that England will struggle to contain.\n\nSpain topped a group containing defending champion Italy and 2022 World Cup semifinalist Croatia, before eliminating host nation Germany and Mbappé\'s France, for many the pre-tournament favorite.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIt\'s six straight wins for La Roja. No wonder they are being so heavily backed ahead of the final.\n\n"They have been the best team," England coach Gareth Southgate said of Spain. "... but we are there and from what we have shown to this point, we have as good a chance as they do."\n\nIndeed, Spain should not underestimate England, whose tenacity and character have stood out way above its quality of play at Euro 2024. The nation\'s most talented squad for 20 years has underperformed, looking unbalanced, short of ideas and in some cases fatigued, but has somehow scrapped through to a second straight European Championship final.\n\nThree years ago, England lost to Italy in a penalty shootout on home soil at Wembley Stadium, extending the birthplace of soccer\'s painful wait for a major men\'s title since its one and only at the 1966 World Cup.\n\nSouthgate\'s team is back in the title match -- its first ever outside England -- and is an increasingly confident underdog, with potential matchwinners dotted throughout the team in Jude Bellingham, Phil Foden, Bukayo Saka and Kane. Someone has always popped up with a crucial goal -- Bellingham with the stoppage-time equalizer against Slovakia in the last 16, Saka with the 80th-minute equalizer against Switzerland in the quarterfinals, even backup striker Watkins pretty much exactly on 90 minutes against the Netherlands in the semifinals.\n\nWho will come to Southgate\'s rescue on Sunday -- if indeed someone does?\n\n"They are able to inflict a lot of damage, even without playing in a very fluid way," Spain defender Dani Vivian said. "But they have that quality that makes them able to produce those sparks."\n\nThe smart money, though, is on Spain winning a seventh straight game to clinch a record fourth European Championship title.\n\nIt would be a just end to a tournament where few teams really clicked apart from the Spanish, who have dovetailed a more ruthless attacking edge with their longstanding possession game that perhaps peaked in the Euro 2012 final when a team of midfielders -- notably Xavi Hernandez, Andres Iniesta, Sergio Busquets, Xabi Alonso and David Silva -- ran over Italy in Spain\'s 4-0 win.\n\nThe class of 2024 might not have those names, but they\'d be worthy successors.\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'qctimes.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Quad-City Times'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@qctimes.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': True}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/qctimes.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/b/96/b9684870-8d90-5f2c-aee0-d00cbcdfefc1/6691a4fa3bec6.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9729240', 'sentiment': 0.2627450980392156, 'wgt': 458519005, 'relevance': 51}

"But certainly an interesting pick."\n\nWhen asked whether he felt it was it was a departure from what the Ryder Cup task force set out to do in 2014, McIlroy couldn\'t say except to note that players still had a voice. Thomas, Johnson and Jordan Spieth are on the committee.\n\n"It seems quite reactionary in terms of what happened in Rome," McIlroy said, referring to the Americans losing a seventh consecutive road match.\n\nMost surprising about the selection was that Bradley says he was never interviewed. The first phone call was to offer him the job. Thomas said he played a practice round with Bradley before that phone call and found it "difficult to act normal."\n\nOther names kicked around if Woods wasn\'t interested included Stewart Cink and Matt Kuchar. Both had been assistants. That was template.\n\n"I don\'t think anyone is ever an obvious choice, especially going outside the box," Thomas said. "It was very apparent that it wasn\'t an obvious choice in the beginning. I think after everybody got together and talked about it, all of the light bulbs flicked off for all of us at the right time.\n\n"Once that was the thought, there was no other way."\n\nBradley will be 39 next year when the 2025 matches take place at Bethpage Black, making him the youngest captain since Arnold Palmer was 34 and a playing captain in 1963 at East Lake. He was the last playing captain in the Ryder Cup.\n\nBradley also is No. 19 in the world and said flatly he wants to play on the next team if he were to qualify.\n\nThat hasn\'t been a serious consideration for the Ryder Cup since Tom Kite was captain in 1997, the year he was runner-up (by 12 shots) to Woods at the Masters. Kite finished 35th on the PGA Tour money list that year.\n\nWoods was a playing captain at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne in 2019. He went 3-0, though the Presidents Cup is not in the same league as the Ryder Cup in attention, promotion or the level of external pressure.\n\nAny American team in golf is tough to make these days. Bradley still is a long way off regardless of his world ranking. Thomas thinks it could happen because the U.S. hired former caddie John Wood as team manager to help with the details.\n\nMcIlroy said his name was kicked around for the 2027 matches in Adare Manor in Ireland, especially if Woods is the U.S. captain. Imagine how much hype a Woods-McIlroy captaincy would create.\n\nEven as a fantasy idea, however, McIlroy wasn\'t buying.\n\n"It\'s been mentioned and I\'ve said, \'No way.\' There\'s no way," he said. "If you want to be the best captain you can be, you can\'t play. And if you want to be the best player you can be, you can\'t captain. It\'s one or the other, especially with how big the Ryder Cup has become."\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'qctimes.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Quad-City Times'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@qctimes.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': True}, {'uri': 'seth_wenig@qctimes.com', 'name': 'Seth Wenig', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/qctimes.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/51/951b2b97-c486-5dab-a0b1-1f9bcf285d96/6691a680c07dc.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9727963', 'sentiment': 0.05882352941176472, 'wgt': 458518952, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8222957135', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:22:24', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:22:24Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:20:40Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7921568751335144, 'url': 'https://napavalleyregister.com/sports/professional/spain-england-euro-2024-soccer-final/article_e900e269-e119-5bc2-a596-038139fa372f.html', 'title': 'Euro 2024 final features the best team against the most resilient', 'body': 'BERLIN -- One is the best team in the tournament, on the brink potentially of a new era of success because of a teenage wonderkid, an outstanding midfield and a tweak in philosophy.\n\nThe other is a survivor, limping to the end with big moments, resilience and an oft-criticized coach who has another chance to end his country\'s long wait for a major men\'s title.\n\nThe European Championship final between Spain and England on Sunday is dripping with narrative -- with one arguably standing out above the rest.\n\nInside Olympiastadion, the historic venue in Berlin built by the Nazis for the 1936 Olympic Games, Lamine Yamal -- a day after his 17th birthday -- will look to crown his breakthrough as soccer\'s newest superstar by leading Spain to a first major men\'s trophy since the 2008-12 era, when it won back-to-back Euros either side of the World Cup in 2010.\n\nPeople are also reading... Ryan Seacrest\'s Napa County home up for sale at $22 million A Napa teen was killed by gun violence. Her life inspired a scholarship. $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Document at center of Supervisor Ramos\' restraining order found in public filings Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 Judge considers vacating temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos St. Helena Cyclery to reopen in wake of Trek\'s closure Napa judge declines to remove temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos Supervisor Belia Ramos files court documents alleging harassment Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life Napa\'s first Fourth of July drone show takes to the sky amid mixed feelings Fire hazards and federal subpoenas: Questions continue to swirl around Clover Flat Landfill Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Napa Farmers Market: There\'s always a place for you at the market Manslaughter case over cyclist couple killed in Napa moves forward\n\nYamal has been the shining light in a tournament where many of the high-profile figures -- Cristiano Ronaldo, Kylian Mbappé, even England\'s Harry Kane -- have underwhelmed. If his three assists before the semifinals hinted at his undoubted promise, Yamal\'s spectacular curling shot that propelled Spain to a 2-1 win over France in the last four signaled a new star had arrived.\n\n"He\'s a generational talent," England striker Ollie Watkins said Friday of Yamal. "He has got the world at his feet."\n\nWhile Yamal and fellow winger Nico Williams now offer their national team a hitherto-lacking directness out wide, it\'s the central midfield that has given Spain the edge over all of its rivals.\n\nRodri, perhaps pound-for-pound the world\'s most effective player, and Fabian Ruiz are the axis from which Spain thrives. Dani Olmo has joined them as the most attacking of pretty much a complete central-midfield three that England will struggle to contain.\n\nSpain topped a group containing defending champion Italy and 2022 World Cup semifinalist Croatia, before eliminating host nation Germany and Mbappé\'s France, for many the pre-tournament favorite.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nIt\'s six straight wins for La Roja. No wonder they are being so heavily backed ahead of the final.\n\n"They have been the best team," England coach Gareth Southgate said of Spain. "... but we are there and from what we have shown to this point, we have as good a chance as they do."\n\nIndeed, Spain should not underestimate England, whose tenacity and character have stood out way above its quality of play at Euro 2024. The nation\'s most talented squad for 20 years has underperformed, looking unbalanced, short of ideas and in some cases fatigued, but has somehow scrapped through to a second straight European Championship final.\n\nThree years ago, England lost to Italy in a penalty shootout on home soil at Wembley Stadium, extending the birthplace of soccer\'s painful wait for a major men\'s title since its one and only at the 1966 World Cup.\n\nSouthgate\'s team is back in the title match -- its first ever outside England -- and is an increasingly confident underdog, with potential matchwinners dotted throughout the team in Jude Bellingham, Phil Foden, Bukayo Saka and Kane. Someone has always popped up with a crucial goal -- Bellingham with the stoppage-time equalizer against Slovakia in the last 16, Saka with the 80th-minute equalizer against Switzerland in the quarterfinals, even backup striker Watkins pretty much exactly on 90 minutes against the Netherlands in the semifinals.\n\nWho will come to Southgate\'s rescue on Sunday -- if indeed someone does?\n\n"They are able to inflict a lot of damage, even without playing in a very fluid way," Spain defender Dani Vivian said. "But they have that quality that makes them able to produce those sparks."\n\nThe smart money, though, is on Spain winning a seventh straight game to clinch a record fourth European Championship title.\n\nIt would be a just end to a tournament where few teams really clicked apart from the Spanish, who have dovetailed a more ruthless attacking edge with their longstanding possession game that perhaps peaked in the Euro 2012 final when a team of midfielders -- notably Xavi Hernandez, Andres Iniesta, Sergio Busquets, Xabi Alonso and David Silva -- ran over Italy in Spain\'s 4-0 win.\n\nThe class of 2024 might not have those names, but they\'d be worthy successors.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'napavalleyregister.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Napa Valley Register'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@napavalleyregister.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': True}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/napavalleyregister.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/e/90/e900e269-e119-5bc2-a596-038139fa372f/6691a4f9dda62.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9729240', 'sentiment': 0.1607843137254903, 'wgt': 458518944, 'relevance': 26}
{'uri': '8222957136', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:21:50', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:21:50Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:20:40Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8352941274642944, 'url': 'https://napavalleyregister.com/sports/professional/bradley-ryder-cup-captain-surprise/article_2af5f2d4-1c6f-58f1-9443-5ad5e695664e.html', 'title': 'Bradley as Ryder Cup captain raises questions whether U.S. task force plan is over', 'body': 'NORTH BERWICK, Scotland -- Justin Thomas was just starting his rookie season on the PGA Tour when the Americans formed the infamous "Ryder Cup Task Force" geared toward building continuity with hopes of restoring U.S. dominance in the matches.\n\nTen years later, Thomas was part of the Ryder Cup Committee that selected Keegan Bradley as the next captain.\n\nIt was a surprising choice because Bradley played in only two Ryder Cups and had no experience as an assistant. That was part of the template that came out of the task force. Future captains would first be groomed as assistants. Captains would stay on as an assistant at the following Ryder Cup. Everyone would be on the same page.\n\nIt\'s what led Phil Mickelson to declare in early 2015 after the task force came up with the plan, "I\'m excited about where we are now, and I\'m excited about where we are headed -- not just into 2016, but really for the next 10 or 20 years."\n\nPeople are also reading... Ryan Seacrest\'s Napa County home up for sale at $22 million A Napa teen was killed by gun violence. Her life inspired a scholarship. $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Document at center of Supervisor Ramos\' restraining order found in public filings Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 Judge considers vacating temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos St. Helena Cyclery to reopen in wake of Trek\'s closure Napa judge declines to remove temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos Supervisor Belia Ramos files court documents alleging harassment Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life Napa\'s first Fourth of July drone show takes to the sky amid mixed feelings Fire hazards and federal subpoenas: Questions continue to swirl around Clover Flat Landfill Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Napa Farmers Market: There\'s always a place for you at the market Manslaughter case over cyclist couple killed in Napa moves forward\n\nIs that the end of the task force plan?\n\n"Yes and no," Thomas said at the Scottish Open. "My thing is I want us to pick the best captain. I don\'t want it to feel like it needs to fit a certain résumé; it doesn\'t need to fit this right mold. It\'s like, \'Look, who\'s our best captain right now?\'\n\n"It doesn\'t matter what they\'ve done," he said. "Are the guys going to be excited to play for him? Is he going to mesh with everybody? That\'s all that matters. That\'s something that potentially is the hope going forward. Next year is the only one that matters right now."\n\nDavis Love III was the first captain that came out of the task force for the 2016 matches at Hazeltine, a U.S. victory against a European team that had six rookies, five of whom never played in another Ryder Cup.\n\nHis assistants included Jim Furyk, Steve Stricker and Tiger Woods. Furyk was the next captain for 2018 in France. His assistants included Stricker, Woods and Zach Johnson. Then it was Stricker\'s turn in Wisconsin. Furyk was an assistant, along with Love (again) and Johnson. And then Johnson got the job for Marco Simone outside Rome.\n\nAnd on it went, the home side winning each time.\n\nIn some respects, Bradley broke the mold. He hasn\'t been involved in a Ryder Cup or Presidents Cup since 2014, except for being part of the Netflix docuseries that filmed him getting the awkward call from Johnson that he would not be a captain\'s pick.\n\nRory McIlroy is a keen observer of all things Ryder Cup and was surprised by Bradley choice, like so many others.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"I think Keegan was probably in disbelief, at some point, too," McIlroy said with a smile. "But certainly an interesting pick."\n\nWhen asked whether he felt it was it was a departure from what the Ryder Cup task force set out to do in 2014, McIlroy couldn\'t say except to note that players still had a voice. Thomas, Johnson and Jordan Spieth are on the committee.\n\n"It seems quite reactionary in terms of what happened in Rome," McIlroy said, referring to the Americans losing a seventh consecutive road match.\n\nMost surprising about the selection was that Bradley says he was never interviewed. The first phone call was to offer him the job. Thomas said he played a practice round with Bradley before that phone call and found it "difficult to act normal."\n\nOther names kicked around if Woods wasn\'t interested included Stewart Cink and Matt Kuchar. Both had been assistants. That was template.\n\n"I don\'t think anyone is ever an obvious choice, especially going outside the box," Thomas said. "It was very apparent that it wasn\'t an obvious choice in the beginning. I think after everybody got together and talked about it, all of the light bulbs flicked off for all of us at the right time.\n\n"Once that was the thought, there was no other way."\n\nBradley will be 39 next year when the 2025 matches take place at Bethpage Black, making him the youngest captain since Arnold Palmer was 34 and a playing captain in 1963 at East Lake. He was the last playing captain in the Ryder Cup.\n\nBradley also is No. 19 in the world and said flatly he wants to play on the next team if he were to qualify.\n\nThat hasn\'t been a serious consideration for the Ryder Cup since Tom Kite was captain in 1997, the year he was runner-up (by 12 shots) to Woods at the Masters. Kite finished 35th on the PGA Tour money list that year.\n\nWoods was a playing captain at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne in 2019. He went 3-0, though the Presidents Cup is not in the same league as the Ryder Cup in attention, promotion or the level of external pressure.\n\nAny American team in golf is tough to make these days. Bradley still is a long way off regardless of his world ranking. Thomas thinks it could happen because the U.S. hired former caddie John Wood as team manager to help with the details.\n\nMcIlroy said his name was kicked around for the 2027 matches in Adare Manor in Ireland, especially if Woods is the U.S. captain. Imagine how much hype a Woods-McIlroy captaincy would create.\n\nEven as a fantasy idea, however, McIlroy wasn\'t buying.\n\n"It\'s been mentioned and I\'ve said, \'No way.\' There\'s no way," he said. "If you want to be the best captain you can be, you can\'t play. And if you want to be the best player you can be, you can\'t captain. It\'s one or the other, especially with how big the Ryder Cup has become."\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'napavalleyregister.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Napa Valley Register'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@napavalleyregister.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': True}, {'uri': 'seth_wenig@napavalleyregister.com', 'name': 'Seth Wenig', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/napavalleyregister.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/2/af/2af5f2d4-1c6f-58f1-9443-5ad5e695664e/6691a680867d6.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9727963', 'sentiment': 0.0980392156862746, 'wgt': 458518910, 'relevance': 51}

He was the last playing captain in the Ryder Cup.\n\nBradley also is No. 19 in the world and said flatly he wants to play on the next team if he were to qualify.\n\nThat hasn\'t been a serious consideration for the Ryder Cup since Tom Kite was captain in 1997, the year he was runner-up (by 12 shots) to Woods at the Masters. Kite finished 35th on the PGA Tour money list that year.\n\nWoods was a playing captain at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne in 2019. He went 3-0, though the Presidents Cup is not in the same league as the Ryder Cup in attention, promotion or the level of external pressure.\n\nAny American team in golf is tough to make these days. Bradley still is a long way off regardless of his world ranking. Thomas thinks it could happen because the U.S. hired former caddie John Wood as team manager to help with the details.\n\nMcIlroy said his name was kicked around for the 2027 matches in Adare Manor in Ireland, especially if Woods is the U.S. captain. Imagine how much hype a Woods-McIlroy captaincy would create.\n\nEven as a fantasy idea, however, McIlroy wasn\'t buying.\n\n"It\'s been mentioned and I\'ve said, \'No way.\' There\'s no way," he said. "If you want to be the best captain you can be, you can\'t play. And if you want to be the best player you can be, you can\'t captain. It\'s one or the other, especially with how big the Ryder Cup has become."\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'newsadvance.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'NewsAdvance.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'associated_press@newsadvance.com', 'name': 'Associated Press', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'seth_wenig@newsadvance.com', 'name': 'Seth Wenig', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/newsadvance.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/2/aa/2aabe312-856c-57c0-81f0-fb32f5744b5a/6691a680ae766.preview.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1764705882352942, 'wgt': 458518833, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8222956058', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:20:13', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:20:13Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:19:27Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8549019694328308, 'url': 'https://lacrossetribune.com/sports/professional/pga/bradley-ryder-cup-captain-surprise/article_4c1f420e-93eb-53f8-97fc-4b806f4d507c.html', 'title': 'Bradley as Ryder Cup captain raises questions whether U.S. task force plan is over', 'body': 'NORTH BERWICK, Scotland -- Justin Thomas was just starting his rookie season on the PGA Tour when the Americans formed the infamous "Ryder Cup Task Force" geared toward building continuity with hopes of restoring U.S. dominance in the matches.\n\nTen years later, Thomas was part of the Ryder Cup Committee that selected Keegan Bradley as the next captain.\n\nIt was a surprising choice because Bradley played in only two Ryder Cups and had no experience as an assistant. That was part of the template that came out of the task force. Future captains would first be groomed as assistants. Captains would stay on as an assistant at the following Ryder Cup. Everyone would be on the same page.\n\nIt\'s what led Phil Mickelson to declare in early 2015 after the task force came up with the plan, "I\'m excited about where we are now, and I\'m excited about where we are headed -- not just into 2016, but really for the next 10 or 20 years."\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Batter and Brew hits the streets in La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Downtown Holiday Inn converting to boutique hotel in La Crosse Human trafficking in La Crosse: Police department raises awareness after recent arrests Local talent shines in first-ever Riverfest Idol karaoke tournament Steve Cahalan: New South Side Aldi store to open July 25 in La Crosse Galesville man charged with eluding police and stealing vehicle in Onalaska One injured in three vehicle crash near Arcadia Elderly man killed in UTV accident on Ettrick farm Farm ordered to pay $210K for wastewater permit violations; owner disputes Monroe County court ruling Criminal complaint implicates two La Crosse residents for human trafficking UPDATE: $500K bond set for man charged with assault in Winona that led to shelter-in-place order Two spills of chemical firefighting foam occurred at La Crosse Regional Airport earlier this year, reports say 21-year-old man drowns in private pond in Grant County, authorities say Amtrak reports strong ticket sales for new line running through Wisconsin Tellurian awarded $35,000 from Mayo Health\n\nIs that the end of the task force plan?\n\n"Yes and no," Thomas said at the Scottish Open. "My thing is I want us to pick the best captain. I don\'t want it to feel like it needs to fit a certain résumé; it doesn\'t need to fit this right mold. It\'s like, \'Look, who\'s our best captain right now?\'\n\n"It doesn\'t matter what they\'ve done," he said. "Are the guys going to be excited to play for him? Is he going to mesh with everybody? That\'s all that matters. That\'s something that potentially is the hope going forward. Next year is the only one that matters right now."\n\nDavis Love III was the first captain that came out of the task force for the 2016 matches at Hazeltine, a U.S. victory against a European team that had six rookies, five of whom never played in another Ryder Cup.\n\nHis assistants included Jim Furyk, Steve Stricker and Tiger Woods. Furyk was the next captain for 2018 in France. His assistants included Stricker, Woods and Zach Johnson. Then it was Stricker\'s turn in Wisconsin. Furyk was an assistant, along with Love (again) and Johnson. And then Johnson got the job for Marco Simone outside Rome.\n\nAnd on it went, the home side winning each time.\n\nIn some respects, Bradley broke the mold. He hasn\'t been involved in a Ryder Cup or Presidents Cup since 2014, except for being part of the Netflix docuseries that filmed him getting the awkward call from Johnson that he would not be a captain\'s pick.\n\nRory McIlroy is a keen observer of all things Ryder Cup and was surprised by Bradley choice, like so many others.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"I think Keegan was probably in disbelief, at some point, too," McIlroy said with a smile. "But certainly an interesting pick."\n\nWhen asked whether he felt it was it was a departure from what the Ryder Cup task force set out to do in 2014, McIlroy couldn\'t say except to note that players still had a voice. Thomas, Johnson and Jordan Spieth are on the committee.\n\n"It seems quite reactionary in terms of what happened in Rome," McIlroy said, referring to the Americans losing a seventh consecutive road match.\n\nMost surprising about the selection was that Bradley says he was never interviewed. The first phone call was to offer him the job. Thomas said he played a practice round with Bradley before that phone call and found it "difficult to act normal."\n\nOther names kicked around if Woods wasn\'t interested included Stewart Cink and Matt Kuchar. Both had been assistants. That was template.\n\n"I don\'t think anyone is ever an obvious choice, especially going outside the box," Thomas said. "It was very apparent that it wasn\'t an obvious choice in the beginning. I think after everybody got together and talked about it, all of the light bulbs flicked off for all of us at the right time.\n\n"Once that was the thought, there was no other way."\n\nBradley will be 39 next year when the 2025 matches take place at Bethpage Black, making him the youngest captain since Arnold Palmer was 34 and a playing captain in 1963 at East Lake. He was the last playing captain in the Ryder Cup.\n\nBradley also is No. 19 in the world and said flatly he wants to play on the next team if he were to qualify.\n\nThat hasn\'t been a serious consideration for the Ryder Cup since Tom Kite was captain in 1997, the year he was runner-up (by 12 shots) to Woods at the Masters. Kite finished 35th on the PGA Tour money list that year.\n\nWoods was a playing captain at the Presidents Cup at Royal Melbourne in 2019. He went 3-0, though the Presidents Cup is not in the same league as the Ryder Cup in attention, promotion or the level of external pressure.\n\nAny American team in golf is tough to make these days. Bradley still is a long way off regardless of his world ranking. Thomas thinks it could happen because the U.S. hired former caddie John Wood as team manager to help with the details.\n\nMcIlroy said his name was kicked around for the 2027 matches in Adare Manor in Ireland, especially if Woods is the U.S. captain. Imagine how much hype a Woods-McIlroy captaincy would create.\n\nEven as a fantasy idea, however, McIlroy wasn\'t buying.\n\n"It\'s been mentioned and I\'ve said, \'No way.\' There\'s no way," he said. "If you want to be the best captain you can be, you can\'t play. And if you want to be the best player you can be, you can\'t captain. {'uri': '8222950182', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:12:47', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:12:47Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:11:44Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/local/2024/07/12/livingston-county-wrestler-representing-5th-smallest-country-in-the-olympics/', 'title': 'Livingston County wrestler representing 5th smallest country in the Olympics', 'body': 'BRIGHTON, Mich. - San Marino is the fifth smallest country in the world, just 24 square miles, and completely surrounded by Italy.\n\nIt has the distinction of being the smallest nation by population ever to win an Olympic medal. That population is just over 33,000 people. For reference in Michigan, that\'s about the size of Eastpointe.\n\nSan Marino sent five athletes to the last summer Olympics in Tokyo, and incredibly, three of them brought home medals, including wrestler Myles Amine.\n\n"We have really a melting pot of nationalities, ethnicities in my family, but the one thing that remains common is our love for wrestling," said Amine.\n\nAmine grew up in Brighton. He won two wrestling state championships in high school, then went on to a standout career at the University of Michigan.\n\nBut when it came time for the Olympics, Amine realized his dual citizenship presented a unique opportunity.\n\n"My great-grandfather came over from San Marino back in the day, and he kept his Sammarinese citizenship. And that\'s something that is passed down through lineage. So my mother actually passed her Sammarinese citizenship down to me," said Amine. "I thought it\'d be a really cool opportunity. It would give me the best opportunity to compete in the Olympic games, travel the world, and then, most importantly, to represent this really small country that I\'m sure a lot of people listening haven\'t even (heard of), are gonna end up Googling."\n\nIn Tokyo, Amine was honored to be selected as one of San Marino\'s flag bearers for the Opening Ceremony.\n\n"It was myself and a swimmer, Arianna, and we both walked in, and we kind of looked at each other, and we both had the same look in our eyes, of like, \'This is happening right now,\'" said Amine. "That was one of those moments where I was like, \'Let\'s just take this in and smell the roses a little bit.\' You know, the competition and all that stuff is going to come, but this is definitely what they mean when they say, live in the moment."\n\nWhile Amine represents his mother\'s side of the family in competition, he is carrying on an Olympic legacy from his father\'s side.\n\nHis grandfather Nazem Amine competed in the 1952 and 1960 Olympics for the country of Lebanon.\n\n"He deserves all the credit for, you know, me getting into wrestling, my father, my uncle, all my cousins. We wouldn\'t be where we were if it wasn\'t for his legacy."\n\nMyles\' older brother Malik Amine also wrestled for San Marino.\n\nSo how much do the Amines love wrestling? Myles\' dad Mike turned their basement into a wrestling room.\n\n"At first I think, I think my mom was, like, thinking he was crazy, but then even she realized that it was a perfect place to send us down to when we started to get rough," laughed Amine.\n\nThe investment has certainly paid off. Myles Amine won a bronze medal in Tokyo.\n\nBut with COVID restrictions, something was missing.\n\n"I won a bronze medal, and you could kind of hear, like a few cheers, but then there was also like crickets in the background," said Amine.\n\nThis time, the stands will be filled with "Team Amine."\n\n"I think anywhere between, like 20 to 30 people," said Amine. "The first day after the world championships, when I qualified, they were already looking at hotels and Airbnbs and trying to buy up allotments of tickets."\n\nFor the Amine family, it\'s already a dream come true.\n\n"I\'m on cloud nine, we are super pumped and excited," said Mike Amine. "Obviously, we all want him to win, but the journey\'s been incredible for the Amine family, the University of Michigan, his extended family, the fans. I think proud is just an understatement."\n\nMyles Amine is proud of everything he\'s accomplished so far, but don\'t expect to see his Olympic medal on display.\n\n"My coach, he, like, he won two Olympic gold medals, and he said the first thing he did was put them away in like a sock drawer when he won them, because he was like, \'It\'s on to the next,\' and so I\'ve tried to share that mentality," explained Amine. "Until I retire, I think that all the medals and stuff, there\'s not going to be a showcase for them, because it kind of defeats the purpose of why I\'m doing this."\n\nAmine said he\'s discovered for him, the joy is in the journey.\n\nAnd this journey isn\'t over yet.', 'source': {'uri': 'clickondetroit.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'WDIV'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'sarah_mayberry@clickondetroit.com', 'name': 'Sarah Mayberry', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://res.cloudinary.com/graham-media-group/image/upload/f_auto/q_auto/c_thumb,w_700/v1/media/anyclip/U5LrqJABTuwtjANW0jw-/1720821153650_1920x1080_thumbnail.jpg?_a=DATAdtfiZAA0', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.2784313725490195, 'wgt': 458518367, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8222948003', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '22:09:51', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T22:09:51Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T22:09:06Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://heraldcourier.com/sports/bhc-boys-basketball-player-of-year-what-can-brown-do-for-tennessee-high-plenty/article_b211131e-4070-11ef-adea-dbf1c86421c6.html', 'title': 'BHC BOYS BASKETBALL PLAYER OF YEAR: What can Brown do for Tennessee High? Plenty', 'body': 'Tennessee High\'s Colin Brown will lead the Vikings against Fulton in a Class 3 sectional tonight with a state tournament berth awaiting the winning team. Fulton won the state championship last season.\n\nTIM HAYES Bristol Herald Courier\n\nIn an era where keyboard warriors and social media contrarians can make their unsolicited opinions on sports known with one simple click, it can be hard to reach common ground in terms of evaluating an athlete.\n\nYet, it seems on a local level there is one opinion unanimously shared.\n\nTennessee High\'s Colin Brown can flat out play some basketball.\n\nThe 6-foot-1 rising senior rose to great heights back in the winter for the Vikings and the sentiments about his skills from folks who know a thing or two about quality hoopsters are similar.\n\n"Colin Brown controls the game on both ends of the floor," said West Ridge coach John Dyer. "His explosiveness allows him to get to the basket for his own shot or he is able to create a shot for his teammates. He has great instincts on defense that disrupts offenses with steals and deflections. He is the attacker for 32 minutes."\n\nPeople are also reading... McNew living her dream as a large truck mechanic LITTLE LEAGUE: Good day for local teams in state softball tournament TVA announces changes at South Holston, Boone properties \'Vampire\' series gives Sam Reid plenty to bite into Simmons to expand manufacturing into Russell County AUTO RACING: Rural Retreat native Will Hostetler\'s a hometown hero at Wythe Raceway COLLEGE BASEBALL: Chase Hungate (Abingdon) headed to Mississippi State, relishes chance to compete in SEC COLLEGE FOOTBALL: You can find Brad Robbins (Powell Valley) coaching at UConn now HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Coaching innovator Mumme to serve on Sullivan East coaching staff LITTLE LEAGUE: Monday\'s State Tournament Results FOOTBALL CAMP: Former Tennessee QBs Hooker, Milton hosts football camp at Sullivan East PREP FOOTBALL: The VHSL master schedule was released on Thursday. Here are some games with intriguing storylines LITTLE LEAGUE: Abingdon falls in Virginia state title game Marketplace dining opening at Hard Rock Bristol Casino donations near $900,000 with Tuesday presentation\n\nAdded Virginia High boss Julius Gallishaw, "Colin is one of those players who can do everything on the court - pass, dribble, shoot, rebound and play defense. He knows the game, so anything you try to throw at him, he\'s prepared for. Just a great all-around player. ... Great kid with a great future."\n\nAbingdon coach Chris Hutton, a Tennessee High graduate, offered this review: "Colin is an excellent point guard who can score and get everyone involved on the floor. He has a swag about him that brings excitement to the crowd. His deep 3s are impressive, but his mentality of getting to the rim makes him special. I have said in the past, besides my players at Abingdon, Colin is my favorite player in this area to watch."\n\nLucas Honeycutt, leader of the Elizabethton Cyclones, added his assessment: "Smooth, confident and collected. Makes everyone around him better. He\'s a great player with a ton of upside to fill out his frame for the next level."\n\nIt should come as no surprise that the game-changer earning such praise was selected as the Bristol Herald Courier\'s boys basketball player of the year for the 2023-24 season as Brown averaged 21 points, three rebounds, three assists and three steals per game for a team that finished as TSSAA Region 1-AAA runner-up.\n\n"Colin had a special season," said Tennessee High coach Michael McMeans.\n\nThe most special moment came on a Saturday night in February at Viking Hall as Tennessee High hosted Grainger in the first round of the regional tourney.\n\n"Obviously, I knew I had to have a good game, because it was win-or-go-home," Brown said. "I was coming off a rough game in the district championship [in a loss to David Crockett], so I knew I had to come to play."\n\nBoy, did he ever.\n\nBy the time it was all said and done he had scored a single-game program record 54 points as his team rolled to an 86-52 victory.\n\nHe broke the previous mark of 50 points established by Hugh McMurray 30 years earlier.\n\nBrown had 23 points at halftime and 39 points entering the fourth quarter.\n\nIn two of the four periods he didn\'t miss a shot.\n\nBrown\'s final line: 20-for-26 from the field - including 8-for-11 from 3-point range - and 6-for-7 from the free throw line.\n\n"He was so hot and could do anything he wanted to do," McMeans said. "But he did it within the flow of the game. I would call a play and he would run it and the ball just found him and he knocked down the open shot. He could have just come down and went one-on-one as hot as he was, and that would have worked, but he kept his teammates involved, worked hard on defense and just let the game come to him."\n\nDerrick Hord, Marc Campbell, De\'Shaud Johnson, Charlie Nickels, Buddy Saunders, Gary "Two" Morton, Kevin Springs, Derek Linkous, Chase Branscomb, Michael Mays (Brown\'s cousin who later starred at King University and is playing professionally overseas) are just a few of the many hoops heroes who have worn a THS jersey and none of them have had a night like the one Brown did five months ago.\n\n"The play I remember most from that game was the play where I broke the record," Brown said. "When I came off the high ball screen and hit the pull-up 3 on the wing."\n\nA few days later Brown had 23 points and converted the go-ahead bucket with 18.6 seconds remaining as the Vikings rallied for a 57-56 win over Greeneville to clinch their first sectional (or sub-state as most people call it) berth since 2005.\n\n"The win against Greeneville was huge for us," Brown said. "They were the higher seed and we played at Claiborne County, which we had never played there and they had, so we were at a big disadvantage I thought. We came out a little slow, especially me and we get to halftime down seven points. We come out [in the second half] playing really well and brought it close going into the fourth and closed it out."\n\nWhile Tennessee High dropped its final two games - Brown had 22 points in a loss to Crockett in the regional finals and 15 points in a 71-42 setback to eventual state champ Fulton in the sub-state showdown - it was still a successful season.\n\nDon\'t let that 18-17 record fool you.\n\nNot many people predicted the Vikings to reach that point after several standouts graduated and the team began the season by losing five of its first six games.\n\n"This season was a roller-coaster is the only way to describe it," Brown said. "We started off the season a little rough, just because it was a new team, but as the year went on, we bonded and built chemistry. We started to get it together and win games and getting to sub-state, but we didn\'t get to the goal of going to state."\n\nCreed Musick was the 2022-23 Bristol Herald Courier\'s player of the year after a stellar senior year as the go-to guy for the Vikings and Brown took over his role as the catalyst.\n\n"The biggest thing that I learned from Creed was just playing every play at 100 percent and good things will happen," Brown said. "Whether that\'s offense or defense and he taught me how to lead the team and keep everything under control."\n\nBrown was one of those players who opponents and spectators alike knew was going to get the ball and could still score at will.\n\n"I knew people were going to guard me very hard and I was going to have to just deal with it," Brown said. "I\'m not the most athletic, but I used my change of pace and just had to be smarter than the person guarding me by drawing a foul and picking and choosing my spots on the floor where I was going to score."\n\nThat comes from years of practice.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\n"I started playing basketball since I was around 5 or 6," Brown said. "The thing I remember the most was being the smallest kid on the court, so I always had to find different ways to score the ball and be effective and I think that helped me a lot."\n\nBrown got better as the season went along as did the Vikings.\n\n"The biggest thing was confidence," Brown said. "Because my sophomore year I was the third or fourth option, so the offense and defense was not as reliant on me, so I didn\'t have to be as confident, but this year I just told myself no matter who we played that I was the best player on the court and just had to show up every night."\n\nHe sure did and his arsenal was full of impressive moves.\n\n"Nobody can stay in front of Colin he is so quick," McMeans said. "His first step and the way he sets his defender up are really something that is special," McMeans said. "Colin was able to continue to score and perform at a high level even when teams ran junk defenses against him because of his willingness to play within our offense. We move Colin around a lot. Sometimes we start him bringing the ball up, sometimes off the ball. We may start him the corner on the wing or at the high post. So, the other teams just can\'t prepare for him always having the ball in his hands. Colin got really good at coming off screens and setting his defender up, which allowed him to be the special playmaker that he is."\n\nHe also had that clutch gene that can be hard to find in some teenage talents.\n\n"There are not many players in the entire state who can take a game over like he does, no matter what defense is thrown at him," McMeans said. "The great thing about it is there is no panic at all in him. When the other team runs a different defense at him, he just normally looks over at me and we get him lined up and have a play we can run to get him open. Some kids tend to panic if they get double-teamed, face guarded or junk defended. Not Colin."\n\nWhile Brown is a volume scorer, he is not some shameless gun firing up low-percentage shots in a detrimental way.\n\n"The most underrated thing about Colin is his willingness to make his teammates successful," McMeans said. "He really cares about his teammates and enjoys when they are successful. He is so unselfish and is all about our team winning."\n\nColin Brown has a valuable mentor in older brother Brandon Brown, who was a high school star and began his collegiate career at Lees-McRae.\n\n"He has been a huge help and not just helping me get better skill-wise, but mentally as well," Brown said. "Just keeping myself in the game when I\'m missing shots or not playing well. He has also taught me a lot about the game and the right way to play it."\n\nKing University, Lees-McRae and Milligan have extended scholarship offers, while NCAA Division I programs such as East Tennessee State University, Radford, North Carolina-Asheville and Western Carolina have expressed interest in securing Colin Brown\'s services.\n\nBrandon Brown transferred from Tennessee High to Teays Valley Christian in West Virginia during his high school career, but Colin Brown will not be taking a similar path.\n\n"I mean yeah, I have thought about it a lot since my sophomore year and have talked to a lot of prep schools around the country," Brown said. "But I think that is best for me to stick to what is working and not have to basically start over somewhere else, so I will be playing my senior year at THS."\n\nThat\'s probably not news area coaches were hoping to hear.\n\nThey are likely already trying to think of gameplans to slow Tennessee High\'s scoring machine.\n\nGood luck.\n\n*\n\nAll-BHC Boys Basketball Team\n\nPlayer of Year: Colin Brown (Tennessee High)\n\nCoach of Year: Julius Gallishaw (Virginia High)\n\nFirst Team\n\nColin Brown, Tennessee High\n\nKeyton Keene, Honaker\n\nReed Kirtner, George Wythe\n\nDeonte Mozell, Virginia High\n\nMarkelle Ray, Graham\n\nSecond Team\n\nKory Bostic, Union\n\nCade Caywood, Patrick Henry\n\nGunner Garrett, Gate City\n\nMike Reece, Lebanon\n\nCorbin Laisure, Sullivan East\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'heraldcourier.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'HeraldCourier.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/heraldcourier.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/b/21/b211131e-4070-11ef-adea-dbf1c86421c6/66919d524a397.preview.jpg?crop=1175%2C617%2C0%2C573&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.2156862745098038, 'wgt': 458518191, 'relevance': 26}

{'uri': '2024-07-420269232', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '21:59:36', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T21:59:36Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T21:52:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8627451062202454, 'url': 'https://www.news.com.au/lifestyle/home/diy/frankston-tradie-fined-11500-by-council-for-filling-in-hole-now-faces-home-inspection-for-unsafe-works/news-story/df0469e222e824b45bf2e64ad4178f34', 'title': "Frankston tradie fined $11,500 by council for filling in hole, now faces home inspection for 'unsafe' works", 'body': 'A Melbourne landscaper says he is being treated like a "murderer or a drug dealer" by his local council after he was slapped with an $11,500 fine for filling in a dangerous hole.\n\nThe fine was followed by a demand to inspect his property for "unsafe" building work after he took his story to the media.\n\nAdam Marsal, 40, says he was only trying to do the right thing when he filled in a large hole that had been left by a fallen tree in the nature strip near his Cranbourne Road home in Frankston late last year.\n\nThe roughly two-metre hole, just behind a bus stop, had been left for months and Mr Marsal had "seen people tumble off the side".\n\n"I tried to do the right thing," he said. "This tree stump was huge. I sort of smoothed it out, used my skills to fix it all up. I put some soil in, put some plants."\n\nThe landscaper, who grew up in nearby Mentone, said he was "passionate about the area" and wanted to help clean it up.\n\n"Driving around you see rubbish everywhere," he said. "I\'m just sorting out my little patch. It\'s that broken windows philosophy -- cleaning up rubbish and needles, making it look normal, it deters people dumping stuff."\n\nBut to his surprise, Mr Marsal was contacted by Frankston City Council officers earlier this year requesting he come to discuss the unauthorised works, after a tip-off by another local.\n\nMr Marsal said he thought he was "just going in to have a conversation", but instead was subjected to an extraordinary police-style interrogation by Bruce Gardiner, the council\'s prosecutions co-ordinator.\n\nFrom the beginning of the 20-minute grilling, described as "disturbing" by a local MP, Mr Marsal was "already on the defensive" after what he alleges was Mr Gardiner\'s "rude and arrogant" treatment of him on the phone.\n\nMr Gardiner -- who made headlines last year after pop star Tones and I and her husband were slapped with $25,000 in fines for illegal renovations to their Frankston investment property -- opens the on-camera interview by telling Mr Marsal he was going to ask about "some allegations about the illegal deposit of litter on the side of the road".\n\n"I don\'t know that it\'s litter, but OK," Mr Marsal says.\n\nMr Gardiner proceeds to read Mr Marsal his rights and requests he state his full name, sparking a hostile back-and-forth that sets the tone for the remainder of the combative interview.\n\n"There\'s probably a lot of Adam Marsals in the world," Mr Gardiner says.\n\n"No not really, if you want to do a Google search," Mr Marsal says.\n\n"Do you want to state your full name or not?" Mr Gardiner says.\n\n"I\'ll just say Adam Marsal," Mr Marsal says.\n\n"Do you want to state your full name or not?" Mr Gardiner says.\n\nMr Gardiner bristles when Mr Marsal similarly refuses to give his age and date of birth, or answer questions about his business, saying he doesn\'t "see how that\'s relevant".\n\n"Well answer my questions or don\'t answer my questions, let me work out what\'s relevant and what\'s not, OK?" Mr Gardiner says.\n\nLater in the interview Mr Gardiner produces a series of photos of the hole.\n\n"Yeah I\'ve cleaned up the site, it used to be a f**king derelict site, full of s**t," Mr Marsal says angrily. "Mind you, there was this big gum tree, it fell over and you left a hole in the ground two metres deep and about four metres wide, right here, for about six months, so I cleaned it up."\n\n"You work for the council -- the council left the hole in the ground," Mr Marsal says.\n\n"Adam, why did you put those items on the side of the road?" Mr Gardiner says.\n\n"I\'ve just been telling you," Mr Marsal says. "Did you hear what I\'ve been talking about. Does that answer your question?"\n\n"No it doesn\'t," Mr Gardiner says. "Your suggestion is that you put those items there to beautify the area."\n\nHe tells Mr Marsal council has no record of him having reported the hole.\n\nMr Marsal insists "I called you guys, I called VicRoads, I cleaned it up because no one was coming".\n\n"This is my home, I live across the road from this place," he says. "I\'ve spent thousands of dollars buying stuff for this."\n\nMr Gardiner informs him that to do works in a road reserve he needs a permit, which Mr Marsal concedes he does not have.\n\nLast month, Mr Marsal received two infringement notices -- one to himself and one to his company -- for "depositing waste of more than 1000 litres" in violation of the Environment Protection Act 2017, totalling $11,500.\n\nAfter his story was featured on Nine\'s A Current Affair earlier this week, Mr Marsal then received another letter from council requesting access to his property for a building inspection on Monday, July 15.\n\n"Frankston City Council has received information that there is potentially unsafe or non-compliant building work at the abovementioned property that requires inspection," the letter said.\n\nnews.com.au does not suggest that Mr Gardiner had any involvement in the issuing of the letter.\n\nMr Marsal said he had owned his two-bedroom freestanding unit for nearly 10 years.\n\n"Years ago I did some renovations inside and landscaped it, put retaining walls up, fixed the veranda that was falling down and put in some stairs," he said.\n\n"That\'s the extent of it. It\'s been like that for years, and coincidentally after the other issue they sent [this letter]. It makes me feel intimidated and harassed. I\'m pretty sure they can go to any house in Australia and pick someone up on anything."\n\nMr Marsal said he did not intend to give consent to the search, meaning the council "have the option to go to a magistrate and get a search warrant".\n\n"I\'m not a murderer, I\'m not a drug dealer," he said. "I try to keep my head down in life, I don\'t want these kinds of issues. You just don\'t go and treat people like this."\n\nPaul Edbrooke, the Labor state MP for Frankston, said watching how Mr Marsal was treated in the video "was actually quite disturbing".\n\n"These kinds of issues can be treated in a much more pragmatic and productive manner," he said. "In the last few months we\'ve had quite a few complaints in regards to the way ratepayers are being treated by council over issues such as this one. Personally I have no idea why council would be this heavy-handed on someone that basically did their job for them."\n\nMr Edbrooke said he had "no idea at all why you would treat anyone in your community like that". "The effect on Adam\'s small business is just amazing and very, very disruptive," he said.\n\nThe MP also said he found the timing of the letter "really suspicious".\n\n"A reasonable person could start thinking that this is targeting, intimidating and bullying someone," he said.\n\n"This council has been pulled up quite a few times for alleged bullying. I think there is some big cultural issue."\n\nMr Edbrooke said "overall the message I\'ve gotten" from constituents was the council was "out of touch, out of focus and they\'ve got a culture problem".\n\n"People are just wondering, when the rates, roads and rubbish portion of their council rates, they don\'t get those services, why council are focusing on these other pet projects they\'ve got," he said.\n\n"Meanwhile a hole that had been there more than six months, two metres deep, a guy that has to take matters into his own hands is then charged $11,500."\n\nAdam Glezer from Consumer Champion, who is representing Mr Marsal, said he had "seen council issues but nothing nearly as disgraceful as this situation".\n\n"It seems like a classic case of bullying," he said.\n\n"The tactics that the council used in this situation were extremely inappropriate."\n\nMr Glezer said from what he had heard, "this is a systemic problem with Frankston City Council".\n\n"How can you give a good Samaritan a $11,500 fine for making an area safe that the council failed to do themselves?" he said.\n\n"Adam went in for a meeting with his local city council, not the AFP. That\'s exactly how they came across."\n\nHe added that "rather than apologising for their egregious behaviour, the council has doubled down".\n\n"He\'s done nothing different to his house in several years, yet the council thought it was appropriate to send him [an inspection] letter shortly after I got involved in his case," he said.\n\n"Frankston City Council representatives need to have a good, hard look at themselves because they are an absolute embarrassment. It appears they couldn\'t care less about their community."\n\nLate on Friday, after news.com.au sent questions to Frankston City Council, Mr Marsal said he received an email informing him Monday\'s inspection would not go ahead.', 'source': {'uri': 'news.com.au', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'News.com.au'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'frank_chung@news.com.au', 'name': 'Frank Chung', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://content.api.news/v3/images/bin/4517712ee28bead48aed2c89dce9ebd1', 'eventUri': 'eng-9729747', 'sentiment': -0.0117647058823529, 'wgt': 458517576, 'relevance': 29}

Not only do lighter vehicles generally offer better fuel efficiency, but they also tend to be more agile and easier to handle. For those who love the thrill of driving, a lightweight car can make all the difference. In this article, we've rounded up the ten lightest cars you can get your hands on in 2024. From zippy city cars to track-ready speedsters, there's something here for every type of driver.\n\nThroughout this list, you'll find a variety of lightweight wonders, from the practical and efficient Mitsubishi Mirage to the high-performance McMurtry Spéirling. We'll explore the rugged off-road capabilities of the Ariel Nomad and the unique single-seater experience offered by the BAC Mono R. Whether you're looking for a car that's easy on the fuel or a speed demon that's built for the track, we've got you covered. Now, let's dive into the lightest cars on the market and see what makes each one special.\n\n1:53\n\nRelated\n\nWhy Smaller And Lighter Electric Vehicles Are A More Sustainable Solution\n\nBy shrinking the size and weight of an electric vehicle, you end up with a smarter solution both for cost-effectiveness and the environment.\n\nIn order to give you the most up-to-date and accurate information possible, the data used to compile this article was sourced from various manufacturer websites and other authoritative sources, including J.D. Power, KBB, and Edmunds. Each model has been chosen for its lightweight design and availability for purchase in 2024.\n\n10 McMurtry Spéirling\n\nWeight: 2,199 LBS\n\nThe McMurtry Spéirling is a prime example of cutting-edge engineering meeting lightweight design. This electric hypercar features a U-shaped battery - structural within the tub - that offers 60kWh of capacity and can sustain 30-60 minutes of flat-out driving depending on weather and circuit. The Spéirling uses twin electric turbines behind the cockpit to suck air from beneath the chassis and kick it out behind the car, providing negative lift from 0 MPH.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nEngine\n\nDual Electric Motors\n\nTransmission\n\nDirect Drive\n\nHorsepower\n\n1,000 HP\n\nTorque\n\n1,033 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nAll-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\nUnder 1.5 seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n190 MPH\n\nThe Spéirling's fan-assisted downforce allows it to maintain superior grip and stability at any speed, making it a thrilling and efficient vehicle for high-performance enthusiasts. With plans for a racing series and future road cars, the McMurtry Spéirling is set to redefine lightweight electric vehicles.\n\n9 Mitsubishi Mirage\n\nWeight: 2,095 LBS\n\nThe Mitsubishi Mirage is an excellent choice for those seeking a practical, lightweight vehicle. This car has been picked for its remarkable fuel efficiency, affordability, and ease of handling, making it perfect for city driving and daily commuting. Its compact size and lightweight build allow for impressive maneuverability and parking convenience in those tight city spaces.\n\nPerformance Specifications\n\nEngine\n\n1.2-liter Inline-3\n\nTransmission\n\nContinuously Variable Transmission (CVT)\n\nHorsepower\n\n78 HP\n\nTorque\n\n74 LB-FT\n\nDriveline\n\nFront-Wheel Drive\n\n0-60 MPH\n\n12.5 seconds\n\nTop Speed\n\n105 MPH\n\nThe Mirage might not be the fastest car on this list, but its lightweight design and efficient engine make it a standout in terms of fuel economy and practicality. With a modest 78 horsepower, it excels in providing a smooth and economical ride, particularly suited for city dwellers. Its front-wheel-drive layout gives you stable and reliable handling, even in less-than-ideal driving conditions. Overall, the Mitsubishi Mirage is a sensible and budget-friendly option for those prioritizing efficiency and convenience over speed.\n\n8 Dallara Stradale\n\nWeight: 1,885 LBS\n\nThe Dallara Stradale is a purebred track car that's also street-legal, making it an intriguing addition to this list.
