Despite having a minuscule 0.6-liter turbocharged engine, it manages to produce 84 horsepower and 86 pound-feet of torque, which is plenty to propel its lightweight frame with whip-snapping acceleration.\n\nThe five-speed manual transmission ensures that every drive is engaging, letting you feel every shift and squeeze every bit of power from the engine. With a 0-60 MPH time of 6.9 seconds, it's no slouch, and its top speed of 105 MPH is more than enough for essentially an adult-sized, road-legal go-kart. If you're looking for the ultimate in lightweight, no-frills driving excitement, the Caterham Seven 170 is the clear winner.", 'source': {'uri': 'topspeed.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Top Speed'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'joshua_brown@topspeed.com', 'name': 'Joshua Brown', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static1.topspeedimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/lightest-cars-on-the-market-in-2024.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.3254901960784313, 'wgt': 458516881, 'relevance': 57}
{'uri': '2024-07-420257488', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '21:36:06', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T21:36:06Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T21:00:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.8823529481887817, 'url': 'https://muscatinejournal.com/news/nation-world/crime-courts/tulsa-race-massacres-first-identified-victim-from-unmarked-burials-is-a-wwi-veteran/article_fe1cb434-fdab-5367-b40e-18eeb3abef17.html', 'title': "Tulsa Race Massacre's first identified victim from unmarked burials is a WWI veteran", 'body': 'Randy Krehbiel Tulsa World\n\nA partially disabled World War I veteran trying to get home to his mother has been identified as a 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre victim buried anonymously in the city\'s Oaklawn Cemetery, researchers and Mayor G.T. Bynum said Friday.\n\nC.L. Daniel, a Georgia native whose name had never before come to the attention of Race Massacre researchers, is the first person identified through a project launched five years ago by Mayor G.T. Bynum to find unmarked burials from the May 31-June 1 calamity in which more than 35 square blocks of Tulsa\'s Black Greenwood District were destroyed by whites and dozens and perhaps hundreds of people were killed.\n\nDNA comparisons, genealogical research and two letters in the National Archives led Intermountain Forensics, a firm working with the city, to Daniel. The DNA and genealogy narrowed the search to two brothers with that last name.\n\nOne of the letters, a 1936 missive from a Georgia attorney to the U.S. Veterans Administration on behalf of Daniel\'s mother, identified C.L. as almost certainly the occupant of what archeologists denote as Burial #3 in the old Black paupers\' section of Oaklawn.\n\nThe letter, from Stanford Arnold of Newnan, Georgia, on behalf of Amanda Daniel, seeks "any benefits that be due her" because of her son\'s service and honorable discharge because of injury.\n\n"She has no discharge (papers) and is going to have difficulty in establishing his death," Arnold wrote. "C.L. was killed in a race riot in Tulsa Oklahoma in 1921 according to best information she has furnished me."\n\nIt is unclear whether the VA responded or if Amanda Daniel, who the lawyer described as "in destitute circumstances," received any assistance.\n\nThe National Archives search also produced a letter written by C.L. Daniel, apparently to the Army, in February 1921 from Ogden, Utah. In poignant language, Daniel says his legs pain him, apparently from an injury suffered in the Army, and make finding work difficult. Daniel says he spent 19 days in the Camp Gordon, Georgia, hospital.\n\n"(F)or some time I have traveled this country over and now sufriend (suffering) with complance (complaints) that (I) was in the base hospitle (hospital) with," Daniel wrote, his spelling and grammar a testament to the sort of education many Americans and especially Black Americans received in the early 20th century. "(D)ear sir, please send me a nof (enough) money to git me a job and to eat with till I Get better."\n\nDaniel\'s burial place was among the first uncovered in 2020 by the team headed by state archeologist Kary Stackelbeck and University of Florida forensic anthropologist Phoebe Stubblefield. Its proximity to headstones of two known massacre victims, Reuben Everett and Eddie Lockard, and to an area in which other remains similarly buried, make the researchers reasonably certain they have found the "original 18" -- 18 Black massacre victims reported at the time to have been buried in Oaklawn Cemetery, but without information about their exact location -- and two sets of remains with signs of gunshot wounds.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nStubblefield said a cause of death could not be determined for Daniel, whose remains were exhumed in 2021 and later reinterred in the same grave. She said it appeared the body had been scrunched into a coffin too small for him.\n\nBynum indicated Daniel\'s family, whose members were not identified, have not decided how they want to proceed with final burial.\n\n"We\'re going to work with them every step of the way," Bynum said. "Whatever they decide to do with the remains, the city of Tulsa is fully supportive of that."\n\nDaniel\'s identification accounts for one of several of Original 18 listed on death certificates as "unknown." It has also has reinvigorated the project.\n\nAt Friday\'s press conference, Bynum said the archeological team will return to Oaklawn on July 22. Stackelbeck indicated this phase will last more than a week and concentrate on the Original 18 area.\n\n"We now feel doubly confident of the criteria we\'ve been using to know which ones are good candidates for exhumation," she said.\n\nDanny Hellwig, director of Intermountain\'s Laboratory Development, said Daniel\'s identification is really the first of its kind.\n\n"This hasn\'t really been done before," Hellwig said. "We\'ve been learning through the process. As we\'ve learned and adapted, we\'re getting better at it. ... We hope this will provide some confidence and context and maybe a lot more trust so that we can expand on this."\n\nIdentification relies on voluntarily submitted DNA, public databases and families\' willingness to answer questions about relatives or ancestors.\n\nIn Daniel\'s case, researchers said, extended family members were mostly unaware of the circumstances of his death, if they knew of him at all. Intermountain\'s Alison Wilde, who handles the genealogical side, said many living family members did not know each other, much less the story of a great uncle who died without direct descendants more than a century ago.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nIn 1921, white mobs invaded Greenwood and burned it down\n\nA growing but divided city had tensions rising. How World War I influenced residents.\n\nKey figures in 1921\n\nGreenwood was defined by freedom and opportunity\n\nAn encounter on an elevator and concerns about a lynching\n\nTulsa Tribune article cited for sparking massacre\n\nDick Rowland\'s life threatened while jailed as crowd gathers outside\n\nTulsans take up arms and there are issues with special deputies\n\nFighting begins in Greenwood and the neighborhood is soon overrun\n\nMobs won\'t let firefighters douse the flames\n\nAirplanes flew over Greenwood as it was attacked\n\nNational Guard called in, denies report that machine guns were used to kill dozens\n\nDr. A.C. Jackson was killed as he tried to surrender in his front yard\n\nDeath toll remains unknown; search for graves continues today\n\nBlack Tulsans were marched through the streets and detained at camps throughout city\n\nRed Cross reports the massive devastation in Greenwood\n\nKey locations in Tulsa during the 1921 Race Massacre\n\nMount Zion Baptist Church was burned down but, like Greenwood, persevered and rebuilt\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Quotes from survivors, officials and others\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Recommended reading\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Was 1921 the first aerial assault on U.S. soil?\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\n"The first time Americans were terrorized by an aerial assault was not Pearl Harbor," a CBS News story says leading up to coverage this weekend of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.\n\n"Scott Pelley reports on a race massacre in which an estimated 300 people, mostly African American men, women and children, were killed, and aircraft were used to drop incendiary devices on a black neighborhood in Tulsa, Oklahoma. The Greenwood Massacre of 1921 has been largely ignored by history, but Pelley finds a Tulsa community seeking to shed more light on what\'s been called the worst race massacre in history," a preview reads for a "60 Minutes" story airing 6 p.m. Sunday on CBS.\n\nContext for viewers: Six airplanes circled the Greenwood area during the morning hours of June 1.\n\nWhat they were doing, and why there were so many, has long been a matter of passionate debate. Many people believe they were used to shoot at people on the ground and bomb Greenwood.\n\nOfficials said the small craft, generally thought to be two-seat, single-engine Curtis "Jenny" biplanes, were merely keeping track of activities on the ground and relaying the information through written messages dropped in weighted metal cylinders attached to streamers.\n\nTo what extent this explanation was initially challenged is unclear, but in October 1921 the Chicago Defender published a story in which it said Greenwood had been bombed under orders of "prominent city officials."\n\nThe story cited a Van B. Hurley, who the newspaper said had given a signed statement to Elisha Scott, a Kansas attorney.\n\nScott filed dozens of lawsuits on behalf of victims but doesn\'t seem to have ever entered the Hurley affidavit into the record. There is no record of a Van B. Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance. Many people believed city officials were behind the burning of Greenwood, and the explanation that the squadron of planes was only used for surveillance struck some as suspiciously thin.\n\nCertainly the planes had a great psychological impact on many. For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. It is also highly unstable and dangerous.\n\nThat has caused some to speculate that something like Molotov cocktails might have been used, or "turpentine balls" -- rags soaked in flammable liquid and wrapped around the head of a stick.\n\nThere are several practical reasons why trying to light and throw incendiary devices from an open cockpit airplane of that era would seem a difficult, dangerous and even foolish idea.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean it wasn\'t done.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921', 'source': {'uri': 'muscatinejournal.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Muscatine Journal'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'tulsa_world@muscatinejournal.com', 'name': 'Tulsa World', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/muscatinejournal.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/f/e1/fe1cb434-fdab-5367-b40e-18eeb3abef17/66919e3b3fc85.preview.jpg?crop=1764%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9728812', 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458516166, 'relevance': 31}
{'uri': '2024-07-420238094', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '20:59:15', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T20:59:15Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T20:56:31Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.47843137383461, 'url': 'https://thegrio.com/2024/07/12/is-serena-finally-getting-style-right-or-are-we-looking-at-it-all-wrong/', 'title': "Is Serena 'finally' getting style right, or are we looking at it all wrong?", 'body': 'Win or lose, whatever we think of Serena Williams\' personal style likely says more about us than her.\n\nWhen Serena Williams stepped onto the red carpet of the ESPY Awards in a sleek black and gold Armani gown and a shoulder-grazing wavy blonde bob that matched the gown\'s sparkling décolletage, Black women were ready with their critiques.\n\n"Yes, she got the assignment right!" wrote one commenter in response to a Facebook post showcasing the look. Others posted memes and GIFs proclaiming "FINALLY!," "It\'s about time," and "continuous improvement."\n\nAnother simply conceded, "This is the OK-ish I seen her in a while..."\n\nWilliams\' famous friends may have been full of compliments as the sports phenom prepared to host ESPN\'s annual awards ceremony on Thursday night (where she donned an array of other looks), but intensive discourse over her beauty and fashion choices is ongoing. In recent months, there has been an uptick in criticism from TikTok fashion pundits and commenters, largely disparaging the tennis legend\'s personal style. Everything from her glam squad to ignorance of what works for her body or skin tone has been under indictment, with some even suggesting she is emulating a white woman. That these critiques have come almost exclusively from Black women adds a striking and nuanced layer to the conversation.\n\n"...[Me] saying that she looks a goddamn mess is not rooted in colorism and misogyny," stated TikTok user @themedusashow in a May 7 post. "While it may not be constructive, it is a valid critique."\n\nFellow influencer @politicsandfashion immediately cosigned the sentiment, saying, "[@themedusashow] just said the thing that a lot of us have been thinking and we have been unwilling to say.\n\n"At the risk of sounding like it\'s coming from a place of internalized misogynoir, I don\'t think that we hold people accountable for the teams that they have around them, because at this point, Serena Williams, you\'re choosing violence," she continued. "At this point, you are too wealthy to be choosing to look like that. I don\'t think I know a celebrity whose glam is always off like that."\n\nAs these posts and others have garnered mass consensus, it\'s fair to say the critiques struck a chord. But while the instinct may be rooted in wanting the best for our good sis Serena, is the criticism as constructive as it claims to be?\n\n"It is 100% constructive criticism from within the black female community that is coming from a good place," wrote a commenter in defense of @politicsandfashion\'s post. "They\'re not saying \'You look awful, haha\', it\'s more \'You deserve and have earned to look your most beautiful, and the team you have surrounded yourself with is letting you down\'."\n\nWhether or not Williams was listening has become the latest topic of conversation, as her recent appearances at this year\'s Essence Fest -- and now, the ESPYS -- have been met with a far more affirmative response.\n\n"It says she don\'t want to hear y\'all talk about her no more..." sang TikTokker @nowletsbeforreal on Monday against a collage of Williams\' festival looks. "We gotta give it to her, y\'all," said TikTokker @amanduuuhplease in a post titled "This is how Serena Williams always should\'ve been styled." "[Williams] went back to the drawing board, she took our notes...and she showed us."\n\nOn the surface, it\'s cute and clickable content -- but good or bad, is it really anyone\'s place to publicly police Williams\' fashion choices or looks? As this for-Black-women-by-Black-women discourse has dominated our timelines in recent days, the Black women of theGrio\'s Lifestyle team weighed in with some critiques of our own.\n\nHaniyah Philogene, Staff Writer\n\nOne of the best yet often unspoken norms of womanhood is fixing another woman\'s hair if it\'s out of place -- or signaling her to adjust her dress because her bra strap is showing. It\'s representative of what social media calls a "girl\'s girl"; in other words, a woman who looks out for and supports other women.\n\nSo, when it comes to the discourse surrounding Serena Williams, part of me believes these creators who so readily offer their critiques think they are simply looking out for Williams. Maybe the possibility of the tennis star or a member of her glam team seeing their videos and implementing some of these changes fueled them to start these discussions -- or maybe they are simply baiting the hook to see if anyone else shares their sentiments. Regardless of their intentions, these videos nevertheless feed into the unfortunate scrutiny Black women en masse face surrounding their appearance.\n\nBeing a Black woman can often feel like you\'re living under a microscope; if we\'re not being judged about our hair, we\'re being judged about our bodies, and the list goes on. Bearing that constant criticism, paired with an ever-changing landscape of trends and what\'s deemed "acceptable," it\'s almost as if Black women are constantly expected to keep up in a never-ending race. But unfortunately, keeping up with norms leaves little room to step out of the box.\n\nWhether social media has deemed a specific look a victory or a loss, Williams has already said she\'s loved all of her fashion choices over the years because they represent her self-expression.\n\n"I think being on worst-dressed lists is important," she said, per People magazine. "Fashion is a way to express yourself and express your personality and...who you are and what you are -- and sometimes it\'s the only way the world can see you is through your style. And so for me, whether it\'s the best list or the worst-dressed list, it\'s all kind of cool."\n\nUltimately, like most people, Williams is experimenting with different styles and looks. She just happens to be an award-winning athlete doing it in front of millions of people who feel entitled to broadcast their opinions about her looks. While this discourse may be intended to be constructive criticism offered with love from one Black woman to another, using a public platform to garner online consensus about another Black woman\'s looks risks doing more harm than good.\n\nRecommended Stories\n\nWhether you loved her Essence Fest looks and her ESPYS glam or not, to say Williams has had consistent issues with her style is disingenuous. If you Google "Serena Williams\' style," you will find that since the start of her tennis career, she has been equally known for boundary-pushing glam on and off the court. She had all the girls wanting to put beads back in their braids in the \'90s. She rocked glorious weaves in the early aughts. She had a buss-down wavy ombre brown ponytail with her edges laid in the 2010s. In competition, she would dazzle the crowds at match after match with sleek, coordinated kits.\n\nAlongside her sister Venus, Serena\'s athletic prowess and penchant for style have earned her clothing and beauty lines, fashion campaigns and magazine covers. If not walking the runway for shows like Vogue World, the red carpet to accept a CFDA Fashion Icon Award, or co-chairing the Met Gala, she can be found in the front row during Fashion Week. This is clearly an arena she enjoys.\n\nRegardless of all of that, if you think someone consistently shows up one way, you are seeing a chosen aesthetic. Some recent critics have been correct in noting that, as a multimillionaire, Williams has access to top fashion and glam squads. So, that should then lead most to assume she is making deliberate choices -- and whether or not you like them, she does. It\'s also possible some of her detractors are working through their own limited imaginations about what a Black woman\'s fashion and style could and should look like. While it\'s true that fashion and personal style can be powerful tools when wielded correctly, ultimately, beauty is in the eye of the beholder -- or in this case, the wearer.\n\nWhy should we expect all the world\'s Black notable women to dress exactly the same, with their hair exactly the same and their glam exactly the same? While Williams may be expected to represent Black women of her complexion or with athletic body types, she shouldn\'t really have to. No one sees Reese Witherspoon and thinks, "She has got to show up better for blonde white women!" Let white people think a few famous Black people represent us. Let\'s just let famous Black women live.\n\nThere\'s not much to say that my colleagues haven\'t already, except if you\'re old enough to remember the genesis of the Williams sisters\' careers, you no doubt also recall that they have never lived up to anyone\'s expectations. They defied them. And after nearly 30 years of scrutiny and insults -- including being compared to men and monkeys -- that has largely had nothing to do with the paradigm-shifting talent she brought to the game of tennis, the truth is, Serena Williams owes us nothing. That so many of us want her to represent the way we think she should, only to critique any and every effort she makes to define her own aesthetic, ironically flies in the face of what she does represent: unparalleled greatness most of us can only dream about.\n\nAs Black women, we are not obligated or entitled to like Serena\'s personal style -- or even to champion her latest endeavors in the beauty and fashion industries. As the saying goes, everything ain\'t for everybody; similarly, every celebrity line ain\'t a winner (ahem, House of Deréon). While we can claim to have the best of intentions, when we engage in this specific discourse, what we largely ignore is that, beyond personal preferences and aesthetics, we\'re participating in a larger narrative that insists Black women can\'t afford to get it wrong. We can\'t afford to experiment or to play, or to straight up screw up sometimes. (Never mind the fact if any of us were to review a montage of our looks from the last 20 or even two years, we might find there were more misses than hits.)\n\nBut if anyone can afford to take those risks, even if they do get it "wrong" by someone else\'s measure, isn\'t it someone who has already defied the odds? Has Serena not already given us enough inspo for a lifetime?\n\nIs Serena Williams my personal fashion icon? No. She doesn\'t need to be. But just like so many of us were rooting for her on every court she stepped onto, maybe we can just support her right to play, win or lose.', 'source': {'uri': 'thegrio.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'TheGrio'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'thegrio_lifestyle@thegrio.com', 'name': 'theGrio Lifestyle', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://thegrio.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/GettyImages-2161691970-e1720809945779.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9720686', 'sentiment': 0.1843137254901961, 'wgt': 458513955, 'relevance': 6}
{'uri': '8222885157', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '20:58:14', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T20:58:14Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T20:57:40Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://pantagraph.com/sports/local/adaptability-and-devotion-send-boody-native-meridian-graduate-lauren-doyle-to-third-olympics/article_d3e8d6e1-5c56-5025-85e3-1430439e3076.html', 'title': 'Adaptability and devotion send Boody native, Meridian graduate Lauren Doyle to third Olympics', 'body': 'DECATUR -- For the past couple of years, the U.S. women\'s rugby team has done a good job of keeping one of its top veterans around.\n\nLauren Doyle, a Meridian High School graduate and Eastern Illinois University Athletics Hall of Famer, was considering retirement around the time of the 2020 Olympic games. Each time she thought she was done, her teammates pulled her back in for another major tournament. After the Tokyo Olympics, they got her to commit to sticking with the team for next year\'s World Cup.\n\nThen, after that, they got her to stay an extra year for the Pan American Games, a top regional tournament that also is an Olympic qualifying tournament. The U.S. and Doyle won the gold medal to qualify for this summer\'s Paris Olympics, so Doyle decided she\'d stick around for that as well.\n\n"Excellent. Now it\'s like, \'OK, now you\'re only about 10 months out from the Olympics, you\'ve got to stick around,\'" Doyle said. "That little bit of a vicious cycle, it\'s how I stayed around. I don\'t know if it would have been any different if the Olympics actually would have been in 2020. I might have hung up the boots back in 2020. COVID has worked in mysterious ways for me."\n\nPeople are also reading... Man found dead behind the wheel of vehicle on Veterans Parkway, police say Body pulled from Illinois River identified as Bloomington teen Bloomington man jailed on weapons, drug charges after traffic stop Flick Fact: How many State Farm employees are college educated? Bloomington woman faces DUI in crash that killed her 8-year-old son LaSalle County man dies in illegal fireworks incident Felon held by armed resident in Macon County gets 2 years 8-year-old boy dies after Wednesday night crash on I-74 Flick Fact: The $800M ex-farm girl from Stanford and Olympia High? Pub II marking 50th anniversary with party in uptown Normal Revolution Dispensary to host grand opening Friday in Normal Man found unresponsive in Bloomington had suffered medical event, police said Behind the Pritzker administration\'s quest to signal Illinois is \'open for business\' Opening statements begin in trial of man accused of killing teen at NYE party in Normal Bloomington police investigating shots fired Wednesday night\n\nDoyle\'s third Olympics start on July 28 when the U.S. faces Japan in women\'s rugby sevens at 9:30 a.m. at Stade de France in Paris. The U.S. will later play Brazil and France in pool play before it attempts to get its first medal in rugby.\n\nHer longevity in what has historically been one of the most physically taxing sports since it was invented in the early 1800s came from a love for the sport and a willingness to adapt.\n\nRugby sevens was introduced at the 2016 Olympics in Rio and Doyle has been a fixture on the US teams for each of its appearances at the past two games. This year she\'lll be an American co-captain heading into this summer\'s games in Paris. During her 12-year international career, she\'s become a fixture for the Americans at the sevens level.\n\n"What\'s kept me in is the absolute constant challenge that it brings every single year -- especially since I\'ve been around for so long -- when you look at how much the game has evolved, how fast it has become and how much you have to think about it," Doyle said.\n\nDoyle had options to try track in college but wanted something different after being burned out from the sport. When Eastern Illinois offered a chance to play college rugby, she jumped at it.\n\n"I was like, \'Well, Mom, I\'m playing rugby,\'" Doyle said. "She was like, \'What the hell?\'"\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nShe got hooked ever since her first game in college. She didn\'t fully grasp all the complicated rules, including offsides, and got a couple of penalties along with some tries -- the rugby equivalent of a touchdown in football -- during her first competitive match as a college freshman. She quickly figured out the intricacies of the game and used her speed to excel.\n\nThe rush of weaving around opponents or scurrying past opponents for a try was something she didn\'t experience as a local track star.\n\n"I just dove right into it. I really liked learning a new sport," Doyle said. "I feel like in America, there\'s not really a lot of ball-in-hand, running around people ... there\'s not really that football option for girls. So it just felt like I had unlocked this other side of me that I had never been able to express."\n\nAfter her college matches at EIU, she\'d watch as much rugby as she could to learn new types of play and strategies. Her speed got her into the door, and then on the radar of the U.S. National Team, but the knowledge she gained of the sport allowed her to stick. She now co-hosts a podcast that breaks down all levels of American rugby with longtime teammate Kristi Kirshe called "Chasing Eagles."\n\n"The more styles of play that you see, the more it kind of starts to make more sense in your head," Doyle said. "The more pictures that you can see on film, the more that you can see them in practice or in games and execute them better. That\'s mainly what I did."\n\nDoyle started with the U.S. team as a winger, a position with speed on the edge of the formation, but became a well-rounded player who\'s switched positions on multiple occasions and now plays mostly as the flyhalf in the middle of the American\'s formation calling plays and facilitating.\n\nThat versatility allowed her to build an international athletic resume that would\'ve been foreign to the teenager who tried out any sport she could in Central Illinois.\n\n"I don\'t even know if I had an Olympic dream necessarily," Doyle said. "When I was a kid, I obviously always thought those people were insanely talented and just like in awe, mainly of the gymnasts. I don\'t know if I\'ve ever thought it was actually attainable."\n\nNow she\'s a well-traveled Olympic veteran. Doyle had never been out of the country before she joined Team USA, and now she\'s gotten her passport filled from participating in multiple World Cups, Olympics and Pan American Games. She\'s been everywhere from Rio de Janeiro to Dubai and has played in major tournaments on five continents.\n\n"I\'m totally honored and blessed to have been a part of this program, and to have gone to those big stages," Doyle said. "And, it\'s also all the things that it\'s taught me about myself, and how to handle those situations and stay calm and composed."\n\nOlympic Women\'s Rugby Sevens\n\nWHEN: July 28-30\n\nWHERE: Stade de France, Paris\n\nHOW IT WORKS: Pool play begins July 28, with the U.S. opening against Japan at 9:30 a.m., then playing Brazil at 1 p.m. Pool play continues July 29, with the U.S. playing France at 8:30 a.m., then quarterfinals. Semifinals and medals matches will take place July 30.\n\nOF NOTE: The U.S. will compete in Pool C. ... The U.S. made the knockout stage in 2016 but lost to eventual silver medalist New Zealand in the first round. ... Australia won the gold in 2016, with Canada earning bronze. ... In 2020, the U.S. again advanced to the knockout stage but lost in the first round, this time to Great Britain. ... New Zealand took the gold in 2020, with France winning silver and Fiji taking bronze.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '8222859023', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '20:29:20', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T20:29:20Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T20:28:45Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://napavalleyregister.com/sports/johnny-miller-champ-junior-championship-golf-silverado-resort-and-spa/article_77c39ef6-4085-11ef-82a4-bf1c38120320.html', 'title': "Junior Golf: Fairfield's Lee, Fresno's Abduraup win Johnny Miller tournament", 'body': 'Jack Keller watches a tee shot during the Johnny Miller Champ Junior Championship at Silverado Resort and Spa on Thursday.\n\nMARTY JAMES\n\nThere were all kinds of challenges facing the players, boys and girls ages 12 to 18, in the final round of the Johnny Miller "Champ" Junior Championship on Thursday at Silverado Resort and Spa.\n\nThere was the brutally hot and extreme weather, with afternoon temperatures soaring to 104 degrees and an unrelenting sun.\n\nThere was the difficulty of navigating your way around the par-72 North Course, a PGA Tour venue that is known for its overall length, rough, bunkering, tight fairways and super-tough greens.\n\nNone of this stopped Sophia Lee and Yasser Aziz Abduraup.\n\nThey won overall titles in their respective divisions in the two-day, 36-hole Junior Golf Association of Northern California premier tournament, which began on Wednesday.\n\nLee, who is from Fairfield, won the girls overall title, shooting an even-par 72 on the South Course in the first round and following that up with an even-par 72 in the second round on Thursday.\n\nPeople are also reading... A Napa teen was killed by gun violence. Her life inspired a scholarship. Ryan Seacrest\'s Napa County home up for sale at $22 million $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Document at center of Supervisor Ramos\' restraining order found in public filings Judge considers vacating temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos St. Helena Cyclery to reopen in wake of Trek\'s closure Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 Napa judge declines to remove temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos Supervisor Belia Ramos files court documents alleging harassment Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life Napa\'s first Fourth of July drone show takes to the sky amid mixed feelings Fire hazards and federal subpoenas: Questions continue to swirl around Clover Flat Landfill Napa Farmers Market: There\'s always a place for you at the market Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Manslaughter case over cyclist couple killed in Napa moves forward\n\n"I made sure to really focus on every shot. And I played well both days. So, it was really fun playing out here. Both of these courses are really tough to play, so I played pretty conservatively," said Lee, a 2024 graduate of Visions in Education University Preparatory Academy. "I\'m just trying to hit the fairways, hit the greens, two-putt for par, and just not getting greedy out there. I think that\'s a big thing. Don\'t try to go for everything. Sometimes it\'s good to just lay up and get your par."\n\nIt\'s the second straight year in which Lee, 17, has won the girls overall title.\n\n"It definitely means a lot. Coming in (Wednesday), I really wanted to win this event because I won it last year and I felt like I could do it," said Lee, who plays out of Rancho Solano Golf Course and Paradise Valley Golf Course in Fairfield.\n\nAlso playing well was Abduraup, a resident of Fresno, who will be a junior this fall at Clovis West High School. He shot a 1-under-par 71 on the South Course and a 4-over-par 75 on the North Course to win the boys overall title.\n\n"This is my first time ever winning a tournament, so it\'s just surreal. I can\'t really believe it," said Abduraup, 16, who plays out of Fort Washington Golf and Country Club. "I knew that (Wednesday) I came prepared and I was like, \'I\'m going to do my best. I\'m just going to play golf. And I\'m going to enjoy the course.\' Because it\'s a privilege playing here at Silverado.\n\n"And after carding a 71, I was like, \'I\'m ready for the North Course. And no matter what, golf is just a game,\' and that I want to enjoy my time on the course."\n\nJGANC flags were also presented to Lee and Abduraup.\n\nThe Johnny Miller "Champ" Junior Championship, a sold-out event with a waiting list, had a field of 84 players. There are divisions for boys 12-13, 14-15 and 16-18, and girls 12-13, 14-15 and 16-18.\n\nThe field included two Napa players - Jack Sennott and Jack Keller.\n\nJohnny Miller, a 25-time PGA Tour champion and World Golf Hall of Fame member, was on hand to present awards, which featured Scotty Cameron putters to the overall and top division finishers, along with plaques.\n\nThanks to the support of the Johnny Miller "Champ" Foundation, the cost is just $25 per player, an entry fee that includes two days of golf and lunch.\n\n"We look forward to it every year. We have it on our schedule every year. It sells out in less than an hour," said Shane Balfour, Executive Director of the JGANC, who is a member of the PGA of America and a Class A golf professional. "For those who do get in, it\'s a wonderful two days for them. It\'s great fun. And, of course, having Mr. Miller here to say hello and present some really nice prizes to the kids is great.\n\n"You couldn\'t ask for more, from the standpoint of enjoying the two days here. Silverado, obviously, speaks for itself with two world-class golf courses, one hosting a PGA Tour event. They get to see the golf course that they\'re going to see the Tour players play at."\n\nThe Johnny Miller Junior Golf Foundation was founded in 1993. The foundation, which promotes junior golf, was renamed the Johnny Miller "Champ" Foundation in 2015, honoring Miller\'s father, Larry Otto Miller.\n\nMiller won two majors, the 1973 U.S. Open and 1976 Open Championship. He was the PGA Tour Player of the Year in 1974. He was with NBC Sports for 29 years as the lead golf analyst, retiring in 2019.\n\n"That\'s the idea of the foundation - that we\'re able to get all sorts of kids into playing golf," said Miller\'s son, Andy Miller, a Justin-Siena High graduate and a four-time NCAA All-American in college at BYU. Andy also played on the PGA Tour and is in the BYU Hall of Fame.\n\n"It\'s done so much for me and so much for my dad. We\'re just doing our best to try to give back and give other people that same opportunity - if they want to play golf, that it\'s there. We offer scholarships for lessons. Thanks to so many generous donors, we have the ability to give these boys and girls an opportunity to play one of the best courses in the world.\n\n"We\'re just trying to promote junior golf in Napa anyway we can."\n\nJohnny Miller is a former co-owner at Silverado and has been a sponsor of junior golf for many years in Northern California.\n\n"I loved junior golf, and that\'s why we have our foundation, to help junior golf and also high school golf, and with my son, Andy, we\'re able to do that," said Johnny Miller, who also works as a golf course designer. "It\'s fun to have them out here at Silverado and see how they can do on a on a PGA Tour course. The North Course is a good championship course. It\'s a good test.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"They all seem to be enjoying the tournament and enjoying being up here."\n\nMiller played out of Silverado during his PGA Tour career and in 2011 re-designed the North Course.\n\nThere was a heat advisory, according to the U.S. National Weather Service and accuweather.com, for the North Bay Interior Valleys, from Wednesday, July 10, at 11 a.m., to Friday, July 12, at 8 p.m.\n\nAccording to its website, jganc.bluegolf.com, the Junior Golf Association of Northern California, a nonprofit, offers a "variety of fun, competitive, affordable junior golf tournaments for boys and girls ages 7 to 18."\n\nJGANC tournaments are held throughout Northern California at a public, semi-private and private courses.\n\n"I love seeing all these kids out here," said Andy Miller. "There\'s going to be some winners. But at the end of the day, it\'s just cool to see all these kids out here playing golf. It\'s cool to give everyone that opportunity to come out here on a course the PGA Tour players play and to test their game, where the best in the world play."\n\nLee got it going early in her round, with birdies on the third, fourth and fifth holes.\n\n"I set myself up for pretty good approach shots, and I just had those numbers pretty dialed in. So, I was able to make those birdies," said Lee.\n\n"I\'ve been playing this tournament since I was 12. Ever since I was little, I was like, \'One day I want to win this tournament.\' I won it last year, and that was really exciting. So, I figured, \'OK, I won it once. I think I could do it again.\' "\n\nLee also holed out of a greenside bunker for birdie from 20 yards on the 18th hole.\n\n"I knew that I had to land it pretty softly, and it just rolled right in," she said.\n\nLee recently played in the First Tee National Championship, June 25-27, at Clemson University\'s Walker Course, in Clemson, South Carolina.\n\nLee is planning to take a gap year to focus on golf, and then will start college in 2025 at Sacramento State, as she joins in the women\'s golf team.\n\n"I just feel like this gap year is just to take the time to prepare to play on the Sac State team," she said. "Golf is a continuous process. So as a golfer, I\'m never content about where my game is at. I just feel like there\'s always that something that I need to work on."\n\nIt was Abduraup\'s first time playing Silverado\'s courses. He made sure to look at his yardage book and to be smart about his club selection.\n\n"I was thinking about what type of shot I really have to hit on this hole, what\'s the smart play, being prudent. I think that really helps with both courses because they\'re really, really challenging. It\'s all just about placement," he said.\n\nSennott was second in the boys 14-15 division, shooting 75-76 - 151.\n\n"It\'s nice to be back at home, getting back on the home track. I left a little bit out there, but it\'s always nice getting a second-place finish," said Sennott, who will be a sophomore this fall at Justin-Siena.\n\n"The greens are rolling quickly and the rough is thick. So, it was tough, and I like it that way.\n\n"It was hot weather out there. But I felt like I fought hard. I felt like I struck the ball. I think I gave it a good fight and I played well."\n\nKeller, who will be a junior in the fall at Justin-Siena, finished ninth in the boys 16-18 division, shooting 77-75 - 152.\n\nThe top finishers in each division:\n\n* Boys 16-18 division: Yasser Aziz Abduraup, 71-75 - 146; Christopher Woody, 73-74 - 147; Jacob Burnett, 72-75 - 147; Eli Slifer, 79-70 - 149.\n\n* Boys 14-15 division: Reid Bulman, 71-78 - 149; Jack Sennott, 75-76 - 151; Tyler Kalfsbeek, 76-77 - 153.\n\n* Boys 12-13 division: Stefano Castaneda, 75-85 - 160; Taejun Kim, 81-81 - 162; Kheean Nathoo, 81-82 - 163.\n\n* Girls 12-13 division: Audrey Yang, 77-81 - 158; Suri Lau, 83-78 - 161; Danica Hidayat, 80-82 - 162.\n\n* Girls 14-15 division: Giana Main, 77-77 - 154; Khloe Chao, 83-76 - 159; Lauren Lee, 77-82 - 159; Angelina Santiago, 80-79 - 159.\n\n* Girls 16-18 division: Sophia Lee, 72-72 - 144; Esther Sheu, 79-78 - 157; Hannah Stouder, 80-78 - 158.\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'napavalleyregister.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Napa Valley Register'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'marty_james_napasports@napavalleyregister.com', 'name': 'Marty James Napasports', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/napavalleyregister.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/40/940b987c-4088-11ef-915e-237f5baf7627/66918df881730.image.jpg?crop=1700%2C893%2C3%2C49&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.07450980392156858, 'wgt': 458512160, 'relevance': 26}
{'uri': '2024-07-420210166', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '20:11:21', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T20:11:21Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T19:30:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7372549176216125, 'url': 'https://journalstar.com/news/nation-world/crime-courts/updated-wwi-veteran-first-identified-victim-of-tulsa-race-massacre/article_ac2513ba-609e-51f2-b0e7-b8488bbadec3.html', 'title': 'Updated: WWI veteran first identified victim of Tulsa Race Massacre', 'body': 'Randy Krehbiel Tulsa World\n\nA partially disabled World War I veteran trying to get home to his mother has been identified as a 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre victim buried anonymously in the city\'s Oaklawn Cemetery, researchers and Mayor G.T. Bynum said Friday.\n\nC.L. Daniel, a Georgia native whose name had never before come to the attention of Race Massacre researchers, is the first person identified through a project launched five years ago by Mayor G.T. Bynum to find unmarked burials from the May 31-June 1 calamity in which more than 35 square blocks of Tulsa\'s Black Greenwood District were destroyed by whites and dozens and perhaps hundreds of people were killed.\n\nDNA comparisons, genealogical research and two letters in the National Archives led Intermountain Forensics, a firm working with the city, to Daniel. The DNA and genealogy narrowed the search to two brothers with that last name.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nUnfinished Marshbanks mansion, barndominium near Lincoln listed for record price \'Grateful and excited\': Megan Conway finds a landing anchor chair at 10/11 in Lincoln Matt Rhule\'s \'right-hand man\' leaves Nebraska football\'s coaching staff Big Chicken restaurant, founded by NBA star Shaquille O\'Neal, is coming to Omaha Social media influencer Cam Wilder draws more than 1,000 to Lincoln park Long-vacant southeast Lincoln corner slated for commercial development Lincoln man shot and killed Friday night in business parking lot Crete, Nebraska: 7 shot in \'welcoming community\' by neighbor who \'hated everybody\' Soft-serve survivors: How Zesto endured in Nebraska after its ice-cream empire melted Lincoln police identify victim, provide details from Friday night shooting 48-year-old man dies in west Lincoln motorcycle crash Nebraska lawmakers \'bewildered\' as Gov. Pillen\'s \'high risk\' special session nears Report: NFL coach emerges as Nebraska\'s potential replacement for Evan Cooper Lincoln police asking for help to find woman who\'s been missing for two weeks Downtown Lincoln facelift: Corridor enchantment plan prioritizes pedestrians\n\nOne of the letters, a 1936 missive from a Georgia attorney to the U.S. Veterans Administration on behalf of Daniel\'s mother, identified C.L. as almost certainly the occupant of what archeologists denote as Burial #3 in the old Black paupers\' section of Oaklawn.\n\nThe letter, from Stanford Arnold of Newnan, Georgia, on behalf of Amanda Daniel, seeks "any benefits that be due her" because of her son\'s service and honorable discharge because of injury.\n\n"She has no discharge (papers) and is going to have difficulty in establishing his death," Arnold wrote. "C.L. was killed in a race riot in Tulsa Oklahoma in 1921 according to best information she has furnished me."\n\nIt is unclear whether the VA responded or if Amanda Daniel, who the lawyer described as "in destitute circumstances," received any assistance.\n\nThe National Archives search also produced a letter written by C.L. Daniel, apparently to the Army, in February 1921 from Ogden, Utah. In poignant language, Daniel says his legs pain him, apparently from an injury suffered in the Army, and make finding work difficult. Daniel says he spent 19 days in the Camp Gordon, Georgia, hospital.\n\n"(F)or some time I have traveled this country over and now sufriend (suffering) with complance (complaints) that (I) was in the base hospitle (hospital) with," Daniel wrote, his spelling and grammar a testament to the sort of education many Americans and especially Black Americans received in the early 20th century. "(D)ear sir, please send me a nof (enough) money to git me a job and to eat with till I Get better."\n\nDaniel\'s burial place was among the first uncovered in 2020 by the team headed by state archeologist Kary Stackelbeck and University of Florida forensic anthropologist Phoebe Stubblefield. Its proximity to headstones of two known massacre victims, Reuben Everett and Eddie Lockard, and to an area in which other remains similarly buried, make the researchers reasonably certain they have found the "original 18" -- 18 Black massacre victims reported at the time to have been buried in Oaklawn Cemetery, but without information about their exact location -- and two sets of remains with signs of gunshot wounds.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nStubblefield said a cause of death could not be determined for Daniel, whose remains were exhumed in 2021 and later reinterred in the same grave. She said it appeared the body had been scrunched into a coffin too small for him.\n\nBynum indicated Daniel\'s family, whose members were not identified, have not decided how they want to proceed with final burial.\n\n"We\'re going to work with them every step of the way," Bynum said. "Whatever they decide to do with the remains, the city of Tulsa is fully supportive of that."\n\nDaniel\'s identification accounts for one of several of Original 18 listed on death certificates as "unknown." It has also has reinvigorated the project.\n\nAt Friday\'s press conference, Bynum said the archeological team will return to Oaklawn on July 22. Stackelbeck indicated this phase will last more than a week and concentrate on the Original 18 area.\n\n"We now feel doubly confident of the criteria we\'ve been using to know which ones are good candidates for exhumation," she said.\n\nDanny Hellwig, director of Intermountain\'s Laboratory Development, said Daniel\'s identification is really the first of its kind.\n\n"This hasn\'t really been done before," Hellwig said. "We\'ve been learning through the process. As we\'ve learned and adapted, we\'re getting better at it. ... We hope this will provide some confidence and context and maybe a lot more trust so that we can expand on this."\n\nIdentification relies on voluntarily submitted DNA, public databases and families\' willingness to answer questions about relatives or ancestors.\n\nIn Daniel\'s case, researchers said, extended family members were mostly unaware of the circumstances of his death, if they knew of him at all. Intermountain\'s Alison Wilde, who handles the genealogical side, said many living family members did not know each other, much less the story of a great uncle who died without direct descendants more than a century ago.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nIn 1921, white mobs invaded Greenwood and burned it down\n\nA growing but divided city had tensions rising. How World War I influenced residents.\n\nKey figures in 1921\n\nGreenwood was defined by freedom and opportunity\n\nAn encounter on an elevator and concerns about a lynching\n\nTulsa Tribune article cited for sparking massacre\n\nDick Rowland\'s life threatened while jailed as crowd gathers outside\n\nTulsans take up arms and there are issues with special deputies\n\nFighting begins in Greenwood and the neighborhood is soon overrun\n\nMobs won\'t let firefighters douse the flames\n\nAirplanes flew over Greenwood as it was attacked\n\nNational Guard called in, denies report that machine guns were used to kill dozens\n\nDr. A.C. Jackson was killed as he tried to surrender in his front yard\n\nDeath toll remains unknown; search for graves continues today\n\nBlack Tulsans were marched through the streets and detained at camps throughout city\n\nRed Cross reports the massive devastation in Greenwood\n\nKey locations in Tulsa during the 1921 Race Massacre\n\nMount Zion Baptist Church was burned down but, like Greenwood, persevered and rebuilt\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Quotes from survivors, officials and others\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Recommended reading\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Was 1921 the first aerial assault on U.S. soil?\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\n"The first time Americans were terrorized by an aerial assault was not Pearl Harbor," a CBS News story says leading up to coverage this weekend of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.\n\n"Scott Pelley reports on a race massacre in which an estimated 300 people, mostly African American men, women and children, were killed, and aircraft were used to drop incendiary devices on a black neighborhood in Tulsa, Oklahoma. The Greenwood Massacre of 1921 has been largely ignored by history, but Pelley finds a Tulsa community seeking to shed more light on what\'s been called the worst race massacre in history," a preview reads for a "60 Minutes" story airing 6 p.m. Sunday on CBS.\n\nContext for viewers: Six airplanes circled the Greenwood area during the morning hours of June 1.\n\nWhat they were doing, and why there were so many, has long been a matter of passionate debate. Many people believe they were used to shoot at people on the ground and bomb Greenwood.\n\nOfficials said the small craft, generally thought to be two-seat, single-engine Curtis "Jenny" biplanes, were merely keeping track of activities on the ground and relaying the information through written messages dropped in weighted metal cylinders attached to streamers.\n\nTo what extent this explanation was initially challenged is unclear, but in October 1921 the Chicago Defender published a story in which it said Greenwood had been bombed under orders of "prominent city officials."\n\nThe story cited a Van B. Hurley, who the newspaper said had given a signed statement to Elisha Scott, a Kansas attorney.\n\nScott filed dozens of lawsuits on behalf of victims but doesn\'t seem to have ever entered the Hurley affidavit into the record. There is no record of a Van B. Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance. Many people believed city officials were behind the burning of Greenwood, and the explanation that the squadron of planes was only used for surveillance struck some as suspiciously thin.\n\nCertainly the planes had a great psychological impact on many. For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. It is also highly unstable and dangerous.\n\nThat has caused some to speculate that something like Molotov cocktails might have been used, or "turpentine balls" -- rags soaked in flammable liquid and wrapped around the head of a stick.\n\nThere are several practical reasons why trying to light and throw incendiary devices from an open cockpit airplane of that era would seem a difficult, dangerous and even foolish idea.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean it wasn\'t done.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nrandy.krehbiel@tulsaworld.com\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'journalstar.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'JournalStar.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/journalstar.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/a/c2/ac2513ba-609e-51f2-b0e7-b8488bbadec3/6691889da3fcf.preview.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9728812', 'sentiment': -0.1764705882352942, 'wgt': 458511081, 'relevance': 31}

Daniel says he spent 19 days in the Camp Gordon, Georgia, hospital.\n\n"(F)or some time I have traveled this country over and now sufriend (suffering) with complance (complaints) that (I) was in the base hospitle (hospital) with," Daniel wrote, his spelling and grammar a testament to the sort of education many Americans and especially Black Americans received in the early 20th century. "(D)ear sir, please send me a nof (enough) money to git me a job and to eat with till I Get better."\n\nDaniel\'s burial place was among the first uncovered in 2020 by the team headed by state archeologist Kary Stackelbeck and University of Florida forensic anthropologist Phoebe Stubblefield. Its proximity to headstones of two known massacre victims, Reuben Everett and Eddie Lockard, and to an area in which other remains similarly buried, make the researchers reasonably certain they have found the "original 18" -- 18 Black massacre victims reported at the time to have been buried in Oaklawn Cemetery, but without information about their exact location -- and two sets of remains with signs of gunshot wounds.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nStubblefield said a cause of death could not be determined for Daniel, whose remains were exhumed in 2021 and later reinterred in the same grave. She said it appeared the body had been scrunched into a coffin too small for him.\n\nBynum indicated Daniel\'s family, whose members were not identified, have not decided how they want to proceed with final burial.\n\n"We\'re going to work with them every step of the way," Bynum said. "Whatever they decide to do with the remains, the city of Tulsa is fully supportive of that."\n\nDaniel\'s identification accounts for one of several of Original 18 listed on death certificates as "unknown." It has also has reinvigorated the project.\n\nAt Friday\'s press conference, Bynum said the archeological team will return to Oaklawn on July 22. Stackelbeck indicated this phase will last more than a week and concentrate on the Original 18 area.\n\n"We now feel doubly confident of the criteria we\'ve been using to know which ones are good candidates for exhumation," she said.\n\nDanny Hellwig, director of Intermountain\'s Laboratory Development, said Daniel\'s identification is really the first of its kind.\n\n"This hasn\'t really been done before," Hellwig said. "We\'ve been learning through the process. As we\'ve learned and adapted, we\'re getting better at it. ... We hope this will provide some confidence and context and maybe a lot more trust so that we can expand on this."\n\nIdentification relies on voluntarily submitted DNA, public databases and families\' willingness to answer questions about relatives or ancestors.\n\nIn Daniel\'s case, researchers said, extended family members were mostly unaware of the circumstances of his death, if they knew of him at all. Intermountain\'s Alison Wilde, who handles the genealogical side, said many living family members did not know each other, much less the story of a great uncle who died without direct descendants more than a century ago.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nIn 1921, white mobs invaded Greenwood and burned it down\n\nA growing but divided city had tensions rising. How World War I influenced residents.\n\nKey figures in 1921\n\nGreenwood was defined by freedom and opportunity\n\nAn encounter on an elevator and concerns about a lynching\n\nTulsa Tribune article cited for sparking massacre\n\nDick Rowland\'s life threatened while jailed as crowd gathers outside\n\nTulsans take up arms and there are issues with special deputies\n\nFighting begins in Greenwood and the neighborhood is soon overrun\n\nMobs won\'t let firefighters douse the flames\n\nAirplanes flew over Greenwood as it was attacked\n\nNational Guard called in, denies report that machine guns were used to kill dozens\n\nDr. A.C. Jackson was killed as he tried to surrender in his front yard\n\nDeath toll remains unknown; search for graves continues today\n\nBlack Tulsans were marched through the streets and detained at camps throughout city\n\nRed Cross reports the massive devastation in Greenwood\n\nKey locations in Tulsa during the 1921 Race Massacre\n\nMount Zion Baptist Church was burned down but, like Greenwood, persevered and rebuilt\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Quotes from survivors, officials and others\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Recommended reading\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Was 1921 the first aerial assault on U.S. soil?\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\n"The first time Americans were terrorized by an aerial assault was not Pearl Harbor," a CBS News story says leading up to coverage this weekend of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.\n\n"Scott Pelley reports on a race massacre in which an estimated 300 people, mostly African American men, women and children, were killed, and aircraft were used to drop incendiary devices on a black neighborhood in Tulsa, Oklahoma. The Greenwood Massacre of 1921 has been largely ignored by history, but Pelley finds a Tulsa community seeking to shed more light on what\'s been called the worst race massacre in history," a preview reads for a "60 Minutes" story airing 6 p.m. Sunday on CBS.\n\nContext for viewers: Six airplanes circled the Greenwood area during the morning hours of June 1.\n\nWhat they were doing, and why there were so many, has long been a matter of passionate debate. Many people believe they were used to shoot at people on the ground and bomb Greenwood.\n\nOfficials said the small craft, generally thought to be two-seat, single-engine Curtis "Jenny" biplanes, were merely keeping track of activities on the ground and relaying the information through written messages dropped in weighted metal cylinders attached to streamers.\n\nTo what extent this explanation was initially challenged is unclear, but in October 1921 the Chicago Defender published a story in which it said Greenwood had been bombed under orders of "prominent city officials."\n\nThe story cited a Van B. Hurley, who the newspaper said had given a signed statement to Elisha Scott, a Kansas attorney.\n\nScott filed dozens of lawsuits on behalf of victims but doesn\'t seem to have ever entered the Hurley affidavit into the record. There is no record of a Van B. Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance. Many people believed city officials were behind the burning of Greenwood, and the explanation that the squadron of planes was only used for surveillance struck some as suspiciously thin.\n\nCertainly the planes had a great psychological impact on many. For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. It is also highly unstable and dangerous.\n\nThat has caused some to speculate that something like Molotov cocktails might have been used, or "turpentine balls" -- rags soaked in flammable liquid and wrapped around the head of a stick.\n\nThere are several practical reasons why trying to light and throw incendiary devices from an open cockpit airplane of that era would seem a difficult, dangerous and even foolish idea.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean it wasn\'t done.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nrandy.krehbiel@tulsaworld.com\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'buffalonews.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Buffalo News'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/buffalonews.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/0/98/0985348e-850e-5fd9-be59-fe2f65c1a04d/6691889b15414.preview.jpg?crop=1763%2C926%2C0%2C124&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9728812', 'sentiment': -0.192156862745098, 'wgt': 458510905, 'relevance': 31}

It cut a paw after apparently leaning on a window and breaking it, officials said.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nNo one was injured.\n\nThe lion was tranquilized about 12:30 p.m. and was taken to the regional office of Arizona Game and Fish, said Michael Colaianni, an agency spokesman.\n\n"He\'s very healthy, which is great news," Colaianni said. {'uri': '2024-07-420204441', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '20:01:24', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T20:01:24Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T19:30:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7490196228027344, 'url': 'https://www.stltoday.com/news/nation-world/crime-courts/first-victim-of-tulsa-race-massacre-identified-as-wwi-vet-through-genealogy-dna-research/article_f57108f1-6d58-5548-bac5-538fcc073555.html', 'title': 'First victim of Tulsa Race Massacre identified as WWI vet through genealogy, DNA research', 'body': 'The family of CL Daniel had no knowledge of how to find his remains for 103 years, Bynum said July 12.\n\nOKLAHOMA CITY -- A World War I veteran is the first person identified from graves filled with more than a hundred victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre of the city\'s Black community, the mayor said Friday.\n\nTulsa Mayor G.T. Bynum made the announcement Friday along with the genealogist team leader from Intermountain Forensics.\n\nThe victim in what became known as "burial 3" is World War I veteran C. L. Daniel of Newnan, Georgia. He was injured and on his way home to Georgia from Utah when his 1921 stop in Tulsa became fatal, genealogist Alison Wilde said the team learned. Daniel had no direct descendants, but his brothers did, she said.\n\n"His connection to the Tulsa Race Massacre was confirmed this week when Intermountain Forensics, the laboratory assisting the City with DNA and genealogical analysis, was able to recover records from the National Archives," a city news release states. "Contained in the records was the most convincing piece of evidence tying him to the Tulsa Race Massacre -- a letter from C. L.\'s family attorney written to the U.S. Veterans Administration on behalf of C. L.\'s mother regarding C. L.\'s survivor benefits."\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nPi Pizzeria closing last remaining location, in St. Louis\' Central West End TV show \'Bar Rescue\' making over a St. Clair restaurant McClellan: Downtown St. Louis is a casualty of the do-gooder war Tropical Storm Beryl could hit St. Louis area with 4 inches of rain or more Wentzville schools investigated board members for alleged retaliation, ethics violations BenFred: Why Jordan Walker\'s name will provide hot-stove fodder as Cardinals near trade deadline St. Louis area to get another Shake Shack St. Louis County Library opens its largest branch with 3D printers, play towns and more Messenger: She sold her house to help support her baby. Missouri\'s AG wants the money. Homeless camp grows on private land in St. Louis. Neighbors want city to take action. Manchester police chief put on administrative leave pending investigation \'A business decision\': Parson defends pulling state workers out of downtown St. Louis Lars Nootbaar wondered about his spate of injuries, too. So he sought answers: Cardinals Extra Frank Cusumano heads to KTRS for news-talk radio show with Wendy Wiese July 4 chaos reignites safety concerns in downtown St. Louis. Chief blames \'small\' group.\n\nThe letter from Daniel\'s mother, noting he was killed in Tulsa in 1921, "confirms that C. L., whose next of kin share a significant portion of their DNA with Burial 3, is a Tulsa Race Massacre victim not previously identified."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"As genealogists, our daily work centers on families and communities," Wilde said. "I know I speak for everyone at Intermountain Forensics, and our genealogy partners, when I say we are continually humbled by the Greenwood and Tulsa Race Massacre descendant communities, as they protect the history of, and serve as guardians of, the unknown victims of the Tulsa Race Massacre. Today the family members of Mr. C. L. Daniel join those communities. I am confident his next of kin, and the memory of their loved one, are in good hands."\n\nRecords show Daniel, a Black male in his 20s, was drafted to the U.S. Army in 1918 and discharged in December 1919. It is unclear why Daniel was in Tulsa, the team notes.\n\nDaniel\'s remains are the first from those graves to be linked directly to the massacre, in which white people killed as many as many as 300 Black people.\n\nThe massacre began when a white mob, including some deputized by authorities, looted and burned Tulsa\'s Greenwood District, also known as Black Wall Street. More than 1,200 homes, businesses, schools and churches were destroyed; and thousands were forced into internment camps overseen by the National Guard.\n\nOklahoma state archaeologist Kary Stackelbeck said the remains that were exhumed, including Daniel, were found in simple wooden boxes. Stackelbeck said investigators were searching for those types of caskets because they were described in newspaper articles at the time, death certificates, and funeral home records as the type used for burials of massacre victims.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nIn 1921, white mobs invaded Greenwood and burned it down\n\nA growing but divided city had tensions rising. The Greenwood Massacre of 1921 has been largely ignored by history, but Pelley finds a Tulsa community seeking to shed more light on what\'s been called the worst race massacre in history," a preview reads for a "60 Minutes" story airing 6 p.m. Sunday on CBS.\n\nContext for viewers: Six airplanes circled the Greenwood area during the morning hours of June 1.\n\nWhat they were doing, and why there were so many, has long been a matter of passionate debate. Many people believe they were used to shoot at people on the ground and bomb Greenwood.\n\nOfficials said the small craft, generally thought to be two-seat, single-engine Curtis "Jenny" biplanes, were merely keeping track of activities on the ground and relaying the information through written messages dropped in weighted metal cylinders attached to streamers.\n\nTo what extent this explanation was initially challenged is unclear, but in October 1921 the Chicago Defender published a story in which it said Greenwood had been bombed under orders of "prominent city officials."\n\nThe story cited a Van B. Hurley, who the newspaper said had given a signed statement to Elisha Scott, a Kansas attorney.\n\nScott filed dozens of lawsuits on behalf of victims but doesn\'t seem to have ever entered the Hurley affidavit into the record. There is no record of a Van B. Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance. Many people believed city officials were behind the burning of Greenwood, and the explanation that the squadron of planes was only used for surveillance struck some as suspiciously thin.\n\nCertainly the planes had a great psychological impact on many. For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance.
