For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. It is also highly unstable and dangerous.\n\nThat has caused some to speculate that something like Molotov cocktails might have been used, or "turpentine balls" -- rags soaked in flammable liquid and wrapped around the head of a stick.\n\nThere are several practical reasons why trying to light and throw incendiary devices from an open cockpit airplane of that era would seem a difficult, dangerous and even foolish idea.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean it wasn\'t done.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nmike.simons@tulsaworld.com\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'siouxcityjournal.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Sioux City Journal'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/siouxcityjournal.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/7/27/7272196e-2927-5eae-84d5-dcdd7618bcfc/6691777679d37.preview.jpg?crop=1625%2C853%2C2%2C54&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9728812', 'sentiment': -0.2549019607843137, 'wgt': 458509916, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '2024-07-420194854', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '19:45:41', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T19:45:41Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T19:30:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://magicvalley.com/news/nation-world/crime-courts/first-victim-of-tulsa-race-massacre-identified-as-wwi-vet-through-genealogy-dna-research/article_95ff6bfc-f359-5d8e-a86c-f5aab1e5b911.html', 'title': 'First victim of Tulsa Race Massacre identified as WWI vet through genealogy, DNA research', 'body': 'The family of CL Daniel had no knowledge of how to find his remains for 103 years, Bynum said July 12.\n\nOKLAHOMA CITY -- A World War I veteran is the first person identified from graves filled with more than a hundred victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre of the city\'s Black community, the mayor said Friday.\n\nTulsa Mayor G.T. Bynum made the announcement Friday along with the genealogist team leader from Intermountain Forensics.\n\nThe victim in what became known as "burial 3" is World War I veteran C. L. Daniel of Newnan, Georgia. He was injured and on his way home to Georgia from Utah when his 1921 stop in Tulsa became fatal, genealogist Alison Wilde said the team learned. Daniel had no direct descendants, but his brothers did, she said.\n\n"His connection to the Tulsa Race Massacre was confirmed this week when Intermountain Forensics, the laboratory assisting the City with DNA and genealogical analysis, was able to recover records from the National Archives," a city news release states. "Contained in the records was the most convincing piece of evidence tying him to the Tulsa Race Massacre -- a letter from C. L.\'s family attorney written to the U.S. Veterans Administration on behalf of C. L.\'s mother regarding C. L.\'s survivor benefits."\n\nThe letter from Daniel\'s mother, noting he was killed in Tulsa in 1921, "confirms that C. L., whose next of kin share a significant portion of their DNA with Burial 3, is a Tulsa Race Massacre victim not previously identified."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"As genealogists, our daily work centers on families and communities," Wilde said. "I know I speak for everyone at Intermountain Forensics, and our genealogy partners, when I say we are continually humbled by the Greenwood and Tulsa Race Massacre descendant communities, as they protect the history of, and serve as guardians of, the unknown victims of the Tulsa Race Massacre. Today the family members of Mr. C. L. Daniel join those communities. I am confident his next of kin, and the memory of their loved one, are in good hands."\n\nRecords show Daniel, a Black male in his 20s, was drafted to the U.S. Army in 1918 and discharged in December 1919. It is unclear why Daniel was in Tulsa, the team notes.\n\nDaniel\'s remains are the first from those graves to be linked directly to the massacre, in which white people killed as many as many as 300 Black people.\n\nThe massacre began when a white mob, including some deputized by authorities, looted and burned Tulsa\'s Greenwood District, also known as Black Wall Street. More than 1,200 homes, businesses, schools and churches were destroyed; and thousands were forced into internment camps overseen by the National Guard.\n\nOklahoma state archaeologist Kary Stackelbeck said the remains that were exhumed, including Daniel, were found in simple wooden boxes. Stackelbeck said investigators were searching for those types of caskets because they were described in newspaper articles at the time, death certificates, and funeral home records as the type used for burials of massacre victims.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nIn 1921, white mobs invaded Greenwood and burned it down\n\nA growing but divided city had tensions rising. How World War I influenced residents.\n\nKey figures in 1921\n\nGreenwood was defined by freedom and opportunity\n\nAn encounter on an elevator and concerns about a lynching\n\nTulsa Tribune article cited for sparking massacre\n\nDick Rowland\'s life threatened while jailed as crowd gathers outside\n\nTulsans take up arms and there are issues with special deputies\n\nFighting begins in Greenwood and the neighborhood is soon overrun\n\nMobs won\'t let firefighters douse the flames\n\nAirplanes flew over Greenwood as it was attacked\n\nNational Guard called in, denies report that machine guns were used to kill dozens\n\nDr. A.C. Jackson was killed as he tried to surrender in his front yard\n\nDeath toll remains unknown; search for graves continues today\n\nBlack Tulsans were marched through the streets and detained at camps throughout city\n\nRed Cross reports the massive devastation in Greenwood\n\nKey locations in Tulsa during the 1921 Race Massacre\n\nMount Zion Baptist Church was burned down but, like Greenwood, persevered and rebuilt\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Quotes from survivors, officials and others\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Recommended reading\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Was 1921 the first aerial assault on U.S. soil?\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\n"The first time Americans were terrorized by an aerial assault was not Pearl Harbor," a CBS News story says leading up to coverage this weekend of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.\n\n"Scott Pelley reports on a race massacre in which an estimated 300 people, mostly African American men, women and children, were killed, and aircraft were used to drop incendiary devices on a black neighborhood in Tulsa, Oklahoma. The Greenwood Massacre of 1921 has been largely ignored by history, but Pelley finds a Tulsa community seeking to shed more light on what\'s been called the worst race massacre in history," a preview reads for a "60 Minutes" story airing 6 p.m. Sunday on CBS.\n\nContext for viewers: Six airplanes circled the Greenwood area during the morning hours of June 1.\n\nWhat they were doing, and why there were so many, has long been a matter of passionate debate. Many people believe they were used to shoot at people on the ground and bomb Greenwood.\n\nOfficials said the small craft, generally thought to be two-seat, single-engine Curtis "Jenny" biplanes, were merely keeping track of activities on the ground and relaying the information through written messages dropped in weighted metal cylinders attached to streamers.\n\nTo what extent this explanation was initially challenged is unclear, but in October 1921 the Chicago Defender published a story in which it said Greenwood had been bombed under orders of "prominent city officials."\n\nThe story cited a Van B. Hurley, who the newspaper said had given a signed statement to Elisha Scott, a Kansas attorney.\n\nScott filed dozens of lawsuits on behalf of victims but doesn\'t seem to have ever entered the Hurley affidavit into the record. There is no record of a Van B. Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance. Many people believed city officials were behind the burning of Greenwood, and the explanation that the squadron of planes was only used for surveillance struck some as suspiciously thin.\n\nCertainly the planes had a great psychological impact on many. For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. It is also highly unstable and dangerous.\n\nThat has caused some to speculate that something like Molotov cocktails might have been used, or "turpentine balls" -- rags soaked in flammable liquid and wrapped around the head of a stick.\n\nThere are several practical reasons why trying to light and throw incendiary devices from an open cockpit airplane of that era would seem a difficult, dangerous and even foolish idea.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean it wasn\'t done.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921', 'source': {'uri': 'magicvalley.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Magic Valley'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/magicvalley.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/5f/95ff6bfc-f359-5d8e-a86c-f5aab1e5b911/669177725cf4e.preview.jpg?crop=1625%2C853%2C2%2C54&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.3098039215686275, 'wgt': 458509541, 'relevance': 56}

The Greenwood Massacre of 1921 has been largely ignored by history, but Pelley finds a Tulsa community seeking to shed more light on what\'s been called the worst race massacre in history," a preview reads for a "60 Minutes" story airing 6 p.m. Sunday on CBS.\n\nContext for viewers: Six airplanes circled the Greenwood area during the morning hours of June 1.\n\nWhat they were doing, and why there were so many, has long been a matter of passionate debate. Many people believe they were used to shoot at people on the ground and bomb Greenwood.\n\nOfficials said the small craft, generally thought to be two-seat, single-engine Curtis "Jenny" biplanes, were merely keeping track of activities on the ground and relaying the information through written messages dropped in weighted metal cylinders attached to streamers.\n\nTo what extent this explanation was initially challenged is unclear, but in October 1921 the Chicago Defender published a story in which it said Greenwood had been bombed under orders of "prominent city officials."\n\nThe story cited a Van B. Hurley, who the newspaper said had given a signed statement to Elisha Scott, a Kansas attorney.\n\nScott filed dozens of lawsuits on behalf of victims but doesn\'t seem to have ever entered the Hurley affidavit into the record. There is no record of a Van B. Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance. Many people believed city officials were behind the burning of Greenwood, and the explanation that the squadron of planes was only used for surveillance struck some as suspiciously thin.\n\nCertainly the planes had a great psychological impact on many. For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. It is also highly unstable and dangerous.\n\nThat has caused some to speculate that something like Molotov cocktails might have been used, or "turpentine balls" -- rags soaked in flammable liquid and wrapped around the head of a stick.\n\nThere are several practical reasons why trying to light and throw incendiary devices from an open cockpit airplane of that era would seem a difficult, dangerous and even foolish idea.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean it wasn\'t done.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nmike.simons@tulsaworld.com\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'lacrossetribune.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'La Crosse Tribune'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/lacrossetribune.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/0/d1/0d1b0ee0-2204-5bf5-9cf9-757c4dd93308/6691777232921.preview.jpg?crop=1625%2C853%2C2%2C54&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9728812', 'sentiment': -0.1843137254901961, 'wgt': 458509307, 'relevance': 51}

Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance. For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. It is also highly unstable and dangerous.\n\nThat has caused some to speculate that something like Molotov cocktails might have been used, or "turpentine balls" -- rags soaked in flammable liquid and wrapped around the head of a stick.\n\nThere are several practical reasons why trying to light and throw incendiary devices from an open cockpit airplane of that era would seem a difficult, dangerous and even foolish idea.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean it wasn\'t done.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nmike.simons@tulsaworld.com\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'pantagraph.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'pantagraph.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/pantagraph.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/6/fa/6fa4de5e-74d4-5aee-8ede-8a7c3730da3e/6691777510a7c.preview.jpg?crop=1625%2C853%2C2%2C54&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9728812', 'sentiment': -0.3568627450980392, 'wgt': 458509264, 'relevance': 51}
{'uri': '8222810336', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '19:40:00', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T19:40:00Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T19:39:25Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.6941176652908325, 'url': 'https://napavalleyregister.com/news/nation-world/crime-courts/first-victim-of-tulsa-race-massacre-identified-as-wwi-vet-through-genealogy-dna-research/article_cad3cbfb-8f26-5a70-b035-237b86bfddc0.html', 'title': 'First victim of Tulsa Race Massacre identified as WWI vet through genealogy, DNA research', 'body': 'OKLAHOMA CITY -- A World War I veteran is the first person identified from graves filled with more than a hundred victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre of the city\'s Black community, the mayor said Friday.\n\nTulsa Mayor G.T. Bynum made the announcement Friday along with the genealogist team leader from Intermountain Forensics.\n\nThe victim in what became known as "burial 3" is World War I veteran C. L. Daniel of Newnan, Georgia. He was injured and on his way home to Georgia from Utah when his 1921 stop in Tulsa became fatal, genealogist Alison Wilde said the team learned. Daniel had no direct descendants, but his brothers did, she said.\n\n"His connection to the Tulsa Race Massacre was confirmed this week when Intermountain Forensics, the laboratory assisting the City with DNA and genealogical analysis, was able to recover records from the National Archives," a city news release states. "Contained in the records was the most convincing piece of evidence tying him to the Tulsa Race Massacre -- a letter from C. L.\'s family attorney written to the U.S. Veterans Administration on behalf of C. L.\'s mother regarding C. L.\'s survivor benefits."\n\nPeople are also reading... A Napa teen was killed by gun violence. Her life inspired a scholarship. Ryan Seacrest\'s Napa County home up for sale at $22 million $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Document at center of Supervisor Ramos\' restraining order found in public filings Judge considers vacating temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos St. Helena Cyclery to reopen in wake of Trek\'s closure Hank McGraw, onetime baseball phenom turned maverick and late-life Napan, dead at 81 Napa judge declines to remove temporary restraining order obtained by Supervisor Belia Ramos Supervisor Belia Ramos files court documents alleging harassment Napa High School Athletic Hall of Fame: Cabral learned from sports how to battle adversity in life Napa\'s first Fourth of July drone show takes to the sky amid mixed feelings Fire hazards and federal subpoenas: Questions continue to swirl around Clover Flat Landfill Napa Farmers Market: There\'s always a place for you at the market Mount Veeder vineyard owners sue own lawyers over money tied to Tubbs Fire Manslaughter case over cyclist couple killed in Napa moves forward\n\nThe letter from Daniel\'s mother, noting he was killed in Tulsa in 1921, "confirms that C. L., whose next of kin share a significant portion of their DNA with Burial 3, is a Tulsa Race Massacre victim not previously identified."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"As genealogists, our daily work centers on families and communities," Wilde said. "I know I speak for everyone at Intermountain Forensics, and our genealogy partners, when I say we are continually humbled by the Greenwood and Tulsa Race Massacre descendant communities, as they protect the history of, and serve as guardians of, the unknown victims of the Tulsa Race Massacre. Today the family members of Mr. C. L. Daniel join those communities. I am confident his next of kin, and the memory of their loved one, are in good hands."\n\nRecords show Daniel, a Black male in his 20s, was drafted to the U.S. Army in 1918 and discharged in December 1919. It is unclear why Daniel was in Tulsa, the team notes.\n\nDaniel\'s remains are the first from those graves to be linked directly to the massacre, in which white people killed as many as many as 300 Black people.\n\nThe massacre began when a white mob, including some deputized by authorities, looted and burned Tulsa\'s Greenwood District, also known as Black Wall Street. More than 1,200 homes, businesses, schools and churches were destroyed; and thousands were forced into internment camps overseen by the National Guard.\n\nOklahoma state archaeologist Kary Stackelbeck said the remains that were exhumed, including Daniel, were found in simple wooden boxes. Stackelbeck said investigators were searching for those types of caskets because they were described in newspaper articles at the time, death certificates, and funeral home records as the type used for burials of massacre victims.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921 In 1921, white mobs invaded Greenwood and burned it down A growing but divided city had tensions rising. How World War I influenced residents. Key figures in 1921 Greenwood was defined by freedom and opportunity An encounter on an elevator and concerns about a lynching Tulsa Tribune article cited for sparking massacre Dick Rowland\'s life threatened while jailed as crowd gathers outside Tulsans take up arms and there are issues with special deputies Fighting begins in Greenwood and the neighborhood is soon overrun Mobs won\'t let firefighters douse the flames Airplanes flew over Greenwood as it was attacked National Guard called in, denies report that machine guns were used to kill dozens Dr. A.C. Jackson was killed as he tried to surrender in his front yard Death toll remains unknown; search for graves continues today Black Tulsans were marched through the streets and detained at camps throughout city Red Cross reports the massive devastation in Greenwood Key locations in Tulsa during the 1921 Race Massacre Mount Zion Baptist Church was burned down but, like Greenwood, persevered and rebuilt Tulsa Race Massacre: Quotes from survivors, officials and others Tulsa Race Massacre: Recommended reading Tulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library Tulsa Race Massacre: Was 1921 the first aerial assault on U.S. soil?\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\n"The first time Americans were terrorized by an aerial assault was not Pearl Harbor," a CBS News story says leading up to coverage this weekend of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.\n\n"Scott Pelley reports on a race massacre in which an estimated 300 people, mostly African American men, women and children, were killed, and aircraft were used to drop incendiary devices on a black neighborhood in Tulsa, Oklahoma. The Greenwood Massacre of 1921 has been largely ignored by history, but Pelley finds a Tulsa community seeking to shed more light on what\'s been called the worst race massacre in history," a preview reads for a "60 Minutes" story airing 6 p.m. Sunday on CBS.\n\nContext for viewers: Six airplanes circled the Greenwood area during the morning hours of June 1.\n\nWhat they were doing, and why there were so many, has long been a matter of passionate debate. Many people believe they were used to shoot at people on the ground and bomb Greenwood.\n\nOfficials said the small craft, generally thought to be two-seat, single-engine Curtis "Jenny" biplanes, were merely keeping track of activities on the ground and relaying the information through written messages dropped in weighted metal cylinders attached to streamers.\n\nTo what extent this explanation was initially challenged is unclear, but in October 1921 the Chicago Defender published a story in which it said Greenwood had been bombed under orders of "prominent city officials."\n\nThe story cited a Van B. Hurley, who the newspaper said had given a signed statement to Elisha Scott, a Kansas attorney.\n\nScott filed dozens of lawsuits on behalf of victims but doesn\'t seem to have ever entered the Hurley affidavit into the record. There is no record of a Van B. Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance. Many people believed city officials were behind the burning of Greenwood, and the explanation that the squadron of planes was only used for surveillance struck some as suspiciously thin.\n\nCertainly the planes had a great psychological impact on many. For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. It is also highly unstable and dangerous.\n\nThat has caused some to speculate that something like Molotov cocktails might have been used, or "turpentine balls" -- rags soaked in flammable liquid and wrapped around the head of a stick.\n\nThere are several practical reasons why trying to light and throw incendiary devices from an open cockpit airplane of that era would seem a difficult, dangerous and even foolish idea.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean it wasn\'t done.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nmike.simons@tulsaworld.com\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'napavalleyregister.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Napa Valley Register'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/napavalleyregister.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/c/ad/cad3cbfb-8f26-5a70-b035-237b86bfddc0/6691777394900.preview.jpg?crop=1625%2C853%2C2%2C54&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9728812', 'sentiment': -0.2235294117647059, 'wgt': 458509200, 'relevance': 51}

{'uri': '2024-07-420188560', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '19:35:40', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T19:35:40Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T19:30:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7529411911964417, 'url': 'https://omaha.com/news/nation-world/crime-courts/first-victim-of-tulsa-race-massacre-identified-as-wwi-vet-through-genealogy-dna-research/article_8f0f20db-d17d-507c-85cd-ba85ffba5ee2.html', 'title': 'First victim of Tulsa Race Massacre identified as WWI vet through genealogy, DNA research', 'body': 'The family of CL Daniel had no knowledge of how to find his remains for 103 years, Bynum said July 12.\n\nOKLAHOMA CITY -- A World War I veteran is the first person identified from graves filled with more than a hundred victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre of the city\'s Black community, the mayor said Friday.\n\nTulsa Mayor G.T. Bynum made the announcement Friday along with the genealogist team leader from Intermountain Forensics.\n\nThe victim in what became known as "burial 3" is World War I veteran C. L. Daniel of Newnan, Georgia. He was injured and on his way home to Georgia from Utah when his 1921 stop in Tulsa became fatal, genealogist Alison Wilde said the team learned. Daniel had no direct descendants, but his brothers did, she said.\n\n"His connection to the Tulsa Race Massacre was confirmed this week when Intermountain Forensics, the laboratory assisting the City with DNA and genealogical analysis, was able to recover records from the National Archives," a city news release states. "Contained in the records was the most convincing piece of evidence tying him to the Tulsa Race Massacre -- a letter from C. L.\'s family attorney written to the U.S. Veterans Administration on behalf of C. L.\'s mother regarding C. L.\'s survivor benefits."\n\nThe letter from Daniel\'s mother, noting he was killed in Tulsa in 1921, "confirms that C. L., whose next of kin share a significant portion of their DNA with Burial 3, is a Tulsa Race Massacre victim not previously identified."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"As genealogists, our daily work centers on families and communities," Wilde said. "I know I speak for everyone at Intermountain Forensics, and our genealogy partners, when I say we are continually humbled by the Greenwood and Tulsa Race Massacre descendant communities, as they protect the history of, and serve as guardians of, the unknown victims of the Tulsa Race Massacre. Today the family members of Mr. C. L. Daniel join those communities. I am confident his next of kin, and the memory of their loved one, are in good hands."\n\nRecords show Daniel, a Black male in his 20s, was drafted to the U.S. Army in 1918 and discharged in December 1919. It is unclear why Daniel was in Tulsa, the team notes.\n\nDaniel\'s remains are the first from those graves to be linked directly to the massacre, in which white people killed as many as many as 300 Black people.\n\nThe massacre began when a white mob, including some deputized by authorities, looted and burned Tulsa\'s Greenwood District, also known as Black Wall Street. More than 1,200 homes, businesses, schools and churches were destroyed; and thousands were forced into internment camps overseen by the National Guard.\n\nOklahoma state archaeologist Kary Stackelbeck said the remains that were exhumed, including Daniel, were found in simple wooden boxes. Stackelbeck said investigators were searching for those types of caskets because they were described in newspaper articles at the time, death certificates, and funeral home records as the type used for burials of massacre victims.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nIn 1921, white mobs invaded Greenwood and burned it down\n\nA growing but divided city had tensions rising. The Greenwood Massacre of 1921 has been largely ignored by history, but Pelley finds a Tulsa community seeking to shed more light on what\'s been called the worst race massacre in history," a preview reads for a "60 Minutes" story airing 6 p.m. Sunday on CBS.\n\nContext for viewers: Six airplanes circled the Greenwood area during the morning hours of June 1.\n\nWhat they were doing, and why there were so many, has long been a matter of passionate debate. Many people believe they were used to shoot at people on the ground and bomb Greenwood.\n\nOfficials said the small craft, generally thought to be two-seat, single-engine Curtis "Jenny" biplanes, were merely keeping track of activities on the ground and relaying the information through written messages dropped in weighted metal cylinders attached to streamers.\n\nTo what extent this explanation was initially challenged is unclear, but in October 1921 the Chicago Defender published a story in which it said Greenwood had been bombed under orders of "prominent city officials."\n\nThe story cited a Van B. Hurley, who the newspaper said had given a signed statement to Elisha Scott, a Kansas attorney.\n\nScott filed dozens of lawsuits on behalf of victims but doesn\'t seem to have ever entered the Hurley affidavit into the record. There is no record of a Van B. Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance. Many people believed city officials were behind the burning of Greenwood, and the explanation that the squadron of planes was only used for surveillance struck some as suspiciously thin.\n\nCertainly the planes had a great psychological impact on many. For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. It is also highly unstable and dangerous.\n\nThat has caused some to speculate that something like Molotov cocktails might have been used, or "turpentine balls" -- rags soaked in flammable liquid and wrapped around the head of a stick.\n\nThere are several practical reasons why trying to light and throw incendiary devices from an open cockpit airplane of that era would seem a difficult, dangerous and even foolish idea.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean it wasn\'t done.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921', 'source': {'uri': 'omaha.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Omaha.com'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/omaha.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/8/f0/8f0f20db-d17d-507c-85cd-ba85ffba5ee2/6691777535291.preview.jpg?crop=1625%2C853%2C2%2C54&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9728812', 'sentiment': -0.3098039215686275, 'wgt': 458508940, 'relevance': 56}
{'uri': '2024-07-420188144', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '19:34:40', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T19:34:40Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T19:30:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7411764860153198, 'url': 'https://www.nwitimes.com/news/nation-world/crime-courts/first-victim-of-tulsa-race-massacre-identified-as-wwi-vet-through-genealogy-dna-research/article_3f3c5a21-0647-5596-afbf-12fa26905c0b.html', 'title': 'First victim of Tulsa Race Massacre identified as WWI vet through genealogy, DNA research', 'body': 'The family of CL Daniel had no knowledge of how to find his remains for 103 years, Bynum said July 12.\n\nOKLAHOMA CITY -- A World War I veteran is the first person identified from graves filled with more than a hundred victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre of the city\'s Black community, the mayor said Friday.\n\nTulsa Mayor G.T. Bynum made the announcement Friday along with the genealogist team leader from Intermountain Forensics.\n\nThe victim in what became known as "burial 3" is World War I veteran C. L. Daniel of Newnan, Georgia. He was injured and on his way home to Georgia from Utah when his 1921 stop in Tulsa became fatal, genealogist Alison Wilde said the team learned. Daniel had no direct descendants, but his brothers did, she said.\n\n"His connection to the Tulsa Race Massacre was confirmed this week when Intermountain Forensics, the laboratory assisting the City with DNA and genealogical analysis, was able to recover records from the National Archives," a city news release states. "Contained in the records was the most convincing piece of evidence tying him to the Tulsa Race Massacre -- a letter from C. L.\'s family attorney written to the U.S. Veterans Administration on behalf of C. L.\'s mother regarding C. L.\'s survivor benefits."\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nGolden Corral in Merrillville reopens after closing in 2020 after then-franchisee\'s cold case arrest for Missouri murder 18-year-old dies in car crash on Fourth of July in Portage, police said Judge rejects plea in domestic shooting; man threatens to throw chair at judge NWI Business Ins and Outs: Taco Pros, Brass Idol, Red Zone Sports Bar, Windy City Pizza Kitchen, Sweet Circle, Starbucks, Alexander McQueen and Caribbean Roots opening; Evvy\'s Coffee and Deep Blue Seafood closing Cedar Lake man found dead while sitting in a pond, police say Dispensaries stacking up on Michigan border despite weed remaining illegal in Indiana New store opens at Southlake Mall Church\'s much-anticipated Harvest Square Strip Mall to have ribbon-cutting, bring \'services of suburbs\' to Gary Mother charged with neglect after 18-month-old overdoses Indiana Toll Road increases tolls 3 injured by runaway draft horse at LaPorte County Fair Twisted Sugar opens in Schererville Friday Inmate death at Porter County Jail ruled a suicide, officials say Hobart roundabout moving to phase two Latest alleged prison smuggling attempt involves cocaine, marijuana and lasagna\n\nThe letter from Daniel\'s mother, noting he was killed in Tulsa in 1921, "confirms that C. L., whose next of kin share a significant portion of their DNA with Burial 3, is a Tulsa Race Massacre victim not previously identified."\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"As genealogists, our daily work centers on families and communities," Wilde said. "I know I speak for everyone at Intermountain Forensics, and our genealogy partners, when I say we are continually humbled by the Greenwood and Tulsa Race Massacre descendant communities, as they protect the history of, and serve as guardians of, the unknown victims of the Tulsa Race Massacre. Today the family members of Mr. C. L. Daniel join those communities. I am confident his next of kin, and the memory of their loved one, are in good hands."\n\nRecords show Daniel, a Black male in his 20s, was drafted to the U.S. Army in 1918 and discharged in December 1919. It is unclear why Daniel was in Tulsa, the team notes.\n\nDaniel\'s remains are the first from those graves to be linked directly to the massacre, in which white people killed as many as many as 300 Black people.\n\nThe massacre began when a white mob, including some deputized by authorities, looted and burned Tulsa\'s Greenwood District, also known as Black Wall Street. More than 1,200 homes, businesses, schools and churches were destroyed; and thousands were forced into internment camps overseen by the National Guard.\n\nOklahoma state archaeologist Kary Stackelbeck said the remains that were exhumed, including Daniel, were found in simple wooden boxes. Stackelbeck said investigators were searching for those types of caskets because they were described in newspaper articles at the time, death certificates, and funeral home records as the type used for burials of massacre victims.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nIn 1921, white mobs invaded Greenwood and burned it down\n\nA growing but divided city had tensions rising. How World War I influenced residents.\n\nKey figures in 1921\n\nGreenwood was defined by freedom and opportunity\n\nAn encounter on an elevator and concerns about a lynching\n\nTulsa Tribune article cited for sparking massacre\n\nDick Rowland\'s life threatened while jailed as crowd gathers outside\n\nTulsans take up arms and there are issues with special deputies\n\nFighting begins in Greenwood and the neighborhood is soon overrun\n\nMobs won\'t let firefighters douse the flames\n\nAirplanes flew over Greenwood as it was attacked\n\nNational Guard called in, denies report that machine guns were used to kill dozens\n\nDr. A.C. Jackson was killed as he tried to surrender in his front yard\n\nDeath toll remains unknown; search for graves continues today\n\nBlack Tulsans were marched through the streets and detained at camps throughout city\n\nRed Cross reports the massive devastation in Greenwood\n\nKey locations in Tulsa during the 1921 Race Massacre\n\nMount Zion Baptist Church was burned down but, like Greenwood, persevered and rebuilt\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Quotes from survivors, officials and others\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Recommended reading\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: Was 1921 the first aerial assault on U.S. soil?\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\n"The first time Americans were terrorized by an aerial assault was not Pearl Harbor," a CBS News story says leading up to coverage this weekend of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.\n\n"Scott Pelley reports on a race massacre in which an estimated 300 people, mostly African American men, women and children, were killed, and aircraft were used to drop incendiary devices on a black neighborhood in Tulsa, Oklahoma. The Greenwood Massacre of 1921 has been largely ignored by history, but Pelley finds a Tulsa community seeking to shed more light on what\'s been called the worst race massacre in history," a preview reads for a "60 Minutes" story airing 6 p.m. Sunday on CBS.\n\nContext for viewers: Six airplanes circled the Greenwood area during the morning hours of June 1.\n\nWhat they were doing, and why there were so many, has long been a matter of passionate debate. Many people believe they were used to shoot at people on the ground and bomb Greenwood.\n\nOfficials said the small craft, generally thought to be two-seat, single-engine Curtis "Jenny" biplanes, were merely keeping track of activities on the ground and relaying the information through written messages dropped in weighted metal cylinders attached to streamers.\n\nTo what extent this explanation was initially challenged is unclear, but in October 1921 the Chicago Defender published a story in which it said Greenwood had been bombed under orders of "prominent city officials."\n\nThe story cited a Van B. Hurley, who the newspaper said had given a signed statement to Elisha Scott, a Kansas attorney.\n\nScott filed dozens of lawsuits on behalf of victims but doesn\'t seem to have ever entered the Hurley affidavit into the record. There is no record of a Van B. Hurley living in Tulsa around the time of the massacre or that anyone by that name ever belonged to the Tulsa police force.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean the story did not have substance. Many people believed city officials were behind the burning of Greenwood, and the explanation that the squadron of planes was only used for surveillance struck some as suspiciously thin.\n\nCertainly the planes had a great psychological impact on many. For example, Mary Jones Parrish wrote about them in her account, as did prominent attorney B.C. Franklin in his.\n\nThe Defender story said the planes dropped "nitroglycerin on buildings, setting them afire."\n\nBut nitroglycerin is an explosive, not an incendiary. It is also highly unstable and dangerous.\n\nThat has caused some to speculate that something like Molotov cocktails might have been used, or "turpentine balls" -- rags soaked in flammable liquid and wrapped around the head of a stick.\n\nThere are several practical reasons why trying to light and throw incendiary devices from an open cockpit airplane of that era would seem a difficult, dangerous and even foolish idea.\n\nBut that doesn\'t mean it wasn\'t done.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre / The Tulsa World Library: See all of the coverage of the race massacre in this special report.\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nTulsa Race Massacre: This is what happened in Tulsa in 1921\n\nmike.simons@tulsaworld.com\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'nwitimes.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'nwi.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'assets@nwitimes.com', 'name': 'assets', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}, {'uri': 'tncms@nwitimes.com', 'name': 'tncms', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/nwitimes.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/f3/3f3c5a21-0647-5596-afbf-12fa26905c0b/669177750655b.preview.jpg?crop=1625%2C853%2C2%2C54&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9728812', 'sentiment': -0.3098039215686275, 'wgt': 458508880, 'relevance': 31}

{'uri': '8222786111', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '19:13:46', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T19:13:46Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T19:13:23Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://nypost.com/2024/07/12/lifestyle/this-strip-club-has-a-ufo-on-its-roof-heres-why/', 'title': "This strip club has a UFO on its roof  --  here's the bizarre reason...", 'body': 'One strip club in Florida is out of this world -- and we\'re not talking about the dancers, either.\n\nTampa\'s aptly named 2001 Odyssey has become a genuine roadside attraction, thanks to the massive UFO -- complete with colorful lights at night -- sitting atop the building.\n\nThe club\'s website notes it has been featured in films like "The Punisher" and the skater video game "Tony Hawk\'s Underground."\n\nThe story of the elaborate piece of rooftop flair dates back to 1969 -- the same year Apollo 11 left Cape Canaveral for the moon -- when a Finnish designer introduced the idea of interstellar, 500 square-foot modular homes, designed to evoke an alien craft.\n\nThey came with a deployable door hatch, porthole-like windows, and all.\n\nBut the "Futuro" concept dreamed up by Matti Suuronen didn\'t land well with the public -- an underwhelming amount of units were sold stateside and the business folded in 1975, according to the Tampa Bay Times.\n\nStill, Florida Futuro sales manager Jerry DeLong wanted to believe in the concept, his son Bruce DeLong told the outlet.\n\nJerry was a diehard lover of the Stanley Kubrick masterpiece and, with partners, opened the strip club in the 1970s in tribute to Dave and HAL 9000.\n\nThey took the display model from a Clearwater site and painstakingly craned it onto the roof -- with the first try resulting in a wind gust slamming the ship into the building\'s side wall.\n\nNowadays, new ownership is at the helm of Odyssey -- DeLong became a Goodyear tire dealer after his partner got busted in a $1 million counterfeit cash scheme. The building continues to offer a glimpse of the future -- as imagined in 1971.\n\nA Google map peek inside shows a very antiquated, cramped main stage room with mirror ceilings, stiff metal chairs, some alien decor, and a neon carpet coveted by most bowling alleys.\n\nThere\'s also a charming neon sign for the bathroom that reads "The Pisser" -- right next to another "Make It Rain" one near an ATM that converts big bills into singles.\n\nThe interstellar enigma has been voted "#1 Full Nude Strip Club in Tampa Bay for 19 years running!" according to the club website, however the source of the award was unnamed.\n\nThe extraterrestrial theme has also been tried closer to home -- Long Island City-based gentlemen\'s club Gallagher\'s 2000 at one time leaned into the concept with a notorious late-night commercial involving aliens seeing all sides of our solar system.', 'source': {'uri': 'nypost.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'New York Post'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://nypost.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2024/07/newspress-collage-0jod0qexm-1720808198060.jpg?quality=75&strip=all&1720793842&w=1024', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.1215686274509804, 'wgt': 458507626, 'relevance': 26}
{'uri': '8222775007', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '19:04:21', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T19:04:21Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T19:03:51Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7215686440467834, 'url': 'https://richmond.com/sports/college/football/acc-clemson-stalemate-fsu/article_dd088ae8-407a-11ef-a120-479c1bf82d9c.html', 'title': "Legal stalemates continue as SC judge rules in Clemson's favor against ACC", 'body': "The judicial impasses among the ACC and its two leading football programs continued Friday as a South Carolina judge declined the conference's motions to stay or dismiss Clemson's April lawsuit challenging the league's exit fee and grant of media rights.\n\nAs reported from the Pickens County courtroom by Chapel Fowler of The State newspaper, Circuit Court Judge Perry Gravely ruled from the bench after a morning hearing. He said the ACC's business activities in South Carolina are prevalent enough that the conference can be sued in the state.\n\nGravely did dismiss Clemson's sovereign-immunity claim that a South Carolina public arm, such as a university, can't be sued outside the state.\n\nPeople are also reading... Kings Dominion gets approval to build new roller coaster New Richmond ballpark now has general contractors on the team 9-year-old boy drowns at Pony Pasture CEO of Virginia's technology authority resigns Richmond radio personality Kat Simons dies at 63 As farmers age out, future of the mythic Hanover tomato is uncertain Teel: New Richmond ballpark, Henrico arenas would defy odds The butterfly effect: Crozet teenager Thomas Heilman's journey to 2024 Paris Olympics Richmond best ice cream results, vote for the Final Four!🍧🍨 🍦 Crash on Pocahontas Parkway in Henrico kills Chesterfield woman Meet the 2024 All-Metro softball team, led by King William's Taylor Johnson Trump co-manager takes online shot at Virginia House speaker 2nd Richmond official in city's communications office had credit card suspended last year UVa alum, NFL vet Wali Rainer's sons following in his footsteps Here's what Warner and Kaine are saying about calls for Biden to withdraw\n\nGravely's ruling came two days after North Carolina Judge Louis Bledsoe said the ACC's countersuit against Clemson should continue in that state. The university filed a notice Thursday signaling its intention to appeal Bledsoe's decision to the North Carolina Supreme Court.\n\nFlorida State is appealing a similar Bledsoe opinion that the ACC's case against the Seminoles should remain in North Carolina. The conference preemptively sued FSU in December, one day before the university filed its complaint against the league in Florida.\n\nLeon County, Florida Circuit Court Judge John Cooper ruled last month that FSU v. ACC could be tried there.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nIn his written opinion Wednesday, Bledsoe suggested that the four actions -- Clemson v. ACC in South Carolina, Florida State v. ACC in Florida, ACC v. Clemson in North Carolina and ACC v. FSU in North Carolina -- be consolidated and heard in the Tar Heel State, home to league headquarters since its 1953 founding.\n\nHow the parties might resolve their stalemates and arrive at such a place is the great unknown, for at each procedural step, the home plaintiff has prevailed.\n\nFlorida State and Clemson are contesting the league's $130 million exit fee and grant of rights, a contract that conveys television rights to each member's home sports contests to the conference through the 2035-36 academic year. The schools want their cases tried separately in their respective home states.\n\nACC presidents and chancellors signed the league's original GOR in 2013 and an amended version in 2016, the latter document reflecting ESPN's agreement to create the ACC Network. But Clemson and Florida State, which have won a combined six national football championships, subsequently determined that the ACC's contract with ESPN, which also expires in 2036, does not pay them enough to compete with the wealthier Big Ten and SEC.\n\nTeel: Most important football season in ACC history on horizon\n\nThe schools' challenges to the grant of rights differ in that FSU seeks to invalidate the contract, while Clemson claims the grant holds only until a member departs the league.\n\nThe ACC and the University Maryland sued one another over the conference's exit fee in 2013 after the Terrapins revealed their intention to join the Big Ten. A Maryland judge deferred the matter to North Carolina, and the parties settled out of court.\n\nThe Terps paid $31.4 million, about 60% of the then-exit fee of $51.2 million.\n\nSports Week in Pictures: Wimbledon, Tour de France gain momentum\n\nDavid Teel (804) 649-6546\n\ndteel@timesdispatch.com\n\nDavid Teel\n\nSports Reporter\n\nAuthor twitter Author email Follow David Teel Close Get email notifications on {{subject}} daily! {'uri': '2024-07-420152182', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '18:41:23', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T18:41:23Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T18:30:12Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://gamerant.com/destiny-2-factions-feature-return-rework-good-why/', 'title': "It's Time for Destiny 2 to Take Another Shot at a Divisive Feature", 'body': "Highlights\n\nDestiny 2 failed to reestablish the excitement of factions, with players always gravitating towards the faction with the best rewards. The lack of engagement from the community led to factions being eventually removed from the game. However, now could be a good time for Destiny 2 to reintroduce factions with fresh twists, like new allies and different activities to keep players invested.\n\nFactions were one of the most exciting things about the original Destiny, bringing the community together in a way that almost no other activity could. By pledging allegiance to a particular faction in Destiny -- Future War Cult, New Monarchy, or Dead Orbit -- players could participate in activities to increase their rank with that faction and then reap unique rewards as a result. Each faction gave players access to powerful rewards along the track to max out their rank, eventually resulting in a unique Exotic class item they could wear to show off their faction pride. However, this is largely where this story ends, as Destiny 2 attempted to implement a faction system but failed to execute it properly.\n\nDestiny 2 reintroduced factions in its first year with week-long Faction Rallies, which saw players once again pledging allegiance to either Future War Cult, New Monarchy, or Dead Orbit and then earning a major discount on a powerful weapon. Unfortunately, since each faction only offered one weapon as a reward, players would simply find out which weapon was best and pledge to the faction that offered it, thereby defeating the purpose. Destiny 2 attempted to improve factions during the Warmind DLC with better rewards, but the entire system was eventually removed from the game due to a lack of engagement from the community. Now, several years later, there might be reason enough for factions to return to Destiny 2.\n\nRelated\n\nDestiny 2 Has The Perfect Blueprint For Prismatic Changes In Each Episode\n\nDestiny 2's Revenant and Heresy Episodes could shake up Prismatic subclasses with a few targeted changes.\n\nIt's Time for Destiny 2 to Bring Back Factions\n\nClose\n\nDestiny 2 Needs Regular Content Loops Like Factions Now More Than Ever\n\nDestiny 2 is hardly ever in need of more content, as it certainly has enough to keep players busy for months on end. However, the goal should never be to keep players busy but to have a content loop that is rewarding enough to keep players coming back. In its current state, there is more than enough content to keep casual players coming back for extended periods, but Destiny 2's hardcore community arguably runs that feeling of reward dry fairly quickly and is then in need of something new. Now, the recent announcement that Destiny 2's episodic acts will no longer be time-gated is a double-edged sword, as it allows players to play at their own pace but simultaneously takes even more incentive away for players to return to the game at regular intervals.\n\nGiven the current state of Destiny 2's regular content loops, it might need something like Faction Rallies again to keep players invested. Sure, it has activities like Iron Banner and Trials of Osiris that make regular appearances, but these only appeal to a certain portion of the Destiny 2 community. Additionally, Desitny 2's limited-time seasonal events, like the Dawning and the Solstice of Heroes, have all but worn out their welcome. Factions, on the other hand, might feel fresh enough to warrant extended playtime from players, especially if they are executed well.\n\nDestiny 2 Now Has a Chance to Reimagine Factions in The Final Shape\n\nTo prevent Destiny 2's faction system from feeling too antiquated or like nothing more than recycled content, they could be reimagined in The Final Shape with the Guardians' new allies. Each of Destiny's former factions either fled the Tower or was killed off, which gives credence to new factions forming in their stead. As such, perhaps some friendly Eliksni or Cabal could represent new factions to be allied with, along with their respective weapons and armor. Commander Zavala could even represent the Guardians as a faction to complete the triangle for the ultimate rivalry.\n\nThe Destiny 2 community has reined in their expectations for factions ever returning to the game, especially now with events like Guardian Games seemingly replacing them. That being said, Bungie has consistently proven that if the cry for a particular feature is loud enough, it will listen and respond accordingly.\n\nDestiny 2\n\nBungie's Destiny 2 is an online FPS that blends single-player and multiplayer content. Constantly evolving, the shooter has established a strong following since its 2017 debut.\n\nSystem Google , PC , PlayStation , Xbox\n\nPlatform(s) PS5 , PS4 , Xbox Series X , Xbox Series S , Xbox One , PC , Stadia\n\nReleased August 28, 2017\n\nDeveloper(s) Bungie\n\nPublisher(s) Bungie\n\nGenre(s) FPS\n\nMultiplayer Online Multiplayer , Online Co-Op\n\nEngine Tiger Engine\n\nESRB T For TEEN for Blood, Language, and Violence\n\nExpansions Destiny 2: Forsaken , Destiny 2: Shadowkeep , Destiny 2: Beyond Light , Destiny 2: The Witch Queen , Destiny 2: Lightfall\n\nHow Long To Beat 100+\n\nMetascore 85\n\nPlatforms That Support Crossplay PC, PS4, PS5, Xbox One & Xbox Series X|S\n\nNumber of Players 1-6 (Co-Op)\n\nPS Plus Availability Essential, Extra, & Premium (The Witch Queen)\n\nExpand\n\nSee at Playstation Store", 'source': {'uri': 'gamerant.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Game Rant'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'josh_cotts@gamerant.com', 'name': 'Josh Cotts', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://static0.gamerantimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/destiny-2-guardians-key-art.jpg', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.3176470588235294, 'wgt': 458505683, 'relevance': 4}

{'uri': '8222661843', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '17:23:26', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T17:23:26Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T17:22:50Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.729411780834198, 'url': 'https://pantagraph.com/sports/professional/baseball/mlb/chicago-white-sox-cubs-mlb-draft-baseball/article_85dffc40-406d-11ef-a6de-872fe075cc99.html', 'title': "Chicago baseball report: White Sox, Cubs finalizing draft plans; a closer look at Kopech's feat", 'body': 'Beau Thompson set a goal in 2017 to collect one million Chicago Cubs baseball cards. He talks about some of the favorites in his collection.\n\nThe Cubs are trying to ride a wave of momentum through the final stretch into the All-Star break to make up important ground in the National League wild-card race.\n\nThey finish the week with four games in three days in St. Louis, one of only two series left this year against the Cardinals.\n\nThe White Sox are in line to match the club mark for the most games played before the All-Star break (98), which was established in 1973. They will head to the break after the three-game home series this weekend against the Pittsburgh Pirates.\n\nEvery Friday during the regular season, Tribune baseball writers will provide an update on what happened -- and what\'s ahead -- for the Cubs and White Sox.\n\nKopech\'s immaculate moment\n\nMichael Kopech started thinking about it "from Pitch 4."\n\nPeople are also reading... Man found dead behind the wheel of vehicle on Veterans Parkway, police say Body pulled from Illinois River identified as Bloomington teen Bloomington man jailed on weapons, drug charges after traffic stop Flick Fact: How many State Farm employees are college educated? Bloomington woman faces DUI in crash that killed her 8-year-old son LaSalle County man dies in illegal fireworks incident Felon held by armed resident in Macon County gets 2 years 8-year-old boy dies after Wednesday night crash on I-74 Flick Fact: The $800M ex-farm girl from Stanford and Olympia High? Pub II marking 50th anniversary with party in uptown Normal Revolution Dispensary to host grand opening Friday in Normal Man found unresponsive in Bloomington had suffered medical event, police said Behind the Pritzker administration\'s quest to signal Illinois is \'open for business\' Opening statements begin in trial of man accused of killing teen at NYE party in Normal Bloomington police investigating shots fired Wednesday night\n\n"As soon as I realized there were no balls on the board, I wanted to finish that feat off," Kopech said.\n\nThe feat: nine pitches, nine strikes.\n\nThe Sox closer did just that while wrapping up a 3-1 victory in Game 1 of Wednesday\'s doubleheader against the Minnesota Twins at Guaranteed Rate Field.\n\n"It feels good, but at the same time, I would have never thought about it again if I threw a ball in there at some point," Kopech said. "Just glad to have a clean inning and get the win."\n\nKopech began the ninth inning facing Brooks Lee, who fouled off a fastball and a cutter. Kopech got strike three looking on a 100.1-mph fastball at the top of the zone, according to MLB Statcast.\n\nKopech got a swinging strike one on the next batter, Matt Wallner, with another fastball. Wallner fouled off a cutter, then swung and missed on a 100.5-mph fastball for strike three.\n\nMax Kepler hit for Manuel Margot. The first two pitches were cutters -- a swinging strike on the first and a called strike on the second. Kopech went back to the fastball, and Kepler couldn\'t check his swing on the 100.1-mph pitch that was out of the zone for strike three.\n\nKopech became the first Sox with a recorded immaculate inning since Hollis "Sloppy" Thurston on Aug. 22, 1923, according to statistician Christopher Kamka.\n\n"It was my first and his first (in the majors), something I\'ll always remember," catcher Korey Lee said. "Good things happen when you throw strikes."\n\nManager Pedro Grifol said the inning -- like Monday\'s 1-2-3 performance in the 10th against the Twins -- is why he never thought of moving Kopech out of the closer\'s role in the aftermath of Sunday\'s blown save against the Miami Marlins.\n\n"We\'re never going to give up on Michael, never," Grifol said. "There\'s too much talent, too much heart, too much character to even think about moving him down."\n\nCubs get No. 14 pick\n\nDays away from the first round of Major League Baseball\'s draft beginning Sunday, Cubs vice president of scouting Dan Kantrovitz and the organization are going through the final stages of lining up their draft board.\n\nBeyond a group of college hitters projected to be chosen among the top picks, Kantrovitz doesn\'t see any other demographics standing out among the class. But by drafting in the top half of the first round, the Cubs have an opportunity to find another talented player after picking left-hander Jordan Wicks, right-hander Cade Horton and infielder Matt Shaw, all out of college, the last three years.\n\n"We try to go into each draft with a blank slate," Kantrovitz said Thursday. "I think if something hadn\'t worked out with one of those picks, we wouldn\'t want it to affect our strategy in a negative way and so I think similarly, the fact that we\'ve had some positive returns so far from some recent picks, we don\'t want to really let that alter our strategy too much either. But it\'s no doubt a source of pride for our scouts and who follow these guys on a daily basis and are just so invested in every single box score."\n\nThe Cubs enter the draft with a bonus pool of $9,802,300. They have shown in the past a willingness to go under slot with certain picks and allocate those funds elsewhere in the draft.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nKantrovitz wouldn\'t tip his hand as to the direction the Cubs might go with their first pick. MLB.com\'s Jonathan Mayo has them picking East Carolina right-hander Trey Yesavage at No. 14 while The Athletic\'s Keith Law projects the Cubs to take Tennessee second baseman Christian Moore.\n\n"Our point of view on that is you don\'t want to take a step back on talent to do that," Kantrovitz said. "If you\'ve got two players that you\'re staring at your first pick and one of them will require $500,000 less than from a signing-bonus standpoint, that\'s a pretty optimal position to be in because then you can end up spreading that out throughout the rest of the draft. I think that\'s probably how most teams look at it."\n\nNumber of the week: 17\n\nWith his walk in the second inning Thursday against the Orioles, first baseman Michael Busch extended his on-base streak to 17 games, the longest by a Cub this year. He and the Atlanta Braves\' Austin Riley are tied for the longest active streak in the majors.\n\nTracking the Sox\'s record-setting losses\n\nRecord: 27-68\n\nThe Sox have the worst record after 95 games in franchise history. The previous mark of 31-64 was set in 1948.\n\nThey\'re on pace for 115 losses, five short of the record set by the expansion 1962 New York Mets. The team record is 106, set in 1970.\n\nThe team\'s 68 losses are the most for the club before the All-Star break. The previous high was 62 in 2018.\n\nCubs note\n\nAlexander Canario is getting another big-league chance, though his game opportunities may again be limited.\n\nWith outfielder Cody Bellinger landing on the 10-day injured list Thursday with a fractured left middle finger, Canario was brought up from Triple-A Iowa and again slots in as a bench option who could get spot starts against lefties.\n\n"I started going down there and working on my timing," Canario said through an interpreter. "Everything that I\'ve done throughout my career, throughout the minor leagues, I just want to come out here and just give my best and show what I\'ve got."\n\nIn 59 games with Iowa this season, Canario is hitting .238 with a .330 on-base percentage while slugging 16 home runs and 13 doubles. In limited action during his first call-up this year, Canario went 6-for-22 (.273) and posted a .360 OBP with two extra-base hits.\n\n"Just learning to make the quick adjustments from the first and second at-bats," Canario said. "Just to learn to make those adjustments as quick as possible and to go out there whenever it\'s needed."\n\nWhite Sox note\n\nThe Sox have been gearing up for the MLB draft, which begins Sunday.\n\nThey will be busy early with three of the first 68 picks -- No. 5, 43 and 68. The team\'s last top-five selection came in 2019, when the Sox drafted first baseman Andrew Vaughn at No. 3.\n\n"I think we all feel good with what\'s happening in the minor leagues," director of amateur scouting Mike Shirley said. "To add this piece of what (No.) 5 could possibly be to the next wave of this, it\'s substantial. It\'s a must."\n\nThe 20-round draft runs Sunday through Tuesday.\n\nQuotable\n\n"Every time I go out there, I\'m competing for the White Sox and trying to give us the best chance to win. I hope I give guys confidence when I step on the mound. {'uri': '8222648175', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '17:12:06', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T17:12:06Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T17:11:38Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://pressofatlanticcity.com/news/local/ocean-city-best-beach/article_7db7a0c4-406b-11ef-a6d6-a759a5542c3c.html', 'title': 'Ocean City again tops best-beach poll', 'body': 'Mayor Jay Gillian accepts the award naming Ocean City the best beach for the 11th year in a row.\n\nBill Barlow\n\nOCEAN CITY -- With rain that morning and more on the way, and gray skies over a fog-wreathed ocean, Friday morning was a beach day only a marine biologist could love.\n\n"Particularly a Seinfeldian marine biologist," said Peter Rowe, executive director of the New Jersey Sea Grant Consortium, an organization that promotes marine and coastal research. He spoke to a small crowd gathered under the logia of the Music Pier to unveil this year\'s winner of a statewide poll of New Jersey\'s favorite beach.\n\nNo one seemed shocked when Ocean City came out on top for the 11th year in a row.\n\nStarted in 2008, the poll is not scientific, Rowe said, just a friendly competition among beach towns to promote pride in, and care for, New Jersey\'s beaches.\n\nThe contest is decided by online voters, with participants prevented from voting more than once.\n\nPeople are also reading... Atlantic City Airshow canceled for 2024 Scientists know rising seas will one day swallow this Jersey Shore climate research center Rents are up, but vacationers are still heading to the Jersey Shore Route 30 reopened in both directions following repairs to Absecon Drawbridge 5 hurt, 76 displaced in 5-alarm Atlantic City apartment fire Longport resident says rats are coming from borough property Cape May County Zoo receives $1.4 million donation Wildwood police identify shooting suspect Greg Goodwin, influential Absegami coach, dies at 63 Egg Harbor City rescue in need of fosters, donors to help animals rescued from Galloway home Some Stanley Holmes Village residents say they will fight to keep their apartments, others ready to go Cape May fishing case has national impact Atlantic City High School principal accused of failing to report child abuse due back in court Aug. 29 Last of brothers who started Starn\'s ShopRite dies at age 89 Atlantic City woman involved in hit-and-run while kids in car\n\nMargate came in second statewide.\n\nThe poll also ranks beaches by county. This year, the countdown ran south to north, starting with Cape May County, where Cape May took second place and Ocean City came in first.\n\nIn Atlantic County, Margate won first, with Brigantine second.\n\nOcean City\'s Seaspray condo for sale at $7M\n\nA 32-unit condominium near the 34th Street bridge in Ocean City is closed over structural concerns and appears likely to remain closed through the summer. The building is now listed for sale at $7 million, pitched as a redevelopment opportunity.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nPoint Pleasant Beach came in first for Ocean County, followed by Seaside Heights, while Asbury Park was number one for Monmouth County and Spring Lake took second.\n\n"It\'s great to see Ocean City achieve this honor," Mayor Jay Gillian said in a statement. "Every year, we face new challenges. But Ocean City remains the best beach in the state and a tradition for generations of families. I want to congratulate and thank the city team, our public safety departments, the Ocean City Regional Chamber of Commerce, the Tourism Development Commission, the Boardwalk and Downtown Merchants associations, local businesses, all volunteer groups and the entire community in making Ocean City a wonderful place to live, work and play."\n\nAt the music pier, Gillian accepted the win with a wave and gave the credit to the Ocean City community. He singled out the Chamber of Commerce, the president of which, Michele Gillian, is also his wife. She was in the crowd, along with most of the members of City Council.\n\nOcean City in recent years has been named "Best Beach in America" and "Best Beach" in many other statewide polls, according to a city statement. "America\'s Greatest Family Resort" also has been recognized for its Boardwalk, downtown, ecotourism, family destinations, women-owned businesses and more.\n\nPatrick Power, Margate\'s superintendent of public works, accepted the honor on behalf of his community, while Mark Virgilio represented Brigantine.\n\nRowe, who holds a doctorate in oceanography from the University of Delaware and has spent decades in marine research and education, appeared to reference a 1994 episode of "Seinfeld" in which the character George Costanza, played by Jason Alexander, impersonates a marine biologist but manages to save a distressed whale.\n\nFor much of this summer, beaches have been packed as people flee intense heat inland. The water has been exceptionally cold close to shore, but that has helped keep the heat at bay on the barrier islands.\n\nNot so much Friday, when just a few people were on the beach behind the lifeguard stand closest to the Music Pier. Rowe said it was a testament to New Jersey\'s dedication to its beaches that anyone was out at all.\n\nWhich South Jersey beach towns allow dogs and bikes on the boardwalk?\n\nTwo shore towns recently cracked down on summertime shore activities: Dogs on the beach and bikes on the boardwalk. Here\'s how South Jersey shore towns regulate their beaches and boardwalks when it comes to allowing dogs and bikes:\n\n"It just goes to show how we in New Jersey love our beaches," Rowe said.
