{'uri': '2024-07-419771053', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '12:05:28', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T12:05:28Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T12:05:14Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7843137383460999, 'url': 'https://www.pcmag.com/articles/exploring-la-in-a-waymo-robotaxi-peaceful-cautious-sometimes-tardy', 'title': 'Exploring L.A. in a Waymo Robotaxi: Peaceful, Cautious, Sometimes Tardy', 'body': 'Waymo\'s driverless taxis are attention-grabbing, but without freeway access or rides to and from LAX, the Alphabet-owned company still has some kinks to work out in Los Angeles.\n\nLOS ANGELES -- When you strap yourself into a Waymo, the constants of the ride-hailing experience vanish in the rearview mirror: air fresheners, talk radio, tipping -- and a human behind the steering wheel.\n\nThe Alphabet-owned service occupies its own lane in the market for self-driving vehicles. Unlike its rivals -- GM\'s Cruise, Amazon\'s Zoox, or Tesla\'s still-vaporware "Cybercab" -- Waymo provides driverless service to the paying public in Phoenix, Los Angeles and San Francisco.\n\nSo when a recent trip to Southern California for the VidCon Anaheim conference left me with a spare day and a half to tool around L.A., there was no question about how I\'d roll in that city. Or at least in Waymo\'s service area, which arcs from downtown to just south of Santa Monica but sadly excludes Los Angeles International Airport.\n\nWith a Waymo-provided code to skip a waitlist in the city -- a speed bump the company has removed in Phoenix and San Francisco -- I took four rides:\n\nAll of those rates landed within a dollar or so of what I later saw Uber and Lyft estimate pre-tip for the same routes. With no human drivers to motivate, Waymo has no surge pricing, but I did see its estimates fluctuate slightly over several minutes.\n\nHailing a Robotic Ride\n\nThe Waymo One app for Android and iOS offers a ride-booking flow like that in Uber and Lyft: Set your pickup point and destination, wait for the service to estimate your price and wait for a car, then confirm the trip if the cost and time work for you.\n\nThe app then shows an estimate of your car\'s arrival and maps its location, including stoplights in its path. Waymo cars -- white Jaguar I-Pace battery-electric hatchbacks festooned with LiDAR and other sensors -- look alike, but you shouldn\'t need to check the license plates on an arriving vehicle because it also displays your initials in a roof-mounted beacon.\n\nWhen the car stops, tap a button in the app to unlock the car via Bluetooth. There\'s plenty of room for three full-sized humans between the front passenger seat and the rear seats; the middle of the back seat can work for shorter rides or smaller humans. The trunk easily accommodated three pieces of rolling luggage.\n\nThe car won\'t move until you tap a "Start Ride" button on the dashboard touch screen, so there\'s no scramble to buckle seat belts. On my first ride, that display played an intro to Waymo that advised that its cars include inward-facing cameras as a safety measure and to "improve our product," plus a microphone that only activates if you call support.\n\nWaymo\'s touch screen lets you choose from a menu of iHeartRadio stations, with the default a chill "Ambient Vibes" instrumental soundtrack. You can also play from apps on your phone, but not via Bluetooth audio. Instead, you need to grant the Waymo app access to your Google account so you can use the "Cast" button in compatible apps.\n\n(If you use Google\'s YouTube Music app on Android, you\'ll need to pay for a subscription to the service of the same name to use that output option. Which is dumb.)\n\nLet\'s Roll\n\nOn all four rides, I found Waymo to be a cautious and courteous driver, sometimes distractingly so. The car used its turn signals every time and stopped for every pedestrian and cyclist in a crosswalk -- even when a bus blocked much of the view -- but I also saw it brake before cars that had only inched out of driveways or garages.\n\nLeft turns at stop lights had cars inching forward and then braking and then inching forward, once only proceeding a second before a yellow light turned red.\n\nThis politeness sometimes wasted time, such as when one car did not pull around a vehicle waiting to turn left at a light to use the lane open to its right. I also found myself wishing that this car would have honked at the pickup truck in the lane to the right that edged toward us until a few inches separated our side-view mirrors.\n\nWaymo programs its cars to obey all speed limits -- a restriction that some Waymo passengers mope about, but one that I appreciated on surface streets shared with cyclists and pedestrians.\n\nWaymo\'s grasp of pedestrian infrastructure, however, may need an upgrade. My ride to Union Station ended badly when the robotaxi drove up to a sidewalk in front of that beautiful work of Mission Revival architecture, did not continue past the construction fencing blocking part of the sidewalk, and instead turned left to unload me on a landscaped median.\n\nHuman Factors\n\nPeople haven\'t always taken well to robotaxis -- a crowd set a Waymo on fire in San Francisco\'s Chinatown in February -- but the reactions I got around L.A. left me feeling more like a rock star. Pedestrians stopped and stared, while other drivers smiled or gave thumbs-up approvals.\n\nI didn\'t expect to get that sort of entertainment value out of a robotaxi ride.\n\n(See also: when I spotted a Serve Robotics delivery bot rolling along on the sidewalk and had to wonder if the smaller autonomous vehicle noticed the larger one and thought "friend?")\n\nAs for other Waymo passengers, all four cars looked fresh-off-the-lot clean inside. A day later, I learned that Waymo checks for lost belongings when I got a "Did you lose something today?" email. It explained that the service sends a note to the last four people to have taken rides in a car when it finds a left-behind item.\n\nAlthough there\'s no tipping, the app asks you to review each ride on a one-to-five-star scale. I handed out five-star reviews for my first three rides, which led to the app inviting me to select among aspects that made the ride great, such as "Smooth drive" or "Wait time."\n\nI was not so happy about the last ride and its improper drop-off. But with no human driver\'s feelings or livelihood at stake, I felt liberated to whack Waymo with a three-star rating.\n\nNot Enough Cars\n\nMy worst experience came before I buckled up for that fourth ride. First, my wait for a car at Pershing Square dragged on for longer than the predicted four minutes. But because the app did not show the car\'s location while it had another passenger onboard, I didn\'t know what was happening. Then the ride\'s status changed from "arriving" to "Trip canceled," leaving me thinking: Wow, just like Uber and Lyft!\n\nDetermined to finish this experiment, I summoned another car and had the longest wait of all four rides; an estimated 20 minutes turned into 25. The delay left me appreciating how the app offers precise walking directions to a pickup spot and thinking that a normal human going to Union Station would have jumped on the subway, a $1.75 fare.\n\nAn automated email from Waymo apologized for my trip cancellation and blamed it on "operational reasons on our end."\n\nAfter I shared my ride information with spokeswoman Katherine Barna, she said in an email that this looked like a case of the system automatically canceling a trip after it got delayed past what it had calculated was "a reasonable amount of time."\n\nShe added that the system should have sent another car automatically, but none were close enough, a complaint now popping up on Reddit\'s r/waymo forum.\n\nThe Roads Ahead\n\nReactions from people about self-driving cars, however, are often less "will I have to wait too long" or "will it make me step through shrubbery?" and more "will the robotaxi accelerate into a bridge abutment?"\n\nThat is not so much Waymo\'s doing, although its cars have committed driving flubs like last week\'s case of a Waymo driving into an oncoming lane in Phoenix after being confused by construction signage-as the fault of an entire industry that has spent years overpromising and underdelivering.\n\nAnd in the case of Uber\'s since-shelved self-driving effort, Cruise\'s robotaxis, and Tesla\'s misleadingly-named "Full Self-Driving," the consequences have included serious injuries and even deaths.\n\nBut you should not overlook how bad human drivers can be. Beyond grim statistics that include 42,514 deaths on American roads in 2022, I\'m also thinking of the two human-driven rides that preceded my introduction to Waymo. First an early-morning run to Washington Dulles International Airport had a Lyft driver disregarding speed limits and safe following-distance principles, then a taxi from LAX to Venice saw our driver apparently allergic to his vehicle\'s turn-signal stalk.\n\nSo would I summon a Waymo for my next ride if transit would not serve me effectively? Yes. But I can\'t until I return to its three active cities. And even there, Waymo\'s service boundaries can hold it back -- especially in L.A., where LAX is sorely absent from its service area.\n\nBarna said "we\'ve been in contact with LAX and it\'s an area we look forward to serving in the future," adding that Waymo has been doing overnight curbside pickups and drop-offs at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport since last year.\n\nFreeways also remain off limits to Waymo passengers, although the company began testing highway driving in January in Phoenix with safety drivers up front. Waymo\'s mandatory speed-limit compliance may make its vehicles a more awkward fit with human-driven cars there.\n\nDon\'t expect rapid advancements. Waymo has been insistent that it\'s not a "move fast and break things" company and will stick with a methodical, iterative approach to testing and deploying robotaxis.\n\nAs a business, Waymo itself is still finding its bearings. In Alphabet\'s most recent quarter, the "Other bets" category of ventures led by Waymo yielded a $1.02 billion loss, while Bank of America reportedly put Waymo\'s 2024 losses at $1.2 to $1.5 billion.\n\nBut Waymo not only has the advantage of technology in use by paying customers and Uber\'s endorsement, it has its corporate parent\'s nearly boundless pockets. So there\'s a lot of on-ramp here, even if that may also mean a long wait for your own Waymo ride.', 'source': {'uri': 'pcmag.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'PC Magazine'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'rob_pegoraro@pcmag.com', 'name': 'Rob Pegoraro', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://i.pcmag.com/imagery/articles/07HPYqfGS4SzCZVxZINO4z9-5.fit_lim.size_1200x630.v1720736243.jpg', 'eventUri': 'eng-9715839', 'sentiment': -0.07450980392156858, 'wgt': 458481928, 'relevance': 83}
{'uri': '2024-07-419759969', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '11:55:15', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T11:55:15Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T11:30:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.5921568870544434, 'url': 'https://qctimes.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/politics-democrats-kamala-harris-trump-election/article_34e76e39-c88d-5ab4-9a44-4bd19e6ab37c.html', 'title': "Here are key takeaways from President Joe Biden's news conference", 'body': 'President Joe Biden opened his highly anticipated news conference Thursday with a recitation of his NATO accomplishments during the summit this week as he faced growing calls to withdraw from the presidential race. He forcefully declared he would stay in the race and would win.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Joe Biden faced a test Thursday that he had avoided so far this year: a solo news conference with questions from the White House press corps.\n\nThe news conference was meant to reassure a disheartened group of Democratic lawmakers, allies and persuadable voters in this year\'s election that Biden still has the strength and stamina to be president.\n\nBiden has tried to defend his feeble and tongue-tied performance in the June 27 debate against presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump as an outlier rather than evidence that at age 81, he lacks the vigor and commanding presence that the public expects from the commander in chief.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nAn early look at Davenport\'s plans for Main Street Landing Chicago company buys apartment buildings in Davenport, Moline Quad-Cities business openings, closings: Shelly\'s Sweet Sensations, Crawford Brew Works and more 7 Quad Cities restaurants that opened in June El Compita in Davenport ordered to pay nearly $50,000 in back wages, damages to workers NEW DETAILS: John Deere announces another 345 layoffs at Waterloo facilities Moline woman gave report of missing mail to postal worker accused of stealing mail Driver of vehicle in LeClaire crash identified Police identify woman killed by crash Monday afternoon northwest of Davenport Matt Moody managed the Village Theater and touched many lives Review: Lainey Wilson sings in the rain Sunday at the John Deere Classic Hungry? Here\'s a list of food trucks in the Quad-Cities to check out Agriculture expert: Deere prepares for future losses due to declining ag economy Review: Counting Crows at the John Deere Classic \'Concerts on the Course\' Davenport interim city administrator to leave job in August for private sector\n\nHe made at least two notable flubs, referring at an event beforehand to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy as "President Putin" and then calling Kamala Harris "Vice President Trump" when a reporter asked about her.\n\nBut he also gave detailed responses about his work to preserve NATO and his plans for a second term.\n\nHe also insisted he\'s not leaving the race even as a growing number of Democratic lawmakers ask him to step aside.\n\nHere are some highlights from the news conference:\n\nHe bungled key names -- and remained defiant\n\nPerhaps Biden\'s biggest slip-up in the news conference came early on when he referred to Vice President Kamala Harris as "Vice President Trump," in saying he picked her because he believed she could beat Trump.\n\nEven before the news conference, Biden bungled an important name at the NATO summit and instantly lowered expectations for his performance.\n\n"Ladies and gentlemen, President Putin," Biden said as he was introducing Ukrainian President President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who is most definitely not Russian President Vladimir Putin.\n\nThe gaffe immediately prompted gasps, as Biden caught himself and said to Zelenskyy: "President Putin? You\'re going to beat President Putin."\n\nBut he was defiant when a reporter brought up his reference to "Vice President Trump" and noted the presumptive Republican nominee\'s campaign was already promoting the slip-up. "Listen to him," he said, before walking off the stage.\n\nOne House Democrat, Rep. Jim Himes of Connecticut, issued a statement minutes later calling on the president to withdraw.\n\nHe insisted, \'I\'ve got to finish this job\'\n\nIt\'s a delicate dance between the president and vice president, with many Democrats openly pining for Harris to replace Biden on the ticket. Biden didn\'t acknowledge that tension, but only brought Harris up in response to pointed questions about whether he believed she had the capability to replace him.\n\n"I wouldn\'t have picked her unless I thought she was qualified to be president," Biden said, citing Harris\' resume from prosecutor to the U.S. Senate.\n\nBut in response to a later question he acknowledged he\'d moved on from his 2020 campaign promise to be a "bridge" to a new generation of Democrats. "What changed was the gravity of the situation I inherited," he said, without a word about his vice president.\n\nRepeatedly, he said, "I\'ve got to finish this job."\n\nThe news conference ended with Biden being asked directly whether he\'d step down for Harris if he saw polling showing she had a better chance of beating Trump.\n\n"No, unless they come back and said there\'s no way you can win," Biden responded. Then he added, in a stage whisper, "No poll\'s saying that."\n\nHe argued he\'s delivered results over rhetoric\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nBiden tried to make the case that what he\'s doing matters more than how he talks about it.\n\nHe praised the just finished NATO summit as elevating America\'s standing. "Have you ever seen a more successful conference?" Biden said to a group of reporters who often only got to see the conference during prepared remarks.\n\nHe drilled down on how inflation eased from its 2022 peak as he reeled off statistics such as the creation of 800,000 manufacturing jobs under his watch, saying world leaders would want to trade their own economies for what United States has.\n\nHe also said he would cap how much rent could grow for tenants of landlords who are part of a tax-credit program for low-income housing.\n\nIt\'s the same pitch Biden made in stump speeches without necessarily doing much to move his own popularity. His team believes it will sink in if repeated constantly.\n\nHe brought up his work on NATO\n\nBiden kicked off the press conference by talking at length about NATO and its value to the United States -- one of his strongest political issues against Trump, who has been openly skeptical of the alliance and once suggested he\'d encourage Russia to attack NATO members whom he considered delinquent.\n\nBiden tied himself to an American tradition stretching "from Truman to Reagan to me" of defending NATO. "Every American must ask herself or himself, is the world safer with NATO?" he asked.\n\nLater, to assure a European journalist asking about governments on that continent worrying Trump could win, Biden launched into a detailed recounting of how he helped shepherd Finland into the alliance.\n\nAfter that, he went into detail about how to push back against China for supporting Russia during its war against Ukraine and contended he will continue to be able to deal with Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping.\n\nOverall, Biden spoke forcefully and fluently about foreign policy, one of his favorite subjects. But the news conference\'s focus wasn\'t really foreign policy, it was reassuring Democrats and the world that Biden is still able to be president and beat Trump.\n\nThat shows how even Biden\'s strengths are being overshadowed by questions about his capabilities.\n\nWhen possible, he went back to the stump speech\n\nEvery politician has a stock set of lines. And whenever Biden could, he went back to his favorite talking points. It was a way to answer the question without necessarily needing to say anything spontaneous or new.\n\nHe went after trickle-down economics, borrowing a line about his father never benefiting much from tax cuts aimed at the wealthy ("I don\'t remember much trickling down to his kitchen table"). He hailed Delaware for leading the country in corporations. He said he\'s the "most pro-union labor president in history." He explained his decision to run for a second term with a variation on his "finish the job" catchphrase. He went into his standard spiel about computer chips.\n\nWith no time limit on his answers like he faced at the debate, Biden went on for several minutes at a time telling stories about his interactions with foreign leaders and making the case for his reelection.\n\nHe answered questions in detail -- unlike at the debate\n\nThere were few fireworks in Biden\'s answers -- with the highly anticipated event at times coming across as more of a think tank lecture than an effort to grab voters\' attention. He went into granular detail on geopolitics and rattled off numbers -- asking at one moment, though, to not be held to the precise figure.\n\nWhile it didn\'t erase the stumbles and blank stares from the debate, it showed that he could engage with reporters\' questions on a range of issues without losing focus.\n\nThere was still regular coughing and throat clearing. And at times he lowered his voice to a hoarse whisper that evoked the rasp of his voice on debate night.\n\nOverall, his presentation was a reminder that people are focused on him now with an almost clinical eye toward possible slip-ups and mistakes, the kind of pressure that is unlikely to go away for as long as Biden insists he\'ll stay in the race.\n\nMore coverage:\n\nThe Latest: Biden news conference is key event as he faces calls to step aside\n\nPresident Joe Biden has held a news conference in what is considered a key event in a monumental week for his campaign. After a dismal debate performance, Biden has been fending off calls to step aside as the party\'s presumptive nominee. His much-anticipated news conference came on the last day of the NATO summit. Peter Welch of Vermont became the first Senate Democrat to call for Biden to step aside. Over a dozen House representatives have publicly called for Biden to end his campaign.\n\nObama and Pelosi huddled as Democrats look to steer Biden out of 2024 race\n\n(CNN) -- Barack Obama and Nancy Pelosi have spoken privately about Joe Biden and the future of his 2024 campaign. Both the former president and ex-speaker expressed concerns about how much harder they think it\'s become for the president to beat Donald Trump. Neither is quite sure what to do.\n\nTrump lawyers press judge to overturn hush money conviction after Supreme Court immunity ruling\n\nDonald Trump\'s lawyers are urging the judge in his New York hush money case to overturn his conviction and dismiss the case in the wake of the Supreme Court\'s recent ruling on presidential immunity. The former president\'s lawyers wrote in papers made public Thursday that prosecutors rushed to try Trump in April and May while the high court was still considering his immunity claims. Trump was originally scheduled to be sentenced Thursday, but that\'s on hold until the trial judge, Juan M. Merchan, rules on whether to set aside Trump\'s felony conviction for falsifying records to cover up a potential sex scandal. Merchan has said he\'ll rule on the defense\'s requests on Sept. 6. Prosecutors have until July 24 to respond.\n\nPresidential debate: Biden, Trump square off in Atlanta, in photos\n\nLove\n\n0\n\nFunny\n\n0\n\nWow\n\n0\n\nSad\n\n0\n\nAngry\n\n0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.', 'source': {'uri': 'qctimes.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Quad-City Times'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'josh_boak@qctimes.com', 'name': 'Josh Boak', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/qctimes.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/3/4e/34e76e39-c88d-5ab4-9a44-4bd19e6ab37c/6690921c391e1.preview.jpg?crop=1741%2C914%2C8%2C42&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9720525', 'sentiment': 0.1372549019607843, 'wgt': 458481315, 'relevance': 30}
{'uri': '8222180583', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': True, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '11:49:50', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T11:49:50Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T11:49:17Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.7764706015586853, 'url': 'https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/fadeaway-world-nba/serena-williams-roasts-lebron-james-hairline-during-the-2024-espy-awards/article_90c4780c-2c24-59c9-850a-ceda91fedacf.html', 'title': "Serena Williams Roasts LeBron James' Hairline During The 2024 ESPY Awards", 'body': 'Tennis legend Serena Williams fired some shots in LeBron James\' direction last night. While hosting the 2024 ESPY Awards, Serena Williams brought up Bronny James\' recent entry into the NBA. She wished Bronny success in his career and made a joke about LeBron James\' hairline receding.\n\n"A big moment in sports this year was LeBron James\' son, Bronny... He got drafted to the Lakers where he will play with his dad. And I truly hope Bronny has a long career... So long that he will see his hairline recede, then, miraculously un-recede, like dad."\n\nIt was clearly a cheeky dig from Serena Williams, who poked fun at LeBron\'s hairline, something that fans, analysts, and even other NBA players have been doing for years. It\'s unlikely James would mind at all, or take any offense to Williams\' comments.\n\nHowever, later in the night, Serena would take a more pointed shot at the The King. While talking with her daughter on stage, Williams pointed out that James wants to win a championship with the Lakers this year with Bronny James on the team.\n\nShe then remarked that she was able to win a grand slam while being pregnant, and claimed her accomplishment was more impressive.\n\n"The women\'s game is extremely physical... LeBron wants to win with his son on his team, I won with my daughter in my belly. I think we know which one is way more impressive."\n\nOnce again, LeBron is unlikely to take offense to this jab from Serena. And while LeBron winning a championship with Bronny James would be an incredible accomplishment, it is hard to rival the incredible achievement of Serena Williams.\n\nJames has often shown Serena Williams a lot of love and respect. Much like James, Williams is considered one of the all-time greats in her sport. And James even suggested that she was the GOAT during her incredible performance at the 2022 U.S. Open.\n\nLeBron James Faces Criticism For Bronny James Getting Drafted\n\nFormer NBA player Steven Hunter recently slammed LeBron James for using his power and cachet within the Lakers organization to get his son Bronny drafted. He claimed that LeBron and Rich Paul abused their power to get Bronny James a guaranteed contract, something second-round picks don\'t usually get offered.\n\n"For those that don\'t know... Late second-round picks don\'t get guarantees (Especially before summer league). Typically late second-round picks don\'t get 4 year guaranteed roster spot deals either. This wasn\'t earned I\'m sorry... And it\'s an egregious abuse of power from LBJ & Rich Paul."\n\n"It\'s a slap in the face to all of the kids out there who work their asses off to get to the league. It\'s sneaky Hollywood s**t like this that turns a lot of people off about LeBron... This is just another example of what they be talking about right when you try to like\'em."\n\nWhile there is some criticism that can be made about Bronny\'s path to the NBA, LeBron James hasn\'t done anything morally wrong. Any father would want his child to have opportunities and will use their power to give them those opportunities. James wanted the best for his son and did what he felt was right to get him what he needed.\n\nFurthermore, several players in the NBA have benefitted from some form of nepotism. While Bronny\'s case might be the most high-profile, and the most extensive, he is not the only second or third-generation player to get a chance in the NBA thanks to their parent.\n\nBronny James will be eager to prove the critics wrong next season. While his opportunities with the Lakers will be limited, as he will spend most of his time in the G-League, he will want to show that he deserves the contract he was given by the 17-time NBA champions.\n\nRelated: 8 No. 1 Overall Picks Sons Have Played In The NBA\n\nThank you for being a valued reader of Fadeaway World. {'uri': '2024-07-419742100', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '11:37:22', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T11:37:22Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T11:30:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0.6901960968971252, 'url': 'https://omaha.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/politics-democrats-kamala-harris-trump-election/article_97edd9de-0a8c-50f1-bd4e-32a613e859cd.html', 'title': "Here are key takeaways from President Joe Biden's news conference", 'body': 'President Joe Biden opened his highly anticipated news conference Thursday with a recitation of his NATO accomplishments during the summit this week as he faced growing calls to withdraw from the presidential race. He forcefully declared he would stay in the race and would win.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Joe Biden faced a test Thursday that he had avoided so far this year: a solo news conference with questions from the White House press corps.\n\nThe news conference was meant to reassure a disheartened group of Democratic lawmakers, allies and persuadable voters in this year\'s election that Biden still has the strength and stamina to be president.\n\nBiden has tried to defend his feeble and tongue-tied performance in the June 27 debate against presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump as an outlier rather than evidence that at age 81, he lacks the vigor and commanding presence that the public expects from the commander in chief.\n\nHe made at least two notable flubs, referring at an event beforehand to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy as "President Putin" and then calling Kamala Harris "Vice President Trump" when a reporter asked about her.\n\nBut he also gave detailed responses about his work to preserve NATO and his plans for a second term.\n\nHe also insisted he\'s not leaving the race even as a growing number of Democratic lawmakers ask him to step aside.\n\nHere are some highlights from the news conference:\n\nHe bungled key names -- and remained defiant\n\nPerhaps Biden\'s biggest slip-up in the news conference came early on when he referred to Vice President Kamala Harris as "Vice President Trump," in saying he picked her because he believed she could beat Trump.\n\nEven before the news conference, Biden bungled an important name at the NATO summit and instantly lowered expectations for his performance.\n\n"Ladies and gentlemen, President Putin," Biden said as he was introducing Ukrainian President President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, who is most definitely not Russian President Vladimir Putin.\n\nThe gaffe immediately prompted gasps, as Biden caught himself and said to Zelenskyy: "President Putin? You\'re going to beat President Putin."\n\nBut he was defiant when a reporter brought up his reference to "Vice President Trump" and noted the presumptive Republican nominee\'s campaign was already promoting the slip-up. "Listen to him," he said, before walking off the stage.\n\nOne House Democrat, Rep. Jim Himes of Connecticut, issued a statement minutes later calling on the president to withdraw.\n\nHe insisted, \'I\'ve got to finish this job\'\n\nIt\'s a delicate dance between the president and vice president, with many Democrats openly pining for Harris to replace Biden on the ticket. Biden didn\'t acknowledge that tension, but only brought Harris up in response to pointed questions about whether he believed she had the capability to replace him.\n\n"I wouldn\'t have picked her unless I thought she was qualified to be president," Biden said, citing Harris\' resume from prosecutor to the U.S. Senate.\n\nBut in response to a later question he acknowledged he\'d moved on from his 2020 campaign promise to be a "bridge" to a new generation of Democrats. "What changed was the gravity of the situation I inherited," he said, without a word about his vice president.\n\nRepeatedly, he said, "I\'ve got to finish this job."\n\nThe news conference ended with Biden being asked directly whether he\'d step down for Harris if he saw polling showing she had a better chance of beating Trump.\n\n"No, unless they come back and said there\'s no way you can win," Biden responded. Then he added, in a stage whisper, "No poll\'s saying that."\n\nHe argued he\'s delivered results over rhetoric\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nBiden tried to make the case that what he\'s doing matters more than how he talks about it.\n\nHe praised the just finished NATO summit as elevating America\'s standing. "Have you ever seen a more successful conference?" Biden said to a group of reporters who often only got to see the conference during prepared remarks.\n\nHe drilled down on how inflation eased from its 2022 peak as he reeled off statistics such as the creation of 800,000 manufacturing jobs under his watch, saying world leaders would want to trade their own economies for what United States has.\n\nHe also said he would cap how much rent could grow for tenants of landlords who are part of a tax-credit program for low-income housing.\n\nIt\'s the same pitch Biden made in stump speeches without necessarily doing much to move his own popularity. His team believes it will sink in if repeated constantly.\n\nHe brought up his work on NATO\n\nBiden kicked off the press conference by talking at length about NATO and its value to the United States -- one of his strongest political issues against Trump, who has been openly skeptical of the alliance and once suggested he\'d encourage Russia to attack NATO members whom he considered delinquent.\n\nBiden tied himself to an American tradition stretching "from Truman to Reagan to me" of defending NATO. "Every American must ask herself or himself, is the world safer with NATO?" he asked.\n\nLater, to assure a European journalist asking about governments on that continent worrying Trump could win, Biden launched into a detailed recounting of how he helped shepherd Finland into the alliance.\n\nAfter that, he went into detail about how to push back against China for supporting Russia during its war against Ukraine and contended he will continue to be able to deal with Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping.\n\nOverall, Biden spoke forcefully and fluently about foreign policy, one of his favorite subjects. But the news conference\'s focus wasn\'t really foreign policy, it was reassuring Democrats and the world that Biden is still able to be president and beat Trump.\n\nThat shows how even Biden\'s strengths are being overshadowed by questions about his capabilities.\n\nWhen possible, he went back to the stump speech\n\nEvery politician has a stock set of lines. And whenever Biden could, he went back to his favorite talking points. It was a way to answer the question without necessarily needing to say anything spontaneous or new.\n\nHe went after trickle-down economics, borrowing a line about his father never benefiting much from tax cuts aimed at the wealthy ("I don\'t remember much trickling down to his kitchen table"). He hailed Delaware for leading the country in corporations. He said he\'s the "most pro-union labor president in history." He explained his decision to run for a second term with a variation on his "finish the job" catchphrase. He went into his standard spiel about computer chips.\n\nWith no time limit on his answers like he faced at the debate, Biden went on for several minutes at a time telling stories about his interactions with foreign leaders and making the case for his reelection.\n\nHe answered questions in detail -- unlike at the debate\n\nThere were few fireworks in Biden\'s answers -- with the highly anticipated event at times coming across as more of a think tank lecture than an effort to grab voters\' attention. He went into granular detail on geopolitics and rattled off numbers -- asking at one moment, though, to not be held to the precise figure.\n\nWhile it didn\'t erase the stumbles and blank stares from the debate, it showed that he could engage with reporters\' questions on a range of issues without losing focus.\n\nThere was still regular coughing and throat clearing. And at times he lowered his voice to a hoarse whisper that evoked the rasp of his voice on debate night.\n\nOverall, his presentation was a reminder that people are focused on him now with an almost clinical eye toward possible slip-ups and mistakes, the kind of pressure that is unlikely to go away for as long as Biden insists he\'ll stay in the race.\n\nMore coverage:\n\nThe Latest: Biden news conference is key event as he faces calls to step aside\n\nPresident Joe Biden has held a news conference in what is considered a key event in a monumental week for his campaign. After a dismal debate performance, Biden has been fending off calls to step aside as the party\'s presumptive nominee. His much-anticipated news conference came on the last day of the NATO summit. Peter Welch of Vermont became the first Senate Democrat to call for Biden to step aside. Over a dozen House representatives have publicly called for Biden to end his campaign.\n\nObama and Pelosi huddled as Democrats look to steer Biden out of 2024 race\n\n(CNN) -- Barack Obama and Nancy Pelosi have spoken privately about Joe Biden and the future of his 2024 campaign. Both the former president and ex-speaker expressed concerns about how much harder they think it\'s become for the president to beat Donald Trump. Neither is quite sure what to do.\n\nTrump lawyers press judge to overturn hush money conviction after Supreme Court immunity ruling\n\nDonald Trump\'s lawyers are urging the judge in his New York hush money case to overturn his conviction and dismiss the case in the wake of the Supreme Court\'s recent ruling on presidential immunity. The former president\'s lawyers wrote in papers made public Thursday that prosecutors rushed to try Trump in April and May while the high court was still considering his immunity claims. Trump was originally scheduled to be sentenced Thursday, but that\'s on hold until the trial judge, Juan M. Merchan, rules on whether to set aside Trump\'s felony conviction for falsifying records to cover up a potential sex scandal. Merchan has said he\'ll rule on the defense\'s requests on Sept. 6. Prosecutors have until July 24 to respond.\n\nPresidential debate: Biden, Trump square off in Atlanta, in photos', 'source': {'uri': 'omaha.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'Omaha.com'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'josh_boak@omaha.com', 'name': 'Josh Boak', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/omaha.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/9/7e/97edd9de-0a8c-50f1-bd4e-32a613e859cd/66909114791bc.preview.jpg?crop=1741%2C914%2C8%2C42&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': 'eng-9720525', 'sentiment': 0.1372549019607843, 'wgt': 458480242, 'relevance': 29}

{'uri': '8222142930', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '11:23:48', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T11:23:48Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T11:23:26Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://lacrossetribune.com/news/local/la-crosse-rail-crossings-upgrades/article_b519c456-3f8b-11ef-ab48-f3b09bf95221.html', 'title': 'Wisconsin DOT proposes safety upgrades at two rail crossings near La Crosse Amtrak Station', 'body': 'Two problematic rail crossings on La Crosse\'s North Side are slated for upgrades.\n\nThe state Department of Transportation held an open house Wednesday at Logan High School to discuss rail at-grade crossings at Hagar and Avon streets and St. Cloud and Liberty streets.\n\nThe state plans to add a third track in La Crosse to accommodate a second Amtrak route launched earlier this year, and DOT officials are using the opportunity to review safety issues at the two crossings. Both are diagonal crossings at street intersections with no stop signs.\n\nDOT project manager Kris Sommers said the two crossings "are on our hot list of crashes."\n\n"These crossings have been quite unsafe for a number of years," Sommers said.\n\nSince 1979, the two crossings have accounted for 11 train crashes, including three fatalities and two injuries. Six of the collisions involved pedestrians and one involved a bicycle.\n\nPeople are also reading... Steve Cahalan: Batter and Brew hits the streets in La Crosse Steve Cahalan: Downtown Holiday Inn converting to boutique hotel in La Crosse Local talent shines in first-ever Riverfest Idol karaoke tournament Human trafficking in La Crosse: Police department raises awareness after recent arrests Galesville man charged with eluding police and stealing vehicle in Onalaska One injured in three vehicle crash near Arcadia Criminal complaint implicates two La Crosse residents for human trafficking UPDATE: $500K bond set for man charged with assault in Winona that led to shelter-in-place order Two spills of chemical firefighting foam occurred at La Crosse Regional Airport earlier this year, reports say Elderly man killed in UTV accident on Ettrick farm 21-year-old man drowns in private pond in Grant County, authorities say Amtrak reports strong ticket sales for new line running through Wisconsin Tellurian awarded $35,000 from Mayo Health Farm ordered to pay $210K for wastewater permit violations; owner disputes Monroe County court ruling These doctors were censured. Wisconsin\'s prisons hired them anyway.\n\nVehicle collisions not involving trains are far more common. From 2018-22, there were 17 collisions at Hagar/Avon and nine at St. Cloud/Liberty. Sommers said the diagonal rail crossing is a major factor.\n\n"It\'s not ideal to have that angle," Sommers said. "The angles compromise safety and vision."\n\nAnother problem is the amount of time trains block intersections, which the third track is designed to alleviate.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\n"The trains sit there for so long," said Jennifer Harnisch. "It makes it hard for pedestrians to cross."\n\nShe and husband, Jeremy, live less a block from one of the intersections. She said trains can block traffic for up to 30 minutes at a time. The DOT estimates "crossing activations" block traffic an average of four hours per day.\n\nSommers said the DOT\'s preferred solution is to close the St. Cloud/Liberty intersection and install an 8-gate closure system at Avon/Hagar. He said the 8-gate system would make it more difficult for motorists to drive around the gates after they\'re activated.\n\nThe plan would also reconstruct sidewalks to create 90-degree pedestrian crossings and erect stop signs at the Avon/Hagar intersection.\n\nDOT began taking feedback last December. Sommers said there was opposition to closing either intersection. He said the public was also cool to an an option that would turn Avon and Liberty into one-way streets.\n\nJeremy Harnisch said closing any north-south roads would increase congestion on the North Side.\n\n"There are only four roads that get by the tracks," he said.\n\nThe third track will run from the Mississippi River to a rail yard east of George Street. DOT projects manager Aaron Bowe said the additional track will allow for more efficient boarding at the Amtrak station in La Crosse. He said there are no plans for additional rail capacity outside La Crosse.\n\nThe project is slated for 2026.\n\nThe public can submit comments through Aug. 10. Questions can be directed to Sommers at 608-266-3341 or Kristen.Sommers@dot.wi.gov. Written comments can be mailed to Sommers at 4822 Madison Yards Way, Madison, WI 53705.\n\nLa Crosse Tribune reporter Steve Rundio can be reached at steve.rundio@lee.net.\n\nLove 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSubscribe to our Daily Headlines newsletter.\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy. {'uri': '2024-07-419722530', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '11:19:06', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T11:19:06Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T11:18:58Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.longbeachstar.com/news/274451633/inbox-hes-the-most-underrated-defensive-tackle-in-the-nfl', 'title': "Inbox: He's the most underrated defensive tackle in the NFL", 'body': 'The Packers are the gravity pulling us all together Wes Hodkiewicz\n\nDar from Mansfield, TX\n\nWes, fine job on Outsider Inbox! So many moving stories about games impacting readers\' lives! I\'ve since heard a great one that you might offer as an OI bonus. My friend Tom from Brookfield\'s sweet mom, Jane, went into labor midgame but didn\'t say a word. Pack wins, she tells hubby Hank, and they race to ER. Tom always assumed his birthdate was delayed into the next morning by an ordinary game, then he recently Googled it. Turns out his mom gritted through the 1962 NFL Championship win over the Giants.\n\nIsn\'t that something? Jane\'s a real trooper. Thanks to everyone who participated in this year\'s Outsider Inbox. The response is a testament to this football team and its devout fanbase. I\'ve personally grown to love this time of the year. Instead of talking about nothing for the sake of speaking, it\'s great to reflect and share some heartwarming stories about the gravity pulling us all together. I think we hit the sweet spot with 10 questions over five days, too. I can\'t wait for 2025.\n\nRoss from Hudson, WI\n\nGoing into last year\'s training camp it felt like there were a number of question marks, many of which became exclamation points by year end - Jordan Love, WRs, TEs, etc. This year, there seems to be a number of question marks, as well: Best five on OL, starting LBs, half of the starting DBs, new defensive coordinator/scheme, etc. The powers that be took a similar method of addressing the areas of weakness this year as last, so the question now is, which concerns will become strengths by year end this season?\n\nI\'m excited about the secondary and the safety position in particular. Xavier McKinney was an exclamation point the day he signed his contract, but overseeding the lawn on the backend was a pragmatic move on Brian Gutekunst\'s part. The addition of Javon Bullard, Evan Williams and Kitan Oladapo not only provides depth on defense but also special teams, where safeties can be extremely valuable. Anthony Johnson Jr. and Zayne Anderson aren\'t going anywhere, either. They\'re both hungry to compete. Overall, it\'s a fresh start for an essential position.\n\nKeith from Springfield, MO\n\nThanks for all your effort! What would you say are the primary professional and personal characteristics that make Matt LaFleur a winner and highly rated NFL head coach? The media\'s highest rating for ML so far has been seventh and I think he deserves to be rated much higher - even before he wins a SB with the Pack (just a matter of time). His teams have won so many games starting from his first year! I think now that ML has the ability to be very tough, yet not offend his players?\n\nHe\'s creative as hell and always willing to learn. To LaFleur\'s successes, I would also attribute his ability to strike a balance between staying true to himself and also evolving as a head coach and leader. I think LaFleur would tell you he\'s a much different man today than he was when the Packers hired him on Jan. 8, 2019.\n\nJeff from Indian Lake, NY\n\nSafe to assume Jordan Love\'s arrow is pointing straight up. In fact, it\'s so high up there I don\'t know if we can see it. I would imagine that\'s how a lot of Packers fans feel. But is that fair? He played absolutely lights out over the second half of last season. And he\'s so young and just starting to get real game experience the expectation must be MVP-level or bust. I just wonder how he\'ll respond to that added pressure and whether that pressure is justified. Progress isn\'t always linear.\n\nI don\'t disagree progress and production aren\'t easily predictable, but that\'s where the third \'P\' matters: the person. Of all the variables this upcoming season, the one of which I worry least is pressure affecting Jordan Love. Composure is his greatest gift. Love is still only 25. He\'s going to make mistakes, but it won\'t be because the lights are too bright for him.\n\nJason from Mt. Prospect, IL\n\nHaving Keisean Nixon in his prime, fully healthy, and very low workload as a returner to this point in his career makes me excited about this new kickoff platform. However, injuries happen. I\'m curious to see whom our returner would be if Nixon were to need time off. Bo Melton did a lot of returning in his college days, although I think mostly on punt returns. Jayden Reed is too valuable as a receiver to toss out there. I\'m not sure Samori Toure makes the 53...Whom do the Packers have in mind?\n\nIt\'s a worthwhile question given the Packers have the option to put two returners back in the landing zone. Reed is listed as the backup to Nixon but seems more like an emergency option at this point. Toure will be in the conversation. Dimitri Stanley was catching balls in OTAs, as well. MarShawn Lloyd is another name to follow. It was mentioned after the draft the rookie third-round pick could be a return candidate, too.\n\nDave from Gwinn, WI\n\nI know this has no merit in your eyes, but Kenny Clark wasn\'t even in ESPN\'s list of top 5 DTs. Is Justin Madubuike seriously better than Kenny? I swear there\'s a "South Park" joke in here somewhere...\n\nI\'m not going to compare one defensive tackle to another, but if you can\'t appreciate what Kenny Clark has done here the past eight years, then you\'re clearly haven\'t watched the Packers. Clark has been the guy on that defensive line for six years while playing a ton of snaps in a read-and-react front. In my opinion, he\'s the most underrated defensive tackle in the NFL. I\'ll stand on that. Maybe it\'s because Kenny is a quieter dude who doesn\'t toot his own horn, but I\'ve never understood how Clark gets continually overlooked in All-Pro voting and other league polls.\n\nTK from Grafton, WI\n\nWhen I started my Packers fandom in the 1970s, the draft was 12 rounds long. In 1994, it was shortened to seven rounds. Is the current value of a seventh-round pick equal to what a 12th-rounder used to be? Is "last round" now worth what a "last round" used to be?\n\nI don\'t think so because organizations invest so much more money and resources into preparing for an NFL Draft than they did in 1970. It\'s still a crapshoot to a certain extent but teams pretty much know everything there is to know about college players these days. Because every pick is valuable. Just look at how much hay the Packers made the past two years with the seventh-round selections of Rasheed Walker and Carrington Valentine, both solid pros at premium positions.\n\nDarrel from Pueblo, CO\n\nII, if someone is picked off a practice squad; do they have to accept, or could they refuse because they think their options are better with the current practice squad/team?\n\nFirst, there\'s no "picking off" because every practice-squad player is a free agent. They\'re signed to two-way contracts that can be terminated by the player or team at any time. The player is free to sign to another team\'s 53-man roster each week, which is how the Packers acquired Bo Melton, Allen Lazard and Rasul Douglas. It\'s common once an interested team moves to sign a player off another team\'s practice squad for that player to go to his current team to see if it wants to sign him to its 53-man roster or increase his practice-squad pay (which counts towards the salary cap).\n\nLori from Broomfield, CO\n\nHow much influence on team character revolves around the direction from offensive and defensive captains?\n\nA lot of it. LaFleur often talks about the best teams being player-led. That doesn\'t necessarily mean which player gives the best pregame pep talk. Julius Peppers barely spoke during his three years here, but he had an aura around him that his teammates rallied around. Marcedes Lewis had a similar impact from 2018-22.\n\nPaul from Northglenn, CO\n\nCan there be any greater solace in 13 world championships than having Reggie and Charles get their lone rings as Green Bay Packers?\n\nIt\'s a pretty sweet achievement. I wish Julius and Cedes could\'ve joined them.\n\nKelly from Stoughton, WI\n\nIn response to Jeff from Brooklyn, Spoff said something along the lines of it\'s on the personnel department to know if a prospect is developing as they should. Can you expand on that? Do we have scouts that just watch our practices and young players to see how development is coming? I would think the coaches can handle that but maybe they are too invested in installs and who is making the correct play? How does that shake out? Loved to hear from Vic, eagle on a par-4.\n\nIf it\'s filmed, someone is watching. Obviously, coaches grade players in the classroom but Brian Gutekunst and his top lieutenants also attend practices to watch players and get feedback. Away from the field, Gutekunst and Matt LaFleur also meet frequently to discuss the state of the roster.\n\nJosh from Playa Majagual, Nicaragua\n\nI think we may be a little naïve in stating coaches in the NFL aren\'t teaching their players how to bend the rules. Offensive linemen are taught how to get away with a hold by keeping their hands inside the frame of the body, DBs are coached on when and how they can get away with a late grab to close the gap, and WRs are instructed how to draw PIs on uncatchable balls. Most coaches are former players, and they all learn and teach how to gain an edge without getting flagged. No longevity!? See: Bill Belichick.\n\nWhat I took from Spoff\'s response was you can\'t teach bad technique. That\'s how bad habits develop. There\'s a difference between understanding where the lines are blurred (e.g. an O-lineman keeping his hands inside the framework of the body) and where contact could get you in trouble as a DB. Even if it\'s not called in a game, teams review tape every week. If you\'re putting bad film out there, the opposition will work to expose it.\n\nJustin from Harrisburg, PA\n\nI did not check the second round, but the last time all first-round QBs were re-signed by the teams that drafted them was in 2008. The Falcons drafted Matt Ryan No. 3, and the Ravens drafted Joe Flacco No. 18.\n\nIt\'s rare for a draft to produce first-rounders who all become franchise quarterbacks for the team that selected them, especially in this day and age when six QBs come off the board in the first 12 picks.\n\nDaniel from Chillicothe, MO\n\nCould a visiting team ever "buy" a win on the road? What I mean is if the visiting team\'s fanbase could acquire enough tickets via home-team resale on the secondary market, would it make a difference in the outcome of the game. I\'ve been thinking about this ever since we hosted Detroit last year and they had way too many fans in attendance.\n\nI\'ve never attended a more Packers-friendly road game than Green Bay and the Los Angeles Chargers in 2019. There might have been 500 Chargers fans at 27,000-seat Dignity Health Sports Park and Philip Rivers didn\'t care one bit during a 26-11 drubbing of Green Bay, which was 7-1 heading in.\n\nWoody from Kill Devil Hills, NC\n\nPickled asparagus! That actually makes sense. I often put pickled cabbage on my brats (aka sauerkraut). It is time to try the asparagus. I\'ll have to try it with spareribs too. Thanks Wes.\n\nNinety percentage of the brat-constructing process is pickling the asparagus. The other half is mental.\n\nGreg from Perkasie, PA\n\nThere was a moment in the first episode of the offseason edition of "Hard Knocks" with the Giants where there was some tension between the GM and owner when discussing Saquon Barkley\'s future with the team. Do you think the Packers lack of a traditional owner creates any sort of advantage in regard to situations like that? I assume there may be some more freedom for a GM if they don\'t have to worry about keeping the owner happy.\n\nI\'m sick of "Hard Knocks." There, I said it. Feels good. To your question, the Packers have the best setup in pro sports. The results speak to that.\n\nEthan from La Crosse, WI\n\nThanks to Mike for sharing news from Vic, and a thanks to Vic for willingly sharing a brief life update. Selfishly I want to ask if the Packers media team would ever consider asking Vic if he\'d be interested in engaging in a one-off Ask Vic column. But I think this is a case where it\'s better to let nostalgia alone than to try to chase it. Thanks again.\n\nNot every classic band requires a reunion tour. What\'s important is Vic is living his best life. Count me among those happy to hear his update.\n\nBarry from De Pere, WI\n\nAs long as we\'re trying out names for Mr. Policy\'s new columns, how\'z about "Ed Talks?"\n\nInsiders is such a gift to us retired folks, not the least of which is the posted date at the beginning of every Inbox. I may not know the day, but I damned sure know the date. Just don\'t ask me the date on Saturday or Sunday.\n\nHaha, Insider Inbox...keeping you locked into the current date since 2017. Fiona O'Keeffe, a former Stanford University star, broke the American course record and ran the sixth best women's time ever en route to victory.\n\n2023\n\nNumber of runners: 10,951 (1,400 in Jr. Bix 7)\n\nMen's winner: Biya Simbassa (Flagstaff, Arizona), 32:34\n\nWomen's winner: Kellyn Taylor (Flagstaff, Arizona), 36:33\n\nWeather: 71 degrees, 93% humidity\n\nThe Bix 7 served as the U.S. championship race for 7 miles for the sixth time and also was part of a 12-race road racing circuit sanctioned by USA Track & Field. Biya Simbassa and Kellyn Taylor, both of whom train in Flagstaff, Arizona, both passed rival runners on the final downhill to take control of the race.\n\nNext up:\n\nSATURDAY: Kenyan domination\n\nSUNDAY: Male Bix Olympians\n\nMONDAY: Beat the Elite\n\nTUESDAY: The first Bix T-shirt\n\nWEDNESDAY: T-shirts 1976-1999\n\nTHURSDAY: T-shirts 2000-2023\n\nFRIDAY: Brady Street Sprints\n\n0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", 'source': {'uri': 'qctimes.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Quad-City Times'}, 'authors': [], 'image': 'https://bloximages.chicago2.vip.townnews.com/qctimes.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/6/3b/63b50252-1c9e-11ef-b35b-a7dec979ccf7/66554910df132.image.jpg?crop=1791%2C940%2C0%2C108&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': 0.3490196078431373, 'wgt': 458478683, 'relevance': 26}
{'uri': '2024-07-419710703', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '11:11:02', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T11:11:02Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T11:00:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://thehill.com/opinion/finance/4759988-drake-vs-kendrick-lamar-its-just-business/', 'title': "Drake vs. Kendrick Lamar: It's just business", 'body': 'Those of you who keep up with pop culture are probably aware of the very public and personal feud between hip-hop artists Kendrick Lamar and Drake. And those of you who are not can draw lessons about free enterprise competition from this dispute.\n\nBoth artists have been sparring verbally by releasing lyrics and making other slights. The latest strike involved Lamar\'s West Coast Juneteenth concert, where he garnered the apparent support of a number of legendary West Coast rappers such as Dr. Dre and Ty Dolla $ign, as well as the endorsement of notable A-list NBA stars such as Lebron James and Russell Westbrook.\n\nSome in the media, such as ESPN\'s Stephen A. Smith, have called on the artists to cut it out. But this call for inaction not only demonstrates a fundamental misunderstanding of the impact of competition on the history of free enterprise in America, it exposes a basic lack appreciation for what has always moved the culture of hip-hop forward: conflict.\n\nThat is to say, "beef" not "chicken" has been the fuel to this culture all along.\n\nThe history of competition in America is a story that traverses economic, social and political arenas. From as early as the Colonial era, there was competition among European powers and American Colonies. There was persistent conflict around price regulation. Later, the American republic ushered in free trade, creating markets in all sectors of the era, including agriculture, manufacturing and shipping.\n\nWhen we push forward in time, we get to the Industrial Revolution of the 19th century, where the business of railroads, oil and steel gave birth to more competition -- so much that the monopolistic approach of industry barons like Rockefeller and Carnegie ultimately required government intervention to rein them in. Legislation such as the Sherman Anti-trust Act of 1890 and, in 1914, the Clayton Antitrust Act and creation of the Federal Trade Commission were intended to seed and spawn greater competition.\n\nIf we leap forward, we land on the late 20th and 21st century. Starting in the 1970s and 1980s, there was a wave of deregulation aimed at increasing competition in industries such as airlines, telecommunications, and finance. This also brought on the advent of globalization.\n\nAmerican companies faced increased competition from international firms, leading to greater innovation and efficiency. Finally, the 21st century gave rise to the digital economy. Technological giants like Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Google to this day engage in epic battles using marketing and innovation to attempt to assert market dominance. Just like the infusion of competition helped write and shape the origins of free enterprise in America, the presence of competition in rap and hip-hop helps define its market and its culture.\n\nThe history of competition among hip-hop artists in America is real. Competition is the very thing that has fueled its evolution over time. Let\'s go old school. The issue of the birthplace of hip-hop can be debated, but most credit the Bronx in the 1970s.\n\nDJs such as Kool Herc, Grandmaster Flash and Afrika Bambaataa showcased their skills. MCs (rappers) began to emerge, competing to entertain crowds with their lyrical prowess.\n\nLater, rap battles became a core element of hip-hop. These live, lyrical competitions between MCs were about showcasing lyrical creativity and stage presence. Notable early battles include those featuring Kool Moe Dee vs. Busy Bee in 1981.\n\nThen came the era of "crews," teams of rappers or rap groups that formed like other groups around a common vision or idea about their music. Crews such as the Sugarhill Gang, Run-D.M.C. and Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five led to crew rivalries and fierce competition that caused innovation and an overall elevation in the rap scene.\n\nThe golden age of hip-hop resulted in the 1980s and early 1990s. Less than a decade later, we saw a further crystallization of competition with such artists as Rakim, LL Cool J, Public Enemy and N.W.A.\n\nBut where the true Apple vs. Samsung, King Kong vs. Godzilla completion reached its pinnacle was in the rise of the East Coast (New York) vs. West Coast (California) rivalry. This epitomized the hip-hop of the 1990\'s.\n\nTupac Shakur and Biggie Smalls (aka The Notorious B.I.G.) became the culture ambassadors for their respective turfs, -- Shakur for the West Coast and Smalls for the East Coast. The rivalry was everything -- business and personal. Some would argue that it went too far, as both men unfortunately lost their lives.\n\nBut we can have healthy competition without violence. For example, just jump forward and look the high profile beef between Jay-Z vs. Nas. Their 2001 battle, highlighted by tracks like Nas\'s "Ether" and Jay-Z\'s "Takeover," is considered one of the greatest rap battles in history.\n\nIn the end, rap and hip-hop are marinated in the same American sauce that has made free enterprise and entrepreneurial ship the catalyst for success for so many before us. Competition can get too personal and go too far in any facet of life, but a healthy dose and the right concoction of it can serve as springboard for a country and a culture.\n\nLet these lions be lions! Let Drake and Lamar continue to do battle. Ultimately, the market will decide. They both will be richer because of it, the lovers of hip-hop will gain an incredible body of work and young up-and-coming artists will be lifted in their wake.\n\nAs The Notorious B.I.G. put, it, "If you don\'t know, now you know."', 'source': {'uri': 'thehill.com', 'dataType': 'news', 'title': 'The Hill'}, 'authors': [{'uri': 'opinion_contributors@thehill.com', 'name': 'Opinion Contributors', 'type': 'author', 'isAgency': False}], 'image': 'https://thehill.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2024/07/Kendrick-Lamar.jpg?strip=1&w=640', 'eventUri': None, 'sentiment': -0.0117647058823529, 'wgt': 458478662, 'relevance': 31}
{'uri': '8222116378', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '11:08:10', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T11:08:10Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T11:07:45Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://qctimes.com/news/local/beat-the-elite-runners-to-start-at-2-mile-mark-in-quad-city-times-bix/article_448f5544-3fee-11ef-8a37-73457eca76c1.html', 'title': 'Beat the Elite runners to start at 2 mile mark in Quad-City Times Bix 7', 'body': 'This year\'s Russell Beat the Elite runners for the Quad-City Times Bix 7 will receive a two-mile head start against this year\'s elite runners.\n\n"We have two outstanding runners in Grace Boleyn and Colin Cartee," former Race Director Ed Froehlich said.\n\nBoleyn is a two-time Quad-City Times Bix 7 high school champ, and a decorated track and cross-country athlete about to start her final year at Pleasant Valley High School.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nCartee is the owner of Crossfit OC3 in Davenport.\n\n"Boleyn had a great junior year, and they\'re both running about 6 ½-minute miles," Froehlich said. "Starting with a two-mile lead they\'ll have to run five miles. If they run 6:30 per mile that will be 32:30 and last year\'s Bix winner ran the course in 32:25.\n\n"I think they\'ll both beat 6:30 per mile because they\'re both getting better," he added. {'uri': '8222097668', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '10:57:19', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T10:57:19Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T10:56:37Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://richmond.com/sports/colonial-downs-racetrack-horse-racing-virginia-churchill-downs/article_dde94cf2-3fc3-11ef-b31e-cb9efd4153d9.html', 'title': 'Colonial Downs Racetrack opens 2024 season seeking another record-setting year', 'body': 'Race 6 (Maiden Claiming) at Colonial Downs opening day for the 2024 season. No. 2 (My Sanctuary) won in 1:43.82.\n\nThe tumult of thundering hooves combined with the rolling roar of the crowd as Bonne Fille, a 2-year-old filly making her second lifetime start, earned her first win after overtaking Beyond Question down the Thursday afternoon during the seventh race of opening day at Colonial Downs Racetrack in New Kent.\n\nFor Chelsie Hardin, the director of marketing for Rosie\'s Gaming Emporium and Colonial Downs, that symphony of horse racing is "the best sound in the world."\n\n"When the teams put in this much work to get us to opening day, it\'s very rewarding to hear the crowd, the thundering of the hooves on the track," Hardin said as she gazed around at roughly 1,500 fans in attendance.\n\nIn 2022, Churchill Downs agreed to pay $2.75 billion for the assets of Peninsula Pacific Entertainment LLC, the company that owns Colonial Downs and Rosie\'s.\n\nPeople are also reading... Kings Dominion gets approval to build new roller coaster New Richmond ballpark now has general contractors on the team 9-year-old boy drowns at Pony Pasture CEO of Virginia\'s technology authority resigns Richmond radio personality Kat Simons dies at 63 As farmers age out, future of the mythic Hanover tomato is uncertain The butterfly effect: Crozet teenager Thomas Heilman\'s journey to 2024 Paris Olympics Richmond best ice cream results, vote for the Final Four!🍧🍨 🍦 Crash on Pocahontas Parkway in Henrico kills Chesterfield woman Meet the 2024 All-Metro softball team, led by King William\'s Taylor Johnson Trump co-manager takes online shot at Virginia House speaker 2nd Richmond official in city\'s communications office had credit card suspended last year Teel: New Richmond ballpark, Henrico arenas would defy odds UVa alum, NFL vet Wali Rainer\'s sons following in his footsteps Here\'s what Warner and Kaine are saying about calls for Biden to withdraw\n\nThat acquisition has generated momentum around the track, as Colonial Downs imbibes the significant resources and racing world connections provided by its parent.\n\nLast year, the first under its new ownership, Colonial Downs hosted a record 250 races over 27 days with 2,047 horses in competition.\n\nTrack personnel hope to exceed those numbers this season over 27 days of live thoroughbred racing on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays to September 7 on two surfaces, the Secretariat Turf Course, North America\'s widest turf course at 180 feet, and a 1¼-mile dirt track.\n\n"(Churchill Downs\') support has really helped us gain the resources that we need to bring Colonial Downs back into the spotlight, and really grow the horse racing industry in Virginia back to where it needs to be," Hardin said.\n\nHoppy Shores bought box seats at Colonial Downs when it first opened in 1997 and has kept them ever since, even amid a 5-year hiatus (2014-2019) caused by a dispute between track management and horsemen\'s groups.\n\nOriginally from Lexington, Kentucky, Shores arrived in Virginia in 1981. He missed Colonial Downs immensely during the 5-year gap.\n\n"That makes my summers, coming out here," he said. "All the friends you meet and connections you make. It\'s like seeing family, coming down here."\n\nA mainstay at the track, Shores fondly recalls memorable Virginia Derbies -- the license plate on his car is VADERBY -- and favorite jockeys and breeders over the years, such as Nellie Mae Cox, a legendary figure in the state\'s horse breeding history.\n\nCox, who died in 2015 at 75, was born in Richmond and lived at historic Rose Retreat Farm in Goochland for 50 years.\n\n"Every year, it\'s picking up and there\'s improvements, the fan experience is getting better," Shores said from the balcony overlooking the track, a short distance from where Cox used to sit.\n\n"It\'s going to be an exciting season."\n\nJockey Trevor McCarthy has made upward of 11,000 starts in a career that dates to 2011. He\'s been racing at Colonial Downs since 2019 and was the track\'s leading rider that year and in 2020.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | Omny Studio\n\nLast year, at the Virginia Derby, McCarthy won the Virginia Oaks and the Colonial Cup.\n\n"It\'s a great atmosphere to be here, a lot of fans come out," McCarthy said, standing in the middle of Colonial Downs\' paddock as stable hands walked horses around prior to the call to post.\n\n"It\'s great racing, great horsemen, great horses, great jockeys, great owners. Everything about it is awesome. It\'s always a pleasure to be here."\n\nAs Bonne Fille trotted to the winner\'s circle, awaiting her was a familiar face.\n\nKaren Godsey\'s mother was on the architectural review committee to build Colonial Downs. A trainer on her farm in Ashland, Godsey has been coming to the track since it opened.\n\nBut this opening day was a little extra special for her. One of Godsey\'s clients tasked her with saddle breaking two fillies this year, Bonne Fille and Bella Bluegrass.\n\nThat gray pair was born and raised together, inseparable until about two months ago, when Bonne Fille was sent off to trainer Michelle Lovell in Kentucky.\n\nOn Wednesday, the horses reunited.\n\n"It was just fireworks, they\'ve been so in love with each other and are so familiar with each other," Godsey said of the meeting.\n\nBonne Fille, the favorite at 3-5 odds, won a short sprint -- five furlongs on the outer turf -- via a hard chase through the far turn before she eased out four wide into the upper stretch and finished well to get up late under strong handling.\n\n"When she was that far back, seeing that stretch run it was \'Ooh, she\'s going to be second,\'" Godsey said of Bonne Fille\'s showing.\n\n"Then she just kept on coming and hammering down, it was a pretty exciting finish."\n\nAn exciting finish indeed, among the first of what\'s sure to be many this summer at Colonial Downs.\n\nLast year the track averaged $700,000 a day in wagers across the 27-day season. Many people bet remotely, through sites such as TwinSpires, which is owned by Churchill Downs.\n\nThe Colonial Downs: A $2 million day at the races\n\nKey dates this season include the Festival of Racing on Aug. 10; the Virginia Derby on Sept. 7; and, new this year, wiener dog races on Aug. 24, honoring former Colonial Downs director of facilities Bo Scott, who died last year and had long hoped for the track to host wiener dog races.\n\nAlso of note is the return of night racing to Colonial Downs. On Friday, the track will host its first races under the lights since 2019.\n\nZach Joachim (804) 649-6555\n\nzjoachim@timesdispatch.com\n\nZach Joachim\n\nDeputy Sports Editor\n\nAuthor twitter Author email Follow Zach Joachim Close Get email notifications on {{subject}} daily! {'uri': '8222080683', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '10:46:22', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T10:46:22Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T10:45:55Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://pressofatlanticcity.com/sports/north-wildwood-hosts-beschen-callahan-lifeguard-races/article_8f83475e-3fd0-11ef-86b3-6f81b8744b4a.html', 'title': 'North Wildwood hosts Beschen-Callahan lifeguard races', 'body': 'NORTH WILDWOOD -- The 55th edition of the Beschen-Callahan Memorial Lifeguard Races will begin at 6 p.m. Friday at 22nd Avenue beach.\n\nThe competing teams will be North Wildwood, Wildwood, Wildwood Crest, defending champion Sea Isle City, Avalon (which lost to Sea Isle on the doubles-row tiebreaker last year after they both scored 20 points), Upper Township and Stone Harbor.\n\n"It\'s a competition for the lifeguards to display their lifeguarding skills," said North Wildwood Beach Patrol Chief Bill Ciavarelli. "Two years ago we added the swim and paddle for the women, and last year we added the women\'s can run. The can run is a very unique event, one athlete simulating a rescue with a (surf) dash and a short swim.\n\n"This year we added the women\'s surf dash, and that was an easy add. Former Chief (Tony) Cavalier, one of his favorite events was always the surf dash. With the passing of Chief this past winter, it\'s a good time to add the event. When he retired the City created the Cavalier Cup for the winning team, and they can take it home for the year."\n\nPeople are also reading... Atlantic City Airshow canceled for 2024 Scientists know rising seas will one day swallow this Jersey Shore climate research center Rents are up, but vacationers are still heading to the Jersey Shore Route 30 reopened in both directions following repairs to Absecon Drawbridge 5 hurt, 76 displaced in 5-alarm Atlantic City apartment fire Longport resident says rats are coming from borough property Wildwood police identify shooting suspect Cape May County Zoo receives $1.4 million donation Greg Goodwin, influential Absegami coach, dies at 63 Egg Harbor City rescue in need of fosters, donors to help animals rescued from Galloway home Some Stanley Holmes Village residents say they will fight to keep their apartments, others ready to go Cape May fishing case has national impact Last of brothers who started Starn\'s ShopRite dies at age 89 Atlantic City woman involved in hit-and-run while kids in car Egg Harbor Township crash sees people rushing from nearby businesses to help\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe Beschen-Callahan Memorials honors the memory of Jim Beschen and Mike Callahan, two North Wildwood lifeguards who were killed in the Vietnam War.\n\n"There will be representatives from the Beschen and Callahan families to say a few words and help with the awards," Ciavarelli said.\n\nThere will be 10 races, including the doubles row, the men\'s and women\'s paddleboard races, swims, surf dashes and can runs, and the singles row.\n\nThe late Cavalier, and three others connected to the event, Lou Cirelli, Buzz Mogck and Bill Kindle, have all died since December.\n\nCirelli was the Beschen-Callahan Memorials\' former race director and later the Chief of the Wildwood Beach Patrol. Mogck (the former Cape May lifeguard Chief) knew the Beschen and Callahan families very well, according to Ciavarelli. Kindle sponsored a lot of North Wildwood patrol events, according to Ciavarelli.\n\n"We have created memorial events in their honor, which will be displayed at the race," Ciavarelli said. "All these people who have passed were influencial in this race back in the \'90s."\n\nContact Guy Gargan: 609-272-7210\n\nGGargan@pressofac.com\n\nCan\'t get enough High School sports?
