{'uri': '2024-07-419681601', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '10:43:38', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T10:43:38Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T10:30:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://buffalonews.com/sports/new-york-amateur-golf-championship-aiden-spampinato-wanakah/article_d58766d8-4000-11ef-b379-cf4f268e803d.html', 'title': 'Aiden Spampinato wins 101st New York State Amateur golf title at Wanakah', 'body': 'Aiden Spampinato pitches onto the 18th green from a tough spot in the New York State Amateur at Wanakah Country Club. Spampinato then holed out in two putts to preserve his victory.\n\nVictor\'s Aiden Spampinato, who helped Methodist University win the Division III championship in May, held off a slew of contenders over the final 18 holes Thursday and won the 101st New York State Amateur Championship at Hamburg\'s Wanakah Country Club.\n\nSpampinato, 21, finished three rounds at 6-under-par 210 to win by a shot over 23-year-old Alex Zurat of Rochester\'s Oak Hill Country Club and Scarsdale\'s James Allen, who just finished his senior season at Penn State University.\n\n"This is amazing," said Spampinato. "So many thousands of hours of hard work have led up to this and I\'m very grateful."\n\nSpampinato, who plays out of suburban Rochester\'s Cobblestone Creek, made second-team Division III All-America for a second straight year this spring, and he was the No. 10-ranked Division III player in the nation. Methodist, in Fayetteville, N.C., is a golf powerhouse, with 14 D-III titles in the last 35 years.\n\nPeople are also reading...\n\nAt least four tornadoes, two packing 110 mph winds, hit Western New York, weather service reports Pregnant in her sophomore year, Bennett High School graduate finds self-worth - with plenty of help Man shot dead by Buffalo police is brother of slain 12-year-old Stop and look: How the new Bills stadium is already drawing in spectators Alan Pergament: \'Beatles\' host JP leaves WECK after disagreement with station owner Buddy Shula Bills quarterback Mitch Trubisky finds his way back home Sabres trade top prospect Matt Savoie to Oilers for Ryan McLeod, Tyler Tullio Do the Sabres need a goal-scorer after landing Ryan McLeod to center the third line? Miranda tries - again - to put a Tim Hortons in Orchard Park Erie County real estate transactions Watch: Video shows Buffalo man killed by police sped off with officer clinging to car Savannah Bananas bring stilts, shimmies and sing-alongs to rock Sahlen Field Ryan McLeod\'s \'whirlwind\' trade has new Sabres center \'excited\' to get to Buffalo Inside the NHL: Jason Zucker is betting on himself to bring Sabres some offense \'The numbers are just astronomical:\' Why developers are putting more projects on hold\n\nWhile Spampinato has had a lot of good finishes - he was third at the NYS Amateur in 2021 and ninth last year - this was his first breakthrough major amateur victory.\n\n"This was a long time coming," he said. "Luckily, I was able to keep it together just by going through my routine every single shot and being 100% committed to every single shot. That was a big goal for today."\n\nA tweak to his putting routine helped. Just before getting set to make each stroke on the green, Spampinato cocked his right shoulder backward twice.\n\n"About a week ago, I was working with Potters Putting," he said, referring to an online coaching program. "They wanted to see my shoulders get more level instead of the right one getting lower. The lower right shoulder was putting me out of whack, my path, and my putter face is a lot better with the shoulders level. I\'ve hit hundreds of putts in my basement this week just working on that, and it really paid off."\n\nThe 5-foot-7 Spampinato took the lead for good with three birdies in a four-hole stretch to move to 7 under after the seventh hole. He made an 8-foot putt on the par-3 fourth, and an 18-footer on the 201-yard seventh, after hitting a 5-iron.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack\n\nA bunch of challengers were within a shot or two the rest of the way but never caught him.\n\nThe top Buffalo-area finishers were 39-year-old Jamie Miller of East Aurora\'s Crag Burn Golf Club and 35-year-old Tonawandan Kris Boyes. They tied for eighth at even par. Miller, a private wealth adviser at UBS Financial Services, is president of the New York State Golf Association. It was a particularly good finish for him, considering he has three children under 22 months old at home.\n\nAllen, the 2021 state amateur champion, got to 7 under after 14 holes and was just a shot behind. But he bogeyed the tough, 210-yard 15th, then bogeyed the par-4 16th.\n\nZurat, who shot a course-record 63 at Oak Hill\'s famed East Course last month, got within a shot after making eagle on the par-5 14th. After a 300-yard drive, he hit a 3-wood from 235.\n\n"It ended up way right, almost on the tee box on 15," Zurat said. "From 35 yards, I can really throw it up in the air. It went pretty high, landed once and rolled in. It was a perfect shot."\n\nBut Zurat mis-hit a delicate chip on 16 to make bogey, then hit an errant drive right on 17 for another bogey.\n\nZurat graduated from Florida Atlantic but didn\'t play golf there, instead opting to play as an amateur in Florida pro mini-tour events.\n\n"I\'m trying to get used to professional golf, where you\'ve got to go low," he said. "You\'ve got to shoot 7 under."\n\nIt was a long day at Wanakah, with 68 golfers playing 36 holes, including a two-hour weather delay. Spampinato\'s final putt went down as the sun was setting at 9 p.m.\n\nThe Wanakah course, which is celebrating its 125th anniversary, withstood 1.5 inches of rain Wednesday, yet the greens still were about 12 on the Stimpmeter on Thursday. Wanakah hosted the state amateur on its 100th anniversary in 1999, but the course is even better than it was then, because there are more close-shaved runoffs around the greens, and a lot of tree removal has opened up views of Lake Erie.\n\n"I was super-proud of having it here," Miller said. "It\'s a 10 out of 10. A lot of it was (member) John Braun, a guy who decided to cut more trees down to create these great views."\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!\n\n* I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.\n\nMark Gaughan\n\nBills/NFL writer\n\nFollow Mark Gaughan\n\nClose Get email notifications on {{subject}} daily!\n\nYour notification has been saved.\n\nThere was a problem saving your notification.\n\n{{description}}\n\nEmail notifications are only sent once a day, and only if there are new matching items.\n\nSave\n\nManage followed notifications\n\nClose Followed notifications\n\nPlease log in to use this feature Log In\n\nDon\'t have an account? The good news is it will come without any local home television territory blackouts. The even better news is fans won't need to shell out subscription fees.\n\nBaltimore's series finale, with first pitch scheduled for 11:35 a.m. at Camden Yards, will be free everywhere The Roku Channel is available. It's the ninth of 18 games slotted into Major League Baseball's new partnership: Sunday Leadoff on Roku. The game will not be available on Mid-Atlantic Sports Network.\n\nFans can watch the American League East's top teams square off on Roku devices and The Roku Channel. It will also be available to MLB.TV subscribers in the MLB App and in the Extra Innings Package. The broadcast will feature a pre and postgame show, each about 15 minutes.\n\nIn- and out-of-market blackouts won't apply. And there are no international restrictions on MLB.TV.\n\nThe Sunday Leadoff games can be found on the home screen of any Roku device. Fans can also simply search for MLB Leadoff. The Roku Channel can also be found on a variety of smart TVs (Roku TVs, Amazon Fire TVs, Google TVs, Samsung TVs, Roku Players, Amazon Fire TV Devices, Google TV Devices) as well as The RokuChannel.com and the Roku Mobile app on IOS or Android. No logins are required.\n\nIt would be hard not to tune in.\n\nThe slumping Orioles, losers of five of their past 10, still hold a two-game lead in the division over the struggling Yankees. New York is 3-7 over its past 10 contests.\n\nThe weekend set comes at a pivotal time. {'uri': '2024-07-419604600', 'lang': 'eng', 'isDuplicate': False, 'date': '2024-07-12', 'time': '09:33:33', 'dateTime': '2024-07-12T09:33:33Z', 'dateTimePub': '2024-07-12T09:15:00Z', 'dataType': 'news', 'sim': 0, 'url': 'https://www.marketwatch.com/story/big-short-investor-steve-eisman-says-shorting-current-market-would-be-insanity-2a33506b', 'title': "Big Short investor Steve Eisman says shorting current market would be 'insanity'", 'body': '""I predicted the end of the world once, it was pretty awful for everybody. I have no interest in predicting it again, and there\'s no data to say that it\'s going to happen, so we should just move on.""\n\n-- Steve Eisman, managing director at Neuberger Berman\n\n\'Big Short\' investor Steve Eisman has said "there\'s no fundamental case to be massively short" in the current stock market and said it would be "insanity" to start shorting stocks like Nvidia.\n\nEisman, who was played by Steve Carrell in the 2015 film \'The Big Short,\' said in an interview with Bloomberg TV that he believes "the economy is fine" and that there\'s "no case to be massively short" on it.\n\n"The economy is fine," Eisman said. "Is it slowing a little bit, sure. Are delinquencies up in consumers, OK. But there\'s no fundamental case to be massively short things."\n\nThe hedge fund manager, who was profiled in Michael Lewis\' book on the 2008 financial crash, also said investors who are shorting technology giants like Nvidia have a "death wish" as he predicted the emergence of artificial intelligence will boost the world\'s biggest tech companies.\n\n"Shorting a stock purely because you think it\'s expensive is a death wish," Eisman said. "You have to have a fundamental reason to be short a stock."\n\n"Is Nvidia NVDA, -5.57% expensive, yeah it\'s expensive but earnings have tripled," Eisman said, as he argued the current winners from the AI rally are likely to be the winners of the future.\n\n"The obvious winners are Nvidia and what I\'d call \'arms dealers,\' and then you have Microsoft MSFT, -2.48%, Amazon AMZN, -2.37%, Meta META, -4.11%, Google GOOG, -2.78%, Oracle ORCL, +0.77%, people who have big cloud, big database businesses, and after that it\'s \'we\'ll see\'"\n\nEisman said he believes the emergence of AI technologies will drive the "biggest refresh cycle in history" as he argued customers will be forced to buy a whole set of new electronic devices in order to use the most cutting edge AI apps in a shift that could boost firms like Apple AAPL, -2.32%.\n\nEisman also said he believes there\'s "no data" showing we\'re nearing the "end of the world" as he brushed aside concerns about the the buildup of commercial real estate and the U.S. fiscal deficit.\n\nHe argued that the commercial real estate debt situaiton is "just not a systemic issue," while noting that only 40% of that debt is held by banks and that very little of that debt is held by the big banks, meaning only regional banks are likely to face any "significant risk".\n\nHe also downplayed fears around the accumulation of the U.S. national debt, as he noted that: "Every single word that people are uttering about the deficit today has been uttered for the past 40 years."\n\nEisman, who is a managing director at asset management firm Neuberger Berman, also said he has "100% certainty Donald Trump wins" the upcoming elections in November, as he argued pro-Palestine protests could sway the national vote.\n\n\'The protestors that have been on the college campuses are going to converge on Chicago on mass and what I\'m quite sure is going to happen is they\'ll burn Israeli flags, they\'ll torch the stars and stripes, they\'ll spew whatever they spew".\n\n"The whole country\'s going to be appalled and the election will be over, just like that," the outspoken investment manager said.', 'source': {'uri':
